name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next item on the agenda is the statements by the European Council and the Commission on the conclusions of the European Council of 17 and 18 March 2016 and the results of the EU-Turkey Summit (2016/2546 (RSP)).

name: Donald Tusk
text: President of the European Council. – Mr President, on 19 January I said here in the European Parliament that the EU had no more than two months to save the Schengen zone and that the March European Council would be the last moment to see if our strategy worked. If it did not we would face grave consequences, such as the collapse of Schengen. We have used these two months as best we could. In this time I called two summits, dedicated almost exclusively to this issue. On 7 March the European Council took three important decisions. The first one concerned the ending of the ‘wave-through’ approach, which meant bringing the flow of irregular migrants along the Western Balkans route to a close. This decision was based on the assumption that a European solution without respect for European law and, above all, without respect for the Schengen borders code is not possible. The second decision was on a massive increase of humanitarian aid to Greece. We set up a new emergency instrument to allow EUR 300 million to be sent this year, firstly to Greece but also to other Member States overwhelmed by the refugee crisis. We also offered further assistance in order to manage the external border in Greece, including the borders with the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and Albania, not to mention other forms of support from Member States. The third decision concerned sending back migrants from Greece to Turkey – those migrants who are not in need of international protection. Leaders also welcomed the presence of NATO in the Aegean to enhance intelligence and surveillance activities, while Turkey agreed to take back all irregular migrants apprehended in Turkish waters. At our first Council in March, I was also asked by leaders to take forward new proposals made by Turkey and work out a common European position, with a view to reaching an agreement later that month. That agreement was finally reached at the European Council on 18 March. We agreed that, as from 20 March, all irregular migrants coming from Turkey to Greek islands would be returned to Turkey. Implementation would be phased in gradually and based on the so-called one-for-one principle. This is what has begun to happen. For me, the two key elements of the agreement were first, to guarantee compliance with all EU and international laws by ensuring that each and every migrant arriving in Europe would be treated individually. This included the respect for the principle of non-refoulement and excluded any kind of collective expulsions. The Commission gave a positive assessment of the legality of the agreement, and I want to express my thanks to Jean-Claude and his team for their work and contribution. Second, as regards accession talks, we took on board Cypriot concerns. The approach to this issue was, to my mind, a test of Europe’s solidarity towards one of its Member States, and Europe passed this test. On the one hand, some were tempted to force Cyprus to make huge concessions. It is quite understandable. But I maintained from the start that we could not sacrifice the most fundamental interests of a Member State, in this case Cyprus, on the altar of a migration deal with Turkey. We are aware of all the tasks and difficulties in resolving this crisis. From the beginning I have thought it is a dangerous illusion to believe that there exists an ideal and 100%-effective solution. I want to say to all the seekers of the political Holy Grail: you will never find it. Convenient and easy solutions are hard to find in politics, and in this case they are virtually impossible. What we are faced with is a perpetual, tenuous and multi-dimensional effort. In fact, something like a never-ending story. The solutions we are putting into practice are not ideal and will not end our work. Also, the deal with Turkey is not perfect and we are fully aware of its risks and weaknesses. We did everything we could to ensure that the agreement respects human dignity, but I am conscious of the fact that everything depends on how it will be implemented. The deal with Turkey and closing the Western Balkans route raised doubts of an ethical and also a legal – as in the case of Turkey – nature. I share some of these doubts too. They can only be dispelled by putting the solutions as they were agreed into practice in every detail. While taking into account all the above-mentioned doubts and even sharing some of them, I would like to recall that the main goal we decided on was to stem irregular migration to Europe. As I have frequently said, without this, and without restoring control over European migration policy, we would be unable to prevent political catastrophes. Here I mean the collapse of Schengen; the loss of control over our external borders, with all its implications for our security; political chaos in the EU; a widespread feeling of insecurity and, ultimately, the triumph of populism and extremism. Today, everyone has finally understood how high the stakes were, and how high they still continue to be. We need to realise that external circumstances will not work to our advantage. We have heard so many times that the only way to stem irregular migration is by solving the root causes of this crisis, namely by stabilising the world around us. I want to state very clearly that this had too often sounded like an alibi not to do anything at all here in Europe. I hope we will finally understand that Europe does not hold golden keys in its hands to help solve all the problems of this world. Let me say more. We were so preoccupied with looking for the key to save the world that for a time we lost the key to solve our own problems. This crisis has eventually shown that we must regain our feeling of responsibility for ourselves before we turn to repairing the world around us. In the two months when we concentrated on what we should do in our own backyard, we managed to achieve results. Those results were possible even though we have not resolved the root causes of migration, like hunger and poverty in sub-Saharan Africa, war in Syria and destabilisation in all regions, from Libya to Afghanistan. Not only have we not solved all those crises, but new ones have appeared, such as tensions between Turkey and Russia, fighting in Nagorno-Karabakh and dozens of terrorist attacks across many regions. It is not humanly possible to resolve all of them with a short-term perspective. Obviously, no one has the right to ignore the root causes of migration, as it is a challenge not only for Europe but also for the whole global community. Therefore we will work hard on our plan to address the migration crisis, which we are going to present at the G7 Summit in Japan and the G20 Summit in China. Our aim should be to increase the socioeconomic development of the affected regions, notably in terms of education, health care, labour conditions, infrastructure and trade. Let us not forget, however, that dealing with the root causes will be a constant and long-term effort. What is even worse, we must work with no guarantee of complete success, because it does not depend on our actions alone. That is why we must be effective first and foremost where almost everything depends on us, namely managing the crisis on European soil. Acting in this spirit, we must remember that the Balkan route is not the only one, and that other countries will also expect our cooperation and solidarity, not only Greece and Bulgaria. I have in mind here the Central Mediterranean route. The numbers of would-be migrants in Libya are alarming. This means that we must be prepared to help and show solidarity to Malta and Italy, should they request it. It will not be possible to simply copy the solutions we have applied in the Balkans, not least because Libya is not Turkey. As regards the Balkan route, we undertook action much too late, which resulted among other things in the temporary closure of the borders inside the eurozone. This is why our full cooperation with Italy and Malta today is a condition for avoiding this scenario in the future. For far too long Europe was divided into advocates of security and advocates of openness. Today we are finally building a synthesis of those two great needs: the need for security at our borders and the need for openness and tolerance. This is perhaps the biggest success of recent months. This synthesis will be one of the main battlefields of the future Europe, and it demands further actions. Let us not be afraid of this tension. In the critical moments of its history, Europe was victorious only when it coped with those two challenges simultaneously. To be true Europeans we need to remain open and tolerant yet at the same time tough and effective. Tensions are something natural, and the European phenomenon was the ability to transform them into positive energy. This phenomenon needs to be preserved.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission. - Monsieur le Président du Conseil européen, Mesdames et Messieurs les députés, une violence fanatique aveugle, voilà ce que des milliers de réfugiés connaissent au quotidien en Syrie ou ailleurs, et cherchent à fuir. En tentant d'atteindre l'Europe, ils tombent très souvent aux mains de trafiquants qui, avec une mise de départ modeste - de quoi investir dans des embarcations de fortune - engendrent des chiffres d'affaires faramineux de trois à six milliards d'euros pour la seule année 2015. C'est cet abject trafic d'êtres humains que nous souhaitons remplacer par des déplacements de demandeurs d'asile contrôlés et légaux. C'est l'intention de l'accord conclu le 18 mars entre l'Union européenne et la Turquie, que nous avons commencé à mettre en œuvre. Soit vous acceptez que les trafiquants et les criminels fassent la loi en mer Égée, soit vous acceptez le bien-fondé de la démarche de l'accord définissant les relations en matière de réfugiés entre l'Union européenne et la Turquie. Bien sûr, ce n'est pas facile. J'ai dit depuis le début qu'il s'agirait d'une tâche herculéenne, et c'est effectivement le cas. Sa mise en œuvre pratique relève de la responsabilité des autorités grecques et des autorités turques, mais sa réussite dépend de nous tous. La Commission est sur place avec son coordinateur, M. Maarten Verwey, qui travaille en étroite coopération avec les agences européennes ainsi qu'avec les autorités grecques et turques pour les aider dans la mise en œuvre pratique de cet accord, en veillant attentivement au plein respect du droit européen et international. À ce jour, depuis le 4 avril, date de la mise en application de l'accord, 325 migrants irréguliers ont été relocalisés de Grèce en Turquie et 79 réfugiés syriens ont été réinstallés de Turquie vers l'Europe. Ce n'est qu'un début et chacun, non seulement la Grèce et la Turquie, mais aussi chaque État membre, doit se montrer à la hauteur des engagement pris pour mener à bien ce processus de retour et de réinstallation. Our responsibility for refugees, Mr President, does not, of course, stop at the external border. The starting point of the action plan with Turkey is that we stand together to offer people on the move a decent life and prospects for the future. That is why the three billion facility is so important. And it is right and important that we top it up by another three billion by the end of 2018. After all, the money does not go to Turkey, as I often have to read untruthfully, but the money goes to the refugees who seek refuge from the rain and cold, who need food and whose children have to go to school because these children have a right to Have a future. This is precisely why we are in the process of approving the first projects under the three billion euro facility. We are spending 55 million euros to ensure that an additional 110,000 children have access to school. In addition, there is a further 40 million euros for humanitarian aid through the World Food Program. This will provide food for 735,000 Syrian refugees. Further projects are in preparation and are on the way. I am often asked - probably here as well - whether Turkey is a reliable partner at all. Of course - and I do not want to hide it at all - there are issues, more than just one, on which Turkey and the European Union have very different views and opinions. But one thing is very clear to me: as much as we value the cooperation on behalf of the refugees, our position on other issues remains unchanged, for example when it comes to basic values ​​such as freedom of the press. I cannot understand at all that a German ambassador is called in because of an admittedly impossible satirical song. (Applause) That does not bring Turkey closer to us, but rather distances us from one another. The partnership with Turkey but also opens up some possibilities in this regard. Because in dialogue, the basic questions that are important to us - and hopefully also to Turkey - can be addressed better than from a frosty distance. And if Turkey moves towards us in the accession negotiations, then I can only welcome that. One day I would like to be able to welcome that too. So of all the solutions we have, the cooperation with Turkey is the best, if only because a border always has two sides and it is always better to protect it than against a neighbor. We also have to be aware of another fact: Turkey alone takes in almost three million refugees - more than any other country in the world and more than we Europeans combined. It is therefore our responsibility not to leave our Turkish neighbors alone with this responsibility. It is a matter of solidarity. If we are capable of only limited solidarity with one another, then we should be capable of unconditional solidarity with those who bear the main burden. (Applause) Solidarity is our guiding light as we prepare to reform our common European asylum system. We know the weak points in our current system, and smugglers know them too. They have exploited the patchwork of national rules to make a fortune from human suffering. Last week the Commission published the options for reform. We need to do three things above all. First, we need to make clear which Member State is responsible for treating an asylum request. This is the foundation of our common asylum system. It must be clear, it must be feasible and it must be sustainable, even in times of crisis. Second, we need to ensure that every man, woman and child receives humane and equal treatment, wherever they are. This requires that we fully harmonize our asylum procedures. Third, we need to ensure that every asylum seeker remains in the country where he or she has been assigned. This is the only way to maintain order. It is the only way to ensure that refugees can enjoy their rights while respecting their obligations. One principle above all will shape our reform: solidarity once again. We cannot abandon any Member State to face a crisis alone. A country’s place on the map should not decide its share of the work. I want our asylum system to be the best in the world, and I want this house to help us to build it. You have an opportunity to provide guidance before we publish our proposal next month. I urge you today: share your ideas with us. I am very pleased that the European Council of March 18 endorsed the Commission's strategy for growth and jobs - that virtuous triangle between investment, structural reforms and public finances. We are applying this strategy, and this strategy is producing initial results. The global economic situation in the European Union remains fragile, growth remains inadequate and we still have 22 million unemployed Europeans. And as long as we have 22 million people out of work, the end of the crisis cannot be decreed for that long. One day before the European Council, the Commission defined its strategy for the steel industry. I would like to make a strong plea for us to take the problems of the European steel industry seriously. The steel industry is not just any industry. The steel industry has ceased to be a heavy industry. The steel industry is the place of future-oriented cutting-edge technology. The steelworkers are not iron girders, but highly skilled workers, and these skilled workers in Europe deserve our full support. (Applause) That is why we must do all we can to combat unfair trade practices. Therefore we have to deal with the causes of global, worldwide steel overproduction. That is why we have to invest in future technologies, and therefore we have to invest in people who work in the steel industry.There are 360,000 steel workers in Europe, but the indirect steel sector is many times larger.These jobs must be preserved in Europe, that is our priority task in industrial policy.(Applause) Free trade should be fair trade.We are now investigating steel products from China to determine whether they were dumped on the market, and we will take other measures if necessary.The European Council agreed the measures the Commission has taken in relation to agriculture.This is an important dimension of our common undertaking.Last week the Commission published a VAT action plan giving our Member States more flexibility to set VAT rates in line with their priorities.In a time of upheaval the Commission continues to defend European interests, driving forward solutions and building bridges.This is our job - to provide stability - and this is how we plan to continue.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Gentlemen Presidents, dear colleagues! We met here in the European Parliament for months and criticized the Council for the disagreement, for the dispute that we witnessed there. I would therefore like to begin by saying thank you that we succeeded in describing a common path with Turkey in the meeting before Easter to solve the migration issues on the Balkan route together. For the first time Europe - the European heads of state and government - has succeeded in giving a common answer. In this context, I would like to expressly thank the President of the European Council, Donald Tusk, for this. It is his success that he has succeeded in bringing together the various interests and finding a common path. Thanks for that! Dear Colleagues! The answer has been found in Turkey. There is only one way together. We have respect, and certainly also recognition, for the achievements that Turkey is practicing. Almost three million people are already in the country and they are now getting work permits. The repatriation of illegal migrants is now working. We are taking on the fight against the smugglers together - that is the first important message. We are re-implementing law and order in migration flows. And the same thing that we are doing there now with the Balkan route, Mr President, we must also consider the Mediterranean route - you mentioned it. I am surprised at the questions that are now being asked about the legal system, that the questions are illegal, especially from the communist factions. I am amazed because Mr Tsipras - one of the communist representatives - was sitting at the table at the council and the laws have now been passed in Greece. I assume that Tsipras is doing the right thing. So if the left criticizes that now, one should first ask the questions in Greece. The same applies to Mr Verhofstadt, who is discussing this because his two colleagues - Rutte as Council President and Michel as Liberal Prime Minister - have confirmed all of this. I hope that the Liberal Group will also stand by these decisions if their heads of government implement them in the Council. The second: Europe needs secure borders, but Europe is not a fortress. We stand by the fact that we need legal routes to Europe in order to accommodate people who are in need in Europe. The EPP Group also supports the development aid aspects, the money. Waving through has ended. In the last few months we have had hundreds of thousands who have simply walked through Central Europe without control, without registration or without a security check. Thanks to the decision of the European Council and also thanks to the activities of Macedonia, this has now come to an end. It is clear that refugees - as the Commission President has said - do not have the right to choose where to help themselves. I would like to add one last thought and underline what Jean-Claude Juncker said today. With these points, we now have the chance to really give relations between the EU and Turkey a fresh start, to show the citizens that the partnership works, that both sides can work together in a spirit of trust. And that's why we also have a clear demand from President Erdoğan: You risk this restart with the way you deal with the issues. You have to respect freedom of expression, freedom of the press and also the rights of minorities, otherwise you will not have understood what Europe means. And on the current occasion, I also say: This applies not only to freedom of expression and freedom of the press in Turkey, but also to freedom of expression, freedom of the press and also to artistic freedom on this continent, in Europe. We expect from Erdoğan Respect for these values. The second big issue in the European Council was the question of growth. I would like to add one more sentence to this because the start is initially positive when we talk about growth. The Cypriot leader of the party that is currently in government in Cyprus was with us in the group yesterday, and Cyprus is out of the bailout program. Cyprus has managed to provide for itself again, to go its own way again. This is a model of success that succeeds in getting back on your feet independently with partnership and friendship in Europe and organizing growth. We are on the right track because we are reforming the states and the budgets have been stabilized. But we are also experiencing national election campaigns in which parties are calling this course into question again, in which the voters are told: No more reforms need to be carried out and we are spending new, fresh money that we do not have. Promises are made. I would like to say to people, especially when it comes to Spain, where we may have another election campaign in a few weeks: please do not believe these empty promises made by certain politicians! Here too, Tsipras is the best example. He has promised everything to the people and must also realize that he has to carry out pension reform in his own country. Do not believe the empty promises made by those who say that reforms must end and we can spend money again. The appeal to the citizens is: The only serious way is that we carry out reforms, reform our countries and that we ensure stable budgets. That is the only honest way forward, and the EPP Group will consistently pursue it. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: blue-card question. – I am going to ask my question in English, Manfred. I heard you speaking about the fact that Mr Erdoğan must respect human rights and all the rest of it, but I really wonder what kind of leverage you and your Chancellor have on this guy when you are forced to accept anything from him just for him to keep the refugees, to the point that when a humourist in Germany mocks Erdoğan, even the Chancellor is ill at ease and wants to please Erdoğan and does not know exactly how to handle it. This is not a sign of strength. If I were Erdoğan I would laugh at what you say: ‘Let him speak, let Manfred Weber speak, anyway I can get from the Chancellor whatever I like.’

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure. - First of all: applause from the right for this question. Very good to hear. Firstly, I should like to make it clear for a moment: Perhaps the Greens do not know it, but I am not the spokesman for the Chancellor, but the spokesman for the EPP Group in the European Parliament. Hopefully word will get around among the Greens as well. Second: We don't fall in front of anyone's door. I can make it clear to my group that there will be no refugee discount on the visa issue. Either Ankara implements all the criteria, then we can talk about visas, or they don't implement them, then there will be no visa liberalization. There is no refugee discount. We don't fall at anyone's feet. And the third thing is just as clear: we will hopefully take a major joint decision with Erdoğan today on the Turkey resolution in which this Parliament makes it clear that on the one hand we are working together pragmatically, looking for solutions with our neighbors who are who they are , and on the other hand we will make it clear that we expect Turkey to claim rights. I hope we do this across parties.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I appreciate President Tusk's words that "this agreement is not perfect", and I understand the genuinely commendable and positive intent that President Juncker recalled: "we must get the ball out of the hands of traffickers. of death". Nevertheless, our doubts, the doubts of my political group, remain. We have concluded the agreement at the very moment when Turkey is withdrawn into itself, the free press is repressed and the rights of minorities trampled on. I ask the Commission and the Council to monitor, as they said to do, Turkey's respect for human rights, humanitarian law, to strengthen economic and human resources support for Greece, to pay particular attention to women and for children, to verify the possibility of a European management of hot spots. Honestly, let's face it frankly, we can criticize this agreement - I am doing it - however, we have been forced into this agreement by the selfishness and closure of some EU Member States who have refused to relocate refugees. None of us have the magic wand to solve these issues, but we all know that the key to overcoming this challenge lies in a mandatory and automatic mechanism, as the European Commission has proposed, of refugees and migrants, and we must also take into account the idea of ​​sanctions against those countries that put a spoke in the wheel. It is no longer acceptable that the Union, on the one hand, punishes a state that goes beyond the deficit by one point zero and, on the other, closes both eyes to the sabotage of those who do not show responsibility for politics immigration; we cannot be strict on accounts and lax on people. Then we need an overall strategy, it was said, there are not only the Aegean and the Balkans, the landings on the southern shore are increasing and we must also propose a development pact to African countries, otherwise in the coming months we will see a new exodus in the Mediterranean and migrants will arrive, if not from Africa, from Albania and what will we do? Will we build walls on the water? Thinking about stopping millions of people with walls is not only unrealistic, it is even shameful. I also say this to Austria, what is this preventive barrier for 25 refugees a day? What is that? A useless, shameful, harmful thing! So, in the coming weeks, we have a historic opportunity, we have the opportunity given us by the possibility of reforming Dublin. Juncker has again offered a pact of alliance with Parliament, I say yes to President Juncker, a pact of alliance with Parliament, but for a courageous reform that goes to the bottom of the Dublin rules, to enact a true common asylum policy at European level. I continue to believe - and I conclude President - that in this difficult time we must maximize what unites us. What unites the sincerely pro-European forces that still exist here and in Europe, rather than favoring what divides us. In this difficult time it would be advisable to avoid turning this House into an agora for the electoral campaign in Spain, in Greece, in other countries. Let's do it there, here we try to maintain our unity to change Europe and to save Europe. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Richard SULÍK
text: a question asked by lifting a blue card.- Mr Pittel, you want to punish countries that refuse to accept migrants.Well, my question is: What if the vast majority of citizens of these countries do not want hundreds of thousands of migrants to come to them?Should these countries ignore the will of their citizens?Thank you for your answer - factual and short.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Answer to a "blue card" question.- (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, certainly very direct, not direct.If a country decides freely, freely, to join the European Union, it is obliged to respect the decisions taken within the European Union.

name: Syed KAMALL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, last September Frans Timmermans stood before the plenary to talk about the immigration and refugee crisis and dramatically announced that winter was coming. Well, as the days get longer and the blossom and leaves appear on the trees, we can now see that summer is coming. The International Organisation for Migration has estimated that eight times more people crossed the seas to come to EU countries in the first three months of 2016 compared to the first three months of 2015. All indications are that the numbers arriving this summer will surpass previous years, many fleeing the horrors of terrorism and barbarism that still exist, but others understandably pursuing a better life in our countries. None of us wants to see another summer like the last, wondering if the public support for the Schengen area or the public’s confidence in our institutions or the public sympathy can last another summer like the last. And whilst the challenge may not change, what does need to change is our attitude and our response. This summer is a chance to show that we have learned the lessons of failure from 2015. And while Mr. Tusk admits that not all agreements are perfect, I have to say that much has come out of the Council and the Commission to tackle the crisis which my political group has called for and supports: measures to better guard the external border; enhancing the Schengen Information System; building a more efficient returns and readmission programme, and taking on the human traffickers. However, other decisions have been made which may make some of us feel better but may store up more problems for the future. And while I have huge admiration for the way that the Turkish nation has received, administered and housed over 2.7 million refugees, as Mr Tusk admitted, many of us still have serious concerns about the EU-Turkey deal on a practical level, on a legal level and (some) on an ethical level. Time will tell if those concerns are allayed. But even as the German Chancellor and the European Commission hailed the deal with Turkey, questions are being asked in other countries. We live in an age of instant messaging and social media, and we have to realise that as one entry point becomes less accessible, messages will be sent back telling others to try alternative routes via Italy, Spain or Malta, to name a just few. Moving on to last week’s communication from the Commission on the review of the Dublin system, we saw a mixed bag: two very different options for reform. One option that reinvents the wheel and centralises asylum applications and distribution. The other, which seeks to make the wheel that we have turn better, offers some improvements to help states on the front line. Or to put it another way, now we face a clear decision between choosing an option shrouded in idealism but which has little chance of success, and one based on realism and making the situation better. I suspect the general public would prefer that we choose pragmatism over idealism. So, rather than an idealistic grand plan or what Mr Tusk calls a ‘golden key’, let us make the rules that we have work properly. Let us enhance and improve the laws and agencies already in place, not scrap and replace them through desperation. Let us put our efforts and our money into controlling our borders; returning those who are not fleeing persecution or war or disaster – of course understandably coming for a better economic life – but allowing them to apply through existing legal migration channels; providing dignified detention conditions; speeding up asylum procedures and getting meaningful and voluntary commitment from Member States about helping refugees closer to their homes, or directly resettling the most vulnerable from conflict regions. But let us show anyone looking to come to EU countries that we have asylum systems which are firm but fair, based on compassion and pragmatism. So my message to this House, to the Commission and to Member States over the next few weeks is a simple one: summer is coming. We do not have time to reinvent the wheel, but we do have time to fix it. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question asked under the 'blue card' procedure.- Mr Kamall, you have said many times that pragmatism is needed, additional measures.We all know and must understand solidarity and the need for humanism.I ask you, if you were the President of the Commission, what would you do to implement what you say needs to be done, because you have said many times what needs to be done, but not how.If you were the President of the Commission, what would you do?

name: Syed KAMALL
text: blue-card answer. – I see that the President of the Commission looks across to me – not for an answer, but with a knowing smile. Look, we can all try to be the President of the Commission, but actually the issue here is pragmatism. It is all very well you coming up and saying to me that we need some grand plan and we must impose solutions on Member States, but you have seen the reactions in Member States. Mr Sulík from my Group asked a very pertinent question when he asked: what do politicians do when the vast majority of the voters in their Member States do not want a solution imposed by the EU? What did Mr Pittella say? Mr Pittella said that they have to accept the decisions of the EU. I am afraid that is not the way forward. The way forward is to sit down with all the Member States and ask what they can all meaningfully do. They all want to offer solutions instead of having a solution imposed on them.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, there is a saying that when you play with fire, you have to expect to get burnt. I have to tell you that my impression is that this is exactly what is happening now with the Turkey deal. Why with the Turkey deal? Because we tried to outsource our problems to an autocratic leader, Mr Erdoǧan. What is he doing? Well, two days ago, Mr Erdoǧan instructed the German Government to prosecute a TV presenter, Jan Böhmermann, for a satirical poem. I can tell you that I am not Mr Böhmermann’s lawyer and what he produced is also not my taste in humour, but in a free society such satirical poems must be possible. That is the price we pay for our freedom, and we pay happily for our freedom. So, to come back to Erdoǧan: we have already given him the keys to the gates of Europe and now we risk handing over the keys to our newsrooms to him so that he decides and controls our media. I have to tell you that I am not surprised that this is happening. If you put yourself at the mercy of somebody like Mr Erdoǧan and if you outsource your responsibilities to a third country like Turkey, that in my opinion it is only the beginning of what I call Turkish bazaar politics. Why do I say that? Well, Mr Erdoǧan has already declared in the Turkish Parliament that he will call off the agreement he has made with you if, within two months, he does not have the visa liberalisation he requested, regardless of whether he keeps his part of the agreement and complies with our conditions for visa liberalisation. So it is clear that we have put ourselves in the hands of Erdoǧan and, in fact, of his government. I have more and more the impression and the feeling, Mr Tusk, that, while Putin uses energy as a weapon, Erdoǧan uses poor refugees as a political weapon. That is what is happening. And I do not say that in a light way, I have to tell you. First proof of that: in Turkey – that was part of the deal, Mr Juncker, and it is not being complied with by the Turks – they need to change their legislation to lift all the territorial restrictions on the Geneva Convention and to make it possible for a Syrian refugee to have asylum in Turkey. They are not doing it and they refuse to do it. Moreover, and more important, is the fact that there are reports – and nobody is talking about this, we have a debate here – from Amnesty International stating that Turkey is sending Syrian refugees back to Syria against international law. Yesterday this was confirmed by Dutch state television in a programme in which they investigated this and proved that the Turkish authorities are doing that. My question to you, Mr Tusk, is: why are you not examining this? Is this true? And if this is true, can we continue with a deal that is against international law and against our obligations? What are you doing? What is your answer to that? Are you investigating this? Is it true what Amnesty International and Dutch state television said yesterday? Thirdly, let us not fool ourselves. It is true: you say the deal is working. On the Greek—Turkish border, yes. There are no longer 1 700 a day but 50 a day now. But yesterday the Italian coastguard rescued not 50 people, as normal, but 2 154 people. So what is the result of yesterday? We can only take yesterday’s figures. People like to talk about figures here and about the deal. Well, they are the figures – from 1 700 to 50, and from 50 to 2 154. Is that a deal that is working? In the meantime, we have in fact put our position, our freedom and our values in the hands of whom? Of Erdoǧan. Well, I am saying that instead of having a debate here about a deal that in my opinion is not working, we ourselves have to get our act together in Europe. That is the priority now and, in my opinion, that means three things. First of all, the European Border and Coast Guard. Do you know what the reality is? The Commission, rightly, has asked the Member States for a number of people. Do you know the figures? Four hundred people were asked for as interpreters: 37 were sent to Greece. The Commission asked for 472 migration officers: 31, Mr Tusk, have been sent to Turkey and to Greece. The Commission asked for 1 500 security officers. How many have been sent? Three hundred and thirty-nine. So in total, more than 2 300 people have been requested by the Commission as the start of this European Border and Coast Guard, and 400 of these people, more or less, have, in reality, been put at the disposal of the Commission. Is that a deal that is working? I have another idea. I think we desperately need this European Border and Coast Guard and to make an agreement so that it can be rolled out. Secondly, I think we desperately need a European asylum system and, like Mr Pittella, I give the support of my Group to go forward with the Commission’s proposal as fast as possible. And desperately, if you want to fight the smugglers, there is only one way and that is to make legal migration to Europe possible too. That is the only way to stop the smugglers – smugglers in Turkey or smugglers in North Africa. (Applause) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card question. – Mr Verhofstadt, you and I will always disagree politically, but I have to agree with your honesty here. You are saying what former President of the Commission, Roy Jenkins – a British politician– was saying, which is that there are now only two clear and consistent positions as regards Britain’s membership of the European Union: all in or all out. I admire your honesty for standing up and saying as much. Would you agree with me that the signals – be they smoke signals or, indeed, hand signals – coming out of this place indicate the understanding that the British people’s patience with the EU institutions has finally run out?

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: blue-card answer. – I like your British sense of humour, but I see it more as a question for Mr Kamall, who is a specialist in this.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - (DE) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, gentlemen, who you spoke earlier to start today's debate! I think your trick is not working. In view of the harsh criticism in the world about the EU-Turkey agreement, to come here and say: We understand that we ourselves have doubts about the ethical and legal admissibility of the agreement, on the other hand to declare: But that's that what we've got out of here and the key to the holy grail doesn't exist - I don't think it works. Because you have to do more. You can't just say: We won't get the key, and we know that everything doesn't work properly, and we don't move around that cleanly, but on the other hand, then again keep silent about what actually led to this situation. And when, in this situation, Mr Weber, plagued by his nightmares, conjures up the specter of communism again, especially that of Mr Tsipras and others, I can only say: Somewhere there is a loss of reality. We as the EU impose on Greece that with every decision to deport a refugee from Greece to Turkey, the deporting country must ensure that Turkey is a safe third country. We are demanding this from Greece, after we had been beating the drum here for months and accusing Greece that it is not doing enough to protect the external borders, one has to consider whether Greece can still be in the Schengen area at all, they always have it not yet understood - completely away from the realities in this country. Mr Verhofstadt has just listed what the implementation of the agreement actually means and what specific help is to be provided by the EU, what has been promised and what has been achieved so far. We are forcing Greece to enforce an asylum procedure, an asylum test based on the lowest standards. This is a lowering, a lowering of the standards for the asylum check. We finally have to take note of that here. And if that is then supposed to be the standard that will in future also apply as a blueprint for further negotiations, for further agreements, then I can only say: Then we will be far from our standards, from our principles, from our demands for humanity , according to dignity. At least we have to make that very clear here. It is one thing to have inadequacies and also to see that in practice we have not made any progress here, but it is another to pretend that one has to be satisfied with them now and those who criticize it should now please keep your mouth shut. That doesn't work, and I'll tell you very clearly: We are still strictly against evaluating this Turkey as it is now - and I always talk about this Erdoğan Turkey - as a safe third country. Even the scientific service of the Bundestag has expressed doubts and declared: Yes, in order to be a safe third country, one must guarantee refugee rights, effectively guarantee them in practice, and that is not done. The reports are available that hundreds of refugees have been deported across the border every day since mid-January, that the border is being closed, that Syrian refugees are being refused registration, that people are being shot, and that children are among the dead. When do we address this here? For me that is the question, and here I can only say: Please face an aggressive asylum policy! Put the responsibility on the Member States, even more than before! Stick with it, do this!

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Dear Presidents, dear colleagues! The idea that was put over the result after the last summit was: we want to work together to ensure that there is order, reliability and the rule of law in the process of immigration and flight to Europe. We also want to guarantee reliability and the rule of law for people on the move. What we have been seeing day after day in the morning and evening in the news from Greece for weeks now shows a situation in which a kind of order is being established, but humanity and the rule of law disappear completely behind it. For example, there were really sensational reports from Idomeni from a former German minister, Norbert Blüm, who insisted again and again: If you want to do something better, then do it in accordance with the European idea of ​​humanity and in accordance with our own laws. And you said earlier, Mr Tusk, that is not all at 100 percent. I believe that at the moment in Greece there is absolutely no mention of the rule of law in the process, and that is Europe's first responsibility. Before we talk about the difficult situation in Turkey, we must first be able to guarantee the rule of law for people who have fled, at home in the European Union. I don't know whether that will work before we have established coast guard and border guard across Europe - because I believe that this is the most important requirement in this context - whether that will work one hundred percent. But letting go of the current situation - I know that won't work. And I believe that the European Union, together with the Greek authorities and Greek politicians, is asked to establish something else, because my impression is that what is happening now discredits the entire EU refugee policy and that the impression is solidifying that this misery is tolerated as a means of deterring people who would otherwise want to make their way to Europe. I think that we in Turkey - because there is this arrangement on refugees - also have responsibility for the rule of law. The fact that an agreement has been concluded does not mean that we can let it go, but that the European Union has had to clarify for weeks - since the news came that Syrian refugees were being pushed back to Syria - whether that was the case, and - if that is the case - would of course have to review the agreement and, if in doubt, withdraw it. I am - and I am now contradicting Mr Verhofstadt, with whom I completely agree on asylum guidelines and border and coast guard guidelines - not of the opinion that the EU has already thrown itself at President Erdoğan's feet. I am of the opinion - as the oppositionists in Kurdistan, Ankara and Istanbul keep saying to me - that Turkey deserves the commitment of Europeans to the rule of law and to better development in Turkey. And in view of the overall situation in the Near and Middle East and simply also in view of the geographic location of Turkey and our history with Turkey, to discredit to such a large extent any attempt to come to better appointments and a dispute. One last word about Germany: The freedom of art and the press will not be decided by Erdoğan in Germany. I am of the opinion that my country is strong enough to hold its own against Mr Erdoğan in this dispute.

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I am very surprised. We are here in what I have been told repeatedly is the home of European democracy, so surely we could have taken the opportunity this morning to celebrate the Dutch referendum last week, in which the people said ‘no’ to EU enlargement, ‘no’ to the deal with the Ukraine, and no doubt had it been Turkey, an even bigger number of people would have said ‘no’ to Turkish accession. It was a victory for democracy but, in particular, it was a victory for a little organisation called GeenStijl, a group of young bloggers who managed to get together 427 000 signatures. So it was also a victory for direct democracy, in the week when we remember that Gianroberto Casaleggio, the genius behind the Five Star Movement in Italy, has died. This, ladies and gentlemen, is the new politics. We were told by Mr Juncker that if the Dutch voted ‘no’ it would be a disaster, but he has not mentioned it today at all. Indeed, his predecessor, Mr Van Rompuy, my old mate, says we should just ignore the Dutch and carry on blithely. So, what we are seeing is the big battalions of vested self-interest doing their best to completely ignore the will of the Dutch people. I think things are changing. I do not believe these institutions can survive 21st-century technology. I think the will of the people is changing politics in a way that makes all of you in this room deeply fearful, and so you should be. As we, in the United Kingdom, enter the final countdown of our referendum, all eyes are on this Turkish deal. What we see is the bosses of the EU bowing and scraping before Mr Erdoğan, who gleefully walks all over them and tramples over human rights at every level. Mr Juncker tells us this morning that we are making progress. Let us just examine that. 1.8 million people have come to the EU in the last 18 months and we have sent back 300. It does not sound like it is going very well to me. The one group that will be pleased, though, are ISIS. They have now managed to put 5 000 of their operatives into the European continent, according to the boss of Europol: something that should send a shiver down our collective spines. I have to say that, in the end, I think it is what the British referendum will turn on. I think we will vote for Brexit, and the reason is we will vote to put our own safety first. It is going to be as it was in the Netherlands last week – a battle of people versus the politicians. You may have the big money, the big businesses and Goldman Sachs, but we have got our armies of bloggers. In the end the people’s will is going to prevail. This place will not survive. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Peter ERIKSSON
text: blue-card question. – I have a question for Mr Farage, sitting behind the British flag. Do you not think it is embarrassing for many Brits that a speaker, speaking behind the British flag, is celebrating a referendum of which the only winner is Mr Putin, who now is celebrating the fact that Europe is not united behind the cooperation with Ukraine?

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: blue-card answer. – I am no fan of Mr Putin, but I am equally not very keen on going to war with Mr Putin. It strikes me as being a very silly idea. What did we do? We encouraged the overthrow of a corrupt but democratically-elected leader in Ukraine. We, in effect, have poked the Russian bear with a stick and we are surprised when he reacts. We should not be. I think we should all have our own individual nation-state democracies, and I want a Europe, Mr Eriksson, where we trade together, cooperate together, work together, are friends and good neighbours with each other. What I do not want is that flag, an anthem, and all these presidents. I do not want political union. I want genuine European friendship.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! I cannot help but make a few remarks on previous speakers from the Social Democrats and the European People's Party when a Mr Pittella seriously claims that Austria must be criticized because, as he says, 25 migrants come to us every day. I can only assure you that last year there were 90,000 who sought asylum here in Austria, that this year there are already 35,000, and last year, with the help of Austrian Chancellor Faymann, a million people passed through Austria that were smuggled through towards Germany. And when, under pressure from my party - the Freedom Party - border protection measures are finally implemented in Austria, then I ask that you speak badly about it. I would also like to say a few words about the head of the European People's Party. If a Mr. Weber here in all seriousness keeps talking derogatory about the rights - yes, Mr. Weber, what are you? I think you are a CSU member. When I hear the words of your Bavarian Prime Minister, he is making conservative politics. What you do is somewhere between red and green. But it's good that the AfD in Germany is just overtaking you and that you will soon be just a part of German party history. And a Mrs Harms from the Greens, who recently claimed in all seriousness that democratic referendums should be held back on European affairs - I wonder what happened to your party? You come from a movement that acted on a grassroots basis. Today you are traveling in a pseudo-dictatorial manner and want to deprive the population of the right to decide their own interests. This Turkey deal is another rotten deal that is headed in the completely wrong direction, and its eyes and ears have been closed to what is happening in Turkey. Human rights, the Kurdish problem, the treatment of women in society and so on and so forth, orientate yourself - Mr President, I am done - by what the population says. In the Netherlands a right decision has been taken against the wrong policies of the European Union. This is a best practice model for all of Europe.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - President! The end result of the EU-Turkey agreement is the legal arrival of immigrants in the European Union. Union leaders say there are good migrants and bad migrants. A bad migrant who arrives in Greece on board a ferry without entry documents will be sent back. However, who Turkey sends to Europe at the expense of this quota is a good migrant. I ask: will they fit into European societies? Are they not going to build a parallel society? Won't there be terrorists among them? There is no guarantee of this. This agreement fulfills President Juncker's idea: he made it clear in a speech here in Parliament that Europe needs immigrants, citing Australia and Canada as examples. Mrs Zimmer has just said that we are the European Union. No, in a democracy we are not the European Union, we are the people of the European Union. However, most of them do not want to make Europe a continent of immigrants. Thank you very much.

name: Herbert REUL
text: - Presidents, Madam President! Sometimes I don't really understand the world anymore: We have had a lot of debates here and we were upset that we don't have any concrete help on the issue of refugees, that our main job is to take care of the people who live on the Escape is helped. And then we attacked the council and said: These crazy idiots, these egoists are not coming to Potte. Now they decide, now you could say: Thank you, that was okay. That would be an idea too! Instead: Ms. Zimmer and Mr. Verhofstadt - I'm taking off my socks - complain as always. That's how we always did it here cheerfully: complain about everything and take no responsibility! The most important sentence this morning was Mr Tusk's: Europe has taken responsibility. Yes, finally! The Member States have finally taken on responsibility and said: We are going to do something now. This is not a perfect solution, who said that? Anyone who does politics and has a bit of all their senses together knows that there is never a perfect solution. There never is, there are always only pieces or steps on the right path. And that is an important step, that is an opportunity, that is concrete help. We have a decline in the number of refugees, that's something! And the nonsense that some people say here, that would surrender us to Turkey - I can't think of anything more. What kind of nonsense is that? In contrast to those who accuse us of this, I can only say: I was always against joining Turkey from the start. Many of those who now have different views always said: record tomorrow. Stop gossiping, on the one hand, to take on Turkey tomorrow, and now - if it fits - to criticize! Stay straight! I found Mrs. Harms' contribution to be very impressive. To say there are a lot of things that don't suit me - I share that. I don't like a lot of what is happening in Turkey. But if you now organize cooperation on the issue of refugees, as Jean-Claude Juncker said, and take a step forward, that is progress. You could say: great, great, made progress, next step! But now be careful that we don't make a mistake - of course. But don't just criticize from morning to night! If things go on like this, this Parliament will develop into an institution in the European concert that cannot be taken seriously, if we keep complaining and being against everything. Being very specific for points and helping people - that's what we get paid for. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Dear Herbert!Let us assume that the deal is good - and I do not see it so uncritically either, but I believe that this is actually a step in the right direction - then the Member States must take responsibility.The Federal Ministry of the Interior said last week: There are two or three people from the Technical Relief Organization on site in Greece to implement the deal, four officials from the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees, eight more will be coming soon, and thirty officials from the Federal Police.Would you agree with me that the Federal Government is not fulfilling its responsibility to implement this deal responsibly, if it is supported, with sufficient human resources, and that Mr Juncker and Mr Tusk are being left hanging here by Angela Merkel and Thomas de Maizière?

name: Herbert REUL
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Yes, the world is not that simple either.But I agree with you, I would also like the Member States to help more quickly and send the staff they promise - one hundred percent right.But unfortunately, sometimes it's not as easy - as you learn when you work in administrations - but it's right.Of course, you have to keep what you promise, regardless of which Member State.Incidentally, also the Member States, which then have to be ready to take in refugees, the game is one of them.Everything as a whole and right, it is also part of it: The staff that you have promised you have to send - crystal clear.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: - Thank you, President. I strongly wanted to say today: we have a good agreement with Turkey, and an agreement that works and has a legal basis, but unfortunately I cannot say that. And although it increasingly seems to me to be a rotten compromise, I see no other alternative at the moment. I want the agreement to work, but in such a way that refugees have their fundamental human rights respected. And not by making our cooperation conditional, by blackmailing refugees into the Greek islands to hear that Turkey is forcibly returning Syrians to Syria? The situation is shocking. There are almost three million refugees in Turkey, most of them on the roads. How safe is this country for these people at all? We know the situation with media freedom, minority rights. The situation on the Greek islands is also shocking, where "hot spots" are becoming closed camps. We need to give refugees the opportunity to apply for asylum. Where are all those of our experts? It is also a fact that even such a good agreement with Turkey will not succeed if the countries of the Union do not start implementing resettlement and relocation programs. The crux of the problem is on our side. We have long been able to strengthen legal and safe routes, prevent the erection of fences, stop the death of people on the shores of Europe, the exploitation of women and children, trafficking in human beings. But we didn't make it. We need an ambitious Dublin reform, and I agree. perhaps it is a historic moment, or rather a last chance to convince people that European policies can also be successful. (the speaker answered the question raised by raising a blue card (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Would you like to either clarify, or maybe join with your leader, Mr Pittella, in the comments that he made earlier? I would be interested in your opinion. Do you agree with him that it is selfish of nation states to decide how many refugees they take? Do you agree with him that Member States should be forced to take certain numbers? Do you join with me in condemning the lack of respect that a leader of a Group which includes the British Labour Party shows to independent nation states as a disgrace? Would you agree?

name: Tanja FAJON
text: The answer to the question posed by raising a blue card.- Dear colleague, I agree with all of us who insist today that European solidarity does not work.And I agree with all of us who insist today that all the countries of the European Union must take responsibility when it comes to sharing the burden.We know that the relocation and resettlement program is not working at the moment, that a number of countries in the European Union are not taking responsibility at the moment.And as long as this is not the case, everything else is superfluous, all agreements are unnecessary and the European Union is in fact rushing into a very, very critical situation.I want us all, together with you, to take moral responsibility here.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: - The course of events has greatly accelerated since the March European Council. I consider two particularly important: the terrorist attacks on the capital of the European Union - Belgium, and the result of the referendum in the Netherlands. In the former case, I expect from all three presidents what you have done and are going to do to ensure the security of the institutions under your command, thousands of employees and thousands of officials from the European Union's Member States visiting Brussels. This is very important for the administrative implementation of all well-worded Council conclusions. Regarding the second case: the result of the referendum in the Netherlands undermined the ability to implement CFSP / CSDP in the East towards Russia. I expect from the leaders of the European Union an idea to solve this problem, more sophisticated than just talking about cooperation with Russia and focusing only on the southern direction. One more remark: I consider deep interference in Polish affairs and the brutal language of the resolution to be voted on today to be a typical substitute topic, diverting attention from the inability to face real challenges. (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising a "blue card" (Rule 162 (8))

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: blue card question.- I do not understand what the Dutch referendum, Russia and Poland have to do with this issue when it comes to a very serious matter, namely how to stop the flow of migrants, the flow of asylum seekers and how to provide people with fair conditions.Don't you have the heart to focus on this issue, which I now think weighs on all European citizens?

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: blue-card answer. – Madam, I do not know how my intervention was interpreted into various languages, yet I think that the future will show there is a clear link between all of these issues. I was also referring to the administrative ability to solve these problems after the terrorist attacks.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: -  Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! I think it is right - a look at the map shows that - to talk to Turkey in this difficult situation, to treat Turkey with respect. It has taken in three million refugees - an achievement that cannot be overestimated. The first glance at the map shows that. A second look at the map shows that the Mediterranean route will work out. Syed Kamall is right when he says: Summer is just around the corner. The figures that Mr Verhofstadt just mentioned here indicate that. So more has to be done. But what also needs to happen now is that the implementation of this agreement is humane, that it is effective and that it is forward-looking. Human - that means we must by no means give up the individual examination. We are a legal community, we are bound by human rights. Turkey, as our partner, must also recognize this. Effective - that is, Member States must keep their promises. I think Germany leaves Europe hanging. Customs and the federal police have 70,000 officers, and a total of 300 have been promised to secure the external border. Forward-looking - we need ways of legal immigration to Europe, otherwise the tragedy will continue in the Mediterranean and in the Aegean.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: - Madam President, "Europe prefers to relocate police officers rather than relocate refugees". This sentence from a European NGO sums up the summit last March. Hotspots have become confinement camps. We are pushing back without real individual examination, including Syrians, to a country where this Parliament denounces human rights violations, migrants who do not need international protection, men and more and more women and of children. The reception is at degree zero. The United Nations special rapporteur on the rights of migrants tells us that the agreement, rather than saving lives, will put them at risk. The UNHCR considers that this agreement is contrary to international law and refuses to participate in its implementation, like many NGOs, and you dare to speak of respect for human dignity. What more can I say except that I am ashamed, ashamed to be European, and to see values ​​such as the right of asylum trampled on because European leaders refuse to confront public opinion. This is how we feed populism. Realists are those who look at the world as it is and seek concrete solutions - yes, like legal avenues, yes, like a real European right of asylum - and who do not let people die in the Mediterranean. The European Union is the richest economic zone in the world. It must show solidarity at the height of the humanitarian crisis facing our planet.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: – Madam President, I am speaking on behalf of  the Verts/ALE Group, which is very concerned about the deal with Turkey. First, the deal does nothing to solve the refugee crisis. Instead of providing a just and humane common European solution, Member States are egotistically trying to hide the crisis from the view of EU citizens, pretending that the illegal mass returns of refugees to Syria have nothing to do with the Union. But we know how terrible the human suffering at the Turkish-Syrian border is. The Union should have proposed an ambitious and united approach in asylum matters based on solidarity and fair sharing of responsibilities. Second, Turkey is not a safe country for refugees. It does not provide basic guarantees of the status of refugees. Moreover, Turkey is not a safe country even for its own nationals. Turkey is engulfed by violence and repression against Kurds and other minorities. The Turkish Government should put an end to censorship and respect freedom of expression. Last but not least, the deal is illegal. By framing it as a statement of the Heads of State and Government, the EU side is trying to avoid the obligations under EU law, including the Charter of Fundamental Rights. It also circumvents the prerogatives of this Parliament to co-decide on asylum and migration matters. We expect Parliament to take all necessary steps to evaluate the legality of this agreement, together with the decisions based on it, and contest it in the Court of Justice. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – As was mentioned this morning in this Chamber, the agreement with Turkey is not perfect, but it seems it is a step forward anyway. What do you think the European Union should do if this agreement is denounced? Mr Erdoğan declared last week that, if the EU does not fulfil its obligations, Turkey could denounce it any time.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: blue-card answer. – Well that is the problem, colleague: everything is in the hands of Turkey. That is the problem, because most probably we cannot denounce the agreement but Turkey can. This shows that it is an illegal, strange and impossible agreement.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we heard today from President Tusk that this agreement is not perfect, that everything possible has been done to respect human rights, but that doubts remain and the same doubts have also been shared by President Juncker. Well, if you had doubts you should not proceed, you should not have proceeded because we are dealing with doubts relating to the risk of violations of fundamental rights. These are doubts that start from facts, from history, even from recent episodes. Of course, we are aware that a solution must be found, we are not looking for the golden fleece or perfection, as President Tusk told us today, but we are looking for a solution and the solution represents for us, it coincides with the modification of the Dublin regulation, but a real change, a real change, not the one proposed days ago by the European Commission. There is no trace of the humanitarian corridors in the proposal of the European Commission and yet we want to fight against irregular immigration, well, then that we give a legal alternative, that we give a legal alternative to reach Europe, that we change the Dublin regulation, also based on the principle that the first country of arrival is the one that has the greatest responsibility in asylum applications. It is by changing this principle that a country is prevented from becoming a huge refugee camp. The Balkan route is still closed, in Idomeni the Macedonian police used tear gas and rubber bullets injuring people, including children, UNICEF reports 22,000 minor refugees, of which 2,000 are unaccompanied, Amnesty International has denounced Turkey as a country not safe for refugees. The situation is disastrous and, unfortunately, it is a summary assessment of the effects of the EU-Turkey agreement. Little has changed compared to the pre-existing human situation, it is evident that by erecting walls the route does not close, it moves, it moves and the Mediterranean route is reopening, 380 migrants have arrived in Crotone, 400 are landing in Reggio Calabria, in Italy. We are faced with a Europe that carries out little incisive actions to intervene at the root of the flows, on the real causes of the problem which are wars, the sale of arms and the exploitation of resources belonging to other peoples, we must affect the causes and protect the fundamental rights of all. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question, Rule 162 (8)))

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: Question asked by raising a blue card.- Dear colleague.Since I really appreciate some of your colleagues in your group who are analytical in their thinking, I would ask you, I would relate to what you said in the last sentence.We are talking today about the agreement with Turkey on many things.From the fact that this is a prediction of a change in policy to the enlargement of Europe and to various other issues.I would like to ask you, but you do not think that we should also focus in this debate on the causes of the crisis, the causes of this humanitarian catastrophe.We are not a humanitarian organization, we are politicians, we should honestly confront who and why caused the catastrophe in the Middle East.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Answer to a "blue card" question.- We are politicians and we have to deal with solutions from a political and regulatory point of view.We are certainly not a charitable voluntary association, but the proposals we put on the plate, the solution proposals we have been presenting, for two years now, are concrete proposals, they are legislative proposals, they are not proposals that come from non-governmental associations.It is a question of humanitarian corridors, it is an embargo on the sale of arms in countries that are at war, it is a question of legal access to the European Union.So I believe that these are absolutely concrete proposals that affect the causes that cause migratory flows, that cause migratory flows.Because migratory flows in themselves are a phenomenon that has always existed, but voluntary movements are one thing, the constraint that comes from wars and persecutions is one thing and we must not be complicit in them.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: - Madam President, on March 18, Chancellor Merkel and the other so-called negotiators of this agreement with Turkey actually gave in to all of Sultan Erdoğan's demands. Eternal turkeys of neo-Ottoman farce, the leaders who preside over the destinies of our adrift continent have signed a new blank check to the Turkish pyromaniac firefighter. The three billion euros previously allocated to Turkey have thus been doubled, all at the expense of our taxpayers. Worse, despite the Turks' obscure ties to Islamic State barbarians, and despite Turkey allowing the smuggler mafia to thrive, the decision was made to grant its 80 million citizens unrestricted access to the media. 'Schengen area. That is why Commissioner Avramopoulos asked us yesterday to - and I quote - "adapt to the new era of human mobility". On July 1, Slovakia will be president of the European Union. Slovak Prime Minister Robert Fico denounces what he called the ritual suicide of Europe. Like his Hungarian, Polish and Czech counterparts, he can see that your multicultural utopia is a failure.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Madam President, despite the expectations raised by the European Union agreement with Turkey on tackling the refugee problem, it is doomed to failure. First of all, Turkey is not prepared to deal with the problem of smuggling people from its territory to Greece. The boats that transport the illegal immigrants from Turkey to Greece depart very early in the morning, while the Turkish Coast Guard starts its patrols at eleven in the morning. So do NATO ships, so how can illegal smugglers' ships be located? In addition, Turkey has issued a large number of several thousand forged Syrian passports to Afghans and Pakistanis. When they are sent back to Turkey, the Turkish authorities will easily find that the passports are fake, since she has issued them, and will send them back to Greece. So, they would only resort to this as a last resort. Finally, there is information but also the certainty that the illegal immigrants will deny that Turkey is a safe country and will not want to go and stay in Greece. So let go of the hypocrisy and press Turkey to implement the agreement. Otherwise, the Greek people impoverished by the memoranda will not allow their government to approve the three billion euro funding of Turkey

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: - Madam President! Dear Chairman of the Committee and the Council! The agreement between Turkey and the Union gives rise to divergent views and strong emotions. We already experienced this in the March session, when the details of this contract were not known yet. But we have to say what were the reasons why we had to conclude this agreement. This is the result of losing the ability to protect our external borders. This was due to all those who delayed the development of common solutions, including the restoration of law and control at the external borders of the European Union. The agreement between Turkey and the Union is a difficult, complicated and delicate compromise. We are all aware of this. We are also aware of the logistical, material and legal challenges that we have to face, but it also brings real help to the refugees who are in Turkey. These unprecedented situations also require extraordinary solutions, but this does not mean that the law of the stronger is to apply or that we are to give up our values ​​when fighting for Europe. I would also like to say that we hope that after the agreement with Turkey, in the wake of the Malta summit on November 11, forms of cooperation with other countries will also crystallize, because the internationalization of the migration crisis is the only way to solve it. I would also like to highlight with satisfaction that the European Council is addressing the situation of, inter alia, in the steel sector. As it has been said, there are 300,000 jobs and hundreds of jobs related to this sector. This also applies to the situation in my country, Poland. Has the situation on agricultural markets, which - as was rightly stated - in the milk market in particular, caused a real drop in farmers' incomes and disturbances on these markets? And the third issue is the security of gas supplies, in particular the transparency of international agreements on the supply of energy resources.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! We all agree: the agreement with Turkey is only part of a solution. Turkey is an important partner for us, especially when it comes to migration and refugee issues, but the main responsibility remains with us here in the European Union. Yesterday, with a large majority, we passed an own-initiative report which makes it very clear what we want: we want more solidarity within Europe, we want more legal channels, we want to revise the Dublin procedure and secure Schengen. I think that is still at the forefront of everything we do. The Turkey Agreement can only function properly if the conditions for it are in place. And that's why it's also about management and also about very specific work so that it can work. If I cannot currently apply for asylum, I cannot be deported. It is also about how we support our Greek colleagues. I'm pretty tired, dear Count Lambsdorff, that we keep crying over our government. I ask the President of the Commission whether he can find 200 of his 30,000 employees who, in consultation with the government, he can send to Greece to provide assistance there if the Member States are not ready. I would help him find it if necessary. One last point: we need pragmatic solutions. The pictures we see of Idomeni are not acceptable. I think that here you sometimes have to act and afterwards delve deeply into the ramifications of the law. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: the question asked when the blue card was raised.- Colleague, I would like to ask about problems in meeting Member States' obligations.Lithuanian officials visited Greek and Italian refugee camps, but almost did not want to go to Lithuania.They were interested in Germany, the Scandinavian countries, but not at all interested in the Baltic countries.Do you think that refugees should be transported by force?

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- You know, I don’t think much of your vocabulary about “compulsory”.It is not about forcibly taking in refugees, but about: When the 28 member states have come together, so to speak, in a European Union, it is not enough to accept the benefits but not want to share the burdens.This applies to your country, it applies to every country - including Germany.We don't always cover ourselves with fame.But we as the European Parliament should remind each other again and again that solidarity is a two-way street.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: - Madam President! At the summit in March, the EU entered into a deal with Turkey under German pressure. Ms. Merkel has tacitly abandoned her policy of welcoming and is now hoping that Turkey will stop the flow of refugees for her. Since then, Germany has experienced a unique interference in the German media world by the Turkish Prime Minister. Instead of defending our values, Ms. Merkel often remains silent and submissive.
