Your own career now depends on Erdoğan's goodwill. You can clearly see where Ms. Merkel's priorities are. It would be better for Europe to take over the protection of the external borders itself. We should send the people of this continent a clear signal that Europe can act on its own and that we uphold our values ​​and not let them degenerate into a bargaining chip. At the same time, taking care of refugees in the region would be easier and cheaper than taking care of us. We should not only make ourselves dependent on Turkey, but also negotiate with Jordan and Lebanon.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Madam President, of course we should negotiate and cooperate with the neighbouring countries, but that is not the same as outsourcing problems. Negotiations take place between two equal powers, but the EU is weak as we are unwilling to solve our own problems, and the Turks realise that. We should have learned from earlier experiences, like in 2010, when we were negotiating a deal with Mr Gaddafi for keeping the refugees there. That was also not a resounding success. I heard Mr Weber speak earlier, saying that there is finally, as he said, ‘Recht und Ordnung’. Well that is not the way I perceive it, because we hear stories about people being pushed back to Syria – refugees – and we have zero answers from the Council or the Member States. It is a disgrace that this continent – the richest, most prosperous and freest continent in the world – is tolerating this, and that we are not able to give our own response to the situation. Finally, we talk a lot these days about our own values, about how immigrants need to embrace our values. Let us uphold our own values and make sure that refugees live in acceptable conditions and not in this misery anymore.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: - Madam President, Mr Weber, finally stop doing injustice and insulting both Greece and the truth. Mr Erdoğan imprisons journalists, closes newspapers, does not even implement the agreement, but you caress him and accuse Tsipras. Mr Orbán, the far right, does not accept a single refugee in Hungary, but you caress him because he is in your group, and of course you denounce Tsipras again, you may even see him in your sleep. The Greek people are proud, with a great history and offer and do not tolerate these insults of every Mr. Weber. Mr Tusk and Mr Juncker, you know very well that you have borne the brunt of your own failure to implement the September relocation decisions on the shoulders of one Member State, Greece, while embellishing Turkey. My country, Greece, bears a huge burden because of the war, the geography, but also the European failure and the Greek people need more help and solidarity, not to be used as a scapegoat or as a punching bag.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: - If you lock people up, they can no longer take care of themselves. When you lock people up, you have to take care of them. You have to give them enough to eat, you have to make sure the sick get help, you have to make sure that the children are protected. But what have 28 prime ministers done? They have concluded a Turkey deal and have forgotten the implementation. And in the meantime we lock up refugees on Greek islands with insufficient food, children between adults in total overflowing camps where there is not enough food and there are no doctors and no lawyers! If the prime ministers put on the big pants to make a deal, they will still have to put on the big pants to arrange the implementation and not look to the European Commission to implement it. Then they must also have an answer to democratic control. Is it the Greek Parliament that has to supervise the detention centers in Greece or can we do something about it? What happens to a 14-year-old girl without food in a detention center with adult men? Mr Tusk, what happens to such a 14-year-old girl? [The speaker addressed a "blue card" question under Rule 162 (8).]

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: blue card question.- The Greens have been very critical of the agreement between Turkey and the EU.It’s not perfect, but I haven’t heard from you about an alternative model.What should the EU do?I hope that you will have a three-point list of what the EU and the EU Member States must do to ensure that everything goes well and fairly.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: blue-card answer. – I have a one-point plan, which is large-scale resettlement from third countries, giving people legal access to the European Union. But as you heard, my critique was not about what Erdoğan does or what Turkey does, but what we are not doing, what we are leaving behind: that is, taking care of vulnerable people in detention centres.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: - Almost a month has passed since the European Council meeting, it seems like too short a timeframe to summarize the results, but it is enough to assess the trends. Under the agreement between the European Union and Turkey, several hundred returned illegal migrants and several Syrian war refugees legally arriving in the European Union from Turkey. Riots on the Greek-Macedonian border, a Czech principled provision against any quotas for the distribution of migrants. The trends are not good, and even if we have succeeded in at least partially limiting the scale of the problem, the problem itself is largely unresolved. Much more decisive solutions are needed. The European Union's external borders must be closed. There must be no illegal movement of migrants between the internal borders of the European Union and quotas must be abolished as an unsuccessful solution. In order to prevent the problems caused by illegal migration in Europe from becoming a catalyst for economic problems, I call for greater attention to be paid to the European Commission President Juncker's plan and for the European institutions and Member States to take concrete decisions on its implementation much more quickly. what we need most in this situation. And despite the fact that the Commission's intention to give Member States more flexibility on VAT rates is not part of this plan, I welcome this proposal, as boosting consumption can be one of the effective measures against the economic slowdown.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, yet another debate, yet another demonstration that Europe does not exist, the Europe that was built on the wrong currency is dying of immigration. Someone would like to import a few million new slaves. In this building we talk about human rights around the world and agreements are made with Turkey, to which we are giving ten billion euros. Turkey denying the genocide of one and a half million Armenians that occurred a century ago. Turkey which militarily occupies a part of a sovereign state of this palace. Someone would like Turkey to enter Europe, forcing history, culture and geography, someone would even like the Turkish language to be recognized as an official language of the European Union, folly upon folly. Meanwhile, 24,000 illegal immigrants landed in Italy in the first months of the year, double that of last year, and of these refugees are less than 5%. So we are happy to leave you this Europe. If this is the Europe you think of, I prefer to think of the 20 million unemployed Europeans that no one cares about.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: - Madam President, the European Union-Turkey decision is adding fuel to the competition for the profits of business groups, with the European Union becoming even more involved in the imperialist intervention in Syria. The decision to open another chapter in Turkey's accession to the European Union rewards and legitimizes the growing aggression of the Turkish bourgeoisie in Syria, the Aegean and Cyprus. What solidarity are you talking about with the refugees? With fences, prisons, deportations and unacceptable "ping-pong" refugees? Everything confirms that you are trying to replace the Geneva Convention, that is, what has been left standing by the protection of refugees with inhumane EU mechanisms. Mr. Weber, why are you deliberately confusing political identities and talking about "SYRIZA communists", looking for a "scarecrow"? SYRIZA is the new social democracy in Greece. It supports big business, promotes barbaric anti-labor measures and memoranda, as, after all, do the social democratic and liberal parties. It calls for the implementation of the European Union's unacceptable decisions on refugees, but is also concerned about NATO's effective action in the Aegean. The Communist Party of Greece calls on the people, resolutely, to organize their struggle with a forty-eight-hour strike in the face of the new barbaric measures brought by the SYRIZA-ANEL government that affect both the Greek people and the refugees.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: - Madam President, I remember that, at the end of 2015, President Juncker told us that there was an urgent need to find a solution before the arrival of spring and the coming increase in the migratory flow. This agreement with Turkey at least has the merit of existing, but there is still a lot to do, because Turkey today is in control of the game, and it is playing on the weakness of the European Union. It is enough to be on the ground to already see major dysfunctions and flaws in the asylum procedure in Athens. Greece, in fact, is facing an explosion of asylum requests, with 500,000 migrants and refugees on its territory and, faced with this situation, there is a cruel shortage of personnel on the ground, and the experts promised by Member States are not coming. Let's not be naive - President Erdoğan hasn't given up on raising the ante either. Last Thursday, he was happy to recall that Turkey would not live up to its part of the deal if the European Union did not honor its promises itself, referring to the too quickly promised visa waiver. to Turkish citizens. The flight of certain European leaders from their responsibilities is scandalous. France also shone by its inaction and its lack of involvement, leaving Merkel to negotiate alone with Turkey. This should not make us forget another urgency, that of the battle against unemployment. And there, I allow myself to speak about the steel industry. Make no mistake, it is not a question of protecting a declining industry but, on the contrary, of defending an industry of the future under the influence of completely unfair competition. So we have to act quickly, very quickly, to fight against dumping, with anti-dumping taxes, and put in place really rapid procedures.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: – Madam President, we should recognise that the deal with Turkey is at best a provisional, fragile and controversial solution. What we really need are European instruments to regain control of the situation, of our territory and of our standards, and this means very clear priorities, which are also on the table due to recent Commission proposals. The first one is to ensure that we really provide European asylum according to European standards. The second is that we adapt our cities to avoid ghettos, for reasons of social cohesion but also to prevent security risks. Finally, we need to build up a real European border system. This is not a line, this is not a wall, this is a border network which should enable our system of relocation and resettlement to work properly, managed by European authorities. What is at stake is no less than European sovereignty. We should not be afraid of using these words. This is a powerful concept, and most citizens do understand that we need to move to this new phase of building the means to have sovereignty over our resources, our territory and our standards. I believe this should be envisaged also as a big investment, so let us prepare for this new stage.

name: Jussi HALLA-AHO
text: – Madam President, it says in the Council conclusions that (I quote): ‘several elements of our common European response to the migrant crisis are in place today and are yielding results’. This is a very optimistic statement, as our common measures, such as the relocation scheme, do not work at all. It is rather the unilateral decisions taken by individual Member States that have reduced the flow of migrants, or at least directed it elsewhere. I refer in particular to the re-establishment of internal border controls and the reduction of unhealthy pull factors at national level. I especially welcome the idea of declaring asylum applications from persons arriving from Turkey inadmissible. And I wonder very much why this is not already the case at the internal borders inside the European Union.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Madam President, I must say that I share President Tusk’s comments on the deal with Turkey, including the critical remarks. I would like to ask him how we are monitoring the implementation on the Turkish side. How are we assessing implementation and how do we analyse and draw conclusions? I would appreciate comments on that. President Juncker, I would like to make two remarks. Firstly, on the migration issue, you have – quite rightly – asked for guidance from the political groups. I would say that the Commission’s proposals contain a number of useful and effective elements. I would probably base myself on the ones that can be speedily and effectively implemented and around which we can unite the European Union. I will make one final remark on China. Yes to fair trade and fair competition, but this is not what China represents, neither in steel, packaging nor in other industries. I think that we really need to fine-tune some of our trade instruments much more speedily than we are doing.

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: - Presidents, the agreement between the European Union and Turkey is a black page in the history of the European Union, and it is a shame for those who have co-signed it. The European Union, in order to get rid of a problem for which it is co-responsible, has christened Turkey a safe country, provocatively ignoring that it violates human rights and violates international law. The Geneva Convention has been thrown away. Thousands of appeals have been locked up in Greece, without actually being given the right to asylum in the country they want. FYROM police violate the rights of refugees and use brutal violence. The agreement opened chapters for Turkey's accession to Europe, while at the same time national and sovereign rights of Greece are being challenged - Greek airspace is being violated daily - and complete and gray zones are being created in the Aegean with NATO present. Mr Tusk, your "we did the best we could" turned the European Union leadership into a playwright on the refugee crisis, starring Mr Erdogan.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: - Madam President, Mr President of the Commission, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen! This agreement with Turkey is simply not a solution. What we're doing here isn't just deporting refugees, and Turkey then deporting some of them back to Syria. We are also shifting responsibility, and that is really unworthy of a Europe of values ​​and fundamental rights. We have to take seriously this criticism of this deal, which Amnesty has made, for example. I propose that we set up an ad hoc mission of MPs, civil society experts, to see what is actually going on here. Because just continue like this, that is not possible. We need legal and secure access via resettlement procedures, and above all - and I am addressing all those from the Member States who think: Distribution, no thanks - we have to say: Solidarity is not a one-way street, you too have to take in refugees. But let me also turn to my own home state and the criticism of the Austrian federal government. Not only the bizarre change of office that has taken place here in the last few days at the behest of the Governor of Lower Austria, but also closing the Brenner border again, which has now been open for so long because of the European Union - we actually offend our neighbors in the south. That scorns every European partnership. These borders and also the others must remain open!

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Before I give the floor to our next speaker Mr Lundgren for one minute, can I say that because of time constraints I will no longer be able to accept blue cards. I hope you understand the reasons for that, and indeed we may have problems with ‘catch the eye’ because I am required to finish this session on time.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: - Madam President!A politician's main task is to safeguard the interests of his country.That is why I stand here - not as a European, but as a Swede.That is why I oppose most of the idiocy produced in this House, where you are constantly trying to turn my country into an obedient state under the corrupt and power-mad EU.Now that you have failed to maintain external border protection and economic migrants are flowing into Europe, your panic solution is to bow to Turkey's blackmail.We are talking about a country that violates human rights, and that does not maintain democracy and freedom of expression.This country is now offering you lots of taxpayers' money to solve your failures.You attract with a fast track into the EU to a country that does not even belong to Europe, but Asia.Who do you think you are?You are trying to impose on the whole of Europe a policy that you do not want to know about.

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: Visa-free entry for Turks, accession to the European Union, a few billion euros and a migrant exchange procedure.That's the great deal with Turkey!And this Commission, meanwhile, also accepts genocide of the Kurdish population, oil and arms trade with the IS, the silencing of the opposition, the occupation of Cyprus and - most sad of all - more violence by migrants for the citizens of Europe, moreoppression due to creeping Islamization, more poverty due to the sky-high costs of reception.This Commission has no moral compass.And I say, we are the voice of the people, and we say on behalf of the people, Enough is enough!This bad deal has to be dropped!Stop mass immigration, close national borders and return migrants!

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: - Madam President, it is very easy to be champions of human rights when problems occur on the other side of the Mediterranean, but how difficult when it comes to us. Of course, refugees must follow established procedures, but sometimes it seems that we care more about procedures than people. One year after the refugee crisis broke out, Europe continues to seek solutions that do not exist in real life. Keep letting Germany and Greece do all the work. Europe's enemies are not those who cross our seas in inflatable boats or those who drown off our coast. Europe's enemies are the ones who push the refugees towards our borders and the ones who smile every time we Europeans renounce our principles. Europe's enemies are those who cause terror, not those who flee from terror. I am in favor of the agreement with Turkey, because Turkey is part of the solution. But Turkey is not the solution. Human rights are not a service that we can buy with euros. Either you always believe in them or you never believe in them. And this crisis is not going to end simply because we close the door to poor Syrians and give rich Turks visas, or because we sublet the management of the border in Greece. Calling yourself a Europeanist and supportive has a price: when the time comes, you have to be European and you have to be supportive. And to give lessons, you first have to practice by example, and a good part of Europe lately has not been there to give lessons either in defense of the weakest or in protection of the persecuted. Member States would do well to learn, in this case, from the work of the Commission.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: - Madam President, is the EU-Turkey agreement - or whatever name we give it for that matter - satisfactory? In my opinion, the answer is no. Those who decided on this arrangement, however, spared no efforts to wrap it all in pretty wrapping paper. On paper, we repeat that it is fully compliant with Union law and international law, but on the ground, the implementation raises questions. Questions about the legality of the proposed scheme - I am not the first to say so. The referral mechanism to Turkey is based on the concepts of "first country of asylum" and "safe third country" and, in both cases, the protection which asylum seekers or refugees can availing oneself in this country is not really satisfactory. It is obviously up to the judge to decide all this, but the first assessments, at this stage, tip the scales in the “no” side. Questions about the applicability: the referral mechanism poses a large number of logistical problems in Greece, in particular to guarantee an individual examination, an appeal procedure and a dignified reception of the populations. Here again, the implementation of the agreement does not seem to comply with the guarantees announced on paper. Questions about effectiveness: this plan seeks at all costs to dry up the flow of migrants crossing the Aegean Sea. It's a safe bet that other routes will open up, and there is also an increase in flows from Libya to Italy and Malta, and there are even reports of passages via Ukraine. More and more, this agreement takes on the air of an infernal machine which could get carried away and become uncontrollable and uncontrolled, participating in the unraveling of European values ​​and foundations. These criticisms must be heard. As you have understood, this agreement, this dangerous object, arouses in me not only questions, but also reservations. However, I realize that it also exists because it was not possible to develop an alternative project due to the lack of solidarity on the part of the Member States.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: - The Trojan horse comes from Ankara.The deal with Erdogan barely works.Only a few hundred refugees are now in Europe and only a few hundred have returned to Turkey.In the meantime, the flow of refugees from Italy is growing by the hour!It is also absurd that the Turks have been promised that they can travel visa-free to the European Union and have a concrete view of accession!Just like the Trojan horse back then, Turkey is now creeping into the EU.Incidentally, when it comes to visa-free travel, the Juncker-Timmermans team has lost my confidence.Five days after the Dutch referendum, the Ukrainians have also been promised visa-free travel.How do you come up with that!The Presidency and the Commission need to do their homework better.There must be a comprehensive plan with selection at the gate to help real refugees.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: - Madam President, of course, we must have a dialogue with Turkey, if only to stop the abominable trafficking in criminal smugglers, but this must in no way distract us from our own responsibilities.Europe cannot delegate its right of asylum to the countries which surround it.On the contrary, it must assume its right to asylum, harmonize it, finally reform Dublin and manage legal and secure access routes for Syrian refugees, as Canada has done recently, for example.Likewise, Europe cannot delegate the management of its own borders.On the contrary, it must set up a body of border and coast guards, and systematize control at its external borders, including for its nationals.Finally, Europe cannot delegate its ability to influence the settlement of the Syrian conflict.On the contrary, it must exist much more and, here too, fully exercise its responsibility, finally.

name: Martina MICHELS
text: - Madam President, gentlemen Presidents! 27 governments are calling on Greece to pretend Turkey is a safe third country. 27 heads of state look the other way when doctors in Idomeni take care of people who have been hit by rubber bullets from Macedonia. That's the result of the deal we're talking about today. Despite all the solidarity shown by Greeks and activists from all over Europe, the life situation of asylum seekers in Greece has been assessed in judgments of the ECJ as a violation of Article 3 of the European Convention on Human Rights. After the Eurogroup, the EU-Turkey deal has now cemented this instead of creating a framework for re-enacting the Geneva Refugee Convention. The Commission and the Council must examine this policy failure and change it instead of robbing Europe of history, soul and future. The EU-Turkey agreement is not a solution, but part of the problem, also in order to find lasting peaceful solutions for Syria and the Kurdish question.

name: Peter ERIKSSON
text: - Madam President!In my mother tongue, Swedish, we have a saying that "no matter how you turn, you have the back end".When we now see the Council's and the Commission's strategy of resolving the refugee crisis by stopping the flow of refugees and concluding agreements with Turkey, then the flow of refugees will change instead, and what looks to be the next step is Libya.Then we are back, my dear friends, to the debts and crises that Europe has helped to create in Libya, which is not a functioning country.So what is the Commission's and the Council's plan to make Libya work?How can we have a functioning country that can take responsibility for its people and the people who come there?The strategy of closing the border with Turkey and sending people back can not just be about that route.In that case, you must also take greater responsibility for other roads and routes for people who want to come here.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: – Madam President, last week Frontex guards dressed up like paramilitary forces and deported 200 migrants from Greece: clearly a staged show of force to pretend the EU-Turkey blackmail deal is a success. The same day as 200 migrants were deported, another 300 entered Greece. Do you really believe the people are being fooled so easily? The truth is that since the blackmail deal, another 5 000 migrants have been smuggled into Greece. We had a million migrants enter the EU last year alone. How are you going to hold back the next tsunami of migrants? We have to take back control of our own borders. It is truly worrying to see the UK border forces committing to this farce. Our own border force is understaffed and underfunded. Other countries have hundreds of patrol boats; the UK’s coastguard has a mere five, two of which were sent to the Mediterranean. This is a symbolic gesture but has left the UK’s borders open and vulnerable. The money – the British taxpayers’ money – given over to Turkey for this blackmail deal could have bought 80 Border Force cutters to keep my country safe. We cannot let this happen. We have handed our keys over to the EU, so therefore we must Brexit.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are focusing on the EU-Turkey agreement, right, for heaven's sake, but we are talking about something that could have the best effect of closing a route, but we know that the routes move and I , as an Italian, I must say that I am very worried because Italians are in the front row in this sense. There are already signs, new directions are opening up that point straight towards Italy. In Albania the police have already identified many rubber boats ready to leave, as well as other possible and possible routes from Greece and Turkey, and then there is the other front, the Mediterranean, the one that worries even more. Between 15 and 19 March alone, 4 000 refugees were rescued in the Mediterranean. There are data provided by German intelligence which say that there are 200 000 people on the Libyan coast ready to leave for Italy, but the High Representative even speaks of 450 000 people ready to leave Libya for Italy. There is another thing that worries us, in May the suspension period that has allowed many European countries to reintroduce border controls will expire and if these are extended, the suspension will last another two years as a maximum limit and we will have the tragic scenario of a Europe that is closing in on southern Europe. Gentlemen, I am appealing to you, because if the migratory problem is not addressed as a whole, you will see that Europe will be shipwrecked in the Mediterranean.

name: Kati PIRI
text: - Turkey and the EU need each other to deal with the refugee crisis in a humane way. For years we thought that the crisis in Syria did not affect us and we did not care much about the fate of the Syrians who fled en masse to neighboring countries. This only changed when more than a million asylum seekers came to the EU last year. The way in which we have dealt with the influx of this vulnerable group of people to date does not deserve a beauty prize. Only a small number of European countries are now hosting the refugees. There is no question of shared solidarity. The agreements with Turkey are far from perfect and require further elaboration. But the alternative is for countries to continue raising the fences and strengthening the barbed wire while people continue to drown at sea. That's not my Europe! So it is our duty to make this agreement work and defend our values. Cooperation with Turkey must comply with European and international law. Amnesty's report on pushing refugees from Turkey back to Syria is alarming. It is now up to the European Commission to ensure that we have clear guarantees that this practice will end and until then Syrians cannot be returned to Turkey. But it is also important for the European government leaders to speed up and fulfill their commitments: taking refugees from Greece and offering large-scale legal and safe routes for the most vulnerable refugees who are still in Turkey.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: - All the steps taken by the European Union, whether the agreement with Turkey or the common asylum policy, automatically provide for the redistribution of migrants throughout Europe.At the same time, the will of the citizens is completely ignored.The European Commission refuses to acknowledge that citizens do not want to accept millions of migrants to Europe.Then European political elites are only very surprised that more and more citizens are rejecting the European Union and electing extremists.Yes, let's help the war refugees, but let's help them there, we don't have to move them together and we have to protect our own borders.No other country or Turkey will take on this role for us.If a Schengen member country is unable or unwilling to protect the common borders, it must leave Schengen, whether Greece or Italy, and we will protect the newly created Schengen border - after all, this is just beginning to happen at Brenner.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: - Madam President, why is Turkey going to do well what we have not done well?Our policy has forced those who flee to risk their lives to seek asylum.Our policy has de facto promoted the growth of the mafias, Mr. Tusk.Canadians have not.In their consulates and embassies they have promoted safe asylum and transit.After a year of ineffectiveness, the Council has decided, without self-criticism, that Greece comply with the Dublin Regulation.But in a police way.And we have invented the expulsion paid to Turkey to get the human rights problem out of our sight.The big problem - relocation and despair - has not changed.They will continue to come, but now without hope, and those who survive will not forget our mistreatment in a globalized world.This is a time bomb for us, Mr. Tusk.And by the way, populism will not decrease if we do not believe what we say.

name: Stefan ECK
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! It is a sad and hopeless time for our Europe, which tolerates the dismantling of democracy and the rule of law in Turkey in order to secure its own borders and completely forgets that the EU should be a community of values, a guarantor of democracy and humanity. How can we still be proud of our Europe today? Turkey is clearly violating the Geneva Refugee Convention. Nevertheless, the EU ignores this fact, despite many warnings from human rights organizations and the United Nations. She is still sticking to her agreement, a dirty human trafficking, a deal bought with silence for Turkish arbitrary politics. As an enthusiastic European and as a Member of this Parliament, I am now ashamed of our total failure. We need a different policy! Above all, we need a human policy, a politically correct policy. Otherwise we will betray the European idea.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the agreement with Turkey has a very dubious legal value and it is incredible that this majority so attentive to human rights entrusts a country like Turkey with the task of carrying out a mass deportation of refugee populations . An expensive, useless operation that is a bluff, the Turks themselves have in fact declared that they will not become the refugee reception center of Europe, it will essentially only make the defense of the borders of Germany pay dearly and in fact it is Germany which in these banks defends this agreement through its representatives. It is easy to foresee the criteria that will preside over the management of the Turkish brand, Erdogan brand of the refugees, while three hundred, who say four hundred thousand refugees threaten to invade Italy and it is no coincidence that Turkey prudently bars its borders. We are blackmailed by a bad guy like Erdogan, a few days have passed and Turkey is already threatening to suspend the agreement - and Amnesty's protests - Erdogan, who is an Islamist extremist, wants the invasion of Europe: never, never, never! Never, the invasion of Europe by the Turks, by the Muslims: never, never, never!

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Can I just inform the House at this point that I did indicate there would be problems with ‘catch the eye’, and unfortunately we are not able to take any of the requests because many people want to speak in this debate. I would, however, invite you to submit your written speeches and I do apologise in advance because of time problems.

name: Elmar BROK
text: - Madam President, Mr President of the European Council, Commissioner! I would like to thank you, Mr President, and also the Commission, for reaching this agreement. If we want fewer migrants to come to Europe and only those who are entitled to come to Europe, if we want traffickers to be pushed back and people no longer have to go into the sea and drown there, then there has to be this deal. It is important that we remember that Turkey - like Lebanon and Jordan - has taken in millions of people in the past three or four years - far more than we have taken - and that these countries are legitimate that the refugees receive better care there, that they ensure that children get school lessons. That is what European money is for, and that is what humanity is being seen in it. If we take action against the smugglers' gangs, then we have to take action on the Turkish and Libyan borders. Once people are out to sea, the only thing left is to save them. That means that external controls cannot work at the sea borders, on our coasts, then people are already at sea. That is a double standard that is being put forward here just because you do not want the deal with Turkey. And we have to see that the opposite is the barbed wire Europe, in which we fence every country with barbed wire. I don't want that! I don't want us to hand this over to our children as a future Europe. That's why we have to talk to our neighbors. That does not mean that we in Turkey accept the loss of human rights, the denial of freedom of expression and so on. No, Turkey does not get a discount for membership in the European Union! We will defend human rights! Turkey must meet all the conditions!

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: - Madam President!The Member States' agreement with Turkey is not the right answer to the refugee situation.Yes, we need cooperation with third countries, including Turkey.But the member states cannot expect Turkey to make up for the lack of solidarity within Europe.What is happening now?Turkey is building a massive wall on the border with Syria, and only Syrian refugees are given any protection status.A legally viable agreement with Turkey could complement a common intra-European strategy.But this is missing.There is neither a distribution of refugees across all Member States, nor a real European resettlement program, nor are all states willing to support those countries that take in refugees.Member States and Turkey - both need to follow up on the refugee issue.

name: Vicky FORD
text: – Madam President, on steel: this is a key strategic sector, jobs are on the line and urgent actions are needed. We must also be sensitive to the impact on other sectors. Anti-dumping measures are vital, and we stand ready in the ECR and in the UK to make them effective. On migration there is no easy solution. The Turkey deal is not perfect, but it may help. Those in the Schengen zone especially need long-term plans to break the link abused by people-traffickers and to have proper border management systems. But the EU cannot afford to throw endless money or dangle promises of visa-free travel to third countries as some sort of reward for cooperation. The UK is not in the Schengen zone, and people should stop scaremongering the people of Britain about the impact of the negotiations with Turkey. Migrants are not criminals, but chaos on borders can be exploited by terrorists. We live in an international world and we are stronger when we work together against crime.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: - Madam President, We’re part of another emotionally stirring debate, I don’t know how many times. If a voter were to ask me how many times we are discussing this question, I would not be able to answer him. Are we successful? I ask the question. In part ... We are talking about a delicate compromise that was reached at the right time. Of course, better decisions could always be made, but under the circumstances, the right decision has been made that the Western Balkans route cannot be operated without control. The right decision has also been made to close the route of human traffickers. And the right decision has also been made to restore order and control at the borders. The decision was made for the safety of 500 million European Union citizens. Yes, the burden on Greece has continued to increase, so it is right that we help to solve the burdens and bear the burdens. Let’s look at this compromise: the agreement is not perfect, of course. The Turks may not be willing and able to abide by the agreement. That is why we need to check, we need to keep checking. President Erdogan had an interesting statement about whether they could actually abide by this agreement. But let's look to the future! And the future is about hotspots not working, about the need to reform the registration system, about the inadequacy of the education system, the lack of good health care. This is a question of the future of Europe.

name: Claude MORAES
text: – Mr President, I share many of the human rights concerns expressed in the House, but let us be very honest in this House today: this deal is predicated on solidarity. My first question to the Council President is very simple. We in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE), which I chair, interviewed the Commission President’s trouble-shooter, Maarten Verwey, and he reported to us very honestly. He said there were 30 asylum processors in the camps. This is a very backbreaking task that the Commission has, and I respect the men and women of the Commission for the task that they have to do. But I say to the Council President, in respect of the speech that he gave earlier, with all the human rights concerns and all the other organisational concerns: is he going to assure us today that the Member States ultimately will supply the resources that we need to make this work and that all of these safeguards will be in place? The devil is in the detail to make this work, and respect for human rights needs to be ensured.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: – Madam President, firstly let me say that, in spite of all the concerns, I appreciate the progress being made in dealing with the migration crisis in Greece. Let me thank all those involved from the Council and the Commission. The speed of the results shows how much time was lost last year, as President Tusk mentioned. Now we should look to the future, make sure that the promising results in Greece continue and focus on other problem areas in the migration crisis. I have in mind Italy, in particular, and other parts of the Mediterranean. We must find a similar solution that will function well. It will be more difficult than in Greece, but the Greek case shows that it is possible. Let me now say a few words on the economy. Just a few days ago I mentioned that it seemed to me that political problems are now larger than economic ones. This is true, and it is not necessarily good news. But let me say that in economic policy we must keep going in the same direction. The government must follow the principles agreed and must implement reform and improve the fiscal situation. On the EU, we have an extensive agenda, including reforms in the tax area and dealing with the future relationship with China. Resolving this issue is very important for our future, and I hope we will take it very seriously.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: - Madam President, in this debate there have been plenty of complacent words that some have used speaking of success when referring to the agreement with Turkey. Mr. Tusk says that first order has had to be put into the house itself, when what he should have done is recognize the evident failure of the management of the migratory crisis in recent months. Failure that he has forced to reach an agreement that has already been questioned by a large part of the humanitarian organizations and that in its first days of application has already demonstrated its ineffectiveness. Meanwhile, public opinion speaks of the shame of Europe and national leaders rub their hands, because to speak of the shame of Europe is to hide, it is to cover up their own ineffectiveness and their own inability to fulfill the commitments and obligations they had to carry out. To give an example, in Spain, only eighteen refugees have been welcomed by Mr. Rajoy's government. Eighteen. Do we really believe that this incompetence is acceptable when we are talking about the lives of hundreds of thousands of people fleeing war and death? We urgently need countries to fulfill their obligations, to apply the principle of solidarity. The Europe project is in jeopardy. Let's not write the last page of our history with the suffering of people.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: - Madam President, Mr President of the Council, Commissioner, what I wanted to make clear here is that we must be on the side of human rights in this refugee crisis. And to be on the side of human rights is, of course, to solve the problem of refugees, namely welcoming in the European Union ... The European Union must show this face of solidarity, this is absolutely essential. And, therefore, I understand that this agreement with Turkey is just ... it is not a good agreement, it is the possible agreement, and it is just a way to buy time to solve this problem more effectively. And then I must say that, just as I criticize, also in this Parliament and with all legitimacy, the Portuguese Government for its economic, financial, budgetary and fiscal policy, which is deplorable and which is leading the country to a terrible situation, I also praise the Portuguese Government for its policy in the area of ​​refugees. We, Portugal, have already shown that we are not only willing to receive the initial 4 000, but we can reach the figure of 10 000 refugees. And we are in a position to receive 1 250 already, the Prime Minister announced this week. I think that here Portugal, Portuguese civil society and the Portuguese Government are setting a good example. I would like other states to follow our example, and I believe that it would be easier to resolve this crisis there.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: - Madam President! It is important that this last opportunity summit produced a result because, firstly, there is no alternative to cooperation with neighboring Turkey - although it is complicated and not without risks - and secondly, Schengen can only work if the external border controls work. The steps are right. They should have happened earlier, and you have to watch closely that everything goes as planned. There are serious doubts. Firstly, the implementation is patchy - there are not enough staff - and secondly, the concerns of human rights organizations must be taken seriously as to whether human rights are actually being respected and whether these are just isolated cases or systematic violations. We should also be aware that these are just first steps and that we need a big solution. This great solution means that we must finally make aid in the countries of origin a priority and that we need humanitarian entry corridors.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! Many legitimate concerns have been expressed. But I ask myself: how would today's debate go if there had been no EU-Turkey agreement, if the Commission had not put a proposal for a common foreign policy on the table, if the Commission's strategy for growth and jobs had not been approved received from the Council? With increasing nationalism, selfishness and the lack of solidarity within the European Union, more barbed wires would have been used, more borders would have been cordoned off and people would have spoken of fortress Europe. Nobody can want that from us. Those who oppose the agreement cause even more suffering, risk even more fences and the real end of Schengen. We don't want the burner to close. We want the Brenners to remain open in Europe. Ladies and gentlemen, the agreement will only work if we comply with international and European law, if we guarantee compliance with human rights, if we assume our responsibility in all Member States, if we understand that the Turkey deal does not really solve the problem solves. Idomeni is an example of this. We also need solutions within the European Union. Unfortunately, the Council did not find these solutions.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this agreement was born out of a state of necessity, because we were in the throes of some countries' refusal to do their part, and it is therefore very ambiguous and insidious. We therefore ask for double vigilance, to control all implementation and management in both Greece and Turkey. Europe must be responsible, we cannot wash our hands like this, it's up to Greece, it's up to Turkey, it's up to us. On 8 March we dedicated it to refugee women. Let's talk about the children, well, I ask what about all these commitments? News of exploitation and degradation arrives from the camp, I think this is unacceptable and that there is a specific European responsibility, moral before political and institutional. We are talking, and we want the possibility of European-managed hot spots to arise because I think that we alone, directly responsible, could truly monitor respect for human rights. And finally, one flaw closes and others open. It was mentioned here that Italy already collects a thousand people at sea on certain days. Here, I ask that also for Italy and Malta, we are already preparing to work in the sign of solidarity and collaboration.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Madam President, Mr. Tusk, Commissioner, it is precisely this debate today and the agreement with Turkey that justifies the thesis that politics is the art of the possible. The fact is that this agreement is not perfect, that this agreement is not ideal, as you yourself said, but it is already a concrete step because, as my colleague Karas said, we would talk today if it were not for this agreement. So we know that Turkey is not the only solution, we know about the problems with Turkey. We are free to ask whether Turkey is a reliable partner. We know about problems with the media, problems with minorities. However, we obviously had to take some initiative and I agree to continue with this. Of course, initially there is not enough capacity, there are not enough officers on the border between Greece and Turkey, which is evident from today's figures. However, I believe that we must be in solidarity. From the beginning we say that our two main theses are solidarity, but also responsibility. I believe that it is our responsibility to offer a solution. The Balkan route is closed, which is also a good move. However, a route across the Mediterranean opens up. It is not good to build wires. No wire can be built at sea, so we have to look for a solution. I agree that we continue in this way, but of course the solution is not only in Turkey, we must continue. I have only one question for Mr. Tusk. However, the question arises as to how we intend to control the implementation of this agreement and the implementation of the use of these three plus three or six billion euros?

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: - Madam President, you see, Mr Tusk, Mr President of the Council, the Agreement that we have signed with Turkey means the resignation en bloc of the responsibilities that European governments have.It is a resignation of our legal, political and ethical obligations: of the three we have resigned.We are in favor of agreements with third countries, but we are not in favor of abandoning our obligations, and in recent months we have been building, by closing borders, an inhumane mousetrap for refugees, and we have done nothing.We have allowed the situation to rot to the point of having to outsource without any control an obligation that European citizens would like governments to be able to fulfill.And since I have so little time, I want to expressly refer to the children, whom we are not protecting, those who need the most protection.And do you know what's up, Mr. Tusk?That this is illegal.

name: Manolis KEFALOGIANNIS
text: - Madam President, not having an agreement on 18 March would be a very worrying development. But the positives stop here. The EU-Turkey agreement is complex, complex, alarmingly vague. The EU-Turkey agreement turned an international European issue into a bilateral issue between Greece and Turkey. The European borders have been moved to the northern borders of Greece, in Eidomeni, the Greek borders are closed. Turkey receives three plus three billion euros. It has not fought the traffickers' circuits, it has not imposed an entry visa on the citizens of the North African states who travel to Turkey for 30 euros and then cross the Greek border and the European Union without a visa. It has not adopted the framework for asylum as defined by the European directives. Greece remains trapped with 53,000 refugees, the relocation of refugees to other countries is problematic and, unfortunately, the only solution is European integration, the European Coast Guard, the enlargement and deepening of our democratic institutions. Europe shows weakness when countries like Lebanon and Jordan can receive three million refugees, Turkey the same, and Europe can not handle one million refugees with the dignity it deserves.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: - Madam President, this debate brings to the fore one of the biggest problems of the European Union, that we agree on things that do not apply. This has become a tradition with Turkey. And it has become a tradition, because we go back at least twenty years. Turkey does not apply everything that has been agreed and endorsed with the European Union and concerns issues of basic rules of law within Turkey itself, but also in particular, in relation to the Member State of the Republic of Cyprus. So, dear Mr Tusk, when we say that we can not sacrifice Cyprus, when I hear Mr Brok say 'we will continue to condemn human rights abuses in Turkey', these are words. When will we decide to leave Erdoğan and protect the principles and rules of law of the European Union itself? That is the question.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: - Madam President, dear President-in-Office of the Council, dear Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! Getting the refugee crisis under control is one of the greatest challenges we face in the EU. The Turkey deal is an important milestone - not the only one, but a very important one - towards solving this task. Because the deal helps to combat inhumane human smuggling and irregular migration, it helps us to get back to orderly procedures, it helps that the European external border is protected. In this respect, I support this deal. What is problematic, of course, is the consideration that Turkey was promised. I'm not talking about the six billion euros that have been pledged. I think this is money well invested. The question of opening further chapters rests in the hands of the Council. We in Parliament have no opinion to give. We have to decide one day about Turkey's accession, and that's where my party's position is known, too, that we are in favor of a privileged partnership, but not for full membership. But that's not on now. And with regard to visa exemptions, all I can say is that we will be discussing this intensively in Parliament. I see that very critically.

name: Sergei STANISHEV
text: - Madam President, colleagues, there have been many interpretations of the agreement with the Republic of Turkey in recent weeks, which have gone to extremes, in that the European Union has capitulated, sold its soul, outsourced the refugee problem. You need to know a few things in principle. The agreement with Turkey was necessary and useful, in part because of the European Union's own weakness and inability to implement even the decisions already taken. The devil is now in the details and in the implementation of this agreement, including the financial part, because we have a duty to help refugees where they are most and where they are closest to Syria, including Turkey, Lebanon and Jordan. Secondly, we will not allow trade in human rights, freedom of the media, democracy. Thirdly and most importantly, this agreement gives the European Union a breath of fresh air to organize its own unified refugee policy, but if we do not do this, no agreement will help us.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I must say that I have some sympathy and indeed admiration for Presidents Tusk and Juncker in their efforts to deal with this unprecedented crisis, and I think they are showing both leadership and courage in trying to find solutions when all around them are criticising them. While it might be unpalatable from the humanitarian point of view to see migrants returned, it is necessary if we are to control external borders and bring order to a sea of chaos. We have to do the same everywhere. If everybody could walk into this Parliament and speak when they felt like it, then we would have chaos. It is the same with the migratory flows. President Juncker also made a very important point regarding the EUR 6 billion for Turkey. He said it is not going to Turkey, it is going to the refugees for their food, shelter, education, and this point has been completely lost in the media. Finally, as an add-on, he was able to say that with 22 million people unemployed in Europe, we need to start working to help them as well.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: - Mr President of the Council, Commissioner, the Council approved, through the agreement with Turkey, and also by reaffirming the priorities of the common security and defense policy, an emergency solution to mitigate the refugee crisis. But it also approved the relaunch of investment, the continuation of structural policies and the application of responsible fiscal policies. In June, it also undertook to give a new impetus to the single market, the digital single market and also the union of capital markets. So, Mr President, there is only one question that makes sense: what do the Member States expect to start implementing what they themselves have approved? Enough of words. We need good examples. Portugal is not waiting, it is doing. You are receiving twice as many refugees as you have been asked. It is promoting a national reform plan to address its potential, growth problems. It is action that we need, it is good examples that multiply.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: –  Madam President, two  conclusions about those who would like to split the European Union and fragment Europe. The migration challenge is a long-term challenge, and we can have different views on how to deal with it. We can be critical of different solutions, maybe because no solution will be perfect anyway. But what is very clear is that if we do not do it together, we will not be able to do it at all. And that would be a moral shame against all those people who are fleeing from brutality and atrocities. That shame would be a boon to those who want us to split and fragment and not to be able to live up to our responsibility. Second, Ukraine: if we turn our back on Ukraine, we are creating an opening for the forces of darkness undermining European stability. This is a message to the Council and the Commission: remain behind Ukraine, give them support and ensure that we can stand up as a united Europe.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: - Madam President, a month ago, in the debate on the forthcoming agreement, we warned you of the legal loopholes. But you gave Mr Erdogan the opportunity to blackmail and demand more and more in return for taking it for granted. If, indeed, Turkey is such a safe country, why don't we ask Mr. Bernemann, who bothered Mr. Erdogan so much about his poem, to recite it in Ankara, or in Istanbul? Today, three weeks after the implementation of the implementation, let us be honest: the flows have decreased, not because the agreement itself has worked, but because the northern borders of Greece have been closed. Some are comfortable with the situation, as refugees no longer reach the borders their. That is why they pretend not to see that Greece has been transformed into a storehouse of souls, with images in Eidomeni and Piraeus that do not honor European values. So if we want to represent the vision of a united Europe, the vision of solidarity, we must impose the process of relocation. And if some do not want to implement, because they have learned to take from Europe what suits them, or because they use ethno-populism as a weapon of internal consumption, then they should have the appropriate sanctions with cuts in the Structural Funds.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: - Madam President, on the issue of the agreement between the European Union and Turkey, everything has been said. So I would like to address two other conclusions of the European Council. The first is that which says that in June, at the European Council of June 28, the question of the completion of Economic and Monetary Union will have to be on the agenda. This discussion needs to be prepared, and I hope that whatever the outcome of the UK referendum, for which we want a 'yes' from the British people to the deal that has been reached, we will be in a position to immediately put on the table the question of the completion of Economic and Monetary Union. This case is long overdue. However, there is an urgent need to consolidate this base of the Union. Then, with regard to the situation of the steel industry, fortunately, the heads of state and government sounded the alarm bells. There is global overcapacity which is undermining the very foundations of a steel industry in Europe. At Council level, the Dutch Presidency must take determined action so that, in terms of trade defense, and in relation to the Commission communication, the answers are provided, those expected by Europeans.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, I am in favour of a constructive relationship with Turkey, but the current one clearly resembles bullying and extortion on the part of Turkish President Erdoğan, with the threat of overloading Europe with refugees in the event of non-compliance. The same applies to threats of sabotaging the whole migration deal should Turkey not get visa-free travel. I wholeheartedly acknowledge the fact that Turkey currently houses and provides for more than 2.5 million refugees and may require assistance. However, the current actions of the Turkish leadership, in relations with the EU and a majority of its members, cannot go unnoticed. In particular, there are serious indications that Turkey played a major role in enabling Jihadist groups, such as Daesh and the Al-Nusra Front in Syria. This support has contributed to the current refugee crisis. That being said, I urge European leaders to promote the interests of European states and Europeans by keeping true to our values.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all I would like to express my thanks for your meaningful contributions, many of which are very much in line with the Commission’s thinking and objectives. Let me clarify some points. Our relationship with Turkey is not about antagonism in terms of power dynamics. It is about an agreement to address an issue in a joint way. Both Europe and Turkey are under great pressure. We are confronted with the same challenges and an unprecedented situation. Cooperation is necessary. It is true that Turkey considers this cooperation to be a catalyst to reenergise our relations as well as its European perspective. This new chapter in EU-Turkey relations is not interpreted as a concession on our basic principles and values of European democracy. On the contrary, it is an opportunity for Turkey to come closer to European standards on all issues: democratic values, rule of law, freedom of expression, respect for minority rights, and resolution of the Cyprus issue. It is in Europe’s interest to have a democratic and stable Turkey as a neighbour, and it is in the interest of Turkey to have the European Union as a stable supporter and partner.   The refugee crisis brought us closer in a spirit of mutual understanding. It needs to be proved whether we mean what we say and what we agree. We are monitoring to ensure that every single aspect of this agreement happens in full accordance with European Union and international law. I do not have any doubt about it, and we persist on that. For example, the Turkish authorities have passed legislation to ensure protection for Syrians. We told them very explicitly that guarantees are needed for all those who are in need of protection, whether they are Syrians or non-Syrians. On visa liberalisation, 35 out of the 72 requirements are fulfilled, but the Commission has been crystal clear: we can only make a proposal to lift visa requirements if all benchmarks are met. Turkey knows this, and it is making efforts to further accelerate the fulfilment of the benchmarks so that we can lift the visa requirements by June 2016. The deal has only started being implemented, with just over 300 people who had not applied for asylum being returned and 74 Syrians resettled directly from Turkey so far. This is only the start. Next week the Commission will formally report on the state of play of implementation of all elements of this agreement. Let me say this: this agreement is an important step for a long-term renewed relationship. A common goal is also to come closer to one another when it comes to values, as I stressed at the beginning of my remarks. In the meantime, the Commission is heavily involved in the situation on the ground in Greece. We are doing everything to support Greece in expanding reception capacities and in making sure that vulnerable applicants, such as women and children, are being treated appropriately. Our people are there, deployed all around the Greek islands, as well as on the Greek mainland, providing our help to the Greek Government and the Greek authorities. Member States need to continue relocating massively from Greece, and I fully agree with what was said in this House today, that all Member States must take their share of their responsibilities. Of the more than 50 000 people stuck in Greece, at least 70% are eligible for relocation. This is important for those who were stranded in Idomeni and Pireus before 20 March. Let us also look at other routes. The arrivals from Libya to Italy show that as long as there is instability, as long as there are smugglers taking advantage of this situation, people will continue to migrate. It is as simple as that. So we have to keep working on the bigger picture. This means continuing our political efforts to bring back stability to Syria and Libya. This also means turning into reality our proposal for a European Border and Coast Guard. We are very happy that this House has presented a draft report and has a timetable which reflects our commitments. We have no time to lose here – indeed, summer is already here. This also means enhancing legal pathways so that people do not have to resort to irregular arrangements. I would like to thank those Members of this House who have raised this and who support our view. Stepping up our efforts on resettlement is an essential part of the solution, primarily from Turkey now but also from Lebanon and Jordan, which are hosting hundreds and thousands of refugees. I have said this before: if we genuinely want to close the irregular backdoor, we have to open a safe and legal window. Fortress Europe is neither desirable nor feasible, simply because as long as people have reasons to flee, they will continue to do so, and they will continue to try to come to Europe. And not only is it our moral and legal responsibility to offer a safe haven for those in need, we also need to make our policies and our approach future-proof. Resettlement is the way forward to ensure orderly, legal and controlled admission from third countries for those who are in need of protection. Some of you also mentioned Dublin. We do not want a cosmetic reform. The President was very clear today on that. We need to reform and improve Dublin to ensure that solidarity and a fair sharing of responsibility is engrained in the new system, because the current one is simply not sustainable. We all know that there is no easy solution to the challenge we face, but one thing is sure: we have to work together and not against each other. This is valid for the European Union institutions, the Member States and also our relations with our neighbours.

name: Donald Tusk
text: President of the European Council. – Madam President, there are several aspects of our debate to which I would like to refer. Firstly, regarding relocation: this is – and will be – one of the key elements of the European solution to the crisis. In this aspect, of course, we need solidarity. I have no doubt about that. But we would be making a mistake if it became the main tool of our policy, because it would be a simple incentive for further, even greater, migration flows, something like an encouragement for possible new migrants. This is why I think we have to be very cautious, especially when it comes to communication with the outside world. In the debate, Mr Kamall and Mr Verhofstadt referred to statistics on irregular migration in the context of the Mediterranean route. I am always very cautious when it comes to statistics. I have some reason to be cautious, but today it is indeed worth considering them. First, concerning the Balkan route, it is true that 150 000 irregular migrants have arrived in Europe since the beginning of this year, but the numbers are falling, month after month, from close to 70 000 in January, to 50 000 in February, to 30 000 in March, and to about 1 000 in April. Just imagine if only in the month of January, in the middle of winter, there were 70 000 migrants, how many of them would have come in April if we had not taken action? Second, it is also true that since the start of this year, 20 000 irregular migrants have come to Europe via the central Mediterranean route and that the numbers are growing. But no Syrians are among them. They are nationals of Africa and countries such as Nigeria, Somalia, Gambia, the Republic of Guinea and Ivory Coast. What does this mean in fact? If we had not closed the Western Balkans route, we would now have three or five times more migrants – those from Africa coming to us through Libya, as well as those who have now been stopped at the border or discouraged from crossing the border. Many have said today that our priority should be to set up the European Coast Guard. I am in favour, even if this Coast Guard will not be operational this year. That is obviously impossible. But we must ask ourselves the question: what exactly should the EU Coast Guard do? Let all through who want to enter Europe, or stop and control them? I think it is obvious – not only for me – that they should stop and control them, which means in fact the same very controversial action that we are applying right now. In the first place we must expect national coastguards to enforce our law on European borders. The European coastguards should support those who need help but cannot replace them.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. I wish to inform the House that before we move to the formal sitting with the President of the Portuguese Republic, we will now have the three institutions sign the Better Law Agreement. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: written. - Mr Tusk should have recognized in this debate the evident failure of the Union governments in managing the migration crisis. Failure that he has forced to reach an agreement questioned by a large part of the humanitarian organizations and that in its first days of implementation has already demonstrated its ineffectiveness. The Agreement with Turkey de facto implies a waiver of our legal, political and ethical obligations. In recent months we have been building, by closing borders, an inhumane mousetrap for refugees, and now we are trying to close the last door. Public opinion speaks of the shame of Europe and national leaders rub their hands, because to speak of the shame of Europe is to hide their own ineffectiveness and inability to fulfill the commitments and obligations that they had to carry out, applying the principle of solidarity. This incompetence is unacceptable because we are talking about the lives of hundreds of thousands of people, many of them minors, fleeing war and death. The Europe project is in jeopardy. Let's not write the last page of our history with the suffering of these people.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - Mr Tusk should have recognized in this debate the evident failure of the Union governments in managing the migration crisis. Failure that he has forced to reach an agreement questioned by a large part of the humanitarian organizations and that in its first days of application has already demonstrated its ineffectiveness. The Agreement with Turkey de facto implies a waiver of our legal, political and ethical obligations. Let's not write the last page of our history with the suffering of these people.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: written. - Mr Tusk should have recognized in this debate the evident failure of the Union governments in managing the migration crisis. Failure that he has forced to reach an agreement questioned by a large part of the humanitarian organizations and that in its first days of application has already demonstrated its ineffectiveness. In recent months we have been building, by closing borders, an inhumane mousetrap for refugees, and now we are trying to close the last door. Public opinion speaks of the shame of Europe and national leaders rub their hands, because to speak of the shame of Europe is to hide their own ineffectiveness and inability to fulfill the commitments and obligations they had to carry out, applying the principle of solidarity. This incompetence is unacceptable because we are talking about the lives of hundreds of thousands of people, many of them minors, fleeing war and death. The Europe project is in jeopardy. Let's not write the last page of our history with the suffering of these people.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - The joint action plan with Turkey brings migrants out, but migration to the center of the EU. For geopolitical paradox in fact, the agreement provides that, while yearning to reach Europe and dying in the attempt, they remain only spectators, outsourced by those who, out of necessity, fear and impotence, cannot find an equitable sharing of responsibility for welcoming them. Migrants must be more than ever at the center of our attention as Europeans because they have been given a placement in a country, Turkey, where the highest standards of democracy, the rule of law, respect for fundamental freedoms and expression they are still in training, not to mention in the embryonic stage. We must have remorse for all that is not accomplished. Despite this, it is undoubted that the agreement represents in any case a good step forward towards a solution, but it is equally undoubted that the latter must propitiate a "humbler and more credible" Europe. The faded version of our human rights that we have managed to ensure to the migrant, does not deprive him and his family, in any case, of specific initiatives of additional funding, essential infrastructures and social cohesion.

name: Lorenzo CESA
text: in writing. - Assuming that in 2015 as many as 1.83 million people tried to reach the borders of the European Union against the "only" 282 000 in 2014, we realize how the refugee emergency is increasing exponentially. The solution can only be found through the cooperation and solidarity of all the Member States of the Union and the third countries directly involved. I therefore welcome the agreement that the EU has reached with Turkey and I hope that it can be implemented in a concrete way and quickly. To effectively resolve the ongoing humanitarian crisis in the Mediterranean we must resolve the geopolitical issues that are its cause: wars, poverty, corruption; coupled with a lack of opportunities mean that thousands of men, women and children consider a sea voyage on overcrowded and run-down boats safer than staying in their own country. Saving human lives must be the top priority, in the name of the dignity of every human being and the principle of solidarity that must inspire our action as Europeans.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: in writing. - The conclusions of the European Council at the meeting of 17-18 March 2016 state that the Heads of State and Government of the Union expect from Turkey "respect for the highest standards of democracy, the rule of law and respect for fundamental freedoms, including freedom of expression". Since then, however, the Erdogan regime has not only continued to fearlessly violate democratic principles and fundamental rights, especially to the detriment of the Kurdish minority inside Turkey, but is already trying to suppress free expression in EU member states. Mr. Erdogan's lawsuit against a German satirical presenter and the systematic harassment of the defendant by various strangers, resulting in him being placed under police protection, are an unprecedented outburst of authoritarianism. At the same time, Turkey continues to behave like an international agitator, systematically violating Greek airspace, threatening the Republic of Cyprus and trying to prevent its legal exploitation of natural resources on the continental shelf south of the mainland, and inciting aggression against the Nagorno-Karabakh. It is clear that the Union must show a stronger stance towards the Turkish regime, because the latter misinterprets tolerance and is intimidated.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. - The agreement reached on 18 March between the European Union and Turkey is the consequence of national selfishness and populist policies on the part of some Member States; what has been happening in recent days on the Brenner border between Italy and Austria is a sad and unacceptable example. An agreement that I certainly do not consider perfect, but which has the merit of helping two member countries of the Union, Greece and Bulgaria, which were in an emergency situation. I therefore hope that this is only the first step in a much broader European strategy for managing migratory flows. In fact, a series of concrete measures will have to follow as soon as possible: a courageous reform of the Dublin rules, a mandatory refugee reallocation system, the community management of hotspots and the more effective and coordinated implementation of a European coast guard system. . The future of the Union will depend not only on the ability and political will to find effective and shared solutions at European level, based on the principle of solidarity, but above all the fate of men, women and children who escape wars every day. and risk their lives to reach our continent.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - The last European Council demonstrated, once again, its inability to respond to the crisis, which continues there, to last. Under the pretext of drawing up the so-called National Reform Programs and Stability Programs, they simply parrot the old recipe for “structural reforms”. Translation: more job deregulation; low wages; promoting monopoly concentration in strategic sectors; privatization of public services; dismantling social functions of States, such as Social Security. They don't know or want to choose another path. And there are the results: economic stagnation, instability in the banking and financial sector and latent deflation. Nor does the ECB's continued pouring of liquidity into the financial system change this outlook. Money created with banks does not reach the real economy and is diverted to speculation, feeding new bubbles, such as the bond bubble. This is the visible result, to date, of Mr Draghi's measures. Mr. Draghi - the ex-Goldman Sachs board member - who had the impudence, the impertinence and the lack of attempt to go to Portugal to discuss what the Portuguese should or should not do, meddling even in aspects of the Portuguese political regime . A deplorable affront to national sovereignty and to the Constitution of the Portuguese Republic that cannot pass without a firm condemnation!

name: Eugen FREUND
text: written. - Europe really cannot be proud of that: it has outsourced the refugee problem to Turkey. Our continent with 500 million people is not in a position to take in anywhere near the same number of refugees as Turkey. And now we can let Ankara blackmail us: because we depend on the deal to work. We therefore do not dare to point the finger at those violations of the law that are on the agenda in Turkey: for example, when freedom of the press is endangered, freedom of expression or the protection of minorities. The outcome of the negotiations on the refugee issue must be an incentive for us to work even more decisively towards a peaceful solution to the war in Syria. One hears more and more these days that the Syrian army is again flying air strikes against individual cities. This breaks the painstakingly negotiated ceasefire agreement. It is therefore important for the European Union to press for the Geneva negotiations to resume as soon as possible. Why do we always have to wait for the US to act? Because one thing must be clear to us: without peace in Syria, nothing will change in the refugee crisis. Or do we want to wait until Jordan and Lebanon also collapse under the burden of the refugees?

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
