text: in writing.- The report concerns the request for technical assistance from the European Commission for the year 2016 for the mobilization of an amount equal to 380 000 euro from the Fund in order to finance monitoring and information, create a basisknowledge / interface and advise Member States on the use, continuity and evaluation of the Fund.I abstained on this issue as I believe that technical assistance should be provided at no additional cost by the European Commission, leaving the entirety of the Fund's resources to the companies and workers affected by the crisis.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing.- We support the Commission's report and proposal for a decision on the mobilization of the EGF.The proposal concerns the mobilization of EUR 380 000 from the Fund, which covers technical assistance to the Commission.The purpose of the technical assistance is to finance the monitoring, the provision of information, the creation of a knowledge base interface and the provision of advice to the Member States on the use, monitoring and evaluation of the EGF.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: in writing. - The report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilization of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund is a positive proposal for the activation of the additional support mechanism. I believe that the existence of such mechanisms is to the benefit of the states, but also of the citizens, as they can offer significant assistance, especially in financially turbulent times. In this light, I agree with its activation and for this reason I voted in favor.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing.- I was in favor of this report as it aims to use part of the European funds with the aim of improving the whole system of funds and clarifying to the various Member States how to access them and how to use them.These funds are in fact aimed at technical assistance consisting in financing monitoring and information and in offering advice in relation to the use and continuity of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund.I believe that this investment is very important because, as it is true that the opportunities that the European Union offers are many, it is equally true that in order to exploit them it is necessary to know them.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ This concerns the mobilisation of EUR 380 000 from the Fund, covering technical assistance for the Commission. The objective of the technical assistance is to finance monitoring, information, to create a knowledge base interface and to advice Member States on using, following up and evaluating the EGF. According to Article 11(1) of the EGF Regulation, 0.5% of the annual maximum amount of the EGF (i.e. EUR 828 060 in 2016) can be made available each year for technical assistance at the initiative of the Commission. According to the Commission’s proposal, in 2016 the requested amount is intended to cover the following activities: Monitoring and data gathering Information Creation of a knowledge base / application interface Administrative and technical support Evaluation

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against giving the unelected and unaccountable EU Commission an extra EUR 380 000 to help implement the globalisation adjustment fund. British taxpayers should not be forced to fund EU institutions to hand out our money for workers made redundant across Europe.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing.- The current proposal concerns the mobilization of an amount of EUR 380 000 from the Fund to cover technical assistance at the initiative of the Commission.The objective of technical assistance is to finance monitoring and information, to create a knowledge base / interface and to provide advice to Member States on the use, continuity and evaluation of the EGF.Considering that the EGF was created to support all those workers who are affected by the consequences of changes in international trade, I felt I had to vote positively, proposing to the Commission, as the rapporteur did, to also include a qualitative and quantitative analysis of the support.of the EGF to young people up to 25 years of age.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been created in order to provide additional assistance to workers suffering from the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns. Apart from this instrument it would be suitable to also have Commission strategies that anticipate labour market changes so as to protect jobs and ensure skills training on the basis of comprehensive trade impact assessments.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written. - The Union has created legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers suffering from the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns or the global financial and economic crisis, as well as to help them re-enter the labor market, including the EGF. These funds are intended to mitigate the disastrous social consequences of the economic crisis of the capitalist system. Although these funds are not capable of solving the problems of the dismissed workers, at least they give the possibility of alleviating a small part of the human drama. In particular with this report, which I voted in favor, it is a question of approving the funding of the Expert Group on EGF Contact Persons and the seminars to promote contacts on the implementation of the EGF, so that this exchange also help to provide better and more detailed information on the success rate of EGF-supported measures in the Member States.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: signed up.- The European Globalization Adjustment Fund (EGF) has been set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in international trade practices.The economic crisis, but also the robotization of industrial processes have led to an increasing number of those who lose their jobs.I voted for the development and modernization of this fund.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: in writing. - On 22 February 2016, the Commission adopted a new proposal for a decision on the mobilization of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund. The proposal is intended to mobilize EUR 380 000 from the Fund for technical assistance to the Commission. The purpose of technical assistance is to finance monitoring, information and the creation of a knowledge base interface, as well as advice to Member States on the use, monitoring and evaluation of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund. Pursuant to Article 11 (1) of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund Regulation, at the initiative of the Commission, 0.5% of the annual maximum amount of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund (ie EUR 828 060 in 2016) may be used for technical assistance. The amount now requested is only 0.23% of the Fund's annual maximum amount. The European Parliament has repeatedly emphasized the need to improve the added value, effectiveness and employability of the EGF as an EU instrument to support redundant workers. I therefore welcome the integration of reports into the electronic data exchange system, as this could reduce the administrative burden on Member States and facilitate the use of reports for evaluation purposes. I voted in favor of the report.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing. - The European Globalization Adjustment Fund (EGF) helps workers find new jobs and acquire new skills when they lose their jobs due to changes in the pattern of world trade, for example when a large company closes a factory or moves outside the EU or when there is a global financial and economic crisis. On 22 February 2016, the Commission adopted a new proposal to mobilize the EGF. Article 11 (1) 1 of the EGF Regulation states that for a year a maximum of 0.5% of the available budget (EUR 150 million in 2011 prices) may be mobilized to provide technical assistance at the initiative of the Commission. The Commission intends to use EUR 380,000 for this purpose (0.23% of the maximum annual budget in 2016 prices) to cover monitoring and data collection, information, the creation of the knowledge base, administrative and technical support, and evaluation activities. I support actions that, when implemented in the policy, create economic growth and employment. However, I do not believe that the EGF is the right tool to pursue such a policy and an effective tool offering value for money for reintegrating the redundant workers back into the labor market. With that in mind, I abstained from voting.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ It is essential that EU expenditure is closely scrutinised on the basis of value for money for taxpayers and I do not believe the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an efficient tool that offers value for money in terms of reintegrating redundant workers back into the labour market. The United Kingdom Government has never availed itself of funding under the EGF due to its inefficiency and I believe it is time that money spent under the EGF was put to better use. For these reasons I cannot support this report.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing.- This report aims to mobilize the European Globalization Adjustment Fund (EGF), As part of the technical assistance to be financed, the Commission intends to mobilize an amount of 380,000 euros for the collection of information, the publication ofinformation, as well as administrative and technical support and networking.Considering that information and communication are essential tools for the transparency of European activities, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of mobilizing the European Globalization Adjustment Fund (EGF) to enable the European Commission to finance technical assistance activities.This amount is used to finance, in particular, monitoring, information, monitoring and evaluation activities of the GEF.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - On 22 February 2016, the Commission adopted a new proposal for a decision on the mobilization of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund. The proposal is intended to mobilize EUR 380 000 from the Fund for technical assistance to the Commission. The purpose of technical assistance is to finance monitoring, information and the creation of a knowledge base interface, as well as advice to Member States on the use, monitoring and evaluation of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund. Pursuant to Article 11 (1) of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund Regulation, at the initiative of the Commission, 0.5% of the annual maximum amount of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund (ie EUR 828 060 in 2016) may be used for technical assistance. According to the Commission's proposal, the amount requested in 2016 is intended to finance the following activities: monitoring and data collection, information, creation of a knowledge base / application interface, administrative and technical support, support for networking between Member States, evaluation. Based on the above, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing.- The text proposes to mobilize 380,000 euros to finance the collection and monitoring of information by the Commission, the expansion of the site of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund (EGF) managed by the Commission, the creation of astandard procedure for EGF intervention requests, administrative and technical support, networking of Member States through the organization of seminars.These provisions, of minor importance, may be useful in encouraging the solicitation of EGF assistance following redundancies.However, this competence must rest with the Member States only and not give the illusion that it is the Union which gives aid when the funds are financed by the national taxpayers.For these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - In principle, I follow my position on this inefficient fund for me and I voted against the proposal to spend money again on small returns. Part of the proposal is a percentage of the funds to be used to promote the fund, which is completely unacceptable, given that this is wasted money that can be much better invested. My group and I are in favor of measures that lead to growth and job creation, but they need to be well researched and their results confirmed, and this fund is not such a measure.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: in writing. - On 22 February 2016, the Commission adopted a new proposal for a decision on the mobilization of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund. The proposal is intended to mobilize EUR 380 000 from the Fund for technical assistance to the Commission. The purpose of technical assistance is to finance monitoring, information and the creation of a knowledge base interface, as well as advice to Member States on the use, monitoring and evaluation of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund. Pursuant to Article 11 (1) of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund Regulation, at the initiative of the Commission, 0.5% of the annual maximum amount of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund (ie EUR 828 060 in 2016) may be used for technical assistance. According to the Commission's proposal, the amount requested in 2016 is intended to finance the following activities: monitoring and data collection, information, creation of a knowledge base / application interface, administrative and technical support, support for networking between Member States, evaluation. Based on the above, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. It is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to local economies hard hit by company closures, and so I voted in favour of this application. I regret that the UK Government has not taken advantage of this fund in Wales.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: written.- Our conviction is that wealth is created through free trade and fair competition.That is why we are in principle opposed to the European Globalization Fund, which we believe is an expression of protectionism.We have previously accepted that the fund has been used as a pure emergency measure in a time of deep economic crisis, as a way to meet people's feelings of hopelessness and the exclusion that follows in the wake of the crisis and which risks further intensifying the wave of nationalism and xenophobia that is spreading.in Europe.Especially in light of the Swedish National Audit Office's analysis, which states that the fund even has a negative effect on the return to work, we believe that the fund has lost its legitimacy and should not be used anymore.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing.- The European Globalization Adjustment Fund was created to provide additional support to workers affected by the effects of major structural changes in world trade patterns and cannot exceed the maximum annual amount of EUR 150 million.The proposal concerns the mobilization of EUR 380 000 from the Fund to cover the Commission's technical assistance expenditure, which aims to finance monitoring and information, in order to create a knowledge base / interface for applications and advise StatesMember States on the use, monitoring and evaluation of the EGF.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: in writing.- Vote against: competence which must rest with the Member States.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - Technical assistance to the European Globalization Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to coordinate applications to the EGF and to publish the results obtained: financial monitoring, creating a knowledge interface to advise Member States on the use of the fund, monitoring and evaluation of the EGF. The budget foreseen for this assistance should be a maximum of 0.5% of the maximum annual amount of the EGF (EUR 150 million). The Commission's proposal for this year provides for the mobilization of 380,000 euros for technical assistance (0.23% of the maximum annual budget available). The report welcomes and values ​​the continued work on standardizing procedures for applications to the EGF, not without pointing out some criticisms such as the relatively high costs. There are positive aspects, such as the requirement to extend support to young people up to the age of 25 who do not work, study and do not undergo training (NEET), changing the current legal framework, as well as calling for a more widespread use of the derogation the eligibility thresholds in favor of SMEs, the extension of the reference periods, and the possibility of including redundant workers who provide services similar to those of redundant workers from reference companies. In addition, it calls for greater monitoring of beneficiaries. We voted in favor.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour. The demand to extend the help for NEETs within the EGF framework after 2017 represents a small victory for our group. It lays down a common position from the EP which that can be recalled in future revisions. As well as the call for a wider use of the derogation criteria that will allow more EGF funding for cases with less than 500 redundant workers, favouring SMEs and/or subcontractors or suppliers touched by the decision of a big group for example.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The amount of the envisaged contribution is EUR 380 000 to be used to finance various activities such as data collection, knowledge base creation, administrative and technical support, information and communication activities, as well as audit, control and evaluation. The activities financed will also contribute to simplifying the application procedure and raising people's awareness of the EGF.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report supporting work and workers in companies in difficulty.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: application EGF/2016/000 TA 2016/Technical assistance on the initiative of the Commission), as the money from the Adjustment Fund should be given primarily to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining programmes. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I welcomed the measures proposed by the Commission as technical assistance and recall the importance of networking and the exchange of information on EGF and therefore supports the funding of the Expert Group of people Contact EGF and networking seminars on the implementation of the EGF. I hope that this exchange of information will contribute to the development of better and more detailed reports on the success rate of the EGF in the Member States, particularly on the scope and rate of re-employment of beneficiaries; I also support all initiatives in favour of increased participation and consultation of local authorities who daily manage the measures supported by the EGF.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 On 22 February 2016, the Commission adopted a new proposal for a decision on the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The proposal aims to use EUR 380 000 from the Fund for technical support to the Commission. The purpose of technical assistance is to finance supervision, the establishment of an information and knowledge base interface and to advise Member States on the use, monitoring and evaluation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. According to Article 11(1) of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund Regulation, 0.5% of the annual maximum amount of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (i.e. EUR 828 060 in 2016) may be used for technical assistance on the Initiative of the Commission. The Commission proposes that in 2016 the amount requested will be used to finance the following activities: monitoring and data collection, information, creation of a knowledge base/application interface, administrative and technical support, support for networking between Member States, evaluation. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. Under the provisions of Article 12(6) of Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2011 on the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 and Article 15 of Regulation (EU) No 1309/2013(7), the Fund shall not exceed a maximum annual amount of EUR 150 million. The corresponding amounts shall be introduced as reserves in the general budget of the Union.  Sweden has submitted an application for access to the EGF, in particular as regards redundancies in the NACE Rev 2 sector (production of motor vehicles and trailers and downward processors) in the NUTS Level II region of Upper Norrland (SE33). Of the 647 redundant workers eligible for the EGF contribution, 500 are expected to participate, as 470 of these workers have lost their jobs as a result of redundancies at the Volvo Group Truck Operation EMEA plant in Umeå and a further 177 have lost their jobs at 4 suppliers and downs processing companies. However, support from the EGF should not replace measures which companies are responsible for taking under national law or collective agreements, nor measures to restructure companies or sectors. I welcome Sweden's measures for redundant workers, and I support Mr Negrescu's report with my vote.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilisation of this Fund because there are economic sectors in crisis within the EU that are currently in a precarious situation. Mobilisation of this section of the Fund will enable the Commission to establish a number of programmes and to have specialised teams to serve workers in all sectors to more easily access viable work alternatives through the help of Commission programmes.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted against mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: Application EGF/2016/000 TA 2016 - Technical assistance on the initiative of the Commission, as I consider the instrument as a whole inappropriate and inefficient.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. It makes sense to provide financial support to the Commission in its advisory and information centres in order to support their technical development. The fact that the data is available to the public on the Internet is also an important investment in informing Member States, public authorities and citizens.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the mobilisation of EU funds, in this case for technical assistance at the initiative of the Commission. Particularly welcome are the fact that the activities will help to make the application process for funds simpler - as well as improving general awareness of the European Globalisation Fund.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of this report, as we consider it important and appropriate to mobilize part of the European Globalisation Adjustment Funds for technical assistance, i.e. in order to finance the activities of preparation, monitoring, data collection and creation of a knowledge base, technical and administrative support, information and communication activities, as well as audit activities , control and evaluation necessary for the implementation of the EGF Regulation. Since the current use of such funds is not due to the type of investment in the affected areas that, in our view, can help solve the problem, we believe that good work to monitor the impact of these funds could give the keys to being able to offer other alternatives that give sustainable exits to these areas and people , and don't just patch situations with compensation.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which regards an uncontroversial mobilisation of funds.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. I consider to be positive that the Commission intends to invest EUR 70 000 of the available budget under the Technical Assistance in particular on improving the monitoring and evaluation of the impact of EGF support on individual participants.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the release of the funds, because despite our disagreement the logic of the European Globalisation Fund, in this case it supports laid-off workers.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the application by the Commission for EUR 380 000 of the EGF to be mobilised in 2016 for measures for technical assistance to finance expenditure. This amount is below the maximum of 0.5% of the annual maximum amount of the EGF and contains the same items to be funded as in the previous year. This assistance provided by the Commission to the Member States supports and enhances the use of the EGF by providing information on the applications and by spreading best practice among Member States. Positive measures proposed are the funding of the Expert Group of Contact Persons of the EGF and networking seminars on the implementation of the EGF as the promotion of the Fund is hugely important. I hope this exchange of information will contribute to better and more detailed reporting on the success rate of the applications in the Member States, in particular about reach and re-employment rates of beneficiaries which are crucial in order to assess the added value of measures. In this regard I also welcome the integration of reporting into the electronic data exchange system which could ease the administrative burden for Member States and facilitate the use of reports for evaluation purposes.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I support this resolution as the European Globalisation Adjustment fund provides much needed support for workers who have been affected by the major structural changes in the global trade patterns as a result of Globalisation.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was formed to support people losing their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation. For the 2016 the provided EGF contribution for technical assistance at the initiative of the Commission of EUR 380 000 is intended to cover different activities as monitoring and data gathering, information, creation of knowledge base, administrative and technical support, as well as audit, evaluation and control activities. I have voted in favour for this report taking into consideration that these financed activities should improve the simplification of the application procedure and its visibility.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a Resolution by the European Parliament on the proposal for a decision by Parliament and the Council to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund – technical assistance at the initiative of the Commission, as I fully support the Commission's proposal to invest €70,000 for technical assistance, in particular to evaluate and monitor the impact of the EGF. I also support activities to standardise the EGF mobilisation application process, as well as additional networking and information sharing around the EGF. In this context, better linking of the parties involved in the submission and processing of EGF applications, and increasing awareness and recognition of the EGF. I believe that the European Union must provide dynamic and swift assistance to the affected workers, and therefore I support this report.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The Navokov report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: "EGF/2016/000 TA 2016/Technical assistance on the Commission's initiative", proposes to mobilise EUR 380,000 to finance the collection and monitoring of information by the Commission, the expansion of the EGF site managed by the Commission, the creation of a standard procedure for EGF intervention requests (with an application interface), administrative and technical support, the networking of Member States through the organisation of seminars, etc. These provisions, of minor importance, may be useful in encouraging the solicitation of EGF assistance following economic layoffs. However, this competence must go to the Member States only, and not give the illusion that it is the Union that grants the aid while the funds come from national taxpayers. My vote was against this text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – Together with my fellow UKIP MEP colleagues I voted against giving the unelected and unaccountable EU Commission an extra EUR 380 000 to help implement the globalisation adjustment fund. British taxpayers should not be forced to fund EU institutions to hand out our money for workers made redundant across Europe.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Novakov report on the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for technical assistance. The report aims to provide EUR 380,000 for technical assistance in fiscal year 2016. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which will enable the European Commission to provide additional support to workers suffering the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. Political decisions can only be based on scientifically in-depth, usable and reliable data. I therefore support the provision of EUR 380 000 for preparation, monitoring, data collection and the creation of a knowledge base.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilisation of the fund, as I support giving assistance to reintegrate workers in the labour market made redundant due to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and the economic crisis.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund aims at providing assistance to enterprises that have gone bankrupt due to globalisation and/or economic crisis. I voted in favour of this report, since we reached to pass one amendment in order to extend the Fund and another amendment to defend the wider use of the Fund. One last positive element of this report is that we will have a better assessment of economic mutations causing the dismissals of EGF beneficiaries.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in view of the fundamental role that the EGF plays at European level, especially in this period of economic crisis, I am voting in favour of the proposal to finance EUR 380 000 to the European Commission, to be used to support the management of the EGF. The amount requested will be invested in several areas including: monitoring and data collection of requests received and contributions spent; the continuous updating of information related to the EGF, through the optimization of the website; technical and administrative support; the promotion of cooperation between the Member States and, finally, the evaluation report.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which proposes to mobilise EUR 380,000 to finance the collection and monitoring of information by the Commission, the expansion of the EGF site managed by the Commission, the creation of a standardised procedure for EGF requests for intervention (with an application interface etc.), administrative and technical support , networking member states through the organisation of seminars etc. These provisions, of minor importance, may be useful in encouraging the solicitation of EGF assistance following economic layoffs. However, this competence must go to the Member States only, and not give the illusion that it is the Union that grants the aid while the funds come from national taxpayers.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it grants the Commission EUR 380,000 to finance minor operations of questionable interest.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. This text aims to mobilise 380,000 euros to finance many minor proposals (collection and follow-up of information by the Commission, expansion of the EGF website, European Globalisation Adjustment Funds, etc.). Of course, the use of the EGF for economic redundancies should be encouraged, but I do not wish to join a proposal that further chains Member States and gives greater powers to the European Union, which allows itself to solve tragedies by distributing funds that come from national taxpayers. So I voted against it.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. The Union has developed legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional assistance to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in the patterns of world trade or the global economic and financial crisis, as well as to help them rejoin the labour market, including the EGF. These funds aim to mitigate the disastrous social consequences of the economic crisis of the capitalist system. While these funds are unable to solve the problems of laid-off workers at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama.  In particular, this report, which I voted in favour of, is about giving the go-ahead to the funding of the EAGF Group of Experts on Contact Persons and the seminars to promote contacts on the implementation of the EGF, so that this exchange of information also contributes to providing better and more detailed information on the success rate of measures supported by the EGF in the Member States.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. The objective of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was to provide additional assistance to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in global trade patterns. The EC must have sufficient resources to carry out good management of the EC.  I therefore support the request for a mobilisation of EUR 380 000 from the Fund, for the Commission, to cover technical assistance. This assistance is intended to finance monitoring and information activities, the creation of a knowledge base/application interface and advice to Member States on the use, monitoring and evaluation of the EGF (European Globalisation Adjustment Fund). I therefore vote in favour of the proposal as I consider it important to adequately cover the above-mentioned activities by the institution.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree with the spending of EUR 380 000 on 'technical assistance', which is essentially bureaucratic expenditure 'to finance the preparation, monitoring, collection of data and the creation of a knowledge base, administrative and technical support, information and communication activities, as well as the audit, control and evaluation activities necessary for the implementation of the EGF Regulation'. In general, I am against the existence of a European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. If the money that the fund distributes remained in people's pockets, it would be better for the economy. In my view, this fund is contrary to the principle of subsidiarity and means interference in the social policy of individual countries.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. \u2012 Since 2007, when it started its work, the EGF has helped tens of thousands of people made redundant due to the economic crisis and the effects of globalisation to find new jobs or reorient themselves professionally. I believe that this programme must increase. Not anyway, but in a responsible way. There is a need, for example, for a qualitative and quantitative analysis of support measures for young people up to the age of 25 who are not in employment and do not follow any educational programme. We need to see the impact on the labour market and to what extent we can extend funding to help them. Romania also benefited from this fund. In 2013, more than 5,000 people who were out of work as a result of redundancies received around 2.9 million euros. The Commission's technical assistance is important for the good implementation and dissemination of this money, but above all, we need proper monitoring. I think the most important thing is that the support allocated to people reaches people and is not lost in the pockets of fraud and in an endless bureaucratic chain.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to support the self-employed and workers made redundant by major structural changes caused by globalisation and the economic crisis. At the initiative of the Commission, in accordance with Article 11(1) of the Decisions on egf, a maximum of 0.5 % of the maximum annual amount of the EGF can be allocated each year for technical assistance. The proposed decision to mobilise the EGF is taken jointly by the European Parliament and the Council. The Commission has requested the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to support the following activities: monitoring and data collection, informing the public about the EGF, holding an EGF seminar, creating a database with all data and providing administrative and technical assistance. I supported the report because it enables better networking between Member States and with the technical activities of the Commission it will be clearer how to use the EGF more efficiently.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 Unlike most of the other votes on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, this concerns the allocation of funds to the European Commission itself, and in this case to the relevant authorities, with a view to financing monitoring and information activities, developing a knowledge base interface and advising the Member States of the European Union on the use, monitoring and evaluation of EGF funding. The total amount to be allocated is EUR 380 thousand. The request as such results from the EGF Regulation, that approximately 0,5 % of the annual resources of the Fund can be claimed each year for this type of purpose. The maximum this year amounts to EUR 828,060. Given that since its creation, the Foundation continues to provide support to thousands of redundant workers every year, helping them to retrain and return to the labour market, and otherwise consistently supporting the competitiveness and economy of the EU as a whole and its future development, it was logical to vote positively.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, because it is well documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this text. This report proposes the mobilization of EUR 380,000 for the financing of administrative technical assistance measures to the Commission. We are not opposed to the one-off mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, but it is worth remembering that it is the States that are the purveyors.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund concerning the request for technical assistance, on the Commission's initiative, as a reserve to finance the mid-term evaluation of the effectiveness and sustainability of the results achieved with the EGF.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. I also support the Commission's proposal to use EUR 380 000 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to cover technical assistance for the Commission.  This mechanism anticipates the possibility of using a small part of its resources to improve the functioning of the same, so this technical assistance comes to meet that objective which, I am convinced, will be beneficial for all. Technical assistance is intended to finance follow-up and information activities, the creation of an application knowledge base and advice to Member States on the use, monitoring and evaluation of the Fund.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of activating the EGAF to help with the necessary changes that need to be made in today’s society with continuous developments.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. In particular, the Commission is in charge of compiling all applications under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which helps licensees of SMEs, as well as multinationals who relocate. It asks for 380,000 euros to manage these requests for state funds, data, publications, the dedicated website and exchange courses between competent national authorities. I welcome Parliament's final request for specific information on the rate of reintegration of licensees and on the type and quality of the contract they obtain. The report also supports wider support, particularly for young people. I note, however, that the Commission has delegated some of this work to a private contractor without seeking advice from anyone. Furthermore, I do not wish to give the Commission any satisfaction until it reconsiders its requirements for companies that relocate. In these circumstances, I abstain.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. I do not forget that the funds requested by this report come from the Member States. It would be inappropriate for the EU to take credit for the fullness of aid delivered. This jurisdiction rests with the Member States. So, although this may allow some help in the face of economic redundancies, I voted against this text.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 Union assistance to workers who are victims of dismissal must be characterised by dynamism and be made available as quickly and efficiently as possible, in accordance with the joint statement of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission adopted at the conciliation meeting of 17 July 2008, taking due account of the provisions of the IIA of 2 December 2013 on the adoption of decisions to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF). This Regulation reflects the agreement reached between Parliament and the Council to reintroduce the crisis mobilisation criterion, to set the Union's financial contribution at 60 % of the estimated total cost of the proposed measures, to increase efficiency in the treatment of EGF applications by the Commission, the European Parliament and the Council, shortening the time limit for evaluation and approval , extend the measures and eligible beneficiaries, also covering self-employed persons and young people, and finance incentives for the creation of the company itself. These improvements are essential for a more effective EGF, hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is one of the tools at the Union’s disposal to provide additional assistance to workers negatively impacted upon by major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Commission approved this specific application as it helps to improve the functioning of the fund. I therefore voted in favour of this report to improve the performance of this fund in order to better address the situation of those affected.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. It was necessary to mobilise EUR 380,000 to take over the Commission's technical assistance, even if the Fund's projects are managed and implemented by national or regional authorities. This technical assistance is primarily aimed at funding monitoring, information and knowledge base activities to simplify requests for intervention, advice to Member States on the use, monitoring and evaluation of the Fund.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was created to provide more effective assistance to those who have lost their jobs as a result of major changes in world trade. This assistance must be provided to people who have lost their jobs in a timely manner and without undue delays, in order to avoid being left without the funds or other opportunities they can obtain through the EGF. The European Parliament has repeatedly stressed the need for increased added value, efficiency and employability of EGF beneficiaries as a Union instrument to support redundant workers. The European Parliament has also drawn attention to delays and a lack of flexibility in the assessment of applications. It is for these reasons that I agree that assistance should be provided to finance the preparation, monitoring, data collection and creation of the knowledge base, administrative and technical support, as well as other activities, such as audit or evaluation activities necessary for the implementation of the EGF Regulation. At the same time, I would like to draw attention to the importance of raising awareness of the EGF, and this task should be carried out mainly by the Member States. At a time of advanced information technology, other means should be used to keep the general public informed of the possibilities of mitigating the negative impact of unemployment, which is plaguing large areas, or even the entire Member States.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour on a report containing a decision to mobilize the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to provide technical assistance at the initiative of the Commission. The amount of the foreseen EGF contribution, EUR 380 000, will be used for financing various activities such as data gathering, creation of a knowledge base, administrative and technical support, information and communication activities as well as audit, control and evaluation activities.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund aims to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. At 2011 prices, the Fund shall not exceed a maximum annual amount of EUR 150 million. On 22 February 2016, the Commission submitted a proposal for a decision to Parliament and the Council to benefit from the Fund for technical support. From the amount requested, the Commission intends to finance the following activities: monitoring and data collection, information, knowledge base and application submission interface, administrative and technical support, organisation of seminars, evaluation. The Committee on Budgets notes in its report that, under Regulation (EU) No 1309/2013, no more than 0.5% of the EGF maximum annual amount is available for technical assistance each year on the Initiative of the Commission. Given that this is EUR 828 060 in 2016 and the EUR 380 000 requested is well within this threshold, it proposes to Parliament that the Commission approve its proposal for a decision. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The Navokov report proposes to mobilise EUR 380,000 to fund the collection and monitoring of information by the Commission, the expansion of the EGF site managed by the Commission, the creation of a standard procedure for EGF requests for intervention (with an application interface etc.), administrative and technical support, the networking of Member States through the organisation of seminars etc. These provisions, of minor importance, may be useful in encouraging the solicitation of assistance from the fund following economic layoffs. However, this competence must be left to the Member States only, and should not give the illusion that it is the Unio that grants the aid while the funds come from national taxpayers. So the vote is negative.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 Union assistance to workers who are victims of dismissal must be characterised by dynamism and be made available as quickly and efficiently as possible, in accordance with the joint statement of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission adopted at the conciliation meeting of 17 July 2008, taking due account of the provisions of the IIA of 2 December 2013 on the adoption of decisions to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF). I am voting in favour of this report on the mobilisation of EUR 380 000 from the Fund to cover the Commission's technical assistance expenditure. The purpose of technical assistance is to finance the monitoring and information in order to create a knowledge base/interface for applications and advise Member States on the use, monitoring and evaluation of the EGF. In accordance with Article 11(1) of the EGF Regulation, 0.5 % of the maximum annual amount of the EGF (i.e. EUR 828 060 in 2016) may be made available annually on the Commission's initiative for technical assistance expenditure.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The Navokov report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: "EGF/2016/000 TA 2016/Technical assistance on the Commission's initiative", proposes to mobilise EUR 380,000 to finance the collection and monitoring of information by the Commission, the expansion of the EGF site managed by the Commission, the creation of a standard procedure for EGF intervention requests (with an application interface etc.), administrative and technical support, the networking of Member States by organising seminars etc. These provisions, of minor importance, may be useful in encouraging the solicitation of EGF assistance following economic layoffs. However, this competence must go to the Member States only, and not give the illusion that it is the Union that grants the aid while the funds come from national taxpayers. I voted against it.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this mobilisation of funds because the case fully meets the requirements set out in the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund Regulation.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to mobilise the sum of EUR 380,000 for the Technical Assistance of the Commission for the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, intended to help people who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in international trade as a result of globalisation. As part of this technical assistance, the fund is involved in funding monitoring, information, knowledge base and interface and advice to Member States on the use, monitoring and evaluation of the WEF.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. The European Parliament has adopted two mobilisation reports from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I have spoken in favour of each of its two reports. The aim of this fund is to enable employees who have been made redundant to have personalised training so that they can retrain professionally. On this issue, the European Parliament has agreed to the release of EUR 380,000 for technical assistance from national authorities for the implementation of co-financed measures under this fund.  In these difficult times, the mobilization of this fund is essential. It is imperative that personalised training be provided to those made redundant so that they can return to work as soon as possible.  The European Parliament once again shows its commitment to one of the founding values of the European Union: solidarity.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. In accordance with the regulation, the European Commission has the possibility of using up to 0.5% of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to finance technical assistance. I therefore voted in favour of the Commission's purely procedural initiative.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to support workers and entrepreneurs made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade in response to globalisation or the global financial and economic crisis and to help them reintegrate into the labour market. Financial support for this purpose should reach the target person as quickly and efficiently as possible, so it is very important to ensure that the process is properly technically covered. Against this background, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report and I trust that the amount provided by the EGF will be used as efficiently as possible.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ This report concerns the mobilisation of 380 000 euro from the European Globalisation Fund to cover technical assistance for the Commission. I have voted for this report that is intended to cover monitor and data gathering, information and website maintenance, creation of a knowledge base, administrative and technical support through the establishment of an Expert Group of Contact Persons regarding EGF, consisting of one member from each Member State.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund on technical assistance at the initiative of the Commission. The Regulation on the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) provides that 0.5% of the maximum annual budget available for the EGF for technical assistance may be allocated at the initiative of the Commission. The aim is to finance preparatory, monitoring, data collection and knowledge base creation, technical and administrative assistance, information and communication activities, as well as audit, control and evaluation activities necessary for the implementation of the EGF Regulation. We support funding for the EGF Contact Expert Group and other activities to ensure the relationship on the implementation of the EGF. We hope that this exchange of information will also contribute to better and more detailed reporting on the success rate of EGF-supported measures in the Member States, in particular as regards the number of people who have benefited from them and the rate of reintegration into work of beneficiaries.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the application for mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (Application EGF/2016/000 TA 2016). The amount of EUR 380 000 will be used to finance the preparation, monitoring, data collection, administrative costs, technical assistance, support for the information and communication structure, advice to Member States on mobilisation and follow-up and evaluation of the EGF.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against giving the unelected and unaccountable EU Commission an extra EUR 380 000 to help implement the globalisation adjustment fund. British taxpayers should not be forced to fund EU institutions to hand out our money for workers made redundant across Europe.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Whereas this proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund concerns technical assistance, and as such is intended to cover activities such as monitoring, information gathering and technical and administrative support, and whereas these actions would help to simplify the analysis of applications for mobilisation of the Fund, I thought it appropriate to vote in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The main purpose of this decision is to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) and finance technical assistance at the initiative of the Commission. Networking and research will achieve a quick response to help workers who have become redundant in the labour market in different ways for some reason. The evaluation achieves monitoring of the implementation of the prescribed measures, the structure of laid-off workers, faster and better exchange of data between Member States in order to better assist workers in getting around the labour market and finding a new job.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report proposes to mobilise EUR 380,000 to fund the collection and monitoring of information by the Commission, the expansion of the COMMISSION-managed WEF site, the creation of a standard procedure for EGF requests for intervention (with an application interface, etc.), administrative and technical support, the networking of Member States through the organisation of seminars, etc. These provisions, of minor importance, may be useful in encouraging the solicitation of EGF assistance following economic layoffs. However, this competence must go to the Member States only, and not give the illusion that it is the EU that grants the aid while the funds come from national taxpayers. I therefore vote against this report.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to support redundant and self-employed workers who have ceased to carry out their activities due to major structural changes in globalisation-induced world trade flows, due to the continuing global financial and economic crisis or the new global financial and economic crisis, and to help them re-enter the labour market.  I welcome the Commission's proposal to mobilise the EGF to provide EUR 380 000 for technical assistance, which aims to help fund monitoring and information, to create an interface that serves as a knowledge base and to advise Member States on the use of EGF funds, the implementation of follow-up measures and evaluations. This measure contributes to providing Union support and financial assistance to redundant workers, which should be dynamic and accessible as quickly and efficiently as possible.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 Technical assistance to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to coordinate eGF applications and publish the results obtained: financial monitoring, create a knowledge interface to advise Member States on the use of the fund, monitoring and evaluation of the EGF. The budget foreseen for this assistance should be a maximum of 0.5% of the maximum annual amount of the EGF (EUR 150 million). The Commission's proposal for this year provides for the mobilisation of EUR 380,000 for technical assistance (0.23% of the maximum available annual budget). The report welcomes and values continued work in standardising procedures for EGF applications, not without pointing out some criticisms, such as relatively high costs. There are positive aspects, such as the requirement to extend support to young people up to the age of 25 who do not work, study and do not train (NEETs), changing the current legal framework, and calls for more widespread use of the derogation to eligibility thresholds for SMEs, the extension of reference periods and the possibility of including redundant workers providing services similar to those of workers made redundant from referral companies. It also calls for greater monitoring of beneficiaries. We voted in favour.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The aim of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is to support redundant and self-employed workers who have ceased their activities due to major structural changes caused by globalisation, due to the global financial and economic crisis, and to help them re-enter the labour market. On 22 February 2016, the Commission adopted a new proposal for a decision to mobilise the EGF.  This proposal concerns the mobilisation of €380,000 from the Technical Assistance Fund to the Commission, which aims to fund monitoring and information, create an interface that serves as a knowledge base and advise Member States on the use of EGF funds, the implementation of follow-up measures and evaluation. In accordance with Article 11(1) of the Regulation, The EGF Regulation states that 0.5% of the maximum annual EGF amount (i.e. EUR 828 060 in 2016 prices) can be used for technical assistance each year at the initiative of the Commission.  The Croatian labour market is also facing many changes and challenges. Although no EGF co-financing has been requested so far, discussions have been held with Croatian EGF bodies on sectors affected by globalisation (e.g. shipbuilding) and on the possibility of applying to support workers. Consequently, I voted for a report by fellow MP Andrey Novakov.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Article 11(1) of the EGF Regulation provides that a maximum of 0,5 % of the available annual budget may be used for technical assistance. The proposal concerns the mobilisation of an amount of EUR 380 000 to cover technical assistance on the Commission's initiative. The objective of technical assistance is to finance monitoring and information, to create a knowledge/interface base and to advise Member States on the use, continuity and evaluation of the EGF.  The European Parliament has repeatedly stressed the need to improve the added value and efficiency of the EGF as a support tool for redundant workers. For this reason, I welcome the fact that the Commission intends to invest additional resources in this area. That is why I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for technical assistance. The report aims to provide EUR 380,000 for technical assistance in fiscal year 2016.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against giving the unelected and unaccountable EU Commission an extra EUR 380 000 to help implement the globalisation adjustment fund. British taxpayers should not be forced to fund EU institutions to hand out our money for workers made redundant across Europe.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide complementary support to workers affected by the effects of major structural changes in world trade patterns. On 22 February 2016, the Commission adopted a new proposal for a Decision on the mobilisation of the EGF concerning the mobilisation of EUR 380 000 from the Fund to cover the Commission's technical assistance expenditure. The aim was to finance monitoring and information in order to create a knowledge base/interface for applications and advise Member States on the use, monitoring and evaluation of the EGF. This is the third transfer proposal for mobilisation of the Fund transmitted to the budgetary authority so far in 2016.  I voted in favour.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 380 000 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to provide technical assistance to the European Commission. This amount will be used to finance activities such as data collection, the creation of a database, administrative and technical support, advice to Member States on the use, monitoring and evaluation of the EGF, communication activities, as well as audit, control and evaluation. The activities financed should also contribute to the simplification of the EGF application procedure and its visibility and to improving the monitoring and evaluation of the effects of EGF support on each of the participants

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) to the tune of EUR 380,000 to finance technical assistance as requested by the European Commission. I have already had the opportunity to say several times that the WEF is an important tool to help workers who have unfortunately lost their jobs as a result of a partial or total closure of their business. This fund allows these workers to acquire new skills in order to increase their chances of finding a job as quickly as possible. As is often the case, some aspects need to be improved, particularly with regard to the time it takes to activate the mobilization of the fund, but this will soon be the subject of debate in the EMPL Committee.  In order for this budget to bring its added value, it is necessary to provide technical assistance in order to follow up on files, disseminate information, provide administrative and technical support or network national experts. In addition, this technical assistance should enable an evaluation of the use of this fund to further improve its relevance.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. The amount requested should be used to finance the following activities: monitoring and data collection, information, development of a knowledge base (application) interface, administrative and technical support, seminars and translation.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this Resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) with the aim of financing the EGF contact expert group and the network seminars on the implementation of the EGF, as the Fund regulation itself provides that 0.5% of the amount can be made available for technical assistance on the Commission's initiative , precisely for the purpose of financing the preparation, monitoring, data collection, administrative and technical support and information and communication, auditing, control and evaluation activities necessary for the implementation of the EGF Regulation.  Given, first, that the amount of the proposed funding — EUR 380 000 — represents about 0.23% of the maximum annual budget available for the EGF in 2016 and that the other assumptions inherent in the allocation of the fund are meeting, I considered that there were no reasons, in my view, to prevent its approval.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of this report, as we consider it important and appropriate to mobilize part of the European Globalisation Adjustment Funds for technical assistance, i.e. in order to finance the activities of preparation, monitoring, data collection and creation of a knowledge base, technical and administrative support, information and communication activities, as well as audit activities , control and evaluation necessary for the implementation of the EGF Regulation. Since the current use of such funds is not due to the type of investment in the affected areas that, in our view, can help solve the problem, we believe that good work to monitor the impact of these funds could give the keys to being able to offer other alternatives that give sustainable exits to these areas and people , and don't just patch situations with compensation.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The Union has developed legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional assistance to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in global trade patterns or the global economic and financial crisis, as well as to help them rejoin the labour market, including the EGF. These funds aim to mitigate the disastrous social consequences of the economic crisis of the capitalist system. While these funds are unable to solve the problems of laid-off workers, they at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of the human drama.  In particular, this report, which I voted in favour of, is about giving the go-ahead to the funding of the EAGF Group of Experts on Contact Persons and the seminars to promote contacts on the implementation of the EGF, so that this exchange of information also contributes to providing better and more detailed information on the success rate of measures supported by the EGF in the Member States.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ EUR 380 000 has been requested for technical assistance at the initiative of the Commission to cover, inter alia, monitoring and data gathering as well as information, technical support and evaluation activities. This funding is necessary and I wish to allow access to this much-needed EGF funding.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I fully support measures aimed at setting policies that create growth and jobs. However, I do not consider the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to be the right and effective instrument for these policies. I therefore voted against.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 In February 2016, the Commission adopted a new proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the EGF concerning the mobilisation of EUR 380 000 for technical assistance to the Commission. The amount requested is intended to monitor and collect data on applications received, paid and executed and measures proposed and implemented. This data will be made available on the Website. Furthermore, the funds will be used to organise two seminars involving representatives of the EGF implementing bodies and the social partners in order to facilitate networking between Member States. In addition, the Commission continues to work on establishing standard procedures for EGF applications and managing them through the SFC 20143 function, where they are integrated. In this way, applications under the EGF Regulation can be simplified, processed at an accelerated rate and extracted data from them for different needs. I supported the motion for a resolution because the funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund are to be addressed to the applicant as soon as possible, and it is precisely the mobilisation of EUR 380 000 for the Commission that could guarantee rapid changes from the recording of the application to the final reimbursement to the beneficiaries.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 I support raising general awareness of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The European Parliament has therefore approved a financial contribution to the European Commission in the form of technical assistance for networking and exchange of information on this fund. The approved aid is also expected to provide more detailed reports on the success of the measures supported by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the Member States, in particular as regards the impact and rate of re-employment of beneficiaries.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ The role of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is to provide support and assistance to workers who are out of work with a view to re-entering the labour market. The EGF also temporarily supports young people who are not in employment, education or training and reside in regions eligible under the YEI.  The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund can only be used in companies where 500 workers have lost their jobs and the maximum available annual budget is EUR 150 million. The aim of this technical assistance is to finance monitoring and information, to advise Member States on the use of EGF funds, administrative and technical assistance and the evaluation of regulations. I support this report and consider that technical assistance is extremely important to inform Union citizens about the possibilities of using the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which regards an uncontroversial mobilisation of funds.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund supports people who have lost their jobs as a result of globalisation-related globalisation trade trends. The fund's budget is 150 million euros and can only be used if more than 500 people lost their jobs in one company. Technical assistance aims to finance more activities in order to improve the work of the fund itself and to inform future beneficiaries, such as the creation of a website for compensation claims and networking of Member States.  These measures will further facilitate access to the fund and encourage various meetings and seminars on the possibilities of using the funds. I support the European Parliament's proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to pay for technical assistance. The European Globalisation Fund plays an important role in the security of EU citizens in the event of job losses caused by globalisation. This stimulates the EU economy and secures the labour market.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of european globalisation adjustment funds – technical assistance at the initiative of the Commission. I support the Commission's proposal to use the amount of EUR 380 000 to cover the Commission's technical assistance. It is about monitoring and collecting data, informing, establishing a knowledge base, administrative and technical support and evaluation. I also support the report, which welcomes the inclusion of reporting in the electronic data exchange system, as this will reduce the administrative burden on Member States and simplify the use of reports for evaluation purposes.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 Although we disagree with the logic of the European Globalisation Fund, we voted in favour of the liberalisation of funds, because they support laid-off workers through various programmes.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should basically be given to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining programmes. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 On 22 February 2016, the Commission adopted a new proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the EGF. This proposal concerns the mobilisation of EUR 380 000 from the EGF reserve for technical assistance on the initiative of the Commission. The objective of technical assistance is to finance monitoring, information activities, to create a knowledge base interface and to provide advice to Member States on the use, monitoring and evaluation of the EGF. The activities financed will also help simplify the application procedure, ensure better information to the general public on the EGF, encouraging the visibility of this instrument. In particular, I welcome the integration of reporting into the electronic data exchange system (SFC2014). I believe that SFC2014 could also be used so that the Commission can obtain detailed information on the impact of EGF funding, in particular as regards the rates of reintegration of redundant workers who have received EGF funding. I support the adoption of this report and bet that this exchange of information will also contribute to better and more detailed reporting on the success rate of applications in the Member States.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. Parliament welcomes the measures proposed by the Commission as technical assistance and reiterates the importance of networking and information exchange on the EGF and, therefore, supports the funding of the WEF Contact Expert Group and networking seminars on the implementation of the WEF. Let us now hope that this exchange of information will also contribute to the development of better and more detailed reports on the success rate of EGF-supported measures in member states, in particular on the scope and re-employment rate of beneficiaries; Parliament also supports all initiatives for increased participation and consultation with local authorities who manage the measures supported by the WEF on a daily basis.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an important instrument in combatting the negative consequences of globalisation, helping workers who lost their job due to conditions outside of their control, to reintegrate the labour market as quickly as possible. The fund is key to reduce unemployment periods to their maximum, encourage labour flexibility and thus increase the competitiveness and sustainability of European market. I also believe that the EGF should help combat ongoing youth unemployment in Europe, by providing the education and training necessary for the youth to access jobs.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The European Union has set up legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers affected by major structural changes in world trade flows, the global financial and economic crisis, and to help them re-enter the labour market. While I support all measures to create jobs and growth, I believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund programme is not an effective tool for reintegration of redundancy and in principle I do not support its work.  For these reasons, I do not support the Commission's proposal to use additional €380,000 to cover, monitor and collect data, information, create a knowledge base, administrative and technical support and assessment activities of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, and voted against this proposal.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. The report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (application EGF/2016/000 TA 2016 – technical assistance at the initiative of the Commission) was supported. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. On 22 February 2016, the Commission adopted a new proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the EGF. It refers to an amount of EUR 380 000 from the Fund to cover the Commission's technical assistance. The objective of technical assistance shall be to finance the monitoring, information, establishment of an interface for the knowledge base and advice to Member States on the use, follow-up and evaluation of the EGF. In accordance with Article 11(1) of the EGF Regulation, 0,5 % of the maximum annual amount of the Fund (i.e. EUR 828 060 in 2016) may be made available for technical assistance at the initiative of the Commission.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of this report, as we consider it important and appropriate to mobilize part of the European Globalisation Adjustment Funds for technical assistance, i.e. in order to finance the activities of preparation, monitoring, data collection and creation of a knowledge base, technical and administrative support, information and communication activities, as well as audit activities , control and evaluation necessary for the implementation of the EGF Regulation. Since the current use of such funds is not due to the type of investment in the affected areas that, in our view, can help solve the problem, we believe that good work to monitor the impact of these funds could give the keys to being able to offer other alternatives that give sustainable exits to these areas and people , and don't just patch situations with compensation.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This text proposes a reform of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund with the aim of making it even more operational, but we must not give the illusion that it is the European Union that provides aid while the funds come from national taxpayers.  It is only the Member States that should return to the Member States.  I voted against this report.

name: István UJHELYI
