For this to happen, the European Union needs a financial instrument for providing emergency assistance, which will be made possible by the report I have adopted today. Thanks to the new instrument, we will finally be able to strengthen the staffing of individual migration and security agencies, which will at least partially reduce the burden on them.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The massive influx of refugees and migrants that entered Europe has created an exceptional situation where a large number of people are in need of urgent humanitarian assistance within the Union. I have voted for this report that will build a more sustainable legal and budgetary framework that will allow humanitarian aid to be mobilised within the Union in the future.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on a new instrument for the provision of emergency aid across the Union. Unfortunately, there is no adequate instrument at Union level to meet the humanitarian needs of the disaster-affected population across the Union. In the future, a more sustainable legal and budgetary framework should be provided to enable the mobilisation of humanitarian aid within the Union, where circumstances so require. In view of its specific nature, this emergency funding, intended to be a response to crises and contingencies, should be made available by special instruments and should not be covered by the ceilings set out in the multiannual financial framework.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I have chosen against Amending Budget No 1/2016 (New Instruments for the Provision of Emergency Aid within the Union). The rapporteur addressed Directive 2016/369/EU, which took place and was adopted without the involvement of the European Parliament. Accordingly, there was no ordinary legislative procedure under Article 294. While more solidarity has been called for among Member States and a sustainable budget and legal framework has been envisaged, the funds (EUR 100 000 000) from the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) will in turn be refinanced from the Emergency Fund. As there are already enough financial resources available for AMIF, I strongly reject the planned amending budget No 1/2016.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the EU's first amending budget for the 2016 financial year, providing for the creation of a permanent emergency humanitarian aid mechanism in the EU. In particular, this will help to relieve Greece, the first EU country affected by the refugee crisis.  An internal humanitarian aid mechanism to the Union had not previously existed, unlike for third countries, and it is in the context of the current humanitarian emergency in the Union that an envelope of 100 million euros in commitments and 80.2 million euros in payments was proposed.  This sum, mainly for civil society engaged on the ground, will complement and support the response to this crisis of the Member States.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against approving an extra EUR 100 million for the EU’s migration policy and EUR 2 million for extra staff at Europol. The EU has helped to create the refugee crisis by encouraging millions of people to come to Europe and make the dangerous journey across the Mediterranean. The EU has no right to make British taxpayers pay for its own failures. Countries should work together on a bilateral basis to solve the refugee crisis and fight terrorism, but not through unelected and unaccountable EU institutions.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 On this motion for a resolution, I voted in favour, as I believe that the influx of migrants and refugees into Europe requires a substantial economic and financial commitment to provide these people with humanitarian assistance. I therefore agree with the proposal that the EU budget should be used to respond adequately to the consequences of the refugee crisis in the coming years.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The huge influx of refugees and migrants into Europe has caused an emergency situation in which a large number of people need urgent humanitarian assistance. The crisis response capacity of most of the affected Member States is overburdened and this draft budget change aims to meet this challenge. €100 million in emergency funding appropriations should initially suffice, but I think we will soon face the need for additional funding.  I fully support the personnel strengthening of europol's European Counter Terrorism Centre so that this agency plays a key role in the fight against terrorism in the EU, in particular in light of the terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels. Funding the payment of new staff must by no means be a problem.  I join calls on the Commission to exclude from the 5% staff reduction plan all agencies whose work covers migration and security, as all these agencies are undercased. I fully support the purpose of the Commission's proposal for a draft budget change and the Council position, and have supported this report.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report proposes ineffective solutions: on the one hand 100 million euros for an umpteenth budgetary structure responsible for managing the migrant crisis, on the other hand the strengthening of the Europol agency, which has nevertheless demonstrated its blindness in the fight against terrorism by underestimating the risk of migrants being infiltrated by supporters of the so-called Islamic State.  The solution to these problems lies in the restoration of national sovereignty. I therefore vote against this text.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The continuing influx of refugees into Europe is putting a strain on the reception capacity of frontline states facing the burden of the crisis. Action by the European Union to support these countries is necessary and necessary. It has been said time and time again that solidarity is a fundamental principle of the Union and that only by acting together, as Europe, will we be able to overcome this situation, guaranteeing human rights and dignity to men, women and children forced to risk their lives on desperate journeys, in order to escape war and persecution. I therefore welcome the Commission's proposal to establish a European instrument to provide aid within the territory of the Union and I hope that, in addition to the emergency, more structured and sustainable measures will be envisaged to deal with a situation that, as we all know, will not be resolved in the short term. I also welcome the Commission's commitment not to take resources out of the external humanitarian aid budget. I welcome the decision to finance this new instrument by reallocation of appropriations from the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund. At the same time, however, I call for this funding to be subsequently compensated, to ensure that AMIF can carry out the relocation of the refugees for which it was created.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 The new associated emergency humanitarian assistance mechanism raises numerous doubts as to the procedure for implementing and using the associated funds and the concrete objectives they will serve. This new emergency instrument is created to respond belatedly to a humanitarian drama in which the EU has heavy responsibilities and has worsened over the past year as a result of the various responses it has implemented, such as the criminal agreement signed with Turkey. This draft budget is not supported by a strengthening of funds, but by the transfer of EUR 100 million from the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) to this new Emergency Fund. We note with alarm the concentration and expansion of power of Europol and its European Counter-Terrorism Centre, with the hiring of 25 more troops, which, on the pretext of the latest events in Paris and Brussels, will serve, yes, to strengthen surveillance of citizens, a natural consequence of the measures that are being adopted to this end.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒u2012 I support draft budget amendment No. 1/2016: New instruments to provide emergency support within the Union. I consider it important to adopt a new instrument aimed at providing urgent support within the EU.  In the event of extreme urgency with significant humanitarian impact, the EU must be able to support the country immediately, in order to save lives, avoid suffering and preserve human dignity. Support can be in food, housing, medicines, etc. Bearing in mind the current migrant crisis, I support the European Commission's assessment of allocating funding for this purpose, in order to create a structure within the EU budget.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the first draft amending budget this year, as it will allow the countries of the European Union affected by the migration crisis to provide emergency assistance of EUR 100 million. I consider it very important that the amending budget be approved as soon as possible, because it will also strengthen the european counter-terrorism centre, which should play a key role in preventing possible further attacks on the territory of the European Union. I am glad that the financing of both humanitarian aid and the fight against terrorism is not being addressed through relocation from other budget chapters and therefore other important policies are not being cut. However, I am not very pleased that this has only happened within the relevant third chapter of 'Security and Citizenship'. The funds in this chapter were also promised to other objectives. I therefore expect the Member States to behave reasonably and responsibly in the context of the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework and to approve the necessary increase in the budgetary ceilings. It is no longer possible to just move funds from one envelope to another or to create financial mechanisms outside the official budget. These actions only undermine transparency, legitimacy and trust.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I very much welcome the Commission's proposal to allow the EU budget to provide emergency aid to respond to the humanitarian consequences of the current refugee crisis. In addition, the proposal provides for an increase in the staff of Europol's European Counter-Terrorism Centre. These new economic resources will enable the Union to strengthen the spirit of solidarity and cooperation between its Member States in dealing with the repercussions of the current refugee crisis. In my work as a Member of the European Parliament, I have always fought to ensure that the first-port states, in particular Italy and Greece, are not left alone in the management of migratory flows. These economic resources are necessary to provide a concrete response. For all these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. As I supported the adoption of the draft amending budget as soon as possible, particularly to support Member States on the front line of the refugee crisis, I supported the adoption of a new instrument to provide emergency aid within the Union.  The aim here is to create a new chapter and two new budget lines, with 300 million euros in 2016 and 200 million in 2017 and 2018 to support the European countries that are most affected by the migration crisis.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against approving an extra EUR 100 million for the EU’s migration policy and EUR 2 million for extra staff at Europol. The EU has helped to create the refugee crisis by encouraging millions of people to come to Europe and make the dangerous journey across the Mediterranean. The EU has no right to make British taxpayers pay for its own failures. Countries should work together on a bilateral basis to solve the refugee crisis and fight terrorism, but not through unelected and unaccountable EU institutions.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this Resolution because the draft amending budget is intended for emergency humanitarian aid. In view of the deteriorating situation of migrants and asylum seekers, in particular because the response of European countries is not coordinated, it seems very opportune to me this amending budget proposal which, resulting in the creation of a specific budget line, thus assumes not to divert appropriations from the external humanitarian aid budget, since the Commission proposes to finance the first tranche of support under this new instrument by reallocating appropriations from the Asylum Fund , Migration and Integration (AMIF), which were already intended to allow the sharing of burdens with refugees between Member States. I therefore gave my positive vote. On the other hand, I agree with the proposal to increase the staff of europol's European Counter-Terrorism Centre, taking into account the current security situation in the European Union.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. The adoption of the first draft of the 2016 amending budget by MEPs will enable the release of EUR 100 million in emergency aid to refugees in the EU and EUR 2 million for the European Counter-Terrorism Centre (ECTC).  The EUR 100 million corresponds to the first tranche of the EUR 700 million promised by the Commission on 2 March in response to the humanitarian emergency caused by the large influx of refugees and migrants into the EU from Countries in Africa and the Near and Middle East.  The EUR 2 million will enable the ECTC to strengthen its workforce in the context of the serious terrorist threats that we are experiencing. The ECTC, established on 1 January 2016 within Europol, aims to become the main counter-terrorism centre in the EU. This new endowment should enable it to make progress in this direction.  The budgetary efforts made this afternoon, however, should not overshadow the real causes of these mass migrations and the rise of religious extremism. A strong, coherent, and canned European development and foreign affairs policy is needed to address the challenges of the 21st century.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 This draft amending budget has no net impact on the level of appropriations in the 2016 budget and essentially has a twofold objective: – To create a budgetary structure for the proposed new instrument to provide emergency support in the Union and for immediate financing needs;  – Strengthen staffing levels of europol's Counter-Terrorism Centre.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The proposed budget changes have two main objectives. On the one hand, enable emergency aid funds to address humanitarian needs arising from the refugee crisis. In particular, EUR 100 million in commitment appropriations and EUR 80.2 million in payment appropriations for the most immediate financing needs. On the other hand, funds are enabled to strengthen the staff of the European Centre for combating terrorism in Europol, namely 25 additional staffing posts, 5 contract agents and 5 national experts. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The European Parliament has adopted the report on the EU's amending budget No. 1/2016 and the first funding under the new instrument to provide emergency aid within the EU to relieve countries, such as Greece, which are experiencing a massive influx of refugees and migrants. The European Parliament has thus approved the redeployment within heading 3 (security) of the multi-year financial framework of 100 million euros in commitment appropriations for immediate funding needs under this new humanitarian aid mechanism on the territory of the Union. In general, MEPs also called for a more sustainable legal and budgetary framework in order, in the future, to be able to mobilise humanitarian aid within the Union when circumstances require it. The vote on this amending budget also strengthens the staff of the European Counter-Terrorism Centre within Europol and provides for the corresponding commitment and payment appropriations of EUR 2.0 million from a redeployment from the Internal Security Fund.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it reflects the realities of today and shows that Europe is aware of the need to respond to those realities. The report essentially proposes the establishment of emergency mechanisms to deal with exceptional humanitarian crises. There is also support for the proposed increase in the number of staff of europol's European Counter-Terrorism Centre, which is necessary to manage and address the situation.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. The migration and refugee crisis that has beset Europe has created an exceptional situation for thousands of people who are inanatably in need of emergency humanitarian aid from the Union. To that extent, thanks to the inability of the most affected Member States to respond and also at the lack of an appropriate instrument at European level to respond to this situation, a regulation was established to this end and, subsequently, an amending budget with a view to creating the budgetary structure capable of addressing immediate financing needs.  It is therefore in this report that it is in this report, which provides for EUR 100 million in commitment appropriations and EUR 80.2 million in payment appropriations, with the need to deal financially and from the outfront with the humanitarian consequences of the current refugee crisis. On the basis of the arguments put forward and attentive to the urgent nature of the situation, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the draft amending budget No. 1/2016.  This amending budget is part of the current migration crisis in the European Union: the aim is to create a new chapter and two budget lines that will be fed by 300 million euros in 2016, 200 million in 2017 and 200 million in 2018 to support the EU countries that are most affected by the migration crisis.  The first tranche of EUR 100 million in commitments will be financed by redeployment of the asylum, migration and integration fund funds, notably since the flexibility instrument has already been used in its entirety for 2016. The aim here is to allow the rapid adoption of this amending budget in order to support the countries of the Union which are on the front line of the refugee crisis.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We are refraining from supporting this report, since while we support the urgent sending of funds to assist in humanitarian aid for refugees, we do not see with good eyes that the same report mixes items for humanitarian aid with items for police, border and counter-terrorism control. This is a humanitarian crisis, and in We can openly disagree with the measures being taken by the EU, outsourcing to other countries of border control and the creation of 'Capon States', together with hot returns, without following the legislation itself on petitions for political asylum, and the rise of xenophobic prospects and state immobility in the face of this refugee crisis , leads us to refrain from supporting the deviating of these funds in this way in order to make up the EU's position.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The recent migration crises faced by the European Union have made it necessary to adopt new instruments for the provision of humanitarian assistance and aid within the EU itself, in particular to help border Member States cope with refugee flows.  That is why I voted in favour of the report, which provides for the allocation of EUR 700 million over the next three years to support the implementation of these support instruments. The project also includes the transfer of EUR 2 million from the Internal Security Fund with the aim of strengthening the level of training of the staff of the European Counter-Terrorism Centre, which is working alongside Europol in the fight against terrorism in the European Union.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution. There is a clear need to provide emergency support and provide it quickly within the EU, as well as the need to strengthen the European Counter-Terrorism Centre, which is tasked with combating the growing terrorist threat.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The massive influx of refugees and migrants into Europe has created an exceptional situation in which large numbers of people require urgent humanitarian assistance within the Union. That is why I supported the motion for a resolution, which increased the budget by EUR 100 million for emergency aid for refugees in the EU and EUR 2 million for the new staff of the European Counter-Terrorism Centre within Europol. For reasons of urgency, we approved the draft first amending budget in an accelerated legislative procedure. In the resolution, we welcomed the Commission's proposal to provide emergency assistance on union territory to address the humanitarian consequences of the current refugee crisis, and we highlighted the deteriorating situation of migrants and asylum seekers, particularly as a result of the uncoordinated response of European countries, which makes this emergency aid even more necessary and urgent. In the context of the recent terrorist attacks, we also appreciated the personal reinforcement of the European Counter-Terrorism Centre, which was established within Europol on 1 January 2016 and should become the central counter-terrorism body in the EU.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the draft amending budget providing emergency funding of EUR 100 million for refugees within the EU. This funding is intended to support the new instrument approved by the Council on 15 March 2016 to meet the humanitarian needs of those affected by disasters on the territory of the Union itself, in particular to respond to the exceptional situation that has been determined and could still be determined due to the massive influx of refugees and migrants into Europe. I regret, however, that the procedure chosen to create this ad hoc instrument does not involve Parliament, which has always been responsible for rapidly adopting proposals on the migration crisis. Furthermore, I agree with the rapporteur that the new emergency mechanism will be created in the absence of a comprehensive and shared strategy to deal with the refugee crisis, and to this end I hope that the other institutions and Member States will accept the proposals made by Parliament in its report on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for an overall approach to immigration.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. The first amending budget of the current year is taking the right steps: the introduction of a new budget line for the provision of emergency aid within the Union will ensure budgetary authenticity. The figure provides planning certainty for the years 2016 to 2018 and allows emergency aid to be rapidly delivered from the Union budget in the territory of the Union to deal with the humanitarian consequences of the current refugee crisis. This solution is a good simplification of procedures. I welcome the fact that funds are to be made available for this purpose through a redeployment in the budget. I would like to see the same for the funds in 2017/2018. The staff of the European Counter-Terrorism Centre, which is based at Europol, will also be increased. This is in line with our call for more resources to increase security in Europe. That is why I voted in favour of the Fernandes report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to address the humanitarian consequences of the refugee crisis, I welcome the Commission's proposal to provide emergency assistance on the territory of the Union from the Union budget. The uncoordinated response of European countries and the deteriorating situation of migrants and asylum seekers make such emergency aid even more necessary and urgent. As there is no appropriate instrument at Union level to address the humanitarian needs of persons affected by disasters within the Union, it is necessary to support the proposal for a Council Regulation aimed at filling the gap in the available instruments. In the future, an increase in the ceiling of the multiannual financial framework under Heading 3 is proving necessary to meet all the needs related to the refugee and migration crisis.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ Given the large influx of refugees and migrants, an emergency situation has arisen in Europe and a large number of people need urgent humanitarian assistance. The crisis response capacities of most of the Affected Member States are overburdened and there is no fully appropriate instrument to address the humanitarian needs of people who have suffered disasters and are currently located within the European Union.  The aim of this proposal is to develop a budget structure and complement existing instruments to meet humanitarian needs. The Commission estimates that this new instrument requires EUR 300 million in 2016 and EUR 200 million each in 2017 and 2018. It also proposes, given the current security situation, an increase in the number of employees at the European Counter Terrorism Centre.  I believe that it is necessary to allocate emergency assistance from the EU budget to cope with the increasing consequences of the migrant crisis, as well as to provide certainty to european union citizens, so I support this report.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ A large number of refugees and immigrants in Europe are on the lookout for urgent assistance. The Member States where the largest number of these people are located are unable to withstand such pressure financially. Accordingly, the Commission is proposing the introduction of a new financial instrument that will greatly facilitate the current situation.  It is proposed to adjust the allocation of funds currently made available to the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund by providing emergency assistance funds as soon as possible. Furthermore, the number of europol workforces at the Counter-Terrorism Centre needs to be increased in order to strengthen security that has been particularly at risk recently. The Commission proposal refers to a period of 3 years. I support the Commission's initiative to amend the budget, as this is an emergency situation in Europe. Moreover, Within its Budget Committee, Parliament adopted a proposal for a resolution in which it accepted all commission proposals and called for a change of budget as quickly as could be made. The fight against terrorism and the migration crisis should be addressed seriously and without hesitation, and they can only be solved if we adopt new instruments.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal. However, a significantly more effective way of combating terrorism is to consistently protect the external borders and prevent entry for those who are well suspected of being involved in terrorist activities. Moreover, strict border protection is also the only way in which the refugee crisis can be truly and sustainably resolved.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the Council position on draft amending budget No 1/2016 for the financial year 2016 – a new instrument for the provision of emergency assistance in the Union. In the European Union, we are facing a massive influx of refugees and migrants, which have caused a state of emergency and also triggered a humanitarian crisis. The European Union has grown on the basis of solidarity and must respond to the needs of the people on its territory. I support a new instrument for providing emergency assistance in the Union of EUR 300 million this year and EUR 200 million over the next two years. I also support the creation of a more permanent legal and budgetary framework for the use of humanitarian aid in the Union where circumstances require it.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed to strengthen europol's staffing level at the same time as funds are cut off from the Humanitarian Aid and Social Protection Fund.  We did not vote against the report, because part of the funds will be given to Greece for support on the refugee issue. We have abstained, always stressing that our perception of dealing with refugees must be solidarity and commitment to humanitarian values, not policing and isolating Member States or marginalising groups of the population. We have many years strongly condemned the racist, xenophobic voices of Member States, and we continue to express our solidarity with the refugees.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission proposes the establishment of a new emergency mechanism for humanitarian aid This is the transfer of EUR 100 million from the FUND to this new emergency fund. This represents around 10% of the EUR 1 billion earmarked for the relocation of 160000 migrants in the period 2015-2017. It should be noted that the AMS is already almost exhausted and that this transfer is therefore worrying. The management of the refugee crisis and the fight against terrorism is being mishandled by the institutions because the European citizen and his security are not prioritised. They turn a blind light to the huge influx of illegal immigrants, jihadists and criminal Islamic extremists who are exploiting refugee inflows to enter Europe. Tackling illegal immigration and terrorism is not achieved by setting up funds, which are more a means of manipulating public opinion than solving the problem. The problem is not economic, but social, religious, ethnic, and much more European.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution, which, on the basis of a proposal from the European Commission and a Resolution of the Council, allows the immediate establishment of a new ad hoc mechanism to address the effects of the refugee crisis. In my decision, I considered the serious humanitarian situation with regard to the flow of refugees to Europe, as well as the eu's latest agreement with Turkey, which creates additional urgent need for supply and funding. Under the new mechanism, 300 million euro of budgetary resources could be redeployed this year and an additional EUR 200 million per year in 2017-18, while I am reassured by the commitment set out in the resolution that the Commission is not doing so at the expense of the EU's external humanitarian aid framework.  I also consider it important for the Commission to undertake that the staff of EU organisations dealing with refugees and counter-terrorism should no longer be burdened with costs or redundancies, and that Europol's European counter-terrorism centre can expect an increase in staffing. However, in agreement with the foreth parties, I do not approve of the fact that, on the basis of a proposal from the Commission, this new emergency mechanism does not fit into the framework of a comprehensive asylum and migration strategy, thereby violating the European Parliament's decision-making rights; I trust that, after addressing the most urgent crisis situations, this shortcoming will also be remedied.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The massive influx of refugees and migrants into Europe has created an exceptional situation in which large numbers of people need emergency humanitarian assistance within the Union. This emergency has forced limits on the responsiveness of the Member States that have been most affected by this phenomenon. There is no adequate instrument at Union level to meet the humanitarian needs of the disaster-affected population across the EU. On 2 March 2016, the Commission presented a proposal for a Council Regulation aimed at filling in existing gaps in the instruments available in order to meet humanitarian needs arising throughout the Union. The Commission subsequently submitted a draft amending budget with the aim of creating the appropriate budgetary structure for the proposed instrument; EUR 300 million is required for this new instrument in 2016. I support the solution proposed by the Commission as a matter of urgency and support the adoption of draft amending budget No 1 of the European Parliament and of the Council. 1/2016 as a first step towards a global strategy to address the refugee crisis.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted positively. I particularly agree with the proposal to increase the number of staff at the European Counter-Terrorism Centre within Europol, given the current security situation in the European Union. It should be remembered that these increases are in addition to those already agreed in the recent revision of Europol's legal framework.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of a new instrument to address humanitarian needs within the EU, as the recent massive influx of refugees and migrants into Europe has created an exceptional emergency situation, which has overstretched the response capacity of the most affected countries. I particularly welcome the proposition to increase the staffing for Europol’s European Counter-Terrorism Centre, considering the current security situation. I also agree that all agencies dealing with migration and security should be exempted from the planned 5% cut in staff, given the remarkable increase in workload over the past two years. However, this crisis is also a lesson for the future. We need to come up with a flexible way how to mobilise humanitarian aid for inside the EU when it is outside the ceiling set out by the annual budget, if we want to be able to address such emergency situations with more dignity and efficiency than this time.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. The European Union is now experiencing unprecedented crises, including a migration phenomenon linked to the influx of refugees fleeing war and persecution by Daesh. While the closure of the borders of the Balkan countries has created a stalemate for refugees now stranded in Greece, we needed to act to support this country that hosts refugees from Syria. Greece cannot, and must, cannot bear the burden of its geographical location alone. We have the decision to release EUR 100 million for an emergency mechanism, which will help the country to welcome the arriving refugees. Moreover, the crisis caused by terrorist attacks leads us to take measures for the security of Europeans. We have directed an additional EUR 2 million for the new European Counter-Terrorism Centre, which will be able to strengthen its staff. If we have managed to redeploy money to the budget this time, the exceptional situation calls for exceptional resources. It will be necessary to find new funds when reviewing the multi-year financial framework: the response to new crises must not be funded at the expense of previous political priorities!

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported a Commission proposal aimed at complementing existing instruments to meet humanitarian needs within the European Union. In my view, this proposal is of utmost importance, as there has not been a single appropriate instrument at Union level to address the humanitarian needs of people who have suffered disasters and are now on the territory of the European Union. I believe the new instrument will allow the Union to act in a spirit of solidarity and to take care of the basic needs of victims affected by disasters. I also support the Commission's proposal to increase the number of staff at the European Counter Terrorism Centre within Europol and to make available appropriate commitment and payment appropriations of €2 million.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \ Report on the Council position on draft amending budget No 1/2016 for the financial year 2016 – I supported the new instrument for providing emergency assistance in the Union because the massive influx of refugees and migrants into Europe has led to an emergency situation in which many people need urgent humanitarian assistance that goes beyond the organisational capacities of one or more Member States. The capacity of most Member States to respond to this emergency has already been exhausted and there has been no adequate instrument at Union level to respond to the humanitarian needs of people affected by disasters. The Commission estimates that eur 300 million (EUR 200 million in 2017 and 2018) will be needed for this new instrument in 2016, but this amount may increase further if migrant and refugee flows are not reduced.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We are refraining from supporting this report, since while we support the urgent sending of funds to assist in humanitarian aid for refugees, we do not see with good eyes that the same report mixes items for humanitarian aid with items for police, border and counter-terrorism control. This is a humanitarian crisis, and in We can openly disagree with the measures being taken by the EU, outsourcing to other countries of border control and the creation of 'Capon States', together with hot returns, without following the legislation itself on petitions for political asylum, and the rise of xenophobic prospects and state immobility in the face of this refugee crisis , leads us to refrain from supporting the deviating of these funds in this way in order to make up the EU's position.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This text provides for two things: - the payment of a fund for migrant reception assistance; - the strengthening of Europol's workforce. These instruments will prove to be perfectly ineffective, costly and even harmful in creating a huge air call for future migrants.  Nor does the solution to countering terrorism be through a strengthening of a police institution that has underestimated the Islamic State and its ability to infiltrate.  The pragmatic solution is to regain control of our borders and establish refugee camps (thanks to the 6 billion euros promised to Turkey) in countries bordering war zones.  I voted therefore against this report.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission has proposed to establish an EU budget line to finance faster and more targeted emergency assistance within the Union by expanding the already available financial toolkit for dealing with emergencies within the Union. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We are refraining from supporting this report, since while we support the urgent sending of funds to assist in humanitarian aid for refugees, we do not see with good eyes that the same report mixes items for humanitarian aid with items for police, border and counter-terrorism control. This is a humanitarian crisis, and in Podemos we openly disagree with the measures being taken by the EU, outsourcing to other countries of border control and the creation of 'stopging states', together with hot returns, without following the legislation itself on petitions for political asylum, and the rise of xenophobic prospects and immobility of states in the face of this refugee crisis , leads us to refrain from supporting the deviating of these funds in this way in order to make up the EU's position.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this technical adjustment of the budget to allow for the new instrument for providing urgent assistance in the EU.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. This decision declares the European Parliament ready to approve draft amending budget No 1/2016 in view of the urgency of the decision in order to be able to provide assistance within the territory of the Union in order to deal with the humanitarian consequences of the current refugee crisis. We are talking about a necessary decision because of the urgency of the situation, so I consider it necessary to vote in your favour.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of this draft amending budget because the current refugee crisis is an unforeseen emergency that makes this draft necessary. I am particularly pleased with the decision to allocate more staff budget to Europol's European Counter Terrorism Centre. This will only improve the security situation in Europe.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The creation of a Union budget line to finance emergency support more rapidly and more specifically within the Union, when until now there was only one line to support eu external emergencies, has extended the range of available financial instruments. However, the new associated emergency humanitarian assistance mechanism raises many questions about how the associated funds will be used and for what ultimate purpose. Moreover, it is clear that this urgency has been/is created by the lack of a coherent strategy and vision to find a solution to the migration crisis at European level. This draft budget does not provide for new funds, as 100 million will be transferred from the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) to this new Emergency Fund. More serious, the power of Europol and its European Counter-Terrorism Centre is intensifying, with the hiring of 25 more troops, under the pretext of the latest events in Paris and Brussels. As we know, it is not only with the increase in staff that this will happen, unless the foreign policy of aggression and occupation changes that the EU is leading.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. There are already countless funds for asylum, migration and integration available.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in favour of this Amending Budget as we believe providing humanitarian aid inside the EU for the refugees fleeing conflict and poverty should be a priority and it is an area in which the EU can help. This mobilisation of funds does not increase the EU Budget but will however help support the countries bearing the greatest burden as well as the refugees themselves.  Separately this Amending Budget reinforces the staffing levels of the European Counter-Terrorism Centre in EUROPOL, to enable the agency to play a central role in the fight against terrorism in the EU, in particular in the light of the recent terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels. Again this is a priority area and we support European co-operation to prevent terrorist attacks.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 On 10 March, the European Commission presented draft amending budget (PBR) No 1 for 2016, which relates in particular to the new instrument providing emergency support within the Union, i.e. to cover the financing of support operations to meet the urgent and exceptional humanitarian needs encountered in the Member States as a result of the massive influx of third-country nationals (refugees and migrants) into their territories. The emergency response can include assistance, rescue and protection operations, aimed at saving and protecting lives in disaster or post-emergency situations. With this amending budget, therefore, 100 million in commitments and 80.2 million in payments to meet immediate financial needs are made available through realassignments under heading 3 of the MFF. I am pleased that the Commission has endeavoured to find these funds within the EU budget without any further increases, but I am very perplexed that these transfers come from the budget line concerning the AMIF fund (asylum, migration and integration), which has absolute priority.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Fernandes report, which approves the draft amending budget, to provide the EU with a new emergency support instrument in the European Union, providing it with the resources needed to address the humanitarian urgency created by the refugee crisis.  Given that there was no adequate instrument at Union level to respond at the scale of the problem, this budgetary correction is essential not only because of the urgency of responding to the exceptional situation in which a large number of people in need of humanitarian aid in the Union, but also because this emergency situation exceeds the responsiveness of the most affected Member States.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \ i supported the draft amending budget, which alloes emergency financial assistance to cope with the emergencies caused by the refugee, humanitarian and security crisis in the Union.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 Appointments to the Court of Auditors should be reserved for persons of marked professionalism and independent of politics. Nevertheless, in these appointments I have found that there are nominations directly from the political world. Furthermore, although not provided for by law, gender equality has not been respected. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote against.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted against the 5 candidates proposed to be members of the Court of Auditors for various reasons: because of their lack of independence, the possibility of conflict of interest, the lack of professional knowledge in the field of audit, as well as the lack of gender balance, since they are all men.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted against this Nomination to the Court of Auditors on the grounds that none of the candidates including Samo Jereb, held the required level of professional qualifications or expertise that would be required to satisfactory fulfil the post. My parties’ policy has always been about transparency, accountability and diversity on all boards, including State Boards. In Ireland, we have seen first had the corrosive culture of cronyism. We are still seeing it in the cronyism of debacle which is currently occurring around Government Formations. Furthermore, despite concerns being raised by the European Parliament on a number of occasions, all 6 candidates nominated were men. This is completely unacceptable and serves only to undermine any positive advances which have been made in recent years to increase the number of women in public life. Sinn Fein will have no hand or part in any such regressive, duplicitous or purposely vague moves. The society we are aiming for is one that is real, meaningful and where issues such as gender equality will be truly tackled and where cronyism is confined to the political dustbin of life.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This vote was by secret ballot, I cannot reveal my choice. For the appointment of the members of the European Court of Auditors, I voted on the basis of three criteria: probity, independence from political forces and competences.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I believe in democracy and transparency, and therefore I believe that my vote on this matter should be a matter of public record. In that spirit, I wish to confirm that I abstained on this appointment.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee responsible for the substance.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I supported Mr Jereb's candidacy as a member of the Court of Auditors: his previous career as an auditor, his current position as Vice-President of the Slovenian Court of Auditors, and his love for his country reveal to us a distant profile of those Eurocrats who give in to the sirens of free trade and federalism at the expense of the peoples of Europe. Let's hope he doesn't re-admit his commitments.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. For my vote, I took into account the report and the vote in the Committee on Budgetary Control.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors is an important European institution which plays the role of external and independent auditor of the Union. Founded in 1977, it only became a fully-capacity EU institution in 1993 and continued to provide support for improving the management of the Community budget. It shall consist of one member from each State of the Union, each of which shall be appointed by the Council after consulting Parliament and shall remain in office for six years.  On this occasion, Parliament was called upon to give its opinion on the appointment of Samo Jereb. Having taken note of the content of the report by the Committee on Budgetary Control and following the advice of my political group (S&D), I voted in secret on the proposed name.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. The selection procedure for the members of the Court of Auditors was highly criticized. However, most candidates lack the right professional knowledge and show strong indications of a potential conflict of interest. None of the candidates presented at the required level of professional knowledge for the position were nor were they able to ensure that they would be able to perform their tasks with the necessary degree of independence. Despite the European Parliament's systematic requests for previous Council reports, the Court of Auditors has an extraordinary gender imbalance that is exacerbated by current nominations, the 6 candidates are men. For all these reasons, we vote against all proposals.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This is the appointment (or renewal) of a Member of the European Court of Auditors. The European Parliament is consulted on their appointment. Mr Samo Jereb is the current Vice-President of the Slovenian Court of Auditors. He was already an auditor. He wanted to mention his time as a reserve officer (captain) in the Slovenian army, which is positive, so I voted for it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not question the professional skills of this candidate, but I do not have enough elements to give him my full support, so I abstained.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. This morning the Plenary of the European Parliament put to the vote, in secret, the proposal to appoint Samo Jereb as a member of the Court of Auditors following the evaluation of the candidate's qualifications and the hearing held on 15 March before the Committee on Budgetary Control, a vote in which I participated.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of appointing the Slovenian candidate, Samo Jeeb, as a Member of the Court of Auditors. Until now, Samo Jereb has served as Vice-President of the Court of Auditors of the Republic of Slovenia. The scope of this candidate's work is limited and covers all jurisdictions of the Slovenian Court of Auditors and all types of audit, i.e. financial audit, regularity/compliance audit or performance audit. At the same time, half of the work of the Slovenian Court of Auditors was directly monitored and controlled. It was specifically responsible for closely monitoring the implementation of the audit of the regularity and performance of the banking asset management company, as well as audits of the largest investments in recent years (construction of Block 6 of the Šoštane Thermal Power Plant), bearing in mind the impact on the profits or losses and cash flows of holding Slovenske elektrarne (Slovenia's largest organisation in the field of electricity production) and the Slovenian state holding company.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \u2012 With my support of the Slovenian candidate for member of the Court of Auditors of the EU, I am pleased to find that the Slovenian has received the most support from meps. It turns out that he is a competent candidate with experience who will be able to easily do this responsible job.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 When appointing a new member of the Court of Auditors, both the provisions of Article 286(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and Article 121 of the Rules of Procedure were taken into account and subsequently the Committee on Budgetary Control assessed the qualifications of the proposed candidate, taking into account the conditions laid down in Article 286(1) of the Treaty which directly concern the functioning of the EU. After the Committee on Budgetary Control heard the candidate proposed by the Council to be a member of the Court of Auditors, it issued a favourable opinion on the appointment of Samo Jereb to be a member of the Court of Auditors, thus leaving only the President's task to transmit the Council's decision and, for information, both the Court of Auditors and the other EU institutions , but also to the control institutions of the Member States. I voted in favour of the report on the appointment of a member of the Court of Auditors – Samo Jereb, because I believe that he has sufficient professional experience to be a member of the Court of Auditors and, with his appointment as a member, an addition will be added to the EU and the Member States.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 On 1 February 2014 he was appointed member of Section II - Structural Policies, Transport and Energy; He is also rapporteur for the chapter Economic, Social and Territorial Cohesion and is responsible for carrying out the audit for the purposes of the DAS and management control in the field of regional policy and the Structural Funds. He is the member representing Section II in the CEAD Section, and has also been rapporteur for several management controls. Abstention vote.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the instructions of the S&D Group, I voted against. In particular, the evaluation was based on the candidate's hearing in the CONT Committee. Despite having a good resume, his presentation was not the best. For many of the questions he was asked, he untangled with considerable effort. A major limitation has been language, which is fundamental to the position for which he is a candidate: although he has indicated an average/high level of English, he has not been able to prove it, so as to be unconvincing and far from certain.  In the questionnaire, on the other hand, it was accurate and prolex. He answered all the questions in full and sincerely, confirming that his current position as Vice-President of COARS, as well as his position as Vice-President of the Court of Auditors in Slovenia, were politically appointed.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this Nomination to the Court of Auditors on the grounds that none of the candidates including Samo Jereb, held the required level of professional qualifications or expertise that would be required to satisfactory fulfil the post. My parties’ policy has always been about transparency, accountability and diversity on all boards, including State Boards. In Ireland, we have seen first had the corrosive culture of cronyism. We are still seeing it in the cronyism of debacle which is currently occurring around Government Formations. Furthermore, despite concerns being raised by the European Parliament on a number of occasions, all 6 candidates nominated were men. This is completely unacceptable and serves only to undermine any positive advances which have been made in recent years to increase the number of women in public life. Sinn Fein will have no hand or part in any such regressive, duplicitous or purposely vague moves. The society we are aiming for is one that is real, meaningful and where issues such as gender equality will be truly tackled and where cronyism is confined to the political dustbin of life.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this appointment not so much because of a personal matter with the candidate but for different reasons. First of all, I regret seeing a fairly marked gender imbalance: out of 28 members, only 5 are women. Where is gender equality? The Member States and the Council should be the first to give a signal to promote gender equality in all institutions and at all levels. In addition, the system of appointing members continues to be a system of political appointment, more than merit. For these reasons, I have decided to vote against all the candidates.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the appointment of Samo Jereb.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the decision of the EPP Cont members and voted in favour of Mr Jareb.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the appointment of Samo Jereb as a new member of the Court of Auditors. My warmest congratulations and good wishes for a good job go to him.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ I see no reason to oppose the favourable opinion on the Council’s by the CONT committee. I accept the opinion of the CONT committee regarding the nomination of Samo Jereb as a Member of the Court of Auditors, thus I voted in favour of his nomination.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted against the 5 candidates proposed to be members of the Court of Auditors for various reasons: because of their lack of independence, the possibility of conflict of interest, the lack of professional knowledge in the field of audit, as well as the lack of gender balance, since they are all men.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the appointment of Mr Samo Jereb as a member of the European Court of Auditors. He is an accomplished professional, who has a career of more than 20 years in the field of audit, with outstanding results at the head of the Court of Auditors of the Republic of Slovenia.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Partial replacement of the composition of the Members of the Court of Auditors takes place in accordance with Article 286(2) TFEU, which provides that the Council adopts a list of candidates proposed by the Member States after consulting the European Parliament. The members of the Court of Auditors shall be appointed for a period of six years. The appointment and renewal of appointments shall be voted on in plenary on the basis of the CONT report. Candidates must comply with the requirements laid down in Article 286(1) TFEU: Members of the Court of Auditors shall be chosen from among persons who are or have been members of external audit bodies in their own countries or who are particularly qualified to take up that post. Their independence must be unquestionable. I supported the candidate in the vote.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. The terms of office of the six members of the Court of Auditors expire on 6 May 2016. After consultation with the European Parliament, the Council will adopt the list of members. Six candidates were nominated by the Member States: one Slovak candidate, one Latvian, one Czech, one Polish, one Maltese and one Slovenian.  Considering that the CONT Committee had expressed doubts about three candidates and offered a favourable opinion on three nominations (the Latvian, Czech and Slovenian candidates), I voted in favour of the appointment of Mr Kozlovs, the Latvian candidate, Mr Gregor, the Czech candidate, and Mr Jereb, the Slovenian candidate.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 Having fulfilled all the formalisms concerning the appointment of Samo Jereb as a member of the Court of Auditors, in particular the assessment of her qualifications and her hearing, and there being no obstacle to her appointment, I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors (ECA) functions as a collegiate body of 28 members, one member of each Member State. These members shall be appointed by the Council, after consulting the European Parliament, for a renewable period of six years. The deadline for 6 of these posts will expire soon, and 6 new candidates have been proposed by the Member States. In a joint assessment of the universe of candidates, doubts are raised as to the full fulfilment of criteria of competence and professional experience, as to the political profile and independence, as to the suitability of the specific place and as to the existence of conflicts of interest. Some of these reasons prompted the rejection of some of the candidates in the Specialised Committee of the European Parliament responsible for assessing applications (Committee on Budgetary Control). Also in a global assessment, there is a lack of gender balance. There's not a single woman among the candidates. These are aspects that have weighed on our group's position in this vote.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the appointment of Samo JEREB as a Member of the Court of Auditors as Mr Jereb's CV and his work are truly remarkable. He has experience in the fight against corruption and waste of resources.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The ECA operates as a collegiate body of 28 Members, one from each Member State. The Members are appointed by the Council after consultation with the European Parliament for a renewable term of six years. Members elect one of their number as President for a renewable term of three years. I supported his nomination.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the appointment of Mr Samo Jereb as a member of the European Court of Auditors.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the appointment of Samo Jereb as a member of the Court of Auditors, as this selection of staff convinced me after examination.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. The selection procedure for the members of the Court of Auditors was highly criticized. However, most candidates lack the right professional knowledge and show strong indications of a potential conflict of interest. None of the candidates presented at the required level of professional knowledge for the position were nor were they able to ensure that they would be able to perform their tasks with the necessary degree of independence. Despite the European Parliament's systematic requests for previous Council reports, the Court of Auditors has an extraordinary gender imbalance that is exacerbated by current nominations, the 6 candidates are men. For all these reasons, we vote AGAINST all proposals.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ The European Court of Auditors is in charge of the audit of EU finances and as the EU’s external auditor, it contributes to improving EU financial management and acts as the independent guardian of the financial interests of the citizens of the Union. It is vitally important that candidates for the Court are selected based on their suitability for the position, their professional background, language skills and the ability to exercise independent judgement are important considerations.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the nomination of Samo Jereb as a Member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted against the proposal for the candidate under reference on the basis of the apparent lack of independence and the possibility of a conflict of interest that undermines both the mission and the role of the Court of Auditors as an independent EU external auditor and "financial supervisor", as well as because of the lack of gender balance.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the nomination of the member of the Court of Auditors, Samo Jereb.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. \u2012 I voted for a proposal for a decision of the European Parliament on the proposed appointment of Sam Jereb as a member of the Court of Auditors on the basis that Mr Jereb proved his expertise in serving as Deputy President of the Court of Auditors of the Republic of Slovenia and the Supreme State Auditor. The skills and competences he acquired during his professional career indicate that Mr Jereb is qualified for the post and that his independence is not in doubt. I believe that Mr. Jereb will serve as a member of the Court of Auditors responsibly and conscientiously, and therefore I vote for this report.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. Current Vice-President of the Slovenian Court of Auditors. Consistent listener's preliminary path. Rather patriotic, he wanted to mention his time as a reserve officer (captain) in the Slovenian army. I voted for it.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Bart Staes' report on the appointment of Mr Samo Jereb as a member of the Court of Auditors.  This text approves the application proposed by the Council after a hearing by the Committee on Budgetary Control. Having served as Supreme Comptroller and Vice-President of the Court of Auditors of the Republic of Slovenia, Mr. Jereb has the necessary qualifications to hold this position. This appointment was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This report concerns the nomination of Mr Samo Jereb as a member of the Court of Auditors. I am abstaining on this report.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The application proposed by the Council to appoint Samo Jereb as a member of the Court of Auditors was considered valid following a thorough analysis of the applicant's credentials and personal background. I am therefore voting in favour of his appointment and wish him well in his work.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted against the 5 candidates proposed to be members of the Court of Auditors for various reasons: because of their lack of independence, the possibility of conflict of interest, the lack of professional knowledge in the field of audit, as well as the lack of gender balance, since they are all men.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒Members of the EU Court of Auditors review the revenues and expenditures of all Union institutions and agencies. In 2016, 10 members of the Court of Auditors will be appointed and new members will be appointed for a period of six years. In order to become members of the Court of Auditors, candidates first have a hearing in the Committee on Budgetary Control, which gives its opinion on candidates.  After that, each candidate shall be voted on at parliament's plenary session, based on a report from the Committee. Each Member State shall submit a proposal for a candidate for a member of the Court of Auditors and the Council shall decide on the list of the best candidates who then have a hearing in the Committee on Budgetary Control and are finally confirmed at parliament's session. The candidate for member of the Court of Auditors, Samo Jereb, is the president of the Court of Auditors in Slovenia, and before that he was the auditor of the Supreme Court. Given Mr. Jereb's nearly 20 years of experience, I supported the report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Court of Auditors functions as an independent external auditor, which regularly monitors the management of the Union budget by the European Commission and consistently reports on the current financial situation, together with recommendations for its improvement. Although that institution has no legal power, its importance in terms of financial verification is undeniable. This, in turn, means that the 28 members of the European Court of Auditors , one from each EU Member State, are the most qualified financial professionals who have proved themselves in their home country on a long-term job and whose primary task is, in fact, to monitor the Union's finances in such a way as to guarantee the interests of its citizens, i.e. taxpayers. I voted negatively when examining and analysing Mr Jereba's candidacy and paying the utmost attention to his professional experience and a number of other factors. However, he was elected with 404 votes in favour and 222 against.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the proposed appointment of Samo Jereb as a member of the Court of Auditors as I do not agree with key points in that report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The Court of Auditors aims to improve the FINANCIAL management of the EU and encourage transparency. It verifies whether the EU budget has been properly implemented and whether EU funds have been collected and spent legally and in accordance with the principles of good financial management.  The Court is composed of 28 members (one per Member State) appointed by the Council, after consultation with Parliament, for a renewable term of six years. The selection process at the Court of Auditors has long been widely criticised for its lack of transparency and lack of independence of candidates, who generally do not have the professional skills required for this position.  The Slovenian candidate, Mr Samo JEREB having no experience of budgetary discharges, which are one of the essential elements of this post, I vote against.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors is a supervisory institution, which verifies the legality and regularity of EU revenue and expenditure, as well as good financial management, carrying out its functions with complete independence. In this spirit, the appointment of the individualities that compose it must be governed by criteria of competence and independence. Thus, at the initiative of the Council, several personalities from various EU countries were appointed to the Court of Auditors. The applicant submitted his Curriculum Vitae, replied to a written questionnaire and was heard in the Committee on Budgetary Control and put forward sufficient arguments to justify the appointment to the Court of Auditors in order to carry out his duties there competently and independently. I voted in favor of the name Of Samo Jereb.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I congratulate Samo Jereb on his appointment as a member of the Court of Auditors. Vice-President of the Court of Auditors of the Republic of Slovenia in 2013, Samo Jereb did not hesitate to supplement his knowledge with various trainings related to this function, such as that of auditor, or legal auditor of auditors.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Samo Jereb was appointed a member of the Court of Auditors. The appointment is the responsibility of the Council, but it must consult Parliament before deciding. The Committee on Budgetary Control evaluated the candidate's capabilities and listened to the candidate at its meeting on 15 March 2016. In its report, it proposes that Parliament give a favourable opinion on the Council's proposal to appoint Samo Jereb as a Member of the Court of Auditors. I supported the nomination of the candidate.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ The European Court of Auditors is in charge of the audit of EU finances and as the EU’s external auditor, it contributes to improving EU financial management and acts as the independent guardian of the financial interests of the citizens of the Union. It is vitally important that candidates for the Court are selected based on their suitability for the position, their professional background, language skills and the ability to exercise independent judgement are important considerations.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report which approves the appointment of Samo Jereb as a member of the Court of Auditors. Samo Jereb was interviewed by the Committee on Budgetary Control. The members of this committee approved this nomination by a very large majority.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted the nomination of Samo Jereb as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering the assessment of the Committee on Budgetary Control regarding the candidate's qualifications and his suitability for the position under consideration, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The Court of Auditors is important for monitoring and controlling the use of EU funding, and its independence and the quality of work of judges guarantee the protection of the interests of all EU citizens. I supported the proposal to appoint Sam Jereb as a member of the Court of Auditors following the assessment of the qualifications of candidates carried out by the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control and after the hearing.  Since Jereb has dedicated his 20-year career to revision, he is a great fit for this function. As Deputy President of the Court of Auditors of Slovenia, with a field of work covering all the competences of the Court of Auditors of Slovenia and all types of audits (financial audits, regularity audits/compliance audits and performance audits), I believe that he has acquired the necessary knowledge, experience and skills to successfully serve as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. Currently Vice-President of the Slovenian Court of Auditors, Samo Jereb has completed a consistent prior auditor's career. Rather patriotic, he wanted to mention his time as a reserve officer (captain) in the Slovenian army. So I'm voting in favor of his appointment.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. Jereb has devoted his entire 20-year career to auditing. Immediately after obtaining his diploma in November 1995, he took a job at a private audit firm and underwent all stages of audit training and practical audit work. Due to his work with utility providers, he was summoned to the Court of Auditors of the Republic of Slovenia and, as the Supreme State Auditor, led the Audit Department.  Only Jereb, in his recital and answers to questions from committee members, noted that he believed that his extensive experience in public sector auditing, management and teaching experience and conducting joint or comparative audits with SAIs were a key asset for the implementation of the ECA's activities.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors (ECA) functions as a collegiate body of 28 members, one member of each Member State. These members shall be appointed by the Council, after consulting the European Parliament, for a renewable period of six years. The deadline for 6 of these posts will expire soon, and 6 new candidates have been proposed by the Member States. In a joint assessment of the universe of candidates, doubts are raised as to the full fulfilment of criteria of competence and professional experience, as to the political profile and independence, as to the suitability of the specific place and as to the existence of conflicts of interest. Some of these reasons prompted the rejection of some of the candidates in the Specialised Committee of the European Parliament responsible for assessing applications (Committee on Budgetary Control). Also in a global assessment, there is a lack of gender balance. There's not a single woman among the candidates. These are aspects that have weighed on our group's position in this vote.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors is a collegiate body composed of 28 members, one for each Member State. The latter shall be appointed by the Council, after consulting the European Parliament, for a renewable period of six years. I welcome the appointment of Samo Jereb as a member of the Court of Auditors and wish him well in his work, in the hope that he will be able to play his role with the utmost independence and transparency in the general interest of the European Union.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. We have been asked to rule on the appointment of a member of the European Court of Auditors. This procedure demonstrates the usefulness of Parliament in exercising its control over the functioning of the European institutions.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the Committee on Budgetary Control has assessed the qualifications of Samo Jereb, in particular as to the conditions laid down in Article 286(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, I welcome the favourable vote in this report, which gives its assent to the Council's proposal to appoint the candidate for the post of member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. This morning the Plenary of the European Parliament put to the vote, in secret, the proposal to appoint Samo Jereb as a member of the Court of Auditors following the evaluation of the candidate's qualifications and the hearing held on 15 March before the Committee on Budgetary Control, a vote in which I participated.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Parliament this lunchtime approved the appointment of Slovenian auditor Samo Jereb to the European Court of Auditors by 404 votes to 222 and 70 abstentions, but rejected the Polish auditor's candidacy, according to the recommendations of the Committee on Budgetary Control. It should be noted that Toni Abela, the Maltese candidate, withdrew his candidacy following the unfavourable opinion of the commission. The final decision on assignment to Luxembourg will be taken by the EU Council of Ministers.  Members of the Court of Auditors are appointed for six years. The Council, after consulting the European Parliament, makes its decision according to the proposals made by each Member State.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of appointing the Slovenian candidate, Samo Jeeb, as a Member of the Court of Auditors. He is currently vice-president of the Court of Auditors of the Republic of Slovenia, has worked as chief public auditor and holds a bachelor's degree in economics (accounting and economics) at the University of Ljubljana.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This nomination proposal has already been assessed by the Committee on Budgetary Control in accordance with criteria of rigour and transparency. Having submitted a proposal by the Council on 15 March 2016 and the selection process has been carried out in an open and transparent manner, I agree with the appointment of Samo Jereb as Member of the Court of Auditors, since, at the hearing by the Committee on Budgetary Control of the proposed candidate, he demonstrated proven competence and proven professional experience for the full performance of these functions.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. The selection procedure for the members of the Court of Auditors was highly criticized. However, most candidates lack the right professional knowledge and show strong indications of a potential conflict of interest. None of the candidates presented at the required level of professional knowledge for the position were nor were they able to ensure that they would be able to perform their tasks with the necessary degree of independence. Despite the European Parliament's systematic requests for previous Council reports, the Court of Auditors has an extraordinary gender imbalance that is exacerbated by current nominations, the 6 candidates are men. For all these reasons, we vote against all proposals.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted against the 5 candidates proposed to be members of the Court of Auditors for various reasons: because of their lack of independence, the possibility of conflict of interest, the lack of professional knowledge in the field of audit, as well as the lack of gender balance, since they are all men.

name: Siôn SIMON
