text: in writing. ‒ The European Court of Auditors plays a vital role in the institutions, being in charge of the audit of the EU’s finances and, as the EU’s external auditor, it contributes to improving the financial management of the EU as well as acting as the independent guardian of the financial interests of the EU’s half a billion citizens. In my view, it is vitally important that candidates for the Court are selected based on their suitability for the position, their professional backgrounds, language skills and the ability to exercise independent judgment are all important for considerations. In the case of Samo Jereb I have chosen not to support his nomination because I do not believe that he did not fulfil the criteria I described above. However, in light of the support that he has received from the European Parliament today, I must add that despite lacking the necessary language skill, he appears to be very competent and I wish him the best of luck in his nomination.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the fact that as a Member of the Court of Auditors, a representative from each EU member country can check that EU funds are being correctly collected and used and help improve EU financial management.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported Sam Jereb's candidacy for a member of the European Court of Auditors because I believe that his professional experience to date shows his professional competence. He has been in the field of auditing since the beginning of his professional career for more than twenty years. Immediately after graduating from university, he was employed by a private audit firm and shortly afterwards became a certified auditor. Having worked with public service providers and municipalities for a long time, he was invited to the Court of Auditors of the Republic of Slovenia in 2004, where he became chief state auditor. In recent years, he has actively participated in audits of government and non-governmental budget consumers, judicial consumers of the state budget and political parties. Since 2013, he has been the second Deputy President of the Slovenian Court of Auditors and is responsible for audits where an objection to the audit report has been lodged, regardless of the scope of the audit. In his career he has already participated in international projects, especially in the field of environmental audits, as he managed several international environmental audits in cooperation with the highest international state institutions, where he also demonstrated his ability to work in English. In addition to his/her functions as a certified auditor, a verified state auditor and a verified internal state auditor, he is also involved in the organization of seminars and educational programmes. In view of this, I am convinced that it will perform its function conscientiously and independently of external influences.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The Court of Auditors has a great responsibility in controlling the use of European funds and assessing the added value of EU policies. Candidates for members of the Court of Auditors must therefore demonstrate superior professional competence and full independence. The Committee on Budgetary Control has assessed the candidate's professional qualifications, in particular in the light of the requirements of Article 286(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and approved the Council's proposal to appoint Jereb himself as a member of the Court of Auditors. Only Jereb has 20 years of professional experience as an auditor, first in the private sector and in the last 12 years at the Court of Auditors of the Republic of Slovenia (formerly as the Supreme State Auditor and then as Deputy President of the Court of Auditors of the Republic of Slovenia). Jereb is not a member of any political party. Its areas of expertise include State aid rules, public service pricing, taxes, public debt and environmental audit. In his presentation to the Committee on Budgetary Control, Jereb demonstrated that, through his concrete and progressive ideas, he can make a significant contribution to improving cooperation between the European Court of Auditors and the National Supreme Audit Institutions. For this above, I voted in favour of his appointment in the vote.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒Given that the Committee on Budgetary Control assessed the qualifications of the proposed candidate, in particular as regards the conditions set out in Article 286(1) of the EIA. the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and at the meeting of the Committee on Budgetary Control of 15 March 2016, I supported the appointment of Sam Jereb as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ The European Court of Auditors is in charge of the audit of EU finances and as the EU’s external auditor, it contributes to improving EU financial management and acts as the independent guardian of the financial interests of the citizens of the Union. It is vitally important that candidates for the Court are selected based on their suitability for the position, their professional background, language skills and the ability to exercise independent judgement are important considerations.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The Court of Auditors plays a unique role that involves instilling trust in the democratic institutions of the European Union. It is therefore important that all members of the Court of Auditors perform their duties to the highest expectations of EU citizens and contribute with their impartiality, objectivity and integrity to the work of the Court of Auditors and cooperation with the European Parliament. I support the draft report on the proposed appointment of Sam Jereb as a member of the Court of Auditors. Jereb itself is a quality candidate for a member of that court and his knowledge, competence and professionalism will be of great value and benefit to the work of the Court of Auditors in terms of cooperation between the court and different institutions, in particular the European Parliament, as well as with regard to other tasks of the Court of Auditors.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The selection of persons for positions of responsibility and Union interest should be based on the integrity of their character and their proven activity with regard to the protection of public money in the broadest sense

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. We have received, studied and issued an opinion on this person's candidacy as a member of the Court of Auditors. The Committee on Budgetary Control assessed the qualifications of the proposed candidate, particularly in light of the conditions set out in Article 286, paragraph 1, of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. A hearing was then undertaken during the month of March by the Council concerning the function of a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the nomination of Samo Jereb as a member of the Court of Auditors. I am certain that his experience at the Court of Audit of the Republic of Slovenia as a Supreme State Auditor, and his experience in audit in the private sector will provide with the tools needed to deliver an excellent job.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The ECA should provide the European Parliament with audit reports that address topics relevant to Parliament and are timely and relevant and contain recommendations that can help to add value to the expenditure of the European Union budget. To this end, the auditor must exhaustively review specific business processes, choose comparable best practices and determine what could be best done.  In view of the education and experience in the field of accounting and auditing gained through audit work as well as through international programmes and projects, I supported Sam Jereb's candidacy as a member of the Court of Auditors. I believe that Mr. Jereb will perform his new function honestly and honorably and use numerous experiences to perform his duties as efficiently as possible.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. In my report on the appointment of Sam Jereb as a Member of the Court of Auditors, I voted in my conscience – a secret vote. The Committee on Budgetary Control has assessed the candidate's professional qualifications, in particular in the light of the requirements laid down in Article 286(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. At its meeting of 15 March 2016, the Committee on Budgetary Control listened to the presentation of the Council's candidate for member of the Court of Auditors and approved the Council's proposal to appoint Samo Jereb as a member of the Court of Auditors and instruct its President to forward this Decision to the Council and, for information, to the Court of Auditors, as well as to the other institutions of the European Union and the audit authorities of the Member States.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. The selection procedure for the members of the Court of Auditors was highly criticized. However, most candidates lack the right professional knowledge and show strong indications of a potential conflict of interest. None of the candidates presented at the required level of professional knowledge for the position were nor were they able to ensure that they would be able to perform their tasks with the necessary degree of independence. Despite the European Parliament's systematic requests for previous Council reports, the Court of Auditors has an extraordinary gender imbalance that is exacerbated by current nominations, the 6 candidates are men. For all these reasons, we vote against all proposals.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control evaluated the capabilities, history and professionalism of the proposed candidate. I voted to follow S&D's position on the nomination of the candidate.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. The selection procedure for the members of the Court of Auditors was highly criticized. However, most candidates lack the right professional knowledge and show strong indications of a potential conflict of interest. None of the candidates presented at the required level of professional knowledge for the position were nor were they able to ensure that they would be able to perform their tasks with the necessary degree of independence. Despite the European Parliament's systematic requests for previous Council reports, the Court of Auditors has an extraordinary gender imbalance that is exacerbated by current nominations, the 6 candidates are men. For all these reasons, we vote against all proposals.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I decided to stick to the vote of the greens in the CONT Committee meaning that I supported candidates Jan Gregor, Samo Jereb and Mihails Kozlovs. I voted against Ladislav Balko and Janusz Woiciechowski. I wanted to stress the need to respect the demands in the TFEU concerning the professional experiences and candidates’ complete independence and the need to assure the gender balance in the EU’s top positions.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the nomination of Samo Jereb as a Member of the Court of Auditors because there are no legal, political or personal reasons on the grounds of which an objection to his nomination would be founded.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of the appointment of Samo Jereb as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The selection process has once again been highly criticized. Once again, most candidates lack adequate professional qualification, and strong indications of possible conflicts of interest are present. None of the candidates has the necessary level of professional specialisation for the position, and neither were they able to ensure that they would be able to perform the functions in question with the necessary degree of independence. Furthermore, despite the systematic requests of the European Parliament in previous reports to the Council and the Court of Auditors, there is a major gender imbalance which is aggravated by current applications, as all six candidates are men. We reject all candidates on the basis of the obvious lack of independence and the likelihood of conflicts of interest, which undermine both the mission and role of the Court of Auditors as an independent external auditor of the EU, as well as the lack of gender balance.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 Five new members of the Court of Auditors had to be appointed. The procedure laid down in Article 286 TFEI provides that members of the Court of Auditors shall be chosen from persons who are or have been members of the external audit institutions in their respective States or who have a specific qualification for that function and who must offer all guarantees of independence. The Council shall, after consulting the non-binding European Parliament, adopt the list of members on a proposal submitted by each Member State.  The six new candidates have a rather varied curriculum and very different characteristics, also noteworthy the lack of a certain "gender equality" in the candidates presented. The Court of Auditors already has a fairly marked imbalance (out of 28 Members, 5 are women) and it is considered that the Member States and the Council should give a strong signal to promote gender equality in all institutions and at all levels. Finally, the system of appointing members continues to be a system of political appointment, more than merit: this has led to a negative vote against all candidates.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 Appointments to the Court of Auditors should be reserved for persons of marked professionalism and independent of politics. Although not provided for by law, gender equality has not been respected and the system of appointing members continues to be a system of political appointment, more than merit. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote against.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted against the 5 candidates proposed to be members of the Court of Auditors for various reasons: because of their lack of independence, the possibility of conflict of interest, the lack of professional knowledge in the field of audit, as well as the lack of gender balance, since they are all men.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted against this Nomination to the Court of Auditors on the grounds that none of the candidates including Mihails Kozlovs held the required level of professional qualifications or expertise that would be required to satisfactory fulfil the post. My parties’ policy has always been about transparency, accountability and diversity on all boards, including State Boards. In Ireland, we have seen first had the corrosive culture of cronyism. We are still seeing it in the cronyism of debacle which is currently occurring around Government Formations. Furthermore, despite concerns being raised by the European Parliament on a number of occasions, all 6 candidates nominated were men. This is completely unacceptable and serves only to undermine any positive advances which have been made in recent years to increase the number of women in public life. Sinn Fein will have no hand or part in any such regressive, duplicitous or purposely vague moves. The society we are aiming for is one that is real, meaningful and where issues such as gender equality will be truly tackled and where cronyism is confined to the political dustbin of life.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This vote was by secret ballot, I cannot reveal my choice. For the appointment of the members of the European Court of Auditors, I voted on the basis of three criteria: probity, independence from political forces and competences.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I believe in democracy and transparency, and therefore I believe that my vote on this matter should be a matter of public record. In that spirit, I wish to confirm that I abstained on this appointment.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee responsible for the substance.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of appointing Mihails Kozlovs as a Member of the Court of Auditors. Mihails Kozlovs is a qualified and motivated specialist with 15 years of extensive experience in EU and national economic policy making, the EU budget, public finances, public administration, institutional relations, development banking, diplomacy, representation, communication, as well as people, change and project management, using a large network at all levels in the EU institutions, this experience is complemented by a prestigious Master's degree in Business Management.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. His position as an advisor to Latvia's finance minister, and then his position as advisor to the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, show Mr Kozlovs as finally quite far from the responsibility of auditor of the European Court of Auditors. So I objected to his appointment.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. In issuing my vote, I took into account the report and the vote in the Committee on Budgetary Control.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors is an important European institution which acts as an external and independent auditor of the Union. Founded in 1977, it only became a fully-capacity EU institution in 1993 and continued to provide support for improving the management of the Community budget. It shall consist of one member from each State of the Union, each of which shall be appointed by the Council after consulting Parliament and shall remain in office for six years.  On this occasion, Parliament was called upon to give its opinion on the appointment of Mihails Kozlovs. Having taken note of the content of the report by the Committee on Budgetary Control and following the advice of my political group (S&D), I voted in secret on the proposed name.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. The selection procedure for the members of the Court of Auditors was highly criticized. However, most candidates lack the right professional knowledge and show strong indications of a potential conflict of interest. None of the candidates presented at the required level of professional knowledge for the position were nor were they able to ensure that they would be able to perform their tasks with the necessary degree of independence. Despite the European Parliament's systematic requests for previous Council reports, the Court of Auditors has an extraordinary gender imbalance that is exacerbated by current nominations, the 6 candidates are men. For all these reasons, we vote AGAINST all proposals.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This is the appointment (or renewal) of a member of the European Court of Auditors. The European Parliament is consulted on the appointment.  Mihails Kozlovs is currently an advisor to his country's finance minister and an advisor to the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. These positions seem to me to be quite far from the profession of auditor of the European Court of Auditors.  So I voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not question the professional skills of this candidate, but I do not have sufficient evidence to give him my full support. That is why I abstained.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. This morning the Plenary of the European Parliament put to the vote, in secret, the proposal to appoint Mihails Kozlovs as a member of the Court of Auditors following the evaluation of the candidate's qualifications and the hearing held on 15 March before the Committee on Budgetary Control, a vote in which I participated.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of appointing the Latvian candidate, Mihails Kozlovs, as a member of the Court of Auditors. This candidate is an independent, qualified and motivated professional with 15 years of extensive experience in EU and national economic policy-making, the EU budget, public finances, public administration, institutional relations, development banking, diplomacy, representation, communication, as well as people, change and project management, using a large network at all levels in the EU institutions. This experience is complemented by a prestigious master's degree in business management.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 When appointing a new member of the Court of Auditors, both Article 286(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and Article 121 of the Rules of Procedure were taken into account, which were consulted by the Council, and subsequently the Committee on Budgetary Control assessed the qualifications of the proposed candidate, taking into account the conditions laid down in Article 286(1) of the Treaty which directly concerns the functioning of the EU. As soon as the Committee on Budgetary Control heard the candidate proposed by the Council to be a member of the Court of Auditors, the Commission issued a favourable opinion on the appointment of Mihails Kozlovs to be a member of the Court of Auditors. Thus, the only remaining task is that of the President - to transmit the Council's decision and, for information, both to the Court of Auditors and to the other EU institutions, as well as to the supervisory institutions of the Member States. I voted in favour of the report on the appointment of a member of the Court of Auditors – Mihails Kozlovs, because I believe that he has enough experience to bring a great deal of extra to the Court of Auditors, to all the EU institutions, as well as to the supervisory institutions of the Member States.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report by the Committee on Budgets asks for approval of the appointment of Mr Kozlovs (Latvia) as a member of the Court of Auditors. I abstained.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the instructions of the S&D Group, I abstained. In particular, the assessment is due to an ongoing administrative procedure involving the candidate. His selection as a member of the Lithuanian Court of Auditors took place not by the normal insolvency procedure, but by government "co-optation".  Thus, last January, one of the competing candidates initiated proceedings questioning the legitimacy of his appointment and calling for his candidacy for the appointment of a member of the European Court of Auditors to be suspended. The administrative court subsequently decided to reject this request for suspension, but, as the situation is still uncertain due to the legitimacy of his first appointment, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this Nomination to the Court of Auditors on the grounds that none of the candidates including Mihails Kozlovs held the required level of professional qualifications or expertise that would be required to satisfactory fulfil the post. My parties’ policy has always been about transparency, accountability and diversity on all boards, including State Boards. In Ireland, we have seen first had the corrosive culture of cronyism. We are still seeing it in the cronyism of debacle which is currently occurring around Government Formations. Furthermore, despite concerns being raised by the European Parliament on a number of occasions, all 6 candidates nominated were men. This is completely unacceptable and serves only to undermine any positive advances which have been made in recent years to increase the number of women in public life. Sinn Fein will have no hand or part in any such regressive, duplicitous or purposely vague moves. The society we are aiming for is one that is real, meaningful and where issues such as gender equality will be truly tackled and where cronyism is confined to the political dustbin of life.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this appointment not so much because of a personal matter with the candidate, but for different reasons. First of all, I regret seeing a fairly marked gender imbalance: out of 28 members, only 5 are women. Where is gender equality? The Member States and the Council should be the first to give a signal to promote gender equality in all institutions and at all levels. In addition, the system of appointing members continues to be a system of political appointment, more than merit. For these reasons, I have decided to vote against all the candidates.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the appointment of Mihails Kozlovs.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the decision of the EPP Cont members and voted in favour of Mr M. Kozlovs.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the appointment of Mihails Kozlovs as the new Member of the Court of Auditors. My warmest congratulations and good wishes for a good job go to him.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Court of Auditors is the EU’s independent external auditor body that exercises control over the EU funds if they are collected and used correctly, and help improve EU financial management. The Committee on Budgetary Control delivered a positive opinion on the nomination of Mihail Kozlov, thus I voted in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted against the 5 candidates proposed to be members of the Court of Auditors for various reasons: because of their lack of independence, the possibility of conflict of interest, the lack of professional knowledge in the field of audit, as well as the lack of gender balance, since they are all men.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Partial replacement of the composition of the Members of the Court of Auditors takes place in accordance with Article 286(2) TFEU, which provides that the Council adopts a list of candidates proposed by the Member States after consulting the European Parliament. The members of the Court of Auditors shall be appointed for a period of six years. The appointment and renewal of appointments shall be voted on in plenary on the basis of the CONT report. Candidates must comply with the requirements laid down in Article 286(1) TFEU: Members of the Court of Auditors shall be chosen from among persons who are or have been members of external audit bodies in their own countries or who are particularly qualified to take up that post. Their independence must be unquestionable. I supported the candidate in the vote.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. The terms of office of the six members of the Court of Auditors expire on 6 May 2016. After consultation with the European Parliament, the Council will adopt the list of members. Six candidates were nominated by the Member States: one Slovak candidate, one Latvian, one Czech, one Polish, one Maltese and one Slovenian.  Considering that the CONT Committee had expressed doubts about three candidates and offered a favourable opinion on three nominations (the Latvian, Czech and Slovenian candidates), I voted in favour of the appointment of Mr Kozlovs, the Latvian candidate, Mr Gregor, the Czech candidate, and Mr Jereb, the Slovenian candidate.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 Having fulfilled all the formalisms relating to the appointment of Mihails Kozlovs as a member of the Court of Auditors, in particular the assessment of his qualifications and his hearing, and there being no obstacle to his appointment, I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors (ECA) functions as a collegiate body of 28 members, one member of each Member State. These members shall be appointed by the Council, after consulting the European Parliament, for a renewable period of six years. The deadline for 6 of these posts will expire soon, and 6 new candidates have been proposed by the Member States. In a joint assessment of the universe of candidates, doubts are raised as to the full fulfilment of criteria of competence and professional experience, as to the political profile and independence, as to the suitability of the specific place and as to the existence of conflicts of interest. Some of these reasons prompted the rejection of some of the candidates in the Specialised Committee of the European Parliament responsible for assessing applications (Committee on Budgetary Control). Also in a global assessment, there is a lack of gender balance. There's not a single woman among the candidates. These are aspects that have weighed on our group's position in this vote.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the appointment of Mihails Kozlovs as a Member of the Court of Auditors as I consider Mr Kozlovs to be a professional Brussels bureaucrat with no experience in the audit field.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The ECA operates as a collegiate body of 28 Members, one from each Member State. The Members are appointed by the Council after consultation with the European Parliament for a renewable term of six years. Members elect one of their number as President for a renewable term of three years. I abstained because of the ongoing process in the regional court in Latvia.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I approved the appointment of Mr Mihails Kozlovs as a member of the European Court of Auditors.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the appointment of Mihail Kozlov as a member of the Court of Auditors, as this selection of staff convinced me after examination.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. The selection procedure for the members of the Court of Auditors was highly criticized. However, most candidates lack the right professional knowledge and show strong indications of a potential conflict of interest. None of the candidates presented at the required level of professional knowledge for the position were nor were they able to ensure that they would be able to perform their tasks with the necessary degree of independence. Despite the European Parliament's systematic requests for previous Council reports, the Court of Auditors has an extraordinary gender imbalance that is exacerbated by current nominations, the 6 candidates are men. For all these reasons, we vote against all proposals.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ The European Court of Auditors is in charge of the audit of EU finances and as the EU’s external auditor, it contributes to improving EU financial management and acts as the independent guardian of the financial interests of the citizens of the Union. It is vitally important that candidates for the Court are selected based on their suitability for the position, their professional background, language skills and the ability to exercise independent judgement are important considerations.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the nomination of Mihails Kozlovs as a Member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted against the proposal for the candidate under reference on the basis of the apparent lack of independence and the possibility of a conflict of interest undermining the mission, but also on the role of the Court of Auditors as an independent EU external auditor and "economic supervisor", as well as on the lack of gender balance.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the nomination of the member of the Court of Auditors, Mihails Kozlovs.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒I voted for a proposal for a decision by the European Parliament on the proposed appointment of Mikhail Kozlovs as a member of the Court of Auditors on the view that I consider Mr Kozlovs to be particularly qualified for this position and that his independence is beyond question. Mr Kozlovs gained his professional and professional experience while serving in the Latvian Ministry of Finance, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the Permanent Representation of Latvia to the EU. I believe that Mr. Kozlovs will hold this function responsibly, and therefore I vote for this report.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. 2012 Adviser to the country's finance minister, advisor to the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, quite far from the profession of auditor of the European Court of Auditors. I voted against it.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Igor Soltes' report on the appointment of Mr Mihails Kozlovs as a member of the Court of Auditors.  This text approves the application proposed by the Council after a hearing by the Committee on Budgetary Control. With more than 15 years of experience in economic policy-making at European and national level, Mr Kozlovs has the necessary qualifications to hold this position.  This appointment was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This report concerns the nomination of Mr Mihails Kozlovs as a member of the Court of Auditors. I am abstaining on this report.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The candidacy proposed by the Council to appoint Mihails Kozlov as a member of the Court of Auditors was considered valid following a thorough analysis of the applicant's credentials and personal background. I am therefore voting in favour of your appointment and wish you every success in your work.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted against the 5 candidates proposed to be members of the Court of Auditors for various reasons: because of their lack of independence, the possibility of conflict of interest, the lack of professional knowledge in the field of audit, as well as the lack of gender balance, since they are all men.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒Members of the EU Court of Auditors review the revenues and expenditures of all Union institutions and agencies.  In 2016, 10 members of the Court of Auditors will be appointed and new members will be appointed for a period of six years. Each Member State shall submit a proposal for a candidate for a member of the Court of Auditors and the Council shall decide on the list of the best candidates who then have a hearing in the Committee on Budgetary Control and are finally confirmed at parliament's session. The candidate for member of the Court of Auditors, Mikhails Kozlovs, was approved by the Committee on Budgetary Control, however, I did not support this report showing that the candidate does not have sufficient audit experience and does not meet the requirements of the European Parliament.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I congratulate Mihails Kozlovs on her appointment as a member of the Court of Auditors. His experience of more than 15 years in many areas, such as economic policy-making at European and national level, the EU budget, public finances, public management, institutional relations, etc., is recognised by all.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Court of Auditors functions as an independent external auditor, which regularly monitors the management of the Union budget by the European Commission and consistently reports on the current financial situation, together with recommendations for its improvement. Although that institution has no legal power, its importance in terms of financial verification is undeniable. This, in turn, means that the 28 members of the European Court of Auditors , one from each EU Member State, are the most qualified financial professionals who have proved themselves in their home country on a long-term job and whose primary task is, in fact, to monitor the Union's finances in such a way as to guarantee the interests of its citizens, i.e. taxpayers. I voted positively when examining and analysing Mr Kozlova's candidacy and paying the utmost attention to his professional experience and a number of other factors. Although the official position of the S&D Group was to abstain, I was for Kozlov. I would like to add that Mr Kozlova has worked for many years in the field of financial management of the Republic of Latvia and also of The European Level – at the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Latvia, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, as well as, by the way, the Permanent Representation of the Republic of Latvia to the European Union. He is not only a high-level professional, but , as his work experience shows, is well orientated in the Pan-European system of financial management and the principles of its control. With the approval of Mr Kozlova's candidacy, I wish him every success in this far from easy work!

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the proposed appointment of Mihails Kozlovs as a member of the Court of Auditors as I do not agree with key points in that report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The Court of Auditors aims to improve the FINANCIAL management of the EU and encourage transparency. It verifies whether the EU budget has been properly implemented and whether EU funds have been collected and spent legally and in accordance with the principles of good financial management.  The Court is composed of 28 members (one per Member State) appointed by the Council, after consultation with Parliament, for a renewable term of six years. The selection process at the Court of Auditors has long been widely criticised for its lack of transparency and lack of independence of candidates, who generally do not have the professional skills required for this position.  The Latvian candidate, Mihails Kozlovs, was actively involved in the conclusion of the latest macro-financial assistance agreement for Ukraine.  I'm voting against his nomination.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors is a supervisory institution, which verifies the legality and regularity of EU revenue and expenditure, as well as good financial management, carrying out its functions with complete independence. In this spirit, the appointment of the individualities that compose it must be governed by criteria of competence and independence. Thus, at the initiative of the Council, several personalities from various EU countries were appointed to the Court of Auditors. The applicant submitted his Curriculum Vitae, replied to a written questionnaire and was heard in the Committee on Budgetary Control and put forward sufficient arguments to justify the appointment to the Court of Auditors in order to carry out his duties there competently and independently. I therefore voted in favour of the name of Mihails Kozlovs.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council nominated Mikhails Kozlov as a member of the Court of Auditors. The appointment is the responsibility of the Council, but it is necessary to consult Parliament before deciding. The Committee on Budgetary Control evaluated the capabilities of the proposed candidate and listened to the candidate at its meeting on 15 March 2016. In its report, it proposes that Parliament give a favourable opinion on the Council's proposal to appoint Mihails Kozlov as a Member of the Court of Auditors. I supported the nomination of the candidate.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ The European Court of Auditors is in charge of the audit of EU finances and as the EU’s external auditor, it contributes to improving EU financial management and acts as the independent guardian of the financial interests of the citizens of the Union. It is vitally important that candidates for the Court are selected based on their suitability for the position, their professional background, language skills and the ability to exercise independent judgement are important considerations.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report which approves the appointment of Mihails Kozlovs as a member of the Court of Auditors. Mihails Kozlovs was heard by the Committee on Budgetary Control. The members of this committee approved this nomination by a very large majority.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted the nomination of Mihails Kozlovs as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Committee on Budgetary Control's assessment of the candidate's qualifications and suitability for the post in question.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The Court of Auditors is important for monitoring and controlling the use of EU funding, and its independence and the quality of work of judges guarantee the protection of the interests of all EU citizens. I supported the proposal on the appointment of Mikhails Kozlovs as a member of the Court of Auditors following the assessment of the qualifications of candidates carried out by the Committee on Budgetary Control of the European Parliament and after the hearing.  Mihails Kozlovs has 15 years of extensive experience in economic policymaking at national and EU level, the EU budget, public finances, public administration, institutional relations, development banking, diplomacy, representation work, communication and human management, change and projects, with a wide network of contacts at all levels of the EU institutions and a master's degree in business management for managers acquired at a prestigious university, all of which support the required function. In addition to these professional experiences and education, I believe that he will successfully serve as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. Mr Kozlovs is an adviser to his country's finance minister and advisor to the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development and has a journey far from being an auditor of the European Court of Auditors. So I'm voting against his nomination.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. Since 1999, when he obtained his master's degree, he has been building professional experience in public finances, economics, fiscal policy and financial management in latvia's public administration (Ministry of Finance) as well as in the international environment in Brussels (Latvia's permanent representation to the EU) and in London (European Bank for Reconstruction and Development). Mikhail Kozlovs arrived in Brussels in 2003, immediately after signing the Accession Treaty, was one of the first advisers to represent national interests in the EU.  In answering questions, Kozlovs wanted to highlight his experience in multilateral economic and fiscal supervision and in the financial sector, where after the crisis we witnessed major changes with far-reaching consequences that in some cases challenge the Work of the Court of Auditors on the tasks arising from the Treaties. For all of the above, I support the appointment of a colleague as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors (ECA) functions as a collegiate body of 28 members, one member of each Member State. These members shall be appointed by the Council, after consulting the European Parliament, for a renewable period of six years. The deadline for 6 of these posts will expire soon, and 6 new candidates have been proposed by the Member States. In a joint assessment of the universe of candidates, doubts are raised as to the full fulfilment of criteria of competence and professional experience, as to the political profile and independence, as to the suitability of the specific place and as to the existence of conflicts of interest. Some of these reasons prompted the rejection of some of the candidates in the Specialised Committee of the European Parliament responsible for assessing applications (Committee on Budgetary Control). Also in a global assessment, there is a lack of gender balance. There's not a single woman among the candidates. These are aspects that have weighed on our group's position in this vote.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors is a collegiate body composed of 28 members, one for each Member State. I welcome the appointment of Mihails Kozlovs as a member of the Court of Auditors and wish him well in his work.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. We have been asked to rule on the appointment of an auditor from the European Court of Auditors. This procedure demonstrates the usefulness of Parliament in exercising its control over the functioning of the European institutions.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 After the Commission has assessed the qualifications of Mihails Kozlovs, and taking into account that, at its meeting of 15 March 2016, the Committee on Budgetary Control held a hearing of the candidate proposed by the Council for the post of member of the Court of Auditors, this report gives its assent to the Proposal of the Council to appoint Mihails Kozlovs to the post of member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. This morning the Plenary of the European Parliament put to the vote, in secret, the proposal to appoint Mihails Kozlovs as a member of the Court of Auditors following the evaluation of the candidate's qualifications and the hearing held on 15 March before the Committee on Budgetary Control, a vote in which I participated.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Parliament this lunchtime approved the appointment of Latvian auditor Mihalis Kozlovs to the European Court of Auditors (386 votes in, 123 against, and 186 abstentions), but rejected the Polish auditor's candidacy, according to the recommendations of the Committee on Budgetary Control. Toni Abela, the Maltese candidate, withdrew his candidacy following the committee's unfavorable opinion. The final decision on assignment to Luxembourg will be taken by the EU Council of Ministers. Members of the Court of Auditors are appointed for six years. The Council, after consulting the European Parliament, makes its decision according to the proposals made by each Member State.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of appointing the Latvian candidate, Mihails Kozlovs, as a member of the Court of Auditors. He is an independent, qualified and motivated professional with 15 years of extensive experience in EU and national economic policy-making, the EU budget, public finances, public administration, institutional relations, development banking, diplomacy, representation, communication, as well as people, change and project management. Mihails holds a master's degree in business management from City University London.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Like the other nomination proposals, this was also assessed by the Committee on Budgetary Control in accordance with criteria of rigour and transparency. Having submitted a proposal by the Council on 15 March 2016 and the selection process has been carried out in an open and transparent manner, I agree with the appointment of Mihails Kozlovs as Member of the Court of Auditors, since, at a hearing by the Committee on Budgetary Control of the proposed candidate, he has demonstrated proven competence and professional experience for the full performance of those functions.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. The selection procedure for the members of the Court of Auditors was highly criticized. However, most candidates lack the right professional knowledge and show strong indications of a potential conflict of interest. None of the candidates presented at the required level of professional knowledge for the position were nor were they able to ensure that they would be able to perform their tasks with the necessary degree of independence. Despite the European Parliament's systematic requests for previous Council reports, the Court of Auditors has an extraordinary gender imbalance that is exacerbated by current nominations, the 6 candidates are men. For all these reasons, we vote against all proposals.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted against the 5 candidates proposed to be members of the Court of Auditors for various reasons: because of their lack of independence, the possibility of conflict of interest, the lack of professional knowledge in the field of audit, as well as the lack of gender balance, since they are all men.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ As I’ve mentioned before, The European Court of Auditors plays a vital role in the institutions, being in charge of the audit of the EU’s finances and, as the EU’s external auditor, it contributes to improving the financial management of the EU as well as acting as the independent guardian of the financial interests of the EU’s half a billion citizens. In my view, it is vitally important that candidates for the Court are selected based on their suitability for the position, their professional backgrounds, language skills and the ability to exercise independent judgment are all important for considerations. In this case, I abstained, not because I believed that Mihails performed badly in his interview or that his CV does not fit into the criteria that I have set out, but the ongoing process in the regional court in Latvia raises concerns for me. Nonetheless, I wish him luck with his nomination after having received approval in this place.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the fact that as a Member of the Court of Auditors, a representative from each EU member country can check that EU funds are being correctly collected and used and help improve EU financial management.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I have decided to support Mihails Kozlovs in his candidacy for the post of Member of the European Court of Auditors because his professional career indicates that he is an independent, qualified and motivated candidate with over fifteen years of experience in economic policy-making at both European and national level. During his career, Mr Kozlovs has already devoted himself to a variety of activities in the areas of the EU budget, public finances, public administration, development banking, but also diplomacy. He was undoubtedly benefiting from the direct experience of Latvia's EU accession negotiations, as he served as Director of the EU Integration Unit at the Ministry of Finance in Riga and later as an adviser on the economy, finance, budget and taxation at the Permanent Representation of Latvia in Brussels. During this period, he managed to deepen his knowledge of the functioning of the EU's institutional structures and also had the opportunity to consolidate his knowledge of foreign languages. He further developed his experience with international institutions as an adviser to the Director of the Executive Board of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development in London, in addition to adding an executive management degree to an MBA. He also actively participated in the exercise of the Latvian Presidency of the Council of the EU, where he had the opportunity to chair the ad hoc group for the European Fund for Strategic Investments and also co-chair a political trilogue with the EP. For these reasons, I believe that his versatile and insightd personality will be of benefit to the Court of Auditors.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors has a great responsibility in overseeing the legality of the use of European funds and, more importantly, in assessing the effectiveness and long-term impact of European Union policies. The Committee on The Court of Auditors assessed the candidate's recommendations, in particular in the light of the requirements laid down in Article 286(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and approved the Council's proposal to appoint Mikhail Kozlovs as a member of the Court of Auditors. Kozlovs is an independent, qualified and motivated expert with more than 15 years of in-depth experience in policy-making at national and EU level. Its areas of expertise include the EU budget, public finances, public governance, institutional relations, development banking, diplomacy, as well as human governance, change management and project management, with numerous contacts within the EU institutions at all levels. Kozlovs led the EU integration department at the Latvian Ministry of Finance, working as an adviser at the Permanent Representation of Latvia to the EU and at the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. For this very reasons, I voted in favour of his appointment.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒Given that the Committee on Budgetary Control assessed the qualifications of the proposed candidate, in particular as regards the conditions set out in Article 286(1) of the EIA. The Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and since the meeting of the Committee on Budgetary Control on 15 March 2016 held a hearing of the Candidates of the Council for Membership in the Court of Auditors, I supported the appointment of Mikhails Kozlovs as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ The European Court of Auditors is in charge of the audit of EU finances and as the EU’s external auditor, it contributes to improving EU financial management and acts as the independent guardian of the financial interests of the citizens of the Union. It is vitally important that candidates for the Court are selected based on their suitability for the position, their professional background, language skills and the ability to exercise independent judgement are important considerations.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. One of the important roles of the Court of Auditors is to instill trust in the democratic institutions of the European Union. It is therefore important that all members of the Court of Auditors perform their duties to the highest expectations of EU citizens. I support the draft report on the proposed appointment of Mikhail Kozlovs as a member of the Court of Auditors. I believe that Mikhails Kozlovs will enhance cooperation between the Court of Auditors, national audit institutions and the European Parliament, namely the Committee on Budgetary Control, when revising the EU budget. I also believe that Mikhail Kozlovs' work will further improve the court's reports so that the European Parliament receives all the necessary information on the accuracy of the data provided by member states to the European Commission.  I believe that Mikhail Kozlovs will perform his duties as a member of the Court of Auditors on a completely independent basis, thus contributing with his impartiality, objectivity and integrity to the work of the Court of Auditors and cooperation with the European Parliament.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The selection of persons for positions of responsibility and Union interest should be based on the integrity of their character and their proven activity with regard to the protection of public money in the broadest sense

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. We have received, studied and issued an opinion on this person's candidacy as a member of the Court of Auditors.  The Committee on Budgetary Control assessed the qualifications of the proposed candidate, particularly in light of the conditions set out in Article 286, paragraph 1, of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. A hearing was then undertaken during the month of March by the Council concerning the function of a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the nomination of Mihails Kozlovs as a member of the Court of Auditors. Through his long year in-depth experience in the field of EU policy-making, including in economic, financial and tax policies, advisory, development banking, diplomacy and communication, as well as his rich network in the EU institutions, I believe that Mihails Kozlovs will be able to up for the challenge.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported the appointment of Mikhails Kozlovs as a member of the Court of Auditors, as Mr Kozlovs is an independent, qualified and motivated expert with more than 15 years of extensive experience in creating economic policies at national and European Union level, in the European Union budget, public finances, public administration and development banking and diplomacy. The Court of Auditors plays an important role in the process of promoting a culture of sound financial management, and I believe that members of the Court of Auditors should be qualified experts who can improve the added value of business efficiency audits. I believe that Mr Kozlovs will justify the trust and I hope that it will be guided by the principle of independence, which is at the heart of the audit in the performance of daily duties and in making strategic decisions.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. In my report on the appointment of Mikhail Kozlovs as a Member of the Court of Auditors, I voted in my conscience – a secret vote. The Committee on Budgetary Control has assessed the candidate's professional qualifications, in particular in the light of the requirements laid down in Article 286(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. At its meeting on 15 March 2016, the Committee on Budgetary Control listened to the presentation of the Council candidate for member of the Court of Auditors and approved the Council's proposal to appoint Mikhail Kozlovs as a member of the Court of Auditors and instruct its President to forward this Decision to the Council and, for information, to the Court of Auditors, as well as to the other institutions of the European Union and the audit bodies of the Member States.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. The selection procedure for the members of the Court of Auditors was highly criticized. However, most candidates lack the right professional knowledge and show strong indications of a potential conflict of interest. None of the candidates presented at the required level of professional knowledge for the position were nor were they able to ensure that they would be able to perform their tasks with the necessary degree of independence. Despite the European Parliament's systematic requests for previous Council reports, the Court of Auditors has an extraordinary gender imbalance that is exacerbated by current nominations, the 6 candidates are men. For all these reasons, we vote against all proposals.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control evaluated the capabilities, history and professionalism of the proposed candidate. I voted to follow S&D's position on the nomination of the candidate.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. The selection procedure for the members of the Court of Auditors was highly criticized. However, most candidates lack the right professional knowledge and show strong indications of a potential conflict of interest. None of the candidates presented at the required level of professional knowledge for the position were nor were they able to ensure that they would be able to perform their tasks with the necessary degree of independence. Despite the European Parliament's systematic requests for previous Council reports, the Court of Auditors has an extraordinary gender imbalance that is exacerbated by current nominations, the 6 candidates are men. For all these reasons, we vote against all proposals.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I decided to stick to the vote of the greens in the CONT Committee meaning that I supported candidates Jan Gregor, Samo Jereb and Mihails Kozlovs. I voted against Ladislav Balko and Janusz Woiciechowski. I wanted to stress the need to respect the demands in the TFEU concerning the professional experiences and candidates’ complete independence and the need to assure the gender balance in the EU’s top positions.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the nomination of Mihails Kozlovs as a Member of the Court of Auditors because there are no legal, political or personal reasons on the grounds of which an objection to his nomination would be founded.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of the appointment of Mihails Kozlovs as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The selection process has once again been highly criticized. Once again, most candidates lack adequate professional qualification and strong indications of possible conflicts of interest are present. None of the candidates has the necessary level of professional specialisation for the position, and neither were they able to ensure that they would be able to perform the functions in question with the necessary degree of independence. Furthermore, despite the systematic requests of the European Parliament in previous reports to the Council and the Court of Auditors, there is a major gender imbalance, which is compounded by current applications, as all six candidates are men. We reject all candidates on the basis of the obvious lack of independence and the likelihood of conflicts of interest, which undermine both the mission and role of the Court of Auditors as an independent external auditor of the EU, as well as the lack of gender balance.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 Taking into account the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control, I supported candidate Mikhail Kozlovs as a Member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 Appointments to the Court of Auditors should be reserved for persons of marked professionalism and independent of politics. Unfortunately, there is no real democratic control in the choice of candidate and the nomination turns out to be purely 'political'. Furthermore, although not provided for by law, gender equality has not been respected. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted against the 5 candidates proposed to be members of the Court of Auditors for various reasons: because of their lack of independence, the possibility of conflict of interest, the lack of professional knowledge in the field of audit, as well as the lack of gender balance, since they are all men.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted against this Nomination to the Court of Auditors on the grounds that none of the candidates including Jan Gregor held the required level of professional qualifications or expertise that would be required to satisfactory fulfil the post. My parties’ policy has always been about transparency, accountability and diversity on all boards, including State Boards. In Ireland, we have seen first had the corrosive culture of cronyism. We are still seeing it in the cronyism of debacle which is currently occurring around Government Formations. Furthermore, despite concerns being raised by the European Parliament on a number of occasions, all 6 candidates nominated were men. This is completely unacceptable and serves only to undermine any positive advances which have been made in recent years to increase the number of women in public life. Sinn Fein will have no hand or part in any such regressive, duplicitous or purposely vague moves. The society we are aiming for is one that is real, meaningful and where issues such as gender equality will be truly tackled and where cronyism is confined to the political dustbin of life.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This vote was by secret ballot, I cannot reveal my choice. For the appointment of the members of the European Court of Auditors, I voted on the basis of three criteria: probity, independence from political forces and competences.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I believe in democracy and transparency, and therefore I believe that my vote on this matter should be a matter of public record. In that spirit, I wish to confirm that I abstained on this appointment.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee responsible for the substance.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of appointing Jan Gregor as a Member of the Court of Auditors. Mr Gregor has been actively involved in the process of negotiating EU accession from the outset, i.e. by checking national laws and their compliance with EU legislation, negotiating a number of negotiating chapters and before the last meeting in 2002. European Summit between the Czech And Danish Prime Ministers during the Danish Presidency in Copenhagen.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. A senior official in his country's finance ministry, a member of the EIB's remuneration committee, vice-president of a local public bank, this Czech with an apparatchik profile did not seem to me to be a good candidate.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. In issuing my vote, I took into account the report and the vote in the Committee on Budgetary Control

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors is an important European institution which acts as an external and independent auditor of the Union. Founded in 1977, it only became a fully-capacity EU institution in 1993 and continued to provide support for improving the management of the Community budget. It shall consist of one member from each State of the Union, each of which shall be appointed by the Council after consulting Parliament and shall remain in office for six years.  On this occasion, Parliament was called upon to give its opinion on the appointment of Jan Gregor. Having taken note of the content of the report by the Committee on Budgetary Control and following the advice of my political group (S&D), I voted in secret on the proposed name.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. The selection procedure for the members of the Court of Auditors was highly criticized. However, most candidates lack the right professional knowledge and show strong indications of a potential conflict of interest. None of the candidates presented at the required level of professional knowledge for the position were nor were they able to ensure that they would be able to perform their tasks with the necessary degree of independence. Despite the European Parliament's systematic requests for previous Council reports, the Court of Auditors has an extraordinary gender imbalance that is exacerbated by current nominations, the 6 candidates are men. For all these reasons, we vote against all proposals.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This is the appointment (or renewal) of a member of the European Court of Auditors. The European Parliament is consulted on the appointment. Mr. Jan Gregor is currently a senior official in the Czech Republic's Ministry of Finance, a member of the EIB's remuneration committee and vice-president of a local public bank. It's a profile that reminds me of an apparatchik course and in doubt, I preferred to vote against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not question the professional skills of this candidate, but I do not have sufficient evidence to give him my full support. That is why I abstained.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. This morning the plenary session of the European Parliament put to the vote, in secret, the proposal for the appointment of Jan Gregor as a member of the Court of Auditors following the evaluation of the candidate's qualifications and the hearing held on 15 March before the Committee on Budgetary Control, a vote in which I participated.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report to appoint the Czech candidate, Jan Gregor, as a Member of the Court of Auditors. This candidate considers that the structure of the Contact Committee already provides a solid basis for the Court's cooperation with the national supreme audit institutions. This cooperation shall include annual meetings and various working groups, networks and working groups set up to address specific issues of common interest. Mr Gregor stresses that this structure is flexible enough to address any relevant issues. The candidate stresses that it would focus on continuing regular cooperation with committees of the European Parliament, in particular the Committee on Budgetary Control, mainly in the areas of annual audit planning and annual reports. This area is duly covered and coordinated by the relatively new office of the Member of the Court responsible for institutional relations. At the same time, there is scope for improvements to extend cooperation with the European Parliament's sector-specific committees.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the appointment of a member of the Court of Auditors – Jan Gregor, because I have consulted his CV and I believe that he has sufficient knowledge to serve as a member of the Court of Auditors and, at the same time, I believe that he will bring a great deal of addition to both the EU institutions and the supervisory institutions of the Member States. After the Committee on Budgetary Control of the European Parliament heard the candidate proposed by the Council to be a member of the Court of Auditors, it issued a favourable opinion for the appointment of Jan Gregor to be a member of the Court of Auditors. Thus, the only remaining task is that of the President - to transmit the Council's decision and, for information, both to the Court of Auditors and to the other EU institutions, as well as to the supervisory institutions of the Member States.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report of the Committee on Budgets asks for approval of the appointment of Mr Gregor (Czech Republic) as a member of the Court of Auditors. I abstained.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the instructions of the S&D Group, I voted against. In particular, the assessment was based on the candidate's hearing in the CONT Committee, in which he proved unconvincing, sometimes evasive. He answered the questions in the questionnaire too succinctly, not taking into account the weight and value of the parliamentary institution.  When asked 'would you withdraw your candidacy if Parliament's opinion on your appointment as a member of the Court were unfavourable?' she replied: 'I am prepared to consider withdrawing your candidacy after understanding the reasons that led to Parliament's opinion and after consulting the Czech Government', while holding the role of Deputy Minister, you say that you 'do not hold and have never held political office'.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this Nomination to the Court of Auditors on the grounds that none of the candidates including Jan Gregor held the required level of professional qualifications or expertise that would be required to satisfactory fulfil the post. My parties’ policy has always been about transparency, accountability and diversity on all boards, including State Boards. In Ireland, we have seen first had the corrosive culture of cronyism. We are still seeing it in the cronyism of debacle which is currently occurring around Government Formations. Furthermore, despite concerns being raised by the European Parliament on a number of occasions, all 6 candidates nominated were men. This is completely unacceptable and serves only to undermine any positive advances which have been made in recent years to increase the number of women in public life. Sinn Fein will have no hand or part in any such regressive, duplicitous or purposely vague moves. The society we are aiming for is one that is real, meaningful and where issues such as gender equality will be truly tackled and where cronyism is confined to the political dustbin of life.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this appointment not so much because of a personal matter with the candidate, but for different reasons. First of all, I regret seeing a fairly marked gender imbalance: out of 28 members, only 5 are women. Where is gender equality? The Member States and the Council should be the first to give a signal to promote gender equality in all institutions and at all levels. In addition, the system of appointing members continues to be a system of political appointment, more than merit. For these reasons, I have decided to vote against all the candidates.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Jan Gregor's nomination not only because he is a Czech candidate, but mainly because I am convinced of his undisputed professional qualities, which he will be able to contribute to as a member of the Court of Auditors of the EU.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the appointment of Jan Gregor.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the decision of the EPP Cont members and voted in favour of Mr Gregor.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the appointment of Jan Gregor as the new Member of the Court of Auditors. My warmest congratulations and good wishes for a good job go to him.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ I respect the favourable opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control, thus I voted in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted against the 5 candidates proposed to be members of the Court of Auditors for various reasons: because of their lack of independence, the possibility of conflict of interest, the lack of professional knowledge in the field of audit, as well as the lack of gender balance, since they are all men.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Partial replacement of the composition of the Members of the Court of Auditors takes place in accordance with Article 286(2) TFEU, which provides that the Council adopts a list of candidates proposed by the Member States after consulting the European Parliament. The members of the Court of Auditors shall be appointed for a period of six years. The appointment and renewal of appointments shall be voted on in plenary on the basis of the CONT report. Candidates must comply with the requirements laid down in Article 286(1) TFEU: Members of the Court of Auditors shall be chosen from among persons who are or have been members of external audit bodies in their own countries or who are particularly qualified to take up that post. Their independence must be unquestionable. I supported the candidate in the vote.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. The terms of office of the six members of the Court of Auditors expire on 6 May 2016. After consultation with the European Parliament, the Council will adopt the list of members. Six candidates were nominated by the Member States: one Slovak candidate, one Latvian, one Czech, one Polish, one Maltese and one Slovenian.  Considering that the CONT Committee had expressed doubts about three candidates and offered a favourable opinion on three nominations (the Latvian, Czech and Slovenian candidates), I voted in favour of the appointment of Mr Kozlovs, the Latvian candidate, Mr Gregor, the Czech candidate, and Mr Jereb, the Slovenian candidate.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 Having fulfilled all the formalisms relating to the appointment of Jan Gregor as a member of the Court of Auditors, in particular the assessment of his qualifications and his hearing, and there being no obstacle to his appointment, I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors (ECA) functions as a collegiate body of 28 members, one member of each Member State. These members shall be appointed by the Council, after consulting the European Parliament, for a renewable period of six years. The deadline for 6 of these posts will expire soon, and 6 new candidates have been proposed by the Member States. In a joint assessment of the universe of candidates, doubts are raised as to the full fulfilment of criteria of competence and professional experience, as to the political profile and independence, as to the suitability of the specific place and as to the existence of conflicts of interest. Some of these reasons prompted the rejection of some of the candidates in the Specialised Committee of the European Parliament responsible for assessing applications (Committee on Budgetary Control). Also in a global assessment, there is a lack of gender balance. There's not a single woman among the candidates. These are aspects that have weighed on our group's position in this vote.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the appointment of Jan Gregor as a Member of the Court of Auditors, since he states that any rejection by Parliament should also come with sufficient and understandable justification to enable him to consider withdrawing his candidacy.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The ECA operates as a collegiate body of 28 Members, one from each Member State. The Members are appointed by the Council after consultation with the European Parliament for a renewable term of six years. Members elect one of their number as President for a renewable term of three years. I abstained on this nomination because of the poor presentation in Committee.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the appointment of Mr Jan Gregor as a member of the European Court of Auditors.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the appointment of Jan Gregor as a member of the Court of Auditors, as this selection of staff convinced me after examination.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. The selection procedure for the members of the Court of Auditors was highly criticized. However, most candidates lack the right professional knowledge and show strong indications of a potential conflict of interest. None of the candidates presented at the required level of professional knowledge for the position were nor were they able to ensure that they would be able to perform their tasks with the necessary degree of independence. Despite the European Parliament's systematic requests for previous Council reports, the Court of Auditors has an extraordinary gender imbalance that is exacerbated by current nominations, the 6 candidates are men. For all these reasons, we vote against all proposals.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ The European Court of Auditors is in charge of the audit of EU finances and, as the EU’s external auditor, it contributes to improving EU financial management and acts as the independent guardian of the financial interests of the citizens of the Union. It is vitally important that candidates for the Court are selected based on their suitability for the position, and their professional background, language skills and the ability to exercise independent judgement are important considerations.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the nomination of Jan Gregor as a Member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted against the proposal for the candidate under reference on the basis of the apparent lack of independence and the possibility of a conflict of interest that undermines the mission but also the role of the Court of Auditors as an independent EU external auditor and "economic supervisor", as well as because of the lack of gender balance.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the nomination of the member of the Court of Auditors, Jan Gregor.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
