text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a decision by the European Parliament on the proposed appointment of Jan Gregor as a member of the Court of Auditors because his previous work experience at the Czech-Moravia Bank for Guarantees and Development, in the Ministry of Finance and in other financial bodies indicates that Mr Gregor has the necessary knowledge and skills to perform the function in question. Likewise, the professional activities for which Mr Gregor was in charge and responsible are a guarantee that he or she will serve as a member of the Court of Auditors professionally and conscientiously.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. Senior official of his country's Ministry of Finance, member of the EIB's remuneration committee, vice-president of a local public bank. Profile of apparatchik. I voted against it.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Igor Soltes' report on the appointment of Mr Jan Gregor as a member of the Court of Auditors. This text approves the application proposed by the Council after hearing with the Committee on Budgetary Control.  This appointment was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This report concerns the nomination of Mr Jan Gregor as a Member of the Court of Auditors. I am abstaining on this report.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The proposal by the Board to appoint Jan Gregor as a member of the Court of Auditors was deemed valid after a careful evaluation of the candidate's credentials, curriculum vitae and personal experiences. I am therefore voting in favour of his appointment and wish him well in his work.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted against the 5 candidates proposed to be members of the Court of Auditors for various reasons: because of their lack of independence, the possibility of conflict of interest, the lack of professional knowledge in the field of audit, as well as the lack of gender balance, since they are all men.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒Members of the EU Court of Auditors review the revenues and expenditures of all Union institutions and agencies. In 2016, 10 members of the Court of Auditors will be appointed and new members will be appointed for a period of six years. In order to become members of the Court of Auditors, candidates first have a hearing in the Committee on Budgetary Control, which gives its opinion on candidates. After that, each candidate shall be voted on at parliament's plenary session, based on a report from the Committee. Each Member State shall submit a proposal for a candidate for a member of the Court of Auditors and the Council shall decide on the list of the best candidates who then have a hearing in the Committee on Budgetary Control and are finally confirmed at parliament's session. Jan Gregor, a member of the Court of Auditors, has over ten years of experience in finance, where he worked in the Czech Ministry of Finance and the European Bank. Given Mr. Gregor's experience, I supported the report.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I congratulate Jan Gregor on his appointment as a member of the Court of Auditors. This Economist by training has held several positions in the Ministry of Finance. His experience as Deputy Minister in charge of public budgets, the state budget, local and municipal budgets, debt management, the public treasury, etc., is an undeniable asset in his new role.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against Gregor according to the position of our group. But he was elected with 382 votes to 256, and 57 abstentions.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the proposed appointment of Jan Gregor as a member of the Court of Auditors as I do not agree with key points in that report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The Court of Auditors aims to improve the FINANCIAL management of the EU and encourage transparency. It verifies whether the EU budget has been properly implemented and whether EU funds have been collected and spent legally and in accordance with the principles of good financial management.  The Court is composed of 28 members (one per Member State) appointed by the Council, after consultation with Parliament, for a renewable term of six years. The selection process at the Court of Auditors has long been widely criticised for its lack of transparency and lack of independence of candidates, who generally do not have the professional skills required for this position.  The Czech candidate, Mr. Jan Gregor, has little kind of agreement on the interweaving of economic and political power. Indeed, over the past 5 years he has held executive positions in several large private companies and in public institutions (the development bank, the general medical insurance company, the remuneration commission of the European Investment Bank...).  I'm voting against his nomination.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors is a supervisory institution, which verifies the legality and regularity of EU revenue and expenditure, as well as good financial management, carrying out its functions with complete independence. In this spirit, the appointment of the individualities that compose it must be governed by criteria of competence and independence. Thus, at the initiative of the Council, several personalities from various EU countries were appointed to the Court of Auditors. The applicant submitted his Curriculum Vitae, replied to a written questionnaire and was heard in the Committee on Budgetary Control and put forward sufficient arguments to justify the appointment to the Court of Auditors in order to carry out his duties there competently and independently. I voted in favour of Jan Gregor's name.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council nominated Jan Gregor as a member of the Court of Auditors.  The appointment is the responsibility of the Council, but it is necessary to consult Parliament before deciding. The Committee on Budgetary Control evaluated the capabilities of the proposed candidate and listened to the candidate at its meeting on 15 March 2016. In its report, it proposes that Parliament give a favourable opinion on the Council's proposal to appoint Jan Gregor as a Member of the Court of Auditors. I supported the nomination of the candidate.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ The European Court of Auditors is in charge of the audit of EU finances and as the EU’s external auditor, it contributes to improving EU financial management and acts as the independent guardian of the financial interests of the citizens of the Union. It is vitally important that candidates for the Court are selected based on their suitability for the position, their professional background, language skills and the ability to exercise independent judgement are important considerations.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report which proposed the appointment of Jan Gregor as a member of the Court of Auditors. Jan Gregor was interviewed by the Committee on Budgetary Control. The members of this committee approved this nomination by a very large majority.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted the nomination of Jan Gregor as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 With regard to the proposal by the rapporteur, Igor Šoltes, on the appointment of Jan Gregor as a member of the Court of Auditors, on the basis of the assessment of the Committee on Budgetary Control, I thought it appropriate to vote positively.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The Court of Auditors is important for monitoring and controlling the use of EU funding, and its independence and the quality of work of judges guarantee the protection of the interests of all EU citizens. I supported the proposal on the appointment of Jan Gregor as a member of the Court of Auditors following the assessment of the qualifications of candidates carried out by the Committee on Budgetary Control of the European Parliament and after the hearing.  Gregor's experience as vice-president of the supervisory board at the Czech-Moravia Bank for Guarantees and Development, as well as his membership in the boards of directors, among which is particularly significant on the board of directors of the European Investment Bank, and the history of his work in the Czech Ministry of Finance, prove Gregor's ability to perform the honorable service of the Judge of the Court of Auditors.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. A senior official in his country's ministry of finance, a member of the EIB's remuneration committee, vice-president of a local public bank, his profile is more that of an apparatchik. I'm voting against his nomination.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Jan Gregor participated in negotiations on allocation and international agreements for pre-accession assistance, eu accession negotiations – budgetary impact, own resources simulation, adjustment for the financial perspective for the 2004-2006 programming period.  He noted that he was proud to have had the opportunity to participate in eu accession negotiations from the very beginning, as part of monitoring the compatibility of national legislation with the EU acquis, negotiating a number of chapters and participating in the final session of the 2002 European Summit in Copenhagen during the Danish Presidency. Together with his team from the National Funds Department, he worked as an extended arm of the European Commission, both as a payment or certifier and a fund authority. Over all these years, the Commission has appreciated the stability and reliability of the National Funds Department team. For all of the above, I support the appointment of a colleague as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors (ECA) functions as a collegiate body of 28 members, one member of each Member State. These members shall be appointed by the Council, after consulting the European Parliament, for a renewable period of six years. The deadline for 6 of these posts will expire soon, and 6 new candidates have been proposed by the Member States. In a joint assessment of the universe of candidates, doubts are raised as to the full fulfilment of criteria of competence and professional experience, as to the political profile and independence, as to the suitability of the specific place and as to the existence of conflicts of interest.  Some of these reasons prompted the rejection of some of the candidates in the Specialised Committee of the European Parliament responsible for assessing applications (Committee on Budgetary Control). Also in a global assessment, there is a lack of gender balance. There's not a single woman among the candidates. These are aspects that have weighed on our group's position in this vote.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I applaud the appointment of Jan Gregor as a member of the Court of Auditors, wishing him well in the hope that he will be able to play his role with the utmost independence and transparency in the general interest of the European Union.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. We have been asked to rule on the appointment of an auditor from the European Court of Auditors. This procedure demonstrates the usefulness of Parliament in exercising its control over the functioning of the European institutions.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 After the Committee on Budgetary Control has held the hearing of Mr Gregor and assessed his qualifications, this report, which I voted in favour of, gives a positive opinion to the Council's proposal to appoint the candidate for the post of the Court of Auditors.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. This morning the plenary session of the European Parliament put to the vote, in secret, the proposal for the appointment of Jan Gregor as a member of the Court of Auditors following the evaluation of the candidate's qualifications and the hearing held on 15 March before the Committee on Budgetary Control, a vote in which I participated.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Parliament this lunchtime approved the appointment of the Auditor of the Czech Republic, Jan Gregor (382 votes in in person, 256 against, and 57 abstentions), but rejected the Polish auditor's candidacy, according to the recommendations of the Committee on Budgetary Control. Toni Abela, the Maltese candidate, withdrew his candidacy following the committee's unfavorable opinion. The final decision on assignment to Luxembourg will be taken by the EU Council of Ministers. Members of the Court of Auditors are appointed for six years. The Council, after consulting the European Parliament, makes its decision according to the proposals made by each Member State.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report to appoint the Czech candidate, Jan Gregor, as a Member of the Court of Auditors. He currently serves as Vice-Chairman of the Supervisory Board of the Czech and Moravian Guarantee and Development Bank and Vice-Chairman of the Supervisory Board of the Czech Export Bank. He holds a bachelor's degree in international trade from the University of Economics in Prague.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The Committee on Budgetary Control, in accordance with criteria of rigour and transparency, assessed the nomination proposal submitted by the Council in March 2016. Since, like the other appointments, at a hearing by the Committee on Budgetary Control, the applicant concerned has demonstrated competence and professional experience attested to the full performance of those functions, I agree with the appointment of Mr Gregor to the post of Member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. The selection procedure for the members of the Court of Auditors was highly criticized. However, most candidates lack the right professional knowledge and show strong indications of a potential conflict of interest. None of the candidates presented at the required level of professional knowledge for the position were nor were they able to ensure that they would be able to perform their tasks with the necessary degree of independence. Despite the European Parliament's systematic requests for previous Council reports, the Court of Auditors has an extraordinary gender imbalance that is exacerbated by current nominations, the 6 candidates are men. For all these reasons, we voted against all the proposals

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted against the 5 candidates proposed to be members of the Court of Auditors for various reasons: because of their lack of independence, the possibility of conflict of interest, the lack of professional knowledge in the field of audit, as well as the lack of gender balance, since they are all men.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ As I’ve mentioned before, The European Court of Auditors plays a vital role in the institutions, being in charge of the audit of the EU’s finances and, as the EU’s external auditor, it contributes to improving the financial management of the EU as well as acting as the independent guardian of the financial interests of the EU’s half a billion citizens. In my view, it is vitally important that candidates for the Court are selected based on their suitability for the position, their professional backgrounds, language skills and the ability to exercise independent judgment are all important for considerations. For Jan Gregor, I could not support his nomination due to his poor performance during the interview.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the fact that as a Member of the Court of Auditors, a representative from each EU member country can check that EU funds are being correctly collected and used and help improve EU financial management.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported candidate Jan Gregor as a member of the European Court of Auditors, as I believe that his work experience shows his expertise in financial planning and control. His career progress shows that he has long profiled himself as an expert at the Ministry of Finance of the Czech Republic, where he started in the fields of European integration and financial policy. Since 2001, he has been director of the Department of the National Fund, where he focused mainly on the financial management and certification of EU funds, as well as the financial perspective and the EU budget. At present, it operates in several prestigious positions, which point to its wide perspective in the field of financial services. Since 2010, he has been Secretary of State for the Minister of Finance for the Public Budgets Section, where he is responsible, among other things, for treasury, accounting and EU funds. In addition, he holds the post of Vice-President of the Supervisory Board of the Czech Export Bank, is a member of the Board of Directors of the European Investment Bank, serves on the Board of Directors of the General Health Insurance Company of the Czech Republic and is also vice-chairman of the Supervisory Board of the Czechoslovak Guarantee and Development Bank. At the same time, however, I hope that its diverse activities will not hinder its independence and impartiality, as it is obliged, as a member of the European Court of Auditors, to exercise control over the use of EU funds in the interests of all European citizens.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. In view of the key role of the European Court of Auditors in overseeing the implementation of the EU budget and, in particular, assessing the added value of European Union policies, it is essential that its members are adequately trained and that there are no doubts as to their independence and potential conflicts of interest. The Committee on Budgetary Control assessed the candidate's recommendations, in particular in the light of the requirements of Article 286(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and approved the Council's proposal to appoint Jan Gregor as a member of the Court of Auditors. Gregor worked in the Czech Ministry of Finance, also as Deputy Minister for Public Budget, is a member of the Board of Directors of the European Investment Bank and the General Health Insurance Office of the Czech Republic and a member of the Supervisory Board of the Czech Export Bank and the Czech-Moravian Bank for Guarantees and Development. The candidate shall have experience in the audit, planning and implementation of the budget and in budgetary control. He was not appointed to the position of deputy minister politically or by the government, but worked as a civil servant. For this reason, I supported his appointment as a Member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒Given that the Committee on Budgetary Control assessed the qualifications of the proposed candidate, in particular as regards the conditions set out in Article 286(1) of the EIA. agreement on the functioning of the European Union, and since the meeting of the Committee on Budgetary Control on 15 March 2016 held a hearing of the Candidates of the Council for Membership in the Court of Auditors, I supported the appointment of Jan Gregor as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ The European Court of Auditors is in charge of the audit of EU finances and, as the EU’s external auditor, it contributes to improving EU financial management and acts as the independent guardian of the financial interests of the citizens of the Union. It is vitally important that candidates for the Court are selected based on their suitability for the position, and their professional background, language skills and the ability to exercise independent judgement are important considerations.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The role of the Court of Auditors is unique and involves instilling trust in the democratic institutions of the European Union, which can have a strong positive impact on the views of EU citizens. It is therefore important that all members of the Court of Auditors perform their duties to the highest expectations of EU citizens for whom transparency of the EU institutions is very important. I support the draft report on the proposed appointment of Jan Gregor as a member of the Court of Auditors. I am of the belief that Jan Gregor will contribute to improving cooperation between the Court of Auditors, national audit institutions and the European Parliament, namely the Committee on Budgetary Control, when revising the EU budget. Furthermore, I believe that Jan Gregor's work will further improve the court's reports so that the European Parliament has access to all necessary information on the accuracy of the data provided by member states to the European Commission.  I believe that Jan Gregor, like all other members of the Court of Auditors, will carry out his duty completely independently, thus contributing with his impartiality, objectivity and integrity to the work of the Court of Auditors and the cooperation thereof with the European Parliament.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The selection of persons for positions of responsibility and Union interest should be based on the integrity of their character and their proven activity with regard to the protection of public money in the broadest sense

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. We have received, studied and issued an opinion on this person's candidacy as a member of the Court of Auditors. The Committee on Budgetary Control assessed the qualifications of the proposed candidate, particularly in light of the conditions set out in Article 286, paragraph 1, of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. A hearing was then undertaken during the month of March by the Council as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the nomination of Jan Gregor as a member of the Court of Auditors. Building on his long-standing experience in the European banking and financial sector, I am certain that Jan Gregor will be able to fulfil the requirements of his new job.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 In my report on the appointment of Jan Gregor as a Member of the Court of Auditors, I voted in my conscience – a secret ballot. The Committee on Budgetary Control has assessed the candidate's professional qualifications, in particular in the light of the requirements laid down in Article 286(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. At its meeting of 15 March 2016, the Committee on Budgetary Control listened to the presentation of the Council's candidate for member of the Court of Auditors and approved the Council's proposal to appoint Jan Gregor as a member of the Court of Auditors and instruct his President to forward this Decision to the Council and the Court of Auditors for information, as well as to the other institutions of the European Union and the auditing bodies of the Member States.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. The selection procedure for the members of the Court of Auditors was highly criticized. However, most candidates lack the right professional knowledge and show strong indications of a potential conflict of interest. None of the candidates presented at the required level of professional knowledge for the position were nor were they able to ensure that they would be able to perform their tasks with the necessary degree of independence. Despite the European Parliament's systematic requests for previous Council reports, the Court of Auditors has an extraordinary gender imbalance that is exacerbated by current nominations, the 6 candidates are men. For all these reasons, we vote against all proposals.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control evaluated the capabilities, history and professionalism of the proposed candidate. I voted to follow S&D's position on the nomination of the candidate.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. The selection procedure for the members of the Court of Auditors was highly criticized. However, most candidates lack the right professional knowledge and show strong indications of a potential conflict of interest. None of the candidates presented at the required level of professional knowledge for the position were nor were they able to ensure that they would be able to perform their tasks with the necessary degree of independence. Despite the European Parliament's systematic requests for previous Council reports, the Court of Auditors has an extraordinary gender imbalance that is exacerbated by current nominations, the 6 candidates are men. For all these reasons, we vote AGAINST all proposals.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I decided to stick to the vote of the greens in the CONT Committee meaning that I supported candidates Jan Gregor, Samo Jereb and Mihails Kozlovs. I voted against Ladislav Balko and Janusz Woiciechowski. I wanted to stress the need to respect the demands in the TFEU concerning the professional experiences and candidates’ complete independence and the need to assure the gender balance in the EU’s top positions.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the nomination of Jan Gregor as a Member of the Court of Auditors because there are no legal, political or personal reasons on the grounds of which an objection to his nomination would be founded.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of the appointment of Jan Gregor to the Court of Auditors.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The selection process has once again been highly criticized. Once again, most candidates lack adequate professional qualification and strong indications of possible conflicts of interest are present. None of the candidates has the necessary level of professional specialisation for the position, and neither were they able to ensure that they would be able to perform the functions in question with the necessary degree of independence. Furthermore, despite the systematic requests of the European Parliament in previous reports to the Council and the Court of Auditors, there is a major gender imbalance, which is compounded by current applications, as all six candidates are men. We reject all candidates on the basis of the obvious lack of independence and the likelihood of conflicts of interest, which undermine both the mission and role of the Court of Auditors as an independent external auditor of the EU, as well as the lack of gender balance.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the four approved candidates for the posts of members of the European Court of Auditors, as I believe that it is these individuals who are able to offer high quality, determination and many years of experience from their position. First of all, I very much appreciate the fact that I was able to support the new Czech member of the Court of Auditors, Jan Gregor, who will replace Jan Kinšt, an extremely capable and hardworking man, whom I greatly appreciate. I believe that Jan Gregor will be a very good successor who will capitalize on his rich experience in the Ministry of Finance of the Czech Republic in his new position and who will push for greater transparency and integrity in the European Union. I am very much looking forward to establishing cooperation between the European Parliament and Mr Gregor and the other new members.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 Taking into account the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control, I supported the candidate Jan Gregor as a Member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The appointment of Ladislav Balko, a former member of the Court of Auditors, was influenced by the poor performance of the cont committee hearing. Moreover, although not provided for by law, gender equality has not been respected. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted against the 5 candidates proposed to be members of the Court of Auditors for various reasons: because of their lack of independence, the possibility of conflict of interest, the lack of professional knowledge in the field of audit, as well as the lack of gender balance, since they are all men.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted against this Nomination to the Court of Auditors on the grounds that none of the candidates including Ladislav Balko held the required level of professional qualifications or expertise that would be required to satisfactory fulfil the post. My parties’ policy has always been about transparency, accountability and diversity on all boards, including State Boards. In Ireland, we have seen first had the corrosive culture of cronyism. We are still seeing it in the cronyism of debacle which is currently occurring around Government Formations. Furthermore, despite concerns being raised by the European Parliament on a number of occasions, all 6 candidates nominated were men. This is completely unacceptable and serves only to undermine any positive advances which have been made in recent years to increase the number of women in public life. Sinn Fein will have no hand or part in any such regressive, duplicitous or purposely vague moves. The society we are aiming for is one that is real, meaningful and where issues such as gender equality will be truly tackled and where cronyism is confined to the political dustbin of life.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This vote was by secret ballot, I cannot reveal my choice. For the appointment of the members of the European Court of Auditors, I voted on the basis of three criteria: probity, independence from political forces and competences.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I believe in democracy and transparency, and therefore I believe that my vote on this matter should be a matter of public record. In that spirit, I wish to confirm that I abstained on this appointment.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee responsible for the substance.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of appointing Ladislav Balk as a Member of the Court of Auditors. Ladislav Balko became a member of the European Court of Auditors on 7 May 2010. Until 10 January 2014, he was a member of Chamber IV. Dr Balko was responsible for the audit statement of assurance in the areas of research and other internal policies, as well as for auditing activities in the same areas. April 2012 he became the substitute member of Chamber IV for the coordination, evaluation, assurance and development of horizontal issues ( cead) and on 1 February 2013 as a substitute for the Chamber IV in the Administrative Committee. He was also a member of the Internal Audit Committee from 12 February 2012 and chaired it from 24 April 2013 to 28 February 2014.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I voted against the appointment of this current member of the European Court of Auditors, former head of tax and customs and director of the Slovak import/export bank, who is reluctant to clearly answer the legitimate questions put to him.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. In issuing my vote, I took into account the report and the vote in the Committee on Budgetary Control.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors is an important European institution which acts as an external and independent auditor of the Union. Founded in 1977, it only became a fully-capacity EU institution in 1993 and continued to provide support for improving the management of the Community budget. It shall consist of one member from each State of the Union, each of which shall be appointed by the Council after consulting Parliament and shall remain in office for six years. On this occasion, Parliament was called upon to give its opinion on the appointment of Ladislav Balko. Having taken note of the content of the report by the Committee on Budgetary Control and following the instructions of my political group, S&D voted in secret on the proposed name.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. The selection procedure for the members of the Court of Auditors was highly criticized. However, most candidates lack the right professional knowledge and show strong indications of a potential conflict of interest. None of the candidates presented at the required level of professional knowledge for the position were nor were they able to ensure that they would be able to perform their tasks with the necessary degree of independence. Despite the European Parliament's systematic requests for previous Council reports, the Court of Auditors has an extraordinary gender imbalance that is exacerbated by current nominations, the 6 candidates are men. For all these reasons, we vote against all proposals.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This is the appointment (or renewal) of a member of the European Court of Auditors. The European Parliament is consulted on the appointment. Mr. Ladislav Balko is currently a member of the European Court of Auditors and former head of tax and customs and director of the Slovak import/export bank. At his hearing, he was apparently reluctant to answer questions clearly and was already subject to question; despite its current status, it made a very bad impression. So I voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not question the professional skills of this candidate, but I do not have sufficient evidence to give him my full support. That's why I abstained.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. This morning, the Plenary of the European Parliament put to the vote, in secret, the proposal to appoint Ladislav Balko as a member of the Court of Auditors following the evaluation of the candidate's qualifications and the hearing held on 15 March before the Committee on Budgetary Control, a vote in which I participated.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report to appoint Slovak candidate Ladislav Balko as a Member of the Court of Auditors. He became a member of the European Court of Auditors on 7 May 2010. Dr Balko was responsible for the audit statement of assurance in the areas of research and other internal policies, as well as for auditing activities in the same areas. On 1 February 2014, he was appointed a member of Chamber II (Structural, Transport and Energy Policy); He is also rapporteur for the Section for Economic, Social and Territorial Cohesion and responsible for auditing the DAS and auditing activities in the field of regional policy and the Structural Funds. He is a member representing Chamber II of the CEAD College and has also been rapporteur for several performance audits. Ladislav Balko has accumulated a great deal of experience and knowledge during his mandate about the work of the European Court of Auditors and the accountability framework under which they work. He is firmly committed to using all this knowledge and experience in further work at the European Court of Auditors to implement their annual and multi-annual strategy papers by 2017 and beyond, providing an even more results-oriented annual report that takes into account the needs of our key stakeholders, in particular the European Parliament, as well as relevant and timely special reports with added value.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the appointment of a member of the Court of Auditors – Ladislav Balko, because, by following his work both in his home country and within the institutions he has administered, he can only add a large addition to the Court of Auditors, the EU institutions, but also to the supervisory institutions of all The Member States. After the Committee on Budgetary Control heard the candidate proposed by the Council to be a member of the Court of Auditors, it issued a favourable opinion on the appointment of Ladislav Balko to be a member of the Court of Auditors. Thus, the last step left is for the President to forward the Council's decision and, for information, to the Court of Auditors and the other EU institutions, as well as to the supervisory institutions of the Member States.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Committee on Budgets has delivered a negative opinion on the appointment of Mr Balko (Slovakia) as a member of the Court of Auditors (formerly an outgoing member). Abstention vote.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I think he is a high-profile person. Former associate professor of financial and commercial law, he has repeatedly held senior roles in the public sector, gaining a long experience in the financial sector. In 2010 he was appointed a member of the Court of Auditors, gaining extensive experience in the fields of "Structural Policies, Transport and Energy" and "Revenue, Research and Internal Policies", an in-depth knowledge of the activities of the Court of Auditors. During its term of office, Parliament, and in particular the CONT Committee, has on several occasions had the opportunity to see its seriousness and competence.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this Nomination to the Court of Auditors on the grounds that none of the candidates including Ladislav Balko held the required level of professional qualifications or expertise that would be required to satisfactory fulfil the post. My parties’ policy has always been about transparency, accountability and diversity on all boards, including State Boards. In Ireland, we have seen first had the corrosive culture of cronyism. We are still seeing it in the cronyism of debacle which is currently occurring around Government Formations. Furthermore, despite concerns being raised by the European Parliament on a number of occasions, all 6 candidates nominated were men. This is completely unacceptable and serves only to undermine any positive advances which have been made in recent years to increase the number of women in public life. Sinn Fein will have no hand or part in any such regressive, duplicitous or purposely vague moves. The society we are aiming for is one that is real, meaningful and where issues such as gender equality will be truly tackled and where cronyism is confined to the political dustbin of life.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this appointment not so much because of a personal matter with the candidate but for different reasons. First of all, I regret seeing a fairly marked gender imbalance: out of 28 members, only 5 are women. Where is gender equality? The Member States and the Council should be the first to give a signal to promote gender equality in all institutions and at all levels. In addition, the system of appointing members continues to be a system of political appointment, more than merit. For these reasons, I have decided to vote against all the candidates.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting against the appointment of Ladeslav Balko.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the decision of the EPP Cont members and voted against Mr Balko.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Court of Auditors is the EU’s independent external auditor body that exercises control over the EU funds if they are collected and used correctly, and help improve EU financial management. The Committee on Budgetary Control delivered a negative opinion on the nomination of Ladislav Balko, thus I voted against.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 According to Article 286 TFET, members of the Court of Auditors are elected from among the personalities of the external audit institutions in their respective Member States. All 28 members of the Court of Auditors are appointed by the Council, after consulting the European Parliament, for a renewable period of six years. The new six candidates have very varied characteristics, which led to a split vote and only three candidates received support. With regard to the appointment of Ladislav Balko, I voted against, as this does not seem to guarantee the political independence necessary to become a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Partial replacement of the composition of the Members of the Court of Auditors takes place in accordance with Article 286(2) TFEU, which provides that the Council adopts a list of candidates proposed by the Member States after consulting the European Parliament. The members of the Court of Auditors shall be appointed for a period of six years. The appointment and renewal of appointments shall be voted on in plenary on the basis of the CONT report. Candidates must comply with the requirements laid down in Article 286(1) TFEU: Members of the Court of Auditors shall be chosen from among persons who are or have been members of external audit bodies in their own countries or who are particularly qualified to take up that post. Their independence must be unquestionable.  I supported the candidate in the vote.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. The terms of office of the six members of the Court of Auditors expire on 6 May 2016. After consultation with the European Parliament, the Council will adopt the list of members. Six candidates were nominated by the Member States: one Slovak candidate, one Latvian, one Czech, one Polish, one Maltese and one Slovenian.  Considering that the CONT Committee had expressed doubts about three candidates and offered a favourable opinion on three nominations (the Latvian, Czech and Slovenian candidates), I voted in favour of the appointment of Mr Kozlovs, the Latvian candidate, Mr Gregor, the Czech candidate, and Mr Jereb, the Slovenian candidate.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 Having fulfilled all the formalisms relating to the appointment of Ladislav Balko as a member of the Court of Auditors, in particular the assessment of his qualifications and his hearing, and there being no obstacle to his appointment, I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors (ECA) functions as a collegiate body of 28 members, one member of each Member State. These members shall be appointed by the Council, after consulting the European Parliament, for a renewable period of six years. The deadline for 6 of these posts will expire soon, and 6 new candidates have been proposed by the Member States. In a joint assessment of the universe of candidates, doubts are raised as to the full fulfilment of criteria of competence and professional experience, as to the political profile and independence, as to the suitability of the specific place and as to the existence of conflicts of interest. Some of these reasons prompted the rejection of some of the candidates in the Specialised Committee of the European Parliament responsible for assessing applications (Committee on Budgetary Control). Also in a global assessment, there is a lack of gender balance. There's not a single woman among the candidates. These are aspects that have weighed on our group's position in this vote.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the appointment and stay of Mr Ladislav Balk as a Member of the Court of Auditors because I am of the opinion that Mr Balko fulfils all professional, professional and personal qualities in order to hold the post in question.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 Abstention vote because the Committee on Budgets has delivered a negative opinion on the appointment.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not support the renewal of mr. Balko for the simple reason that in his 6 years of work in the Audit Council he has not presented any achievements on corruption fraud etc. All it presents is its relations with EU actors.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The ECA operates as a collegiate body of 28 Members, one from each Member State. The Members are appointed by the Council after consultation with the European Parliament for a renewable term of six years. Members elect one of their number as President for a renewable term of three years. This candidacy was a renewal. I voted against his renewal because his presentation was very poor, insufficient for an ECA member with experience in the field.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the appointment of Mr Ladislav Balko as a member of the European Court of Auditors.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the appointment of Ladislav Balko as a member of the Court of Auditors, as this selection of staff convinced me after examination.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. The selection procedure for the members of the Court of Auditors was highly criticized. However, most candidates lack the right professional knowledge and show strong indications of a potential conflict of interest. None of the candidates presented at the required level of professional knowledge for the position were nor were they able to ensure that they would be able to perform their tasks with the necessary degree of independence. Despite the European Parliament's systematic requests for previous Council reports, the Court of Auditors has an extraordinary gender imbalance that is exacerbated by current nominations, the 6 candidates are men. For all these reasons, we vote against all proposals.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ The European Court of Auditors is in charge of the audit of EU finances, and as the EU’s external auditor, it contributes to improving EU financial management and acts as the independent guardian of the financial interests of the citizens of the Union. It is vitally important that candidates for the Court are selected based on their suitability for the position, and their professional background, language skills and the ability to exercise independent judgement are important considerations.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the nomination of Ladislav Balko as a Member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted against the proposal for the candidate under reference on the basis of the apparent lack of independence and the possibility of a conflict of interest that undermines the mission but also the role of the Court of Auditors as an independent EU external auditor and "economic supervisor", as well as because of the lack of gender balance.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the nomination of the member of the Court of Auditors, Ladislav Balko.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a decision by the European Parliament on the proposed appointment of Ladislav Balk as a member of the Court of Auditors, which gives a negative opinion on the Council's proposal to appoint Mr Balko as a member of the Court, because that is the position of the ALDE Group which I have decided to follow in this vote.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. Current December of the European Court of Auditors, former head of tax and customs and director of the Slovak import/export bank. Unwilling to answer questions clearly and already subject to caution, despite his current status, he made a very bad impression. I voted against it.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted against my colleague Igor Soltes' report on the appointment of Ladislav Balko as a member of the Court of Auditors. The Slovak candidate does not, in my view, have the experience and skills required for the position.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This report concerns the nomination of Mr. Ladislav Balko as a Member of the Court of Auditors. I am abstaining on this report.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted against the 5 candidates proposed to be members of the Court of Auditors for various reasons: because of their lack of independence, the possibility of conflict of interest, the lack of professional knowledge in the field of audit, as well as the lack of gender balance, since they are all men.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒Members of the EU Court of Auditors review the revenues and expenditures of all Union institutions and agencies.  In 2016, 10 members of the Court of Auditors will be appointed and new members will be appointed for a period of six years. In order to become members of the Court of Auditors, candidates first have a hearing in the Committee on Budgetary Control, which gives its opinion on candidates. After that, each candidate shall be voted on at parliament's plenary session, based on a report from the Committee.  Each Member State shall submit a proposal for a candidate for a member of the Court of Auditors and the Council shall decide on the list of the best candidates who then have a hearing in the Committee on Budgetary Control and are finally confirmed at parliament's session. The candidate for member of the Court of Auditors, Ladislav Balko, does not have the same experience in auditing as other candidates, so I voted against the report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mr Balko's candidacy and paying the utmost attention to his professional experience and a number of other factors. He was elected with 328 votes to 317, and 52 abstentions.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the proposed appointment of Ladimir Balko as a member of the Court of Auditors as I do not agree with key points in that report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The Court of Auditors aims to improve the financial management of the EU and encourage transparency. It verifies whether the EU budget has been properly implemented and whether EU funds have been collected and spent legally and in accordance with the principles of good financial management.  The Court is composed of 28 members (one per Member State) appointed by the Council, after consultation with Parliament, for a renewable term of six years. The selection process at the Court of Auditors has long been widely criticised for its lack of transparency and lack of independence of candidates, who generally do not have the professional skills required for this position.  The Slovak candidate, Mr Ladislav Balko, has already been a member of the European Court of Auditors with poor results, so the committee rejected his appointment. I also vote against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors is a supervisory institution, which verifies the legality and regularity of EU revenue and expenditure, as well as good financial management, carrying out its functions with complete independence. In this spirit, the appointment of the individualities that compose it must be governed by criteria of competence and independence. Thus, at the initiative of the Council, several personalities from various EU countries were appointed to the Court of Auditors. The applicant submitted his Curriculum Vitae, replied to a written questionnaire and was heard in the Committee on Budgetary Control and put forward sufficient arguments to justify the appointment to the Court of Auditors in order to carry out his duties there competently and independently. I voted in favour of ladislav balko's name.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council nominated Ladislav Balk as a member of the Court of Auditors. The appointment is the responsibility of the Council, but it is necessary to consult Parliament before deciding. The Committee on Budgetary Control evaluated the capabilities of the proposed candidate and listened to the candidate at its meeting on 15 March 2016. In its report, it proposes that Parliament give an unfavourable opinion on the Council's proposal to appoint Ladislav Balko as a Member of the Court of Auditors. I did not support the nomination of the candidate.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ The European Court of Auditors is in charge of the audit of EU finances and as the EU’s external auditor, it contributes to improving EU financial management and acts as the independent guardian of the financial interests of the citizens of the Union. It is vitally important that candidates for the Court are selected based on their suitability for the position, their professional background, language skills and the ability to exercise independent judgement are important considerations.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted against this report which proposed the appointment of Ladislav Balko as a member of the Court of Auditors. Ladislav Balko was heard by the Committee on Budgetary Control. The members of this commission gave an unfavourable opinion on this nomination, finding that this candidate did not have the experience or skills required for the position.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the committee responsible did not recommend Mr Balko, I voted in favour. In such a responsible position, it is important that my country is represented by a qualified professional. Mr Balko's professional biography is honourable, pointing out that he is not only an official, but has a forward-looking vision and a complex, systemic reform vision. It is important to point out that although he has come into contact with politics on numerous occasions throughout his career, he has maintained a pure and apolitical, exclusively professional status, and has been involved in the public sector as a professional. I see his role in the introduction of the euro as an important point in our country.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted the nomination of Ladislav Balko as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 With reference to Mr Šoltes' proposal, given the position taken by the Committee on Budgetary Control, I cannot but vote against the appointment of Ladislav Balko as a member of the Court of Auditors. I therefore voted against.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The Court of Auditors is important for monitoring and controlling the use of EU funding, and its independence and the quality of work of judges guarantee the protection of the interests of all EU citizens. After Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control assessed the qualifications of the proposed candidate and after the hearing of the Council candidates for membership in the Court of Auditors, the Committee on Budgetary Control gave a negative opinion on the appointment of this candidate as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. Although he is currently a member of the European Court of Auditors, former head of tax and customs and director of the Slovak import/export bank, he has shown little inclination to answer questions clearly during the hearing. Already subject to bail, despite his current status, he made a very bad impression. I'm voting against his nomination.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. Ladislav Balko was born in Slovakia. He holds a law degree from Comenius University in Bratislava. After that, he completed his doctoral degree in law and earned the title of Doctor of Science and began to teach financial and commercial law. In 1990 and 1991 he was head of the legal service of the Customs Administration of the Slovak Republic. From 1991 to 1999 he held a number of management positions, including as deputy director-general of Slovakia's largest commercial bank, Všeobecná úverová banka (VÚB). From 2001 to 2004 he worked as deputy governor and member of the board of directors of the Slovak Export and Import Bank, and in 2003 he was chief business manager of the Slovak Investment and Trade Development Agency (SARIO). In 2004 he was appointed as a member of the management board - managing authority - of the National Bank of Slovakia (NBS). Thanks to his years of experience working in the financial sector, Dr Balko became an adviser to the Prime Minister of the Slovak Republic for Finance and Foreign Investment in 2006. For all of the above, I support the appointment of a colleague as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors (ECA) functions as a collegiate body of 28 members, one member of each Member State. These members shall be appointed by the Council, after consulting the European Parliament, for a renewable period of six years. The deadline for 6 of these posts will expire soon, and 6 new candidates have been proposed by the Member States. In a joint assessment of the universe of candidates, doubts are raised as to the full fulfilment of criteria of competence and professional experience, as to the political profile and independence, as to the suitability of the specific place and as to the existence of conflicts of interest. Some of these reasons prompted the rejection of some of the candidates in the Specialised Committee of the European Parliament responsible for assessing applications (Committee on Budgetary Control). Also in a global assessment, there is a lack of gender balance. There's not a single woman among the candidates. These are aspects that have weighed on our group's position in this vote.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the Slovak candidate for the European Court of Auditors Ladislav Balk, whom I highly appreciate for his professional experience and work done so far.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors is a collegiate body composed of 28 members, one for each Member State, who are appointed by the Council, after consultation with the European Parliament, for a renewable period of six years. I welcome the appointment of Ladislav Balko as a member of the Court of Auditors and wish him well in the hope that he will be able to play his role with the utmost independence and transparency in the general interest of the European Union.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. We have been asked to rule on the appointment of an auditor from the European Court of Auditors. This procedure demonstrates the usefulness of Parliament in exercising its control over the functioning of the European institutions.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the Committee on Budgetary Control assessed The Qualifications of Ladislav Balko and held its hearing, this report gives its assent to the Council's proposal to appoint the candidate to the post of member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. This morning, the Plenary of the European Parliament put to the vote, in secret, the proposal to appoint Ladislav Balko as a member of the Court of Auditors following the evaluation of the candidate's qualifications and the hearing held on 15 March before the Committee on Budgetary Control, a vote in which I participated.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Parliament this lunchtime approved the appointment of Slovakia's auditor, Ladislav Balko (328 votes in for, 317 against, and 52 abstentions) to the European Court of Auditors, but rejected the Polish auditor's candidacy, according to the recommendations of the Committee on Budgetary Control. Toni Abela, the Maltese candidate, withdrew his candidacy following the committee's unfavorable opinion. The final decision on assignment to Luxembourg will be taken by the EU Council of Ministers. Members of the Court of Auditors are appointed for six years. The Council, after consulting the European Parliament, makes its decision according to the proposals made by each Member State.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report to appoint The Slovak candidate Ladislav Balko as a Member of the Court of Auditors. Ladislav graduated in law from J.A. Komensky University in Bratislava. He later received a PhD in law and became an associate professor of financial and commercial law. He became a member of the European Court of Auditors on 7 May 2010. Until 10 January 2014, he was a member of Chamber IV. Dr Balko was responsible for the audit statement of assurance in the areas of research and other internal policies, as well as for auditing activities in the same areas.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the appointment of Ladislav Balko as Member of the Court of Auditors, since, at the hearing by the Committee on Budgetary Control, the candidate demonstrated competence and professional experience in the performance of those functions. Following the Council proposal dated 15 March 2016, the selection process has been carried out in an open and transparent manner, so I have no objection to this appointment.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. The selection procedure for the members of the Court of Auditors was highly criticized. However, most candidates lack the right professional knowledge and show strong indications of a potential conflict of interest. None of the candidates presented at the required level of professional knowledge for the position were nor were they able to ensure that they would be able to perform their tasks with the necessary degree of independence. Despite the European Parliament's systematic requests for previous Council reports, the Court of Auditors has an extraordinary gender imbalance that is exacerbated by current nominations, the 6 candidates are men. For all these reasons, we vote against all proposals.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted against the 5 candidates proposed to be members of the Court of Auditors for various reasons: because of their lack of independence, the possibility of conflict of interest, the lack of professional knowledge in the field of audit, as well as the lack of gender balance, since they are all men.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ As I’ve mentioned before, The European Court of Auditors plays a vital role in the institutions, being in charge of the audit of the EU’s finances and, as the EU’s external auditor, it contributes to improving the financial management of the EU as well as acting as the independent guardian of the financial interests of the EU’s half a billion citizens. In my view, it is vitally important that candidates for the Court are selected based on their suitability for the position, their professional backgrounds, language skills and the ability to exercise independent judgment are all important for considerations. I could not support the re-election of Mr. Balko in the vote; despite his experience, his poor presentation in the committee was surprisingly sub-par for someone with such experience in the field.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the fact that as a Member of the Court of Auditors, a representative from each EU member country can check that EU funds are being correctly collected and used and help improve EU financial management.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the public hearing of candidate Ladislav Balk did not go according to the wishes of the Committee on Budgetary Control, I nevertheless decided to support Mr Balk's candidacy for the post of Member of the European Court of Auditors. According to the information available, he is a qualified professional who has held the post since 2010 and would thus guarantee the continuity and stability of his work for the Court of Auditors. He held management positions in the field of financial and commercial law from the 1990s, when he served as Deputy Director-General of the General Credit Bank. Since 2001, he has held the position of Deputy Governor and Member of the Board of Directors of the Export-Import Bank of the Slovak Republic, later served as Executive Director of the Slovak Investment and Trade Development Agency, and was finally appointed a member of the Bank Board of the National Bank of Slovakia in 2004. Based on his many years of experience in the financial sphere, he became an adviser to the Prime Minister of the Slovak Republic on Finance and Foreign Investment and in this capacity also contributed to the adoption of the euro in Slovakia. He joined the European Court of Auditors in May 2010 and was responsible for auditing during his time at the institution for the purpose of the Statement of Assurance in the field of research and other internal policies. In view of his professional and professional experience, I believe that his continued work at the Court of Auditors would be beneficial.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 The Court plays an irreplaceable role among the European institutions. In future, it will have to place even greater emphasis on overseeing the efficiency of the use of European funds. I am pleased that the European Parliament has once again given its trust to the Auditor from Slovakia, Doc. JUDr. Ladislav Balk, PhD., who has many years of experience in the financial sphere and during his career held the position of adviser to the Prime Minister on Finance and Foreign Investment.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ The European Court of Auditors is in charge of the audit of EU finances, and as the EU’s external auditor, it contributes to improving EU financial management and acts as the independent guardian of the financial interests of the citizens of the Union. It is vitally important that candidates for the Court are selected based on their suitability for the position, and their professional background, language skills and the ability to exercise independent judgement are important considerations.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The role of the Court of Auditors is unique and involves instilling trust in the democratic institutions of the European Union, which can have a strong positive impact on the views of EU citizens. It is therefore important that all members of the Court of Auditors fulfil their duties to the highest expectations of EU citizens for whom the transparency of the EU institutions is very important and contribute with their impartiality, objectivity and integrity to the work of the Court of Auditors and their cooperation with the European Parliament. I do not support the draft report on the proposed appointment of Ladislav Balk as a member of the Court of Auditors. Unfortunately, Ladislav Balko did not show competence or interest at the hearing. Therefore, I cannot agree to appoint him as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The selection of persons for positions of responsibility and Union interest should be based on the integrity of their character and their proven activity with regard to the protection of public money in the broadest sense

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. We have received, studied and issued an opinion on this person's candidacy as a member of the Court of Auditors. The Committee on Budgetary Control assessed the qualifications of the proposed candidate, particularly in light of the conditions set out in Article 286, paragraph 1, of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. A hearing was then undertaken during the month of March by the Council as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Ladislav Balko the renewing the nomination of as a member of the Court of Auditors. In addition to his experience in the court of Auditors, his journey in the financial field, but also his role as adviser to the Prime Minister of the Slovak Republic for finance and foreign investment, during which he played a strong role in contribution to the adoption of the euro in Slovakia will make of him an excellent candidate for the job.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Given that Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control assessed the negative qualifications of the proposed candidate, in particular as regards the conditions set out in Article 286(1) of the EIA. Agreement on the functioning of the European Union, I did not support Ladislav Balk's candidacy to appoint a member of the Court of Auditors. At a session of Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control, on 15 March 2016, a hearing of the Candidates of the Council for Membership in the Court of Auditors was held and after that hearing the Committee gave a negative opinion on its appointment. Consequently, I voted against the appointment of Ladislav Balk as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 In my report on the appointment of Ladislav Balk as a Member of the Court of Auditors, I voted according to my conscience – a secret vote. The Committee on Budgetary Control has assessed the candidate's professional qualifications, in particular in the light of the requirements laid down in Article 286(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. At its meeting of 15 March 2016, the Committee on Budgetary Control listened to the presentation of the Council's candidate for member of the Court of Auditors and approved the Council's proposal to appoint Ladislav Balko as a member of the Court of Auditors and instruct its President to forward this Decision to the Council and, for information, to the Court of Auditors, as well as to the other institutions of the European Union and the audit bodies of the Member States.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. The selection procedure for the members of the Court of Auditors was highly criticized. However, most candidates lack the right professional knowledge and show strong indications of a potential conflict of interest. None of the candidates presented at the required level of professional knowledge for the position were nor were they able to ensure that they would be able to perform their tasks with the necessary degree of independence. Despite the European Parliament's systematic requests for previous Council reports, the Court of Auditors has an extraordinary gender imbalance that is exacerbated by current nominations, the 6 candidates are men. For all these reasons, we vote against all proposals.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control evaluated the capabilities, history and professionalism of the proposed candidate. I voted to follow S&D's position on the nomination of the candidate.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. The selection procedure for the members of the Court of Auditors was highly criticized. However, most candidates lack the right professional knowledge and show strong indications of a potential conflict of interest. None of the candidates presented at the required level of professional knowledge for the position were nor were they able to ensure that they would be able to perform their tasks with the necessary degree of independence. Despite the European Parliament's systematic requests for previous Council reports, the Court of Auditors has an extraordinary gender imbalance that is exacerbated by current nominations, the 6 candidates are men. For all these reasons, we vote against all proposals.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I decided to stick to the vote of the greens in the CONT Committee meaning that I supported candidates Jan Gregor, Samo Jereb and Mihails Kozlovs. I voted against Ladislav Balko and Janusz Woiciechowski. I wanted to stress the need to respect the demands in the TFEU concerning the professional experiences and candidates’ complete independence and the need to assure the gender balance in the EU’s top positions.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the nomination of Ladislav Balko as a Member of the Court of Auditors because there are no legal, political or personal reasons on the grounds of which an objection to his nomination would be founded.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of the appointment of Ladislav Balko as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The selection process has once again been highly criticized. Once again, most candidates lack adequate professional qualification and strong indications of possible conflicts of interest are present. None of the candidates has the necessary level of professional specialisation for the position, and neither were they able to ensure that they would be able to perform the functions in question with the necessary degree of independence. Furthermore, despite the systematic requests of the European Parliament in previous reports to the Council and the Court of Auditors, there is a major gender imbalance which is aggravated by current applications, as all six candidates are men. We reject all candidates on the basis of the obvious lack of independence and the likelihood of conflicts of interest, which undermine both the mission and role of the Court of Auditors as an independent external auditor of the EU, as well as the lack of gender balance.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 Appointments to the Court of Auditors should be reserved for persons of marked professionalism and independent of politics. Janusz Wojciechowsk is currently a Member of the European Parliament in the ECR Group, so it is impossible for him to have the political independence sought in a future Member of the Court. That is why I voted against.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted against the 5 candidates proposed to be members of the Court of Auditors for various reasons: because of their lack of independence, the possibility of conflict of interest, the lack of professional knowledge in the field of audit, as well as the lack of gender balance, since they are all men.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Janusz Wojciechowski in connection with the appointment of a member of the Court of Auditors. Indeed, in view of his CV, I find that his experience is in line with that expected of a member of the Court.  In addition, the Committee on Budgetary Control accused him of being Eurosceptic. However, the role of the European Court of Auditors is precisely to be neutral. The question is therefore not so much whether the candidate is in favour of Europe or not, but rather whether his experience and background allow him to be objective and competent.  Janusz Wojciechowski is the best candidate for me.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted against this Nomination to the Court of Auditors on the grounds that none of the candidates including Janusz Wojciechowski held the required level of professional qualifications or expertise that would be required to satisfactory fulfil the post. My parties’ policy has always been about transparency, accountability and diversity on all boards, including State Boards. In Ireland, we have seen first had the corrosive culture of cronyism. We are still seeing it in the cronyism of debacle which is currently occurring around Government Formations. Furthermore, despite concerns being raised by the European Parliament on a number of occasions, all 6 candidates nominated were men. This is completely unacceptable and serves only to undermine any positive advances which have been made in recent years to increase the number of women in public life. Sinn Fein will have no hand or part in any such regressive, duplicitous or purposely vague moves. The society we are aiming for is one that is real, meaningful and where issues such as gender equality will be truly tackled and where cronyism is confined to the political dustbin of life.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This vote was by secret ballot, I cannot reveal my choice. For the appointment of the members of the European Court of Auditors, I voted on the basis of three criteria: probity, independence from political forces and competences.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I believe in democracy and transparency, and therefore I believe that my vote on this matter should be a matter of public record. In that spirit, I wish to confirm that I voted against this appointment.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee responsible for the substance.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of appointing Mr Wojciechowski as a Member of the Court of Auditors. Janusz Wojciechowski was chairman of the Supreme Audit Authority, the constitutional state audit body that monitors the state budget and other areas of state activity from 1995 to 2001, after he was elected by the Polish Parliament for a six-year term.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. A Member of the European Parliament since 2004 of the PiS, current Vice-President of the Agriculture Committee, a former member of CONT, his many talents and experience are in line with those expected of a member of the Court. So I voted in favour of his appointment.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. In issuing my vote, I took into account the report and the vote in the Committee on Budgetary Control

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors is an important European institution which acts as an external and independent auditor of the Union. Founded in 1977, it only became a fully-capacity EU institution in 1993 and continued to provide support for improving the management of the Community budget. It shall consist of one member from each State of the Union, each of which shall be appointed by the Council after consulting Parliament and shall remain in office for six years. On this occasion, Parliament was called upon to give its opinion on the appointment of Janusz Wojciechowski. Having taken note of the content of the report by the Committee on Budgetary Control and following the instructions of my political group, S&D voted in secret on the proposed name.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. The selection procedure for the members of the Court of Auditors was highly criticized. However, most candidates lack the right professional knowledge and show strong indications of a potential conflict of interest. None of the candidates presented at the required level of professional knowledge for the position were nor were they able to ensure that they would be able to perform their tasks with the necessary degree of independence. Despite the European Parliament's systematic requests for previous Council reports, the Court of Auditors has an extraordinary gender imbalance that is exacerbated by current nominations, the 6 candidates are men. For all these reasons, we vote against all proposals.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This is the appointment (or renewal) of a member of the European Court of Auditors. The European Parliament is consulted on the appointment. Mr Wojciechowski has been an MEP since 2004, a member of the ECR group and the Polish Law and Justice party. He is also the current vice-chairman of the agriculture committee and a former member of CONT. His talents and experience are in line with those expected of a member of the Court.  Moreover, its seriousness, which I have observed in other functions such as the presidency of an intergroup in which I sit, encourages me to vote in support.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported with my vote the appointment of Janusz Wojciechowski as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing.
