This morning the Plenary of the European Parliament put to the vote, in secret, the proposal to appoint Janusz Wojciechowski as a member of the Court of Auditors following the evaluation of the candidate's qualifications and the hearing held on 15 March before the Committee on Budgetary Control, a vote in which I participated.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report to appoint The Polish candidate, Janusz Wojciechowsk, as a Member of the Court of Auditors. From 1995 to 2001, he was the Supreme Audit Institution (1995-2001). NIK), the president of the constitutional state audit body, which monitors the state budget and other areas of state activity, has been elected by the Polish Parliament for a six-year term. When Mr Wojciechowski was in office, he submitted six audit reports on the implementation of the state budget to the Polish Parliament and answered questions from Members of Parliament. As Chairman of NIK, he was also responsible for preparing and managing the NIK budget itself. This candidate has worked on issues relating to the EU budget since 2004, both as a Member of the European Parliament and, in particular, as vice-chairman of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report which approves the appointment of Janusz Wojciechowski to the Court of Auditors. The experience and competence of this Polish MEMBER of the ECR, who is currently Vice-President of the Agriculture Committee, appears to be in line with those expected of a member of the Court.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 In the light of both Article 286(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and Article 121 of the Rules of Procedure, which have been consulted by the Council with a view to appointing a new member of the Court of Auditors, the qualifications of the proposed candidate have been assessed, taking into account the conditions laid down in Article 286(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. After hearing the candidate proposed by the Council to be a member of the Court of Auditors, the Committee on Budgetary Control issued a favourable opinion on the appointment of Janusz Wojciechowski to be a member of the Court of Auditors, and the last step is for the President to forward this decision to the Council and, for information, both to the Court of Auditors and to the other EU institutions , but also to the control institutions of the Member States. I voted in favour of the report on the appointment of a member of the Court of Auditors – Janusz Wojciechowski, because I believe that he will be an important pawn in the Court of Auditors and will bring a great deal of addition to the European institutions as well as to the institutions of the EU Member States.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Committee on Budgets gave a negative opinion on the appointment of Mr Wojciechowski (Poland) as a Member of the Court of Auditors. Wojciechowski is currently a Member of the European Parliament of the ECR Group and the governing party in Poland, PiS. I prefer to approve the appointment proposed by the Polish Government. I am voting in favour.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I think he is a very good candidate, given the audit role he played as President of the Higher Institute of Control, his long career as a judge and his previous experience in the European institutions. In the questionnaire replies it was very convincing. His expertise and character: his previous experiences in managerial and decision-making roles, the work carried out in multilingual and multicultural contexts, the results obtained. I was particularly struck by the clarity of ideas in identifying how cooperation between the Court of Auditors, the national audit institutions and the European Parliament can be improved.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this Nomination to the Court of Auditors on the grounds that none of the candidates including Janusz Wojciechowski held the required level of professional qualifications or expertise that would be required to satisfactory fulfil the post. My parties’ policy has always been about transparency, accountability and diversity on all boards, including State Boards. In Ireland, we have seen first had the corrosive culture of cronyism. We are still seeing it in the cronyism of debacle which is currently occurring around Government Formations. Furthermore, despite concerns being raised by the European Parliament on a number of occasions, all 6 candidates nominated were men. This is completely unacceptable and serves only to undermine any positive advances which have been made in recent years to increase the number of women in public life. Sinn Fein will have no hand or part in any such regressive, duplicitous or purposely vague moves. The society we are aiming for is one that is real, meaningful and where issues such as gender equality will be truly tackled and where cronyism is confined to the political dustbin of life.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this appointment not so much because of a personal matter with the candidate but for different reasons. First of all, I regret seeing a fairly marked gender imbalance: out of 28 members, only 5 are women. Where is gender equality? The Member States and the Council should be the first to give a signal to promote gender equality in all institutions and at all levels. In addition, the system of appointing members continues to be a system of political appointment, more than merit. For these reasons, I have decided to vote against all the candidates.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting against the appointment of Janusz Wojciechowski.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the decision of the EPP Cont members and voted against Mr Wojciechowski.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Court of Auditors is the EU’s independent external auditor body that exercises control over the EU funds if they are collected and used correctly, and help improve EU financial management. The Committee on Budgetary Control delivered a negative opinion on the nomination of Janusz Wojciechowski, thus I voted against his nomination.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted against the 5 candidates proposed to be members of the Court of Auditors for various reasons: because of their lack of independence, the possibility of conflict of interest, the lack of professional knowledge in the field of audit, as well as the lack of gender balance, since they are all men.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Partial replacement of the composition of the Members of the Court of Auditors takes place in accordance with Article 286(2) TFEU, which provides that the Council adopts a list of candidates proposed by the Member States after consulting the European Parliament. The members of the Court of Auditors shall be appointed for a period of six years. The appointment and renewal of appointments shall be voted on in plenary on the basis of the CONT report. Candidates must comply with the requirements laid down in Article 286(1) TFEU: Members of the Court of Auditors shall be chosen from among persons who are or have been members of external audit bodies in their own countries or who are particularly qualified to take up that post. Their independence must be unquestionable. I supported the candidate in the vote.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. The terms of office of the six members of the Court of Auditors expire on 6 May 2016. After consultation with the European Parliament, the Council will adopt the list of members. Six candidates were nominated by the Member States: one Slovak candidate, one Latvian, one Czech, one Polish, one Maltese and one Slovenian.  Considering that the CONT Committee had expressed doubts about three candidates and offered a favourable opinion on three nominations (the Latvian, Czech and Slovenian candidates), I voted in favour of the appointment of Mr Kozlovs, the Latvian candidate, Mr Gregor, the Czech candidate, and Mr Jereb, the Slovenian candidate.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 Having fulfilled all formalisms relating to the appointment of Janusz Wojciechowski as a member of the Court of Auditors, in particular the assessment of his qualifications and his hearing, his appointment was nevertheless vetoed by the Commission. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors (ECA) functions as a collegiate body of 28 members, one member of each Member State. These members shall be appointed by the Council, after consulting the European Parliament, for a renewable period of six years. The deadline for 6 of these posts will expire soon, and 6 new candidates have been proposed by the Member States. In a joint assessment of the universe of candidates, doubts are raised as to the full fulfilment of criteria of competence and professional experience, as to the political profile and independence, as to the suitability of the specific place and as to the existence of conflicts of interest. Some of these reasons prompted the rejection of some of the candidates in the Specialised Committee of the European Parliament responsible for assessing applications (Committee on Budgetary Control). Also in a global assessment, there is a lack of gender balance. There's not a single woman among the candidates. These are aspects that have weighed on our group's position in this vote.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 Janusz Wojciechowski, among all the candidates presented who have been given an opinion by the European Parliament, presents a clear vision of the functioning of the European Court of Auditors, has judicial experience, experience in the work of the legislator in national and European territory, unique audit experience (six years of the Presidency of the Supreme Audit Office). These are unique qualifications for the role of ECA judge. His candidacy was the only one to be negatively reviewed. The EP's decision was political. I look hope for a positive decision from the Council.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 Mr Wojciechowski is a professional politician (MP, MEP, State Secretary) and former magistrate during poland's Communist regime. These two facts are of concern about his impartiality, but also his ethics, which is why I am voting against the report on the appointment of Janusz Wojciechowski as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The ECA operates as a collegiate body of 28 Members, one from each Member State. The Members are appointed by the Council after consultation with the European Parliament for a renewable term of six years. Members elect one of their number as President for a renewable term of three years. I supported this candidacy.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the nomination of Mr Janusz Wojciechowski as a member of the European Court of Auditors.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I was very happy to vote in favour of the appointment of my ECR colleague Janusz Wojciechowski as a member of the Court of Auditors, as this selection of staff convinced me after examination.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. The selection procedure for the members of the Court of Auditors was highly criticized. However, most candidates lack the right professional knowledge and show strong indications of a potential conflict of interest. None of the candidates presented at the required level of professional knowledge for the position were nor were they able to ensure that they would be able to perform their tasks with the necessary degree of independence. Despite the European Parliament's systematic requests for previous Council reports, the Court of Auditors has an extraordinary gender imbalance that is exacerbated by current nominations, the 6 candidates are men. For all these reasons, we vote against all proposals.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ The European Court of Auditors is in charge of the audit of EU finances and, as the EU’s external auditor, it contributes to improving EU financial management and acts as the independent guardian of the financial interests of the citizens of the Union. It is vitally important that candidates for the Court are selected based on their suitability for the position, and their professional background, language skills and the ability to exercise independent judgement are important considerations.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the nomination of Janusz Wojciechowski as a Member of the Court of Auditors because I believe that the candidate is enough competent to carry on duties of the Court of Auditors.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted against the proposal for the candidate under reference on the basis of the apparent lack of independence and the possibility of a conflict of interest that undermines the mission but also the role of the Court of Auditors, as an independent EU external auditor and "economic supervisor", as well as because of the lack of gender balance.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the nomination of the member of the Court of Auditors of Janusz Wojciechowski.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. I voted against the proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament on the proposed appointment of Janusz Wojciechowski as a member of the Court of Auditors, as this rejects a negative opinion on the Council's proposal to appoint Mr Wojciechowski as a member of the Court of Auditors. That's the position of the ALDE Group that I've decided to follow in this vote. Mr. Wojciechowski is qualified for this position which I believe he will hold responsibly.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. European MP since 2004 (ECR), current Vice-President of the Agriculture Committee, former member of CONT. His talents and experience are in line with those expected of a member of the Court. I voted for it.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted against my colleague Igor Soltes' report on the appointment of Janusz Wojciechowski as a member of the Court of Auditors because of doubts about his political independence.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This report concerns the nomination of Mr Janusz Wojciechowski as a member of the Court of Auditors. I am voting for his nomination.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. Mr Janusz Wojciechowski's candidacy for the Court of Auditors was not accepted after an unfavourable opinion by the Committee on Budgetary Control.  A Member of the European Parliament since 2004 (ECR), current Vice-President of the Agriculture Committee and a former member of the Committee on Budgetary Control, Mr Wojciechowski nevertheless has the knowledge and experience that is in line with what a member of the Court of Auditors expects.  His candidacy was sabotaged simply because he is a member of a patriotic party and therefore considered Eurosceptic. This is outrageous.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted against the 5 candidates proposed to be members of the Court of Auditors for various reasons: because of their lack of independence, the possibility of conflict of interest, the lack of professional knowledge in the field of audit, as well as the lack of gender balance, since they are all men.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒Members of the EU Court of Auditors review the revenues and expenditures of all Union institutions and agencies. In 2016, 10 members of the Court of Auditors will be appointed and new members will be appointed for a period of six years. In order to become members of the Court of Auditors, candidates first have a hearing in the Committee on Budgetary Control, which gives its opinion on candidates. After that, each candidate shall be voted on at parliament's plenary session, based on a report from the Committee.  Each Member State shall submit a proposal for a candidate for a member of the Court of Auditors and the Council shall decide on the list of the best candidates who then have a hearing in the Committee on Budgetary Control and are finally confirmed at parliament's session. The candidate for member of the Court of Auditors, Janusz Wojciechowski, does not comply with the conditions, so I voted against the report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted positively when examining and analysing Mr Vojcehovska's candidacy and paying the utmost attention to his professional experience and a number of other factors, as did our entire group. However, he was not elected (288 votes in for, 358 against and 48 abstentions).

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposed appointment of Janusz Wojciechowski as a member of the Court of Auditors as I agree with key points in that report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The Court of Auditors aims to improve the FINANCIAL management of the EU and encourage transparency. It verifies whether the EU budget has been properly implemented and whether EU funds have been collected and spent legally and in accordance with the principles of good financial management.  The Court is composed of 28 members (one per Member State) appointed by the Council, after consultation with Parliament, for a renewable term of six years. The selection process at the Court of Auditors has long been widely criticised for its lack of transparency and lack of independence of candidates, who generally do not have the professional skills required for this position. The Polish candidate, Janusz Wojciechowski, currently an MEP, sits with the most conservative EPP. I'm voting against his nomination.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. His reported experience and talent were convincing for the mission that awaited him. As a result I voted for it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors is a supervisory institution, which verifies the legality and regularity of EU revenue and expenditure, as well as good financial management, carrying out its functions with complete independence. In this spirit, the appointment of the individualities that compose it must be governed by criteria of competence and independence. Thus, at the initiative of the Council, several personalities from various EU countries were appointed to the Court of Auditors. The applicant submitted his Curriculum Vitae, replied to a written questionnaire and was heard in the Committee on Budgetary Control and did not put forward sufficient arguments to justify the appointment to the Court of Auditors in order to carry out his duties there competently and independently. I therefore voted in favour of janusz wojciechowski's non-appointment

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council nominated Janusz Wojciechowski as a member of the Court of Auditors. The appointment is the responsibility of the Council, but it is necessary to consult Parliament before deciding. The Committee on Budgetary Control evaluated the candidate's capabilities and listened to the candidate at its meeting on 15 March 2016. In its report, it proposes that Parliament give an unfavourable opinion on the Council's proposal to appoint Janusz Wojciechowski as a Member of the Court of Auditors. I did not support the nomination of the candidate.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ The European Court of Auditors is in charge of the audit of EU finances and as the EU’s external auditor, it contributes to improving EU financial management and acts as the independent guardian of the financial interests of the citizens of the Union. It is vitally important that candidates for the Court are selected based on their suitability for the position, their professional background, language skills and the ability to exercise independent judgement are important considerations.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted against this report which proposed the appointment of Janusz Wojciechowski as a member of the Court of Auditors.  Janusz Wojciechowski was heard by the Committee on Budgetary Control. The members of this committee gave an unfavourable opinion on this nomination by casting doubt on the political independence of this candidate.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted the nomination of Janusz Wojciechowski as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012As a result of the examination of the curriculum vitae and the answers given by Mr Janusz Wojciechowski at the hearing by the Committee on Budgetary Control, and in line with what the Committee on Budgetary Control said, I voted against the nomination proposal.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The Court of Auditors is important for monitoring and controlling the use of EU funding, and its independence and the quality of work of judges guarantee the protection of the interests of all EU citizens. Janusz Wojciechowski's nomination to be a judge of the EUROPEAN Court of Auditors was assessed in a negative opinion after the Committee on Budgetary Control heard and assessed the qualifications of the proposed candidate, with wojciechowski's hearing deemed very poor and the Committee overwhelmingly rejecting his nomination to be a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. Mr Wojciechowski, a member of the European Parliament since 2004 (ECR), the current Vice-President of the Agriculture Committee and a former member of CONT, has talents and experience in line with those expected of a member of the European Court of Auditors. I therefore vote for his appointment in this proceeding.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. From 1995 to 2001, he was president of the Supreme Audit Office (NIK), the constitutional body of the state audit overseeing the state budget and other state activities, appointed by the Polish Parliament for that six-year term. During his mandate, he presented six revisions of the implementation of the state budget to the Polish Parliament and answered questions from members.  Since 2004 he has been dealing with issues related to the European Union budget as a Member of the European Parliament and in particular dealing with the budget of the Common Agricultural Policy as Vice-President of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. For all of the above, I support the appointment of a colleague as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors (ECA) functions as a collegiate body of 28 members, one member of each Member State. These members shall be appointed by the Council, after consulting the European Parliament, for a renewable period of six years. The deadline for 6 of these posts will expire soon, and 6 new candidates have been proposed by the Member States. In a joint assessment of the universe of candidates, doubts are raised as to the full fulfilment of criteria of competence and professional experience, as to the political profile and independence, as to the suitability of the specific place and as to the existence of conflicts of interest. Some of these reasons prompted the rejection of some of the candidates in the Specialised Committee of the European Parliament responsible for assessing applications (Committee on Budgetary Control). Also in a global assessment, there is a lack of gender balance. There's not a single woman among the candidates. These are aspects that have weighed on our group's position in this vote.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the appointment of Janusz Wojciechowski as a member of the Court of Auditors. I hope that it will be able to play its role with the utmost independence and transparency in the general interest of the European Union.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. We have been asked to rule on the appointment of an auditor from the European Court of Auditors. This procedure demonstrates the usefulness of Parliament in exercising its control over the functioning of the European institutions.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 After the Committee on Budgetary Control has held the hearing of Janusz Wojciechowski and has assessed his qualifications, this report gives its assent to the Council's proposal to appoint the candidate for the post of the Court of Auditors.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. This morning the Plenary of the European Parliament put to the vote, in secret, the proposal to appoint Janusz Wojciechowski as a member of the Court of Auditors following the evaluation of the candidate's qualifications and the hearing held on 15 March before the Committee on Budgetary Control, a vote in which I participated.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Parliament this lunchtime rejected the appointment of The Polish Auditor, Janusz Wojciechowski (288 votes in for, 358 against, and 48 abstentions) to the European Court of Auditors on the basis of the recommendations of the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control. Toni Abela, the Maltese candidate, had withdrawn his candidacy following the unfavourable opinion of the committee. It should be noted that the members of the Court of Auditors are appointed for six years. The Council, after consulting the European Parliament, makes its decision according to the proposals made by each Member State.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report to appoint The Polish candidate, Janusz Wojciechowsk, as a Member of the Court of Auditors. He is a lawyer, a former judge, currently a lawyer. He received a master's degree in law from the Faculty of Law and Administration of the University of Łódź. Janusz is currently a Member of the European Parliament and vice-chairman of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 After a proposal was submitted by the Council on 15 March 2016, and since the hearing of the candidate proposed by the Committee on Budgetary Control was made on the basis of criteria of rigour and transparency, and the competence and professional experience of candidate Janusz Wojciechowski for the performance of the proposed functions was proven, I agreed with this appointment of Member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. The selection procedure for the members of the Court of Auditors was highly criticized. However, most candidates lack the right professional knowledge and show strong indications of a potential conflict of interest. None of the candidates presented at the required level of professional knowledge for the position were nor were they able to ensure that they would be able to perform their tasks with the necessary degree of independence. Despite the European Parliament's systematic requests for previous Council reports, the Court of Auditors has an extraordinary gender imbalance that is exacerbated by current nominations, the 6 candidates are men. For all these reasons, we vote against all proposals.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted against the 5 candidates proposed to be members of the Court of Auditors for various reasons: because of their lack of independence, the possibility of conflict of interest, the lack of professional knowledge in the field of audit, as well as the lack of gender balance, since they are all men.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ As I’ve mentioned before, The European Court of Auditors plays a vital role in the institutions, being in charge of the audit of the EU’s finances and, as the EU’s external auditor, it contributes to improving the financial management of the EU as well as acting as the independent guardian of the financial interests of the EU’s half a billion citizens. In my view, it is vitally important that candidates for the Court are selected based on their suitability for the position, their professional backgrounds, language skills and the ability to exercise independent judgment are all important for considerations. In the case of Wojciechowski, I do not feel that he can fulfil these criteria and as a member of Prawo i Sprawiedliwość, which has shown its anti-democratic position, I do not believe that in the position in the Court of Auditors that Mr Wojciechowski would be impartial.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the fact that as a Member of the Court of Auditors, a representative from each EU member country can check that EU funds are being correctly collected and used and help improve EU financial management.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Despite some doubts raised during the public hearing in committee, I supported the candidacy of Janusz Wojciechowski as a Member of the European Court of Auditors. As a colleague in the European Parliament, Mr Wojciechowski is familiar with the functioning of the European institutions, having been here since 2004. At the beginning of his career, he proved himself to be an impartial and objective judge who gained the trust of the judiciary even after the transition to a democratic regime. In 1990, he was elected by Polish judges to the then-appointed State Judicial Council, the body responsible for monitoring the independence of judges and courts. Shortly afterwards, he was elected to the Court of Appeal as one of the judges and also became a Supreme Court judge. In the field of control of public finances, he proved himself during his time as President of the Supreme Audit Office. Within this constitutional body of state control, among other things, he was responsible for controlling the implementation of the state budget and was responsible for preparing and managing the budget of the SAO itself. He gained international experience mainly as a Member of the European Parliament, where he deals with matters of the EU budget, in particular as Vice-President of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. His work so far suggests that he would perform his duties impartially. However, the final decision on his candidacy is in the hands of the Council of the EU.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. In accordance with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, 'the members of the Court of Auditors shall be chosen from among persons who belong to or belonged to external audit bodies in their countries or who are specially qualified for that service. Their independence must be uneasy." The Committee on Budgetary Control assessed the candidate's recommendations, in particular in the light of the requirements of Article 286(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, at its meeting on 15 March 2016, he listened to his presentation and decided, on that basis, not to approve the Council's proposal to appoint Janusz Wojciechowski as a member of the Court of Auditors. Wojciechowski is a lawyer by profession, a former judge, now a lawyer; has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2004. From 1995 to 2001 he was president of the Polish Supreme Audit Authority (NIK). The candidate shall be suitably qualified, but there are doubts about his political independence which the candidate has not sufficiently explained in his presentation to the Committee on Budgetary Control. In addition, there could be conflicts of interest due to his current role as Vice-Chair of the EP Committee on Agriculture. In view of the above, and in line with the decision of the committee, I did not support the candidate in the vote.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ The European Court of Auditors is in charge of the audit of EU finances and, as the EU’s external auditor, it contributes to improving EU financial management and acts as the independent guardian of the financial interests of the citizens of the Union. It is vitally important that candidates for the Court are selected based on their suitability for the position, and their professional background, language skills and the ability to exercise independent judgement are important considerations.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The Court of Auditors, as the EU's independent external auditor, is very important because, among other things, it has the purpose of instilling trust in the democratic institutions of the European Union, while protecting the interests of taxpayers. It is therefore important that all members of the Court of Auditors fulfil their duties to the highest expectations of EU citizens for whom the transparency of the EU institutions is very important and contribute with their impartiality, objectivity and integrity to the work of the Court of Auditors and their cooperation with the European Parliament. I do not support the draft report on the proposed appointment of Janusz Wojciechowski as a member of the Court of Auditors. Unfortunately, I believe that Janusz Wojciechowski does not meet all the criteria necessary for the performance of the duties of a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The selection of persons for positions of responsibility and Union interest should be based on the integrity of their character and their proven activity with regard to the protection of public money in the broadest sense

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. We have received, studied and issued an opinion on this person's candidacy as a member of the Court of Auditors. The Committee on Budgetary Control assessed the qualifications of the proposed candidate, particularly in light of the conditions set out in Article 286, paragraph 1, of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. A hearing was then undertaken during the month of March by the Council concerning the function of a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against of the nomination of Janusz Wojciechowski as a member of the Court of Auditors, in line with the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control (CONT).

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \ u2012 In my report on the appointment of Janusz Wojciechowski as a Member of the Court of Auditors, I voted in my conscience – a secret ballot. The Committee on Budgetary Control has assessed the candidate's professional qualifications, in particular in the light of the requirements laid down in Article 286(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. At its meeting on 15 March 2016, the Committee on Budgetary Control listened to the presentation of the Council's candidate for member of the Court of Auditors and approved the Council's proposal to appoint Janusz Wojciechowski as a member of the Court of Auditors and instruct his President to forward this Decision to the Council and for information to the Court of Auditors, as well as to the other institutions of the European Union and the audit bodies of the Member States.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. The selection procedure for the members of the Court of Auditors was highly criticized. However, most candidates lack the right professional knowledge and show strong indications of a potential conflict of interest. None of the candidates presented at the required level of professional knowledge for the position were nor were they able to ensure that they would be able to perform their tasks with the necessary degree of independence. Despite the European Parliament's systematic requests for previous Council reports, the Court of Auditors has an extraordinary gender imbalance that is exacerbated by current nominations, the 6 candidates are men. For all these reasons, we vote against all proposals.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control evaluated the capabilities, history and professionalism of the proposed candidate. I voted to follow S&D's position on the nomination of the candidate.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. The selection procedure for the members of the Court of Auditors was highly criticized. However, most candidates lack the right professional knowledge and show strong indications of a potential conflict of interest. None of the candidates presented at the required level of professional knowledge for the position were nor were they able to ensure that they would be able to perform their tasks with the necessary degree of independence. Despite the European Parliament's systematic requests for previous Council reports, the Court of Auditors has an extraordinary gender imbalance that is exacerbated by current nominations, the 6 candidates are men. For all these reasons, we vote AGAINST all proposals.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I decided to stick to the vote of the Greens in the CONT Committee, meaning that I supported candidates Jan Gregor, Samo Jereb and Mihails Kozlovs. I voted against Ladislav Balko and Janusz Wojciechowski. I wanted to stress the need to respect the demands in the TFEU concerning the professional experience and candidates’ complete independence and the need to assure gender balance in the EU’s top positions.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the nomination of Janusz Wojciechowski as a Member of the Court of Auditors because there are no legal, political or personal reasons on the grounds of which an objection to his nomination would be founded.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted against the appointment of Janusz Wojciechowski to the Court of Auditors in view of the negative opinion of the relevant parliamentary committee.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The selection process has once again been highly criticized. Once again, most candidates lack adequate professional qualification and strong indications of possible conflicts of interest are present. None of the candidates has the necessary level of professional specialisation for the position, and neither were they able to ensure that they would be able to perform the functions in question with the necessary degree of independence. Furthermore, despite the systematic requests of the European Parliament in previous reports to the Council and the Court of Auditors, there is a major gender imbalance, which is compounded by current applications, as all six candidates are men. We reject all candidates on the basis of the obvious lack of independence and the likelihood of conflicts of interest, which undermine both the mission and role of the Court of Auditors as an independent external auditor of the EU, as well as the lack of gender balance.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this motion was born as a democratic appeal for respect for the precautionary principle, which is not actually applied in the Commission's proposal.  It was also born in defence of the prevailing public interest, to which we call for the publication of those studies that Monsanto, let us remember, EFSA has declared fundamental in the formulation of its negative opinion on the carcinogenicity of glyphosate. We asked for their publication and what did we get? A physical reading room that we don't even know how it will work.  What we want, however, is very clear: studies must be totally public. I am not saying this, but Article 10 of the regulation on the marketing of plant protection products says so. Commissioner Andriukaitis still has responsibilities, and he cannot and must not go it alone in this process. We have voted on an absolutely absurd motion for a resolution, we absolutely cannot allow the glyphosate authorisation to be renewed for another 7 years, it is completely unconscious on our part and you have voted for it and have allowed the health of all citizens not to be respected.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Mr President, an attempt has been made to confuse the debate on glyphosate by painting critics as enemies of science and progress, but it is the Commission that intentionally ignores the opinion of experts, such as the International Cancer Research Centre, which has classified glyphosate as likely carcinogenic. On the basis of the precautionary principle and the text of the Regulation itself, the Commission cannot carry out an automatic authorisation, it cannot side with the multinational Monsanto and its agricultural production model, in which the health risks do not count. I regret the warmth of this Parliament. Even more so when several States have opposed unjustified and exceptional authorization. We ourselves, from the United Left, have replaced glyphosate in many town halls with less polluting methods, demonstrating that there are alternative solutions. We are not worth any argument for trivializing the use of agrotoxics. No, of course, with our vote.

name: Vicky FORD
text: – Mr President, the East of England is the bread basket of Britain, and I have received hundreds of emails from my local farmers about glyphosate, the weed killer many gardeners know as Roundup. It is the only product available to control weeds such as black grass. It is vital to no-till regimes that enhance soil quality and it is crucial for maintaining crop yields of wheat, barley and rape. The environmental impact of losing glyphosate would be enormous, as would be the effect on food production. We need farmers to produce the food for our growing population and they tell us that glyphosate is not a luxury, it is essential. European expert scientists have concluded that the product is not carcinogenic to humans, but people are concerned and it is right that research should continue. Despite all this, Socialist MEPs were trying to demand an immediate ban now. I disagree. We should let our farmers and our scientists do their work, and this vote gives them time to come to a more rounded conclusion.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: Mr President, in parallel with this objection, I myself had also proposed, on behalf of the ENF Group, an objection to the renewal of the authorisation of glyphosate, an initiative which was not followed by the other groups, who preferred to present a text together. However, we have seen today that there are great divisions within the political parties. I therefore maintain that the European Commission has exceeded its powers by proposing to renew the authorisation of glyphosate for several reasons. The scientific context and the study of the International Agency for Research on Cancer encourage us to be cautious in the face of a product that is probably carcinogenic and present everywhere. This caution should be at the heart of the Commission's thinking, as the European Ombudsman reminded it. Finally, it is not acceptable to postpone the publication of the list of coformulants that accentuate the toxicity of the product to an unknown date. Commercial wording and coformulants are at the centre of all concerns. Today's turn of events, however, is such that the spirit of the text and the whole meaning of the objection are misguided.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: – Mr President, we voted against it since the amendments adopted do not reflect the outcome of the discussions we have had in committee. It is irresponsible to call for the renewal of glyphosate for seven years. From Podemos we call on the competent authorities to apply the precautionary principle. The World Health Organization report determined that glyphosate is likely carcinogenic to humans; however, we have plenty of reason to think that the European Food Safety Authority has other interests behind it because it reached conclusions contrary to those of the World Health Organization. We cannot allow such a substance to be marketed in Europe, which is used as fertilizer for our fields and which ends in food and which also jeopardizes the work of farmers and ranchers. We can't play with the health of our people.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the If we agree on a procedure in politics, we should respect this procedure to the end and also accept the results. And so we left the scientific assessment of plant protection products to the Risk Assessment Office, our European EFSA. EFSA has delegated this to the German authority, and this has come to clear conclusions. Our decision today in the European Parliament is in line with this technical, scientific assessment. We have decided three things. We have said that we want to continue to provide scientific support for the next seven years. Secondly, we want to define the proper professional use in more detail. Thirdly, we also want to check the so-called cooperative substances – that is, the additives – more closely in terms of their mode of action. It was a good compromise, and it was also a proper, appropriate decision based on a technical and scientific analysis.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: Mr President, I definitely choose to see the glass half full this lunchtime. This is a good time for the protection of the health of Europeans: by saying no to the renewal of the authorisation of glyphosate for fifteen years proposed by the Commission, and by voting on the resolution of which I am one of the authors, our Parliament has just shown that it is on the side of the citizens, that it is on the side of innovation and that it is on the side of less intensive agricultural practices. It is the role, it is our role, the role of politicians to make choices, especially when science does not allow us to conclude and when the opinions of the experts who are responsible for enlightening us diverge. In conclusion, and even if Parliament has here - unfortunately - a power of evocation, our message is clear: we say no to this maximalist option of the Commission, to this blank cheque given for fifteen years and to the prohibition of a single coformulant out of five hundred. The seven-year authorisation voted this lunchtime is far too broad in my opinion, but that is the signal that matters here, and it is clear that the Commission must redo its duties and propose a new text, propose a new text to the Member States which will be responsible for making the decision.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – I also voted against the Commission's proposal to extend the application of this glyphosate substance for another 15 years.  I believe that, at a time when there is clear scientific evidence that creates doubts that this substance is acceptable to health, responsible politicians cannot simply prolong the use of this substance for another 15 years. There are clear conclusions from the International Agency for Research on Cancer, which made it clear in its March 2015 materials that glyphosates should belong and belong to the category of likely carcinogens for humans. This is why I think that a 15-year extension is a gamble, a gamble on the health of our citizens. I therefore think it is good that the Commission has not passed this deadline, that Parliament has given its opinion.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as long as there are concerns about the carcinogenicity of glyphosate endocrinologist, the Commission should not renew any authorisation.  The precautionary principle must always prevail in these cases, because the primary objective of the European Union is the protection of citizens' health. The fact that we had to resort to a parliamentary objection shows that something has not worked in the decision-making process. Glyphosate is classified as probably carcinogenic by the World Health Organisation. The French Environment, Food and Health Agency (ANSES) recently issued its opinion pointing out that some mixtures of glyphosate with other substances may pose significant health risks, both for citizens and for those working in the agricultural sector.  France has, in fact, decided to ban herbicides combining glyphosate and tallow amine because of uncertainty about possible health risks. In spite of all this, the Commission's intention would be to extend the licence. This is an absurd position when it comes to the health of our citizens. Rather, the Commission must present a review independent of the classification of glyphosate based on all available scientific data on carcinogenicity as well as its possible impacts on the human hormonal system.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Parliament had the opportunity to express a strong and clear political position against renewing the authorisation of glyphosate, a herbicide described as probable carcinogen by the IARC.  We are well aware that the European Commission, as the executive body, has full power to decide to adopt acts and measures independently. Despite this, it was important for this House to express itself, and that is a great pity. The 5 Star Movement was one of the strongest supporters of the motion to object to this act and, in the light of the amendments tabled and the result achieved in the end, we were forced to vote against it. In fact, we have turned a motion of objection into a motion in support of a renewal for another seven years, quite simply, the health of citizens and the environment cannot be traded, but must come before commercial opportunities for companies.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I think we came to a sensible compromise: to ban outright glyphosate at this particular time would not be wise based on improbable evidence. To say that something is probably carcinogenic sounds terrible, and that is why we took the action we took to limit it to seven years. Having said that, Stuart Agnew spoke last night, and he mentioned here on Monday night that other aspects which are regarded as carcinogenic by the WHO are sitting in front of a log fire, cutting human hair, etc. So giving us the space to look at it, to ensure that the product is absolutely safe for humans in the food chain, is ultimately a wise decision. I think that it will allow the farmers to continue with their work, otherwise they would have to stop and grow no arable crops possibly. That would be very disruptive. We have come to a sensible compromise. Let us all work together and ensure that we know exactly what is happening and assure our citizens that everything in their food is absolutely safe.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur One of the main problems is that glyphosate is largely non-selective in its activities and thus destroys not only unwanted medicines, but also all plants, as well as algae, bacteria, fungi, and this has a major negative impact on biodiversity and ecosystems in the areas where it is used. I agree, colleagues, that the draft Commission implementing regulation still does not ensure, to an acceptable extent, human and animal health, nor does it make efforts to protect the environment itself. I also support the need to develop as soon as possible an independent review of the classification of glyphosates, firstly with regard to its carcinogenicity and endocrine impact. In the light of all this, I have unequivocally voted against the renewal of the use of glyphosates, and I also agree with the call for the Commission to publish data on the basis of which, once again, the renewal of the approval of the use of glyphosates has already been proposed. Thank you!

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Mr President, what did we vote on? This is an objection that Parliament wanted to make in relation to the European Commission's desired renewal of this dangerous substance, glyphosate, for fifteen years. It was irresponsible, and we did the right thing in making that objection. Let us remember the positive aspect of what we have done and the message we have sent today, which is that there is no question of renewing a dangerous product authorization for 15 years without further analysis. The aim is also to ban coformulants, which increase the dangerousness of this product.  However, I regret the adoption of Amendment 11, which was requested by the EPP Group, which is still aimed at obtaining a renewal for a limited period of seven years. It's like we're crossing a river and stopping in the middle. It doesn't make sense! This distorts and weakens the message that should have been given today.  That is why, in the end, the Belgian Socialists abstained on this resolution, which they obviously consider relevant, while regretting, unfortunately, that the message is losing its strength because of the authorisation granted for seven years.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – I will admit that my view on this matter developed, even when that objection was discussed in the last plenary, so I took the liberty of criticising the Commissioner for a certain laxity in this matter, precisely as regards the provision of scientific knowledge. It has also been explained to me by farmers' representatives that while glyphosate is probably a cancer-forming substance, it is as likely to be a cancer-forming substance as, for example, exhaust fumes from cars, and we will not immediately ban them from driving.  As a result, I joined the draft compromise tabled here in this House and therefore approved, and I also changed my mind, which I had last time, which I had the opportunity to present in plenary after being made aware of the specific findings presented by farmers, for example.  I think it is important that this deadline be used for further scientific monitoring not only of the substance itself, but also of the 500 or so derivatives still around it.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 Glyphosate is a systemic herbicent mostly used in the agricultural, forestry and gardening sectors. It is a non-selective herbicide which causes the death of herbaceous vegetation and which, according to studies published by the International Agency for Research on Cancer, is probably carcinogenic to humans. The data, confirmed by evidence acquired in relation to humans, animals and on the basis of mechanistic data, are still disputed by efsa's opinion. Indeed, the European Food Safety Authority denies the carcinogenicity of glyphosate, while refusing to publish the studies in its possession. For these reasons, I voted against the resulting text, which in fact renews the use of glyphosate for a further seven years.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. This report contains positive aspects such as that it is critical of authorisation procedures, the impact of glyphosate on fauna and flora and the residues detected. Older it recommends not to use glyphosate for non-professional uses, not to use it in gardens, public parks or playing fields or in cases where pest management systems are sufficient. I have still voted against it because instead of recommending the absolute ban on all products containing glyphosate, it proposes a renewal of its use for seven more years.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted against this text on the objection to the renewal of the glyphosate authorization because I consider the value of this objection to be only symbolic.  Indeed, the text, as voted in the end, advocates the authorisation of glyphosate for seven years and suggests very few restriction provisions when this product has been repeatedly identified as very dangerous, both for consumers and farmers. I have therefore spoken out against this text, which, moreover, does not take into account the precautionary principle and does not oblige the Commission to act on Parliament's requests in this matter.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted against this resolution on the EU approval process for the chemical glyphosate. I do not believe that any such process calling itself a scientific safety assessment can be based on unpublished, industry-sponsored and non-peer-reviewed data.  Given that IARC, the well-respected cancer expert group of the World Health Organisation, using publicly available, peer-reviewed and independent data based on its strict policy on conflicts of interest, found that glyphosate was ‘probably carcinogenic’ raises serious concerns that the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) found contradictory results (‘unlikely’ to cause cancer) just months later.  EFSA claims that the reason for its differing conclusion is because it included data the WHO did not include, but this data was excluded from the WHO assessment precisely because it did not meet its standards on independent and peer-reviewed data.  Scientific assessment should not be based on secret industry data and any approval process of glyphosate should be halted until EFSA releases the data it used to come to its conclusion. Not to do so risks further undermining confidence in the EU approval process as a whole.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I regret that the European Parliament did not follow our Committee on Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, which had called for a ban on glyphosate. The European Right, for its part, has succeeded in its bet: to poison European citizens for another 7 years. Declared a "probable carcinogen" by the World Health Organization (WHO) in March 2015, glyphosate remains the world's best-selling herbicide. Several European countries such as Denmark, the Netherlands and Sweden have decided to ban or limit its use because of its possible effects, ranging from malformations in newborns to autism to kidney problems. "It is our responsibility to apply the precautionary principle and remove from the market dangerous molecules that threaten the health of millions of European citizens, starting with those of the farmers themselves," stresses the MEP. The very short-term urgency is to help producers using glyphosate by offering alternative solutions. This requires support based on both the use of the least dangerous products but above all on the development of biocontrols and a gradual change in production models.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the objection under Article 106 to renew the authorisation for the active substance glyphosate, because the objection is contrary to the draft measure, on the grounds that the draft implementing act fails to ensure a high level of protection of human and animal health and the environment, and fails to apply the precautionary principle. It is therefore compatible with the objective and content of the basic act, and goes beyond the implementing powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009.  There are contradictory views on glyphosate, with the International Centre for Research on Cancer (IARC) classifying glyphosate as a potential carcinogen for humans after evaluation by a large body of scientists, and the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), and relying on the decision in republished studies carried out by industry.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. As long as serious concerns remain about the carcinogenic effects of glyphosate, further scientific studies will need to be carried out. Anything else would be contrary to the precautionary principle in force in the EU. I therefore supported an amendment to this effect. In my view, extending the authorisation of the herbicide by only seven years instead of fifteen years and restricting the authorisation to the professional sector is by no means sufficient. Apparently, the majority doubted the correct use of the herbicide, otherwise no restriction of the authorisation for professional use would have been required. But if health is endangered, it is in both domestic horticulture and agriculture. That is why I consider Parliament's current position to be inconsistent. It is also essential that the Commission and Member States finance research and innovation on cost-effective solutions in the field of pest control products. This is the only way in which we will achieve a high level of protection of human and animal health and the environment in the future.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. National Front MEPs had objected to the European Commission's approval of the renewal of glyphosate, an active substance considered carcinogenic by WHO and strongly present in food. Glyphosate is the basis of a herbicide widely used in France. I have maintained my position by opposing the new text of the objection proposed in Strasbourg. National Front MEPs welcome the restriction of the use of this product only to professionals, as are farmers. Nevertheless, the finally decided 7-year renewal period does not encourage the chemical industries to seek alternatives, while the health of our farmers and consumers is at stake! I would have liked to vote for an immediate ban on this substance, but the crisis in our agriculture is serious enough not to overwhelm French farmers even further. However, the original text was profoundly modified, which led us to object to this objection, the original meaning of which was misguided.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This was an incredibly difficult decision to take, and I found many constituents writing to me on both sides of the argument. I had to balance the public health concerns with the risks to farmers and crops if glyphosate does not continue to be used.  The difficulty lies in assessing the two questions: To what extent is glyphosate dangerous? At what level does it become toxic? My understanding of the situation, having reviewed the evidence as best I can, is that glyphosate could be a carcinogen but that the levels encountered are so low as to present little danger. Indeed, I note that glyphosate residues are pretty much even undetectable in food and water. On the whole, I did not see sufficient evidence to convince me that a ban would be necessary.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. Due to concerns about the carcinogenic and endocrine disruptor nature of glyphosate, I voted to reduce the duration of use to 7 years, instead of the 15 initially proposed, and only for professional purposes. This delay should allow the executive to launch an independent study on the overall toxicity and classification of glyphosate and to clarify the dangerousness of the substance. Nevertheless, the European Union must stop legislating chemical molecules by chemical molecule and would be more effective in acting globally on harmful substances through a single regulation. This method would have the benefit of increasing the understanding of standards and the adaptation of users of these substances.  Finally, it is important to ensure that the application of these standards is the same across Europe and that it does not encourage technological dumping between EU member states.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: in writing. ‒ A ban on glyphosate would be highly problematic for farmers. As long as there is ongoing scientific debate on whether glyphosate is indeed carcinogenic, I will not support an immediate ban. Further scientific research should be conducted. Therefore I vote against this motion for a resolution.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, in which the European Parliament declares that the draft Commission implementing regulation on the extension of the active substance glyphosate does not provide a high level of protection of human and animal health and the environment. Glyphosate is a non-selective herbicide that destroys all grasses. To date, there are no allayed concerns about the harmful effects of this chemical on human health, which could even cause cancer. Parliament asks the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing regulation and calls on the Commission not to extend the approval of glyphosate. Instead of an unlimited 15-year renewal of the glyphosate marketing authorisation, the European Commission must use an independent impact assessment of this chemical to make available the data of the European Food Safety Authority used for the assessment of glyphosate. It is necessary to ensure that the classification of glyphosate is reviewed on the basis of scientific evidence on the carcinogenicity of glyphosate.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, of which I am a member, objected to the draft Commission implementing regulation on the placing on the market of plant protection products containing glyphosate. In this Regulation, the European Commission intends to extend the authorisation of these products to a maximum of 15 years.  In March 2015, the International Agency for Research on Cancer classified glyphosate as a substance likely to have carcinogenic effects on humans. In addition, glyphosate has properties that damage the endocrine system. However, according to the assessment of the European Food Safety Authority, glyphosate is unlikely to pose a carcinogenic risk to humans.  In this unclear but worrying situation, following the precautionary principle, the Commission, in its motion for a resolution, asked the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing regulation and to submit a new proposal. The plenary of parliament amended the proposal on a number of points and set the granting of the authorisation for a period of 7 years, subject to the fulfilment of other conditions. This period is, in my opinion, impermissible. Nevertheless, I supported the amended motion in the final vote because, as a result of the non-reception, the Commission's original unconditional decision of 15 years would have remained in force.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ There have been suggestions that the popular herbicide glyphosate could be carcinogenic – although it has been in widespread use for decades with no evidence of harm, and a number of studies find that used properly it represents no threat to human health. Banning glyphosate would substantially increase farmers’ costs, and could result in the use of other herbicides which may even be less safe than glyphosate. It would also require more cultivation and use of tractors, resulting in increased emissions.  And after all that, we should still be importing cheaper foreign food products that had been grown with the benefit of glyphosate. UKIP does not support a ban given the very limited evidence of harm, but would support further research.  We also believe that this decision should be made for the UK in the British parliament, not imposed from Brussels.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. In the name of the precautionary principle for a product that the International Agency for Research on Cancer has described as carcinogenic, I support the objection to the renewal of the active ingredient glyphosate. The arguments presented by the scientific world - such as the German Heinrich Boll Foundation, which this year established a high level of exposure of the most vulnerable groups to glyphosate - shows that the Commission, by authorising this antibiotic substance while the fight against the massive use of antibiotics is a recurring subject in European regulation, has gone beyond its areas of competence, which legitimises this objection.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. Indeed, Parliament wished to object to the Commission's desire to renew for fifteen years the authorisation of this dangerous substance, glyphosate. Unfortunately, the EPP has introduced an amendment to obtain a 7-year authorisation.  That is why the Belgian Socialists abstained in the final vote.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution, which ensures greater caution with regard to health and the environment through the use of scientific criteria. The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) assesses the approval of glyphosate on the basis of rigorous scientific criteria. However, there are mixed conclusions between the analyses of this and the study of the International Cancer Research Centre (IARC). EFSA considered that some of the studies that IARC had not assessed were of fundamental importance for the final evaluation. According to this agency and the Bundesinstitut f'r Risikobewertung (BfR), the health risk is "unlikely". Both concluded that glyphosate meets the standards required for approval of its use and poses no risk to human, animal or environmental health. Therefore, we must not let yourself be carried away by sensationalism or rule out its prohibition. We must be responsible for the environment and also with farmers. That is why my position is to reduce the extension of 15 years — as proposed by the European Commission — to 5 years for future review, clarification by the scientific community and professional use of glyphosate.

name: Bendt BENDTSEN
text: Written. I have voted today in favour of extending the authorisation for the use of glyphosate, but I support a more limited period than the one proposed by the Commission - 7 years rather than 15 years. I hope that the Member States and the Commission will take parliament's views into account when they consider the extension to May. I am aware that the Left has strongly advocated a full ban on glyphosate, but I believe that we have found a compromise that benefits both agriculture and health and is based on the scientific basis available to us now. I am pleased that at the same time we are calling for clear restrictions on the use of glyphosate - both for individuals and professionals. In particular, I believe that the use of glyphosate when detecting should be restricted - that is, spraying just before harvest, where there is a high risk of affecting the food chain. We must ensure that the substance is used correctly and that health and safety is taken into account. It is important to make it clear, as we have done today, that the authorisation can and should be withdrawn if we are given new information on health risks. I expect the Commission to continuously assess scientific data and withdraw approval, if there is a basis for it.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 Glyphosate is a particular type of non-selective herbicide that is able to cause the death of all the herbaceous vegetation on which it is placed. Scientific studies have also shown its action on other types of organisms such as algae, fungi and bacteria on which it acts, as in plants, interfering in the path of shikimate. It is a type of action that, in the case of bacteria, causes changes in the response to antibiotics. According to the International Agency for Research on Cancer, glyphosate is likely to be a substance that is likely to be carcinogenic to humans, although efsa's conclusions on this, based on studies not made public, take the opposite view. The existence of a number of doubts about the carcinogenic potential of glyphosate is also linked to concerns about its endocrine interference and the consequences it would appear to have on the metabolic pathways of vertebrates, in particular with regard to the hepatorenal damage found by several studies. Considering for all these reasons that the Commission's implementing regulation does not guarantee high standards for the protection of health and the environment, I have chosen to vote in favour of the objection presented to Parliament today.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted against it since the amendments adopted do not reflect the outcome of the discussions we have had in the Commission. It is irresponsible to call for the renewal of glyphosate for seven years. We call on the competent authorities to apply the precautionary principle to the World Health Organization (WHO) report, which determined that glyphosate is "probably carcinogenic to humans". However, there is plenty of reason to think that EFSA (European Food Safety Agency), whose study reached conclusions contrary to WHO's, is not entirely independent and we must therefore question its recommendations. We cannot allow such a substance, which is used as a herbicide for our fields, to be marketed in Europe and ends up in the food we eat.

name: Joëlle BERGERON
text: In writing. Many of our colleagues, before voting on this resolution, probably did not know, before the subject was put on the agenda, that glyphosate is a non-selective herbicide absorbed by the leaves and having a widespread action, formerly patented, this patent, we were told, having fallen into the public domain in 2000. But that was not the issue. In the debate that took place in our Chamber on whether or not the Commission should have the approval of the substance renewed, two logics clashed, one of which is guided by the precautionary principle and advocates non-approval, while the other believes that scientific studies carried out on the harmfulness of the product are sufficient to authorise its dissemination. Not being an expert on the issue myself, I sided with the precautionary principle and voted against approval, even if I reconsidered my position if further conclusive studies should show that this caution was ultimately not necessary.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I objected to this text, which, if originally objected to the renewal of approval for glyphosate, ultimately led to its authorisation for a period of 7 years, and suggested only a few provisions of restrictions. For example, it did not accept a ban on the use of glyphosate in public parks and gardens. I recall that the International Agency for Research on Cancer had previously described glyphosate as a "probably carcinogenic" product, a caution that is not shared by the European Food Safety Agency. However, the risks associated with glyphosate are established, particularly in its commercial formulations. Given the differences of opinion on this subject between IARC and EFSA on the subject, doubt persists and calls for respect for the precautionary principle.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Due to its carcinogenic potential for human health, I did not support this text which moves in the direction of granting the renewal of permits for the application of 'glyphosate' in Europe. The health of our citizens must always be the only priority, and I believe that it would only really be protected if the use of this substance were prevented immediately.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, in which the European Parliament takes the position that the draft Commission implementing regulation on the extension of the active substance glyphosate does not provide a high level of protection of human and animal health and the environment. The European Parliament asks the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing regulation and submit a new draft to the committee. In addition, Parliament calls on the Commission not to extend the approval of glyphosate and to set a clear deadline for drawing up a list of co-formulants not authorised to be included in plant protection products. It also calls on the Commission to ensure, as a matter of urgency, that the classification of glyphosate is reviewed on the basis of scientific evidence on the carcinogenicity of glyphosate, as well as to review possible endocrine disrupting properties on the basis of scientific horizontal criteria for endocrine disruptors. In addition, the Commission and EFSA shall publish without delay, in the interest of the public interest in disclosure, all scientific evidence relied on for the positive classification of glyphosate and the proposal for an extension of approval shall be published without delay. In addition, the Commission should authorise its Food and Veterinary Office to test and monitor residues of glyphosate in food and beverages produced in the EU and in the importer's production.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \ u2012 I supported the european Parliament's corresponding resolution on the draft implementation of the Commission regulation renewing the approval of the active substance glyphosate. I have been using glyphosate as one of the herbicides most commonly used in fruit growing and wine growing for 25 years. It is in our great interest to those of us who use these preparations to come to the true truth about its side effects. Thus, in the report, we have preventively halved the approval period from the proposed 15 to 7 years. At the same time, we have proposed to the Commission to thoroughly examine the health effects and, if it turns out that some research suggesting carcinogenicity has a professional basis, it also takes immediate action and withdraws the product from the market. Given that the herbicide has been used for the last 40 years, establishing scientific facts about the consequences of use should not be a problem. As the herbicide does not currently have a real substitute on the market, an immediate ban on use would have a significant impact on European agriculture, while not affecting countries outside the EU, e.g. the US, which is by far the largest consumer of glyphosate, particularly in the production of GMOs. I believe in the maturity of the European Commission that it will focus on and verify all the facts and arguments that are circulating around today and, if necessary, take appropriate action.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ Controversy over the extension of the glyphosate licence went far beyond the scope of the Commission's decision, but this could have been avoided if the extension had not been proposed for a maximum of 15 years. The Commission persistently underestimates the speed at which public opinion is evolving and that is why conflicts over implementing and delegated acts have been increasing recently.  The likelihood that glyphosates are carcinogenic should not be simply reduced and discarded, and therefore I consider that 7 years is too long a period. However, such a complaint is better than no objection. Impartial examinations should be carried out as soon as possible and the actual situation should be irrefutably stated.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this objection because I believe that the Commission's draft implementing regulation does not guarantee a high level of protection of human and animal health and the environment, does not apply the precautionary principle and exceeds the implementing powers established by Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 I said no to the use of glyphosate in agriculture substance used to produce almost all pesticides. Indeed, I rejected the European Commission's proposal to renew the authorisation to use glyphosate for the next fifteen years, on the basis of the precautionary principle, given that no reliable data are available on the potential carcinogenic effects. We also opposed the Amendments tabled by the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, which proposed authorisation for a shorter period of time. Parliament has expressed its opinion and sent a clear message to the European Commission and the Member States that they will be called upon to discuss and decide again in the coming weeks.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. I voted against the objection to the renewal of the authorization of glyphosate because I consider the value of this objection to be purely symbolic. Indeed, the text, as voted in the end, advocates the authorisation of glyphosate for seven years and suggests very few provisions to restrict this product on the market, even though it has been repeatedly identified as very dangerous for both consumers and farmers. I have therefore spoken out against this text, which does not take into account the precautionary principle and does not oblige the Commission to act on Parliament's requests.

name: Daniel BUDA
