text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the Objection under Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure: renewal of the approval of the active substance glyphosate, given that the Commission's proposal was based on EPSA studies from which it was clear and doubtful that this substance had not been shown to be potentially harmful to human health. Furthermore, there are sufficiently clear provisions governing the possibility and even the obligation for a substance to be withdrawn from the market where it is found that it could become harmful to animal health. Moreover, the removal of this substance from the market and the control of weeds by mechanical means would cause climatic disturbances as a result of the release into the air of gases from agricultural machinery, which would strongly accentuate the phenomenon known as the 'greenhouse effect'. However, I appreciate that research must continue, with a view to identifying mechanisms and solutions that enable the effective control of weeds and which, at the same time, constitute a guarantee for human health.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 EFSA found that glyphosate (the main ingredient of Monsanto's Roundup herbicant) is not likely to be carcinogenic or genotoxic (harmful to DNA), gaining enthusiastic acclaim from Monsanto itself. Instead, the WHO's International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) found that glyphosate is "probably" carcinogenic to humans (Group 2A).  Efsa's review of the risk assessment of the active substance glyphosate is limited to glyphosate per se; while the IARC has reviewed glyphosate together with its formulated products, which are more relevant in assessing risks to human health and biodiversity. The Commission's decision, which is the subject of this objection, therefore appears to be a unilateral act which does not take account of risks and intergovernmental consensus.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. Glyphosate is a chemical widely used in pesticides, being the main herbicide used in agriculture. There are conflicting studies by international independent bodies (IARC-WHO, EFSA) on a possible carcinogenic effect, among other possible harmful effects harmful to human health, and whether it is the base component or co-formulants.  The European Commission has submitted its proposal for an implementing regulation authorising the renewal of the authorisation for a period of 15 years, a maximum possible period, which excludes the use of tallowamine for use in plant protection products containing glyphosate among other co-formulants.  However, the EP proposes in its (non-binding) decision that it be for a period of 7 years, appealing to the precautionary principle and revoking authorisation in the event that the investigation to be carried out and/or other findings confirm serious harmful effects on human health, in compliance with European regulation on the use of pesticides. At the same time, the Commission is requested to make appropriate and professional use of the pesticide in question and to limit it in public spaces as a precautionary measure.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution on the EU approval process for the chemical glyphosate. I do not believe that any such process calling itself a scientific safety assessment can be based on unpublished, industry-sponsored and non-peer-reviewed data.  Given that IARC, the well-respected cancer expert group of the World Health Organisation, using publicly available, peer-reviewed and independent data based on its strict policy on conflicts of interest, found that glyphosate was ‘probably carcinogenic’ raises serious concerns that the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) found contradictory results (‘unlikely’ to cause cancer) just months later.  EFSA claims that the reason for its differing conclusion is because it included data the WHO did not include, but this data was excluded from the WHO assessment precisely because it did not meet its standards on independent and peer-reviewed data.  Scientific assessment should not be based on secret industry data and any approval process of glyphosate should be halted until EFSA releases the data it used to come to its conclusion. Not to do so risks further undermining confidence in the EU approval process as a whole.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ There have been suggestions that the popular herbicide glyphosate could be carcinogenic – although it has been in widespread use for decades with no evidence of harm, and a number of studies find that used properly it represents no threat to human health. Banning glyphosate would substantially increase farmers’ costs, and could result in the use of other herbicides which may even be less safe than glyphosate. It would also require more cultivation and use of tractors, resulting in increased emissions.  And after all that, we should still be importing cheaper foreign food products that had been grown with the benefit of glyphosate. UKIP does not support a ban given the very limited evidence of harm, but would support further research.  We also believe that this decision should be made for the UK in the British parliament, not imposed from Brussels.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because I agree that the Commission proposal on the renewal of the approval of the active substance glyphosate needs to be revised. The renewal period of 15 years proposed by the Commission is certainly too long and while I understand that the substance cannot be completely banned due to the lack of alternatives, stricter limitations need to be applied until such alternatives are found.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Glyphosate is the systemic herbicant with the highest volume of production globally; it is a non-selective herbicide that causes the death of all herbaceous vegetation and is used in 76% of cases in the agricultural sector but also in forestry, urban context and gardening. In March 2015, the International Agency for Research on Cancer classified glyphosate as "probably carcinogenic to humans" on the basis of "limited evidence" of carcinogenic effects in humans (resulting from cases of actual and actual exposure), "sufficient evidence" of in laboratory animals (from "pure" glyphosate studies) as well as "solid evidence" of mechanistic data concerning the carcinogenicity (genotoxicity and oxidative stress) of "pure" glyphosate and glyphosate-containing formulae. Nevertheless, the European Food Safety Authority has completed a joint evaluation of glyphosate and has come to the conclusion that glyphosate is unlikely to pose a cancer threat to humans and has refused to make the studies public. I therefore voted against renewing the authorisation of glyphosate.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against this objection because I believe that the process of evaluating the active substance glyphosate is transparent, subject to firm rules and also to scrutiny by the CS, independent institutions and citizens. It also provides sufficient guarantees that immediate remediation will be agreed on the proven negative effects of the pesticide active substance. An EP resolution on this matter would set a precedent that would deny the credibility of existing procedures based on the scientifically sound conclusions of the EFSA evaluation and on the ability of Member States to assess and decide on the risks of formulations of products at national level.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report calling on the Commission not to renew the authorisation of glyphosate and to set a clear timetable for drawing up a list of auxiliary substances that may not be contained in plant protection products.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Today's vote on the motion for a resolution on the Commission's draft implementing regulation renewing the authorisation of the active substance glyphosate in accordance with the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the placing of plant protection products on the market, as well as amending the Annex to the Implementing Regulation, concerns a technical but particularly important issue. It is the obligation of all of us to analyse and make a very careful analysis and decision on issues relating to chemical or pharmaceutical elements. I do not think that this proposal has sufficient evidence to support the renewal of the approval of this substance. And that is why I decided to vote against.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 There has been a lot of discussion in parliament in recent days about the use of glyphosate and the health implications that this substance may have, with this vote I wanted to clarify my position on it. It is clear that glyphosate is nowadays the most widely used herbicide in the world, a spread that has made it increasingly necessary in agricultural production. Recent studies have set out the implications that this substance can have on human health in particular, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) has concluded that 'glyphosate is unlikely to pose a danger of carcinogenicity to humans'. My intention with this vote has been to seek a balanced compromise that takes account of scientific uncertainty and the fact that there are no viable alternatives to date. I therefore voted in favour because I fully agree with the proposal to raise new levels of safety which will make the control of glyphosate residues in food stricter, because I am of the opinion that, especially when it comes to health, prevention is never too much.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this motion for resolution which allows the market renewal of glyphosate for just 7 years, not 15, and for professional uses only. I also supported an amendment calling for an independent review and the publication of all scientific evidence that the European Food Safety Authority uses to assess the use of glyphosate.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I support the compromise reached as a temporary solution. The shortened extension of seven years under very strict conditions can be a viable compromise that takes account of my and the concerns that have been expressed to me: the use of glyphosate for private use must not continue, and I support the ban on the use of glyphosate in public places and parks, as is already the case in my own state. Some Member States have already legislated for this, and many cities and municipalities have already taken initiatives in this direction. Health comes first!

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – There have been suggestions that the popular herbicide glyphosate could be carcinogenic – although it has been in widespread use for decades with no evidence of harm, and a number of studies find that used properly it represents no threat to human health. Banning glyphosate would substantially increase farmers’ costs, and could result in the use of other herbicides which may even be less safe than glyphosate. It would also require more cultivation and use of tractors, resulting in increased emissions.  And after all that, we should still be importing cheaper foreign food products that had been grown with the benefit of glyphosate. UKIP does not support a ban given the very limited evidence of harm, but would support further research.  We also believe that this decision should be made for the UK in the British parliament, not imposed from Brussels.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ With constant growing concern on health and the increased connection between the former and the environment, I value the provision aimed to ensure that active substances or products placed on the market do not adversely affect human or animal health or the environment. I welcome the possibility for Member States to apply the precautionary principle where there is scientific uncertainty as to risks with regard to human or animal health or the environment posed by the plant products to be authorised in their territory, particularly but not only on substances which are potentially carcinogenic to humans.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. This report contains positive aspects such as that it is critical of authorisation procedures, the impact of glyphosate on fauna and flora and the residues detected. Older it recommends not to use glyphosate for non-professional uses, not to use it in gardens, public parks or playing fields or in cases where pest management systems are sufficient. I have still voted against it because instead of recommending the absolute ban on all products containing glyphosate, it proposes a renewal of its use for seven more years.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the objection to renewing the approval of glyphosate. The primary objective of the European Union must continue to be to protect the health of its citizens. The World Health Organisation considers glyphosate 'probably carcinogenic'. This is an indication that we cannot ignore and that we cannot ignore. Today we have achieved only a positive part, but this positive aspect we must relaunch it and make the message clear to the Commission, namely that it is not possible, as was attempted to do, to renew, without further analysis and for fifteen years, the authorisation for a dangerous product.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 Glyphosate is a herbicide that destroys all vegetation, regardless of its nature, and is used in agriculture in 76%. I voted for the classification of this herbicide as a risk factor and carcinogen, which often interacts with domestic use or nutrition. I voted to entrust the test task to the Food and Veterinary Office to monitor glyphosate residues. The Commission and EFSA should also present as a matter of urgency the evidence underlying the classification of glyphosate and the authorisation to use it, although it is a carcinogenic factor, and therefore a major risk factor.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Glyphosate is an active substance used in plant protection products and authorised in all Member States. It is subject to strict rules which allow use if it does not have adverse effects on human health and the environment. The marketing authorisation for glyphosate will expire on 30 June 2016. The proposed extension of the marketing authorisation , the subject of this objection, was issued in accordance with Regulation 1107/2009. It provides for a detailed safety and environmental impact assessment by EFSA and Germany (acting as rapporteur country). The investigation concluded that glyphosate does not cause unacceptable risks if used appropriately, a result that coincides with other assessments.  In addition, the implementing measure provides that the substance POE-tallowamine (mixed with glyphosate to achieve the pesticide) should be excluded from the production of plant protection products containing glyphosate and that a negative list of similar substances will be issued in July 2016. In view of the fact that the document does not provide a high level of protection for human and animal health and the environment, does not comply with the precautionary principle and therefore does not comply with the basic act, Regulation 1107/2009, I voted against.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. In this motion for a resolution, a majority on the left wanted to object to the renewal of the authorization of glyphosate. However, I believe that an outright ban on this product widely used in agriculture would be irresponsible to professionals in this sector already in crisis. Moreover, without a technically and economically viable alternative, this decision would have a counterproductive impact in terms of health and environmental security.  Therefore, I welcome the adoption of the amendments we have tabled with my colleagues in the EPP Group, in order to preserve the competitiveness of the agricultural sector while guaranteeing a high level of health security. We propose to reduce the period of authorisation from 15 to 7 years, in order to take into account the lack of consensus among scientists, but also the time it takes for agricultural professionals to adapt to possible regulatory changes.  We also advocate stricter supervision of the use of glyphosate, limiting it to professionals, strengthening the training of farmers and prohibiting its use before harvest. Finally, we must be able to review the authorisation at any time if new scientific evidence justifies the banning of the product. In light of these elements, I supported this resolution.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: in writing. – I have voted against this resolution because it undermines the trust in the European Food and Safety Authority EFSA, a key EU agency. EFSA was created in 2002 after it had become clear that there was great necessity of such an agency, as Member States individually failed to effectively prevent a number of food crises. I strongly believe in the expertise and trustworthiness of this agency and therefore do not agree to the criticism that this resolution brings towards it.  The main argument by opponents of glyphosate was its probability of being carcinogenic. After having taken knowledge of the fact that EFSA has taken into account hundreds of studies, I have again no other choice than placing my trust in EFSA. Specifically, they base their studies on the fact that there is great difference in the study results depending on whether the product is used in a concentrated or a diluted form. In addition, glyphosate is of great importance to our agricultural sector and therefore for food security in the EU. In sum, I believe that emotions should not prevail over scientific evidence in such matter, and that it is therefore not the politician’s place to question EFSA’s competences when it is clearly doing its job.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. A debate has emerged on the risk of carcinogenicity of glyphosate, a total weedkiller, following the findings of the European Food Safety Authority and the International Agency for Research on Cancer. Glyphosate is used by many European farmers, there is no economically viable alternative to human health. However, citizens' concerns must be heard. I have therefore proposed amendments, on behalf of the EPP Group, limiting and framing the authorisation to market: 7 years instead of 15 (proposed by the Commission), which will have to be reviewed according to the analyses of the European Chemicals Agency by the end of 2017; Certification system for professionals; limitation and/or prohibition for non-professionals; accelerating the work of the Commission and Member States on the list of co-formulating to be banned; strengthening research and innovation towards alternatives to glyphosate. As these essential points were adopted by my colleagues, I voted in favour of the resolution. On this issue it was important to have a more pragmatic than political approach in order to propose a solution to the ongoing deadlock between the Commission and the Member States.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 A number of worrying research findings have been published on the carcinogenic effects of a pesticide called glyphosate and special attention should therefore be paid to the extension of the EU authorisation for the active substance. Currently, of all herbicides, glyphosate is the most popular drug in the world, whose global use has increased dramatically over the past 40 years. The problem is that in many Member States, from large-scale agricultural production to forestry and hobby gardening, almost anyone can use this plant protection product without proper qualifications or restrictions on use. In my opinion, the compromise offered by the PpE Group is capable of strikeing the right balance between the concerns of European citizens and the legitimate interests of agricultural operators. According to the amendment adopted, the European Commission should only renew the marketing authorisation for glyphosate for 7 years instead of 15, subject to strict restrictions on professional qualifications. In parallel, it should ensure that the toxicity of glyphosate is independently reviewed for its carcinogenic effects and its properties in relation to substances that disrupt hormone balance. It should be noted that the authorisation may be withdrawn at any time if new evidence of the safety of the product emerges in the meantime.  The incorporation of all these guarantees could also lead to the sustainable use of glyphosate in Europe, which is already common practice in Hungary.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Written. 'I did not support the resolution calling for the renewal of the licence of the active substance glyphosate for 7 years. There is currently no scientific consensus on the hot question in this dossier, namely whether or not glyphosate is carcinogenic. The European Food Safety Agency (EFSA) and the World Health Organisation's International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) come to different conclusions. It is also not ruled out that glyphosate has endocrine disrupting properties.  That is why I am calling for more research in which the role of so-called co-formulats or additives is thoroughly assessed. These additives are, after all, an important explanation for the scientific disagreement. Whereas EFSA's analysis focuses on the active substance glyphosate (in accordance with its mission), IARC has also analysed additives. The starting points of the risk analyses are therefore different. Everyone knows that you can't compare apples with pears. The European Commission also seems to realise this: why else would the Commission link the possible extension of the glyphosate licence to a ban on tallowamine as a co-formulant? More research and transparency are being urged to remove the many uncertainties in this dossier in the interests of public health and the environment.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: In writing. More commonly known as Round up, the herbicide glyphosate should soon be banned in Europe, with the research sector, in conjunction with the agricultural world, finding environmentally friendly alternative products and methods and speeding up conversions. The European Commission intended to extend the authorisation by 15 years. In the end, the majority of MPs opted for a shorter extension, reduced to 7 years. I think it's a half-success. I encourage those involved in the agricultural world who are still using glyphosate to turn as quickly as possible to other non-toxic active substances for the benefit of their health and that of all citizens.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. Given the remaining concerns about the carcinogenic and endocrine disruptor nature of glyphosate, I absolutely did not agree to renew its marketing authorization for 15 years. I was in favour of a brief period of extension (2-5 years) of this authorization, which in particular would allow farmers to have access to alternative solutions. Since the First Amendment put to the vote provided for a period of 7 years and only for professional purposes, I voted in favour of it for fear that the objection would ultimately be rejected.

name: Jørn DOHRMANN
text: Written. I am pleased that a compromise was reached in which Parliament agreed to extend the authorisation of glyphosate. The substance is generating a great deal of scientific debate, but in my view there is not enough evidence that the substance is harmful to an extent that requires a ban.  Studies on the substance must continue as long as there are doubts and we have the possibility of withdrawing the authorisation if new crucial knowledge comes to light. However, imposing a ban on such an uncertain basis as what has been presented so far by, among others, IARC would be untenable. Glyphosate is a very important tool for our troubled agriculture. I'm glad they shouldn't have another problem to worry about.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 A number of worrying research findings have been published on the carcinogenic effects of a pesticide called glyphosate and special attention should therefore be paid to the extension of the EU authorisation for the active substance. Currently, of all herbicides, glyphosate is the most popular drug in the world, whose global use has increased dramatically over the past 40 years. The problem is that in many Member States, from large-scale agricultural production to forestry and hobby gardening, almost anyone can use this plant protection product without proper qualifications or restrictions on use. In my opinion, the compromise offered by the PP group is capable of strikeing the right balance between the concerns of European citizens and the legitimate interests of agricultural operators. According to the amendment adopted, the European Commission should only renew the marketing authorisation for glyphosate for 7 years instead of 15, subject to strict restrictions on professional qualifications. In parallel, it should ensure that the toxicity of glyphosate is independently reviewed for its carcinogenic effects and its properties in relation to substances that disrupt hormone balance. It should be noted that the authorisation may be withdrawn at any time if new evidence of the safety of the product emerges in the meantime.  The incorporation of all these guarantees could also lead to the sustainable use of glyphosate in Europe, which is already common practice in Hungary.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this resolution. I am opposed to the renewal of the licence for the weed killer glyphosate, but Parliament voted to renew it for a further seven years. I welcome the serious concerns highlighted in the resolution, such as a ban on its use close to public playgrounds and gardens, but it did not go as far as I wanted. I have received strong lobbying in opposition to glyphosate from my constituents in Wales, and until the health and environmental concerns are dealt with, I cannot support its approval.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. \u2012 We voted on a non-binding opinion to the Commission on renewed authorisation for glyphosate. For me, it was important to highlight in particular the fundamental issues of how the Union should deal with chemicals. I think it is important to stick to the principle that it is not politicians who should make scientific assessments, but that it is something that should be left to science. In Europe, we have a system in which EFSA, as a scientific expert, makes the scientific analysis on which we then base a possible authorisation. As the regulatory framework currently stands, it is possible to withdraw a permit for a substance if scientific evidence emerges that will bring a different conclusion to the scientific analysis. It is important that this possibility is used and that EFSA makes new analyses if new facts emerge. With regard to glyphosate, I note that EFSA has made a recommendation to the Commission which allows it to propose an extended authorisation for glyphosate. For me, the important thing is not how many years a permit is given, but that we have a system where chemicals can get approval based on a scientific analysis by experts, not politicians.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. Phytopharmaceutical products containing glyphosate are one of the preferred tools of Portuguese farmers as systemic herbicides, due to their efficacy and low cost. Currently represent 70% of the total volume of herbicide sales in Portugal, being used in vineyards, fruit trees, olive groves and cereals. Its use is part of farm support programmes under the 2020 RdP. I therefore agree with the conclusions of the European Food Safety Agency, which dissociates the carcinogenic potential of glyphosate by associating it with a co-formulant (thaloamine), which, yes, should deserve special attention from the authorities.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The results of research on glyphosate toxicity by the European Food Safety Authority are contradictory to the conclusion of the World Health Organisation Agency for Cancer Research as to the classification of the carcinogenic potential of this substance in humans. A high long-term risk has been identified in almost all uses of glyphosate for non-target terrestrial vertebrates, including mammals and birds. The use of this herbicide – not selective – eliminates not only weeds, but all plants, as well as algae, bacteria and fungi, causing a significant negative impact on biodiversity and the ecosystem. Nevertheless, the European Commission proposes to authorise the use of glyphosate by 2031, i.e. for as long as possible for any use, without any restrictions (with the exception of one of the more than 500 co-formulants), only subject to confirmatory information on endocrine disrupting properties.  The European Commission's proposal therefore does not guarantee the desirable high level of protection of human and animal health and the environment and does not apply the precautionary principle. We therefore advocate the non-renewal of glyphosate approval and the establishment of a timetable for the creation of a list of non-accepted co-formulants for inclusion in plant protection products.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Glyphosate is an active substance widely used in herbicides. The approval of the active substance glyphosate in the European Union expires on 30 June 2016. This draft measure, subject to this objection, renews the approval of the active substance glyphosate for a maximum authorised period of 15 years. There are conflicting views on glyphosate in relation to the WHO International Agency for Research on Cancer, which classifies glyphosate as possibly carcinogenic to humans after evaluating a large body of scientific evidence. On the other hand, the European Food Safety Authority does not accept any danger. However, he based his claims on unpublished studies in the field of industry. This objection is opposed to the draft measures on the grounds that the draft implementing act fails to ensure a high level of protection of both human and animal health and the environment and is unable to apply the precautionary principle. I am of the opinion that the European Commission should not renew the approval of glyphosate and should ensure an independent review of its classification on the basis of available scientific evidence and studies.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against because the report does not take into account the risks of glyphosate and intergovernmental opinions.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the objection pursuant to Article 106: renewal of the authorisation for the active substance glyphosate as these amendments attempt to alter the substance of the resolution and continue the circulation of Glyphosate, serving the interests of its production company, the well-known Monsanto.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution as I believe it is wrong to argue that this implementing measure fails to apply the precautionary principle and is incompatible with the terms of its basic act. It is scaremongering to claim that glyphosate-based products are not thoroughly checked before they can be sold to the public and that they do not undergo stringent scientific assessment. British farmers would experience a significant loss in their arable and horticultural yields were such products to be pulled from the market, and face a significant increase in costs in controlling weed growth.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ There are contradicting opinions regarding glyphosate, with a WHO International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) classifying glyphosate as probably carcinogenic to humans after evaluating a large body of scientific evidence, and the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) dismissing any danger while basing its decision on unpublished studies commissioned by the industry. Moreover, there are serious doubts as regards a possible mode of action in relation to the endocrine disrupting properties of glyphosate, and in the absence of proper scientific horizontal criteria an endocrine-mediated mode of action cannot be ruled out.  The objection opposes the draft measure on the grounds that the draft implementing act fails to ensure a high level of protection of both human and animal health and the environment, fails to apply the precautionary principle, is therefore not compatible with the aim and the content of the basic instrument, and exceeds the implementing powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009. I believe the Commission should not renew the approval of glyphosate and should rapidly ensure an independent review of the classification of glyphosate based on all available scientific evidence relating to carcinogenicity of glyphosate as well as possible endocrine disruptive properties.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 A number of worrying research findings have been published on the carcinogenic effects of a pesticide called glyphosate and special attention should therefore be paid to the extension of the EU authorisation for the active substance. Currently, of all herbicides, glyphosate is the most popular drug in the world, whose global use has increased dramatically over the past 40 years. The problem is that in many Member States, from large-scale agricultural production to forestry and hobby gardening, almost anyone can use this plant protection product without proper qualifications or restrictions on use. In my opinion, the compromise offered by the PpE Group is capable of strikeing the right balance between the concerns of European citizens and the legitimate interests of agricultural operators. According to the amendment adopted, the European Commission should only renew the marketing authorisation for glyphosate for 7 years instead of 15, subject to strict restrictions on professional qualifications. In parallel, it should ensure that the toxicity of glyphosate is independently reviewed for its carcinogenic effects and its properties in relation to substances that disrupt hormone balance. It should be noted that the authorisation may be withdrawn at any time if new evidence of the safety of the product emerges in the meantime.  The incorporation of all these guarantees could also lead to the sustainable use of glyphosate in Europe, which is already common practice in Hungary.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 A number of worrying research findings have been published on the carcinogenic effects of a pesticide called glyphosate and special attention should therefore be paid to the extension of the EU authorisation for the active substance. Currently, of all herbicides, glyphosate is the most popular drug in the world, whose global use has increased dramatically over the past 40 years. The problem is that in many Member States, from large-scale agricultural production to forestry and hobby gardening, almost anyone can use this plant protection product without proper qualifications or restrictions on use. In my opinion, the compromise offered by the PpE Group is capable of strikeing the right balance between the concerns of European citizens and the legitimate interests of agricultural operators. According to the amendment adopted, the European Commission should only renew the marketing authorisation for glyphosate for 7 years instead of 15, subject to strict restrictions on professional qualifications. In parallel, it should ensure that the toxicity of glyphosate is independently reviewed for its carcinogenic effects and its properties in relation to substances that disrupt hormone balance. It should be noted that the authorisation may be withdrawn at any time if new evidence of the safety of the product emerges in the meantime.  The incorporation of all these guarantees could also lead to the sustainable use of glyphosate in Europe, which is already common practice in Hungary.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution since we have been able to amend the original text with the aim of giving a period of adaptation to both farmers and producers, also safeguarding public health. The proposal put forward, which involved the abolition of the use of glyphosate products, would have been a great insecurity for farmers, but also for users, as well as a great cost to an already severely damaged sector, as we discussed yesterday in plenary. I believe that the solution proposed is aimed at replacing the use of this substance in the medium term, thus ensuring the precautionary principle and ensuring that substitution can be done progressively from the professional sectors that use it.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of Parliament's objections to the extension of the authorisation of the active substance glyphosate and the correspondingly modified requirements, as I take the recently proven carcinogenic effect very seriously and expect a harmless, adequate replacement as soon as possible – without, however, putting too much pressure on our farming or making it a scapegoat.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Some campaigns have spread misleading information in recent weeks. These include the alleged health risks of traces of glyphosate in German beer. This accusation was immediately refuted by the Federal Institute for Risk Assessment (BfR): the residues found in the beers were 1000 times below the maximum residue limits set by the authorities. Based on the BfR's calculations, an adult would have to drink about 1000 litres of beer per day in order to exceed the health-relevant limit value. Before that, of course, the amount of alcohol or water to be absorbed would be fatal. Both the BfR and the European Food Safety Authority consider glyphosate to be safe, while respecting the relevant limit values. A ban on glyphosate would be disproportionate in this context. As a PPE-DE, we are committed to sound legislation based on facts, scientific studies and impact assessments. In Parliament, we have pushed for a compromise against a disproportionate ban. Authorisation for the plant protection product, which is of considerable importance to agriculture, is to be extended by seven years (instead of the original 15).

name: Julie GIRLING
text: in writing. ‒ As a firm proponent of evidence-based policy-making in the regulation of agricultural technologies, the UK delegation welcomes Parliament’s decision to reject calls to ban glyphosate. The authorisation of active substances is based on the scientific evaluation of a rapporteur Member State and EFSA. This process views glyphosate to be safe, when used appropriately, and concludes that glyphosate is not carcinogenic. Ignoring this advice would set a dangerous precedent and undermine the EU’s entire risk assessment system. However, the UK delegation still considers the basis for this objection resolution remains fundamentally flawed. It is incorrect to argue that the Commission’s implementing measure fails to ensure a high level of protection and is incompatible with Regulation 1107/2009. All active substances authorised for use undergo a comprehensive assessment to ensure they pose no unacceptable risk. Moreover, the resolution misuses the precautionary principle, dismisses the existing regulatory framework for the sustainable use of pesticides and attempts to forge a link between glyphosate and potential endocrine disrupting properties despite both EFSA and the USEPA concluding that there is no evidence of such effect.  For these reasons the UK Delegation cannot support the resolution.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. Unfortunately, the objection to the renewal of glyphosate is only symbolic: the Commission is under no obligation to act on Parliament's requests.  Faced with the dangers posed by this herbicide, I supported all the amendments aimed at restricting its use as much as possible: banning the use of non-professionals, restricting agricultural uses, banning certain agricultural uses or banning agricultural use when other methods are sufficient. In 2015, I myself objected to GMOs that are tolerant to glyphosate, especially for the risks posed by this product.  While the ban on this product would be a major public health decision, it should undoubtedly be accompanied by a ban on the importation of glyphosate-treated products.  The text as voted by the parliament finally advocates authorisation for a period of 7 years, and suggests only a few provisions of restrictions. For example, it did not accept a ban on the use of glyphosate in public parks and gardens.  With this seven-year term, the text leaves consumers and farmers at great risk and ignores the necessary precautionary principle. So I voted against it.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted against it since the amendments adopted do not reflect the outcome of the discussions we have had in the Commission. It is irresponsible to call for the renewal of glyphosate for seven years. We call on the competent authorities to apply the precautionary principle to the World Health Organization (WHO) report, which determined that glyphosate is "probably carcinogenic to humans". However, there is plenty of reason to think that EFSA (European Food Safety Agency), whose study reached conclusions contrary to WHO's, is not entirely independent and we must therefore question its recommendations. We cannot allow such a substance, which is used as a herbicide for our fields, to be marketed in Europe and ends up in the food we eat.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: In writing. Glyphosate is a controversial substance that is probably carcinogenic to humans. The health risks associated with the use of this herbicide stem from the fact that glyphosate residues are present in the environment and in many everyday products and are not metabolized by humans. In the name of protecting consumer health, I strongly oppose the renewal of the marketing authorization for glyphosate.  The original resolution was amended by an amendment calling for a 7-year transition period, against which I voted. However, I voted in favour of this resolution because it was important to me that Parliament objected and asked the Commission to review its original proposal.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text because it aims to more strictly regulate the marketing of glyphosate, a product used in many herbicides including Monsanto's famous "Round-up". In light of the continuing controversies surrounding glyphosate, we have asked the Commission to renew its authorisation only for a period of seven years, instead of the fifteen initially proposed, and only for professional purposes.  In the absence of viable alternatives today, an outright ban on the product would have had a devastating impact on farmers for whom it is very useful. This is why the text also stresses the urgent need to fund research in order to quickly find viable, effective and safe alternative substances.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. Glyphosate is found in 750 weedkillers and detected in 44% of citizens, while glyphosate has been classified as "probably carcinogenic" by WHO. However, it is in this context that the European Commission has voted in favour of renewing the authorisation of glyphosate for the next fifteen years.  We are once again faced with a file managed in a totally opaque manner by the Commission: it is impossible to know the composition of the expert committee or even to have access to the working papers when EFSA is showing a blatant lack of independence. This position is unacceptable when it is the health of Europeans that is at stake.  That is why we and my group have tabled a resolution of objection to the Commission's enforcement act. During the plenary session, amendments changed the meaning of the resolution and I voted against authorisation for 7 years because an immediate ban is necessary. 7 years, even to set up a transition, is far too long. On the other hand, I voted in favour of the final resolution because its main purpose is to send a message to the European Commission and the Member States, to defend alternative solutions that respect public health.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the renewal of the approval of the active substance glyphosate because the document had many paragraphs which have to be reviewed.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Written. We support the resolution because it has not been scientifically satisfactorily excluded that glyphosate has a carcinogenic and endocrine disrupting effect on humans, which is contrary to the precautionary principle. We therefore object to the Commission renewing the authorisation of glyphosate for 15 years to come. In order not to bring down the resolution, we were forced into certain compromises in the vote.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 A number of worrying research findings have been published on the carcinogenic effects of a pesticide called glyphosate and special attention should therefore be paid to the extension of the EU authorisation for the active substance. Currently, of all herbicides, glyphosate is the most popular drug in the world, whose global use has increased dramatically over the past 40 years. The problem is that in many Member States, from large-scale agricultural production to forestry and hobby gardening, almost anyone can use this plant protection product without proper qualifications or restrictions on use. In my opinion, the compromise offered by the PpE Group is capable of strikeing the right balance between the concerns of European citizens and the legitimate interests of agricultural operators. According to the amendment adopted, the European Commission should only renew the marketing authorisation for glyphosate for 7 years instead of 15, subject to strict restrictions on professional qualifications. In parallel, it should ensure that the toxicity of glyphosate is independently reviewed for its carcinogenic effects and its properties in relation to substances that disrupt hormone balance. It should be noted that the authorisation may be withdrawn at any time if new evidence of the safety of the product emerges in the meantime.  The incorporation of all these guarantees could also lead to the sustainable use of glyphosate in Europe, which is already common practice in Hungary.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 The report concerned the renewal of the authorisation for the active substance glyphosate. A wealth of independent research reveals a number of worrying findings on health and the environment. Our position was in favour of not renewing the authorisation of the pesticide and that we should go one step further in calling for its withdrawal. Unfortunately, our position was not adopted and that is why we voted against the report.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I support a limited – 7 year not 15 as proposed by the Commission – extension of the approval of glyphosate, a widely used herbicide. EFSA has declared it is unlikely to pose a carcinogenic hazard. IARC categorises it as probably carcinogenic – in the same category as red meat, lead compounds, frying emissions and biomass fuel. Properly used by trained operators the chemical can be safely used and assist conservation agriculture which seeks to be more climate and environmentally friendly. I also support continued research into alternative and effective herbicides and pesticides.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 A number of worrying research findings have been published on the carcinogenic effects of a pesticide called glyphosate and special attention should therefore be paid to the extension of the EU authorisation for the active substance. Currently, of all herbicides, glyphosate is the most popular drug in the world, whose global use has increased dramatically over the past 40 years. The problem is that in many Member States, from large-scale agricultural production to forestry and hobby gardening, almost anyone can use this plant protection product without proper qualifications or restrictions on use. In my opinion, the compromise offered by the PpE Group is capable of strikeing the right balance between the concerns of European citizens and the legitimate interests of agricultural operators. According to the amendment adopted, the European Commission should only renew the marketing authorisation for glyphosate for 7 years instead of 15, subject to strict restrictions on professional qualifications. In parallel, it should ensure that the toxicity of glyphosate is independently reviewed for its carcinogenic effects and its properties in relation to substances that disrupt hormone balance. It should be noted that the authorisation may be withdrawn at any time if new evidence of the safety of the product emerges in the meantime.  The incorporation of all these guarantees could also lead to the sustainable use of glyphosate in Europe, which is already common practice in Hungary.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. I have chosen to approve the European Parliament's resolution on the objection to glyphosate, which seems to me to be sufficiently cautious in view of the divergent scientific studies on the harmfulness of this weeding product and the lack of an economically viable and safe alternative to human health. I am aware of the concerns of the citizens and that is why my colleague Angélique Delahaye, herself a farmer, has proposed many solutions such as limiting or even banning the sale to non-professionals, training professionals, limiting pre-harvest use, extending the authorisation limited to 7 years and strengthening research to find alternatives. Those who advocate an immediate ban must understand the folly of such a decision. Farmers who are already crushed by the agricultural crisis would not recover from the ban on this essential product in their business. The ban on glyphosate is a shovel of soil in the graves of farmers. If we wanted to kill French agriculture, which was already very burdened, we could not do it better.  It is true that we will always have imported products whose composition we do not know to feed ourselves!

name: Richard HOWITT
text: in writing. ‒ With 1.4 million farmed hectares across the East of England and GBP 998 million worth of income stemming from farming in my region in 2014, I understand the importance of listening to the views of our farmers. I received many letters emphasising the assistance provided to farmers by products containing glyphosate and I am grateful for them. I also received many representations from constituents raising concerns about its safety – and those of other chemical products – particularly as many people come into contact with them.  That is why I voted for this report which will urge the Commission to undertake further work to establish the level of any harm to health and the environment that is caused.  My vote is not a vote against glyphosate itself and I do not want to ban farmers from using a popular herbicide without a substitute being available. The outcome does not ban the product, but simply denies a 15 year approval for its continued use at this stage. I think the responsible thing to do is seek approval for a shorter time span, undertake further scientific investigation, and vote for more robust safety assessments of any chemical which can potentially cause cancer.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ It is important to emphasise that this vote in the European Parliament is not a final or legally binding one: it merely offers a political opinion on the subject. The actual decision will be taken by representatives of the 28 EU Member States in the European Commission’s Standing Committee on Plants, Animals, Food and Feed. I recognise that the science is not entirely settled on glyphosate. Therefore, it would not be right to ignore concerns and write a blank cheque for glyphosate through a standard 15-year re-authorisation with no conditions. In particular, the European Chemicals Agency is launching a review of glyphosate, which should report by the end of 2017. I felt it appropriate to support amendments calling for a compromise approach: a re-authorisation for 5-7 years. Following a complex series of votes, with more than 50 conflicting amendments having been tabled, MEPs have chosen not to endorse the position taken by our Environment Committee, which had called for an outright ban. Instead, our majority opinion was to suggest a seven-year approval, with some conditions attached. I think that position is reasonable in the circumstances, and voted in favour of it.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the objection regarding the renewal of the approval of the active substance glyphosate due to the serious doubts regarding its carcinogenic effect on humans. This issue appeared after evaluating a large body of scientific evidence by the WHO Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC).

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: Written. \u2012 I voted in favour of continued use of glyphosate. However, I want it to be accessed only by professionals and in a more limited way in the future. I think it would be unreasonable to ban the use of glyphosate from agriculture if there are no better alternatives. A seven-year extension to use is a good compromise. Harm must be studied comprehensively and more environmentally friendly substitutes must be developed as quickly as possible.  I am also prepared to review the use of glyphosate if new scientific evidence of its adverse effects is obtained. I would also point out that in Finland, for example, the use of glyphosate for the drying of bread grain is already prohibited.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted against the European Parliament's resolution on the Commission's draft implementing regulation on extending the approval of the active substance glyphosate in accordance with parliament and council regulation on the marketing of plant protection products and amending Annex to Implementing Regulation (EU) No 1000/2013/ 2013. 540/2011 because the text of the resolution does not show unequivocally and precisely that the use of glyphosate is very dangerous for human and animal health. As many studies show that the use of glyphosate is very likely to contribute to the development of cancer on the human body, I voted against this resolution.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The European Commission has proposed to postpone the publication of the list of banned adjuvants to an indefinite date. At the same time, the Commission manages to be in a hurry and to remain evasive in its regulatory intentions. This paradox is also contrary to the precautionary principle with regard to the health of consumers and farmers. Transparency remains an essential element in regulating and framing agricultural practices and the use of plant protection products. FN elected officials, meanwhile, have called for funding for alternative solutions for agriculture. Hence my vote in favour of this text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – There have been suggestions that the popular herbicide glyphosate could be carcinogenic – although it has been in widespread use for decades with no evidence of harm, and a number of studies find that used properly it represents no threat to human health. Banning glyphosate would substantially increase farmers’ costs, and could result in the use of other herbicides which may even be less safe than glyphosate. It would also require more cultivation and use of tractors, resulting in increased emissions.  And after all that, we should still be importing cheaper foreign food products that had been grown with the benefit of glyphosate. UKIP does not support a ban given the very limited evidence of harm, but would support further research.  We also believe that this decision should be made for the UK in the British parliament, not imposed from Brussels.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report of my colleagues Pavel Poc, Kate-ina Koneon, Bas Eickhout, Piernicola Pedicini, Mark Demesmaeker, Sirpa Pietik-inen, Frédérique Ries concerning the objection under Article 106 of the renewal of the approval of the active substance glyphosate. Many farmers in Europe use glyphosate as a basic chemical agent for weeding.  Unfortunately, at present, no economically viable and harmless alternative to human health can be offered to farmers. Thus, the use of this product must be supervised: it is a question of limiting a renewed use of this product, of limiting or even prohibiting its sale to individuals, of training professionals and of limiting the use of this substance before harvest. At the same time, it is imperative to develop a list of co-formulating to outlaw and strengthen research and innovation in this sector in order to find viable alternatives.  This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the final resolution on a renewal of the authorization of glyphosate. The report by the Independent European Food Safety Agency (EFSA) concluded that the substance did not pose a carcinogenic risk to humans. Extending this authorization will not prevent the imposition of strict rules on the control of these substances. Moreover, removing Glyphosate would be a blow to farmers who use it because there is no alternative at the moment. The 7-year period will thus allow us to find a way out to take into account the issues of agriculture but also the defence of citizens and the environment.

name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Glyphosate is a substance used in the production of herbicides. In addition to its use in horticulturism or forestry, this measure is mainly used to protect crops in agriculture, and since its entry into the market in 1974, glyphosate production has increased almost 260-fold. I think this shows its effectiveness and safety for human, animal and plant health. As agreed in 2002, the European Commission proposed by means of an implementing regulation to renew the authorisation to place glyphosate on the market.  I believe that one of the most popular and effective ingredients used in the production of plant protection products should not be removed from the market without scientifically sound arguments and reliable evidence of its harmfulness to humans and the environment. Let us not create additional difficulties for our farmers, who have been in a difficult situation in recent years. At the same time, let us remember that if we prohibit the use of substances tested and tested, the risk of the use of substitute products, much more harmful and at the same time distributed illegally, will increase. And that would be a very bad decision.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of the resolution to remove glyphosate from the food chain, thereby taking full account of the precautionary principle.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. – At the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg, I voted in favour of the objection under Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure to the renewal of the approval of the active substance 'glyphosate'. The European Commission's proposal provided for the renewal of the authorisation of the active substance glyphosate for a further 15 years. The European Parliament resolution and the objection emphasise the potential dangers and possible adverse consequences for human health of glyphosate, and is therefore opposed to the use of such a substance for such a long period of time. The European Parliament resolution provides that the substance is to be authorised for a further 7 years, but if new studies reveal and can demonstrate that the substance concerned no longer meets the criteria for approval, the Commission may withdraw the approval of the active substance. In addition, Member States may decide at national level whether they wish to authorise or whether to prohibit the substance. The resolution also stressed that the harmful substance should only be used at a professional level and calls on the Commission to recommend that Member States restrict or prohibit the sale of glyphosate to non-professional users. Considering the information I know, I believe that, for health reasons, it is right not to allow the renewal of glyphosate for a period of 15 years, allowing it for a much shorter period of time and with much stricter rules for its use.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. My group proposed a compromise to counter the proposal on glyphosates presented by the Commission. Renewal of the use of glyphosate cannot be allowed without applying the strictest conditions, and it should not be extended to 15 years. I support cutting the time to 7 years – a temporary limited renewal, under strict conditions and with a clear indication that the Commission should withdraw their approval if it no longer satisfies the criteria. Although the concentrations of glyphosate remain below legal thresholds, it still poses a possible risk to human and animal health and to environment. Therefore the decision by the Commission to renew the approval of glyphosate in the proposed form is unacceptable.  I also welcome the call to prohibit or at least limit the use of glyphosate in private sector and on public ground and to take more co-formulants off the market.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 On Wednesday 13. 4. our objection to the renewal of the approval of the herbicide glyphosate for use in the EU was voted on. To begin with, I am very disappointed with the overall result of the vote. The need to vote against the text you have submitted is never a pleasant experience. Our objection has been warped by right-wing factions who have proposed amendments to weaken the eu's total ban on glyphosate. And unfortunately, they managed to accept them. Finally, an amendment calling on the Commission to renew the authorization of glyphosate for another 7 years without further evaluation succeeded. This has turned the original text, which was supposed to say no to the use of glyphosate in the EU, become a blank cheque for the Commission in the spirit: if you allow the use for 7 years, we do not care on what basis you do so. Perhaps a small consolation is that the proposal calls on the Commission to authorise the use of this substance only to professionals. Glyphosate is carcinogenic to both animals and probably humans, and in my opinion its authorisation should not be extended in any way. This is a heinous gamble on the health of European citizens. It is also completely against the will of more than 2/3 of the citizens of the European Union. Since the original meaning of the adopted text has completely disappeared, I have been forced to vote against this proposal.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 A number of worrying research findings have been published on the carcinogenic effects of a pesticide called glyphosate and special attention should therefore be paid to the extension of the EU authorisation for the active substance. Currently, of all herbicides, glyphosate is the most popular drug in the world, whose global use has increased dramatically over the past 40 years. The problem is that in many Member States, from large-scale agricultural production to forestry and hobby gardening, almost anyone can use this plant protection product without proper qualifications or restrictions on use. In my opinion, the compromise offered by the PpE Group is capable of strikeing the right balance between the concerns of European citizens and the legitimate interests of agricultural operators. According to the amendment adopted, the European Commission should only renew the marketing authorisation for glyphosate for 7 years instead of 15, subject to strict restrictions on professional qualifications. In parallel, it should ensure that the toxicity of glyphosate is independently reviewed for its carcinogenic effects and its properties in relation to substances that disrupt hormone balance. It should be noted that the authorisation may be withdrawn at any time if new evidence of the safety of the product emerges in the meantime.  The incorporation of all these guarantees could also lead to the sustainable use of glyphosate in Europe, which is already common practice in Hungary.

name: Elisabeth KÖSTINGER
text: Writing. Plant protection products guarantee protection against pests and thus ensure the high quality of our food. The active substance glyphosate is one of the best controlled active substances used in the European Union. I abstained from the vote because the decision on new authorisation should only be taken on the basis of current scientific evaluation. The European authorisation procedure ensures that each active substance is controlled under constant supervision. This makes it certain that, if new scientific facts are available, plant protection products will no longer be authorised. They are only used as long as they meet the high standards of the European Union.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. Like a majority of my colleagues, I have voted to object to the renewal of the marketing authorization for the glyphosate substance, the total weedkiller particularly used in agriculture, because of the many reservations and doubts expressed in this objection as to the possible carcinogenic nature of this product.  We finally voted for a renewal of the marketing authorization for glyphosate for only 7 years instead of the 15 years proposed by the European Commission and for the limitation of the use of glyphosate to professionals only.  We have therefore supported the European Commission's request to glyphosate manufacturers to publish additional technical elements to determine precisely whether or not glyphosate can be carcinogenic to humans.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. This vote validates the re-authorization of glyphosate pesticides despite their proven health hazards. The extended 7-year authorisation of this pesticide perfectly sums up the existing doubts about the impartiality of EFSA, the European body responsible for analysing the health risks of products put on the market. While WHO considers this pesticide, produced by Monsanto, a carcinogen and there are serious doubts about its role as an endocrine disruptor (i.e. it affects the hormonal composition of our body), EFSA is extending its authorisation! Parliament's decision is ubuesque because, while recognising these risks, it validates the re-authorization by limiting it to 7 years instead of the 15 proposed by the Commission, and only to professionals. Moreover, the restriction of the use of this pesticide by many prohibitions (forbidden in playgrounds, public parks, before harvests), sounds like a confession, of which no consequences are drawn. How do you tell the difference between professionals and individuals? How can we ensure that the use of this pesticide complies with all of these restrictions? Parliament would have been much better advised to refuse this authorisation as I did and as its Environment Committee advocated.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the active substance glyphosate. The International Agency for Research on Cancer had described glyphosate as a "probably carcinogenic" product, a precaution not shared by EFSA, the European food safety agency. The risks of glyphosate are established in particular in its commercial formulations whose toxicity is increased by the presence of co-formulants. Glyphosate is also considered an antibiotic, and a patent is even filed for such use.  However, the fight against antibiotic resistance and the massive use of antibiotics is a recurring topic in European regulations. Amendments 32, 35 and 20 were important. They proposed not to approve the authorization for non-professional uses, and not to approve the use of the product just before harvest. Amendment 20 was based on the precautionary principle. As just Amendment 32 was adopted, I voted against the text.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it too easily accepts the use of glyphosate just before harvest. It is a toxic product that is then present in food. Unfortunately, the ENL group's amendment, which was intended to recall the existence of conflicts of interest within the organizations that produce studies on the subject, was rejected.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. With my vote against the objection raised by the Committee on the Environment, I de facto supported the European Commission's decision to extend the authorisation for the use of the chemical glyphosate. The chemical glyphosate is commonly used in gardening and agriculture to protect against pests. The substance does not have a demonstrable unquestionable negative effect on human health and I am in a positive way that it can continue to be used and its effect on human health can be further investigated.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: In writing. The herbicide glyphosate has been used for more than 30 years. Marketed as Round up, it was declared a "probable carcinogen" by the World Health Organization in March 2015. However, it is the best-selling herbicide in the world. Present in more than 750 weedkillers, this dangerous product has recently been detected in 44% of European citizens who have never been in direct contact with the herbicide. We therefore consume this herbicide on a daily basis, without knowing it and especially without wanting it. To our surprise, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) has deemed the carcinogenic risk of glyphosate "unlikely" and the European Commission recently recommended the renewal of the marketing authorization for glyphosate for 15 years, until 2031. The resolution initially called on the European Commission not to renew the authorisation to market glyphosate. Alas, an amendment tabled by the European right has been approved by a narrow majority, and calls for a seven-year renewal of the authorisation to market this product. For the sake of public health, I am voting against this resolution.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the motion for a resolution on the Commission's draft implementing regulation renewing the authorisation of the active substance glyphosate in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. This Regulation should therefore be amended accordingly. 540/2011 (D044281-01 – 2016/2624(RSP), because this motion for a resolution, as finally formulated by the Ep plenary with the adoption of specific amendments, allows the use of glyphosate for 7 years which is particularly dangerous to the public health of millions of people.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this text. The National Front urges caution on glyphosate, which is widely used in agriculture. This product has been the subject of warnings from the European Food Safety Agency ("EFSA"). It is indeed carcinogenic, and, because of its antibiotic nature, would promote antibiotic resistance.  The Europe of Nations and Freedoms Group considers that the Commission has exceeded its powers by renewing this authorisation, which is moreover in defiance of the precautionary principle.  However, it is important not to rush a ban and to use all means so that farmers who use glyphosate can find an alternative solution.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. I voted against, because extending the authorisation to use glyphosate for another 7 years is to give in to the economic interests of multinationals. When we talk about glyphosate, we talk about a chemical that has already been classified by the WHO as potentially carcinogenic. However, unlike other chemicals with equal classification by the WHO, glyphosate is impossible to avoid. Every day we are exposed to glyphosate, without choice and without protection, in soils, water, food and even hygiene items produced on the basis of cotton. With the decision now adopted, the majority of this Parliament sacrifices the rights of all citizens to health and quality of life, once again deprecating environmental and social interests in relation to economic ones.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. I agree with Parliament's request to renew the marketing authorisation in the EU for only seven years, instead of the fifteen proposed ones, and exclusively for professional use. We believe that an independent assessment should also be carried out as well as the publication of the scientific evidence that led the European Food Safety Agency to give its favourable opinion on the authorisation, in the face of concerns about the effects of this product.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: In writing. Declared a "probable carcinogen" by the World Health Organization (WHO) in March 2015, glyphosate remains the world's best-selling herbicide. Present in more than 750 weedkillers, this dangerous product has recently been detected in 44% of European citizens who have never been in direct contact with the herbicide: it is simple, a good part of our food chain is contaminated.  Despite this, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) has deemed the carcinogenic risk of glyphosate "unlikely". But the studies used by the latter are "at best" sponsored by the agrochemical industry, at worst written by the latter. In the face of this risk, it is our responsibility to apply the precautionary principle and remove dangerous molecules from the market. Also, the very short-term urgency is to help producers using glyphosate by offering alternative solutions. This requires support based on both the use of the least dangerous products but above all on the development of biocontrols and a gradual change in production models.  I therefore voted against the text addressed to the Commission to reintroduce glyphosate to the market for 7 years.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I support a limited – 7 year not 15 as proposed by the Commission – extension of the approval of glyphosate, a widely used herbicide.  EFSA has declared it is unlikely to pose a carcinogenic hazard. IARC categorises it as probably carcinogenic – in the same category as red meat, lead compounds, frying emissions and biomass fuel. Properly used by trained operators the chemical can be safely used and assist conservation agriculture which seeks to be more climate and environmentally friendly. I also support continued research into alternative and effective herbicides and pesticides.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Glyphosate is a systemic, non-selective herbicide that destroys all plants. It is now the herbicide with the highest production volume in the world, its use has increased 260-fold in the last 40 years from 3,200 tons in 1974 to 825,000 tons in 2014. As a result of this massive use,"the presence of glyphosate and/or its residues has been found in water, soil, food, inedible products and the human body (particularly in urine and breast milk)". In March 2015, the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) classified glyphosate as "probably carcinogenic to humans" (Group 2A).  But in November 2015, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) ruled otherwise that it is unlikely to pose a human carcinogen. Strangely, EFSA has always refused to make these studies public, on the grounds that their publication would be detrimental to commercial interests. The resolution called for the publication of these studies and the non-renewal of the authorization of glyphosate. Unfortunately, the intrigues of the right have allowed an amendment authorizing glyphosate to pass for another 7 years. In these conditions I vote against it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. According to the International Cancer Research Centre, the product is "probably carcinogenic". The Commission has remained very evasive about its regulatory intentions on the subject, while the fight against antibiotic resistance is nevertheless a very recurring point in European regulation. We are in favour of financing alternative solutions for agriculture. There are none at the moment.  So I believe that we should not remain too radical in our position. Moreover, the basic text has been diverted from its original meaning. In the end, if I am in favour of the ban on glyphosate for individuals, I believe that, pending necessary solutions, it would be inappropriate to deprive farmers in difficult situations of glyphosate. As a result I voted against the objection to glyphosate.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the draft Implementing Regulation of the Commission renewing the approval of the active substance glyphosate, in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009 of the European Parliament and the Council on the placing of phytopharmaceutical products on the market. The European Food Safety Agency (EFSA) is the competent body of the European Union, responsible for independent scientific advice on food safety and possible risks in the food chain. EFSA has confirmed that glyphosate has no carcinogenic or mutagenic properties and has no toxic effect on fertility, reproduction or embryonic development. Therefore, and given that glyphosate represents a very important tool for the productivity and competitiveness of Portuguese agriculture, it is very important to renew the marketing license of glyphosate in the Community space for another 7 years.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I joined a majority in the European Parliament by voting in favour of a compromise on the controversial plant protection product glyphosate, dismissing the initial European Commission proposal calling for a renewal of another 15 years without substantial conditions. A much shorter period was needed.  While a temporary limited renewal was justified, above all, I voted for much stricter conditions that will prohibit or at least limit the use of glyphosate in the private sector and on public grounds.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – The licence for weed control glyphosate in Europe expires at the end of June. The Commission then put forward a proposal to grant a new 15-year authorisation for glyphosate after 1 July. The potentially adverse effects of the use of glyphosate have been the subject of heated discussions between the advocates and opponents of this weedkiller for many years. Opponents argue that exposure to glyphosate would be carcinogenic. Proponents rely on studies that show no harmful effects. In its proposal, the Commission relied on EFSA's findings, based on numerous scientific reports indicating that glyphosate is unlikely to be harmful to health. In a non-binding opinion to the Commission, a majority in the European Parliament asked for the authorisation period for glyphosate to be limited to 7 years. Personally, I welcome the Commission's original proposal, because the proposed deadline provides scope for sustainable and economically responsible innovation in crop protection.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – Glyphosate is a substance known mainly as an effective anti-weed agent. Under Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009, an active substance may be authorised only if it is not or is not to be classified as a category 1A or 1B carcinogen.
