The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) concluded that glyphosate is unlikely to pose a carcinogenic hazard to humans and the evidence does not support classification with regard to its carcinogenic potential under Regulation (EC) No 1272/2008. It should be recalled here that the criteria used by the IARC for Group 2A are comparable to those for category 1B, therefore glyphosate continues to pose a threat. There are also known concerns that glyphosate, in addition to its cancer-forming properties, disrupts the endocrine system. The decision to approve or not to approve glyphosate is very important, since if it is included among the approved substances, the population will be in contact with it directly and frequently, especially in close proximity to dwellings, for spraying, since glyphosate was commonly used in spraying with the intention of destroying different types of herbs. The protection of human, animal and environmental health comes first and decisions that may affect it in any way must be considered with caution and responsibility.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ Based on the fact of the WHO International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) classifying glyphosate as probably carcinogenic to humans after evaluating a large body of scientific, I believe that the Commission should not renew the approval of glyphosate and rapidly ensure an independent review of the classification of glyphosate based on all available scientific evidence relating to carcinogenicity of glyphosate as well as possible endocrine disruptive properties. Therefore, for the moment I fully support the objection to renew the approval of the active substance glyphosate for the maximum permissible period of 15 years.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Glyphosate is a non-selective herbicide, its global use has increased 260-fold in the last 40 years. The International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) classified glyphosate as a substance with a 'likely carcinogenic effect on humans' in March 2015, but according to a finalised assessment by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) in November 2015, 'glyphosate is unlikely to pose a carcinogenic risk to humans'.  The Commission proposes to approve glyphosate by 30 June 2031 in order to extend the approval of the active substance glyphosate under Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council on the placing of plant protection products on the market and to amend the Annex to Implementing Regulation (EU) No 540/2011 (hereinafter referred to as the "draft implementing regulation").  The Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety recommends that Parliament states that the draft implementing regulation does not ensure a high level of protection of human and animal health and the environment and goes beyond the implementing powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009.  It therefore requests the Commission to withdraw the draft implementing regulation and to submit a new draft which does not renew the approval of glyphosate. It also calls on the Commission and EFSA to publish without delay the scientific evidence on which the positive classification and proposed re-approval of glyphosate is based. I voted in favour of the draft resolution.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. This objection to the renewal of the glyphosate licence originally called for an end to its use on European territory. Glyphosate is a total weedkiller produced exclusively by Monsanto under the Roundup brand and first entered the public domain in 2000. It is considered "probably carcinogenic" by the National Cancer Research Centre, and its toxic effects are increased by the presence of co-formulants in commercial formulations containing it. Furthermore, the objection was based on the fact that glyphosate is considered an antibiotic and that the European Union was fighting against the massive use of antibiotics in the fight against antibiotic resistance. This objection also raised the point that the Commission had gone beyond its jurisdiction and that it had to respect the precautionary principle, which was also made by the European Ombudsman. All this is contrary to the precautionary principle with regard to the health of consumers and farmers, and transparency must remain an essential element for the use of plant protection products. We support the original text of the objection. However, since the amendments adopted in plenary have reversed the meaning of the request for objection, we are voting against the final text.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. While the UN International Cancer Research Centre (composed of some of the world's most renowned experts, and whose independence is guaranteed) had given an unfavourable opinion on glyphosate (considered probably carcinogenic), EFSA (a European agency whose impartiality is relative and whose opinion is based only on studies carried out by industrialists) has decided , to give the benefit of the doubt to the substance in question.  However, scientific studies show that glyphosate, which is part of Monsanto's Roundup, leads to an increase in rare cancers in exposed male rats, thereby eliminating random bias. The meta-studies carried out all conclude that the molecule is dangerous. Considering that this report is aimed at not renewing the authorisation of glyphosate and concerned with the precautionary principle, I have decided to vote for this text.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion to send a strong message that the precautionary principle must be strictly observed in the process of authorising chemical substances with direct impacts on humans and the environment. This is especially relevant in case of doubts as to whether glyphosate and its formulations are completely safe to use. This motion is not against a particular substance or product, but will ensure that a robust safety assessment process takes place and that Europeans are safe from any adverse impacts from chemical products.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this objection to the Commission's renewal of the approval of the active substance glyphosate. Glyphosate is a weedkiller pesticide widely used in agriculture, of which there is currently no economically viable substitute that guarantees human health. Research on the possible impact of glyphosate on ours must continue. That is why the resolution we voted on, balanced by amendments tabled by members of my EPP political group, calls on the Commission to renew the authorisation of glyphosate for 7 years instead of 15, while stressing that it is possible at any time to 'withdraw the approval of an active substance during the period during which it is authorised if it no longer meets the approval criteria'.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the considerable uncertainty about the wholesomeness of glyphosate, assessing the discrepancy in the judgments expressed by the European Food Safety Authority and the World Health Organisation agency responsible for research into melanomas and the reluctance of the European Food Safety Authority to make known the studies on the basis of its opinion, I welcome the hope that the European Commission will not renew , for a maximum of fifteen years, the marketing of this substance until its possible harmfulness to human health is excluded. The massive use of this type of herbicent in agricultural production and in the parks of our cities would pose, in the event of a proven harmfulness, a serious threat to the health of European citizens. Taking into account the restrictive and precautionary measures taken by some Member States and the opposition of some of them, in the Council of the European Union, I consider it essential that the European Commission postpones the decision on the extension of the marketing authorisation for glyphosate and that, in the meantime, it should carry out more in-depth studies on the effects of the substance on the environment and health. Finally, in order to ensure maximum institutional credibility, I hope that EFSI will avoid any further reservations about the publication of its studies.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. The resolution on glyphosate has been largely amended to meet the expectations of both citizens and the needs of our agricultural sector. Many farmers and wine growers now use glyphosate, especially as a weeding substance. However, the absence of an economically viable and safe alternative to human health requires us to be a force of proposal to achieve a safer framework for the use of glyphosate. It is important to remember that Parliament's testing procedure for substances has been followed, and as such the authorisation for the use of glyphosate is monitored and monitored. If new information in the future sheds new light on the use of glyphosate and its consequences, the European Commission may reconsider its authorisation. I would like to commend the excellent work of my colleague Angelique Delahaye, which has notably led to a reduction in the authorisation for the use of glyphosate to a maximum of seven years, as well as a better supervision of the use of the substance by encouraging the Commission and the Member States to provide a list of co-formulats to be banned. Although without legal consequences due to its act of execution, this resolution is part of the search for greater security in the use of glyphosate. So I voted for him.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that in such a situation it is important to make decisions on the basis of professional arguments, excluding the influence of politics and emotions. Glyphosate has long been very prevalent in agriculture, its substitution and alternatives are in question. For me, the safety and health of citizens is paramount, which is why I support initiatives calling for deeper research and monitoring of this substance.  However, I believe that the results currently available to us are not clear enough that it would be professionally acceptable to ban the substance, let alone the possible amenities of this for farmers. Banning glyphosate, which has been on the market for more than 40 years, could pose serious difficulties for the agricultural sector, particularly for small businesses and family businesses. I have therefore not been able to support a ban on the substance with my vote, but I am actively watching the results of new research and will be prepared to intervene in the event of a potential threat supported by relevant results.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ Glyphosate is a herbicide used by farmers to kill weeds without killing their crops and in 2007 it was the most used herbicide in the United States agricultural sector. I have voted for this report that will enable an independent review of the classification of glyphosate based on all available scientific evidence relating to its carcinogenic nature.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution because it asks the European Commission and the European Food Safety Authority to make public all the information they have on the active substance glyphosate. The possibility that this substance, widely used in agriculture, forestry and gardening, is carcinogenic. In this respect, I support the clarification and publication of this information of public interest, the testing of the presence of this substance in foodstuffs and the presentation of the results on the implications for human health.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the 'objections under Article 106 of the CRP: extension of the authorisation of the active substance glyphosate'. In order to take full account of the precautionary principle, glyphosate should be banned from the food chain. A health hazard caused by this plant killer cannot be completely ruled out.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted against Parliament's resolution that validates the renewal of the marketing authorization for glyphosate, an active substance found in herbicides (such as RoundUp) that is harmful to the environment and human health.  The European Parliament's resolution is shocking as it radically ignores the opinion of the scientific community and the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), which in March 2015 assessed the substance and classified it as "probably carcinogenic to humans".  The precautionary principle, enshrined in the European treaties, should oblige us to be cautious about the use of such substances, and I regret that the European Parliament is supporting the position of the industrial lobbies, which are profiting from its marketing at the expense of the health of European farmers and citizens.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. Glyphosate is a herbicide marketed by several agrochemical companies and used in fields, gardens and industrial areas. As has been discussed many times, reports published by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) and the WHO-dependent International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) are in contraposed, alerting the latter agency to the possible carcinogenic effect of glyphosate.  It should also be recalled that a number of scientific studies show evidence that glyphosate can act as an endocrine disruptor and that the European Commission has not yet complied with its obligations to regulat these substances.  In view of the lack of unity in the scientific criteria, I believe that it is best to appeal to the precautionary principle and therefore I have decided not to support the renewal of glyphosate.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – The use of the active substance glyphosate should not be extended. In particular, no scientific evidence has been provided that the substance does not present any unacceptable risk to human health, animal health or the environment. It should be noted that glyphosate is the main active ingredient used in many commercial herbicides. Therefore, it is very important to properly investigate its possible adverse effects on plants, animals and humans. It should be noted that there is growing concern about the increase in glyphosate levels in the animal and human food chain and in the organisms themselves. In this context, Member States should restrict or prohibit the sale of glyphosate to non-professional users. I believe that the Commission should withdraw its draft implementing regulation and submit a new draft to the committee.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The JRC voted against the resolution on the renewal of the licence of glyphosate, an active substance herbicide, widely used in agriculture, crops, etc. and produced and marketed mainly by the monopoly of "Mosado".  The World Health Organization recently classified glyphozeit as a category of "potential carcinogens for humans". Nevertheless, the Commission decided to continue its authorisation, while the European Parliament, by voting in favour of the Amendments of the People's Party and the resolution, approved it for another seven years. Since the opinion of the European Parliament is not binding, it paves the way for the renewal of its licence for 15 years, as provided for in the relevant Commission implementing regulation.  It should be noted that other herbicides and pesticides with similar or worse effects are marketed. The whole debate that the EU and monopolies are involved in is part of fierce competition between business groups. It turns out that they do not hesitate to sacrifice even the health of workers for the profits of business groups. This economy and the power of the people to target them so that they can, by socialising monopolies and freeing themselves from the EU, produce themselves and enjoy cheap, healthy products with environmental protection.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ There have been suggestions that the popular herbicide glyphosate could be carcinogenic – although it has been in widespread use for decades with no evidence of harm, and a number of studies find that used properly it represents no threat to human health. Banning glyphosate would substantially increase farmers’ costs, and could result in the use of other herbicides which may even be less safe than glyphosate. It would also require more cultivation and use of tractors, resulting in increased emissions.  And after all that, we should still be importing cheaper foreign food products that had been grown with the benefit of glyphosate. UKIP does not support a ban given the very limited evidence of harm, but would support further research.  We also believe that this decision should be made for the UK in the British parliament, not imposed from Brussels.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 With regard to the Commission's draft implementing regulation renewing the approval of glyphosate, I voted in favour because some data have shown that this substance, although it has increased in its use in recent years, could pose a danger to the health of people living near the places where glyphosate is used. Furthermore, it is not possible to say with certainty to date that glyphosate residues do not pose a danger to human health, as well as to animals and the environment. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. - I did not support the resolution proposing to extend the authorisation of the use of glisofate for a further 7 years because health comes first for me. Since I got over cancer, my guide is "Health First." Research by the International Agency for Research on Cancer has found a sufficient association of glyphosate with cancer, and there are other studies linking it to adverse consequences for the human hormonal and nervous system, and that is sufficient for me. Otherwise, I supported amendments that contain more restrictions on the ways and places of use, greater control over product sales and better monitoring of health and environmental impacts and for more education for users, and were also voted on. I expect the European Commission to take them into account when preparing the updated proposal for the re-approval of glyphosate.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I voted against the decision to grant an extension of the glyphosate period to seven years because I do not think it is a reasonable and optimal solution. In relation to the Commission proposal, this is a shift, but not sufficient, as research linking glyphosate in relation to increased B-cell lymphoma diseases in farmers has not been taken into account, nor the fact that the International Agency for Research on Cancer has included glyphosate in the category of substances likely to be carcinogenic. EFSA has not included glyphosate in potentially carcinogenic substances, and herbicide manufacturers also deny its carcinogenicity. Given such conflicting attitudes, but also the fact that glyphosate is used in hard-hit agriculture and that farmers fear its ban, the need to conduct targeted research has opened up.  According to experts, research into the health impact of glyphosate, and within the framework of the identified risk, can be carried out within a year, while research and development of a new product takes several years. The extension of the glyphosate use period should have followed this framework and my view was that it should be limited to a period of one to three years after which a final decision on its use or prohibition would be taken upon conducting this targeted survey.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The International Agency for Research on Cancer described glyphosate as a "probably carcinogenic" product, a caution not shared by EFSA, the European food safety agency. The risks of glyphosate are established in particular in its commercial formulations whose toxicity is increased by the presence of co-formulants. Glyphosate is also considered an antibiotic and a patent is even filed for such use.  However, the fight against antibiotic resistance and the massive use of antibiotics is a recurring topic in European regulations. The European Commission has proposed to postpone the publication of the list of banned adjuvants to an indefinite date. At the same time, it manages to be in a hurry and to remain evasive in its regulatory intentions. This paradox is also contrary to the precautionary principle with regard to the health of consumers and farmers.  Transparency remains an essential element in regulating and framing agricultural practices and the use of plant protection products. Instead, I am asking for funding for alternative solutions for agriculture. Unfortunately, the amendments I supported were not accepted by the other Members. So I finally vote against this text.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Glyphosate is an indiscriminate herbicide that works by influencing the so-called chicimate pathway, a pathway that is also present in algae, bacteria and fungi. The population is exposed primarily if it lives near sprayed areas, through domestic use and through food. The effect of glyphosate on human health should not be underestimated. A number of Member States have already taken precautions to protect public health and the environment.  As clear and legally binding conditions should be set at Union level in the event of authorisation of an active substance with a view to achieving an equal level of protection in all Member States, I call on the Commission to give its Food and Veterinary Office a mandate to examine and monitor glyphosate residues in food and drink produced in the Union, but also in imported products.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. The results of research on the toxicity of glyphosate on the classification of the carcinogenic potential of this substance in humans by the European Food Safety Authority are contradictory to the conclusion of the World Health Organisation Agency for Cancer Research. There is evidence of the high long-term risk, whatever its use, for non-target terrestrial vertebrates, including mammals and birds. The use of this non-selective herbicide promotes the indiscriminate elimination of plants, as well as algae, bacteria and fungi, which corresponds to a significant negative impact on biodiversity and the ecosystem. Nevertheless, the European Commission proposes to authorise the use of glyphosate by 2031, the maximum possible period for any use, without any restrictions (with the exception of one of the more than 500 co-formulants), only subject to confirmatory information on endocrine disrupting properties.  The European Commission's proposal not only does not guarantee, but also the desirable high level of protection of human and animal health and the environment, and chooses not to apply the precautionary principle. We therefore advocate the non-renewal of glyphosate approval and the establishment of a timetable for the creation of a list of non-accepted co-formulants for inclusion in plant protection products.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒I support the report of colleagues Pavel Poc, Kateřina Koneka, Bas Eickhout, Piernicole Pedicini, Mark Demesmaeker, Sirpa Pietikäinen and Frédérique Ries on the Commission's draft implementing regulation on extending the approval of the active substance glyphosate. As march 2015 was the first year in which The Hague tribunal sentenced him to 10 years in prison, the The International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) classified glyphosate as a substance that "probably causes cancer in humans" and 76% of the use of glyphosate is agricultural, I believe it is justified to call on the Commission not to extend the approval of glyphosate. Furthermore, the use of glyphosate herbicides kills not only unwanted weeds, but also all herbs and algae, bacteria and fungi, thereby risking biodiversity and ecosystem. The extension of the authorisation of active substances shall be valid for a maximum period of 15 years. Consequently, all available scientific evidence suggesting a link between cancer and glyphosate should be reviewed.  By refusing to publish all scientific studies on the use of glyphosate, we question human, animal and environmental health. Citizens of the Republic of Croatia are also witnesses of the pervasive illness of malignancies, so although publishing studies would potentially harm the commercial interests of manufacturers, it is our duty to protect them.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. – There has been a fierce dispute over glyphosate in Europe for months. This herbicide is used not only to control weeds, but also, for example, to dry rapeseed, corn, sunflower, cereals and other agricultural crops before harvesting. Research from 2013 showed that up to 60% of the Czech population has glyphosate in their urine. We must therefore take scientific studies that show that this substance is probably carcinogenic, very seriously. The objection, which was approved by the European Parliament this week, will have the impact that glyphosate-containing products will cease to be used near public playgrounds and parks or in gardens and gardens. The authorisation for its use will then have to be renewed every seven years compared to the original 15 years proposed by the Commission. Even so, the result certainly cannot be considered a massive success, because the changes are not sufficient. I would, of course, like to see substances such as glyphosate, for which there is more than a legitimate concern for the health of the citizens of the European Union, simply withdrawn from the market. Thanks in particular to the PPE Group's amendments, some of the original proposals have not been enforced, and I can only speculate on whether the softening of the original text by the PPE was due to persuasion by the agrotechnical giant Monsanto, whose flagship product Roundup contains this most wide-used pesticide. However, as Social Democrats, we must not leave the battlefield when it comes to the health of our people.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. The issue of renewing the licence for the active substance glyphosate has been the subject of much debate. On the one hand, legitimate concerns have led to an understanding of the carcinogenic and endocrine disruptor nature of glyphosate. On the other hand, it is clear that many European farmers use glyphosate, a herbicide commonly used in large crops, viticulture or arboriculture. Today, there is no economically viable and safe alternative for farmers.  For these reasons, I have called on the European Commission to renew its authorisation on the market for a period of only seven years, instead of the 15 years initially proposed, and only for professional purposes. Also, an independent study and publication of the scientific evidence used by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) to assess glyphosate will have to be carried out.

name: Carolina PUNSET
text: in writing. – The non-renewal of the extension of the use of herbicide glyphosate is due to the criterion of prudence, when there is evidence that this substance is a possible carcinogenic agent in humans and convincing evidence of being a carcinogenic agent in animals, according to the WHO-dependent International Cancer Research Centre (IARC). In addition, there is demonstrated evidence of the damage caused to pollinators and the fact that ESFA (European Food Health Authority) has not been able to rule out the effects as an endocrine disruptor of this substance, are more than sufficient reasons to apply caution and not renew its use any longer. 39.5% of MEPs (262) followed this criterion in the Strasbourg vote on 13 April against 387 and 15 abstentions.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ There have been suggestions that the popular herbicide glyphosate could be carcinogenic – although it has been in widespread use for decades with no evidence of harm, and a number of studies find that used properly it represents no threat to human health. Banning glyphosate would substantially increase farmers’ costs, and could result in the use of other herbicides which may even be less safe than glyphosate. It would also require more cultivation and use of tractors, resulting in increased emissions.  And after all that, we should still be importing cheaper foreign food products that had been grown with the benefit of glyphosate. UKIP does not support a ban given the very limited evidence of harm, but would support further research.  We also believe that this decision should be made for the UK in the British parliament, not imposed from Brussels.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I supported the resolution opposing the Commission's proposal for a 15-year renewal of the authorisation of glyphosate and asking it to table a new text, based on a much shorter authorisation period.   There are real uncertainties about this product, including its effects on human, animal and environmental health. Our public opinion is concerned. Member States have differing views. So are the scientists. In doubt as to whether or not this substance was carcinogenic, it was essential that the Commission review its copy. She can't act like nothing happened and propose a new authorization of 15-year-old glyphosate! I would have preferred a shorter period, of 2 years or even 5 years maximum. But I supported Parliament's position first because 7 years is already better than 15 years and we exclude non-professional uses; secondly, because we will be vigilant and a withdrawal of approval remains possible during the period and finally, because we need to give our agricultural systems a transition period to put in place alternative products and methods.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 It is a herbicide widely used in Portugal (in agriculture and by the Chambers in gardens and roads). The opinions of the experts are many and contradictory.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. Glyphosate is an active chemical widely used in a number of pesticide products and is subject to strict regulation in Europe. Regulation 1141/2010 lays down the procedure for the renewal of active substances belonging to Group II referred to in Directive 91/414/EEC. This list includes the active substance glyphosate.  In March 2015, the International Agency of the World Health Organization for Research against Cancer (IARC) concluded that glyphosate was "probably carcinogenic to humans", while the official EU risk assessment, carried out by EFSA, reached the opposite conclusion, referring to three studies whose results industry has not made public for free scientific scrutiny. There are also doubts as to its action as an endocrine disruptor. In view of this context and given the current state of the art, it is not appropriate to renew the approval of glyphosate for the maximum possible period of fifteen years and, therefore, I voted in favour of a renewal for the minimum period, consistent with the precautionary principle.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The European Commission's proposal to renew the approval of glyphosate (a substance included in round up) for 15 years was not acceptable due to concerns about its use in the composition of agricultural and household products.  The European Parliament's Committee on the Environment and Public Health had seized on this and part of the scientific community had highlighted probable health risks when using products - widespread - containing glyphosate. Today, during the plenary vote in Strasbourg, this objection was not accepted and I regret it: a majority of MEPs supported a seven-year renewal agreement while I personally opposed it.  In fact, in my view, by granting this 'half-white-seing' to the Commission, the European Parliament is sending the wrong signal. It is now up to the Commission and then the States to take into account the reluctance expressed and I will continue to advocate for a reformulation of the proposal taking into account the potential dangerousness of this substance, while allowing a sustainable transition for farmers and economically and environmentally responsible alternative products.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which aims to significantly strengthen the use of glyphosate in the European Union. I share the view expressed by Members that Member States must, in particular, restrict or prohibit the sale of glyphosate to non-professional users, prohibit its use before harvesting, and prevent it from spraying near parks and playgrounds. It is important that the report notes the need for training to present how glyphosate is needed in safer ways. Alternative measures could also be provided during the training. I would like to believe that the European Commission will draw attention to Parliament's position and not extend the authorisation of glyphosate for a period of 15 years. This term must be much shorter and used for alternatives to search, research and education.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this European Parliament resolution approving the renewal of the licence for the use of glyphosate, exclusively for professional uses for another 7 years, instead of the 15 years originally envisaged. It was based on a study by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) which states that glyphosate is "unlikely to have a carcinogenic risk to humans". However, given the doubts raised by other studies, I strongly support the European Parliament's request by this resolution to the European Commission to make public, from now on, all the scientific evidence that led to this positive classification of glyphosate by EFSA.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The EPP, together with a large majority in Parliament, has reached an important compromise between the demands of agricultural production and those of health and environmental protection. With this vote, the Commission was asked to present a new draft for the renewal of the authorisation for the use of glyphosate, taking into account some fundamental changes. The GROUP of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats did not reject this authorisation ideologically, but instead stood out by rejecting those amendments which proposed an absolute ban on the use of this substance for agricultural use and for professionals, voting in favour of a reduced authorisation from 15 to 7 years, which could be revoked and monitored. As the protection of health and the environment cannot be overlooked, Parliament called on the Commission to review the classification of glyphosate, based on independent scientific studies, and called for the full dissemination of the scientific data used in the evaluation. By voting for this report on a point which is difficult to reach agreement between the Member States, Parliament is showing its strength and representative weight, indicating a political line to the Commission's action and offering the European Council a position to which it can refer.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted against it since the amendments adopted do not reflect the outcome of the discussions we have had in the Commission. It is irresponsible to call for the renewal of glyphosate for seven years. We call on the competent authorities to apply the precautionary principle to the World Health Organization (WHO) report, which determined that glyphosate is "probably carcinogenic to humans". However, there is plenty of reason to think that EFSA (European Food Safety Agency), whose study reached conclusions contrary to WHO's, is not entirely independent and we must therefore question its recommendations. We cannot allow such a substance, which is used as a herbicide for our fields, to be marketed in Europe and ends up in the food we eat.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. ‒ The European Food Safety Authority and an agency of the World Health Organisation have drawn contrasting conclusions about the possible harmful effects of glyphosate. This shows that further investigation is necessary before the substance is authorised for another 15 years. It is not unusual that scientific bodies disagree, but such a profound difference between agencies of this stature cannot be ignored by the Commission. It is appropriate to conduct a thorough review of glyphosate and its classification, and also to consider whether EU level authorisation of the active substance and then separate, national authorisation for herbicide and pesticide products is really the best way to ensure the highest standards of health and safety.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the compromise on the continued use of the plant protection product glyphosate. A time-limited permit with clear conditions that is valid throughout Europe helps farmers and consumers.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: Written. I have voted in favour of this resolution because it opens the way for the continued but prudent and responsible acceptance of glyphosate. The EU Food Safety Authority EFSA has come to the established conclusion that glyphosate, the active substance in plant protection products used in many EU countries, is unlikely to pose a cancer risk. The approval of glyphosate is now extended for seven years and would be reassessed in the event that EFSA would reach other scientifically based conclusions.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. This report contains positive aspects such as that it is critical of authorisation procedures, the impact of glyphosate on fauna and flora and the residues detected. Older it recommends not to use glyphosate for non-professional uses, not to use it in gardens, public parks or playing fields or in cases where pest management systems are sufficient. I have still voted against it because instead of recommending the absolute ban on all products containing glyphosate, it proposes a renewal of its use for seven more years.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favor of continuing the authorization of the use of glyphosate. Scientific evidence on carcinogenic effects and as an endocrine disruptor is not consistent. Glyphosate has the seal of the European Food Safety Autorithy. Yes, the arguments of agricultural and habitat conservation and biodiversity organisations seem to me to be consistent, in particular with regard to the countries of southern Europe, which are more exposed to invasive species.  A ban on the use of this product would entail serious damage to our agriculture and to the success of conservation actions under the Birds Directive and the Habitats Directive. Like any product, handling is conditioned by rules that serve to ensure that there are no risks to the population and the environment.  Precautionary principle, as a precautionary principle, I prefer to apply it in favour of the conservation of species and habitats where glyphosate has proven to be a unique and useful weapon, which has passed the negative impact tests conducted on the basis of monitoring programmes, which I believe to be rigorous.  I fear that, in addition to the negative impact on agriculture, a ban on the use of glyphosate would waste years of good conservation practices and habitat restoration.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Glyphosate is one of the most widely used by European farmers, foresters and herbicides, for which it is currently difficult to find an alternative.  On the other hand, there are voices about the possible carcinogenicity of this substance, but there is no clear evidence. It is therefore good that parliament's resolution today, thanks to the efforts of our group, the Group of the European People's Party, has become more balanced than in the initial version. On the one hand, we have called for the approval of glyphosate to be renewed for 7 years, not 15, as proposed by the European Commission, but provided that it is used only for professional use, and at the same time a request to the relevant authorities to re-examine the matter. Let us hope that the final decision on the approval of glyphosate will take due account of the fact that the possible withdrawal of this active substance from the market will cause serious disturbances in European agriculture, which could jeopardise the competitiveness of our production in relation to third countries that do not plan to do so.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I have supported this motion of objection pursuant to Rule 106 regarding the renewal of the approval of the active substance glyphosate, just as my Socialist colleagues did when they voted in the ENVI Committee. The Labour Party in the European Parliament holds the position that Genetically Modified Organisms – GMOs – must be approached with caution and assessed from the point of view of their impacts on human health and the environment. This position has informed a number of recent plenary votes when I and other Labour Party MEPs opposed the authorisation of other strains of GMOs; this is, inter alia, because of their links with glyphosate..  Although not binding, I hope that the vote today will send a message to the Commission and have them either reconsider their position, or disclose the scientific evidence that has been the basis for the positive classification of this chemical, a matter which I have brought up with them in a recent parliamentary question.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 The systematic herbicide glyphosate is currently produced in the largest volume of all herbicides worldwide. In doing so, it has been shown that some bacteria that are part of commercial glyphosate preparations have caused a change in antibiotic resistance, with glyphosate residues recorded in water, soil, food or even breast milk. For this reason, I voted in favour of adopting a resolution rejecting the extension of the authorisation for glyphosate for a further 15 years, while at the same time calling on the European Commission not to authorize any unprofessional use of glyphosate.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I abstained for this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Glyphosate herbicide is currently produced in the largest volume of all herbicides worldwide and its use has increased dramatically worldwide over the last 40 years by a factor of 260 from 3200 tonnes in 1974 to 825 thousand tonnes in 2014. Glyphosate is a non-selective herbicide that kills all herbs, and up to 76% worldwide is used in agriculture, but it is also used in forestry, cities and gardens. Also for this reason, glyphosate and its residues have been recorded in water, soil, food, beverages and goods not intended for consumption, but also in the human body. For these reasons, we have also called on the Commission, by resolution, to come forward with a new proposal to extend the authorisation for glyphosate in order to take better account of the sustainable use of the herbicides containing it. At the same time, we requested the prompt initiation of a review of the overall toxicity and classification of the problematic herbicide on the basis of all available scientific evidence on its carcinogenicity and possible endocrine disrupting properties. We also called on the Commission to renew the authorisation to sell products containing glyphosate for only seven years, even for professional use only.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament resolution on glyphosate in the form to which it was amended by the proposals of my PPE faction. We know that in the past year the safety of glyphosate used mainly for herbicides has been investigated by both the International Agency for Research on Cancer and the European Food Safety Authority. These institutions have achieved different results and therefore this matter should be addressed, also in the light of the precautionary principle. It should also be noted that the European Food Safety Authority, which did not find a danger to human health in glyphosate, has been subject to public debate with the help of EXPERTS from EU countries. In view of the above circumstances, and also in view of the opinion of the Czech Ministry of Agriculture, I consider it right to reach a compromise solution, i.e. not to ban glyphosate altogether, but to exercise more control over its use in order to maintain precautions. The European Parliament proposes to limit the use of glyphosate only to professionals who should be provided with the necessary information, as well as to subject the use of glyphosate immediately before harvesting to strict restrictions. I also voted in favour of reducing the period by which the possibility of taking glyphosate should be extended to 7 years.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The public discusses conflicting scientific aspects of the various assessments regarding the carcinogenicity of glyphosate and the fact that glyphosate causes endocrine disorders. For the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), glyphosate is a substance that is 'probably carcinogenic to humans'. The world currently produces the most systemic herbicide glyphosate. Its use has increased drastically (by 260 times) in the last 40 years. 76% of glyphosate worldwide is used in agriculture, as well as in forestry and in urban and horticultural use. The European Commission has proposed renewing the approval of glyphosate for the next 15 years. However, the motion for a resolution adopted by envi calls on the Commission to reconsider its proposal. Glyphosate could seriously damage our health, but it can also endanger animals and plants, so it is important that it does not occur privately, unjustified use of glyphosate and that it is not used in public parks, playgrounds, gardens or in their vicinity. In the case of pre-existing alternatives to weed control, the use of glyphosate should be strictly prohibited. There was no complete rejection of the use of glyphosate in the motion for a resolution, which is why I abstained in the vote.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. \u2012 Currently, the most systematic herbicide glyphosate is produced in the world of all herbicides, the use of which has increased drastically in the last 40 years. Glyphosate is an indiscriminate herbicide, which means that it destroys all plants and its remains are found in water, soil, food and drink, as well as in the human body.  Also, the impact of glyphosate on the environment as well as on human and animal health is unquestionable. The European Parliament considers that the Commission's draft implementing regulation does not apply the precautionary principle and does not provide a high level of protection of human and animal health and environmental protection. In view of these shortcomings, the European Parliament asks the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing regulation and submit a new one to the committee.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ Glyphosate, which came on the market in 1974, is the most widespread herbicide in the world that can reach our organism through the food we consume, which is not familiar to a large number of people. The BRITISH Food Safety Authority estimated that a third of the bread was contaminated with traces of glysophate.  Likewise, the Americans claim that 90% of the soybeans they produce are contaminated with glyphosate, and the Germans say that every other beer is contaminated with said herbicide. A German survey in 18 European countries found that the presence of glyphosate-based toxic herbicides in urine has 44% of Europeans. The presence of traces of glyphosate in our bodies is worrying because this herbicide is associated with a number of health problems, from metabolic problems, liver and kidney diseases, to cancer.  The World Health Organisation considers glyphosate to be "probably carcinogenic to humans", while the European Food Safety Agency considers it unlikely that glyphosate is carcinogenic to humans. I accepted an amendment extending the use of glyphosate for a maximum of seven years, so I supported such an objection.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the proposal as I do not share the criticism of the approval of glyphosate, which, moreover, is based on a number of factually incorrect claims.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the draft Commission implementing regulation renewing the approval of the active substance glyphosate in accordance with the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the placing of plant protection products on the market and amending the Annex to the implementing Regulation. The Commission should withdraw the draft implementing Regulation and submit a new draft, nor should it extend the authorisation of glyphosate and should set a clear deadline within which it will draw up a list of additives not authorised for inclusion in plant protection products. This is needed because of serious concerns that the herbicide glyphosate, which is otherwise widely used in agriculture, is carcinogenic and causes endocrine disorders.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. ‒ As a firm proponent of evidence-based policy-making in the regulation of agricultural technologies, I welcome Parliament’s decision to reject calls to ban glyphosate. The authorisations of active substances are based on the scientific evaluation of a rapporteur Member State and EFSA. This process views glyphosate to be safe, when used appropriately, and concludes that glyphosate is not carcinogenic. Ignoring this advice would set a dangerous precedent and undermine the EU’s entire risk assessment system. However, I still consider that the basis for this objection resolution remains fundamentally flawed. It is incorrect to argue that the Commission’s implementing measure fails to ensure a high level of protection and is incompatible with Regulation 1107/2009. All active substances authorised for use undergo a comprehensive assessment to ensure they pose no unacceptable risk. Moreover, the resolution misuses the precautionary principle, dismisses the existing regulatory framework for the sustainable use of pesticides and attempts to forge a link between glyphosate and potential endocrine disrupting properties, despite both EFSA and the USEPA concluding that there is no evidence of such effect.  For these reasons I cannot support the resolution.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Pesticides must be used with respect for the environment, but much more in the light of consumer health and the protection of human life.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 A number of worrying research findings have been published on the carcinogenic effects of a pesticide called glyphosate and special attention should therefore be paid to the extension of the EU authorisation for the active substance. Currently, of all herbicides, glyphosate is the most popular drug in the world, whose global use has increased dramatically over the past 40 years. The problem is that in many Member States, from large-scale agricultural production to forestry and hobby gardening, almost anyone can use this plant protection product without proper qualifications or restrictions on use. In my opinion, the compromise offered by the PpE Group is capable of strikeing the right balance between the concerns of European citizens and the legitimate interests of agricultural operators. According to the amendment adopted, the European Commission should only renew the marketing authorisation for glyphosate for 7 years instead of 15, subject to strict restrictions on professional qualifications. In parallel, it should ensure that the toxicity of glyphosate is independently reviewed for its carcinogenic effects and its properties in relation to substances that disrupt hormone balance. It should be noted that the authorisation may be withdrawn at any time if new evidence of the safety of the product emerges in the meantime.  The incorporation of all these guarantees could also lead to the sustainable use of glyphosate in Europe, which is already common practice in Hungary.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which deals with a European Commission proposal on a multi-active substance. One element of this is glyphosate, the use of which is very serious. The motion for a resolution calls on the Commission to review the draft regulation and to submit a new one instead. According to the explanatory memorandum, due to the contradictory results of IARC and EFSA and the further investigation by ECHA, the effects of glyphosate on human and animal organisms have not been demonstrated at this time.  I support not extending the authorisation of glyphosate for another 15 years from July this year. I think it is important, in the interests of animal and public health, that controversial opinions be clarified first. I would add that this difference in theoretical approach has already been raised on several points in the TTIP negotiations: everything can be marketed in the US until it can be scientifically proven that the product is harmful; the EU, on the other hand, is already taking action if there is a suspicion.   In my opinion, there is no industrial interest that can override our commitment to health. Residue levels have already increased significantly, while resistance to glyphosate has also increased significantly among weeds. Alternative solutions should therefore be found and innovation encouraged. The European Union spent more than EUR 100 million researching alternative methods between 2007 and 2013 and will continue to support this in this financial cycle.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In recent months, Europe has been run by reports of a controversial chemical called glyphosate, which is widely used as an ingredient in plant protection products. Recent studies have shown that this substance is intended to pose a real health risk and increase the risk of cancer in humans and animals. Nevertheless, the European Commission has proposed renewing the approval of this substance for the next 15 years. In many countries, the use of glyphosate is still possible, while in others this substance is completely prohibited. Given the existence of a single market and an unrestricted exchange of goods, it is important for the Union to have a unified position on this issue, which is why it is right for the European Parliament to respond by calling on the European Commission to reconsider or withdraw its decision on the renewal of the approval of this substance. The Union's objective should be to ensure a high level of protection of human and animal health and the environment and to improve the functioning of the internal market, which is why I have chosen to vote in favour of Parliament's resolution calling for immediate action by the Commission to ensure that these objectives are met.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: Written. \u2012 I voted against the motion for a resolution, namely in favour of continued use of glyphosate, as proposed by the Commission, because, according to EFSA, the use of glyphosate is still safe and I trust this authority. It is also clear that EFSA's investigations cannot be entirely public, as it also receives market-relevant information directly from companies. Instead, all scientific research must be transparent. I would also point out that EU imported cereals use glyphosate and therefore its ban would put the EU in a special position on the world market. On the other hand, there has been no condational impact assessment on the rapid transition to alternative substances from the point of view of food safety and health effects. The use of glyphosate enables direct sowing, which prevents climate change and also reduces production costs, taking into account that farmers are already in a difficult situation. On the other hand, the use of glyphosate in non-professional activities should be studied and critically examined.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this resolution, which I consider shamefully hypocritical. Most of the premises are actually fully acceptable: they point out that glyphosate herbication is a pervasive chemical (it is present in the food chain and in our bodies), which has been declared 'probably carcinogenic to humans' by the IARC but which has been deemed safe by EFSA which is based on information contained in studies that are not made public because glyphosate producers believe this would harm their commercial interests. These premises and the precautionary principle, which has also been mentioned several times in the resolution, have only one possible logical consequence: the request to the European Commission not to renew the authorisation to use glyphosate. On the other hand, the resolution, in the face of logic, explicitly calls for the authorisation to be renewed. It's just outrageous. Hence my No. I hope, however, that the European Commission will put into practice two minor demands contained in the resolution: the independent review of all scientific literature on glyphosate toxicity (meaning: review of EFSA's assessment) and the publication of secret studies used by EFSA to declare glyphosate safe.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this objection because the existing evidence of the effects of the use of glyphosate is contradictory. We have, on the one hand, studies proving that this substance is carcinogenic and, on the other hand, EFSA's decision removing any negative accusation as to how glyphosate works. We need scientific evidence, independent studies that will test this substance and clarify the impact of its use on human health. Given this unclear situation, but also pending a conclusive analysis, the Commission should renew the authorisation for glyphosate for a limited period of 7 years, instead of 15, as originally envisaged.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ Glyphosate is an active substance widely used in herbicides. The approval of the active substance glyphosate in the EU expires on 30 June 2016. The draft measure subject to this objection renews the approval of the active substance glyphosate for the maximum permissible period of 15 years. The WHO International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) classifies glyphosate as probably carcinogenic to humans after evaluating a large body of scientific evidence. Moreover, there are serious doubts as regards possible mode of action in relation to the endocrine disrupting properties of glyphosate. The objection also fails to ensure a high level of protection of both human and animal health and the environment, fails to apply the precautionary principle, and is therefore not compatible with the aim and the content of the basic instrument. Based on this, I do not support the renewal of the approval of glyphosate. I believe the Commission should rapidly ensure an independent review of the classification of glyphosate based on all available scientific evidence relating to carcinogenicity of glyphosate as well as possible endocrine disruptive properties.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I do not consider an EU-wide ban on glyphosate necessary as I believe the regular evaluation process is transparent, follows standard rules and is subject to scrutiny by member states, independent institutions as well as the people, and that it has sufficient safe checks. I therefore voted against the European Parliament resolution. I believe that questioning EFSA science based evaluation put the credibility of the existing procedures into question.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. The report by the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), the agency of the World Health Organization (WHO), considers glyphosate to be a "probable carcinogen for humans and animals". Thus, in addition to an environmental problem, the renewal of this substance is also a real public health problem.  While the United States has taken the decision to ban this endocrine disruptor, applying the precautionary principle, it is incomprehensible that the European Union should not do the same.  On 22 March, the European Parliament's Environment Committee adopted a resolution to prevent the European Commission from renewing the authorization to use and sell weedkiller.  This objection to the European Commission, which is subject to the plenary vote, was voted on but under pressure from the lobbies, right-wing groups chose to reintroduce an authorisation for 7 years, less than the 15 years provided by the Commission, but too much in the eyes of the victims of this poison.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Experts have been warning for years about the harmfulness of glyphosate, the most widespread herbicide in the world whose use has grown greatly in the past 40 years. Glyphosate is the most widely used agricultural chemical used in almost all herbicides. Given that glyphosate and its remains were found in water, soil, food and drink and inedible products and the human body, I think it is necessary to pay greater attention to its effects on human health. The World Health Organization argues that glyphosate probably has carcinogenic potential and has qualified it as a cancer-causing substance in humans, while the European Food Safety Agency argues that glyphosate poses no danger to humans due to carcinogenic potential. Although the two mentioned organizations have opposing views, I believe that there needs to be a high level of protection, both in human and animal health and the environment, and I voted not to extend the approval of glyphosate.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. - Objection under Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure: extension of the approval of the active substance glyphosate, as well as the overwhelming majority of the European Parliament, which today voted in favour of the controversial plant protection in relation to glyphosate. MePs have rejected the European Commission's original proposal, which requires renewal within a period of another 15 years without any significant conditions. In addition, MEPs want to ban, or at least restrict, the use of glyphosate in the private sector and in the field of public use, as well as any additives in the poe-tallowamine formulation that the Commission intends to ban and withdraw from the market.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ Glyphosate is a herbicide placed on the market by several agrochemical companies. In my constituencies I have several agriculture producers who experienced negatives aspects of using various pesticides in nature and their effects on bees for example. In my voting list I applied a line in favour of the precautionary principle and at least halt the re-authorisation procedure until there is further clarity given the disagreements between major groups of respected scientists (IARC v. EFSA) considering also cumulative and combinatory effects as well as unpublished studies.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 Glyphosate is one of the best-selling herbicide pesticides in the world. This substance has been on the market since 1974 and currently occupies 25% of the world pesticide market. In 2014, 825 million tonnes of glyphosate were used globally, 90% of which were used in agriculture. It is also used to control the growth of uncultivated herbaceous plants in gardens or in uncultivated areas. In a study by the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), it classified glyphosate as "probably carcinogenic to humans", despite other assessments by suprastate institutes and national regulatory agencies that glyphosate is not carcinogenic. Moreover, until now, it is not known what was the basis of the IARC assessment, since their monograph has not been published. The European Parliament's motion for a resolution refers in particular to the precautionary principle and the need to ensure a high level of health and environmental protection. Furthermore, it proposes an extension of the authorisation for a maximum period of 7 years, the time required to carry out the studies. I therefore voted in favour of the Objection on the renewal of approval.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The International Agency for Research on Cancer classified glyphosate as a substance with a "likely carcinogenic effect on humans". Of all herbicides, systemic glyphosate herbicide has the highest global production volume; has increased dramatically – 260 times – in the last 40 years. I voted in favour of this document.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted against it since the amendments adopted do not reflect the outcome of the discussions we have had in the Commission. It is irresponsible to call for the renewal of glyphosate for seven years. We call on the competent authorities to apply the precautionary principle to the World Health Organization (WHO) report, which determined that glyphosate is "probably carcinogenic to humans". However, there is plenty of reason to think that EFSA (European Food Safety Agency), whose study reached conclusions contrary to WHO's, is not entirely independent and we must therefore question its recommendations. We cannot allow such a substance, which is used as a herbicide for our fields, to be marketed in Europe and ends up in the food we eat.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution where the European Parliament is setting out its position on a proposal by the Commission to reapprove the controversial toxic substance glyphosate for use in Europe. The resolution was approved. I would have preferred if MEPs had followed the recommendation of Parliament’s Environment Committee in clearly calling for an outright rejection of the re-approval of glyphosate.  But we had some positive results, since the European Parliament highlighted serious concerns with the proposal, notably calling for significantly restricting the uses for which glyphosate could be approved.

name: Inese VAIDERE
text: Writing. – A Study by the World Health Organisation shows that glyphosate can potentially cause cancer. The numbers are dramatic. The use of this agricultural chemical in the world has increased 260 times in the last 40 years. Glyphosate is one of europe's most used weed-destroying products, or herbicides. The most well-known is the round. Farmers are increasingly using the round to make it easier to prepare fields for the coming season, destroy weeds or speed up grain drying. In the plants after their harvesting, there remain round-the-foot traces. Everyday, by eating flour-making oat flakes, bread, cookies and other products, we take a round. A few years ago, a study showed that the level of glyphosate in the urine of the Latvian population is one of the highest in Europe. At the same time, concerns are growing about the effects of glyphosate on the hormonal system and the reproductive system, as well as its effects on pregnancy. Glyphosate and its residues have also been found in water, soil, food and beverages, as well as in non-food products. It harms the environment and nature by reducing the biodiversity of agricultural land and destroying the feed sources of birds and insects. Given that glyphosate destroys not only unwanted weeds, but also plants, pollutes the environment in which we live and poses a serious threat to human health, I voted against extending the licence to glyphosate. I believe that the use of plant protection products recognised as a potentially carcinogenic by the world's leading agency for health should not be tolerated.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the objection pursuant to Rule 106 concerning the renewal of the approval of the active substance glyphosate. There has been a quite controversial debate surrounding this objection. The mandatory renewal assessment on glyphosate was carried out by Germany (Bundesinstitut für Risikobewertung ‘BfR’), which, on the basis of around 900 scientific publications, came to the conclusion that the available data does not give evidence for harmful effects in humans, animals or the environment. EFSA peer-reviewed this assessment with all other Member States and largely subscribed to their conclusions. However, the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) published their own assessment in an IARC monograph in July 2015. Their evaluation, on the other hand, assesses the risk of glyphosate as being probably carcinogenic for humans. In conclusion, until there is no unanimous assessment on the harmfulness of glyphosate to humans, I believe that it is wise to stick to the findings of the German BfR, based on a vast amount of scientific evidence. The related legal provisions do mention that if new reliable evidence is found on the possible carcinogenicity of glyphosate, this assessment can be reverted and that is why in the meantime I decided to vote against the objection.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. Thanks to the amendment tabled by the European People's Party to seek a compromise to make the extension seven years instead of fifteen years, the European Parliament has been able to reach agreement on a vital issue for European farmers. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of this decision.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. I voted against this resolution, which, thanks to an amendment tabled at the last minute by the GROUP of the European People's Party, was transformed into a call for a renewal of the authorisation to use glyphosate for a further 7 years, even though the original text put to the vote contained an unconditional objection to the renewal of the concession, for which the Movement fought hard. Glyphosate is the most widely used herbicide in the world at the moment, but it has been classified as 'probably carcinogenic to humans' by the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), on the basis of studies that are certainly more reliable than those carried out by the European Food Safety Agency which, using data provided by the glyphosate companies themselves, came to the opposite conclusion that the substance would be 'probably not carcinogenic'. Data which, moreover, have not been published in order to "not harm the commercial interests" of these large companies. European legislation and the precautionary principle allow the EU to stop the use of a substance that is potentially dangerous to human health and the environment, even if there is the slightest scientific doubt. However, in order not to affect the commercial interests of multinationals and lobbies, the majority in Parliament preferred to accept such a serious risk to man and the environment. Unfortunately, this is what matters to the health of our citizens and the environment in Europe.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted against the objection to the extension of the approval of the active substance glyphosate. While many have pointed to the potential carcinogenic risks to mammals, and therefore to humans, the European Food Safety Authority said in 2015 that glyphosate is unlikely to pose a carcinogenic hazard to us. The current extension of 7 years contains the decomposing condition that if it were to become apparent that this substance does have carcinogenic effects, this decision can be reversed.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. The European Commission's plan was to renew for 15 years the authorisation of glyphosate, the active ingredient in the world's best-selling herbicide, RoundUp, marketed by Monsanto.  Glyphosate: a substance deemed by the World Health Organization to be "probably carcinogenic" and "probably endocrine disrupting".  The European Parliament's Environment and Public Health Committee has spoken out categorically against the renewal of this authorisation. The text before us should therefore have supported this non-renewal.  However, if it is a motion to reject this proposal that has been presented to us, it is somewhat curious to see that it is a question of rejecting the 15-year renewal for... a seven-year renewal, on the pretext that, under more than obscure conditions, the European Food Safety Authority would have given a favourable opinion to this renewal. Concerned about the health of European citizens, I voted against this text without hesitation. The European Parliament had an opportunity to oppose a Commission proposal, it refused to do so with a somewhat surprising vote of 374 in, 225 against and 102 abstentions, a large majority of whom were European Greens.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 A high long-term risk has been identified in almost all uses of glyphosate for non-target terrestrial vertebrates, including mammals and birds. The use of this herbicide – not selective – eliminates not only weeds but all plants, as well as algae, bacteria and fungi, causing a significant negative impact on biodiversity and the ecosystem. Nevertheless, the European Commission proposes to authorise the use of glyphosate by 2031, i.e. for as long as possible for any use, without any restrictions (with the exception of one of the more than 500 co-formulants), only subject to confirmatory information on endocrine disrupting properties.  The European Commission's proposal therefore does not guarantee the desirable high level of protection of human and animal health and the environment and does not apply the precautionary principle. We therefore advocate the non-renewal of glyphosate approval and the establishment of a timetable for the creation of a list of non-accepted co-formulants for inclusion in plant protection products.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. Glyphosate is a major component of some broad-spectrum herbicides and has been used worldwide for weed control since the 1970s, despite health concerns. According to the WHO, glyphosate is classified as "probably carcinogenic" and the EU Commission classifies the herbicide as safe. Until it is clear what impact it has on both human health and the environment, further sales must be stopped immediately. Several Member States of the European Union, such as France, the Netherlands and Italy, are already opposed to the use of the controversial plant protection product. Glyphosate must therefore be subject to proper, independent scientific study and classification. If there is a suspicion that glyphosate is carcinogenic, it is essential to stop the sale.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the proposal as I believe that the new knowledge of glyphosate urgently requires changes in the way this chemical is handled in order to save lasting damage to the flora and fauna. The greed for profit and profiteering of individual corporations must not be above human health! Similarly, with these new findings, there must be no simple "continue like this" in the handling of the carcinogenic substance! As politicians, we have a responsibility towards our peoples and the people seerians of our homeland.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ With this vote, Labour MEPs have responded to the concerns voiced by the scientific community and the public with regard to the most popular herbicide, widely used in farming, gardening and in public spaces and thus very often open to direct contact with people. Our aim now is to ensure a comprehensive evaluation of this substance with full regard paid to the safety of humans and the environment, in line with the precautionary principle.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the objection of the ENVI Parliamentary Committee against the extension of the authorisation for the use of glyphosate. This extension of authorisation has been proposed by the European Commission on the basis of new studies according to which glyphosate does not have carcinogenic effects. However, ENVI does not consider these conclusions to be sufficiently reviewable, in particular because some key studies are not made public. Moreover, given its widespread use as a herbicide in the Member States, which comes into close contact with citizens, this substance has long been considered by experts to have likely carcinogenic effects. That is why I support the view that, unless the likely carcinogenic effects have been sufficiently, transparently and scientifically refuted, we are obliged to apply the precautionary principle and not to risk the health of the people of the European Union.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the objection of renewing the approval of the active substance of glyphosate, taking into account that it has now included an amendment which states that the approval of glyphosate extends for 7 years, not 15 as originally envisaged, and the Commission may withdraw the approval of an active substance during the period of its authorisation if it no longer meets the criteria for its approval. The amendment also provides for the exclusion of taloamine, a co-formulant which has highlighted a genotoxic potential and which cannot be used in phytopharmic products, and also proposes that efforts be made to speed up work on the establishment and consolidation of Annex III to Regulation (EU) No 1107/2009 on prohibited co-formulants.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. I voted against parliament's resolution calling on the European Commission to renew for a further 7 years the authorisation of the use in agriculture of glyphosate, the active ingredient of a herbicide produced by the multinational Monsanto. The Commission's intention was to renew the authorisation to use glyphosate for 15 years, and Parliament's motion was originally designed to call for the precautionary principle to be applied and for its renewal to be completely denied. Instead, the final text of the resolution as it emerged would have enabled the European Commission to arrive at the committee (where the fate of glyphosate is really decided together with the Member States) proposing 7 years, with parliament's support. A scandalous concession that we in the 5 Star Movement could only strongly reject. As a probably carcinogenic substance, glyphosate poses a real danger to humans. Recently, the Heinrich Böll Foundation published a study with shocking results showing that glyphosate residues were recorded in the urine of 99.6% of the more than 2 000 people monitored. The most significant values were found in children and adolescents. Mine could only be a dry no to the use of glyphosate.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the draft Commission implementing regulation renewing the approval of the active substance glyphosate for 7 instead of 15 years, as proposed by the Commission. The EPP/EPP has also advocated for many other safeguards in order to minimise the potential adverse effects of this herbicide. I advocated greater control over the health impact of glyphosate, more sustainable use, restrictions on professional use only, greater control over the sale of glyphosate in the Member States and more education for users. The abrupt abolition of glyphosate would have a major impact on European fruit and wine-growing, with European agriculture already under pressure from the dairy and pig sector crisis.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
