text: - Dear European Citizens, Watchful eyes on Brussels and Strasbourg. The eradication of nations and national self-determination began as aggressively as possible. This report is perhaps the roughest open example to date. Here is the point between points 22 and 23: strengthening multilateral global governance as an objective.  And then let me read some more color while my huge one-minute time is up. Objective: to promote free trade and investment throughout the world, better market access, of course not for small businesses, everyone knows this, to protect the stability of the global financial system.  And then a few more colours: the European Union should be competent to negotiate and sign all the energy supply contracts. In addition, they should be multinational military units, the complete elimination of autonomous military, independent defence. Be careful, be careful.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the In essence, the report contains four points. The first point was about the defence of the European states. So it is necessary to strengthen the EU's strategic autonomy in terms of nato's defence capability and capabilities – that is right. Secondly, it is a question of stabilising Europe's wider neighbourhood – and that is also true. Thirdly, it was a question of the European Union being more concerned with being a rule-setter. In other words, we should not only monitor things, we should also actively influence them. Fourthly, and fourthly, I personally found it particularly interesting, is that we have also introduced a revision clause, that every five years we want to discuss, together with the national parliaments and the citizens of the European Union, how we want to continue working in this area. So, on the whole, a good report, with which we can only agree.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – I finally voted in favour of this report. I consider some of the thesis concerning the defence capabilities of individual EU Member States to be very correct, such as that our key partner for the future must be the United States of America, that NATO is a key organisation in terms of Europe's security. I consider it important then that we call on individual Member States to increase defence spending up to 2% of their GDP. I think it is very right, it is not possible for us here in Europe to feel that defence is not about us and that we can use the money in state budgets for various good things, not for our own defences.  On the other hand, I have some doubts about the Common Defence Union. I would not agree with a model that would be a competition against NATO, i think it is better to cooperate with NATO than to create some kind of parallel defence structure of my own.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr I take this message with shared feelings. On the one hand, it is clear that the European Union has been a very influential player on the world stage for several years, decades. This also applies to the protection of our values. In military terms, I would say, a rather more specified division of responsibilities between the European Union and NATO, largely due to the 'Berlin plus' system, and the potential of the Member States is not being exploited well in this respect. On the other hand, the report looks like a mottly dress. In fact, we need to spend 2% of GDP on national budgets to just spend it. We need to strengthen relations with the United States, because we expect as if there is some threat from our eastern neighbours that our nationalists so much like. Consequently, I also voted against this report with such shared feelings, because I believe that it is simply not as well prepared as I would have liked. Thank you!

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – I supported this report with my vote. There are several reasons. Firstly, I think that the report is very good at developing the concept of a wider European neighbourhood, which is supposed to be a certain answer to the fact that not all the states of the European continent as such are likely to be admitted to the Union, but it is this system of wider neighbourhood with these regions that, for various reasons, cannot become members of the Union. I think that is very correctly handled in this report. I also support the development or further deepening of the defence and security policy strategy, including the creation of my own defence and security forces. I believe that, although there is a Berlin 1 and Berlin 2 agreement that allows the EU to use NATO's security forces in certain circumstances, this issue is unsustainable in the future without the Union building at least part of its security forces. That is why I supported the report.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Mr President, today the fog around the intention of the European Union to form, formulate and control a central military and defence capability was finally revealed. My only surprise is that this EU decision and this EU announcement today were made so close to the Brexit date, given how contentious the subject is in the United Kingdom. I chose to vote against every vote relating to the EU intention and ambition in defence and military capability and strategy. It is my strongly-held belief that defence and associated military resourcing decisions are those of a sovereign nation and its government. I do not support interference or ambitious future control in this domain by the European Union.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Mr President, in 2013 the European Council gave concrete tasks to the European Commission on: 1. a comprehensive security supply regime; 2. control of industrial capabilities in the field of defence; and 3. monitoring of safety and defence procurement. However, the Commission has not carried out these tasks in time and that has cost us and is costing us today in human lives. The European army must become a reality as soon as possible. It is vital to strengthen the partnership between the European Union and NATO and to cover the security and security gap in the wider neighbourhood of the European Union. If there is a time and a place and a time for solidarity, it is today, here and now, to be together and to be able to protect the lives, freedom and safety of European citizens together.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The report contains comments on the need for collective solidarity between Member States on security and the call for appropriate use to be made of the instruments already available in the Treaties. However, the report also contains a number of negative aspects, including the reference to the need for strengthening and cooperation between the EU and NATO and the welcome for the decision committing Member States to spending at least 2% of their GDP on military resources. Another negative aspect is the total lack of regret towards those Member States that are reluctant to share asylum seekers fairly across the EU. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote against.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. We voted against this report because this report does not reflect the Union's negative and growing role in current conflicts (southern and eastern neighbouring countries); and because it advocates intensified defence cooperation and greater military integration through the European Defence Agency. In addition, it proposes greater militarization and strengthening of EU-NATO cooperation, and supports the industrial and technological base of European defence (BITDE) and NATO's goal of increasing defence spending. We do not agree that military expenditure should be financed with funding from the Union budget, not counting that it is also insisted on strengthening NATO's European pillar and that the Member States of the Union live up to their commitments to it, and supports the tactical groupings of the Union, the NATO Response Forces and their combination, as well as the permanently grouped multi-national military units. We also object because the report emphasizes the merger of internal and external security, as well as the subordination of trade, development and energy policy under the CFSP/CSDP.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – Despite the vague name of the report ‘The EU in a changing global environment - a more connected, contested and complex’ the report itself is essentially calling for increased harmonisation, synergy, development and investment for EU military capabilities, and a closer relationship with NATO. We voted against the report as a whole as we reject the militarisation of the EU, and the erosion of Irish neutrality which is essentially what this report is calling for.  Sinn Féin has long advocated a policy of active neutrality, rejecting participation in any military alliance and supporting an enhanced role for the United Nations in resolving conflicts around the world. Sinn Féin has consistently called for a greater focus on solving the causes of conflict, such as political and economic inequality and instability and the absence of democracy. Our own experience of conflict and conflict resolution has taught us that the path to peace is not to be found in increasing military capabilities but in dialogue, inclusivity and equality.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to better defend the values of the European Union, stabilise Europe's neighbourhood, strengthen global multilateral governance and better interact with the Union, national parliaments and European citizens.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 This report by the European Parliament emphasises the formation of a Union that has an effective and strategic role on the international stage, so as to address as an autonomous factor the challenges arising from the ever-changing global environment in which we live today. In the report I voted in favour of, the Group of the Party of Socialists and Democrats managed to include the need for a strong sense of solidarity between the Member States, so as to combat any crises or conflicts more quickly and effectively and to promote the security of European citizens.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. A report that perfectly illustrates policy through good feelings (of which hell is paved), violation of sovereignty and submission to NATO. I obviously voted against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I could not in all conscience, as an MEP elected on a mandate of withdrawal from the European Union, support such a pro-EU report as this!

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. In favour of a powerful Europe on the international stage and the establishment of a common defence policy, and I voted in favour of this report. The European Union must improve its strategic autonomy in defence, in order to be able to defend and protect its citizens from civil and military threats and risks.  In addition, I am working to establish a federal Europe because I believe that the European Union is destined to be a constructive and solid global player, to be a 'decision maker', who establishes effective rules for global multilateral governance.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Sandra Kalniete’s well-written report. Since the world is becoming more interconnected and globalised the European Union nowadays is facing new challenges and threats. We have to look for appropriate solutions and responses to these challenges, as well as for the allocation of necessary resources. The EU and its Member States should step up their defence capabilities, while not forgetting about our partners. Cooperation with NATO and other global and regional actors  in solving global threats and challenges is a key to success. Furthermore, I support a call for a swift and full implementation of the fifth pillar of the European Energy Union and believe that it is in the strategic interest of the EU to endow the Commission with a prerogative to co-negotiate and co-sign contracts on energy supplies with third countries.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on EU foreign policy. Stabilising the European Neighbourhood, complying with EU enlargement and integration commitments, allocating 2% of EU countries' GDP to defence is part of the European Parliament's main recommendations to the EU Global Strategy for EU Diplomacy, Federica Mogherini, head of EU diplomacy.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP completely rejects any notion of an EU foreign or defence policy. We firmly believe that both historic and contemporary security within Europe is best secured through NATO. This report was filled with calls for greater development of the EU’s role in these policy areas, including the establishment of common EU forces, an EU military HQ and greater alignment of Member State foreign policy to suit the EU’s interests. With regard to paragraph 6, UKIP is fully committed to the 2% defence spending pledge, to which we are obliged to uphold through our NATO membership and the current government have committed themselves to.  There is no need for the EU to make any encouragements or statements in this area, as such we rejected its inclusion in the report.  Defence of the realm is the sovereign duty of the state and the whole review process of the EU’s new Global Strategy, to which this report is linked, represents the further erosion of Member State sovereignty.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Ideological imperialism of "human rights", submission to NATO, etc.: I voted against this report.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The recent attacks on European soil are events that have deeply moved citizens around the world who believe in a model of society based on freedom and tolerance.  I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the European Union must provide concrete answers to this security challenge without hindering the exercise of civil liberties. Faced with the macabre ingenuity of terrorist organizations such as Daesh, the political authorities must find the necessary means to avoid further 13 November and 22 March while preserving fundamental freedoms.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has been facing an extremely complex international scenario in recent years, with a perennial crisis. Economic difficulties, migration, instability and the development of conflicts on its borders are due to a chronic lack of common solutions adapted to the challenges of our time. The Kalniete report, which I supported today with my vote, effectively illustrates the extent of these threats and offers a range of concrete solutions to bring the EU to the centre of the global scenario. One of the main objectives to be achieved is that of common defence. The full implementation of Article 42(7) TEU must be the starting point for developing and defining a common defence policy framework leading to the establishment of a European Defence Union. Multinational military units grouped on a permanent basis, a joint defence force and the establishment of a permanent EU military headquarters are key pieces of a plan to improve military crisis management capacity. Emergency planning must be ensured, which must also be based on strengthening the EU's role as an international player, in particular by promoting the leading role of European diplomacy in the neighbouring areas of the greater neighbourhood.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted against an initiative that advocates an alarmist, ultra-securitarian and warmongering approach to international relations, which bases the EU's policies and actions towards peace and security on global arms escalation (making the objectives of radicalisms and extremism functional) and the alliance with countries that have promoted wars and provoked and fuelled the emergence of threats to combat. on the contrary, we advocate a collaborative and humanistic approach to comprehensive, comprehensive international relations of the structural causes of conflicts (unequal exchange relations, willingness to hoard and exploit primary resources of developing countries by highly industrialized countries), and a full review of international relations and their institutions in compliance with international regulations , as the main pillars for peace and human security in Europe and the world.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work in bringing this report on the Union to the fullest in a global environment in mutation: a more connected, contested and complex world. It is necessary to have clear lines on the defence of the peoples of the Union, the stabilisation of Europe's broadly understood neighbourhood and the strengthening of multilateral global governance.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report mentions the fact that the EU's overall strategy on foreign and security policy issues should "pave the way for a strong political ambition for the EU as an international player". The report actually calls for ever more submission to NATO and undermines the sovereignty of states.  The EU must strengthen its partnership with NATO, strengthen the role of the European Defence Agency (EDA) and increase its resources or launch an EU-funded defence research and technology development programme in the next multi-year financial framework (MFF). The report also calls for a "long-term strategy on asylum, migration and readmission policies" thus involving the strengthening of Schengen. Finally, the report calls for the EU to establish synergies between security, development, trade, human rights, the promotion of democracy and EU external action, thus making the EU an EU that is increasingly interfering in domestic policies under the guise of human rights.  So I voted against this report.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is totally partisan and totally contrary to my political line. The prospect of a European military Union does not convince me at all, much less the call to strengthen the Schengen system, given the current situation in which each Member State decides for itself given the EU's inability to find a solution to the flow of migrants that are constantly arriving. I therefore voted against.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. In addition to many challenges facing the Union, both present and future, are complex and interrelated, originate from state and non-State actors and come from within and outside common borders, so local, regional and global contexts need to be connected in order to respond proactively to them. The need to establish strong solidarity between Member States to address these threats, as well as a strong political will and a common objective among States, is presented as indispensable. We consider it important that arms control and Common Position 2008/944/CFSP focus on human security. In addition, the EU must take a central role in global climate action and the promotion of sustainable development.  With regard to the refugee crisis, we support the need for a joint European approach and concerted and urgent action and resolution. We believe that Member States should work together, developing their defence capabilities and pooling them, in order to manage and prevent the crises and conflicts that arise and ensure the safety of EU citizens. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which examines the EU's situation in a changing global environment. The European Parliament therefore believes that, in order to be a more effective and credible global player, the EU should take greater responsibility and focus on ending the security vacuum in the immediate and wider neighbourhood and creating stability and welfare conditions based on the rule of law and respect for human rights, which necessarily means addressing the root causes of current wars and conflicts, migration flows and the refugee crisis. He is also convinced that the EU should step up its diplomatic action to de-escalate the situation, especially in the southern neighbourhood. Parliament is of the opinion that, in order to build stability and peace and to promote human security, the rule of law and respect for human rights and democratisation, the EU should fulfil its enlargement and integration commitments based on policies that foster economic growth and an inclusive society, and should continue to work with very closely associated countries in the context of the newly revised European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP). The European Parliament considers inclusive multilateral diplomacy, under the coordination and leadership of the High Representative/Vice-President, to be a crucial tool for resolving conflicts and managing crises in neighbouring countries and the world. It is therefore necessary to provide for a more strategic direction, to ensure consistency and positive synergies between external action policies and internal policies, which are increasingly interconnected, at EU level, between the Member States and between the EEAS and the Commission.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union faces a number of complex challenges and threats that require decisive joint action to address the situation in such a way that Europe's core values are not undermined. The Union should therefore ensure its resilience, both internally and externally, take greater responsibility for its own security and territorial protection and take into account the inseparable link between internal and external security. It must be a constructive, flexible and stronger player in a multipolar world.  In order to achieve peace and stability, we must stick to our enlargement commitments and continue to cooperate with countries with close ties with the Union in the context of the EU's neighbourhood policy. These priorities are one of the priorities in this report and I therefore supported its adoption.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \u2012 We majorityly supported the European Parliament resolution on the EU in a changing global environment in view of a more integrated, conflicted and complex world. It is in the interests of all Members to ensure the safety of our citizens, to preserve our values and social model. Given the current situation facing the whole of Europe, we need to strengthen the European Union's strategic autonomy and integration with NATO. At the same time, we must not forget foreign policy, where we must focus on cooperation with global partners in the area of common interests for our future.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 If we want to safeguard European values and the social model, we must promote the European Union as an increasingly central player in the chessboard of global international relations. The report voted on today marks the political will of the European Parliament to encourage Community action in this area by supporting the achievement of strategic objectives through a more coherent and pragmatic approach both internally and externally. Increasing European autonomy and effectiveness in the field of foreign policy is essential if we are to be able to face up to the common threats that challenge our security today. European actions must therefore be applied promptly and in a coordinated manner, especially in order to try to reduce the instability of neighbouring regions. In this respect, we must therefore redouble our efforts to increase synergy and the sharing of information between the Member States, in order to be able to meet the constantly changing challenges posed by the international environment through real European instruments. I therefore welcome the adoption of the report, convinced that greater integration in the field of foreign policy is also essential for the future of the EU.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I support this report, which recognises the EU as a true international actor capable of shaping events and being a ready leader in a changing environment. In my view, EU Member States need to work in synergy, develop their defence capabilities and pool and share them more effectively.  The EU needs to be more active in its environment and be able to prevent and manage crises and conflicts that pose a threat to the security of every EU citizen.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the EU must ensure its resilience both internally and externally and its ability to anticipate, prevent and resolve foreseeable challenges and threats, as well as being ready to act quickly in the face of unpredictable crises, as well as its ability to recover from various types of attacks, as well as protect the security of energy and raw material supply.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 We Europeans are now in a more fragile and divided world than we were twenty years ago: the difficulties of the international scene are approaching our doors, there are notes and the answers they require are more pressing. Nevertheless, the short-sightedness of many national governments, which still persist in using energy in small internal disputes rather than investing them in the federal progress that the globalised world is demanding of Europe today, is astonishing. A Europe that is still strong and with soft power spread throughout the world, but which is in danger of losing if it does not return to strong international leadership and abjures its values. Europe's soft power in the world is to be the home of welfare and rights, peace and freedom, art and technological development: without these elements it is weak and its influence melts like snow in the sun. It is the responsibility of each of us in this House to do everything possible to overcome national self-interest and to protect the security and well-being of our citizens in a Europe that we want to be more cohesive, more supportive and more up to its role in the world.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 There are currently a number of challenges that threaten the stability of the Union, which is why a strong political will is needed on the part of both the Union and the Member States in order to respond effectively to these challenges and to maintain the values promoted by the Union. Collective responsibility and solidarity must be found in Union policies, in particular in the common foreign and security policy. Threats to Member States must be considered as threats to the whole Union, requiring solidarity and unity. A clear identification and ranking of concrete threats is required in order to formulate appropriate responses and put in place coherent measures in line with the necessary resources. Against the background of recent terrorist attacks, strong security policies are needed to ensure the safety of citizens. I was in favour of this report because I believe that a common comprehensive approach based on solidarity is needed in response to the challenges that threaten internal and external security, and synergies between external action, human rights and security are needed.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the report, the EU strategy should be based on: a. identifying and prioritising the face of threats and challenges; b. the definition of the responses to be adopted in relation to them; c. the determination of the resources to be allocated to it. The report stresses that the borders of each Member State are the borders of the Union and as such must be defended, but calls for the strengthening of the Schengen system, the European Border and Coast Guard and Frontex. It also considers it essential to strengthen EU-NATO cooperation. Consideration must be taken to the transition to multinational military units, joint defence forces and the establishment of a framework for the common defence policy, leading, finally, to a European Defence Union. The EU must deliver on its enlargement and integration commitments, based on policies designed to boost economic growth and inclusive societies. The current refugee crisis requires a holistic European approach and urgent and concerted action, using both external and internal instruments; calls for a long-term strategy and sustainable management of asylum, migration and readmission policies on the basis of common principles and solidarity. I am voting against it out of my favour.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 In a permanent process of globalisation, the EU is becoming more complex, trying to meet the current challenges and risks. In this context, the effects of the crisis that has disrupted the entire global financial and economic system continue to be an important source of vulnerabilities and, therefore, insecurity at national, regional and global level. The economy is the fuel without which national power, be it political, social or military, cannot function at normal parameters. I support the identification of new ways to achieve better results, such as the principle that Member States use at least 2% of GDP for defence spending by 2024 in order to implement the objectives of foreign and security policy at Union level. For the development of the Union, an essential role can also be energy security, which will complement the European objectives of reindustrialisation and economic growth. I conclude that we must work together today for the European Union tomorrow. We need a new strategy, ready to respond to crisis situations and with an ability to recover immediately after the attacks. We must be aware that the EU has the capacity to spread European values, which are meant to bring back unity, peace and well-being.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. In 2012 The Socialists promote the EU to be a true international player capable of influencing events and dealing with a rapidly changing global environment and growing assembly security problems. EU member states are therefore asked to work together, develop their defence capabilities, pool them and share them more effectively. The EU needs to be more active in its neighbourhood and must be able to prevent and manage crises and conflicts that also pose challenges to the security of EU citizens. The EU can and should do better.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The European Union needs a security strategy that is adapted to the changes that have changed in the world in recent years. The threats we are currently facing come from both state and non-state actors, which profoundly disrupts the functioning of our security arsenal. The European Union must be able to respond to the various challenges that the new global arrangement entails. There is a need for common security responses. We find that isolated reactions are not enough. I voted in favour of this report, which proposes a comprehensive approach to security while preserving the fundamental values of the European Union.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ Despite the vague name of the report ‘The EU in a changing global environment - a more connected, contested and complex’ the report itself is essentially calling for increased harmonisation, synergy, development and investment for EU military capabilities, and a closer relationship with NATO. We voted against the report as a whole as we reject the militarisation of the EU, and the erosion of Irish neutrality which is essentially what this report is calling for.  Sinn Féin has long advocated a policy of active neutrality, rejecting participation in any military alliance and supporting an enhanced role for the United Nations in resolving conflicts around the world. Sinn Féin has consistently called for a greater focus on solving the causes of conflict, such as political and economic inequality and instability and the absence of democracy. Our own experience of conflict and conflict resolution has taught us that the path to peace is not to be found in increasing military capabilities but in dialogue, inclusivity and equality. My party in Europe will continue to focus on these issues in addition to ensuring that vital public funding is not being diverted to propping up military actions outside of the European Union. I call on all other Irish MEPs to commit likewise.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP completely rejects any notion of an EU foreign or defence policy. We firmly believe that both historic and contemporary security within Europe is best secured through NATO. This report was filled with calls for greater development of the EU’s role in these policy areas, including the establishment of common EU forces, an EU military HQ and greater alignment of Member State foreign policy to suit the EU’s interests. With regard to paragraph 6, UKIP is fully committed to the 2% defence spending pledge, to which we are obliged to uphold through our NATO membership and the current government have committed themselves to.  There is no need for the EU to make any encouragements or statements in this area, as such we rejected its inclusion in the report.  Defence of the realm is the sovereign duty of the state and the whole review process of the EU’s new Global Strategy, to which this report is linked, represents the further erosion of Member State sovereignty.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ The world is changing rapidly and so is the context in which the EU is situated.  I believe that the EU is still capable of solving both its internal and external crises and of becoming an even stronger actor on the international arena. I voted in favour of this report as it provides a number of good proposals with regard to the EU Global Strategy on foreign and security policy. It is important to increase cooperation in Europe in order to find truly common solutions to EU problems.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report focuses on the European Parliament's recommendations to the High Representative on the development of the eu's new comprehensive common foreign and security policy strategy. As a member of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Human Common Security and Policy, I have tabled a number of amendments aimed at overcoming the critical issues of the draft report. From the outset, the Latter presented a number of controversial aspects, such as the welcome for the decision committing Member States to using 2% of their annual GDP in defence spending, as well as the total lack of regret towards Member States still reluctant to proceed with a fair distribution of asylum seekers. The text of the report is also rather weak on the issue of creating real European intelligence. In view of the fact that the amendments I have proposed have not been adequately taken into account in the drafting of the final text, I have decided to give my negative opinion on the report.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and note that many of the current and future challenges and threats facing and will be faced by the EU are complex and interrelated and come from state and non-state actors, both inside and outside its common borders. Strong political will and leadership are needed for decisive joint action on the part of the EU and its Member States in order to pre-actively, collectively and effectively address these challenges, preserve the EU's values and social model, and make the EU a more effective and strategic player and contribute to global security.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the EU's presence in a raging global environment concerns a range of issues in the light of the modern needs that the European Union is called upon to meet, such as terrorism issues and security strategies, citizens' participation in decision-making and global governance. I do not think that this text expresses and should not be expressed by all European citizens, as it is particularly conservative and phobic. As I believe that Europe needs more democracy and respect for citizens' rights than conservative policies, I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which gives an account of the relationship between the European Union and the current global context as it takes care to set important objectives with which I could only agree. Indeed, I agree with proposals such as greater security for our citizens and safeguarding our values and models of society, or even the intention to stabilise Europe's relationship with its Member States and individual regions with the aim of strengthening the existing coalition. In essence, I am in favour of this report because it moves towards a More Connected European Union within and in foreign policy as a concrete response to the global changes to which we are constantly exposed.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ Since the 2003 Security Strategy, the EU’s strategic environment has changed radically. While much has been achieved over the last decade, today an arc of instability surrounds the Union. Further afield, we see conflicts in Africa and security tensions in Asia, while climate change and scarce natural resources harbour the risk of more conflict. At the same time, global growth, interdependence and technological progress enable ever more people to escape poverty and live longer, healthier and freer lives. The EU must confront both the challenges and the opportunities that come with its changed environment.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support Mrs Kalniete's report on the CHALLENGES of the EU in a more connected and complex Global World. This Report reaffirms the EU's founding principles such as the promotion of Peace and the Well-Being of Peoples, with emphasis on the ability to anticipate, prevent and respond to challenges and threats, not forgetting the security of energy supply and the effects of climate change. Mrs Kalniete supports the guidance that the US remains the EU's most important strategic partner, but points out that we need to rely less on this partner on collective security and territorial defence, requiring more involvement from Member States. I agree with the express guidelines that arms export controls are an integral part of the EU's foreign and security policy and member states are being asked to respect the common position on arms exports. I agree with proposals such as the creation of the Format of the Council of Defence Ministers (under the chairmanship of the High Representative), the enhancement of neighbourhood policy (and the creation of conditions for stability and prosperity of neighbouring states), as well as the establishment of partnerships with regional actors on specific sectoral issues resulting from global threats and challenges.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP completely rejects any notion of an EU foreign or defence policy. We firmly believe that both historic and contemporary security within Europe is best secured through NATO. This report was filled with calls for greater development of the EU’s role in these policy areas, including the establishment of common EU forces, an EU military HQ and greater alignment of Member State foreign policy to suit the EU’s interests. With regard to paragraph 6, UKIP is fully committed to the 2% defence spending pledge, to which we are obliged to uphold through our NATO membership and the current government have committed themselves to.  There is no need for the EU to make any encouragements or statements in this area, as such we rejected its inclusion in the report.  Defence of the realm is the sovereign duty of the state and the whole review process of the EU’s new Global Strategy, to which this report is linked, represents the further erosion of Member State sovereignty.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Development and security are interlinked and often interdependent, two sides of the same coin. The EU needs to reinforce a coordination mechanism for identifying the potential implications of policies on development objectives, and for integrating development aspects into policy initiatives from the outset. Sustainable Development Goals, in particular those of promoting good governance, human rights, democracy and justice, combating poverty, reducing inequalities and social exclusion, help in tackling unemployment and barriers to sustainable and inclusive social and economic growth. But we need a more systematic measurement of impacts.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report aims to clarify the European Parliament's position on the European Union's overall foreign and security policy strategy. The report identifies the EU's objectives on these issues. At the moment, the EU needs to respond to internal and external threats (including climate change, major migration flows and international terrorism) that are very different from those highlighted in the security strategy drawn up in 2003. I fully support the desire to seek greater solidarity between the Member States in the field of security, as is Parliament's call for effective use of the many international instruments available for managing the migration crisis and the attention paid to the issues of sustainable development and the protection of human rights. Despite all this, a number of critical aspects emerge in the report, including the decision to reserve 2% of Member States' GDP in military resources. In addition, the report is inadequate and inadequate with regard to a fair distribution of asylum seekers in the various EU states and the creation of European intelligence. I am voting against.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. We voted against this report because this report does not reflect the Union's negative and growing role in current conflicts (southern and eastern neighbouring countries); and because it advocates intensified defence cooperation and greater military integration through the European Defence Agency. In addition, it proposes greater militarization and strengthening of EU-NATO cooperation, and supports the industrial and technological base of European defence (BITDE) and NATO's goal of increasing defence spending.  We do not agree that military expenditure should be financed with funding from the Union budget, not counting that it is also insisted on strengthening NATO's European pillar and that the Member States of the Union live up to their commitments to it, and supports the tactical groupings of the Union, the NATO Response Forces and their combination, as well as the permanently grouped multi-national military units. We also object because the report emphasizes the merger of internal and external security, as well as the subordination of trade, development and energy policy under the CFSP/CSDP.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution puts at the centre the importance of a European strategy, in line with its core values, that can respond to common threats to the EU and its Member States. Issues such as internal and external security, the refugee crisis, regional conflicts, arms exports and climate change affect all Member States and their citizens. Therefore, they require a unified, concrete and proactive response at European level. My vote in favour expresses my support for a European strategy for the effective management of these issues. In particular, I agree that the EU should contribute more to stability, security and respect for human rights in neighbouring countries and the southern neighbourhood and, at the same time, involve national parliaments, regional actors and civil society in the process of implementing the strategy.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU's role in a changing global environment prioritises the EU's role in the world. The European Union faces a number of complex challenges and threats, which need to be resolved with decisive joint action, in order to deal with the situation in such a way that Europe's core values are not undermined. The Union should therefore ensure its resilience, both internally and externally, take greater responsibility for its own security and territorial protection and take into account the inseparable link between internal and external security. In order to achieve peace and stability, we must continue to cooperate with countries with close ties with the Union. In summary, according to the report, the EU must be a constructive, flexible and stronger actor in today's multipolar world. I supported the report.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Sandra Kalniete's report reflects in many ways the European Commission's intentions to create a military dimension to the EU. It is clear from its content that 'the main objective should be to promote permanent multinational units and voluntary joint defence forces and to form a Community defence policy which should ultimately lead to Community defence'. Since I believe that defence policy should remain a sovereign issue for the member states and NATO remains the foundation of European security, I have decided to abstain.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ Defence policy is matter of national sovereignty, therefore I cannot support the elements of this report that seek a significant expansion of the EU role in this area. The NATO alliance is the bedrock of European security and British defence policy, and I will not support anything that risks undermining that.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 Today the European Union is surrounded by an arc of instability that extends from Eastern Europe to North Africa via the Middle East: the policies of migration and the threat of jihadist terrorism "Isis" are two obvious examples. As the Kalniete report points out, the EU finds itself divided internally and unable to react because of different strategic views between the Member States that have so far prevented the coordination of foreign and defence policy. As the resolution points out, one of the EU's fundamental objectives is to promote peace, its values and the well-being of its citizens, while ensuring their security (Article 21 TEU). Therefore, I believe that in order to deal with the threats and challenges facing the EU, there must be greater cooperation between The Member States in implementing a common framework for defence policy. To this end, the report emphasises the importance of improving intelligence exchanges between Member States in order to ensure adequate control mechanisms that strengthen international security.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report is the European Parliament's contribution to the EU's new comprehensive security strategy, which the High Representative was tasked with drawing up last summer by the European Council. This report aims to defend the states, societies and values of Europe and stabilise the neighbourhood of Europe at large. Considering that the influence of the European Union on the international stage is a prerequisite for its security, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. This report represents the European Parliament's contribution to the EU's "comprehensive foreign and security policy strategy" which the EU High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy is due to submit to the Council in June 2016. This report takes into account the need to cooperate more with regional actors, particularly on defence research, in order to deal with global threats, while respecting the fundamental principles and interests of the Union. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The political situation in much of the European Union's neighbourhood is deeply unstable. The wars in Libya and Syria have been going on for five years and the Ukrainian conflict is bogged down. That is why the EU must have a comprehensive strategy to address these challenges. The EU and its Member States must take greater responsibility for their own security, improve their intelligence cooperation, and pool their defence efforts.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union faces a number of complex challenges and threats, which need to be resolved with decisive joint action, in order to deal with the situation in such a way that Europe's core values are not undermined. The Union should therefore ensure its internal and external resilience, take greater responsibility for its own security and territorial protection and take into account the inseparable link between internal and external security. It must be a constructive, flexible and stronger player in a multipolar world.  In order to achieve peace and stability, we must stick to our enlargement commitments and continue to cooperate with countries with close ties with the Union in the context of the EU's neighbourhood policy. These priorities are included in the report on the Union's role in a changing global environment. I voted in favour of this document.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. To the extent that this text defends an ideological vision of human rights, does not respect the sovereignty of nations, aims to strengthen the European Union's submission to NATO and global governance and advocates a Europeanisation of defence, I voted against it.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the EU report in a changing global environment – a more connected, contested and complex world, as it reflects the European Commission's intention to move towards the creation of a common European army and a common defence policy. Like me and the majority of my colleagues in the Group of European Conservatives and Reformists, we believe that the army and defence policy are a matter of national sovereignty of the Member States, many of whom are members of THE EU. In addition, the creation of a common European army will also undermine THE ROLE OF THE EU as a security guarantor in Europe.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union faces a number of complex challenges and threats that require decisive joint action to resolve, so that the situation is dealt with in such a way that Europe's core values are not undermined. The Union should therefore ensure its resilience, both internally and externally, take greater responsibility for its own security and territorial protection and take into account the inseparable link between internal and external security. It must be a constructive, flexible and stronger player in a multipolar world.  In order to achieve peace and stability, we must stick to our enlargement commitments and continue to cooperate with countries with close ties with the Union in the context of the EU's neighbourhood policy. These priorities are included in the report on the Union's role in a changing global environment. I voted in favour of this document.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because I do not agree with the establishment of a common EU joint defence force or that the EU should have military units. There is strong support in Wales for an EU civilian conflict prevention corps but this report did not expand that idea.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. Many of the present and future threats and challenges facing the EU are complex and related to each other, arise from state and non-state actors and originate both within and outside common borders. These threats are identified in the 2003 European Security Strategy (terrorism, weapons of mass destruction, regional conflicts, loss of state authority and organised crime) and remain largely relevant.  I therefore consider it important to strengthen structured and coherent cooperation in defence research and development, industrial and cyber defence, through pooling and resource sharing and other cooperative projects; devote 2% of defence spending to research and launch an EU-funded defence research and technology programme.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. The report presents an extensive set of justifications for the need to deepen the strengthening of European militarism and EU security policy. It addresses the changes that the world has experienced in recent years and the supposed new threats to which the EU is subject. It calls for the overcoming of interinstitutional barriers so that threats are overcome, i.e. deepening harmonisation and the federalist aspect of the EU. It advocates strengthening investment in the different European security-related sectors and increasing support for the European military complex, paving the way for the creation of EU military forces. It advocates increasing member states' military expenditure. Advocate complementarity and cooperation, read subservience, with NATO, defining it and the US as key strategic partners.  It relates the militaristic and security posture with the consolidation of the said Energy Union. It understems EU migration policy, FRONTEX action and the establishment of the European Coast and Border Guard. It supports the strengthening of Schengen, the logic of "Fortress Europe" and the EU's neighbourhood policy.  Policies and stances contrary to the construction of policies of solidarity, cooperation and peace, with respect for the sovereignty of states.  Obviously, we voted against it.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. – I voted against as I have serious concerns about its military nature.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The report in question draws attention to old and new security challenges for the European Union and presents more effective methods that will strengthen the European Union's position and its strategic role as an international actor. The European Union and its Member States need to take greater responsibility within the framework of collective security and be more active in Europe's neighbourhood, making full use of the provisions of the Lisbon CSDP Treaty. The European Union must make more effective use of its diplomatic, economic and other instruments at its disposal in order to promote the stability, security and prosperity of the region. There is no doubt that the European Union must act in cooperation with NATO, but it must also learn to act alone. If there is no change, the European Union will have a serious problem in the future, how to face ever-changing global environments and new security challenges.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report as there are many foreign policy points that I do not agree with.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report. I strongly disagree with the creation of a joint EU military force and cooperation with NATO, as I recognise that the interests of the Member States differ considerably, and even more so of the EU with NATO and the US.  I also disagree with the EU's attempts to deepen governance in cyberspace. I believe that the strengthening of Schengen, the European Border Guard and FRONTEX will further reinforce the threats faced by States as proven terrorists, taking advantage of FRONTEX's free movement and incompetence, have infiltrated the EU and engaged in murderous acts of terrorism. The EU should not "transmit European values" as this I consider to be cultural imperialism which considers the values of other peoples to be inferior and inferior.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the fact that the report recognises the United States as key strategic partner of the EU, stresses the need for the EU and its Member States to take greater responsibility for their collective security and to be more active in Europe’s own neighbourhood, making full use of the Lisbon treaty provisions on CSDP. I strongly believe we need to promote the strategic autonomy of the EU and its capacity to act in synergy but also autonomously from NATO. I advocate an EU that is a real international actor capable of shaping the developments and dealing with a rapidly changing global environment and mounting security challenges. I urge, therefore, the EU Member States to work in synergy, develop their defence capabilities and pool and share them more effectively. The EU needs to be more active in its neighbourhood and be capable of preventing and managing crises and conflicts that represent challenges for the security of EU citizens too.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union faces a number of complex challenges and threats that require decisive joint action to resolve, so that the situation is dealt with in such a way that Europe's core values are not undermined. The Union should therefore ensure its resilience, both internally and externally, take greater responsibility for its own security and territorial protection and take into account the inseparable link between internal and external security. It must be a constructive, flexible and stronger player in a multipolar world.  In order to achieve peace and stability, we must stick to our enlargement commitments and continue to cooperate with countries with close ties with the UNION in the context of the EU's neighbourhood policy. These priorities are included in the report on the Union's role in a changing global environment. I voted in favour of this document.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. – The European Union faces a number of complex challenges and threats, which need to be resolved in a strong joint way, so that the situation is dealt with in such a way that Europe's core values are not undermined. The Union should therefore ensure its resilience, both internally and externally, take greater responsibility for its own security and territorial protection and take into account the inseparable link between internal and external security. It must be a constructive, flexible and stronger player in a multipolar world. In order to achieve peace and stability, we must stick to our enlargement commitments and continue to cooperate with countries with close ties with the UNION in the context of the EU's neighbourhood policy. These priorities are included in the report on the Union's role in a changing global environment. I voted in favour of this document.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report with the conviction that unity, not uniformity, will make us all stronger and more competitive. The EU must ensure its resilience both internally and externally and its ability to anticipate, anticipate and resolve predictable challenges and threats, as well as be prepared to act quickly, so it must assume a leadership role at the global level, taking on greater responsibility. The EU must take important steps towards greater defence cooperation, as well as really bet on a common foreign policy, without which it is at a clear global disadvantage.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the non-legislative resolution on the EU in a changing global context – A more connected, contested and complex world because I believe strong joint action by the Union and its Member States is needed to respond vigorously to the challenges of safeguarding European values and its model of social development. I maintain that it is necessary for the European Union to assume greater responsibility for its neighbourhood, so as to create the conditions for peace, stability and prosperity that would also have a positive impact within Europe's borders. Finally, I believe it is essential to involve the European Union, national parliaments and European citizens in the implementation of a comprehensive strategy that takes into account the security environment and possibly the new threats to the Union's resilience.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I abstained today in the final vote on the report on "The EU in a changing global environment – a more connected, conflict-ridden and complex world". In principle, I would like the EU to play a stronger role in global strategic issues. However, the report sets the wrong tone on too many points that stand in the way of a stronger role for the EU worldwide.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The terrorist attacks in Brussels have once again highlighted security gaps in our systems. The solution to this security problem and the fight against danger can only be done collectively through greater networking between the Union in the common, sustainable foreign and security policy.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: in writing. ‒ Defence policy is matter of national sovereignty. While cooperation is important, the EU cannot and should not be allowed to expand its role in this area. In the UK, the NATO alliance is the bedrock of British defence policy and a leading instrument of our national security. Close cooperation with NATO is also seen as vital in fulfilling UK strategic objectives as well as shared security and defence challenges.  To call for a stronger EU role within the realm of security and defence is not only an infringement of national sovereignty, but it is also a threat to the UK’s security framework. Of course cooperation is vital. In today’s environment, security threats are increasingly transnational in nature. Indeed, threats such as terrorism and organised crime do not respect state boundaries and require coordinated responses. Such coordination should however be left to the Member States and national governments. Not an increasingly centralised EU.  NATO is also a vital cornerstone of Europe’s security policy and so any attempt to sidestep this organisation will be counterproductive and damaging to European security more broadly. It is for these reasons that I voted against.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted against an initiative that advocates an alarmist, ultra-securitarian and warmongering approach to international relations, which bases the EU's policies and actions towards peace and security on global arms escalation (making the objectives of radicalisms and extremism functional) and the alliance with countries that have promoted wars and provoked and fuelled the emergence of threats to combat. On the contrary, we advocate a comprehensive collaborative and humanist approach to international relations, integral to the structural causes of conflicts (unequal exchange relations, willingness to hoard and exploit primary resources of developing countries by highly industrialized countries), and a full review of international relations and their institutions in compliance with international regulations , as the main pillars for peace and human security in Europe and the world.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which sets out the EU’s foreign policy strategy for the years ahead. It emphasises the need to better link internal and external EU policy and touches on defence and trade policy, as well as more general foreign affairs points.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that Europe must finally speak with one voice on the international stage, when it faces global challenges and its action is part of an ever-changing global environment (terrorism, the migrant crisis, political instability around the Mediterranean...). The European Union can only be a credible player on the international stage if it gains autonomy, notably by developing its presence and influence within international organisations. The EU's foreign policy priority must be to stabilise and secure its neighbours and external borders.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. I support a further deepening of the efficient governance of global common domains such as sea, air, space and cyberspace.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Written. We welcome the initiative for a new broad strategy for the EU's overall external relations and believe it is important that the European Parliament, through the report, should be involved in influencing its design. We are convinced that, among other things, strengthened cooperation with a reformed UN, increased European diplomacy and multilateral cooperation are crucial for the EU to be able to respond effectively to current security challenges, such as terrorist attacks. However, we believe that increased cooperation should not affect the specific nature of member states' security and defence policies. We are therefore opposed to wordings calling for the development of common defence forces and the development of a common defence policy with the aim of a European Defence Union. We are also critical of the report's call to increase the EU's own resources.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union faces a number of complex challenges and threats that require decisive joint action to resolve, so that the situation is dealt with in such a way that Europe's core values are not undermined. The Union should therefore ensure its resilience, both internally and externally, take greater responsibility for its own security and territorial protection and take into account the inseparable link between internal and external security. You must be a constructive, flexible and strong player in a multipolar world.  In order to achieve peace and stability, we must stick to our enlargement commitments and continue to cooperate with countries with close ties with the UNION in the context of the EU's neighbourhood policy. These priorities are included in the report on the Union's role in a changing global environment. I voted in favour of this document.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted against the whole report because we disagree on the substance with the EU's foreign policy.  As a group we have tabled a minority view which, inter alia, emphasises full nuclear disarmament at EU and global level, the financing of military expenditure from the EU budget, and that all activities must be strictly limited within the framework of the UN Charter and International Law.  It also stresses the peaceful orientation that the Union must take in resolving conflicts and, finally, calls for a complete separation of the EU from NATO and the dissolution of NATO.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to vote for this resolution. The EU has a key role in upholding the principles enshrined in international human rights law, and that therefore, human rights must be meaningfully integrated into the new Global Strategy. EU foreign policy must adopt a strategic approach to human rights, emphasising concrete actions and outcomes and demonstrating coherence in the EU’s engagement on human rights across different countries and regions, regardless of security, foreign policy, trade, energy, aid or other concerns. The EU must recognise the full extent of the deterioration in its immediate strategic environment, and the long-term consequences thereof. The fact that multiple crises were occurring simultaneously within the Union meant that no Member State could respond alone and that Europeans should exercise their responsibilities collectively to ensure their security.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained from voting as this report did not reflect Ireland’s position as a neutral country

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union faces a number of complex challenges and threats that require decisive joint action to resolve, so that the situation is dealt with in such a way that Europe's core values are not undermined. The Union should therefore ensure its resilience, both internally and externally, take greater responsibility for its own security and territorial protection and take into account the inseparable link between internal and external security. It must be a constructive, flexible and stronger player in a multipolar world.  In order to achieve peace and stability, we must stick to our enlargement commitments and continue to cooperate with countries with close ties with the UNION in the context of the EU's neighbourhood policy. These priorities are included in the report on the Union's role in a changing global environment. I voted in favour of this document.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ This report is vague and incoherent and adds little to the general debate on our changing global environment. I therefore voted against it. The report deals with important issues but does nothing in terms of finding realistic solutions.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that the EU is an important international actor which has the capacity to deal with a changing global environment and numerous challenges to our security. The EU should be more active in its neighbourhood. We have to be capable of preventing and managing crises and conflicts that also represent challenges for the EU citizens.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the EU in a changing global environment – a more connected, conflicted and complex world because I think it needs, above all, to strengthen the EU as a foreign policy actor. In this context, the security situation in the vicinity of the EU and in the wider neighbourhood should be reviewed in the form of creating lasting stability and promoting the rule of law and respect for human rights.  Particular attention should certainly be paid to the refugee crisis, which requires a comprehensive European approach and poses a major challenge for the entire international community. Energy security will play a major role in the internal development of the European Union, while its further prosperity will depend on its ability to be innovative and competitive.  I believe that the EU's global strategy for foreign and security policy is crucial so that the role played by the Union globally is consistent and at the level of current threats and challenges.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This report once again highlights the policy of violating national sovereignty and the European Union's submission to NATO. I, unsurprisingly, voted against this text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – Diane James and her fellow UKIP MEPs voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP completely rejects any notion of an EU foreign or defence policy. We firmly believe that both historic and contemporary security within Europe is best secured through NATO. This report was filled with calls for greater development of the EU’s role in these policy areas, including the establishment of common EU forces, an EU military HQ and greater alignment of Member State foreign policy to suit the EU’s interests. With regard to paragraph 6, UKIP is fully committed to the 2% defence spending pledge, to which we are obliged to uphold through our NATO membership and the current government have committed themselves to.  There is no need for the EU to make any encouragements or statements in this area, as such we rejected its inclusion in the report.  Defence of the realm is the sovereign duty of the state and the whole review process of the EU’s new Global Strategy, to which this report is linked, represents the further erosion of Member State sovereignty.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Sandra Kalniete's report on the European Union in a changing global environment. This report highlights the importance of defending European values, strengthening the security of its citizens and ensuring the integrity of its territory. It is also a question of securing Europe's neighbourhood by strengthening cooperation with regional actors against global threats. I support this legislative proposal which will enable the Union to defend its fundamental interests by consolidating its strategic autonomy in terms of defence capabilities in addition to NATO. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. This text is the European Parliament's contribution to the EU's new comprehensive security strategy, which the High Representative was tasked with drawing up last summer by the European Council.  This new strategy attempts to respond to the changing regional security environment, which is currently very changing and uncertain, in order to offer the European Union greater resilience and to stabilise our immediate neighbourhood. A number of other proposals for the Union's representation in the world, its place as an actor in a multipolar world or the values to be defended in the world aim to strengthen the Union's primary objective: to ensure the security of its citizens and territory. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. Although there are a number of points on which I agree with the rapporteur, the report envisaging a massive expansion of the EU's activities and competences. These include, for example, closer cooperation with NATO or the call for an EU army. Even though the global framework has changed, I see no need for such a massive increase in competence, which is why I reject the report.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: Written. It is clear to everyone that Europe is facing a markedly changed security situation now than we did just a few years ago. The need for cooperation and common solutions is increasing, as the threat to the countries of Europe evolves. At the same time, we must take into account the defence opt-out that resulted from the Edinburgh Agreement. We are doing this by abstaining from voting for or against concrete proposals for greater coordination of defence policy and military resources within the European Union. Of course, those EU countries that wish to see more formalised military cooperation in the EU should have the opportunity to do so, but Denmark cannot take part in this.  In the long term, we want to remove the defence opt-out because we believe that it is in Denmark's clear interest to be able to cooperate more closely on our common security in Europe. But until then, we operate in full respect of the reservation. For the Socialists, there is no doubt that NATO is, and will continue to be, our most important and primary military cooperation body. However, in addition to NATO cooperation, we are already working together in a number of areas with non-NATO countries, such as Nato. Sweden, and we want to continue to do so. Similarly, we also support increased cooperation between the EU and NATO in the field of defence policy.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. The own-initiative report by Sandra Kalniete reflects the European Commission's intentions to deepen and consolidate a military dimension for the EU. Security is an essential condition for a stable and prosperous Europe. However, the rapporteur's position raises the possibility of creating a new, possibly redundant, security organisation alongside the national defence policy of each Member State as a sovereign task and already existing security structures, such as .B the OSCE and NATO. That is why I did not vote in favour of this report.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Since the motion for a resolution contained in paragraph 13 that the European Parliament "notes the importance of deepening EU-NATO cooperation that could ensure coordination of operations, and supports the creation of European forces to complement NATO in the field of territorial defence and capable of conducting independent operations outside the EU; stresses that the CSDP should strengthen NATO's European pillar and ensure that European NATO members truly fulfil their commitments within nato; suggests combining the concept of EU battlegroups and NATO rapid response forces; recalls that military contributions should be based on the principle of solidarity between EU Member States', I could not support this document. I believe that the existence of an organisation whose justification ended with the Cold War complicates the security and military situation. Military intervention by NATO countries often destabilises the situation in countries close to the EU, and we also see consequences in the context of the migration crisis. So I do not understand how an organisation that is directly responsible for some of the problems we face can help us and why it should be a partner for us. An organization that is in the 20th century mentality cannot help us with the dilemmas of the new millennium, so we should rather talk about ending cooperation with NATO.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union faces a number of complex challenges and threats that require decisive joint action to resolve, so that the situation is dealt with in such a way that Europe's core values are not undermined. The Union should therefore ensure its resilience, both internally and externally, take greater responsibility for its own security and territorial protection and take into account the inseparable link between internal and external security. It must be a constructive, flexible and stronger player in a multipolar world.  In order to achieve peace and stability, we must stick to our enlargement commitments and continue to cooperate with countries with close ties with the Union in the context of the EU's neighbourhood policy. These priorities are included in the report on the Union's role in a changing global environment. I voted in favour of this document.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I would like to thank Mrs Kalniete for her work on this report on the state of the EU and its presence in an ongoing global world. The report focuses on four central characteristics that the Union has, but which it must necessarily strengthen in order to keep up with this progress. They are, in particular, ensuring the security of the Member States, their citizens and territories; responsibly support a state of security both with states bordering the EU's borders and with those further ary; to ensure that the Eu ropean Union becomes an influential rule-maker in an increasingly multipolar context; finally, undertake to carry out regular EU ballots with the cooperation of the various participating members. In this way, the Union will be able to maintain a competitive and influential position within an increasingly global context.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the report on "the European Union in a changing global environment - A more connected, more contested and more complex world". This report interferes with the internal affairs of the Member States. In particular, it calls for the Europeanisation of intelligence and defence. It calls for a strengthening of the EU-NATO axis. It aims to make the European Union a global player in the service of global governance. None of this is unacceptable.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it pours too much into the "right of hommism". It is also wrong to call for the Europeanisation of defence while increasingly inferring the EU to NATO. Defence must remain national. France's sovereignty depends on it.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. We voted against this report because this report does not reflect the Union's negative and growing role in current conflicts (southern and eastern neighbouring countries); and because it advocates intensified defence cooperation and greater military integration through the European Defence Agency. In addition, it proposes greater militarization and strengthening of EU-NATO cooperation, and supports the industrial and technological base of European defence (BITDE) and NATO's goal of increasing defence spending.
