We do not agree that military expenditure should be financed with funding from the Union budget, not counting that it is also insisted on strengthening NATO's European pillar and that the Member States of the Union live up to their commitments to it, and supports the tactical groupings of the Union, the NATO Response Forces and their combination, as well as the permanently grouped multi-national military units. We also object because the report emphasizes the merger of internal and external security, as well as the subordination of trade, development and energy policy under the CFSP/CSDP.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. In this report, Parliament would like to stress the need for the Union to act as a single player in the complex global environment. Today, the crises and problems we face cannot be tackled alone from the Member States, but rather joint strategies adopted within the Union are required. In this connection, from Parliament we urge the Union to advocate concerted action on matters of such caliber as common security and defence, the climate crisis or the refugee drama. Therefore, my vote on this report will be favourable.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The own-initiative report by Sandra Kalniete reflects the intentions of the Eu Commission to deepen and consolidate a military dimension for the EU. Security is an essential condition for a stable and prosperous Europe. However, the rapporteur's position raises the possibility of creating a new, possibly redundant, security organisation alongside the national defence policy of each Member State as a sovereign task and already existing security structures, such as .B the OSCE and NATO. That is why I did not vote in favour of this report.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. The report supports the creation of a European military structure. I support the principle of unanimous decision-making on military actions as contained in the NATO Treaty and for bilateral military cooperation. I therefore do not support any steps to make joint decisions on military actions. The joint decision on migration and asylum is a warning to us.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. The resolution refers to promoting the European Union's objective of defending its citizens, societies and values, stabilising the wider neighbourhood and strengthening multilateral global governance and cooperation. The EU needs to be a constructive global actor that is regionally focused and has the necessary civilian and military resources. I supported the resolution because it underlines the need to improve cooperation with global and regional actors in the fight against global threats.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the EU in a raging global environment – a more connected, controversial and complex world, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 12/4/2016, and because this report is not complete and documented.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EU report in a changing global context - A more connected, contested and complex world. The promotion of peace, values, the well-being of the population, the security of citizens and the territory are all priorities for the European Union, which is increasingly facing a series of complex and interconnected challenges and threats, which involve strong solidarity between the Member States, since the threats made against individual States must in fact be seen as threats to the Union itself. A link between the various local, regional and global contexts, joint action between the European Union and the Member States to respond efficiently to challenges, to safeguard the Union's own values and to contribute to common security, is of prime importance.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. The international environment is becoming more and more complicated every day. The EU must adapt to a changing situation almost every day and also equip itself with the means and tools needed to maintain a global leadership role. My support for the Union report in a global environment in mutation: a more connected, disputed and complex world, which largely reflects the position we should take in this situation.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. In the wake of the 13 November attacks, François Hollande, hoping to win the support of other states to wage his wars in Mali and Syria, has mostly reopened debates on community defence. The German Minister Of Schauble hastened to open Pandora's box. The European Parliament and the Commission are seized on this opportunity to advance step by step the idea of a European army allied to NATO. Starting with the increase in the budget and competences of the European Defence Agency.  A "research company" that decides on its own the scenarios of conflict and the strategies to be implemented to do so. The report seeks to develop this transfer of powers even though defence is a jurisdiction described by treaties as exclusive to states. The bottom line is damning: "the United States is the Eu's main strategic partner", energy the means of nuisance to Russia, migrants of terrorists and the United Nations just an analysis body.  France has a master card. It alone has the expertise, staff and facilities to initiate another foreign policy in Europe. In the meantime, I oppose any army in the service of this policy of tension.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The idea of this report stems from Western imperialism. It is about imposing our style of democracy on nations in the name of human rights. The tremendous desire for interference outlined in this report is coupled with a submission to Atlanticism through the strengthening of the EU-NATO link. As a result I spoke out against text

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. The objective of the European Union is to promote peace, its values and the well-being of its peoples, while ensuring the security of its citizens and its territory.  The EU must therefore ensure its internal and external resilience, its ability to anticipate, prevent and solve foreseeable challenges and threats, be prepared to take swift action on unpredictable crises and also ensure its ability to recover from different types of attacks, as well as safeguard security of supply in terms of energy and raw materials , while taking into account the effects of climate change, which need to be addressed urgently, and the EU should take a leading role in global climate action and the promotion of sustainable development.  In such a volatile and random international environment, the EU must have strategic autonomy to ensure its security and promote its interests and values.  Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I want the EU to truly act as a global player on the world stage. I therefore supported this resolution on a more engaged European Union which will help to stabilise the European neighbourhood and lead to strengthened multilateral global governance.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of this report, which puts the European Union's primary missions at the heart of the concerns. The preservation and defence of peace, humanist and European values, the promotion of global governance, concerned with international law and the stabilisation of the immediate neighbourhood, are in line with an ambitious and hopeful European policy.  It is all the more essential to reformulate them vigorously as the threats to all Member States and the many challenges they face require each of them to show solidarity, cohesion and coherence in their actions. Both the terrorist threat and the migration crisis, financial crime or cybernetics call on the European Union to provide a structured and comprehensive response, to intensify defence and security cooperation and to position itself as a strategic, effective and indispensable international actor and partner.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – Europe is facing a changed security situation in recent months. Most of the threats identified in the 2003 European Security Strategy — terrorism, proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, regional conflicts, state failure and organised crime — remain up to date, despite the fact that 13 years have passed since its designation. Moreover, other problems were added that no one was counting on at the time. The strategy should be revised more frequently, providing a completely different view of current threats and the security environment, while allowing effective and timely action to be taken that new situations will require. I am critical of the fact that the Commission has failed to fulfil its tasks entrusted to it by the European Council in 2013 in relation to the planned comprehensive EU-wide security of supply regime, the planned Green Paper on the control of defence and sensitive security industrial capabilities, the monitoring of defence and security procurement, as well as interstate sales in the defence sector.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. Europe faces numerous challenges, such as combating terrorism, organised crime, migration flows, regional conflicts, among others. These realities pose serious challenges to common security and so they require swift and concerted action. In view of promoting its objectives and values, the EU must play a role in promoting peace and security and stability for its citizens.  The EU's foreign and security policy is based on the preservation of international peace and security, the promotion of international cooperation, as well as the development and consolidation of democracy, the rule of law, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. To this end, the EU should adopt a coherent and concerted strategy so that it has the capacity to anticipate, prevent and solve emerging challenges and threats.  To this end, I am voting in favour of this report, as I consider it essential to delineate a common strategy that promotes an effective and effective response to the challenges facing the EU, in particular with regard to security.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This snoring report aims to pave the way for a strong political ambition for the EU as an international player, and to increase its security and defence powers at the expense of Member States (nationalisation of losses, Europeanisation of profits) in the face of the "deterioration of its immediate strategic environment". But should we remind the EU that has threw oil on the fire of its immediate environment, if not it, to serve foreign interests to its Member States? Who creates a huge call for air by encouraging migrants to come to Europe, making the situation worse? The Europe of defence, an old sea snake that has been crawling since the 1950s, is another European fad. What would a European army have done during the war in Iraq, when 90% of the Member States were in favour of intervention? I have therefore decided to vote against this text.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which sets out the EU’s foreign policy strategy for the years ahead, noting particular complex and interrelated challenges such as the refugee crisis, state failures and climate change.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. The reference in this report to a common defence policy that will eventually lead to a common European defence is not acceptable. In a European Union that must be a Europe of nations, which respects the national sovereignty of each Member State, defence policy must remain a national competence. That is why I abstained in the vote on this report.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Kalniete report.  The report is divided into four main parts: defending Europe's states, societies and values - the Union's primary objective is to ensure the security of its citizens and territory, while preserving its values and model of society and defending its fundamental interests; stabilizing Europe's neighbourhood at large - the Union must shoulder its responsibilities by filling the security gap in its neighbourhood and among our neighbours and respect its enlargement commitments; becoming a more present player in a multipolar world - the Union should aspire to become a "decision maker" that establishes effective rules of global multilateral governance, for which it is necessary to strengthen cooperation with regional actors on global threats, to maintain a comprehensive approach to foreign policy (building synergies between different "external policies") , but also to build it on the fundamental principles and interests of the Union; interact - the EU, national parliaments and European citizens; Parliament calls for the introduction of a revision clause (every five years) and stresses the importance of the European Parliament and national parliaments, which should provide joint control.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the increasing global geopolitical precariousness, the deterioration and systematic crisis situation in areas of immediate European strategic interest and the complexity of the causes of this continuing instability, we are voting in favour of the Kalniete report. The proximity of the regions affected by the conflicts, the common nature of the threats, both inside and outside the borders of the European Union, and the interconnection of the historic challenges to which the European people are exposed require, in fact, a holistic approach that is deeply and unifiedly European. The violence in Europe has revealed the weakness and ineffectiveness of individual and non-shared measures and the consequent need for greater coordination at European level. Migration crises, security threats and the urgent need to stabilise neighbouring countries, which are closely linked, go beyond the national borders of individual Member States. The change and disturbances affecting the international scene indeed require a strengthening of the role played by the European Union in the field of foreign policy. On the international stage, therefore, the European Union must emerge as a credible and decisive player capable of effectively guaranteeing regional peace.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. The attacks in Brussels on 22 March demonstrated once again the importance of further developing European security. The adoption of the NRP is another step in the right direction. The High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Common Security is responsible for the conduct of European security policy, but the European Parliament has a role to play.  As such, I voted in favour of this report, which sets out Parliament's contribution to the High Representative's security strategy. We thus make the defence of the States, societies and values of the Union our priorities, at the same time as stabilizing the Union's neighbourhood and strengthening the Union's presence in a multipolar world.  Finally, since the defence of the Union and the search for security cannot be carried out in an opaque manner, the resolution calls for better interaction between the European Parliament on the one hand, and national parliaments and European citizens on the other.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the report, which is Parliament's contribution to the report drawn up last year by the European External Action Organisation, the Union's overall foreign and security policy strategy. The EU faces a major challenge, its threat is complex and the situation needs a thoughtful strategy. I agree that preserving the Union's achievements, values and social model is a serious task that no Member State can solve alone. The threats identified in the 2003 strategy have not only remained timely, but have multiplied and become much more complex. If we are to achieve peace, we must acknowledge that without compromise and cooperation, this is difficult to achieve. We need to increase the Union's influence on the international stage, for which internal unity is essential. I support the idea that the Union needs a more independent engagement, and therefore the common security policy needs to be reassessed towards stronger strategic autonomy and increased defence capabilities and capacities, in cooperation with NATO. I believe that the report is good political guidance, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ To defend the European Union’s people, and its states, societies and values is one of the top priorities of the EU. I have voted for this report that should improve the EU’s strategy by identifying and prioritising threats and challenges, defining a response to the situation and determining the necessary resources for implementation.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ Given the ever increasing volatile regional security environment I support this timely resolution, as it emphasises the urgency of setting out a shared EU global strategy.  As the resolution stresses, no member state can alone respond to the many security challenges we face today at home and abroad. Thus, a shared EU global strategy with a clear analysis of a wider set of threats to European society and in turn formulated responses to such threats should be a priority to identify. For the EU to become an influential global actor a unified voice is required.  Speaking from a common foreign and security policy platform is therefore necessary for the EU to globally retain political credibility, allowing it to be an instrument of diplomacy by spreading the values of democracy, good governance, peace, stability, the rule of law and the protection of human rights outside EU borders.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. Following the adoption by the EU of a European security strategy, identifying a series of threats to the UNION's security interests, this report endorses the strengthening of security measures and proposes the strengthening of the Union's defence capabilities. Despite some positive elements on the defence of human rights and the values of the Union, the report supports an advanced militarisation of Europe, with increases in member states' budgets for the military, to the detriment of other policies, and considers among other things that the USA is the main strategic partner of the EU, all of which have founded my vote against this report.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – Further military integration is not the right way to address existing and new problems. I do not think it is appropriate to develop European intelligence and EU military staff, as well as to improve European intelligence exchanges and to develop truly European intelligence and forecasting capabilities with an appropriate surveillance mechanism. It should be noted that the creation of common defence forces and the formulation of a common defence policy are aimed at moving towards a European Defence Union and ultimately establishing a European army. There are doubts as to whether increasing the EU's military capabilities will not violate the sovereign rights of the Member States in the same way, or whether it will strengthen the EU's role as a global actor. It should be noted that defence issues are discussed at national level or on the basis of membership of the North Atlantic Alliance. Therefore, member states cannot be required to increase spending and defence forces and to take greater responsibility for building the EU's urgently needed capabilities and to contribute to the EU's strategic autonomy.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the ROLE of the EU "in a mutant global environment" is a war call by the representatives of the chapter on the intensity of the EU's military aggression to defend and broaden the positions of the monopolies it serves throughout the planet.  It called on the EU to increase its military capabilities by strengthening the 'European Technological and Industrial Defence Base', the forces of the Euro-army and the 'battlegroups', and their development into 'joint multinational military units' integrated into a common 'European Defence Union', even reiterating the proposal for a 'permanent EU military headquarters' as a first step. It calls for the promotion of military cooperation between its Member States, to strengthen cooperation with NATO and to order military forces in support of it, but also for autonomous military operations.  Member States are also called upon to make 2% of GDP available for war spending, in line with a NATO decision. All this in order for the EU to multiply its military operations and wars around the world, using every pretext. The EU and NATO are wolf alliances, enemies of the peoples. Their interest and duty is to fight to get their hands on the power and wealth they produce, free from the chains of monopolies and their associations.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP completely rejects any notion of an EU foreign or defence policy. We firmly believe that both historic and contemporary security within Europe is best secured through NATO. This report was filled with calls for greater development of the EU’s role in these policy areas, including the establishment of common EU forces, an EU military HQ and greater alignment of Member State foreign policy to suit the EU’s interests. With regard to paragraph 6, UKIP is fully committed to the 2% defence spending pledge, to which we are obliged to uphold through our NATO membership and the current government have committed themselves to.  There is no need for the EU to make any encouragements or statements in this area, as such we rejected its inclusion in the report.  Defence of the realm is the sovereign duty of the state and the whole review process of the EU’s new Global Strategy, to which this report is linked, represents the further erosion of Member State sovereignty.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the European Union is currently facing threats from both internal and external actors on the EU's borders, that these threats require a unified and effective response, aimed at safeguarding the principles and values of the Union and that in defending the States and people living in them, the Member States must cooperate with each other and also focus on improving relations with the countries of the neighbourhood policy. Furthermore, given that a greater connection with the United States and NATO is necessary to deal with global threats, I voted in favour.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. ‒ It was time for the European Parliament to give a strong message on how to further develop the EU project. The world needs an EU capable of delivering on global challenges and counterbalance the multipolar world. Most importantly being a political project able to provide not only peace but also security to its citizens, create stable relations with its neighbours and engage citizens to actively participate in caring for the values of the EU.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒I support the objective of the European Union's new global strategy for a comprehensive foreign and security policy that enhances its consistency and improves coordination between institutions and Member States. Development is not possible without security. Likewise, safety is not possible without development.  I agree that development policy should be an important part of the EU's global strategy for foreign and security policy. I believe that achieving the SDGs, in particular those promoting good governance, human rights, democracy and justice, combating poverty, combating inequalities and social exclusion, tackling unemployment and removing barriers to sustainable economic growth for the benefit of all residents, and improving health and education, contributes to addressing the root causes of ongoing migration challenges.  I agree that we must consider threats of various types targeting individual Member States as threats to the whole Union and I urge strong solidarity and unity between Member States.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report takes the pretext of the current developments in the world, the tensions and crises taking place there, to call, unsurprisingly, to build a federal Europe whose defence policy and diplomacy would be entirely subservient to NATO. For my part, I defend a free, sovereign France, determined to defend the interests of the French people in the face of any external power. It is therefore obviously not a question for me to support a text with such harmful and obsolete ideology, not at all up to the challenges of the contemporary world. So I'm voting against it.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I consider it a priority for the Union to strengthen its action in the field of foreign policy by identifying the interests shared by all 28 Member States in every region of the world and in every relevant policy area. The global challenges we face today pose the need for coherent and structured cooperation in defence research, the industrial base and cyber defence through the pooling of data, resources and good practices, in order to use national defence budgets more efficiently. I also support the importance of urging the Commission to achieve the objectives designated in 2013 for a comprehensive security regime, as well as to set up joint defence forces to improve military crisis management capacity and ensure emergency planning. Eu-NATO cooperation must therefore be strengthened, which should ensure coordination between operations and support interventions beyond the EU's borders. Finally, the Union must commit itself to filling the security gap in neighbouring areas and creating conditions of stability in line with its values, addressing the causes of current conflicts, migratory flows and the refugee crisis.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒Strong political will and leadership is needed for decisive joint action between the EU and the Member States to respond proactively, jointly and effectively to challenges, protect EU values and social model, and to turn the EU into an effective stakeholder with a more elaborate strategy and to contribute to security on the international stage.  The European Union should urgently take all necessary measures against strategic environmental degradation and its long-term consequences. In order to build stability and peace and promote people's security, the rule of law, respect for human rights and democratisation, commitments to enlargement and integration should be respected, based on policies advocating economic growth and the inclusion of society.  I regret that there is still no regulatory framework for corporations to respect human rights and obligations in relation to social and environmental standards, allowing certain countries and businesses to circumvent them with impunced.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. The report presents an extensive set of justifications for the need to deepen the strengthening of European militarism and EU security policy. It addresses the changes that the world has experienced in recent years and the supposed new threats to which the EU is subject. It calls for the overcoming of interinstitutional barriers so that threats are overcome, i.e. deepening harmonisation and the federalist aspect of the EU. It advocates strengthening investment in the different European security-related sectors and increasing support for the European military complex, paving the way for the creation of EU military forces. It advocates increased investment by Member States in Defence. Advocate complementarity and cooperation, read subservience, with NATO, defining it and the US as key strategic partners. He advocates un reform.  It links the militaristic and security posture to the consolidation of the Energy Union. It understems EU migration policy, FRONTEX action and the establishment of the European Coast and Border Guard. It supports the strengthening of Schengen, the logic of "Fortress Europe" and the EU Neighbourhood Policy. Policies and stances contrary to the construction of policies of solidarity, cooperation and peace, with respect for the sovereignty of states.   We voted against it.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of the events of recent years, I voted in favour of the report on the EU's position in a changing world. European integration has always been a process that brought peace and stability in Europe. However, given the EU's role in the global world, it is its duty not only to ensure the security of its citizens, but also to promote peace and values in external relations, thus contributing constructively to global security and cooperation. The challenges we face every day in the EU show that we must not only behave in a reactive way, but, on the contrary, we must be prepared to prevent diverse crises. To do this, however, it is necessary to find agreement across the Union. We should prove that the EU, as an actor in international relations, is capable of shaping world development. However, in order to achieve this, it is necessary to take greater responsibility for one's own safety. For this reason, I welcome the reference to the urgent need to develop our own capacities and to explore possibilities for effective cooperation in accordance with common principles and solidarity.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 In this very difficult international situation, where several conflicts are taking place near the borders of the European Union, it is very right for the European Parliament to adopt a report summarizing what is our unifying element. The report recalls that the European Union's objective is to promote the peace and democratic values on which the EU is built and to promote the well-being of its people, while ensuring the security of its citizens within the EU. I would like to stress the importance of the requirement that the EU should ensure the security of energy and raw materials supply, while taking into account the consequences of climate change, which need to be addressed urgently, with the EU playing a leading role in the global response to this change and in promoting sustainable development.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Sandra Kalniete's report reflects in many ways the European Commission's intentions to create a military dimension to the EU. One paragraph states that 'the main objective should be to move towards permanent multinational troops and voluntary joint defence forces and to form a Community defence policy which should ultimately lead to Community defence'. Defence policy should remain a sovereign issue for Member States and no action should be taken to enhance the EU's role in this area. NATO remains the cornerstone of European security. For this reason, I abstained.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's contribution to the EU's new comprehensive security strategy, led by Federica Mogherini, THE EU's High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. In defence, we call on the EU to strengthen its autonomy, in addition to NATO's policy areas.  Stabilizing Europe's neighbourhood, in the broadest sense, must also be a priority. Moreover, making the European Union and its Member States more present in a multipolar world, marked by constant threats, must be strongly recalled. Finally, interaction at all levels (the Union, national parliaments and citizens) will be the condition for the success of this new comprehensive strategy.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP completely rejects any notion of an EU foreign or defence policy. We firmly believe that both historic and contemporary security within Europe is best secured through NATO. This report was filled with calls for greater development of the EU’s role in these policy areas, including the establishment of common EU forces, an EU military HQ and greater alignment of Member State foreign policy to suit the EU’s interests. With regard to paragraph 6, UKIP is fully committed to the 2% defence spending pledge, to which we are obliged to uphold through our NATO membership and the current government have committed themselves to.  There is no need for the EU to make any encouragements or statements in this area, as such we rejected its inclusion in the report.  Defence of the realm is the sovereign duty of the state and the whole review process of the EU’s new Global Strategy, to which this report is linked, represents the further erosion of Member State sovereignty.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. Many of the threats and challenges facing the EU are complex, related to each other, come from state and non-state actors and originate both within and outside common borders. This report states that the EU's objective is to promote peace, its values and the well-being of its peoples, while ensuring the security of its citizens and its territory. In order to address this changing global environment, the report states that the strategy must be to identify and prioritise threats and challenges, define responses and determine the necessary means. Furthermore, it stresses that the borders of each Member State are the borders of the Union and should therefore be defended, stressing that development is not possible without security and that there can be no security without development.  In view of the above, I voted in favour.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. The EU must be an actor capable of dealing with a changing world with permanent security challenges. Member States should work in synergy, developing their defence capabilities and cooperate more effectively.  The EU needs to be more active in its neighbourhood and be able to prevent and manage crises and conflicts that pose challenges to the security of its citizens.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. There are many challenges facing the Union, both present and future, complex and interrelated, stem from state and non-State actors, and come from within and outside common borders, so local, regional and global contexts need to be connected in order to respond proactively to them. The need to establish strong solidarity among Member States to address these threats, as well as strong political will and a common objective among States, is presented as indispensable. We consider it important that arms control and Common Position 2008/944/CFSP focus on human security. In addition, the EU must take a central role in global climate action and the promotion of sustainable development.  With regard to the refugee crisis, we support the need for a joint European approach and concerted and urgent action and solution. We believe that Member States should work together, developing their defence capabilities and pooling them, in order to manage and prevent the crises and conflicts that arise and ensure the safety of EU citizens. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. This report, entitled 'The European Union in a Changing Global Environment - a more connected, more contested and more complex world', is the European Parliament's contribution to the EU's new overall security strategy that the Vice-President/High Representative was tasked with drawing up last summer by the European Council.  This report aims to: defend Europe's states, societies and values - the Union's primary objective is to ensure the security of its citizens and territory, while preserving its values and model of society and defending its fundamental interests; - stabilise Europe's neighbourhood at large (the Union must fulfil its responsibilities by filling the security gap in its neighbourhood and among our neighbours and respect its enlargement commitments); - become a more present player in a multipolar world - the Union should aspire to become a 'decision maker' who establishes effective rules of global multilateral governance, for which it is necessary to strengthen cooperation with regional actors on global threats and, finally, to interact more with national parliaments and European citizens.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I could not support the under-drafted report. It also leaves it unclear how different external policies should be combined. The question of how a comprehensive approach should be implemented is therefore unanswered. Among other things, it does not contain new and clear ideas even in the field of defence. It is often repeated what has already been adopted or decided last year.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which is the European Parliament's contribution to the revision of the EU's Comprehensive Strategy on Foreign and Security Policy to be presented by the High Representative in June.  It is crucial that the Union identifies and affirms its strategic interests on the international stage.  The Priority of the Union must be the stabilisation of crises in its neighbourhood. Indeed, the Union must become more involved in its neighbourhood in order to guarantee its security. As such, I have supported this text which calls for the Union and the Member States to improve their defence capabilities and spend at least 2% of GDP on defence spending by 2024. It is essential that the Union enjoys greater strategic autonomy and develops a genuine European intelligence capability.  It is necessary to remember that the Union has set itself the goal of being the world leader in multilateral governance and respect and promotion of international law. It must continue to promote effective multilateralism based on the rules of law.  In view of the rapidly changing challenges facing the Union, this text calls for the strategy to be revised every five years.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted against an initiative that advocates an alarmist, ultra-securitarian and warmongering approach to international relations, which bases the EU's policies and actions towards peace and security on global arms escalation (making the objectives of radicalisms and extremism functional) and the alliance with countries that have promoted wars and provoked and fuelled the emergence of threats to combat. on the contrary, we advocate a collaborative and humanistic approach to comprehensive, comprehensive international relations of the structural causes of conflicts (unequal exchange relations, willingness to hoard and exploit primary resources of developing countries by highly industrialized countries), and a full review of international relations and their institutions in compliance with international regulations , as the main pillars for peace and human security in Europe and the world.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. We voted against this report because this report does not reflect the Union's negative and growing role in current conflicts (southern and eastern neighbouring countries); and because it advocates intensified defence cooperation and greater military integration through the European Defence Agency. In addition, it proposes greater militarization and strengthening of EU-NATO cooperation, and supports the industrial and technological base of European defence (BITDE) and NATO's goal of increasing defence spending.  We do not agree that military expenditure should be financed with funding from the Union budget, not counting that it is also insisted on strengthening NATO's European pillar and that the Member States of the Union live up to their commitments to it, and supports the tactical groupings of the Union, the NATO Response Forces and their combination, as well as the permanently grouped multi-national military units. We also object because the report emphasizes the merger of internal and external security, as well as the subordination of trade, development and energy policy under the CFSP/CSDP.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I ultimately voted in favour of this report because I think that the EU can play – and has played – a real and positive international role, capable of shaping development and deal with a rapidly changing global environment. However, I did not support Paragraph 10, along with my Labour colleagues, because I believe that now is not the right time for an ‘EU Army’ or similar and that the way that military organisation is at present does not warrant this to be necessary.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution is advocating, besides other topics, for the European Union as a military power. Furthermore, it tries to limit the influence of Member States and disrespects the subsidiarity principle. Therefore, I voted against.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I did not support this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Many current and future challenges and threats to the EU are complex and interlinked, coming from state and non-state actors, both within and outside common borders, strong political will and leadership are needed, leading to strong joint action to be plurally proactive, jointly and effectively responding to these challenges, protecting the EU's values and social model. The EU faces many threats – terrorism, organised crime, regional conflicts, ... That is why the EU's objective must be to promote peace, its values and the well-being of the people, while ensuring the security of its citizens and territory. In order to be able to address the changing global environment, the EU's strategy must be based on identifying and prioritising threats and challenges, defining responses to these threats and challenges, and identifying the necessary means. The EU must continue its efforts to promote development and resilience in its neighbourhood and to strengthen these efforts in areas that are crucial to the EU's interests. The global strategy should be revised every five years in cooperation with the new EP and the new Commission, which would make it possible to verify that its objectives and priorities still correspond to threats and the security environment.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. Europe is globally exposed to a number of complex challenges and threats that are interconnected. The report looks at the European Union's global strategy, which must be based on identifying threats and challenges and prioritising them, defining responses to them and identifying the necessary resources. There is talk of a very general idea of a common defence policy, which would provide for some contributions from the EU budget and some budgetary criteria for defence as in NATO. There is little concrete hint in the report on specific policy areas and on how to link the different areas of foreign policy. The question of a comprehensive approach and on the implementation of it remains unanswered. Individual countries and regions are only partially mentioned. The following matters should be deepened: the international order (e.g. multilateral for a, relations with the UN, AU, ASEAN, WTO, etc.) and the EU's role in this regard, the need to integrate partners, promote cooperation and spread universal norms and values. Other important aspects that should be taken into account are the human rights situation in the new global strategy, the importance of the criminal justice approach in the fight against terrorism and the need to create a regional security structure similar to the KSCE. For this is why I voted against the report.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. The own-initiative report by Sandra Kalniete reflects the intentions of the Eu Commission to deepen and consolidate a military dimension for the EU. Security is an essential condition for a stable and prosperous Europe. However, the rapporteur's position raises the possibility of creating a new, possibly redundant, security organisation alongside the national defence policy of each Member State as a sovereign task and already existing security structures, such as .B the OSCE and NATO. That is why I did not vote in favour of this report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 Many current and future threats to the EU are complex and interlinked, originating from state and non-state actors, and therefore strong political will and ability to act proactively is needed on the part of the EU and its Member States. Today, the EU faces many serious and unforeseen challenges, such as the efforts of revisionist powers to rewrite borders by force by violating international law, and to oppose the rules-based world order, climate change, sluggish economic growth, large flows of migrants and refugees, and the biggest refugee crisis since World War II, as well as technological development in space and cybernetics, financial crimes , nuclear proliferation and arms race, hybrid and asymmetric warfare. In order for the EU to be able to act globally and face these threats, a more effective management of regional security, a willingness to cooperate and overcome institutional obstacles are a prerequisite, and the allocation of sufficient and flexible financial resources is a matter of course.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒Many of the current and future challenges and threats to the EU are complex and interconnected and originate from state and non-state actors, both inside and outside common borders, and strong political will and leadership are needed for collective action by the European Union and the Member States. An effective response to challenges and threats to protect European values and the social model of the European Union is important.  Terrorism, regional conflicts and organised crime, as well as many other threats and challenges, in particular the current migrant crisis, requires a swift and effective response based on strong solidarity between Member States, cooperation and sufficient and flexibly applicable budgetary resources. In order to counter global threats and challenges, the European Union strategy must focus on identifying and identifying their priorities, determining appropriate responses to them and determining the necessary resources.  Consequently, I support this report and emphasise the importance of safeguarding European values while ensuring the safety of EU citizens.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, which sets out the EU’s foreign policy strategy for the years ahead, with reference to particularly pertinent challenges such as the refugee crisis, state failures and climate change. I am particularly supportive of the assertion that we need a better link between external and internal EU policy.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The European Union faces many threats and challenges every day. The focus of the threats themselves is difficult to identify in a targeted manner and it is essential to react in a timely manner. Threats come from various actors and from different places. Good communication between the EU institutions and their joint action at regional level and globally is essential to address the problem. Stabilisation and security of the wider neighbourhood across Europe is important. I support the Report on the European Union in a changing global environment. The aim is to jointly protect EU values so that no Member State has to respond to threats alone. Attacks on individual member states are seen as ATTACKS on the whole EU. Over the previous decade, the challenges are very similar: from the threats of terrorism to the climate change that has plagued Europe.  It is essential to respond to all these threats through strong political will and joint efforts by all EU institutions and Member States. Not only EU citizens, but also the whole world benefit from the strong and effective actions of the EU institutions.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the report as I do not agree that the competences of the Member States in the field of defence should be transferred to the European Union. This area should continue to be subject to national sovereignty in cooperation with NATO.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the EU in a changing global environment – a more integrated, conflicted and complex world. The European Union nowadays faces many challenges and threats that are interconnected. If we want to tackle all these challenges seriously, we need uniform, decisive and effective solutions at European Union level. I support the call for the European Union to strengthen consistent and structured cooperation in defence research, industrial base and cyber defence through pooling and sharing and other cooperation projects in order to use national defence budgets more efficiently.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's report on the EU in a changing global environment – a more connected, contested and complex world, which is the European Parliament's contribution to the EU's new global security strategy, prepared by the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. The report assumes that, in order for the EU to fulfil its fundamental tasks, namely to ensure the security of its citizens and to create the conditions for the preservation of a democratic society, national cooperation in the field of foreign and security policy needs to be strengthened, while maintaining transatlantic ties, to strictly promote its interests in the world, to stabilise the regions neighbouring the EU and to reflect the growing role of new technologies in the security field.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 EU foreign policy is currently inextricably linked not to the interests of the peoples, but to monopolistic groups and American imperialism. Our group voted against the report as a whole and submitted a minority opinion with its main views which are complete (and nuclear) disarmament at EU and global level, no financing of military expenditure from the EU budget and that all activities should be strictly limited within the framework of the UN Charter and International Law ,;strict civilian and peaceful approaches to conflict resolution;

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We disagree with the creation of a joint EU military force and its cooperation with NATO as we recognise that the interests of member states differ considerably, while the EU with NATO and the US even more. Strengthening Schengen, the European Border Guard and FRONTEX will further reinforce the threats faced by Member States, as terrorists, by exploiting FRONTEX's free movement and incompetence, have infiltrated the EU and engaged in murderous acts of terrorism. The EU's treatment of Member States must be done with respect for their national sovereignty and with acceptance of their particular characteristics.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this decision because I believe it is important that the High Representative/Vice-President, by decision of the European Council, participates meaningfully and decisively in the preparation of the global strategy to be developed by the High Representative/Vice-President through an independent report by the European Parliament, for which this report provides an excellent basis for this report. It is clear that, in recent years, significant changes in the global environment, new challenges such as terrorism and mass migration have only managed the deterioration of the European Union's specific security environment on the basis of a new, comprehensive and coherent defence and external relations strategy.   I consider the report to be an important element: (a) to push for and help to implement an autonomous European defence system;  (b) lay down the importance of protecting the EU's borders and the responsibility of the Member States in this relation;  (c) considers it important to strengthen the EU's role in content and organisation in multilateral global governance;  (d) points to the urgency of closer and more targeted cooperation between the European Union and other international actors, in particular NATO;  (e) attaches great importance to the implementation of the global strategy in supporting public opinion and political and parliamentary forces.   For my part, as a Member, I consider it particularly important and will continue to push for an increase in the ROLE of the EP in the EU's external relations and defence activities, in the prevention and management of international conflicts and in the supervision of the activities of the USSS in general.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Years of peaceful coexistence are coming to an end. The Union must adapt to a new conflicted and complex reality. Therefore, one of the most important objectives of our global foreign and security policy strategy should, in my view, be to strengthen the EU's defence capabilities. The European Security Strategy, prepared in 2003, described the risks that have partly been overdue, which is why it is so important for the Union to develop a new global strategy that outlines the most important and urgent security challenges.  The European Parliament's report properly outlines the need for action to create a European Defence Union. It can be risky to rely on the United States and NATO forces in the event of so many threats in our immediate neighbourhood. Moreover, the need, highlighted in the document, to focus primarily on the security of the region, rather than dealing with all conflicts, seems most appropriate. Otherwise, the Community may lose credibility. I am pleased that Parliament has proposed such a fair and proper analysis of the European Union in a changing global environment, which is why I have chosen to vote in favour of the report.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 In recent years, the European Union has faced several threats to its own security. A more connected world requires a comprehensive European strategy of participation. We need to think about a strategy that can withstand prolonged crises. There are parts in the report that we can support, such as the need to move towards collective solidarity between Member States in terms of security, the necessary long-term strategy to manage migration crises, the numerous references to sustainable development and respect for human rights as key principles of the security strategy. Despite the positive aspects, there are many critical aspects such as the reference to the need to strengthen cooperation between the EU and NATO and the call for Member States to spend at least 2% of their GDP on military resources. However, there is nothing to do with the efficient use of Europol and nothing about the sharing of information between the investigative agencies. Although some of our amendments have been accepted, the final text is still unacceptable and I therefore voted against it.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ This report draws attention to security challenges for the EU and advocates a more strategic role for the European Union as an international actor. This document stresses the need for the EU and its Member States to take greater responsibility in what concerns their collective security and be more active in Europe’s own neighbourhood, making full use and respect of the Lisbon Treaty provisions. At the same time, it calls on the European Union to make use of diplomatic, economic and all other tools that it has at its disposal to promote security, stability and prosperity. We want an EU that is a real international actor able to shape the developments and deal with a rapidly changing global environment and mounting security challenges. So this report urges the EU Member States to work in synergy, develop their defence capabilities and to pool and share them more effectively. The EU needs to be more active and be capable of preventing and managing crises and conflicts that represent challenges also for the EU citizen’s security. The truth is that the EU can and must do better. For this reason, I support the report.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution proposing elements for a new strategy in this area. The European Union aims to preserve peace, safeguard its values and promote the well-being of its peoples by guaranteeing the safety of its citizens and its territory. The Union must therefore ensure its internal and external resilience, its ability to anticipate, prevent and resolve foreseeable challenges and threats (by being prepared to take swift action in the face of unpredictable challenges and threats) and its ability to recover from different types of attacks, while at the same time preserving its security of energy and raw materials supply and taking into account , to do this, the effects of climate change, which need to be urgently addressed, given that the Union plays a leading role in the global fight against climate change and in aid for sustainable development. A new strategy is therefore essential.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ This report sets out the EU’s new global strategy in light of the new global challenges and security threats. I voted in favour, as I agree that our strategy must be anchored in our fundamental values of peace, well-being and security and carried by a real commitment to implement them. However, we must ensure that these values are inclusive and shared, which has not been the case, as this year’s tragic events have reminded us. While our presence globally is very important, we need to pay particular attention to stabilising Europe’s wider neighbourhood, by standing firm by our values, taking on more responsibility and engaging in constructive partnerships. Strengthening our defence capabilities as well as real intelligence sharing between all members is also essential.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. \u2012 The ongoing economic and political crises have increasingly immediate consequences on EU territory and no Member State can deal with them alone, so Europeans should assume their responsibilities collectively, as enshrined in the Eu ropean Union Treaty. The EU must therefore ensure both internal and external transformation, and institutions need to anticipate, prevent and resolve foreseeable challenges and threats. It is crucial to implement measures that ensure the security of energy supply and raw materials, implement ambitious environmental policies to limit the effects of climate change, promote long-term economic and industrial policies that enable the EU to play a leading role in global action.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ In such a volatile and uncertain environment, the European Union should have strategic autonomy that will enable security and promotion of its own interests and values, and I believe that the security of people must be at the heart of the Global Strategy of the European Union.  However, the Report on the European Union in a changing global environment – a more connected, conflicted and complex world calls on the Institutions of the European Union and the Member States to take a comprehensive, common and holistic approach in their external action in order to ultimately lead to a common defence policy. I believe that each Member State has jurisdiction over its defence policy and that NATO should remain the basis of security and stability in Europe, and for these reasons I voted against this report.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I have supported the report on the EU in a changing global environment – a more integrated, conflicted and complex world, as many of the current and future challenges and threats facing the EU are complex and interconnected, originating both within and outside common borders. It is necessary to link the local, regional and global level, because we need strong political will and leadership to act decisively together on the part of the EU and its Member States if we are to respond proactively, collectively and effectively to these challenges, in order to protect the EU's values and social model and to ensure that the EU is an effective and more strategic player and contributes to global security.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted against an initiative that advocates an alarmist, ultra-securitarian and warmongering approach to international relations, which bases the EU's policies and actions towards peace and security on global arms escalation (making the objectives of radicalisms and extremism functional) and the alliance with countries that have promoted wars and provoked and fuelled the emergence of threats to combat. on the contrary, we advocate a collaborative and humanistic approach to comprehensive, comprehensive international relations of the structural causes of conflicts (unequal exchange relations, willingness to hoard and exploit primary resources of developing countries by highly industrialized countries), and a full review of international relations and their institutions in compliance with international regulations , as the main pillars for peace and human security in Europe and the world.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the report. I am fundamentally convinced that, instead of building European troops, we should strengthen Europe's position in NATO. The creation of new units would also be very difficult from a command point of view. We already have one very functional defense system, so it is completely useless to build parallel.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 In the current geopolitical context, the European Union faces challenges and threats from state and non-state actors, internal and external. Member States and the European Union must show firmness and leadership in order to respond collectively and as effectively as possible, in order to guarantee the safety, values and society model promoted by the EU. I believe that priority should be given to stabilising the EU's immediate neighbourhood, taking into account the threats identified in the 2003 European Security Strategy on terrorism, weapons of mass destruction, regional conflicts, failed states and organised crime, which unfortunately remain largely topical. The vote in favour of the REPORT on the EU in a changing global environment underlines that human security, the defence of peoples, societies and values must be at the heart of the European Union's strategy. Increased cooperation for research in the field of defence and, at the same time, respect for human rights and democratisation must be stended.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. – Many of the current and future challenges and threats facing the European Union stem from complex, interrelated, state and non-state actors. Strong political will and leadership on the part of the Union and its Member States in favour of strong joint action is needed in order to respond proactively, collectively and effectively to these challenges. The Union's overall foreign and security policy strategy should promote this development, defining the political level of the Union's aspirations as an international actor. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. U2012 We voted AGAINST an initiative that advocates an alarmist, ultra-securitarian and warmongering approach to international relations, which bases eu policies and actions towards peace and security on global arms escalation (making the objectives of radicalisms and extremism functional) and on the alliance with countries that have promoted wars and provoked and fuelled the emergence of threats to combat. On the contrary, we advocate a comprehensive collaborative and humanist approach to international relations, integral to the structural causes of conflicts (unequal exchange relations, willingness to hoard and exploit primary resources of developing countries by highly industrialized countries), and a full review of international relations and their institutions in compliance with international regulations , as the main pillars for peace and human security in Europe and the World.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ The report says very little about specific policies areas and how different external policy areas should be linked. In brief, the question about the comprehensive approach and how to implement it remains unanswered. Therefore, I voted against.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about a report by which the European Parliament contributes to the new global security strategy, by ensuring the security of citizens and the territory of the Union, the development of a wider and more stable European neighbourhood policy as well as safeguarding European values and their social model. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: in writing. – This report is disingenuous and self-serving. It is trying to advance misplaced EU ambitions in defence while appropriating aspects of our NATO relationship. It is seeking to claim commendable NATO initiatives as its own (notably the 2% GDP defence spending target). It advances an EU agenda on ‘EU strategic autonomy’; ‘a European intelligence capacity’; integrated military forces; ‘a permanent EU military HQ’; an EU Council of Defence Ministers; and PESCO – all concepts of which we fundamentally disagree. The ECR Group therefore voted against the report.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. This report reflects the European Union's new global strategy in the light of today's global challenges. I voted in favour of this report because the Union must be able to meet the challenges of the future. Strengthening our defence capabilities as well as the exchange of information between intelligence services is essential to our security.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The report on the defence of EU militarisation, enhanced cooperation with NATO and the 2% of GDP defence target. It speaks of strengthening the cooperation and support of the European Defence Industrial and Technological Base and also criticises internal and external security policy and its subordination to the market, development policy, energy policy.  We regret the fact that the report does not reflect the EU's contribution to the negative escalation of conflicts (south and east of the EU), not to criticise military and defence reinforcement policy, nor to strengthen relations with NATO, to strengthen European internal security and EU military bases.  We demand complete disarmament, including nuclear, from the EU at various global levels and that money from the EU budget for military research is not forwarded, that all military activities be carried out under the auspices of the UN and under the values that come in the UN charter, always focusing on civilian solutions to conflict resolution.  We demand the separation of the EU from NATO, as well as the dissolution of NATO.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The report calls, on the one hand, for greater cooperation with NATO and, on the other hand, for member States to link European battlegroups with NATO intervention forces. In the spirit of a European Defence Union, agencies such as the FDFA will also be subsidised by means of the multiannual financial framework. For these reasons, the report must be rejected.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on Europe in a changing international context. The report highlights the old and new challenges for Europe and calls for a strategic role at international level. The report identifies the US as a strategic partner and calls on Europe and its Member States to take greater responsibility for their own security and be more active in foreign policy, making maximum use of the provisions of the Lisbon Treaties on CSDP. I am convinced that the Member States must work in synergy to prevent crises and conflicts in neighbouring countries.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Writing. The report advocates a global EU policy that uses all policy instruments to create a world internal market, promoting connectivity with NATO, relying on an EU military headquarters and promoting integration within the European Defence Agency (EDA). Such priorities are not capable of making the EU a sovereign player on the international stage, particularly free of US and NATO requirements, which is why I voted 'no'.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament resolution of 13 April 2016 on "The EU in a changing global environment – a more interconnected, conflict-ridden and more complex world". The European Parliament suggests that the EU is an independent state with its own foreign policy and security doctrine, its own foreign and defence minister. But it is not. This becomes clear at the latest when the European Parliament criticises those Member States that, in the Council of Foreign Ministers, do not wave through what Brussels is asking for. They are being urged to "show more flexibility" – that is, to put aside legitimate national reservations in favour of the EU. The EU should also continue to make a name for itself in the institutional management of social values and norms. This will certainly not please the African partner countries, because they have been criticising the EU's sovereignty of interpretation over social values and standards in development cooperation for some time. Before such resolutions, the European Parliament should have the courage to ask the peoples of the member states directly whether there is a political will to continue to cede core state powers to unlegitimate EU technocrats. However, the EP deliberately wants to conduct this dialogue unilaterally, because it proposes under the last paragraph to have 'a dialogue on necessity and benefits'. I don't support that.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I thank my Socialist and Democratic colleagues for inserting into this report the important call to include a gender perspective in security, defence, and global governance policies. A perspective on gender equality is often pushed out by chauvinist ‘realpolitik’, and women are often under-represented. The European Union must strive to put peace, human rights, sustainability and social justice at the heart of our developing global governance systems. I regret that the European Parliament has so far failed to take a stand on the important issue of nuclear non-proliferation, arms reduction and multilateral disarmament, since the last NPT Conference in 2015. The EU must seek to engage and advance the ongoing UN initiative on multilateral nuclear disarmament, and the European Parliament must provide the Union’s representatives with a mandate to do so.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I have decided to support this Report of the European Parliament, as I believe that one of the fundamental objectives of the European Union is to promote peace, European values, well-being and security of its people throughout the EU. I consider it essential that the EU be able to ensure its internal and external resilience and be able to anticipate and address the problems and threats of today's increasingly complex world. In this respect, I believe that the European Union must play a leading role in the global response to climate change and be able to address these changes swiftly in order to ensure its energy security. The European Union must become a more credible global actor and take greater responsibility for filling the security vacuum in its near and far neighbourhood.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Union is now facing crises, both external and internal. The main challenges are migration, the situation in Ukraine, but also terrorism, Brexit and the economic situation in many Member States. In order to combat them effectively, long-term solutions should be proposed, not just short-sighted and partial.  In this context, compromise and solidarity are essential above all. The EU must speak with one voice on issues relating to our common security, namely the migration crisis, the conflicts in Ukraine and Syria, or energy security. A stable neighbourhood, as one of the necessary conditions for international security, is a priority. We are experiencing the effects of political instability today in the form of a wave of refugees seeking refuge in Europe. It is therefore necessary to continue to support efforts to ensure conditions conducive to stability and prosperity based on the rule of law and respect for human rights also in the EU's eastern neighbourhood. In addition, coherent cooperation on defence research, industrial base and cyber defence will also be crucial in the coming years. The joint use of military capabilities, particularly multinational military units such as the Eurocorps, will benefit the more efficient use of defence resources, while increasing economies of scale through mutual cooperation. However, achieving such ambitious targets requires proper funding. It is therefore necessary to reflect in the EU budget the priorities contained in the EU Global Strategy.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support Mrs Kalniete's report on the role of the European Union in a changing global environment. Although the report identifies many of the current challenges facing not only the European Union and seeks ways of addressing them in order to stabilise the situation in the European neighbourhood, but also to strengthen cooperation with NATO, it sees one of the main solutions in achieving permanent joint multinational military units, joint defence forces and defining a common defence policy, which should ultimately lead to a European Defence Union. In my opinion, this rhetoric significantly interferes with the competences of the Member States, as defence policy has always been, and should always be, the exclusive competence of the Member States. I therefore do not support such interventions in any way and voted against this report.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Union very often seeks to play a role in global politics that it has not been appointed to. Its creation was motivated from the outset by a desire for closer economic integration and not by a desire to duplicate the role of institutions appointed to deal with military security. Defence issues are an issue at the exclusive disposal of the Member States and should remain so. The attempt to extend the competences of the European institutions to this area is incompatible with the fundamental values on which the EU was built. The only institution that can effectively support European countries in their defence policy-making is the North Atlantic Alliance. It is through close institutional cooperation with the United States that we have military capabilities that are of real value.  I agree with many of the diagnoses made in this report, but I consider the proposed solutions to be wrong. The European Union, which is experiencing an immigration crisis, has no capacity to play a greater role in the development of its members' security policies. The disasters suffered by Member States in the fight against terrorism show that instead of looking for new solutions, we need to draw more experience from our American partners. Instead of multiplying tasks and objectives, we need to better enforce existing rules and carry out more effectively the tasks that we face. I do not agree with the call to increase the EU's role in member states' defence policy, as this will damage the integrity and effectiveness of NATO's action. I voted against this report.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Kalniete report, which calls for a renewed role for the European Union on the international stage. We need an EU that is more active in its neighbourhood and able to prevent and manage crises more effectively. The European Union must ally itself with strategic partners of international importance, but it also has an obligation to do more and better in synergy with its own Member States to respond to global security, climate change and sustainable development challenges.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. The EU's foreign and security policy is facing a number of challenges from the refugee, humanitarian and security crisis. I supported the report on the EU in a changing global environment – a more integrated, conflicted and complex world, because I agree on the need to protect European society and values, stabilise the wider Neighbourhood of the Union and strengthen cooperation with citizens, civil society, industry and local and regional authorities in establishing a stronger framework for Europe's security.

name: Tatjana ŽDANOKA
text: – Mr President, I would like to explain why I abstained in the vote on this resolution. I could not vote against, since I do agree with the main idea of the report that the EU needs a coherent and consistent approach towards the Central Asia region in order to avoid any overlapping or sending out mixed and confusing signals. But I could not vote in favour either, for the reason that the report is, to my regret, coherent and consistent in adopting the western tradition of trying to teach the whole world how it should live, disregarding objective distinctions between nations and cultures and without showing sufficient respect for the partners. In my capacity as Vice-Chair of the Central Asia Partnership and Cooperation Committee, I prefer to depart from this tradition and opt for mutually-respectful intercultural dialogue.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – I supported this report, on the contrary, I think it is good that this report contains aspects that affect respect for human rights in the Central Asian region. On the one hand, this is a promising region for us, with which we must cooperate and we should want to cooperate, on the other hand, it is right that not only the economic aspects of our cooperation are oversteered, but that we will also make it clear that, in addition to the economic aspects, there are other aspects just like human rights. The debate that is being held here in Parliament is also being conducted in some Member States, as well as in the Czech Republic, where we are now having a very intense debate after the Chinese President visited the Czech Republic. Whether only the economy is important in international relations or even intangible aspects. I believe that it is the intangible aspects that are as important as the economic ones. That is why I supported the report. It is necessary to support and cooperate with these countries, but to draw attention to their problems.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Although Central Asia is territorially close enough to Europe, for example, compared to South America, unfortunately, over the last couple of decades, this region has not received enough attention from the European Union. It can be said that only, in view of the aspect of my country, Latvia, and the Latvian Presidency, thanks to the Council of Europe, the European Union's policy in the region has come to a little life.
