It is a fact that this region is historically, economically and politically largely influenced by Moscow or Beijing. But that doesn't mean we don't have the opportunity to take our share. The entire region is a deeply rooted country with principles of the development of public administration, the beginnings of which, incidentally, are centuries old — much older than the same central Asia being part of the Soviet Union. I generally support this report, but I would like to add that much remains to be done in the region. Thank you!

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU's interest in establishing bilateral and multilateral relations with Central Asian countries begins in 2007, with the development of a complex and comprehensive strategy. In 2015, the European institutions embarked on a long review process. All key issues, such as respect for human rights, economic integration and energy cooperation, have been renewed in an organic and coherent manner. Among the main objectives, we find the increase in funds allocated to the development of the region, education and the enhancement of the specificities of the territory, as well as support for the renewable energy sector and energy efficiency. I have chosen to vote in favour, believing that the strategy is positive and in harmony with the EU's fundamental values and principles, which are given due attention in the same way as economic interests.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. U2012 We are against this report, because validation of EU foreign policy continues, supported by an interference and interference approach to third countries that has as its main objective the achievement of conditions favourable to the interests of large financial groups over the economies and well-being of these countries, particularly in the areas of energy. Interference that forces them to comply with structural reforms. We voted against it because this report is in line with the EU's ambition for geopolitical and economic domination in that part of the world as well.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as it is part of the European Union's wider effort to expand its relations with Central Asian countries since they have important security and energy interests. This effort should under no circumstances be made at the expense of democratic values.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. I voted against this report: foreign policy is a competence of states. The EU needs not add confusion in an already unstable area such as Central Asia.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I want the United Kingdom to be out of the European Union, and consequently voted against this report.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing. – The European Parliament stresses the strong strategic, political and economic interest of the EU in strengthening its bilateral and multilateral relations with all the Central Asian countries, on the basis of common shared values as stated in the existing Partnership and Cooperation Agreements between the EU and Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan. The European Parliament also reiterates the EU’s strong interest in a prosperous, peaceful, democratic, stable, and inclusive Central Asia that functions as an economically and environmentally sustainable region, as stated in the strategy of 2007.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP completely rejects any notion of an EU foreign or defence policy. Friendly relations and trade with Central Asia is something to be supported and encouraged, however we do not believe that the EU should have any role in doing this and take the view that an independent Britain would be able to pursue friendly relations far more effectively outside the EU.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. By taking on this prerogative of the Member States, which is foreign policy, the EU has shown that it plays the role of a force of subversion and destabilization, as shown by the various developments of its "Eastern Partnership"... mainly directed against the Russian Federation. The EU therefore does not have to add confusion in an area as fragile as Central Asia.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. In 2007, the European Union strengthened relations with Central Asian countries (Kazakhstan, Kyrgyz Republic, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan) with the aim of strengthening ties and cooperating in the face of common threats and challenges. In 2012, the publication of a follow-up report supported the relevance of this strategy between these countries and the European Union.  I voted in favour of this new implementation because I think it is essential to have diplomatic relations that find stability over time and offer greater pacifism for the Member States. This mutual commitment is also important on security issues, which are now taking a large place in meetings between European and Asian actors.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the collapse of the Soviet Union, Central Asia has assumed crucial importance within the international scene, becoming a zone of contention between Russian and Chinese influence. A crossroads of cultures, religions and ethnic groups, the region and its five countries are now witnessing a number of shortcomings in respect for human rights and the rule of law, as well as a dangerous spread of Islamic extremism, which is attracting more and more resources and people to Daesh. The European Union has a strong strategic interest of a political, economic and social nature in promoting stable relations with the states of the region, promoting economic, infrastructural and rights development throughout the region. The review of the EU-Central Asia strategy is, in this context, an important step towards improving diplomatic relations and accompanying the process of democratic transition affecting the region, paying particular attention to the issues of forced labour and child labour.  Because of an error in registration, I was unable to vote, but I nevertheless stated my intention to vote in favour of the Meszerics report.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of a report focusing mainly on the human rights situation in Central Asia (and not on trade aspects, as is often the case in such texts), noting in it the major problems to which the EU must contribute: democratic deficit, repression of human rights defenders and journalists, child labour , gender gap, basic service deficit and environmental deterioration. The text also rightly points to Europe's responsibility for arms exports, and in the necessary collaboration in the fight against radicalism and drug trafficking.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report concerns the implementation and revision of the EU's Central Asia strategy. I objected to this report because foreign policy must remain a prerogative of states. The EU is generally a force for subversion and destabilization, as the various developments in the Eastern Partnership have shown.  It adds confusion here in an already fragile area. The EU in this report uses every opportunity to legitimise itself. For example, it uses the ecological alibi to legitimise its international role or it welcomes its enhanced cooperation programme, which is tantamount to giving money against the adoption of the European vision of human rights.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the implementation and review of the EU-Central Asia strategy addresses important issues, such as the promotion of freedom of religion and the rights of women, children and minorities. However, the text does not give sufficient attention to the social and political changes taking place in Central Asia and, in particular, to the increasing spread of Islamic religious fanaticism and the support given to terrorist organisations.  I am therefore convinced that the EU must carefully consider the possible strengthening of relations with this Asian region. For all these reasons, I have chosen to abstain.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. As this report underlines, the framework for relations between the EU and the five Central Asian countries needs to be revised: Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan and Turkmenistan, which have been increasing their relevance on the international stage in recent years. It is an exporting and energy-producing region, and a transit zone for goods between Europe and East Asia, and Russia and South Asia, of great strategic, political and economic interest to the EU, so it is necessary to strengthen our bilateral and multilateral relations. The strategic approach taken to date has proven to have only limited viability and success. In addition, respect for democratic norms, human rights and fundamental freedoms is insufficient and the human rights situation remains worrying, even if there has been some positive developments in some countries in the region, through legislative reforms, renewed efforts to prevent torture, and measures to eradicate child labour and forced labour. All these issues are fully contained in the report which I supported with my vote.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. – The European Parliament in its report stresses the strong strategic, political and economic interest of the EU in strengthening its bilateral and multilateral relations with all the Central Asian countries, on the basis of common shared values as stated in the existing Partnership and Cooperation Agreements between the EU and Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan and in the agreement – albeit not yet in force – with Turkmenistan. Parliament points out that the strategic approach adopted to date to shaping relations with Central Asian countries has demonstrated only limited viability and success. Finally, Parliament stresses that respect for human rights and democracy must be at the core of the EU strategy vis-à-vis the scope of cooperation envisaged in the PCAs, entailing the application of the human rights and democracy clause.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 I would like to stress that the EU has a strong strategic, political and economic interest in strengthening its bilateral and multilateral relations with the Central Asian countries on the basis of the common values set together. The EU has a strong interest in a prosperous, peaceful, democratic, stable and inclusive Central Asia, which acts as an economically and environmentally sustainable region. Despite the unsatisfactory results so far, I believe that the EU's positive role in the region needs to be further developed through education and people-to-people contacts, taking advantage of the experience of the EU's international exchange programmes, including Erasmus+, Erasmus Mundus and Erasmus Tempus. It is to be welcomed that the EU has provided a budget of EUR 115 million for the Erasmus+ education cooperation programme in the region. In view of all this, I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. By supporting the proposed resolution on the EU Strategy for Central Asia, MEPs stressed the importance of this region to the EU. It is a great economic potential, an energy-enriched, geostrategic and security area with which good relations must be built. In order to achieve long-term sustainable results, we have adopted the re-establishment of the eu Special Representative for strengthening foreign policy relations in the region. It is in the EU's interest to strengthen democracy, human rights, abolish child labour and forced labour, gender equality,.. Etc. All this will need to be even more focused on the countries in the region.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 Central Asia is a region of increasing strategic importance to the European Union in countless areas. With a view to greater and more effective cooperation with the countries that make up this area, we therefore need a review of the strategy adopted in 2007, taking note of the progress, but also of the shortcomings, which have so far characterised our approach to these realities. I supported the report voted on today because it outlines a differentiated approach to the Central Asian macro-area, based, on the one hand, on a perspective that embraces the peculiarities common to the whole region, on the other, on an approach that looks more at the specificities of the individual states that are part of it. There are still many areas in which we need to strengthen our unified action at European level and cooperation with the countries of the region: from energy to promoting security and stability in the region, including with a view to promoting greater economic cooperation and increasing investment in the area, to human rights dialogues, respect for gender equality and minorities. , the development of full democracy and the rule of law. These principles remain key points for us and we must never stop promoting them in our external action.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I support this report, which supports the additional engagement of EU countries with Central Asian countries, where security and energy interests are important. At the same time, I believe that this engagement should not be carried out at the expense of democratic values, such as the protection of human rights.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that Central Asia is an area of enormous strategic interest to the European Union and that it is therefore important that the EU-Central Asia strategy is reviewed in order to respond more effectively to the many challenges that this region poses.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Central Asian region, while not strategically speaking, is not one of the priority areas for the European Union, nevertheless appears, given the growing economic and trade links and given its privileged position bordering the Middle and Far East, as an important geographical area not to be underestimated. In this sense, the new EU-Central Asia strategy must be an important vehicle for transmitting soft power and the founding values (democracy, the rule of law, protection of human rights) of European integration, in order to stabilise an area that still presents considerable difficulties in terms of respect for the rule of law and many of the fundamental freedoms, including, in particular, freedom of opinion and sexual orientation. While it is therefore important to deepen cooperation with the countries of this area (for example by increasing funds for development aid), not least in order to promote the diversification of the main energy suppliers for the European market, so is the subordination of all agreements and economic aid with respect by the third countries in question for fundamental human rights and strict democratic criteria.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU Strategy on Central Asia becomes all the more important as security threats and challenges are increasingly present, and strong cooperation is needed. It is important for the Union to maintain its interest in strengthening its bilateral relations with Central Asian countries, based on the same values. Interest must be shown in the human rights situation, democracy, but also the sustainability and prosperity of Central Asian countries, in order to become strong regions capable of responding to the current difficulties. The main focus of the review of this strategy is enhanced cooperation in order to improve the economic situation, but also internal and external security. Respect for democracy is also a key component, requiring joint efforts by both sides to ensure respect for freedoms. I have expressed myself in favour of this report, because I believe that, only through close cooperation between the Union and Central Asia will the rule of law, good governance and respect for human rights be established.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report does not grasp the real problem and results in mere statements of principle, although we can support them. Abstention vote.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. Clear red lines have been introduced concerning respect for human rights, greater involvement in democratic promotion and transformation, respect and integration of women and minorities, preservation of religious freedom and a commitment to advance the participation of civil society. References have also been made to the prevention of radicalization, such as arms control, the fight against support for the Islamic State, Al-Nusra or any other terrorist group, and the need to address marginalization as a determining factor in the exposure of citizens to these groups.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The countries of Central Asia are of considerable strategic importance to the European Union. A review of the EU's strategy for the region is needed to strengthen bilateral and multilateral relations with all the countries that make up it. It is important to develop action plans tailored to the specifics of each partner given the differences between these countries. It is also very important to strengthen the promotion of the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights in the region. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report 'on the implementation and review of the EU-Central Asia strategy'. There are many issues that have been taken into account and analysed in detail: women's rights and gender equality, border management, democratisation, human rights and the rule of law, the prevention and combating of corruption, respect for labour law, free and fair elections, the elimination of drug trafficking, development, human security and good neighbourly relations. The EU has a strong strategic, political and economic interest in strengthening its bilateral and multilateral relations with all Central Asian countries on the basis of shared common values, but the approach taken so far to structure relations with Central Asian states has shown limited sustainability and little success. EU funding to these countries should be based on incentives and performance, taking into account the results achieved against a set of benchmarks defined for each country and on measurable progress, in particular on democratisation.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP completely rejects any notion of an EU foreign or defence policy. Friendly relations and trade with Central Asia is something to be supported and encouraged, however we do not believe that the EU should have any role in doing this and take the view that an independent Britain would be able to pursue friendly relations far more effectively outside the EU.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I agree with the importance of having a strong EU-Central Asia Strategy, both economically and strategically. I also welcome the strengthening of this partnership by the re-establishment of the post of EU Special Representative for Central Asia, whose role will be to oversee and coordinate our activities in the region. I also look forward to making use of this strategy to promote human rights, democracy and good governance in the region.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report addressed the European Parliament's recommendations on the new EU strategy to review the EU-Asia strategy. The report is consistent and reflects EU values and priorities in the area of human rights and the rule of law. Despite some less acceptable aspects, such as the section on energy security, I have chosen to vote in favour of the report.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report. The EU-Central Asia Strategy was adopted in the context of the growing importance of the region and the eu's increased participation in neighbouring Afghanistan, the expansion of the European Neighbourhood Policy in the Caspian region, the EU's continued support for the reform and modernisation of post-Soviet societies and the EU's energy security interests.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the implementation and review of the EU-Central Asia strategy aims to review Europe's strategies and policies to support and promote its interests in the Central Asian geographical area, as well as to develop partnerships with the countries of the region. This report contains a number of positive elements relating to the smooth development of partnerships and the design of new policies that can benefit Europe over time, which is why I have decided to support it.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 This report represents a strengthening of bilateral relations between Europe and Asia as well as multilateral relations with all Central Asian countries on the basis of shared common values. I could therefore only speak in favour of it, because particular importance is attached to the promotion and strengthening of bureaucracy, human rights and good governance. I believe that we need a response from the European Union to a country where respect for democratic standards and human rights is at worrying levels, especially as we make it a basic pillar of humanity and integration within the Union. In my opinion, cooperation between the two great nations must not stop at a mere trade relationship, but rather I feel it is our responsibility to participate in this process of development with the aim of mutual development, not only economic but also democratic and social.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on implementation and review of the EU-Central Asia Strategy as it stresses the strong strategic, political and economic interest of the EU in strengthening its bilateral and multilateral relations with all the Central Asian countries on the basis of common shared values.  However it also highlights the promotion and reinforcement of democracy, human rights, the rule of law and good governance. It stresses that despite limited positive developments in the countries of the region, democratic standards and human rights remain an issue, and pays special attention to women’s rights and gender equality. It also considers education to be a crucial pillar of integration and a democratic, economic and social development enabler for all the countries of Central Asia.   For these reasons, I supported this report as a balanced one, recognising the importance of a strategic partner but also that there is more work to do on other key areas.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP completely rejects any notion of an EU foreign or defence policy. Friendly relations and trade with Central Asia is something to be supported and encouraged, however we do not believe that the EU should have any role in doing this and take the view that an independent Britain would be able to pursue friendly relations far more effectively outside the EU.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ There is great scope for the EU to enhance its action and cooperation with Central Asian countries. However, there is a fundamental factor which needs to remain a priority. It is respect for human rights and democracy, which remain at the core of the EU strategy vis-à-vis the scope of cooperation envisaged. I regret that the legal obligations vested in the PCAs for upholding democracy and the rule of law have not been properly implemented at all times and there have been instances where progress was gauged through financial opportunities rather than core obligations which distinguishes the EU from other regional blocs.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Strategy for Central Asia adopted by the European Union in 2007 was reviewed in 2015 by the European Commission, this process initiated the parliamentary procedure on the implementation and review of the strategy that will end with the adoption of this report. The EU strategy has so far been a failure in all areas and is therefore claimed to take into account the differences of the various partners involved in the agreements, with benchmarks and precise indicators for monitoring progress. In addition, development funds must be allocated to the region if it shows improvements in the strengthening of democracy, the rule of law, governance, the protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms. The report points out that the human rights situation in Central Asia does not reach adequate standards, especially with regard to the protection of fundamental freedoms. That is why the countries involved are called on to do more to protect human rights, to support the development of renewable energies and to seek greater economic integration between the different regions. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. U2012 We are against this report, because validation of EU foreign policy continues, supported by an interference and interference approach to third countries that has as its main objective the achievement of conditions favourable to the interests of large financial groups over the economies and well-being of these countries, particularly in the areas of energy. Interference that forces them to comply with structural reforms. We voted against it because this report is in line with the EU's ambition for geopolitical and economic domination in that part of the world as well.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 At international level, it is essential that the EU plays a leading role in the area of neighbouring countries, including those in Central Asia (Kazakhstan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan). This area is of increasing strategic importance to the EU today and, consequently, I think it is important that the Central Asia strategy be updated. The EU should take strong action to become a key player. Furthermore, in order to ensure greater efficiency in its actions, it would also be appropriate for the European Union to strengthen its cooperation with other actors in the region, such as the United States and the OSCE. In the region, the EU should focus on a number of key issues such as fundamental rights, respect for press freedom, gender equality and a serious lack of infrastructure. In order to achieve these objectives, I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the implementation and review of the EU-Central Asia strategy.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 The importance of the Central Asian region in relation to the EU, from both economic and geostrategic, security and cooperation perspectives, is underlined. The Central Asian area currently possesses a variety of natural resources, fossil fuels and arable land. It is also recalled that Central Asia is in the exposure area of various natural hazards, being one of the most seismically active areas. I voted for the construction, modernisation and reliability of the Silk Road, which is a valid and decision-making point of major interest to China, Russia and the EU. Of particular importance is also the development of programmes on business links between The FDI and SMEs for faster identification of investments. I also voted for the importance of increasing the level of education, which can lead to a decrease in violence and the potential for radicalisation among young people. The budgetary support that the EU could provide should be strictly linked to achievements at the level of human rights, democracy or basic freedoms in the countries of the Central Asian region.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report on the implementation and review of the EU Strategy for Central Asia underlines that the new EU strategy for Central Asia is adopted in the context of the growing importance of the region and the increased EU involvement in neighbouring Afghanistan, the extension of the European Neighbourhood Policy to the Caspian Region, the EU's constant support for reforms and modernisation of post-Soviet societies, and the interests of the EU's energy security.  The report also identifies security threats and challenges that require cooperation between Central Asia and the EU. Eu efforts to improve economic and political stability in a region whose geopolitical position is becoming increasingly complex and fragile due to the growing conflict of interest between the Russian Federation and the EU in this area and the vulnerability to the influence of extremist and terrorist groups operating in Afghanistan, Iran and Pakistan should be supported. I voted IN FAVOUR.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I support the position of this report and all efforts to improve the economic, political and security situation in the Central Asian region, which is becoming ever more complex and fragile due to the increasing conflict of interest between Russia and European countries in this area. This is an area of the world of growing economic importance and of strategic interest to the UK, so I welcome the suggestions in this report for enhancing mutual relations.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 Since women play a key role in agricultural production and land cultivation in all Central Asian countries, I believe that all Central Asian countries must encourage employment and entrepreneurship among women, especially in rural areas. I also believe that the promotion and monitoring of economic and social rights and the empowerment of women and girls must be the main objectives of the EU's external relations with this region.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report highlights the strategic, economic and political interest that the Union sees in strengthening its bilateral and multilateral relations with all Central Asian countries. It emphasizes the importance of regional cooperation to achieve long-term sustainable results and advocates the strengthening of democracy, human rights and good governance. Considering that Central Asia is a key economic and political partner for the European Union, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The report on the implementation and revision of the European Union's Strategy for Central Asia stresses the importance of maintaining close relations with Central Asia and strengthening regional cooperation. I supported this report because I believe it is essential to strengthen cooperation between the European Union and Central Asia in order to deal with current challenges such as the threat of the Islamic State, drug trafficking, human trafficking, violent extremism and terrorism.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: in writing. – Central Asia is becoming increasingly important to the EU. It is therefore that I voted in favour of this resolution.  Our interests in the region are of both a political and economic nature. The resolution reiterates what the EU envisages in Central Asia, which is peace, prosperity, democracy and environmental sustainability. Positive relations between us will lead to economic and other benefits to both of us. While Central Asia has important resources to offer, the EU has the technology and know-how to build up the region’s infrastructure and to support it. Thus economic integration, trade and sustainable development are key.  However, democracy, the rule of law and human rights also remain at the centre of the discussion. Especially with regard to gender equality there is still work to be done. But I strongly believe that through economic prosperity and innovation, the first steps will be taken in the modernisation of the region in the direction of gender equality. The resolution also recognises that there are many differences across the region. Therefore, I am delighted to see that a list has been included, with specific issues regarding every country in the region, and thereby recognising their individual situation.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: Written. \u2012 The SP voted against the amendment which welcomes kyrgyzstan's GSP+ application. GSP+ trade preferences should only be granted to countries that sign 27 UN Conventions on Human Rights, Labour Rights and Environmental Protection. Kyrgyzstan has not successfully implemented these conventions and should therefore not receive trade preferences through GSP+ schemes. The SP did vote in favour of the report as a whole, because it is very critical of developments in the fields of human rights, democracy and the fight against corruption in the relevant partner countries and stresses that the Union's trade interests and geopolitical interests are subordinate to human rights, the environment and development in (European) policy in the region.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This text introduces confusion in a context where Central Asia is a fragile area, plagued by regular destabilization. To the extent that foreign policy remains a prerogative of states, I voted against this text which allows the EU to overstep its remit and undermine the balance of this part of the world.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report because I think that despite the many problems and unexplained things in this area, we in the EU can become a guardian and guarantor of respect for human rights, legal peace and security. Of course, closer cooperation in this region will bring us the diversification of gas and oil supplies to the Community so desired by the Commission. Of course there is much more to be achieved in this area, but I hope this is a first step in the right direction. I will be watching with interest what is happening in these countries.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 On the path of what has been approved by the majority of the European Parliament on other occasions, we are dealing with yet another report whose content is essentially a repository of interference in third countries, not hiding – quite the contrary – the clear objective of obtaining favourable conditions for the interests of the large European economic groups—financial groups and the powers that represent them. As the report notes, the countries of Central Asia, particularly the former USSR, are of great importance to the EU. Importance that is strategic. The region has particular characteristics, being a heterogeneous, multiethnic, multinational reality, where tensions have been constant, particularly with regard to the control of natural resources. Tensions are appalled, exploited and exploited in favor of imperialist interests that sway over the region, and that this report clearly highlights. The interest in the energy sector is evident. It is evident that this area of the world triggers. The interest resulting from proximity to Russia is evident. This is at the heart of this report and the strategy it highlights. We voted against it.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of a new EU strategy for Central Asia. The EU has a strong strategic, political and economic interest in strengthening its bilateral and multilateral relations with all Central Asian countries. Furthermore, the current worrying security threats, such as terrorism, require greater cooperation between these two regions. The growing importance of the Asian region requires new long-term strategies, with the aim of mutual and lasting enrichment.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The Central Asian region is of unquestionable strategic importance to the European Union, as it is considered to be an area where Europe can obtain significant diversification of energy supplies in the future. It will also be no less important in the area of security and the fight against terrorism. However, we must not forget that the human rights situation is disastrous throughout the area and shows no signs of improvement, with the only partial exception of Kyrgyzstan. The European Union should respect democratic values in these countries. We must also focus on the fight against extremist organisations such as Daesh and strive to improve coordination and cooperation between the security forces in the region.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstain because despite some positive parts of the text, other points could be dealt with better and more carefully.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The report is full of contradictions and inconsistencies. While recognising that human rights, freedom of expression and association are being suppressed and opposition leaders are being arrested in these countries, the text recognises common values, which is offensive to Europeans.  At the same time, it recognises that EU policy in the region has failed, but wants to continue it. It also wants to prevent Member States from strengthening their relations with these countries. For the above reasons I am voting against report A8-0051/2016.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The report is a European Parliament contribution to the review of the EU Central Asia strategy. The region is seen as acquiring a strategic importance in terms of diversification of energy supplies, security and counter-terrorism. At the same time, the human rights situation throughout the region’s countries remains appalling and shows no sign of improving, with the partial exception of Kyrgyzstan, where it was relatively less bad than in other countries. I support the EU’s deeper engagement with the Central Asian states, where important security and energy interests lie. At the same time, this engagement should not be pursued at the expense of democratic values. I am especially in favour of fighting extremist organisations like Daesh, Al-Qaeda and Taliban in the region, and of the adoption of specific recommendations concerning a better coordination and cooperation between the security services in the region, but also stressing the need to engage in dialogue with non-violent organisations as a way of reducing the terrorist threat.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU has a strong strategic political and economic interest in strengthening bilateral and multilateral relations with the countries of the region. It is in our strong interest to have a stable Central Asia. The EU Strategy for Central Asia has been adopted in the context of the region's growing importance and, inter alia, the EU's energy security interests. However, further efforts are needed to tackle gender inequality in the area of women's rights. I voted in favour of parliament's report on the implementation and review of its strategy for Central Asia.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report in view of the need to continue to strengthen ties with central Asian countries and regions. While it is a sine qua non condition for the EU for these countries to have democratic regimes to further advance cooperation, it should be noted that the multiplicity and complexity of these countries sometimes makes cooperation very difficult. It should also be noted that the differences between countries and regions do not facilitate the task of moving in the same direction at the same time, but the EU and many Central Asian countries are ready to move forward on this path.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. – I supported this report as it outlines a good and solid plan of action in regards to the EU’s external relations with Central Asia. The report takes into account relevant experiences in the past that we can learn from when it comes to cooperation with Central Asia and our influence there. To customise our approach to each individual country in the region is therefore of utmost importance if we want to have any relevant impact in these countries where the EU does not have the same general leverage as in our neighbourhood.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP non-legislative resolution on the implementation and review of the EU-Central Asia strategy because I believe it is necessary for the European Union to strengthen its bilateral and multilateral relations with all central Asian countries, on the basis of shared values and the historical link between the two continents. Central Asia is a multi-ethnic and multi-faith region and respect for democracy and human rights is a sine qua non for closer understanding and cooperation between the European Union and Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan, which are precisely the bloc of the five Central Asian countries. It should be pointed out, however, that the approach implemented so far has not produced the desired results, since trade agreements and economic relations, in addition to the desirable promotion of cooperation and integration, have remained weak and have not sustained a sufficient degree of modernisation and development in the countries concerned. Finally, I would stress that the fight against terrorism and the enhanced security measures put in place to protect against the danger of ISIS infiltration cannot in any way justify highly repressive measures against civil society and opposition.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the implementation and revision of the EU's Central Asia Strategy, as I warmly welcome a stronger and more coordinated role for the EU in this region and sets the right priorities for the report co-drafted by my esteemed ECR colleague Charles Tannock.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Central Asia is an important strategic region for the EU. However, the strategy adopted nine years ago from the Treaties of that time has not been sufficiently implemented. I support the new unified approach of improving problems such as corruption and drug trafficking, as well as respect for human and fundamental rights.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: in writing. ‒ Central Asia is vital for UK economic and security interests. I consequently support efforts to improve the economic, political and security situation in the region, which is becoming more complex and fragile due to the increasing conflict of interest between Russia and the EU, as well as the threat from extremist groups.  In line with the UK Government’s commitment to defending human rights objectives globally, this report also placed significant emphasis on the need to improve the lives of women. While in some Central Asian states, steps are being taken to fully implement the UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women, the situation of women in this region has nevertheless been described by the UN as prolific and pervasive. Indeed, one third of girls report domestic violence as part of their lives and in rural areas, women remain in a state of severe disadvantage and poverty. Calling on these states to address such issue is therefore a crucial step in ensuring the lives of women are improved. It is for these reasons that I voted in favour.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of a report focusing mainly on the human rights situation in Central Asia (and not on trade aspects, as is often the case in such texts), noting in it the major problems to which the EU must contribute: democratic deficit, repression of human rights defenders and journalists, child labour , gender gap, basic service deficit and environmental deterioration. The text also rightly points to Europe's responsibility for arms exports, and in the necessary collaboration in the fight against radicalism and drug trafficking.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which stresses the strong strategic, political and economic interest of the EU in strengthening its bilateral and multilateral relations with all the Central Asian countries, based on shared values and the existing Partnership and Cooperation Agreements between the EU and Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan. Importantly, the report stresses that respect for human rights and democracy must be at the core of the EU strategy, with the human rights situations in these countries, and Turkmenistan, remaining of concern.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The report stresses the strong strategic, political and economic interest of the EU in strengthening its bilateral and multilateral relations with all the Central Asian countries, on the basis of common shared values as stated in the existing Partnership and Cooperation Agreements between the EU and Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan and in the agreement – albeit not yet in force – with Turkmenistan.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Written. We Swedish Social Democrats welcome a review of the EU's strategy on Central Asia and believe that the report very clearly emphasises the importance of respecting human rights and democratic principles in the region. We believe that GSP+ can be an important instrument for achieving this, and that is why we welcome Kyrgyzstan's request for application. However, we would like to underline that we believe that the European Commission now has a very great responsibility to ensure that Kyrgyzstan now fully complies with the requirements of GSP+.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 The report deals with the EU's strategy in Central Asia. Unfortunately, however, it contains several negative elements such as macrofinancial assistance, the extension of its failed policies to neighbouring states, energy de-russianization and cooperation with the US in the whole region to address the various problems.  The report also has positive elements, particularly with regard to human rights, child labour, drugs and the arms trade. For these reasons, we consider this abstention to be an appropriate attitude.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution as the report highlights the rising importance of the relationship between the EU and Central Asia on the topics of trade and energy.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ The EU has strong strategic, political and economic interests throughout Central Asia and it is important that we continue to foster links with that part of the world. This report is fair and well-balanced and I accordingly voted in favour.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that the EU should engage more with Central Asian states, mostly in terms of security, counter-terrorism and energy. However, the EU should also tread carefully when making agreements as there are still deep concerns with regard to the human rights situation in the region.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the Implementation and Review of the EU Strategy for Central Asia (2015/2220(INI)) given the strategic importance of close relations with this part of Asia covering Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan, Tajikistan, Kyrgyzstan and Turkmenistan. These countries are important in a trade term where the EU is the most important trading partner, but trade links need to be strengthened even further. Central Asia is also important in security and energy terms due to the diversification and security of the EU.  The 2007 Central Asia Strategy needs to be reviewed to take into account new circumstances and a commitment to the EU's core values. It is necessary to look at and take into account the shortcomings of the political systems of these countries, such as insufficient involvement of citizens in politics, growing inequality and poverty despite large economic resources. There are major challenges and needs in terms of improving human rights, promoting women's rights, media freedom, gender equality, children's rights and others.  Given this state of democratic social relations, it is recommended that the EU take greater account of the coherent implementation of long-term democratic reform when designing its human rights policy and external financial instruments.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. Considering that foreign policy is a competence of states, the EU does not have to add confusion in an already unstable area such as Central Asia. I am going against the spirit of this text and I have obviously voted against this text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP completely rejects any notion of an EU foreign or defence policy. Friendly relations and trade with Central Asia is something to be supported and encouraged, however we do not believe that the EU should have any role in doing this and take the view that an independent Britain would be able to pursue friendly relations far more effectively outside the EU.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by my colleague Tamus Meszerics on the implementation and revision of the Union's Strategy for Central Asia. The report highlights the strategic, economic and political interests that the Union has in consolidating its relations with its partners in Central Asia. The promotion and strengthening of democracy, human rights, the rule of law and good governance are all aspects on which this report stresses. The resolution also underlines the growing importance of trade and energy relations with Central Asia. I the example of this proposal, which underlines that partnership and cooperation agreements represent a real boost in economic cooperation that enables the region to modernise and democratise itself. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. Central Asia is an important region, located between several major international players (Russia, China, India, Iran). That is why the European Union must be able to develop privileged relations with these countries in order to strengthen trade and energy relations. However, the report stresses the importance of respect for human rights by these countries and an intensive dialogue on infrastructure development, particularly with regard to energy, the environment and water management.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This region, which is becoming increasingly important in geostrategic and economic terms, should also be adequately considered in the foreign policy of the Member States and the European Union. I am therefore very receptive to the points of economic policy incentives for businesses. On the other hand, the report interferes with the interests of sovereign states, which is why I reject the report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as it stresses the strong strategic, political and economic interest of the EU in strengthening its bilateral and multilateral relations with all the Central Asian countries, based on shared values and the existing Partnership and Cooperation Agreements. Importantly, the report stresses that respect for human rights and democracy must be at the core of the EU strategy, with the human rights situations in these countries.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament resolution of 13 April 2016 on the implementation and review of the EU Strategy for Central Asia, in particular because the document states that "the key interest of China, the EU and Russia is to build a strategic, modern and interoperable road and rail infrastructure system along the Silk Road route and that the successful integration of the region through modern and reliable infrastructure would be an excellent opportunity not only for deeper regional economic integration , but also to promote population mobility and multicultural exchanges, while creating an environment more conducive to progress on the rule of law and democracy". I am glad that the European Parliament is trying to find common points of interest among these world actors in this resolution and is not limited to criticising these states. By working together, we can learn a lot from each other, and this also greatly helps to create peaceful coexistence. The resolution also addresses efforts to develop strong and friendly relations with Uzbekistan, Turkmenistan, Tajikistan, Kyrgyzstan and Kazakhstan. Personally, I am glad for any report that acknowledges that cooperation and diplomacy are better ways than confrontation.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ The priorities for the Central Asia Strategy are human rights, the rule of law, trade, energy and transport. The partnership is about mutual interest, sustainable development and human rights. I voted in favour of this report since it focuses on boosting regional development, the rule of law and mutual partnership.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. With regard to the strong strategic, political and economic interest that the EU is having in strengthening bilateral and multilateral agreements with all Central Asian countries, I express a positive assessment of the content of this report. Its strategy provides for priorities, objectives and targets to be aligned with the interests and methods implemented by other Central Asian trading partners, which operate through targeted action plans, which may be able to bridge the differences between countries. It also tends to pay more attention to women's rights and, above all, to gender equality; education, considering it a solid and fundamental pillar for democratic, economic and social development for all central Asian countries. Finally, an important part of the document is aimed at safeguarding the freedoms of the media, expression, association and even assembly, which are fundamental to the democratic order of a country.

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of strengthening the role and visibility of the EU in the Central Asia region. This region has a potential to become a transit gate between Europe and Asia. The EU is able and willing to do more to help the countries address the challenges and use the opportunities, by building closer cooperation to foster a socio-economic development in the region and respect for universal values, democracy and human rights. The EU and the Member States should put more emphasis on professional training and education, providing opportunities for students, youngsters and young professionals to learn, study and be trained in the European higher education institutions, organisations and companies, and provide technical support for education sectors in the region. Persistent corruption must be addressed; it is one of the main impediments discouraging credible foreign investment.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against Mr Meszerics' report on the implementation and revision of the Union's Central Asia strategy. Foreign policy is a prerogative of the Member States. The European Union is generally a force for subversion and destabilization, as the various developments in the Eastern Partnership have shown. It adds confusion in a fragile area, with its double standards and its interference in the internal affairs of sovereign states.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it tries to justify the EU's interference in the foreign policy of the Member States with regard to Central Asia. However, foreign policy is and must remain a prerogative of states.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. U2012 We are against this report, because validation of EU foreign policy continues, supported by an interference and interference approach to third countries that has as its main objective the achievement of conditions favourable to the interests of large financial groups over the economies and well-being of these countries, particularly in the areas of energy. Interference that forces them to comply with structural reforms. We voted against it because this report is in line with the EU's ambition for geopolitical and economic domination in that part of the world as well.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The EU has recognised the deficit of democracies and human rights violations in some Central Asian countries and wants to make greater efforts to correct them, and sees an advantage in being able to act on smaller Central Asian countries, increase partnerships and energy cooperation. Central Asia is essential for the European Union in economic and energy terms, and further cooperation promotes common values and respect for human rights, so I supported the report.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the implementation and review of the EU-Central Asia strategy, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 12/4/2016, and because this report is not complete and substantiated.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on the implementation and review of the EU-Central Asia strategy. Central Asia is a region of strategic importance for the European Union, in terms of economic potential, energy diversification and security interests. Despite this, this strategy has not yet produced any major progress. A strong strategic, political and economic commitment is therefore needed to strengthen this relationship, through greater political and economic cooperation, with a commitment based on the principles of responsibility and ownership. Trade and energy links between the EU and the countries of Central Asia and cooperation on security and stability must be strengthened, bearing in mind the importance of democratisation, respect for human rights and the rule of law. This will provide answers to the needs of the region with regard to regional cooperation, poverty reduction and the improvement of living standards, as well as good governance and economic reforms.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Central Asia will become the new scene of a fossil fuel race for the EU. Trapped in the escalation of the tensions it has generated, the European Union is seeking ways to gain independence from Russian gas. The Green rapporteur tried to minimise the social and environmental impacts and to insist on cooperation in the service of regional development with the major players involved, Russia and China, engaged in the new Silk Road. There are also clear references to respect for human rights, starting with a condemnation of child labour during cotton harvests in Uzbekistan. But these demands by Parliament will remain a dead letter in the face of proposed trade agreements. All this for European companies that for years have been at the service of authoritarian regimes, such as Bouygues who generates 40% of its turnover in export to Turkmenistan and warmly thanked the president by having him build a golden statue in his effigy. I note the good elements of the rapporteur but I vote against opposing this double standard between human rights and trade agreements.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. Foreign affairs are a competence of the State, the Union has been clumsy in the various developments of the Eastern Partnership. As a result, I believe that Central Asia is already suffering from some confusion, and that the Union will add more. As a result I voted against the text.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. The EU Strategy for Central Asia was adopted in a context of increasing the importance of this region, strengthening EU participation in Afghanistan, extending the European neighbourhood policy to the Caspian Sea region, continued EU support for the reform and modernisation of post-Soviet societies and eu energy security interests.  We must recognise that security threats and challenges require cooperation between Central Asia and the EU, including its Member States. This strategy has been in implementation for almost eight years.  It is therefore important to strengthen bilateral and multilateral relations with all Central Asian countries on the basis of common and shared values. This plan has a substantial strategic, political and economic interest for the EU, as set out in the existing partnership and cooperation agreements concluded by the EU with Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan, as well as in the agreement with Turkmenistan, which has not yet entered into force.  Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I have given my support to this resolution on the cooperation between Europe and Central Asia. By implementing this strategy we can work towards further rights protection and democratisation. This strategy can also contribute to closer economic cooperation.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. In an increasingly interconnected world, Central Asia is a region of increasing strategic importance to the EU because of its geographical position at the crossroads between Europe, Asia and the Middle East and its significant energy resources. Strengthening cooperation between the European Union and Central Asia is mutually beneficial in achieving fundamental objectives such as peace in Afghanistan, an effective fight against terrorism and the development of dynamic trade and economic relations between our two regions. For most Central Asian states, relations with the EU are defined by partnership and cooperation agreements. Given the political and economic heterogeneity of Central Asian countries, and the low degree of inter-regional cooperation, Europe must favour a targeted approach, based on the needs and interests of individual countries, while favouring European values. The evolution of Central Asian countries towards democracy is positive, although much remains to be done in terms of the rule of law, good governance, the fight against violence against women, etc.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – Developing and deepening relations with central Asian countries has long been one of the EU's most important foreign policy priorities. Since 2007, the states of the former Soviet bloc, namely Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Uzbegistan and Turkmenistan, have been part of the so-called '2007'. EU strategies for Central Asia. Within the framework of that strategy, the Union has set out the main objectives within the framework of its strategic, political and economic interests, which are part of bilateral or multilateral relations with those countries. Specific interests include, in particular, the areas of democratisation and human rights, gender equality and women's rights, education, youth and mobility, economic integration, trade and sustainable development, energy, the environment, transport, regional cooperation, security and border management. These areas of cooperation are of key importance for both sides, but I believe that strengthening relations with the region must be conditional on a significant improvement in the level of respect for human rights (in particular freedom of speech and women's rights) and the rule of law, which is still a fundamental problem for the countries concerned. The Central Asian region has huge potential for the EU, be it energy resources, the market or human capital, but without this basic condition it is not possible to build stable cooperation based on shared values and trust. I am voting in favour of the report as proposed.

name: Anne-Marie MINEUR
text: Written. \u2012 The SP voted against the amendment which welcomes kyrgyzstan's GSP+ application. GSP+ trade preferences should only be granted to countries that sign 27 UN Conventions on Human Rights, Labour Rights and Environmental Protection. Kyrgyzstan has not successfully implemented these conventions and should therefore not receive trade preferences through GSP+ schemes. The SP did vote in favour of the report as a whole because it is very critical of developments in the fields of human rights, democracy and the fight against corruption in the partner countries concerned and stresses that the Union's commercial and geopolitical interests are subordinate to human rights, the environment and development in (European) policy in the region.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the implementation and review of the EU-Central Asia Strategy, which is Parliament’s contribution to the review of the EU Central Asia strategy. The region has a strategic importance in terms of diversification of energy supplies, security and counter-terrorism. At the same time, the human rights situation throughout the region’s countries remains appalling and shows no sign of improving, with the partial exception of Kyrgyzstan, where it was relatively less bad than in other countries to begin with. I support the report that makes it clear that the EU engagement should not be pursued at the expense of democratic values.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Report of the Committee on Foreign Affairs assumes that the multiplying and concurrement of crises shows that no Member State can respond to this alone, and that Europeans must jointly guarantee their own security. It states that threats to Member States should be seen as a threat to the Union itself, that the borders of the Member States are the borders of the Union and should be protected as such. This requires strong unity and solidarity between Member States and requires a consistent common foreign and security policy.  It points out that in the future, the Member States of the European Union must act with greater unity and be prepared to take greater responsibility for their common security and territorial protection, with less reliance on the United States. The main objective is to move towards the development of permanent consolidated multinational military units, the common defence forces and the common defence policy, which will ultimately lead to common defence. Calls for the establishment of a permanent EU headquarters to improve military crisis management capability and provide emergency security. Finally, it calls on the European Union and its Member States to step up defence capabilities and to make full use of the provisions of the Treaty of Lisbon in the field of common security and defence policy. I voted in favour of the draft resolution.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2007, within the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy, a set of objectives was outlined under the EU-Central Asia strategy. However, despite the progress made in this area, these objectives have not yet been fully achieved, and it is therefore necessary to review and strengthen their implementation, following a bilateral line of cooperation and taking into account the specificities of each country in this region. The strengthening of the EU-Central Asia strategy should be based on promoting respect for human rights, respect for the principles of the rule of law, women's rights and the defence of gender equality, promoting equal access to education and sustainable economic integration and development as crucial vehicles for the economic and social development of this region. In this regard, it is important to re-establish the EU Special Representative for Central Asia with the aim of ensuring an effective and cohesive implementation of the strategy outlined for this region.  I therefore vote in favour, in that I consider it essential to review the strategy outlined and to restore a special EU representative for the Central Asia region.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The sole objective of this report on the "implementation and revision of the EU strategy for Central Asia" is, of course, to seek, for the Union, by any means, energy independence from Russia, by going to "waste" resources in Central Asia while minimizing social and environmental impacts, and ignoring the sacrosanct human rights. As a result, this text is for the exclusive benefit of large groups who will be able to shamelessly affair with local dictators to increase their profits. On the other hand, I deny any competence of the Union in matters of energy policy, an eminently strategic area. So I voted against it.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it stresses the strong strategic, political and economic interest of the EU in strengthening its bilateral and multilateral relations with all the Central Asian countries, based on shared values and the existing Partnership and Cooperation Agreements between the EU and Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan. Importantly, the report stresses that respect for human rights and democracy must be at the core of the EU strategy, with the human rights situations in these countries, and Turkmenistan, remaining of concern.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the implementation and revision of the European Union's Strategy for Central Asia. In particular, I support the presence of provisions calling for cooperation with Russia for the development of this part of the world but also to deal with the growing threat of Islamist radicalisation in Central Asia. While the European Parliament has unfortunately been voting on resolutions with profoundly anti-Russian terms for months, I welcome the adoption of such a text which, I hope, paves the way for a more constructive attitude on the part of the European Parliament in relations with Russia.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which underlines the strong strategic, economic and political interest that the Union sees in strengthening its bilateral and multilateral relations with all Central Asian countries, on the basis of common values. It stresses that priorities and objectives should be more based on the interests, needs and general situation of Central Asian partner states. It emphasizes the importance of regional cooperation in achieving long-term sustainable results. The report welcomes the re-establishment of the post of The European Union's Special Representative for Central Asia, whose main role is to ensure that the union's external actions in the region are consistent. Great importance is given to the promotion and strengthening of democracy, human rights, the rule of law and good governance. It stresses that, despite some positive developments in the countries of the region (legislative reforms, increased efforts to prevent torture or measures to eradicate child labour and forced labour), the situation in respect of democratic standards and human rights remains a concern.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has recognised that the strategy towards these countries that has been pursued to date has gaps that need to be filled. The European Union has an important strategic, political and economic interest in the region which it is essential to maintain and strengthen. The cooperation and partnership agreements concluded by the Eu ropean Union with a number of central asian countries are along these lines. Europe is in favour of cooperation with countries that are protective of citizens' rights, capable of maintaining inclusive democratic institutions and promoting peaceful coexistence between peoples. The new strategy goes in the direction we had hoped for, promoting enhanced cooperation on trade, political and diplomatic relations. It is important to remember that it is in the European interest for these countries to be stable and prosperous, because security in the region is a direct consequence of this and the Union is an important player, always committed to supporting lasting peace. Finally, in order to ensure the full implementation of the strategic objectives, the report encourages the use of highly performance-related incentives, trying to give relations with Central Asia a new impetus.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. In our relations with Central Asian countries, it is important to consider our partners on a case-by-case basis based on their specificities on the one hand, and our common interests on the other. This should not, however, lead to neglecting regional cooperation, which is essential and which will be strengthened by the action of the Union's Special Representative for Central Asia. I welcome the adoption of this report, which attaches all due importance to the promotion and strengthening of democracy, human rights, the rule of law and good governance. However, the situation in most of these countries remains a concern about respect for women's rights. We reaffirm our commitment to see their situation improve. The same applies to respect for the freedoms that Europe considers fundamental, first and forth freedom of the press, of expression and association.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I am sure that Europe's strategic cooperation with Central Asia is useful for both sides. I believe that our economic, political and strategic interests are to be strengthened by cooperation. I support the importance of coordinating common interests and objectives, as this will be the way in which we will be able to produce sustainable results. The report also emphasises the growing importance of cooperation in the field of energy and trade and aims to provide a kind of impetuity in the areas of modernisation, democratisation and development.  In addition, it points out that, although respect for human rights remains worrying despite positive reforms, it places great emphasis on strengthening democracy and good governance. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union External Action Service, otherwise known as the EEAS, is the EU’s diplomatic service that helps carry out the Union’s Common Foreign and Security Policy. I have voted for this report that reiterates the strong strategic, political and economic interest of the EU in strengthening its bilateral and multilateral relations with all the Central Asian countries.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I am convinced that the European Union's foreign policy on Central Asia must be reinvigorated in the current international political and economic context, especially since this relationship is a win-win relationship for both partners. Considering that Central Asia has experienced significant economic growth in recent years and that some European countries have already built a stable bilateral relationship with the countries in this area, I believe and believe that the European Union must have the same strategy. I also supported this report because I am also considering the possible contribution of the European community to the countries of Central Asia in terms of human rights, democracy, education, press freedom, gender equality, the environment.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report on the implementation and review of the EU Strategy for Central Asia. Central Asia is a region of strategic importance. It is therefore essential to continue to strengthen and promote better and stronger political, diplomatic and trade relations with all the countries of Central Asia. Relations based on the principles of responsibility and autonomy should continue to be maintained in order to make the Central Asian region democratic, stable, sustainable from an economic and environmental point of view and prosperous. Particular attention must be paid to strengthening relations between the EU and central Asian countries in the fields of trade and energy and for closer cooperation on security and stability, including sustainable management of natural resources. I believe that Kyrgyzstan should be subject to the GSP+ regime. Tajikistan and Uzbekistan should also make such requests.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP completely rejects any notion of an EU foreign or defence policy. Friendly relations and trade with Central Asia is something to be supported and encouraged, however we do not believe that the EU should have any role in doing this and take the view that an independent Britain would be able to pursue friendly relations far more effectively outside the EU.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 On this motion for a resolution, I voted in favour, as I believe that cooperation with the Asian region is of fundamental importance for strengthening the European Union's neighbourhood policy and for strengthening trade and energy relations with Asian countries. I therefore believe that trade, political and diplomatic cooperation, which is also aimed at supporting a democratic transition in Asia and promoting the defence of human rights, must be stepped up. In addition, the bilateral relations that some EU Member States have developed with central Asian countries "impose" a more active role on the EU in this geographical area. In this way, the European Union will be able to speak with one voice and show great unity among its Member States.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. ‒ I support the fact that we pay special attention to this part of the world. I would like to highlight that I truly welcome the re-establishment of the post of EU Special Representative for Central Asia, in order to ensure consistency of the external actions of the Union in the region, which is necessary to avoid unnecessary pains of inconsistency.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ There is a great deal of political and economic interest from the EU in strengthening bilateral and multilateral relations with Central Asian countries. The EU's strategic approach has so far been partly successful. I think we should focus more on strengthening democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights.  In this regard, I regret that this resolution highlights the particular rights of sexual minorities, as highlighted in Articles 36, 37 and 151, rather than addressing common genuine challenges in improving and promoting the state of women's rights and gender equality, as well as combating domestic violence, girls being abducted, trafficked, premature marriage and physical abuse.  We find the same case in the Kyrgyzstan proposal. Although it is stated at the outset that abductions of girls, marital rapes and domestic violence are still present, nevertheless, in a special part of the proposal where Kyrgyzstan is discussed in Art. 151. The focus is only on improving the standards and rights of sexual minorities.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. Foreign policy is a prerogative of sovereign states. The interests of the Member States of the European Union are often divergent in this area. Moreover, whenever the Union acts as such, it tends to destabilise the regions in which it operates. It is not a factor of peace, prosperity and stability for its members or for third countries in the affairs of which it interferes in a perfectly illegitimate manner. It would do better to focus on its own serious democratic dysfunctions rather than lecture the world. I therefore vote against this report.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution as I support the need to strengthen EU-Asia relations in line with the review carried out by the EEAS, the Commission and the Council in 2015. The redefinition of objectives must enable a process of cohesion and prosperity in the region, whose political, economic and environmental stability is of fundamental importance to the Union.
