The implementation of the new strategic objectives of bilateral cooperation with Europe must be based on the transfer of good practices, models and values that can support the States of Central Asia in the process of regional cooperation and integration and kick-start social models based on respect for human rights, the rule of law, the modernisation of political structures and overcoming the serious economic and environmental problems that continue to destabilise the area. I also support the importance of a differentiated approach, that is, one that takes account of the specific nature of each State's challenges with a view to initiating their dialogue. Security issues, the protection of ethnic and religious minorities and LGBTI people, as well as the protection of women's rights and the promotion of gender equality, are also of prime importance.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I emphasise the EU's great strategic, political and economic interest in strengthening its bilateral and multilateral relations with Central Asian countries. Better regional cooperation would improve both the economic and security situation in the region.  Respect for human rights and democracy must be at the heart of the EU strategy on the scope of cooperation envisaged in partnership and cooperation agreements, which imply the application of the human rights and democracy clause. I strongly condemn the continued persecution of human rights defenders, opposition political figures and journalists in Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan.  I underline the growing importance of trade relations between the EU and Central Asia, with the EU now the first trading partner in the region. It is necessary for the EU to further strengthen trade and investment relations with Central Asian countries.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. The report addresses the review of the EU's Strategy for Central Asia following the 2007 case. The countries of Central Asia have great geopolitical importance for the EU. It is not surprising that the EU's position of interference in third countries, in particular in this region. The siege of Russia and China is deepened, seeking bridges for countries in the region that enhance regional economic cooperation developments that are in the interests of the EU, its powers and major economic groups.  Structural reforms are advocated, which should focus apostolically on specific areas of intervention: respect for human rights, the rule of law, good governance, democracy, youth and education policies, trade, economic, development, transport, environmental and water management policies. Of course, it is forcing alignment with 'values', 'practices', but above all the INTERESTS of the EU, in a one-way logic of 'cooperation', in particular through free trade agreements, which ensure favourable conditions on the resources and wealth of those countries.  Energy policy is relevant and, behind its capabilities, the interest of ensuring access to and control of the energy resources of those countries emerges. We voted against it.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I support colleague Tamás Meszerics' report on the implementation and review of the EU Strategy for Central Asia. On the basis of shared values, I welcome the EU's strategic, political and economic interest in strengthening bilateral and multilateral relations with Central Asian countries. I also welcome the EU's great interest in being peaceful, progressive, democratic, stable and inclusive and functioning as an economically and environmentally sustainable region, as outlined in the 2007 strategy. I believe that an important contribution will be made by the EU Special Representative for Central Asia, in implementing the strategy for central Asian countries and shaping relations with these countries by ensuring consistent external action by the Union in the region and communicating the EU's position to political leaders and societies in Central Asia. I express concern about the increased number of laws in countries in the region restricting media freedom, freedom of expression, freedom of assembly and association, aimed at against civil financing. In addition to promoting these freedoms, the EU must also include in its priorities the promotion of freedom of religion and belief and the rights of women, minors and minorities.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 From a strategic point of view, we need to strengthen the EU's relations with countries in the Central Asia region in the long term. Above all, trade ties and exchanges need to be strengthened. In response to the growing regional influence of Russia and China, the EU must be more proactive. The conclusion of an enhanced partnership and cooperation agreement with Kazakhstan can serve as a good example, but much more needs to be focused on bilateral relations with other countries in the region. At the same time, the EU must make trade agreements subject to improved human rights and freedom of speech and media in particular. For me, as a member of the ITRE Committee, the key role of Central Asia as a strategic partner for the EU is to work to diversify energy sources and ensure energy security. I will support the modernisation and diversification of the economies of the states in the region and the creation of a favourable environment for foreign investment, but this requires strengthening the rule of law, improving the business environment, reforming the judiciary and ensuring a more comprehensive protection of property rights and foreign investment.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2013 2015, the volume of commercial transactions between the European Union and Central Asia increased by 8%. Kazakhstan alone (with which a strengthened partnership and cooperation agreement has recently been concluded) accounts for 88% of the total volume between the EU and Central Asia, worth EUR 31 million. With Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan, final partnership agreements have already been concluded and there is still a provisional agreement with Turkmenistan. With regard to accessions to the WTO (World Trade Organisation), the scenario is varied: some of these countries have recently joined, for others participation is a long-term objective. WTO membership provides investors with more guarantees and better legal protection, but corruption remains a problem for the whole region. In reviewing the EU-Central Asia strategy, the Commission includes as its main objectives those of economic development, trade, investment, energy and transport. For all this, I voted in favour and I hope that the EU will call for greater commitment in the fight against corruption, in reducing red tape and in protecting foreign investors.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union should certainly not be seen as a closed community of its 28 Member States, but as an organisation that represents these states and is ready to enter into active partnerships with other democratic states outside the Union, which can undoubtedly be beneficial for the citizens of the European Union. The European Union's cooperation with Central Asia has an important role to play in increasing security and promoting the democratisation of post-Soviet societies and putting emphasis on respect for human rights in these Asian countries. I see the launch of European Union cooperation with Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan as an important step towards strengthening relations with strategic, political and economic importance. I respect the emphasis placed on strengthening peace and respect for human rights in these regions and working together to reach compromises and a common agreement. An important positive is that the report itself also leads to the elimination of educational gaps in these areas, the establishment of trade and the promotion of sustainable development in these regions.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the implementation and revision of the European Union's Strategy for Central Asia. Indeed, it is worth noting the major economic and political interest that the Member States of the European Union have in strengthening relations with Central Asian countries, as indicated by the EU-Central Asia strategy of 2007. Beyond the framework of cooperation for the whole area, however, I call for country-specific approaches, the differences of which can sometimes be significant. Finally, economic integration and trade, along with the EU's core values such as human rights and the rule of law, must guide our relations with Central Asia.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP completely rejects any notion of an EU foreign or defence policy. Friendly relations and trade with Central Asia is something to be supported and encouraged, however we do not believe that the EU should have any role in doing this and take the view that an independent Britain would be able to pursue friendly relations far more effectively outside the EU.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 This report highlights the strengthening of bilateral and multilateral relations with the countries of Central Asia, on the basis of common and shared values, stating that it has a substantial strategic, political and economic interest for the EU.  Until then, the strategic approach followed to define relations with the Central Asian countries has proved unfeasible and unfruitful and the report recognises that economic relations between the EU and the countries targeted by the Central Asia Strategy (Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan) have not developed substantially. According to the report, the objective of promoting regional cooperation and integration between these countries through the sharing of experience and the transfer of EU standards has not advanced.  In this way, the document welcomes the EU's strategic review for Central Asia, understanding that priorities, targets and objectives should be aligned more specifically with the interests and requirements of central Asian partner states, taking due account of the differences between the countries of the region and the unique character of each of them , so I gave my positive vote.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU has many commercial, energy and security interests in Central Asia. These interests cannot jeopardise human and democratic rights.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. As this report underlines, the framework for relations between the EU and the five Central Asian countries needs to be revised: Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan and Turkmenistan, which have been increasing their relevance on the international stage in recent years. It is an exporting and energy-producing region, and a transit zone for goods between Europe and East Asia, and Russia and South Asia, of great strategic, political and economic interest to the EU, so it is necessary to strengthen our bilateral and multilateral relations. The strategic approach taken to date has proven to have only limited viability and success. In addition, respect for democratic norms, human rights and fundamental freedoms is insufficient and the human rights situation remains worrying, even if there has been some positive developments in some countries in the region, through legislative reforms, renewed efforts to prevent torture, and measures to eradicate child labour and forced labour. All these issues are fully contained in the report which I supported with my vote.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. This report I voted on on the implementation and revision of the EU's Central Asia strategy underlines the strong strategic, economic and political interest that the Union sees in strengthening its bilateral and multilateral relations with all Central Asian countries. The adopted text emphasizes the importance of regional cooperation in achieving long-term sustainable results. It also welcomes the re-establishment of the post of The European Union's Special Representative for Central Asia, whose main role is to ensure that the union's external actions in the region are respected. Last but not least, great importance is given to the promotion and strengthening of democracy, human rights, the rule of law and good governance. For despite some positive developments in the countries of the region, the situation in respect of democratic norms and human rights remains worrying in more ways than one...

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. It highlights the need to strengthen regional cooperation with Asian countries in order to meet common challenges. The report talks about the development of democracy, respect for human rights, youth education, sustainable growth. In this respect, the report is comprehensive and well-designed and would be difficult to oppose.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This report on the implementation and review of the EU Strategy for Central Asia underlines the interest of the EU's political and economic strategy in strengthening its bilateral relations with the countries of Central Asia, in particular at energy level. Regional cooperation in achieving sustainable results in the medium and long term is therefore key to the success of this strategy.  To this end, there are principles by which the EU must continue to fight, such as strengthening democracy and the rule of law, protecting human rights and freedom of expression, as well as good governance. Despite limited positive developments in the countries of the region, democratic principles and the defence of human rights remain a cause for concern. The rapporteur takes particular attention to the remaining (and unfortunately prevalent) gaps in the rights of children, women and gender equality, religious fanaticism, drug trafficking, environmental preservation, stressing that education is one of the key areas where the Union should implement its long-term measures - as an absolutely essential pillar for integration and as an engine of economic development , social and democratic in Central Asia.  As I said earlier, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the revision of the Union's strategy for Central Asia, carried out in 2015. First of all, it is a reminder of the Union's strategic, economic and political interest in strengthening relations with Central Asian countries. It calls for closer ad hoc collaboration, greater monitoring of the use of funds and a concrete action plan with measurable criteria for assessing progress or progress. Democratisation, human rights and the rule of law must be the EU's top priorities in the region. Indeed, it is regrettable that very little progress has been made on democracy and the rule of law, particularly in the areas of freedom of expression, women's rights or freedom of the press.  I supported this text which calls for an intensification of economic and trade relations with these countries. It is also a question of cooperating more on energy, since Central Asia is an additional potential source of energy security for the Union.  Finally, it is essential to strengthen the UNION's security cooperation with Central Asia in order to effectively combat terrorism.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of a report focusing mainly on the human rights situation in Central Asia (and not on trade aspects, as is often the case in such texts), noting in it the major problems to which the EU must contribute: democratic deficit, repression of human rights defenders and journalists, child labour , gender gap, basic service deficit and environmental deterioration. The text also rightly points to Europe's responsibility for arms exports, and in the necessary collaboration in the fight against radicalism and drug trafficking.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. U2012 We are against this report, because validation of EU foreign policy continues, supported by an interference and interference approach to third countries that has as its main objective the achievement of conditions favourable to the interests of large financial groups over the economies and well-being of these countries, particularly in the areas of energy. Interference that forces them to comply with structural reforms. We voted against it because this report is in line with the EU's ambition for geopolitical and economic domination in that part of the world as well.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the state of implementation and review of the EU-Central Asia strategy. It stresses the importance of maintaining cooperation with the countries of Central Asia in order to promote the stability and security of the region, whose geopolitical situation is becoming increasingly complex and delicate. The European Union and the countries involved in the strategy need to work together effectively to strengthen their bilateral and multilateral economic and political partnership relations, with the aim of addressing together the challenges and threats that hinder the security, development and stability of these territories of great interest to the EU.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I support the deeper engagement with the Central Asian states by the EU; important security and energy interests are at stake in this region, as well as the potential to expand democratic values otherwise not afforded to the people of this region. The deepening of such relations should not be pursued without proper recognition of the political context in the region.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution reflects the EU strategy for central Asian countries. It gives an overview of democracy, human rights, and rule of law, women’s rights, education, economic issues, environment and more. As the recommendations in general aim at a positive impact, I voted in favour.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU-Central Asia Strategy was adopted in the context of the region's growing importance and increased EU engagement in neighbouring Afghanistan. Despite its common past, Central Asia is a heterogeneous region with a multi-national and multi-religious character. The lack of mutual trust and the ongoing tensions arising from the exploitation and sharing of natural resources have so far undermined the development of genuine regional cooperation. Achieving an equal understanding of democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights is a prerequisite for closer cooperation between the EU and Central Asia. Although all five Central Asian states have ratified the UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women, their culture remains patriarchal with male dominance, and there are still significant inequalities between women and men in many areas, including access to higher education, parts of the labour market and legal protection.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The EU strategy for a new partnership with Central Asia (EU Strategy for Central Asia) was adopted in 2007, due to the growing importance of the region to EU security, stability, governance and energy diversity. The strategy sets out a framework for the EU's relations with five countries: Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan. This is the Third Report of the European Parliament on EU-Central Asia relations. The importance of this part of the council to the EU has increased in recent years mainly due to the energy resources present. Human rights and democracy play an important role in determining the EU's approach to these countries, the former republics of the Soviet Union. The EU has strengthened and improved the structure of its relations with the five countries, as meetings of senior officials from Europe and Central Asia have become common. The EU has also launched regular bilateral dialogues on human rights and national water wealth. However, the EU does not yet have sufficient visibility in Central Asia and should take steps to step up its efforts, with a focus on those objectives and actions addressing the following pressing challenges: human rights and the rule of law, water and energy and regional security. Issues on security, development and environmental protection require close cooperation between the EU and each country and cooperation between the countries themselves. For this very reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 The extension of the Eastern Partnership Strategy to countries in the Caspian Sea region and Central Asia is an important task for the EU to support the development, modernisation, implementation of human rights and the fight against terrorism in the region. Most of the countries involved are recovering from the socialist regime, and it is therefore essential that the EU provides steps that ensure political and economic stability and that cooperation with the EU is established at the level of energy, which is crucial for the development of these countries. Democratic values such as free elections and women's rights, improving education, and also providing support for the fight against corruption and drug trafficking must therefore be promoted in these regions for greater political visibility of the EU.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ There is a great strategic, economic and political interest in strengthening bilateral and multilateral relations between the European Union and Central Asian countries in the context of the region's growing importance. The European Union also said in its 2007 strategy that it seeks to make Central Asia a prosperous, peaceful, democratic, stable and inclusive and functioning as an economically and environmentally sustainable region.  The strategic approach to building relations with Central Asian countries so far has proved only partly sustainable and successful, as the European Union has failed to make a relevant contribution to solving difficult socio-economic and environmental problems and modernising Central Asian societies. In 2015, the European External Action Service, the Commission and the Council adopted a review of the Central Asia Strategy with a view to more concretely aligning priorities, objectives and tasks with the interests, needs and framework situation in central Asian partner countries so that they can be adapted more flexibly to the framework situation in the region.  I consider that joint action by the Institutions of the European Union, the Member States and central Asian countries for the stable development and improvement of the security situation of the region is essential, and I therefore support this report.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The Central Asia region is becoming increasingly important for the EU, especially due to its specific relationship with neighbouring Afghanistan. Various security threats and challenges are also present in this area. The region's bigger problems include the use of natural resources, respect for democracy and various disregards for human rights. Joint action and communication between all Member States, the EU institutions and central Asian countries is essential.  I support the Report on the implementation and review of the EU Strategy for Central Asia. I believe that the priority is to further improve relations between the EU and central Asian countries, which will consequently lead to progress in respecting human rights and democracy. Education is the key to maintaining the stable development of these countries. The strategy benefits the EU economy, helps the rule of law and civil society organisations in Central Asian countries.  In addition to economic, I believe that there is also a great strategic and political interest of the EU in strengthening relations with central Asian countries. Strengthening regional cooperation will improve the security situation across the region

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal and support the European Union's actions in relation to its strategy in Central Asia.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the implementation and review of the EU Strategy for Central Asia. It is in the interest of the European Union to strengthen good relations with all central Asian countries on the basis of common values. We need greater progress and better regional cooperation and integration between Central Asian countries through the exchange of experience and the transfer of standards by the European Union. I support the report, which stresses that the distribution of EU funds should be clearly based on initiatives and performance, take into account achievements in the various benchmarks developed for all countries, and should depend on measurable progress.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament's report on the implementation and review of the EU Strategy for Central Asia, because, although it rightly notes the strategic importance of the region to the EU, it does not address the shortcomings in respect for human rights, the rule of law and the democratic way of government in the individual states of the region. On the contrary, it draws attention to specific cases of discrimination against opposition figures and further appeals to the EEAS to evaluate not only the adoption of reform laws, but also the quality of their subsequent implementation. The report also rightly points out that, if the EU is to increase its 'presence' in the region, this can only be achieved by applying as uniform a foreign policy as possible to individual Member States of the region.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 This report promotes the imposition of a Western culture and culture on eastern countries, without taking into account the specificities of the respective countries. This approach has proved to be wrong, harmful and destructive to these countries. Any strategy must be based on respect for the particular components that exist in the societies and cultures of every region of the planet.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the adoption of this report, which now provides a regular overview of the implementation of the EU Strategy for Central Asia adopted in 2007, on the development of our relations with the five partner countries concerned (Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan).  I consider it appropriate that, in the light of European values, the report devotes a great deal of space to the rule of law, democratic civil rights, freedom of the press and women's equality. It finds for a reason that these rights are deficient to varying degrees, but practically in all five countries, while, with certain exceptions, significant progress cannot be reported despite all the efforts of the European Union. This is also hampering the development of potentially important economic, energy and other relations with EU Member States as indicated in the report. For me, the overall picture outlined confirms the need to rethink and renew the EU strategy for Central Asia, for which the facts and considerations contained in the report provide an appropriate basis.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In June 2007, the European Union adopted a strategy for a new partnership with Central Asia in recognition of the region's growing importance to the EU, in particular in terms of security, stability and diversification of energy sources. This strategy defines the framework for the Union's relations with Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan. The 2007 strategy identified 7 main areas of cooperation. These are: democratisation, human rights, youth and education, economic development, trade and investment, energy and transport, sustainable environment and water, common threats and challenges, intercultural dialogue. Most of these priorities have not lost their relevance. Despite the progress that has been achieved in relations with central Asian countries, cooperation must be stepped up, especially in the area of trade and energy. A similar position was adopted in the EP report, which highlighted the need to develop economic links, eu support for democratic transition and better cooperation in the fight against organised crime and terrorism. Furthermore, the report rightly points out that a differentiated approach based on conditionality and incentives should be applied in order to achieve better results both bilaterally and regionally.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the own-initiative report on the review of the Central Asia Strategy. We share the report's critical attitude towards the substantial failure of the strategy followed so far and support for a more targeted and, at the same time, more coherent approach in bilateral and multilateral relations with the countries of Central Asia, with the common objective of creating a stable area of peace, prosperity and democracy. We recognise that the measures proposed in the report go in the right direction in supporting, on the one hand, the increase in development funds and, on the other, in conditioning their disbursement to the strengthening of democracy, human rights and fundamental freedoms, including access to education, gender equality and sustainable development. We firmly believe that respect for these principles must take precedence over any form of economic, commercial and energy relationship. In this regard, we support the perspective presented in the report, according to which greater connectivity and cooperation with the countries of Central Asia can promote European energy diversification, only and exclusively by operating in the development of renewable energies and energy efficiency. On the other hand, it is stressed that other EU projects such as the construction of the trans-Hawthorn gas pipeline are not justified in the forecasts on the evolution of Europe's energy needs and should be reviewed as contrary to the principles of sustainable development.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ Central Asia has a strategic importance in terms of diversification of energy supplies and counter-terrorism. At the same time, the human rights situation throughout the region’s countries remains lamentable and shows no sign of improvement, with the exception of Kyrgyzstan, where it was relatively less bad than in other countries to begin with. This document, which is reviewing the European strategy on Central Asia, makes it clear that the EU engagement should not be pursued at the expense of democratic fundamental values.  In addition, this document reflects realistically the part on fighting extremist organisations in the region, with some recommendations on better coordination and cooperation. Therefore, I support the report and the EU’s deeper engagement with the Central Asian states, where important security and energy interests lie. At the same time, I think that this engagement should not be pursued at the expense of democratic values.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I reaffirm the need to increase the Union's political reach in the Central Asian region; urges the European Union and its Member States to speak with one voice and refrain from bilateral negotiations which often give less importance to respect for human rights, so as to promote coherence and coordination of foreign policy in the region and to jointly implement joint programme of aid and projects with Member States in order to exploit the full potential and create synergies. I urge the Council, the EEAS and the Commission to adopt a concrete action plan, with measurable benchmarks, to properly assess progress in the future; I welcome the increased participation and ownership shown by Member States in the implementation of the strategy.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Central Asia is a natural bridge between Eastern Asia and Europe, but also a region of increasingly strategic importance due to its important energy resources. Nevertheless, our economic and political cooperation and engagement with Central Asia set out in the EU-Central Asia Strategy has been far from successful. This is why I voted in favour of this review. While our strategy already goes in the right direction, we need to adapt our approach more to country specificities. We should also make cooperation and aid conditional upon the fulfilment of criteria such as democratisation, fighting corruption, stopping drug trafficking, and improving labour laws. In fact, the human rights record in several of these countries is precarious, and it is our moral duty to support the victims of frequent abuses.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Central Asian region plays an essential role for the EU in terms of economic potential, geostrategic interests related to security and energy diversification. It is important to bear in mind that Central Asian countries are facing major external shocks, such as the economic slowdown in Russia and China and the current geopolitical tensions in the area. Despite the fact that they are countries that have experienced rapid economic growth in recent years, the region is facing high rates of poverty, a marked income disparity and a decrease in life expectancy. The Role of the European Union should be to support the growth of these countries by ensuring that it takes place in accordance with democratic principles.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report because the strategy relating to Central Asia needs to be revised in order to reconcile it with modern problems and bilateral relations. The European Union should take into account the growing importance of the region, in particular its economic potential. The report stresses in particular the need for EU participation in social affairs, in particular in helping to combat poverty, which is the biggest problem in Central Asia. Such decisions are worthy of support.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒During the eight years of implementing the Central Asia Strategy, significant progress has been made in developing the European Union's relations with Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan, as well as with the Central Asian region as a whole. The strategic, political and economic interest of the European Union in strengthening bilateral and multilateral relations with Central Asian countries is very important, as the region is increasingly affected by religious fanaticism and increasing conflicts of interest between the Russian Federation and the European Union. I hold essential respect for democracy, the rule of law and human rights as key preconditions for closer cooperation between the European Union and the five Central Asian countries, as the overall state of democracy and human rights in the region is to a greater or lesser extent poor and worrying. As I support the European Union's efforts to improve economic and political stability in this region, I voted to adopt this report.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the report on the EU in a changing global environment – a more integrated, conflicted and complex world, because respect for democracy, the rule of law and human rights is a prerequisite for closer cooperation between the EU and the five central Asian countries in areas of mutual interest, in the literal sense of partnership, as stated in the Partnership and Cooperation Agreements. The overall situation in the area of democracy and human rights in the region remains largely poor and worrying. In June 2015, the Foreign Affairs Council reiterated its commitment to stand up for women's rights and concluded that increasing the influence of women in the region is essential to ensure long-term stability and good governance.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of a report focusing mainly on the human rights situation in Central Asia (and not on trade aspects, as is often the case in such texts), noting in it the major problems to which the EU must contribute: democratic deficit, repression of human rights defenders and journalists, child labour , gender gap, basic service deficit and environmental deterioration. The text also rightly points to Europe's responsibility for arms exports, and in the necessary collaboration in the fight against radicalism and drug trafficking.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Despite its common history, Central Asia is a multi-ethnic and multi-religion heterogeneous region. The lack of mutual trust and ongoing tensions over the use and sharing of natural resources have so far prevented effective regional cooperation. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Traian UNGUREANU
text: in writing. \u2012 The Central Asian region is of particular importance to the European Union in terms of economic potential, energy diversification, as well as geostrategic and security interests. The European Parliament resolution underlines the importance of strengthening relations between the European Union and the countries of Central Asia. Although the EU Strategy for Central Asia was revised during 2015, the approach to meeting the objectives contained in this strategy should be reviewed. Priorities should be adapted more to the interests, requirements and framework conditions of Central Asian partner countries, taking into account, of course, the differences between the countries of the region, but also the uniqueness of each. The resolution urges the Member States of the Union to speak with one voice and promote coherence and coordination of foreign policy in this region, and calls on the Commission, the Council and the European External Action Service to adopt a concrete action plan, with clear and specific measurable objectives, enabling a clear and accurate assessment of future results and progress. I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of a report focusing mainly on the human rights situation in Central Asia (and not on trade aspects, as is often the case in such texts), noting in it the major problems to which the EU must contribute: democratic deficit, repression of human rights defenders and journalists, child labour , gender gap, basic service deficit and environmental deterioration. The text also rightly points to Europe's responsibility for arms exports, and in the necessary collaboration in the fight against radicalism and drug trafficking.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because it makes clear that respect for democracy, the rule of law and human rights is a basic condition for deeper cooperation between the EU and the five countries of Central Asia in areas of mutual interest.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on implementation and review of the EU-Central Asia Strategy. The report suggests that European Fund expenditures should be performance-based and dependent on the measurable progress in human rights, democratisation and corruption. It equally calls for a country-to-country approach and no compromise on human rights, the rule of law or corruption. The report also expresses concern regarding media freedom, the suppression of civil society and widespread human rights abuses including torture in prison in the region.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The report highlights the EU's enormous political, economic and strategic interest in strengthening its bilateral and multilateral relations with all Central Asian countries. It stresses the need for priorities, objectives and targets to be aligned with the interests, requirements and legal frameworks of Central Asian countries, taking into account differences between countries through the development of detailed action plans. The report highlights key issues such as the promotion and strengthening of democracy in the area, respect for human rights, the rule of law, good governance or the need to strengthen trade and energy relations with these countries. We are therefore talking about a full and balanced report, so I think it is appropriate to vote in your favour.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ In Central Asia the EU faces multiple issues, the European Union has strong and increasing political, strategic and economic interests in the area and it is important that we use our shared values to help build these links to improve on the ties already established with Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan.  However, as this report stresses, we also have lingering concerns over the issue of potential human rights abuses in this country. I am happy to back this report because it stresses that respect for human rights and democracy must be at the core of the EU strategy in this area. These are not pawns to be swapped for material gain. As an area where multiple outside players are taking an interest, both through improving transit links and the sale of natural resources, it is important that we all play a constructive role in bringing about improvements for the people of the region.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'The European Union has strong strategic, political and economic interests throughout Central Asia and it is important that we promote ties with that part of the world. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The Central Asian countries resulting from post-Soviet societies are of great importance to the EU, which is a strategic importance. The increase in religious fanaticism and the increased participation of the populations of these countries in terrorist groups are considered worrying. They consider education fundamental to the development of democracy in the region. They advocate ensuring women's rights and gender equality. They believe that the problems relating to global warming and, in the foreground, those relating to water should be investigated. They value China and Russia's involvement in policies in the region. We are sensitive to human rights violations anywhere in the world. We reject any external intervention, especially by the EU, which has no legitimacy to lecture democracy on anyone else. The solution involves the sovereignty of states and the ability of peoples to solve their own problems.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. One thing that could be to create economic incentives for businesses in this region is that the report is very ideological and seeks to interfere in the interests of sovereign states. On the other hand, further EU foreign policy action in this unstable region would not be recommended. That is why, in my view, the report must be rejected.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Writing. The report sets out one-sided, even arrogant, guidelines for the implantation of Western values and democracy ideas in the countries of Central Asia. Last but not least, it is pushing for progress in the area of equality for LGBTI people and in the establishment of a "civil society" according to Western ideas; gender equality is also a concern of the report, i.e. eu foreign policy. The report's consistent trend is to disregard independent national and regional development, if necessary. developing alternative social and political models – the countries concerned in Central Asia; that is why I voted 'no'.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's report on the implementation and revision of the EU strategy for Central Asia. The text refers to issues such as the state of the rule of law in Central Asian countries such as Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan, which are not within the competence of the EU. That is why I rejected this report.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report’s reaffirmation that human rights and democracy must be at the core of the EU’s strategy in Central Asia, and I share the regret expressed at the overall lack of progress being made in the region. I would like to use this opportunity to raise the censorship and lack of freedom of expression in Kazakhstan, and particularly that of the critical news organisation Respublika that is currently suffering from persecution. The Kazakh government is pursuing law suits in the US to try to force American companies to shut down Respublika’s servers, which also raises great concern about internet freedoms more generally. The EU must take a stand to pressure Kazakh authorities to stop this kind of abuse, and condition further cooperation on upholding human rights norms.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. This report highlights the EU's need to strengthen bilateral and multilateral relations with Central Asian countries in political and economic terms. Such relations should be well founded taking into account the country-specific characteristics, so that I support the development of concrete action plans for each country. In addition, I also agree with this report because it defends democracy, human rights, law enforcement and good governance in these countries, where conflicts and tensions continue to grow.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I have decided to support this report by the European Parliament because I am aware of the EU's strong strategic, political and economic interest in strengthening bilateral and multilateral relations with the Central Asian countries. The European Union is interested in prosperity and peace in the region. I am fully aware of the importance of the Central Asia region to the EU in terms of its economic potential, energy diversification and geostrategic and security interests. Personally, I am in line for the already existing links between the countries of the region to be deepened, while at the same time coordinating individual policies with the EU. At the same time, I also believe in the importance of close cooperation in this area, including with the United States, With Russia and China, in order to ensure long-term and sustainable development.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Central Asia is an area of great political and economic importance that has been in the orbit of influence by many since the collapse of the Soviet Union. Russia, China and the United States are trying to strengthen their presence there and pursue their own economic interests. Europe should also be present in the region and take advantage of its favourable situation. The countries of the region present different levels of economic development and political stability, but there is no doubt that the European Union should deepen and continue to cooperate with each central Asian country. This cooperation must be multifaceted, taking into account economic exchanges, the common fight against terrorism and radicalisation and the fight against organised crime and drug trafficking. Of course, we cannot ignore the problems faced by these young countries in order to build stable civil societies, but we cannot easily condemn them and punish them for the difficult geopolitical and cultural conditions in which they have come to operate.  The European Union should monitor the human rights situation in the region and provide all the assistance that central Asian countries will need to build standards of democracy and the rule of law.  Particular emphasis must be placed on the education of young people and the possibility of exchanging pupils and students. I agree with the shape of the CURRENT EU policy and future strategies for Central Asia presented in this report, which is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. The EU has a strong strategic, political and economic interest in strengthening bilateral and multilateral relations with all Central Asian countries on the basis of common values. As I believe that integration is important, particularly in terms of confronting security threats and challenges, but also in the area of political, diplomatic and trade relations, I supported the report on the implementation and review of the EU Strategy for Central Asia.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – As I pointed out in the debate on Zika virus infection in the last plenary session, abortion is not healthcare. He hurts his mother and kills the baby. It is absurd and totally unacceptable for senior UN officials and now the European Parliament to abuse the tragic situation of infected women and their families. They impose their pro-abortion agenda on countries that ensure the protection of conceived life in their legislation. For decades, many of these countries have resisted repeated political and economic pressures from the West to promote a culture of death. And now we are seeing women and girls from developed countries being imposed on the so-called 'right to abortion' and unrestricted access to contraception instead of the necessary support and genuine professional medical assistance. For pregnant mothers facing insecurity and immense pressure, there is a lethal solution. I cannot agree with that in any way, which is why I voted against it.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Of course, I voted in favour of the report on the Zika virus. Of course you'd vote for a report on a tragedy like this, another epidemic. But it was instructive that I, too, read the text of the report with great suspicion, looking at where the interests of multinationals and pharmaceutical companies might be involved. Where does it say that sensationalist media might distort things?  Indeed, as the previous commenter said, it was not difficult to discover how the Western world is forcing the cult of abortion on so-called developing countries and finding this opportunity in the context of such a tragedy, rather than focusing on preventing abortion in the so-called developing countries, as well as in Western Europe and throughout the European Union.  On the one side, therefore, there is always a global interest, economic power and political power interconnected, and on the other side are vulnerable people trying to understand the context amid all the lies. Thank you.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – I am ingusing because there was no roll-call vote on this point, and I therefore want my vote recorded on a microphone in this way. I supported this report, which I consider important.  At first glance, Europe may not be affected by the Zika virus problem, which is very shortsighted and wrong. As an international player, the EU cannot reclaim its international responsibility. It is good that we have released at least EUR 10 million for further research with this report. Whether this amount is sufficient or not, I can not assess it, in any case, if it turns out not to be sufficient, then it is necessary to increase this amount and do everything possible to find out more about malformations of the brain, whether and how they are associated with this disease, with this virus and, above all, to look for prevention.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Clearly, evolution is not something exclusive only to people. The same viruses in the mouth have been for decades and are becoming more dangerous, deadly. The Zika virus is one of the last examples, and the principled difference is its dire effect on unborn children, as it causes microcephaly. In adults, however, it causes Guilly-Barren syndrome. This is very important. This virus has been detected in twenty-eight countries, including Spain. And the point is that if it initially affected equatorial areas in Asia and Africa in the middle of the 20th century, it actually moved through Oceania and South America three years ago. In view of all this, I unequivocally agree with the commission's welcome assessment of the use of EUR 10 million for the research into the Zika virus, and I call on all specialised bodies to deal with it, all the more so since it is up to date, especially before the Summer Olympics in Brazil.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Written. I voted in favour of the resolution on measures to prevent further spread of the Zika virus. The resolution contains a number of important proposals on prevention and coordination of action and planning. I voted against the wordings which contained comments on other countries' legislation on medical ethics. The European Parliament should respect the principle of subsidiarity and respect the national nature of these issues. Controversial parts are proposals for demands for action in the field of sexual and reproductive health including abortion. The EPP's line was to vote freely on sexual and reproductive health issues and to vote against demands for access to abortion and to vote against the resolution as a whole. I voted against the wording on abortion on the grounds of subsidiarity but for the resolution as a whole.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 In early 2016, zika virus outbreaks and spreads in tropical and subtropical regions of the Americas. It is a viral disease, transmitted by mosquitoes of the genus Aedes, which generally causes a mild infection, except for pregnant women, in which case there is a high probability for newborns to report fetal microcephaly. The WHO has stated that the spread of the virus represents a public health emergency of international importance. The EU has therefore decided to allocate EUR 10 million from the Horizon 2020 programme for research and vaccine development, while a further EUR 40 million could be allocated to research into malaria and infectious diseases. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I welcome the assumption that the possible causes of microcephaly are numerous and that its origin is often unknown. Thus, the text of this resolution not only contemplates the possibility that consequences such as microcephaly may be caused by an infected Aedes mosquito, but also takes into account that researchers from Argentina and Brazil have established a relationship between concentrations of microcephaly cases in Brazil and pyriproxifen, a larvicide used in the supply of drinking water in 2014 in the affected areas of Brazil.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I abstained on the vote of this motion for a resolution on the Zika virus epidemic in support of JOELle Mélin, ANG MP. In early February, the MEP called for the Zika epidemic to be included in emergency proceedings. This proposal, which was rejected by Parliament, was referred to committee. That evening, WHO declared a public health emergency of international concern. Other initiatives were taken by the Member such as an oral question and a draft resolution on the subject, which proved unsuccessful. Finally, the Member who was co-reporter finally withdrew from the project in the face of the observation of great amateurism and the total lack of method in terms of infectious diseases. The "precautionary principle" for example does not appear in any place of the text. In addition, the votes on this issue come three months after our group's initiative and the emergency declaration. It is also important to note that this emergency was lifted on 30 March under pressure from the tourism and sports lobby.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this resolution which refers to the need to address the threat of the Zika virus which mainly threatens women and children who are born, and live mainly in less developed areas. It is therefore necessary to re-discuss the problem of access to contraception and safe abortions as well as other more extensive issues around the rights of girls and women in many countries.  This resolution stresses the need to intensifie research efforts around the virus and the suspicions of its symptoms, tests for rapid diagnosis, treatments and vaccinations. Prevention must be promoted through mosquito control and contraception, but we must also be ready for an outbreak of the virus in central Europe, which this resolution describes in detail.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The ins and outs of this hypertrophied text are characterized by a very serious amateurism and a total lack of the necessary method for infectious diseases. In particular, at no time does the term "precautionary principle" appear. This is a blatant demonstration of the inept and, ultimately, totally unstructured functioning of the "thought" of this institution.  The votes come three months after our group's request and the emergency declaration. Meanwhile, under pressure from the tourism and sports lobby (Rio Olympics) the emergency was lifted on 30 March. so I abstained

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ The Zika virus outbreak is a tragedy, and we must all do what we can to help. Although I was unable to vote in favour of the final resolution due to having problems with the specific text of the report, I abstained and of course agree with the principle of it.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution on the outbreak of the Zika virus.  The Zika virus is a new mosquito-borne virus, the largest outbreak of which has been recorded in Brazil, especially in northeastern Brazil. According to the evaluation of the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control, as there are no treatments and vaccines for this disease, protection is currently based on personal protective measures. It is therefore essential to draw up communication plans, adapting them to the most appropriate scale, and in order to raise awareness among the population and to promote appropriate behaviour to prevent mosquito bites. The Commission decided to grant a capital allocation of EUR 10 million to the Commission. Eur 100 million for research into the Zika virus. I support the calls on the Commission to ensure that, if EU public funds are used for research, the results of those studies are not subject to intellectual property rights and patients are guaranteed affordable products produced using the results of those studies. The Commission must propose specific measures for European regions where the Zika virus has already spread, in order to prevent all routes of transmission of the virus in those regions and to provide support to infected individuals.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on the Zika virus aims to clarify the problem of the virus and to call for full solutions. It is important to point out that the text draws attention to the possibility and need for a global response, which would prevent an even more serious global epidemic. It also draws attention to the importance and effectiveness of biological control against mosquitoes carrying the virus. The text underlines that there is a link between the spread of poverty and disease in South American countries and that the exposure of women and girls in this social group is much higher than in other social groups.  At the same time, it is important to mention that the proposal calls on the EU to encourage the countries affected by the epidemic to ensure women's rights and to engage in dialogue in this area. It should also be mentioned that it also implicitly wants to force the guarantee of the rights of sexual minorities in these countries. This is primarily about LGBTQ rights. It is ineligible to import these rights under the pretext of an epidemic into States which have a different position on this issue, or to make aid against the spread of the epidemic subject to the conditions for the acceptance of such rights. Despite this criticism, I supported the proposal in the final vote.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP fully supports the fight against the Zika virus. We support the scientific efforts that aim at providing a scientific explanation for the link between the virus and severe brain malformations reported in newborn children. UKIP would not oppose funds designated to study this issue.  However, we believe that initiatives of this kind should be decided at the national level, not by the unelected EU Commission, so we have decided to abstain in this occasion.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. In view of the amateurism of the ENVI Committee (environment, public health and food safety) in relation to the Zika epidemic, amateurism that led the co-reporter and member of the ENL group, Dr Joelle Mélin, to withdraw from the project, I cannot support it: the votes on the measures necessary to contain the epidemic come three months after the application , the Zika epidemic in emergency procedures, and the WHO emergency declaration. Moreover, the final text shows a total lack of the necessary method for infectious diseases, even neglecting to speak of the "precautionary principle", which is crucial in such circumstances. The ineptitude of the European institution and its functioning is glaring: far from wanting to settle things, this text is used to undermine sovereign decisions in societal matters.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. On February 1, 2016, the World Health Organization declared the Zika virus outbreak a global public health emergency. Cases have been sporadically recorded in Africa, the Americas, Asia, the Pacific and European regions such as Martinique, French Guiana, Guadeloupe and St. Martin.  I voted in favour of this report because it takes into account two action plans to combat this devastating virus: on the one hand, an action to raise awareness and promote appropriate behaviours and on the other hand the deepening of medical research. It is essential that the Commission prevents the spread of Zika in the European Union and helps countries already affected

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Zika virus, first isolated in 1947 in Uganda, is transmitted by mosquitoes of the genus Aedes. On 1 February 2016, who declared the Zika virus epidemic a public health emergency of international importance, following the serious events that have affected the northeastern part of Brazil. The appearance of the virus has been associated, in this situation, with a concentration of cases of microcephaly and other neurological pathologies, among which Guillain-Barré syndrome stands out in particular. Some transmission episodes have already occurred in the outermost regions of the EU but the greatest risk to the continent could occur in the summer of 2016, through a native transmission of the virus via vectors.  The resolution adopted by Parliament and supported by me calls on the Commission to consult member states and third countries that have gained experience in monitoring and combating the Aedes mosquito, by drawing up an action plan to prevent the spread of the virus in Europe and to provide assistance to the states and regions most affected. In addition to the funds already allocated to research, it would be necessary to provide for a free and targeted distribution of sufficient mechanical barriers such as mosquito nets and condoms, in order to avoid sexual transmission in particular.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report as this report highlighted the need for the EU to support scientific research in order to conclusively establish the link between Zika virus and microcephaly. It is highlighted in various amendments that delaying pregnancy is not enough as in many countries women are not granted access to information on their reproductive rights, so concrete measures must be taken to ensure that women have the information, support and services they need to exercise their right to determine whether and when they become pregnant. It is also proposed that where sexual violence exists and sexual and reproductive rights are criminalized, efforts to stop this crisis are not improved.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. On 1 February 2016, at the request of an elected member of my group (ENF), the registration of the ZIKA epidemic in emergency procedure was refused by Parliament and referred to committee. At 7 p.m., WHO, to avoid the scandal of the delay in the Ebola epidemic, declares a public health emergency of international concern. The question was what the Commission intended to do about this new viral epidemic, which had already been submitted to WHO in November 2015 by the public health services of French Polynesia. This question quickly turned into an enlarged, amateurish and highly disregarding the necessary precautions in terms of infectious diseases. This is a testament to the totally ineffective functioning of Parliament on such matters, especially since in the meantime the emergency was lifted on 30 March.  The very co-reporter of the project, belonging to ENF, withdrew from the project and I decided to follow his recommendation to vote, that is to say to abstain.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The World Health Organization has classified the Zika virus as an "international public health emergency" because it poses a potential threat to the health of European citizens.  I agree with the text that reiterates the need to provide assistance to third countries affected by the epidemic and I believe it is appropriate for the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) to set up a committee of experts to monitor the situation and prepare a clear action plan to prevent the spread of this virus in Europe. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. WHO stated that the Zika virus outbreak is a public health emergency of international concern on 1 February 2016. Sporadic outbreaks of the virus-causing disease have been detected in two European regions, Martinique and French Guiana, and cases of contamination in Guadeloupe and Saint Martin. The European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control has continuously monitored the situation, but it is requested that the Centre regularly update its risk assessments and epidemiological bulletins, as well as establish a committee of experts on communicable tropical diseases.  We welcome the Commission's decision to allocate EUR 10 million to research on the virus, aimed at both vaccine prevention and disease treatment. We also call for the establishment of a prenatal diagnosis protocol and the possibility of continuing with pregnancy in the event of malformations, as well as the impetus for research for the eradication of the carrier mosquito, using insecticides not harmful to humans. That's why I voted for it.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution on the outbreak of the Zika virus. The Zika virus is transmitted to humans through the bite of infected Aedes mosquitoes, and in tropical regions most often, the bite of the Aedes aegypti mosquito, which is the same type of mosquito that spreads dengue fever, chikunguny and yellow fever. According to the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control Assessment, whereas there are no treatments and vaccines for this disease, and since mosquitoes spreading the virus bite both indoors and outdoors, mainly during the day, and therefore the protection is currently based on personal protective equipment, such as wearing permethrin-treated long sleeves and long trousers (especially at times when mosquitoes spreading the Zika virus are the most active) and sleeping or resting in rooms with mosquito nets or air conditioning , or also use mosquito nets. The European Parliament calls on the Commission to draw up an action plan to halt the spread of the virus in Europe and to assist Member States and third countries fighting the epidemic in the regions with the highest outbreaks (in particular the Caribbean, Central America and South America). Parliament calls on the Member States to increase the knowledge of doctors and clinics specialising in the treatment of travelling patients about the evolution of the Zika virus epidemic and the control of the transmission of infection by the authorities of infected areas so that they can include zika virus infection in the differential diagnosis of populations and travellers from those areas.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 As stated by the WHO last February, the Zika virus outbreak represents a health emergency of international importance. If we want to help stop the epidemic and prevent it from spreading further to other parts of the world, including Europe, we must provide a prompt and coordinated response at European level, capable of acting on several fronts. These include support for research into the virus, for which there is still no vaccine and, of fundamental importance, prevention. As the resolution adopted today points out, on both levels we need to coordinate with our international partners and, in particular, with the countries most affected by the epidemic.  It is necessary to clarify the possible causal connections between the virus and the cases of severe brain malformations recorded in Latin America, as well as the actual methods of transmission of the virus, while contributing to the development of effective treatments and vaccines available to the most vulnerable sections of society. Finally, we must quickly take appropriate measures to prevent the cross-border transmission of the infection and its spread in Europe.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. \u2012 I'm calling this resolution because it highlights important moments in the fight against the global threat of zika virus. The Zika virus is a danger that threatens women in a pre-proportional way. There are inappropriate calls for women to refrain from becoming pregnant because pregnancy is often not a matter of choice, especially in poorer and more underdeveloped corners of the world. I also support un recommendations regarding access to sexual and reproductive health services. Women in poorer areas often do not have access to information, tests and medicines. I therefore call on the Commission and the authorities of the affected countries to take into account the specific challenges and difficulties faced by women.  At the moment, the danger to Europe is relatively small, but with the arrival of warmer and wetter weather, there is a chance that mosquitoes will start spreading the virus in our part of the world. If that happens, he won't be stopped by national borders. Therefore, Member States, regional authorities and the Commission must be ready to respond in a coordinated and effective way. Furthermore, prevention is the best medicine and that is why I call on the Commission to strongly support efforts to find vaccines and provide all necessary assistance to countries struggling with Zika.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This report is characterized by a cruel lack of competence and a complete lack of the necessary method of infectious disease. Moreover, this text does not refer to the term "precautionary principle"." This clearly demonstrates the absurd and ill-organized functioning of the "thought" of this institution. It is only after three months, the request made by our group and the declaration of urgency, that the votes come. The emergency was lifted on 30 March under pressure from the tourism and sports lobby. Therefore, I abstained on this report

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the Zika virus that has been affecting South America at this time and which has important side effects, especially on foetuses, must be eradicated as quickly as possible and that the European Union must commit itself substantially to this.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The recent major outbreaks of zika virus outbreaks, particularly in Polynesia French in 2013, Brazil and Colombia in 2015, are at the origin of the declaration of the state of emergency of public health of the Emergency Committee of the International Health Regulation. Although they have not yet been scientifically proven, reports of malformations and microcephaly of babies born to mothers who contracted the virus during pregnancy have been found more than likely. In this context, the European Union must deepen its efforts to support more scientific studies in relation to the nature of the virus and its development in Europe and throughout the world, and must also promote the implementation of a prevention and law enforcement programme at European level and in cooperation with the main countries affected, with the means and resources to match a situation that must not be underestimated. More specifically, work on the short-term development of an effective vaccine must be intensified, as well as closer coordination between the various Member States and their national and European health authorities, including the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. I abstained on this motion for a resolution on the Zika-related epidemic in support of ENF MEP Joelle Mélin. In early February, the National Front MEP called for the Zika epidemic to be included in emergency proceedings. This proposal, which was rejected by Parliament, was referred to committee. That evening, WHO declared a public health emergency of international concern. Other initiatives were undertaken by the Member, such as an oral question and a draft resolution on the subject, which proved unsuccessful. Finally, the Member, who was co-reporter, finally withdrew from the project in the face of the observation of great amateurism and the total lack of method in terms of infectious diseases. The "precautionary principle" for example does not appear in any place of the text. In addition, the votes on this issue come three months after our group's initiative and the emergency declaration. It is also important to note that the emergency procedure was lifted on 30 March under pressure from the tourism and sports lobby.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Zika virus has become a real threat to citizens, spreading at a rapid pace. At present, there are still no treatments or vaccines to combat the effects of this virus, which is why it is very important to prevent and take personal protective measures. At Union level, concrete measures need to be taken for regions where the Zika virus has already spread, precisely in order to eradicate all possible methods of transmission in these regions. Moreover, it is necessary to support people already infected. An immediate action plan is also needed to help both Member States and third countries combat this epidemic in the most affected areas. I welcome the Commission's decision to allocate EUR 10 million for zika virus research and efforts to find effective solutions against this virus. I have expressed myself in favour of this resolution because I believe that a joint effort by the Member States and the Union is needed to eradicate this virus and ensure a high level of protection of human health.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Resolution calling on the EU to provide assistance to third countries affected by the Zika virus epidemic, and ecdc to stay alert and set up a commission of experts on communicable tropical diseases; it congratulates the Commission on allocating EUR 10 million for research into the virus, although it wonders whether this is sufficient, and is being asked to draw up an action plan to prevent its spread in the EU. I am voting in favour, health protection in the first place.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the motion for a resolution on the Zika virus epidemic, tabled following the debate at last month's plenary session, which aims to bring some directions of action in addressing this epidemic at both European and global level, with EU aid to the regions most affected. As we argued in last month's written statement, our objectives are clear: prevention and treatment of the epidemic. To do this, we need to focus our efforts on the discovery of a vaccine against the Zika virus. However, research should also be encouraged through Horizon 2020 and beyond. The Commission must then commit to providing patients with affordable treatment as a result of the research results. A key role in this process is also played by the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control, through the continuous monitoring it undertakes and, through this resolution, we recommend the periodic assessment of the risks of the epidemic, as well as the updating of epidemiological reports. With regard to prevention, I stress that both the Commission and the Member States must act to monitor invasive mosquito species and eliminate their breeding areas.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The Zika virus epidemic is spreading very rapidly. European Union territories are now affected by the virus, such as the French overseas territories (Guadeloupe and Saint-Martin). We must act as soon as possible so that the virus does not spread further within the European Union and regress in the rest of the world. In this resolution, the European Parliament welcomes the European Commission's decision to commit ten million euros for research on the virus. It would also make sense for the Commission to put in place a real strategy to counter the Zika virus. As the spread of the virus is widespread, it is essential to act accordingly. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because the least that can be asked of the richest areas in the world is that they provide the most depaid areas with specific elements of protection for pregnant women and children for free. There is no doubt about a basic human tragedy.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this resolution to call on the Commission to propose an action plan to prevent the spread of the Zika virus in Europe and to provide assistance to Member States and third countries committed to combating the epidemic. I call on the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) to regularly update its risk assessments and epidemiological bulletins and to set up a committee of experts on communicable tropical diseases to effectively coordinate and monitor all measures to be put in place in the EU. I welcome the Commission's decision to allocate EUR 10 million for research into the Zika virus and I think it is appropriate to focus on cases of severe congenital brain malformations in Latin America and their suspected link with Zika virus infection. I would stress that, in view of the likely further spread of Zika virus infection, it is necessary for the international community to rapidly put into practice the lessons learned from last year's Ebola crisis.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP fully supports the fight against the Zika virus.
