We support the scientific efforts that aim at providing a scientific explanation for the link between the virus and severe brain malformations reported in newborn children. UKIP would not oppose funds designated to study this issue.  However, we believe that initiatives of this kind should be decided at the national level, not by the unelected EU Commission, so we have decided to abstain in this occasion.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ Although I fully recognise the concerns about the spread of the Zika virus and the serious consequences it has on new born children I voted against this resolution as it contains unacceptable references to termination of pregnancy. I am against the free access to abortion and voting in favour of such measures would be contrary to my beliefs.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the text on the European Commission decision on the allocation of EUR 10 million for Zika virus research. It is a viral disease which, although mild, is highly compromising for the state of health of pregnant women and for children born to infected mothers. The funds allocated by the EU will lead to the possible development of a vaccine. In addition, a further EUR 40 million could be allocated from the Fund for Research on Malaria and Neglected Infectious Diseases.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and call on the Commission to present an action plan to prevent the spread of the virus in Europe and to assist Member States and third countries in combating this epidemic in the areas where the outbreak of the disease is most serious.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Zika virus is now a public health emergency, so an immediate response is needed to counter this real epidemic. There is a lot of information we have about it, for example it is now clear that the transmission of the Zika virus to humans occurs mainly through the bite of an infected mosquito. In my opinion, however, further research is needed, particularly on three fronts: a study on the strong suspicion of a link between the Zika virus and congenital brain malformations, the development of cures and vaccines and, above all, the development of tests for a rapid and effective diagnosis. It is essential to react immediately by providing assistance to infected people, especially pregnant women, and to avoid wider transmission of the virus in those regions and in other parts of the European continent. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report in order to prevent the spread of the virus in Europe as well and to provide assistance to Member States and third countries committed to combating the epidemic in the regions most affected.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ The World Health Organisation has declared the Zika virus a global public health emergency. The infection is suspected of leading to thousands of babies being born with underdeveloped brains. Some areas have declared a state of emergency, doctors have described it as ‘a pandemic in progress’ and some are even advising women in affected countries to delay getting pregnant.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. The Zika virus is identified as the main responsible for the multiplication of microcephaly cases in newborn babies. The virus has been found in 28 countries and mainly affects young and poor women living in less developed countries or regions. I agree with the finding of common sense that the international community must learn from the experience of the Ebola crisis and should invest in research and prevention of the causes that favor the disease. I call for new funding opportunities for research into the development of malaria vaccines and infectious diseases such as Zika to be explored in Horizon 2020. I agree with the mandate given to the Commission to present a plan to prevent the spread of the virus in Europe.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP fully supports the fight against the Zika virus. We support the scientific efforts that aim at providing a scientific explanation for the link between the virus and severe brain malformations reported in newborn children. UKIP would not oppose funds designated to study this issue.  However, we believe that initiatives of this kind should be decided at the national level, not by the unelected EU Commission, so we have decided to abstain in this occasion.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ I support focused research on preventive measures to avoid the spread of the virus, and on treatments investigating the strongly suspected link between the Zika virus and congenital brain malformations. This should lead to the development of treatments and vaccinations and rapid and effective diagnosis. I disagree with calls in both the original text and amendments favouring access to safe abortion in order to combat the rise in unsafe abortions. This is something which falls out of the European legislative remit to decide upon.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I welcome the assumption that the possible causes of microcephaly are numerous and that its origin is often unknown. Thus, the text of this resolution not only contemplates the possibility that consequences such as microcephaly may be caused by an infected Aedes mosquito, but also takes into account that researchers from Argentina and Brazil have established a relationship between concentrations of microcephaly cases in Brazil and pyriproxifen, a larvicide used in the supply of drinking water in 2014 in the affected areas of Brazil.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 For several months, the Zika virus has raged in various parts of the globe and, in particular, in some Latin American countries. Some governments are still facing one of the biggest health crises. Currently, the most effective means of combating this virus lies in prevention. It is a priority to take all the necessary precautions to protect yourself from infections, but the current lack of vaccine complicates this task. The downstream action is also made complex by the fact that there is no treatment against the Zika virus. For this reason, there is an urgent need to develop an effective action plan to prevent a greater spread of the virus, especially in the Member States of the European Union. The risk is that the virus may also spread in some European countries, and that is why I consider the action plan called for in the resolution to be important, but it will have to be equipped with the necessary resources if it is to be effective.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In early February 2016, the IHR Emergency Committee (International Health Regulations) declared that the zika virus was an international public health emergency. Experts agreed that there is a serious suspicion of a causal link between Zika virus infection during pregnancy and microcephaly, but this has not yet been scientifically confirmed.  It was unanimously concluded that there is an urgent need to coordinate international efforts to improve surveillance, strengthen the eradication of mosquito populations and speed up work on diagnostic tests and vaccines for vulnerable people, especially pregnant women. An EU early warning and response system has been launched.  I support the motion for a resolution on the Zika virus, which calls for further research into how the virus is transferred, the health effects of infection (including the suspected association with microcephaly) and how to combat the virus (including the development of vaccines). However, I cannot support the proposals put forward in many amendments because they are either not based on scientific knowledge or are contrary to competence. I voted in favour of the document.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the spread of the Zika virus in several European countries poses a danger, I believe that the European Union must support the governments of the affected countries in providing information and allocating EU funds for research that should focus mainly on preventive measures, in order to avoid the spread of the virus, but also on treatments. The development of treatments and vaccines and tests is needed for rapid and effective diagnosis.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution aims to establish an emergency system in the context of the Zika virus outbreak. It stresses the urgent need to coordinate international efforts to improve surveillance of the evolution of the virus, intensify population control, and accelerate the development of diagnostic tests and vaccines. Considering that the Zika virus is a real danger to public health and that it must be contained at all costs in order to eradicate it, I supported this report.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: in writing. – The reason I voted in favour of this resolution is obvious. As both policy makers and citizens have probably realised in recent months there has been an outbreak of the Zika virus in Latin-America, posing a potential threat to other regions of the world. The resolution reminds us that the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) has stated that around 80% of the infections remain asymptomatic. In addition, it calls for specific action, for example, for the set-up of improved communication plans and increased research on preventive measures.  In addition, I strongly welcome the trust that is put in the ECDC and its efforts to continuously monitor the situation and the Commission decision to increase the funding available to spend an additional EUR 10 million on researching the virus. In the end, the resolution shows us the importance of continuous research and innovation. In this case, it will save lives.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. 23 countries and territories are affected by the virus, including our overseas departments (Guadeloupe, Guyana, Martinique and Saint-Martin). The health emergency caused by Zika calls for an adequate response from the European Union. A rapid action plan is needed to combat the spread of the virus, with the distribution of mosquito nets to protect populations, and condoms to prevent sexual transmission of the virus.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. The Zika virus must now be a global concern. On February 1, 2016, the World Health Organization called the epidemic a public health emergency of global concern. Since October 2015, 5,000 cases of microcephaly have been reported in Brazil. More than 20 countries are affected by the virus, including French overseas territories such as Guadeloupe and Saint-Martin. As the Zika virus is sexually transmitted, there is a real risk of cross-border transmission and there is still no treatment. That is why I wanted to send a strong signal by voting in favour of the resolution on the Zika virus, which highlights the consequences of the epidemic on the health of women and newborns. Stronger cooperation is needed, which is why I support the Commission's decision to mobilise EUR 10 million for scientific research.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The fight against the Zika virus needs greater scientific and operational cooperation between EU Member States and Latin American countries most affected by Zika in order to establish better prevention, control, diagnosis and possible treatment measures. According to the World Health Organization, this virus could affect about four million people on the American continent alone in 2016. News of this outbreak is increasingly alarming and there are high suspicions that this virus could cause birth defects and neurological syndromes.  I consider it essential that research also includes the possible links between the virus and congenital malformations and neurological syndromes.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Abstention: The votes come three months after our group's request and the declaration of emergency.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. The International Committee for Health Emergency Regulations has declared that the Zika virus outbreak is an emergency of international public health concern. Experts agree that the causal relationship between Zika virus infection during pregnancy and microcephaly is strongly suspected, although not yet scientifically proven. All agreed on the urgent need to coordinate international efforts to improve surveillance, to step up control of mosquito populations, and to accelerate the development of diagnostic tests and vaccines to protect people at risk, especially during pregnancy.  This resolution, among other things, calls for the application of specific measures for potentially exposed European regions, the establishment of communication plans, investment for research into the possible causal relationship between microcephaly and pyriproxyfen, as well as other possible and complementary causes of microcephaly. The Zika epidemic in the American continent continues to evolve and expand geographically, with Brazil being the most affected country. There is strong evidence of an association between Zika virus infection during pregnancy and congenital malformations of the central nervous system, as well as between Zika virus infection and Guillain-Barré syndrome. All international solidarity on the part of the EU is due at this time.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. – Our amendments focused on: the implementation of specific measures for European regions, the establishment of communication plans, the possible causal relationship between microcephaly and the use of pyriproxyfen, as well as other possible and complementary causes of microcephaly. As they were accepted I voted in favour.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Cases of the Zika virus have been reported in 39 countries and regions around the world in the last two months. This includes some areas in the outermost regions of the European Union, although there is currently no risk of the Zika virus being transmitted to the rest of the European Union, we must be vigilant, because this may change in the summer months. I therefore welcome the european Commission's action, which has released EUR 10 million to fund, research and prevent the Zika virus. We need to support prevention by all means available through contraception control in many countries and to actively prepare for the possibility of an outbreak of the virus in continental Europe as well.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report supporting research and calling for an action plan to prevent the spread of the virus in the EU.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against this motion for a resolution because, while in theory it deals with the outbreak of the Zika virus, it promotes abortion in a lateral way, not only as a means of prevention for the virus but more generally as a concept, which I am strongly opposed to.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Considering the fact that experts agreed that a causal relationship between Zika infection during pregnancy and microcephaly is strongly suspected, although this has not yet been scientifically proven and therefore all possible causes of microcephaly should be investigated, I support the call on the Commission to explain what is the current state of this outbreak of the disease and the incidence of microcephaly in the EU. I strongly believe citizens should be aware of the degree of risk of transmission of the Zika virus infection in the EU. Moreover, the Commission should inform us if they have already considered advising EU health authorities to collaborate with the transport sector to ensure disinfection of cargo, cargo carriers and cabin and passenger compartments of planes arriving from affected areas.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 The situation is faithfully reflected in the WHO's declared the Zika virus outbreak a public health emergency of international concern (PHEIC). It should be noted that young and poor women in particular are at risk of infection, especially those living in the least developed regions of the countries concerned. In addition, the international community urgently needs to put into practice the lessons of last year's Ebola epidemic. I supported the text of parliament's resolution.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution since the European Union, in collaboration with the medical institutions, must continue to fight Zika virus and, in particular, the effects it has on newborns. Relevant medical guidelines should therefore be established in European overseas areas that have been affected by Zika outbreaks, as well as support the fight against the virus globally.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. I agree with the utmost urgency of a European strategy that takes the necessary measures to combat the Zika virus that has hit Central and South America by advancing rapidly and creating serious risks of malformations or microcephaly in the fetuses of pregnant women from the 'killer mosquito'. I therefore support the motion for a resolution by my colleagues in the ENVI Committee to ensure that the Eu ropean Union implements new funding measures for research, prevention, assistance, monitoring and information as soon as possible, in order to combat and stem as soon as possible the dangerous virus, declared by the WHO as a 'public health emergency of international importance'.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the Zika virus epidemic because I believe it is necessary for Parliament to sound the alarm about the consequences of this disease, also in the light of recent studies that have shown a causal link between the virus and the phenomenon of malformations found in foetuses. We absolutely must be able to stop this epidemic, which mainly affects women and children, and which also highlights a problem linked to the gender dimension and the issue of access to contraceptive mechanisms in those countries, which are often particularly poor. I believe it is essential to strengthen research by increasing the CONTRIBUTION of EUR 10 million allocated by the Commission and by coordinating international efforts to find vaccines and specific treatments for diseases. I welcome the call for specific awareness-raising and training of health personnel, so that the disease can be better distinguished from other similar diseases. Given the possibility of an explosion of the virus in Europe too, given the frequency of transoceanic travel during the summer, I think it is essential to speed up prevention in relation to protection against vector insects and the use of contraceptive methods.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. The fight against Zika is an important task – and the EU must play a leading role in this. However, I had to abstain in the final vote in favour of the resolution on the outbreak of the Zika virus, as, under the leadership of ALDE, the Left and the Greens, it has been possible to make unnecessary references to stem cell therapy and to call for the promotion of abortion. Here, a resolution which is in itself valuable is being misused for ideological purposes.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The World Health Organisation (WHO) declared a global emergency on 1 February. This was due to the zika virus outbreak in 41 countries. Brazil was the hardest hit. According to the virologist Jonas Schmidt-Chanasit of the Bernhard Notch Institute for Tropical Medicine, the danger has not yet been eliminated, but he warns against scaremongering. He assumes that the virus soon spread in Brazil. An outbreak on a similar scale is not expected in Europe, but individual cases are to be expected. As the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, we have therefore called on the European Commission to draw up an action plan to prevent the Zika outbreak in Europe. It is important to detect individual cases at an early stage in order to contain the spread of the virus as quickly as possible. The EU has already allocated EUR 10 million for research into vaccines. Experts expect such a vaccine to be available in a few years.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: in writing. ‒ Alongside my conservative colleagues, I strongly welcome demands for better and more effective prevention, surveillance and control mechanisms when combatting the Zika virus. Indeed, while the Zika virus has been around for a number of years, a true understanding of the disease, particular in terms of when it is most fatal, is severely lacking. The need for more assertive and targeted action is therefore not only timely given the recent outbreak, but it is also clearly long overdue. As a virus that poses international risk, a coordinated approach is crucial. The EU possesses a public health function and can therefore serve as a useful platform to facilitate communication and if needed, to provide advice and any other information required by the Member States. Such collaboration will ensure a more efficient allocation of resources and subsequently make any response more effective and therefore successful when minimising the destructive effects of this disease.  It is for these reasons that I voted in favour.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. With this resolution, Parliament is signaling to the European institutions how it wants the Zika virus epidemic in South America to be dealt with.  This resolution compiles a set of good intentions without, however, fulfilling the objectives that must be those of the elected representatives: to be objective about a health situation presented as catastrophic, to give solutions.  In terms of communication and management by WHO, there is an inadequate response, particularly in terms of communication. Many mothers-to-be are very anxious, even though the epidemiological data are not as alarming as the media suggests. Indeed, the number of microcephaly carried by babies with the virus remains less important than microcephaly babies who do not carry the virus. There is a need for in-depth research, which Parliament proposes to fund with the EUR 10 million allocated by the Union.  Faced with this text with good intentions, but somewhat removed from reality, I abstained.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report as this report highlighted the need for the EU to support scientific research in order to conclusively establish the link between Zika virus and microcephaly. It is highlighted in various amendments that delaying pregnancy is not enough as in many countries women are not granted access to information on their reproductive rights, so concrete measures must be taken to ensure that women have the information, support and services they need to exercise their right to determine whether and when they become pregnant. It is also proposed that where sexual violence exists and sexual and reproductive rights are criminalized, efforts to stop this crisis are not improved.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution which welcomes the EUR 10 million set aside for research into Zika but questions whether this is adequate for the scale of the challenge. The S&D priority is to ensure adequate resources are available for research into Zika: research should focus on prevention, the development of a vaccine and tests for rapid diagnosis, and the link between Zika and microcephaly.  All available funding options should be used, including Horizon 2020 and FP7.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I supported this text, which stresses in particular the need for a coordinated approach at European and international level in the fight against this epidemic. Parliament also mentions the need to support research on the Zika virus, for which the Commission has already allocated almost EUR 10 million, and which could benefit from further funding under the European Programme for Research and Innovation: Horizon 2020. The text also calls on the Commission to present an action plan to prevent the spread of the virus in Europe and to help Member States and third countries in their fight against this epidemic in the most affected regions.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the document. It discussed possible future measures which should be taken in order to develop diagnostic tests, vaccine, and treatment for the disease.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 The report calls on the Commission to present an action plan aimed at preventing the spread of the virus in Europe, but also to assist Member States and third countries in combating this epidemic. It also stresses the need to draw up immediate plans to prevent and address the Zika epidemic. We therefore consider this vote to be an appropriate stance.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution. It calls on the Commission to mobilise EUR 10 million for research on the Zika virus in order to strengthen the laboratory capacity to confirm suspected Zika virus infections and to differentiate Zika virus infections from other arboviral infections as well as to prove the possible causal link between Zika virus and microcephaly. It further calls on Member States to increase awareness of clinicians and travel health clinics about the evolution of the Zika virus epidemic and the affected areas, and to include Zika virus infection in their differential diagnosis for travellers from those areas.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ Our understanding of the Zika virus is still in its infancy but the disease is undoubtedly of grave concern throughout the world. The EU is at the forefront of global medical research and it is also home to some of the world’s strongest economies. It is therefore essential that we play a lead role in researching and ultimately eliminating this frightening virus.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ The Zika virus has become a global health problem. The spread of the Zika virus epidemic in Central and South America is likely to continue. In a globalised world, plagues can travel fast, as we have seen with bird flu and swine flu and we must be prepared for an outbreak in Europe.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's resolution on the Zika virus outbreak because I support measures aimed at investigating the virus, especially in severe congenital brain malformations to prevent further spread.  It is important to note that in existing European programmes, such as Horizon 2020 and FP7, there are also opportunities for additional research into the virus. It is clear that there is currently no vaccine or therapy available and that prevention is based on individual protection measures.  This epidemic has shown shortcomings in public health systems and the fact that the virus can have severe consequences especially for young and poor women. In this context, I believe that strong synergies at international level and strong support from the European Union to affected countries are needed to support universal access to primary protection. Further EU research is certain to help the Union itself, as local vector transfers are at risk of establishing local vector transfers in Europe during the 2016 summer season.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The ins and outs of this hypertrophied text are characterized by a very serious amateurism and a total lack of the necessary method for infectious diseases. In particular, at no time does the term "precautionary principle" appear. This is a blatant demonstration of the inept and, ultimately, totally unstructured functioning of the "thought" of this institution. The votes come three months after our group's request and the emergency declaration. Meanwhile, under pressure from the tourism and sports lobby (Rio Olympics) the emergency was lifted on 30 March. That is why I abstained on this text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP fully supports the fight against the Zika virus. We support the scientific efforts that aim at providing a scientific explanation for the link between the virus and severe brain malformations reported in newborn children. UKIP would not oppose funds designated to study this issue.  However, we believe that initiatives of this kind should be decided at the national level, not by the unelected EU Commission, so we have decided to abstain in this occasion.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution of my colleagues in the Committee on the Environment on the Zika virus disease epidemic. The text calls on the Commission to present an action plan to prevent the spread of the virus in Europe and calls for prevention strategies to be put in place. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution calling for the European Union to adopt an action plan on the Zika virus. The disease has been declared a "global public health emergency" by WHO and requires more coordination between Member States at European level.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the Zika virus outbreak. The countries concerned are suffering greatly, which is why the EU must provide them with the necessary support, also in order to avoid destabilising these states.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as it calls for the EU to support action on Zika, in particular through support for research and development for treatments, diagnosis and vaccines.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 On 13. 4 we voted on the motion for a resolution on the Zika virus epidemic. As a co-author of the adopted text, I was able to participate in its text from the very beginning. When negotiating the proposal, I was based on information provided by the Agency as the European Parliament's contact person for the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC). Unfortunately, it is already a rule that we encounter a terrible new epidemic of some kind of virus every year. Last year it was Ebola, today it's Zika. Contrary to the first reports of this virus, we are now discovering the shocking truth that Zika is an even bigger problem than originally thought. In addition to severe developmental disorders manifested by stunting or ending brain growth, or the entire head, the fetus (called microcephaly) is found to be likely to cause other disorders and brain damage. I am pleased that the proposal welcomes the greater mobilisation of resources for the investigation of this virus and its effect on the human body. We need to find out as quickly as possible exactly what is causing Zika and how to successfully prevent it. The text also called for further examination of the effects of the use of pyriproxifen on the virus as well as its link to microcephaly. I am very glad that we have managed to create a balanced text, which I was able to support in the end.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ Sadly, the Zika virus, responsible for numerous cases of death and birth defects in Brazil, is spreading rapidly in Latin America and Caribbean. This trend is very embarrassing particularly when we take into account the fact that there is no vaccine to prevent or medicine to threat Zika virus. In this regard, EU response to the Zika virus should be on one hand immediate and on the other similar to the response that the Union had to Ebola outbreak. This means that the EU should mobilise political, financial and scientific resources to help contain, control, treat and ultimately defeat Zika. The fight against Zika virus in reality is a fight for the future of humanity therefore the EU should lead this fight.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I abstained on the Zika resolution. The ins and outs of this hypertrophied text are characterized by a very serious amateurism and a total lack of the necessary method in terms of infectious diseases. In particular, at no time does the term "precautionary principle" appear. This is a blatant demonstration of the inept and, ultimately, totally unstructured functioning of the "thought" of this institution. The votes come three months after Dr. Joelle Mélin requested on behalf of our group. Meanwhile, under pressure from the tourism and sports lobby (Rio Olympics) the emergency was lifted on 30 March.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I abstained on this vote because this resolution on the Zika virus problem is poorly drafted.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. Co-reporter of this text, Dr Joelle Melin, a Member of the European Parliament in our group, had to dissociate himself. After expressing alarm at the lack of response from WHO (World Health Organization) to the ZIKA viral epidemic, she made an emergency request and co-authored the report. However, the subject has been distorted and shows a staggering amateurism and a total lack of method, necessary in terms of infectious diseases, and ignores the precautionary principle. That is why I abstained.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I welcome the assumption that the possible causes of microcephaly are numerous and that its origin is often unknown. Thus, the text of this resolution not only contemplates the possibility that consequences such as microcephaly may be caused by an infected Aedes mosquito, but also takes into account that researchers from Argentina and Brazil have established a relationship between concentrations of microcephaly cases in Brazil and pyriproxifen, a larvicide used in the supply of drinking water in 2014 in the affected areas of Brazil.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Zika virus is a virus transmitted by mosquitoes with its sting and has recently become a major danger to the population of the world. The World Health Organisation has declared a public health emergency on an international scale due to the outbreak. There are more and more cases of Zika outbreaks worldwide, for example recent cases in two European regions. The most problematic areas are with the population living near rivers, lakes, streams and water sources. Most often, such a population is not prepared to suppress the virus. As the risk of Zika virus infection becomes increasing, in particular due to the high flow of travellers and world trade, this proposal calls on the Commission to allocate €10 million in funding for Zika virus research, which will contribute greatly to tackling this problem at European and global level.  I supported this proposal for a resolution and hope that the resources allocated will help prevent the spread of the virus.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: In writing. Since the emergence of the Zika virus in different parts of the world, the European early warning and response system for medical emergencies has been activated and the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control has been continuously monitoring the situation. With this resolution, the European Parliament urges the EU and its Member States to redouble their efforts in prevention, as millions of Europeans travel to areas likely to be affected in the coming months. At the same time, it stresses the need for the EU to step up its research on both the virus and its presumed effects, as well as on treatments and vaccines. In addition, the text recommends that the Commission and interested Member States increase their special vigilance in the early detection of Cases of Zika virus infection in RUP and PTOTs. Finally, as the EU develops its strategy to combat this infection, the European Parliament is highlighting the unique know-how and expertise available to our overseas overseas in the area of emerging vector-borne diseases, including the Zika virus. I therefore vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the Zika virus epidemic because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I abstained on this text. The Europe of Nations and Freedoms group had demanded that this text be included in emergency procedure (a fact done by the World Health Organization on the same day). The refusal of the European Parliament has resulted in a long procedure and a mediocre text. In particular, this text does not respect the appropriate methods of infectious disease, and ignores the precautionary principle.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The Zika virus is an emerging virus transmitted by the mosquito. After a first outbreak in 2007 in Micronesia, it is now spreading to the South American continent, so that in 2016, WHO "declared the Zika virus outbreak a public health emergency of global concern." In addition, a causal link between Zika infection during pregnancy and microcephaly is strongly suspected, although it is not yet scientifically proven. The resolution also supports "the UN's call for the repeal of laws and policies that restrict women's access to sexual and reproductive health services and rights, in violation of international norms." But the resolution also stresses "the need for further research on the possible link between microcephaly and larvicide pyriproxyfen" (made by a Monsanto partner to protect from the crazy). I vote for this text, which does not rule out any possible explanations.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. On February 1, I asked for the Zika outbreak to be listed in emergency proceedings. This was rejected by Parliament, while two hours later, WHO for not being left behind (as with Ebola), announced a public health emergency of international concern. An oral question and a motion for a resolution were prepared by the Committee on the Environment and Health. The aim was to hold the Commission to account for its action in the face of this new epidemic. The text was distorted by a very serious amateurism after many amendments disregarding the precautionary principle. I ended up withdrawing my name as co-reporter from this motion for a resolution. As a result I abstained.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. On February 1, 2016, who declared the Zika virus outbreak an international public health emergency. Zika virus is an emerging virus transmitted by mosquitoes, having been first identified in 1947 in the rhesus monkey of the Zika forest in Uganda by a network of monitoring of selvática yellow fever. Zika virus is mostly transmitted to people through the bite of infected mosquitoes of the genus Aedes, especially Aedes aegypti, in tropical regions, the same mosquito that transmits dengue, chicungunha and yellow fever. It is important to create communication plans at the most appropriate scale in order to raise awareness and promote appropriate behaviour to prevent mosquito bites.  Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ While the proposal contained a number of very valid points that deserve discussion, I could not support it as the final version included unacceptable references to abortion, which is an issue that the EU has no competence on.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. Both the rapid spread of the Zika virus and its modes of contamination or its serious consequences on public health, especially that of women and children, make it formidable. While WHO believes that there is a plausible link between the contamination of pregnant women and the increase in cases of microcephaly in children and that a vaccine is currently not available, I strongly encourage the implementation of preventive measures that will preserve the health, well-being and comfort of life of these two more fragile groups. With this in mind, I enthusiastically support better information for women in the field of reproductive health, safe access to abortion and the use of condoms. I would also like to draw attention to the essential symbolic dimension of these measures. Through these, we are sending a positive signal by defending the rights of women to dispose of their bodies while promoting and working to improve the health situation in countries affected by the virus. In the same way that we raise awareness of pandemic risks.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – The Zika virus is one type of viral disease that has a low mortality rate but a high infection rate. As an effective antibody is not yet known, it is essential that the EU, like the entire international community under the auspices of the World Health Organisation, spends the maximum possible amount of resources (both financial and human) on research and development of vaccines, but also on combating it. However, it should be remembered that the mother's infection does not necessarily mean that the disease is passed on to the fetus. I am harshly distancing myself from the claim that Zika automatically causes damage to the central nervous system of the fetus, as we know many cases where babies are born perfectly healthy. In this context, I therefore see the proposals towards the blanket liberalisation of abortion as unfortunate and medically totally unfounded. We have already seen with rubella that many infected women who defied the pressure of society and refused to have an abortion subsequently gave birth to healthy babies. Similarly, we must understand Zika – if we had introduced a procedure whereing each infected mother would have been automatically recommended for abortion, it can be argued that we would have deprived 99 healthy children of their lives in order to prevent a single harm. I believe that the rubella practice serves as sufficient evidence that abortion is not and cannot be the way to combat zike.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I hope that we have learnt our lesson from the recent Ebola outbreak and our experience of the past epidemics, and that the structures we already have in place stand us in good stead to make an effective and swift response to developments. I welcome the EU funding of EUR 10 million to examine the potential link of the Zika virus with the epidemic of congenital brain malformations and other neurological complications observed across Latin America and French Polynesia.  We have to step up efforts to research the virus and its suspected effects, tests for rapid diagnosis, and treatments and vaccines. Prevention must be promoted by way of mosquito control, and we must also be prepared for an outbreak in mainland Europe. Therefore, I have voted in favour of the resolution with some exceptions on paragraphs on abortion, which are not competences of the EU.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 In a communication of 1 February 2016, the World Health Organization (WHO) declared the Zika virus outbreak to be a public health emergency of international concern, announcing that there was a high probability of a causal link between infection with the Zika virus during pregnancy and small-headedness, although this is yet to be scientifically proven. In several European countries, cases of infection caused by the zika virus have been detected: on 11 February 2016, the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) reported a case of small-headedness in relation to a pregnant woman in Slovenia, where the Zika virus infection occurred during the pregnant woman's stay in Brazil. In its report, the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety takes into account the opportunities and measures that European authorities can take to prevent the introduction of the Zika virus into Europe and the spread of the infection in Europe. At the same time, it places great emphasis on what the EU can do to help the competent authorities fight against and eradicate the spread of the epidemic in various regions of the world, in particular in the disease centres in the north-east of Brazil. I voted in favour of the draft resolution.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution follows the request of JOELle Mélin, ANF MP, to register the Zika epidemic in emergency procedure on 1 February 2016. Two hours after Parliament's refusal and referral to committee, WHO declares a public health emergency of international concern....  From a simple question of what the commission intended to do in the face of this viral epidemic, the text became an accumulation of assertions and questions characterized by a very serious amateurism and a total lack of methodology in the field of infectious diseases. Moreover, the vote on this proposal comes three months after the request of the ENF group and the declaration of urgency. And two weeks after the lifting of the emergency by WHO... We therefore abstain against this proposal for an enlarged resolution, which reflects the heaviness and incompetence of the European institutions.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the World Health Organisation statement of 1 February 2016, which classified the Zika virus as an international health emergency and taking into account that some cases of infection have been reported in the Member States of the Union, an action plan is urgently necessary to prevent the spread of the virus in Europe and support third countries. Zika virus is a serious public health problem, as it mainly affects economically disadvantaged women with less access to health and hygiene care and worse living conditions, as cases of babies born with microcephaly are associated.  In this sense, it is necessary to deepen and support scientific research, improve access to primary health care and prevent the spread of viruses. In this regard, My vote is in favour, because I believe that the Union should play an active role in delineating strategies to prevent the spread, in supporting research and access to health care.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. While the ENF group had requested the zika epidemic to be registered as a matter of emergency procedure as of February 1, 2016, the vote came more than three months later. Meanwhile, under pressure from the tourism and sports lobbies (Rio Olympics), the emergency was lifted on 30 March. In the end, the text is characterized by amateurism and a complete lack of method in terms of infectious diseases. For example, there is no mention of the precautionary principle, even though WHO, in order to avoid the Ebola delay scandal, has declared an international public health emergency. I have therefore decided to abstain in the vote on this text.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report to call for the EU to support action on Zika, in particular through support for research and development for treatments, diagnosis and vaccines.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. The Zika virus, which has been found in Martinique and French Guiana, is also present on the soil of the European continent. This virus, which results in microcephaly in the children of infected women, cannot currently be treated with a drug or prevented by a vaccine. This resolution stresses the need for further research to find an effective treatment, but also the need for a coordinated international approach to the fight against the virus. So I voted for this resolution.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the Zika virus disease epidemic. I commend the European Parliament for taking concrete action in the face of this serious virus, which is spreading dramatically and rapidly in this part of the world, and particularly in the French West Indies. Martinique, as well as Guadeloupe are French and European overseas departments affected by this epidemic, we could not remain inactive. In keeping with the victories in France for women's rights, I could only encourage safe access to prenatal medical care for pregnant women infected with the Zika virus. Finally, we must continue to encourage scientific research, particularly on severe cases of congenital brain defects, through the raising of additional funds.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the Zika virus disease epidemic, as it reiterates our concerns about the spread of the disease and its health consequences, particularly for pregnant women and infants. At present, the epidemic has already affected the French overseas territories. It is essential that action by the entire international community and the European Union is taken to combat the spread of the virus, that care is developed as soon as possible, and that it can be made accessible. It is up to the European Commission to put in place a strategy to combat the epidemic, and to take appropriate measures in the affected regions.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I have already stressed the importance of public health issues, as well as the need to take the outbreak of infections and epidemics caused by various viruses very seriously. I think the best weapon for the Zika virus is knowledge, which we can get with the help of research teams. New hypotheses are constantly emerging, with some reports showing that, for example, the virus can be transmitted by blood transfusions or even sexually. Our main task is to provide continuous information at EU level, in which our citizens will have access to relevant, reliable information and will be able to consider the situation before heading to the countries concerned.  The report that we voted on today recognises the importance of this, so it also has my support.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ An evolving outbreak of Zika virus infections is currently spreading in the Americas and the Pacific region. I have voted for this motion for a resolution that stresses the need for a treatment or vaccine for the Zika virus according to the ECDC. The European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control was established in 2005 and is the EU agency that strengthens Europe’s defences against infectious diseases.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I consider the information on the links between Zika virus infections and microcephaly cases to be worrying and alarming. The lack of clear information on the effects this virus has on babies, as well as the lack of certainty about the mechanisms of transmission of this virus, requires greater involvement of the EU and the international community in the investigation of these cases. In this respect, the EUR 10 million allocated by the EU for the research of the Zika virus, although not a large enough amount compared to its implications for human health, is a first step in the discovery of a vaccine or a way of combating the virus.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution which, in the context of the Zika virus epidemic, highlights weaknesses both in the response of public health systems, in particular at primary care level, and in the provision of reproductive health services and the rights of women and girls in the affected countries, in particular as regards information and care during and after pregnancy. Simply recommending delaying pregnancy until more is known about the Zika virus is certainly not an adequate and satisfactory response. In the absence of prevention, treatment or vaccine to protect against this viral infection at present, and given that there could be a risk of local transmission in Europe during the summer of 2016, the Commission should urgently analyse insect control products in terms of human health and mosquito efficacy – carrier infections.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution. The ongoing outbreak of mosquito-borne Zika virus infection is raising public health concerns internationally. The virus is spreading very quickly and has already reached Europe. Immediate action is therefore urgently needed, as the Zika virus is scarier than originally thought. Global anxiety infection is particularly dangerous for pregnant women. In view of the threat posed by this virus, communication plans should be drawn up to the widest possible extent and to raise awareness among the population. The Commission should draw up an action plan to halt the spread of the virus in Europe and assist Member States and third countries in combating the epidemic in the regions with the highest outbreaks. I welcome the Commission's decision to allocate EUR 10 million to the European Union. In 2005, the Commission adopted a communication on the development of the Zika virus in the United States, which has been awarded the Following Information on The Virus virus.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP fully supports the fight against the Zika virus. We support the scientific efforts that aim at providing a scientific explanation for the link between the virus and severe brain malformations reported in newborn children. UKIP would not oppose funds designated to study this issue.  However, we believe that initiatives of this kind should be decided at the national level, not by the unelected EU Commission, so we have decided to abstain in this occasion.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Last February, the World Health Organization called the Zika virus outbreak an international public health emergency; transmission of the virus occurs mainly through the bite of an infected mosquito and an association has been established between the appearance of the virus and cases of microcephaly and other neurological pathologies. There is currently no vaccine capable of eradicating the virus, and scientific research, if encouraged, could also help prevent congenital malformations and abortions associated with such serious situations. However, in view of the votes of the other Members of the European Parliament with regard to abortion, I felt it appropriate to abstain.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. I did not support the resolution on the Zika virus outbreak because it proposes measures that are outside its scope and directly violate the principle of subsidiarity for topics related to family, health and education. It is unacceptable that the resolution, which focuses on research on outbreaks of the virus, vectors, the necessary supply and development of the vaccine, on preventive and public health measures, in view of the shortcomings of health systems detected, is being used to introduce access to abortion in the affected countries, in stark contrast to the judgment of the COURT of Justice of the EU in Brüstle v Greenpeace, which found that "life begins after conception" and against the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, Article 3, which states that 'everyone has the right to life, to liberty and to personal security', including unborn children. This is also recognised by the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and other international human rights documents.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The Zika virus is arguably a global public health problem. However, the European Parliament's resolution, in the form in which it was put to the surface, also presents a not-so-new perspective on solving this problem that looks more like the product of time that we all in Europe want to forget. Such a view of life, under the guise of humanity and dedication to science, says that only some have the right to live while some others, as well as people like us, do not have that right.  According to research published by nature in March this year, it is still said that scientists are trying to determine the association of the causative agent of Zika disease with the more frequent occurrence of microcephaly in Brazil and say that the findings so far are the tip of the iceberg. Data on 97 positive findings for zika virus in 854 confirmed cases of microcephaly out of 2,197 investigated in the period up to November 2015 suggests that the situation is worrying, however scientists agree that the number of studies quantifying the risk of the virus is too small and only preliminary. This does not give the right to make decisions lightly and promote terminations of pregnancy. It is regrettable that the current situation is being exploited for this purpose, and this is the main reason why I voted against this resolution.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. On February 1, my colleague Dr. Mélin, for the ENF group, requested the inclusion of the Zika epidemic in emergency procedure. In the face of Parliament's refusal, the draft discussion was sent to the ENVI committee where an oral question and a draft resolution were drawn up. The initial question was simple: "What does the commission intend to do about this new viral epidemic, which was already submitted to WHO in November 2015 by the public health services of French Polynesia?". The final text, enlarged, is characterized by a serious amateurism and a total lack of method necessary in terms of infectious diseases. In particular, at no time does the term "precautionary principle" appear. This is a blatant demonstration of the unstructured functioning up to the aberration of this institution. The votes come three months after our group's request and the emergency declaration. Meanwhile, under pressure from the tourism and sports lobby (Rio Olympics), the emergency was lifted on 30 March. For all these reasons, the co-reporter, Dr. Joelle Mélin, withdrew from the project. Like her, regretting the shortcomings of a necessary and important text, I prefer to abstain.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The outbreak of the Zika virus, which is mainly recorded in Latin American and Caribbean countries, has shed light on the social inequalities in the populations of the regions concerned and on the specific problems of public health systems. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe it is essential to act as a matter of urgency: the European Union must follow an integrated approach in providing all the necessary resources so that countries with high risk and an already infected target are put in a position to fight the virus and apply preventive measures to contain it. It is therefore a priority to finance research to ensure that vaccines and targeted treatments are carried out and that, at the same time, the alleged link between the virus and congenital malformations in the brain is investigated: since the outbreak of the epidemic, more than 3 500 cases of microcephaly children have been recorded. Given that pregnant women are the most at-risk target, the need to act in a gender-sensitive approach goes without saying. The Commission should also propose specific measures for European regions where the Zika virus has already spread, in order to eliminate all possible transmission vectors.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Zika virus is a new mosquito-borne virus first detected in 1947 in uganda's Zika forest and on rhesus monkey under forest yellow fever surveillance network. On February 1, 2016, the WHO declared a public health emergency of international proportions due to an outbreak of the Zika virus outbreak.  As there is a real threat of cross-border transmission of viral infection through infected travellers and global trade, it is important to draw up a communication plan on the most appropriate scale to raise awareness of the population and encourage appropriate behaviour to protect against mosquito bites. EU and third country airlines should adequately and properly disinfect aircraft arriving from member states' infection areas and raise awareness among doctors and passenger sickness centres regarding the development of the Zika virus outbreak and vector control established by authorities in the affected areas so that they include the Zika virus in their differential diagnosis for the inhabitants of these areas and the passengers arriving from them and to prevent indigenous transmission.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. The International Committee for Health Emergency Regulations has declared that the Zika virus outbreak is an emergency of international public health concern. Experts agree that the causal relationship between Zika virus infection during pregnancy and microcephaly is strongly suspected, although not yet scientifically proven. All agreed on the urgent need to coordinate international efforts to improve surveillance, to step up control of mosquito populations, and to accelerate the development of diagnostic tests and vaccines to protect people at risk, especially during pregnancy.  This resolution, among other things, calls for specific measures to be adopted for potentially exposed European regions, the establishment of communication plans, investment for research into the possible causal relationship between microcephaly and pyriproxyfen, as well as other possible and complementary causes of microcephaly. The Zika epidemic in the American continent continues to evolve and expand geographically, with Brazil being the most affected country. There is strong evidence of an association between Zika virus infection during pregnancy and congenital malformations of the central nervous system, as well as between Zika virus infection and Guillain-Barré syndrome. All international solidarity on the part of the EU is due at this time.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Resolution on the Outbreak of the Zika Virus, which caused a state of emergency on the international stage, calling into question the health of European citizens. I share my concern that there is currently no vaccine or cure to protect people from Zika virus, and I urge all Member States to increase laboratory opportunities for early detection and diagnosis of the Zika virus. Furthermore, although the virus causes almost no or mild symptoms, it is known that it can infect the unborn child and potentially cause microcephaly, which would be devastating to the demographic picture in the Republic of Croatia, which anyway records a low fertility rate and a large proportion of the old population in the total population. I welcome the Commission's decision to mobilise medical teams and equipment in case of emergencies inside and outside the EU. We must be prepared to transmit the Zika virus in the coming summer months. I therefore call on all competent institutions to focus their efforts on eradicating or at least preventing this epidemic.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the adoption of a report aimed at proposing preventive measures to prevent the spread of the Zika virus. On February 1, 2016, the World Health Organization identified the Zika virus epidemic as a threat to public health of international importance. The Zika virus has been sporadically recorded in two European regions in the past, Martinique and French Guiana. It later appeared outside its endemic territory, leading to an outbreak in Micronesia and a few years later also in French Polynesi. In addition, it has been revealed that this virus can cause neurological diseases. Although no case of transmission of the disease has yet been reported on the European continent, sufficient preventive measures are needed to prevent the spread of the virus. The need to prevent and spend sufficient resources to combat the virus is particularly important given the possible link between Zika virus infection in pregnant women and the increase in microcephaly. Unfortunately, there is no precise treatment for microcephaly or the Zika virus yet, so there is a particular need to raise awareness among citizens and experts about how to protect themselves from infection. In the context of this report, I also welcomed the Commission's decision to allocate EUR 10 million for research into the Zika virus.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 On February 1, 2016, who declared the Zika virus outbreak an international public health emergency. There is a strong suspicion, although not yet scientifically proven, of a causal link between Zika infection during pregnancy and microcephaly. At present there are no prophylaxis, cures or vaccines against Zika virus infection and there is a risk that during the summer season 2016 the infection will also spread in Europe. These reasons give rise to the importance of defining communication plans to raise awareness and promote appropriate behavior to avoid mosquito bites. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 On 1 February 2016, the IHR Emergency Committee (International Health Regulations) declared that the zika virus had caused an international public health emergency. Experts agreed that there is a serious suspicion of a causal link between Zika virus infection during pregnancy and microcephaly, but this has not yet been scientifically confirmed. It was unanimously concluded that there is an urgent need to coordinate international efforts to improve surveillance, strengthen the eradication of mosquito populations and speed up work on diagnostic tests and vaccines for vulnerable people, especially pregnant women. An EU early warning and response system has been launched. Research should continue on how the virus is transferred, the health effects of infection (including suspected microcephaly) and how to control the virus (including the development of vaccines). Unfortunately, the proposals put forward in many amendments are not based on scientific knowledge (suggesting a link between the use of a larvicid called 'pyriproxifene' and microcephaly, with the additional suspicion that this larvicid is causing an increase in microcephaly), they are also at odds with EU competences. The occurrence of the Zika virus cannot be used as an excuse to put pressure on some countries to change their abortion laws. For this reason, I could not support the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. On February 1, 2016, the World Health Organization declared the Zika virus outbreak, the main outbreaks of which were identified in Brazil, as a global public health emergency. Today, the virus has been reported in 28 countries. In voting in favour of the resolution, I called on the European Commission to propose an action plan, with specific measures for the European regions affected by the virus, to prevent the spread of the virus in Europe. This is all the more so since France is the only European country affected by the virus through its outermost regions. Finally, Europe must help, where necessary and possible, third countries affected by the epidemic.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP fully supports the fight against the Zika virus. We support the scientific efforts that aim at providing a scientific explanation for the link between the virus and severe brain malformations reported in newborn children. UKIP would not oppose funds designated to study this issue.  However, we believe that initiatives of this kind should be decided at the national level, not by the unelected EU Commission, so we have decided to abstain in this occasion.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. On February 1, 2016, who declared the Zika virus outbreak an international public health emergency. This report notes that the Zika virus, transmitted through mosquito bites, has been found in 28 countries and that its consequences can change the lives of victims, particularly young and poor women. This report calls on the Commission to present a virus prevention plan in Europe and stresses that research should be linked to three strands: research into the strong suspected links between the virus and congenital brain malformations, the development of treatments and vaccines and the creation of tests to enable rapid and effective diagnosis. In addition, it wants eu public funds to be invested in research if eu public funds are invested, its results are exempt from intellectual property rights and there is a guarantee that patients can benefit from affordable products.  The document also welcomes the Commission's decision to mobilise EUR 10 million for research, recommending that it be included in cases of severe congenital brain malformation in Latin America and the suspicion of its relationship with Zika virus infection.  I voted positive.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I supported the resolution on the Zika virus outbreak. Last February, WHO declared the outbreak a public health emergency of global concern. According to a growing number of preliminary studies, Zika virus is one of the causes of microcephaly - a disease that causes the birth of babies with smaller-than-average skulls and a delay in brain development - as well as Guillain-Barré syndrome. Currently, there is no specific treatment or vaccine.  Knowing that the consequences of this virus can disrupt the lives of victims, it is urgent to take all necessary measures to combat it, to help the most affected regions and prevent its spread in Europe. In particular, research should be carried out on preventive measures, treatments and the suspected link between the virus and microcephaly. I welcome the Commission's decision to mobilise EUR 10 million for this purpose.  Finally, awareness-raising and information work is needed with citizens and health stakeholders.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Proposal for a Resolution 'Zika Virus Outbreak'. On 1 February 2016, WHO declared the Zika virus outbreak to be a public health emergency of international concern. Sporadic outbreaks of the virus-causing disease have been detected in two European regions, Martinique and French Guiana, and cases of contamination in Guadeloupe and Saint Martin. The European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control has welcomed continuous monitoring of the situation, but it is requested that the Centre regularly update its risk assessments and epidemiological bulletins, as well as establish a committee of experts on communicable tropical diseases.  We welcome the Commission's decision to set EUR 10 million to investigate the virus for both vaccine prevention and treatment. We also call for the establishment of a prenatal diagnosis protocol and the possibility of continuing with pregnancy in the event of malformations, as well as the impetus for research for the eradication of the carrier mosquito, using insecticides not harmful to humans.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution calling for the European Union to adopt an action plan on the Zika virus. Transmitted by mosquito bites (Aedes aegypti type), the Zika virus is suspected of causing fetal malformations carried by infected pregnant women and causing Guillain-Barré syndrome. It was declared a "public health emergency of global concern" by the World Health Organization (WHO) on 1 February 2016. The resolution calls for more coordination in the EU in the face of this virus. It recommends, for example, that the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control establish a committee of experts on tropical communicable diseases to effectively coordinate and supervise all necessary measures in the EU. It also calls on the Commission to present an action plan "with sufficient targets for the free distribution of mechanical barriers, such as nets that protect against mosquito bites and condoms that prevent sexual transmission".

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. It clearly and unequivocally demonstrates the need to fight the Zika virus. The fight can be achieved in several stages: in particular by investing in research and ensuring that their results are easily accessible; secondly, to adequately inform people what protective measures need to be taken to prevent the spread of the virus; thirdly, ensure appropriate treatment and care of infected people.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. In 2016, the World Health Organization (WHO) declared the Zika virus (mosquito-borne) outbreak as an international public health emergency and was named as the main responsible for multiplying cases of microcephaly in newborn babies.  Zika has been found in 28 countries and its consequences can change the lives of victims, particularly young and poor women, who mostly live in the less developed regions of the most battered countries, so it is urgent that research primarily includes preventive measures to prevent the spread of the virus, and zika research should be articulated between preventing the spread of the virus to other regions , develop treatments and vaccines and also create tests that allow for a rapid and effective diagnosis. The European Commission has already made it ready to mobilise EUR 10 million for research into this virus. However, it will not be too much for the need to create an action plan to prevent the spread of the virus in Europe, supporting Member States and third countries in the fight against this epidemic in the worst affected regions.  For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution calling for the Union to adopt an action plan against the Zika virus. Transmitted by mosquito bite, the Zika virus is suspected of causing fetal malformations carried by infected pregnant women and causing Guillain-Barré syndrome. It was declared a "public health emergency of global concern" by WHO on 1 February 2016.  The text calls for greater coordination in the EU to deal with the virus and calls for the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control to set up a committee of experts to coordinate the EU's action. It is also a welcome to welcome the Commission's mobilisation of EUR 10 million for research on the virus, but also to call for the work of European laboratories carrying out research to be coordinated.  There is an urgent need for the Union to provide a coordinated and effective response to global health crises.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report as this report highlighted the need for the EU to support scientific research in order to conclusively establish the link between Zika virus and microcephaly. It is highlighted in various amendments that delaying pregnancy is not enough as in many countries women are not granted access to information on their reproductive rights, so concrete measures must be taken to ensure that women have the information, support and services they need to exercise their right to determine whether and when they become pregnant. It is also proposed that where sexual violence exists and sexual and reproductive rights are criminalized, efforts to stop this crisis are not improved.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. ‒ The link between the Zika virus and birth defects has now been confirmed by the US Centre for Disease Control and Prevention.  Zika is already a global public health emergency and there is a greatly increased risk of transmission in the EU in the coming summer months.  I welcome the regular meetings of the Health Security Committee, the activation of the EU’s Early Warning and Response System, and the mobilisation of EU funds to support urgent research.  Recent reports of progress towards a vaccine are encouraging, but it is clear that multiple measures will be needed to deal with this emergency, including preventative actions and proper access to existing health services.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution, which stresses the need for research into the Zika virus as well as the need for rapid diagnosis, treatment and vaccination. The Zika virus epidemic is a global health threat and measures must be taken to stop it. Its consequences are all the more serious because it mainly affects pregnant women and newborns. Last but not least, it also highlights the seriousness of the problem of complex access to contraception in the least developed regions of the world.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I welcome the assumption that the possible causes of microcephaly are numerous and that its origin is often unknown. Thus, the text of this resolution not only contemplates the possibility that consequences such as microcephaly may be caused by an infected Aedes mosquito, but also takes into account that researchers from Argentina and Brazil have established a relationship between concentrations of microcephaly cases in Brazil and pyriproxifen, a larvicide used in the supply of drinking water in 2014 in the affected areas of Brazil.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I join my colleagues in this place to call for the EU to support action on the Zika virus, which is sullying so many people’s lives across the world, and the risk to the EU – including the UK – is growing. It is problems such as this which call for internationalist action, and the EU represents a great opportunity, with its institutional set-up ready to be utilised for activities like this.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The Zika virus, which is mostly transmitted to humans by the bite of an infected Aedes mosquito in tropical areas, spread dangerously in many countries last year, and in the absence of a vaccine or treatment, prevention is currently based on personal protective measures. It has been recorded in 28 countries, and the consequences of the Zika virus can be mainly affected by young and poor women, most of whom live in the least developed regions. I am therefore glad that the Commission has released EUR 10 million for research into the Zika virus, with a recommendation to focus on cases of severe congenital brain malformations in Latin America and their possible association with Zika virus infection. With the EP resolution, we called on the Commission to draw up an action plan to prevent the spread of the virus in Europe and to assist Member States and third countries in combating this epidemic in the regions most affected (especially in the Caribbean and Central and South America).

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's motion for a resolution highlighting the current and serious problem of the Zika virus epidemic has been ideologically abused. In the end, I couldn't support him.  The resolution focuses on scientific research, its support and coordination. Intensive development of vaccines and medicines is essential, research should also help to more clearly identify the Zika virus from other diseases based on symptoms, as well as to clarify why an epidemic of this magnitude has arisen in humans as early as 1952. The resolution calls on the Commission to consider increasing the amount to be allocated to the fight against the Zika virus. Even with an approximate comparison with EUR 10 million, it seems insufficient to the billions to be released in the US to combat the virus. The proposal also targets practical things such as disinfection on the way out of infected countries or population information. On all these points, the resolution has my clear support. However, amendments have also been voted on in the resolution, which I cannot agree with. The resolution in its final text also contained generalisation references in favour of abortion. This is not the first time that resolutions have been devalued by these amendments, and this practice negatively affects the outputs of the European Parliament. The resolution in its final form was therefore adopted without my support.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The Zika virus was detected in 1947 in rhesus monkeys in the Zika forest in Uganda.
