In 2007, the virus was first recorded outside known endemic boundaries (an epidemic on Yap Island in the Federated States of Micronesia). In 2015, the virus erupted badly in Brazil (especially in the north-east) and has been linked to an unusual number of babies born with microencephaly. Now the Zika virus, caused by mosquito-borne sting, is becoming more prevalent. There have also been "imported" cases of Zika virus infection in various European countries. A case of microencephaly has been reported in a pregnant woman from Slovenia who has become infected with a virus with similar symptoms to the Zika virus during her stay in Brazil. The European Commission has therefore earmarked EUR 10 million for research in the field of this virus. The report states that the results of this research are free of intellectual property rights and that patients are afforded the affordability of such developed products. A potential link between the larvicide substance pyriproxifen and microencephaly should be further investigated. In addition, reproductive health services and rights for women and girls must be guaranteed and to try to address the social issues of families with children born with microencephaly. For this purpose, I supported the motion for a resolution.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 In the last year and especially in the months we have seen the spread of the Zika virus, which has infected about four million people in South America from Brazil and prompted the WHO to declare the epidemic a public health emergency of international importance. One of the most worrying aspects of the Zika virus is the existence of a possible correlation between zika virus infection during pregnancy and microcephaly of newborns, although this has not yet been scientifically proven. The resolution adopted today calls for research to focus mainly on preventive measures to prevent the spread of the virus first and is based on three priorities: study of the possible link between the Zika virus and congenital brain malformations, development of treatments and vaccines and development of tests for rapid and effective diagnosis. In order to prevent the spread of the virus in Europe, we also call on the Commission to draw up an appropriate action plan and to provide assistance to Member States and third countries committed to combating the epidemic in the most affected regions. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ February 1, 2016 The World Health Organization (WHO) has declared the Zika virus outbreak an international emergency. The virus has been reported in 28 countries around the world and has particularly bad consequences for poor young women. The Zika virus is the most widespread in Brazil and is a realistic transmission of the virus across borders through infected travellers and world trade. It was also discovered in two European regions - Martinique (Martinique) and French Guiana. There is currently no cure for the Zika virus. Therefore, research into this virus proposed by the Commission to allocate €10 million should be addressed.  In my view, it is of utmost impact to achieve an action plan to prevent further spread of the virus.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ On February 1, 2016, an expert committee of the World Health Organization declared the Zika virus epidemic an international emergency. The virus was first discovered in 1947, but it's only been in the last few years that an epidemic has occurred. Currently, there is no vaccine or cure against the spread of the Zika virus, which is transmitted by the bite of a mosquito. Experts agreed that there is an association between pregnancy infection with the Zika virus and the microcephaly of the newborn baby. In addition, there is a real chance of zika virus transmission on European Union soil. I support the proposal for a resolution on the Zika virus. It is very important to contain the virus as soon as possible and not to allow the transmission of zika virus into the EU. The EU's funding for research will help develop vaccines and combat the further spread of the virus. This protects the health of EU citizens and prevents the development of microcephaly in pregnant women.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the proposal. I fully support research that could help reduce the current and future negative impacts of the Zika virus. However, in several places, the proposal bases its conclusions on factually incorrect information that contradicts scientific knowledge and, moreover, exceeds the competences of the European Union.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. I voted against the resolution to the oral question on the Zika virus outbreak. The resolution has some good initiatives, such as the need to establish a communication plan at the most appropriate levels in order to raise public awareness and promote appropriate action to prevent mosquito bites. However, the resolution also has a few points that I cannot support. These are, above all, points relating to the prevention and termination of pregnancy, sexual reproductive health and contraception, as this does not, in my opinion, fall within the resolution on the outbreak of the Zika virus.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The report stresses the need to draw up immediate plans to prevent and address the Zika epidemic. It also calls on the Commission to present an action plan to prevent the spread of the virus in Europe and to assist Member States and third countries in combating this epidemic. That is why we voted in favour.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution, while theoretically dealing with the outbreak of the Zika virus, in a lateral way promotes abortion, not only as a means of prevention for the virus, but more generally as a perception.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion on the zika virus epidemic, as I believe that we should draw attention to all challenges to public health. This virus infects people by stinging certain mosquitoes and causes, among other things, small heads in newborns. It is important to note that the same mosquito also carries through dengue fever, Chikungunya fever and yellow fever. I believe that, therefore, a great deal of emphasis should be placed on scientific studies, developments and prevention. All the more so because the infection can easily reach Europe. Rapid testing, treatment and vaccines are needed to prevent the spread of the epidemic. The European Union already has a health protection instrument, namely the Early Warning and Response System (EWRS). In order for this system to fully perform its function, its operation must be constantly reviewed. In addition to the Zika virus, the motion also states that the location of small-headedness in Brazil is also linked to the larval killer piriproxifen, which was introduced into the drinking water network in affected areas of Brazil in 2014, according to Argentine and Brazilian researchers. I believe that this element should not be ignored either, so we must also draw attention to the unreasonable use of chemicals.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Since the first reported cases of Zika virus infection, almost a year has passed and cases of new infections have already been reported in 45 countries, and the number of patients has been steadily increasing, especially in Brazil. Worse still, there is evidence that the virus contributes to the formation of birth defects and serious neurological complications. However, so far it has not been possible to find an effective method of treatment or prevention of the spread of the virus. Due to the high mobility of persons, the epidemiological risks on other continents must under no circumstances be underestimated. The upcoming summer season means an increased risk of transmission of the virus to Europe. Therefore, we need the right strategy, especially to combat the mosquitoes that are the main carrier of Zika. So far, the Commission has allocated €10 million to research related to this virus, and the European Medicines Agency (EMA) has set up an expert group to find medicines or vaccines against the virus. The European Commission's activities should therefore be multi-pronged. The situation should continue to be monitored and supported by the most dangerous countries, to increase the knowledge of EU citizens about preventive measures to avoid the spread of the virus and to develop modern treatments.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: Written. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution because the World Health Organisation (WHO) has declared the spread of the Zika virus an international public health threat, which is why it is important to effectively study the effects of the Zika virus and to try to prevent the spread of the virus to ever wider areas.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ On 1 February 2016, the World Health Organisation declared the Zika virus outbreak a Public Health Emergency of International Concern and it is considered a serious cross-border threat to health, having been reported in 39 countries or territories worldwide, including two European regions.  The appearance of the virus has been associated with clusters of microcephaly cases and other neurological disorders, including cases of Guillain-Barré syndrome, and WHO declared that a causal relationship between Zika infection during pregnancy and microcephaly is strongly suspected. Although no cases of autochthonous Zika virus transmission have been reported on the European continent, there is a risk of establishment of local vector-borne transmission in Europe during the 2016 summer season and there is no specific treatment or vaccine currently available.  I agree that there is an urgent need to raise awareness of the effects of the virus, to adopt measures in order to eradicate all vectors of transmission and to assist regions that have already been affected by the Zika virus. Furthermore, we need to avoid transmission of the virus on the European continent and to increase our research funding in order to find solutions to eradicate this health-threatening virus. Due to all these factors, I support the proposed resolution.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The Zika virus is mainly transmitted to humans through the bite of an infected Aedes mosquito, mainly the Aedes aegypti species in tropical regions, a mosquito that also transmits dengue, chikungunya and yellow fever. According to the assessment of the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control, in the absence of treatment or vaccine and since mosquitoes that transmit the Zika virus bite both indoors and outdoors, most often during the day, prevention currently relies on personal protective measures, such as wearing long-sleeved T-shirts and pants treated with permethrin. , favouring rooms equipped with mosquito nets or air-conditioned areas for sleeping and resting, or the use of a mosquito net.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, as I believe it is fundamental that the European Union sets up an action plan to fight the emerging mosquito-borne virus, Zika, inside Europe, as prevention will be much more effective than coming up with emergency responses once it is too late. Increasing awareness about the virus, about its channels of transmission and its symptoms through a good communications plan, would be an essential first step.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. \u2012 Dear President – (DE) Mr President, I voted in favour of the resolution on the outbreak of the Zika virus because the situation requires decisive action from the European Union. Cases of infection with this virus have already been reported in some European countries. Unfortunately, according to the assessment by the authority dealing with this problem, there is still no treatment or vaccine to prevent infection, especially in children. The resolution therefore rightly calls for the current situation to be taken into account and to focus on disseminating preventive measures to prevent mosquito bites. The European Commission should therefore further financially support countries at risk of mosquito invasion in order to protect European citizens from the threat in the best possible way.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The Zika virus was detected in 1947 and has largely ravaged Africa, Southeast Asia and the Pacific islands ever since. In Europe, local vector transmission of the disease is at risk of forming during the 2016 summer season. It is currently investigating whether there is a link between infection of pregnant women with zika virus and a large increase in cases of microcephaly, which cause children to be born with an unusually small head and in most cases delayed brain development.  While I support the view that the danger of this disease needs to be warned early and that the development of diagnostic tests and vaccines must be accelerated, I find it inappropriate to call on states to introduce the right to abortion in response to this virus. Therefore, I voted against this report.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. - I supported the motions for resolutions on the Zika virus outbreak. On 1 February 2016, the World Health Organization declared a global public health emergency due to the Zika virus outbreak. The Zika virus is an increasingly prevalent mosquito-borne virus, and was first discovered in 1947 in rhesus monkeys in the Zika forest in Uganda as part of a network to control silvatic yellow fever. Outbreaks of the Zika virus have been sporadic in two European regions, Martinique and French Guyana, and in Africa, both the Americas, Asia and the Pacific, and cases of infection have also been detected in Europe, particularly in the overseas territories of Guadeloupe and Saint-Martin. According to the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC), most infections are still asymmptomical (about 80%).

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report as this report highlighted the need for the EU to support scientific research in order to conclusively establish the link between Zika virus and microcephaly. It is highlighted in various amendments that delaying pregnancy is not enough as in many countries women are not granted access to information on their reproductive rights, so concrete measures must be taken to ensure that women have the information, support and services they need to exercise their right to determine whether and when they become pregnant. It is also proposed that where sexual violence exists and sexual and reproductive rights are criminalized, efforts to stop this crisis are not improved.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that in cases where there is such risky harm to the fetus, the mother should have a free choice whether to end motherhood or not. I therefore voted against my Polish colleagues and supported the report.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support this resolution. I welcome the intention to mobilise additional EUR 10 million approved by the Member States for urgent research on the Zika virus in response to the upsurge in cases of severe congenital brain malformations across Latin America, and their suspected link to Zika virus infections (as seen in Brazil and French Polynesia). If the link is proven, this money could be used to combat the Zika virus, for example, by developing diagnostics and testing potential treatments or vaccines. One of the other proposed directions of research is also research leading to sterilising male mosquitos.  The aim is to establish a multinational and multidisciplinary consortium across Latin America and other affected or at-risk regions, able to implement the urgently needed research during the ongoing Zika virus outbreak.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. Our ENL group is at the origin of the debate on the Zika virus, with the aim of ensuring that the phenomenon is treated as soon as possible.  There is an urgent need to address the problem of this virus before it is no longer in a position to respond to the threat. However, the increased text by multiple underified and epidemiologically unnecessary recitals makes it inefficient.   There is also an attack on the sovereignty of member countries.  I choose abstention on this motion for a resolution.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The Zika virus is a newly transmitted mosquito-borne virus first identified in 1947 in the Zika forest in Uganda through a monitoring network for the monitoring of yellow fever in rhesus monkeys. The Zika virus outbreak has highlighted inequalities in the affected countries, including public health systems and living conditions, disproportionately affecting the poorest members of society, who often live near open water sources and are not adequately prepared to prevent and combat the disease. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report as this report highlighted the need for the EU to support scientific research in order to conclusively establish the link between Zika virus and microcephaly. It is highlighted in various amendments that delaying pregnancy is not enough as in many countries women are not granted access to information on their reproductive rights, so concrete measures must be taken to ensure that women have the information, support and services they need to exercise their right to determine whether and when they become pregnant. It is also proposed that where sexual violence exists and sexual and reproductive rights are criminalized, efforts to stop this crisis are not improved.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which introduces a number of balanced measures to combat the Zika outbreak in the EU. Human rights, especially women and children, are taken into account, as well as urging research in this area and measures that go beyond pharmacological ones.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. Unfortunately, zika virus is spreading rapidly in Latin America. That is why I supported this report, which calls on the European Union to fight this virus. The European Union must support the research and development of a treatment and a vaccine for this purpose.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The Zika virus outbreak is an emergency of international public health concern. Experts agree that the causal relationship between Zika virus infection during pregnancy and microcephaly is strongly suspected, although not yet scientifically proven. All agreed on the urgent need to coordinate international efforts to improve surveillance, to step up control of mosquito populations, and to accelerate the development of diagnostic tests and vaccines to protect people at risk, especially during pregnancy.  The Zika epidemic in the American continent continues to evolve and expand geographically, with Brazil being the most affected country.  This resolution calls, among other things, for the application of specific measures for potentially exposed European regions, the establishment of communication plans, investment for research into the possible causal relationship between microcephaly and pyriproxyfen, as well as other possible and complementary causes of microcephaly. All international solidarity on the part of the EU is due at this time.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The critical resolution on the Zika virus outbreak, which also emphasises the prevention of the spread and the fight against the virus, must be approved.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ The Zika virus outbreak has hit women and children in some of the most vulnerable countries in South America and the Caribbean. The outbreak has exposed the severity of lack of access to sexual and reproductive health for women in many developing countries.   The EU’s response must ensure prevention, and guarantee the health and safety of Europeans. Nevertheless, it must also reinforce a robust development cooperation policy which tackles the situation of women and the provision of maternal and sexual and reproductive health facilities.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The Zika virus epidemic is now a serious threat, mainly due to the still insufficient level of medical understanding of the transmission of the virus and the effects it has on the human body. I consider the approved text of the resolution to be wrong precisely because it makes premature conclusions from the presumptions and partial information on the virus. The policy recommendations drawn from such conclusions always bring much more harm than good. The call in paragraph 19 for the EU to support measures aimed at accessing contraception and abortion in states with Zika virus is not based on medical consensus, but on the ideological activism of the liberal left in this House. I could not support such a text.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Zika virus epidemic is a serious problem in which the European Union should be actively involved. We have funding, research staff and research institutes to support efforts to find an effective vaccine. There are worrying signs that this epidemic is spreading to more countries. Stopping this epidemic should be a priority for the authorities of the South American countries, and Europe should support these efforts as far as possible. Such a pragmatic approach would merit full support, but, as is often the case in this House, pragmatism very often loses out against ideology. References to abortion in this text and calling on countries tackling the effects of the Zika virus epidemic to liberalise abortion laws are a mistake and proof of a misunderstanding of the substance of the problem. I cannot support a resolution in which Parliament wants to use the tragedy of many women and children to promote abortion as a universal medicine for all the problems of developing countries.  Taking life is never the right thing to do, and in this particular case it will not bring us one step closer to eradicating this epidemic. I support all the necessary measures to combat the Zika epidemic, but I cannot agree with the demands for easier access to abortion, which are contained in this text. For this reason, I voted against this resolution.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the Zika virus outbreak, which presents a set of proposals to fully address this threat to global public health. In the last two months, cases of Zika virus infection have been reported in 39 countries that include some territories in the outermost regions of the EU. While there is currently no risk of autocopenone transmission of the virus in the rest of the EU, this could change during the summer months, so we should be prepared to react to an outbreak in continental Europe. I therefore advocate intensifying efforts to investigate the virus and its effects, as well as to carry out rapid diagnostic tests, screening, treatments and vaccines.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the outbreak of the Zika virus, which calls, inter alia, on the Commission to draw up an action plan to prevent the spread of the virus in Europe and to assist Member States and third countries in combating this epidemic in regions where the outbreak is more severe.

name: Michał MARUSIK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We have just voted here on a resolution on the assessment of the situation in Poland, on the assessment of the rule of law in Poland. The peculiarity of this vote is that this resolution does not bring anything about the rule of law in Poland, but it says a great deal about the rule of law in the European Parliament and in the European Union. The Treaty on European Union does not confer on the EU institutions the right to control and decide on such elements of the rule of law. These are the internal affairs and internal competences of the Member States. Therefore, the European Union thus shows that it does not care about the rule of law because it does not respect the law it has established itself. It makes us a little ridiculous as an institution and disgraces us.  I am, of course, a Polish patriot and I always try Polish to defend the Polish interest, but at the moment I am simply defending the rules, at the moment I am speaking not as a patriot, but as a man of the political right, as a man to whom the elementary righteousness of conduct and the rule of law are no strangers and are not indifferent. The righteousness of the proceedings lies mainly in the fact that not only do we require others to respect their laws, but also that we know, respect and obey our own laws, and if we consider them wrong, we will be able to change them. But let us respect the law so that we can also demand respect for the law from others. I therefore voted against this resolution , not because of its content, but because it was a clear violation of the law by the European Parliament and a clear abuse of the rule of law.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – There is no doubt that the EP made a serious mistake today by voting down this resolution, underestepping the EU's stool not only in Poland, but also in other EU Member States.  I remember that this is the third time that the EP has openly meddled in the internal affairs of an EU member state. It was Austria a long time ago, hungary followed, now it is Poland, and there were always political reasons behind it. It has always been a move against representing the same country that did not share the ideas that are represented in the EP by the mainstream, in particular the European People's Party and the European Socialists. It's a kind of warning to the new Polish government.  I don't think it's acceptable. It was a mistake, and as president of the Alliance of European Conservatives, of which poland's ruling Law and Justice party is a member, I strongly object to this procedure.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European It's rare to be in this room, in this mostly empty room... Let's be honest, we know this isn't where decisions are made. So no one who sees these meetings through the monitor thinks that decisions would be made here, when there are eight of us, ten, 30, brackets closed... So it is rare to hear a speech as sensible, clear, clear and professionally correct as that of a Polish colleague in the Polish debate, who said that we have asked, nicely, in writing, in accordance with the rules, that the European Union should mark the legal basis on which it interferes with Poland's internal life. We're familiar with Hungary the same problem for many people. In our case, they were unable to show the legal basis, nor did they meet the deadline. It's been three months, they should have answered within six weeks.  I would like to ask our dear friends in Western Europe to take care of their own business now, not to blame us for democracy and the rule of law. Explain to their own populations in Germany, Belgium and so on, for example, the basis on which mass immigrants are allowed in against the express will of the population, and what Hungary rule of law there Hungary where the police do not work, the various official bodies do not work, not to mention the secret services, etc. and put the whole of Europe at risk... (the President has withdrawn the floor from the Member)

name: Stanisław ŻÓŁTEK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Some of the actions of the Polish government, such as attitudes towards expatriates, attitudes towards the family, are correct. Yes, some activities, such as the Surveillance Act or the nationalisation of the earth, are like a result of nightmarish communism. However, the authors of the adopted resolution on the situation in Poland are hardly bothered by these socialist actions. The resolution raises objections mainly to the election of the Constitutional Tribunal. In practice, it is about stools and not only in the Court. However, I voted against the resolution solely because the European Union should not meer in the internal affairs of the sovereign Polish. Schuman, the founder of the European Union, falls over in the grave, seeing how wonderful the idea of a community of nations is turning into a creation whose sole purpose is official power over all states, robbed of the struggle against Christianity and the family and the promotion of homosexuality.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – The election of the day on which this debate takes place – a debate which is intended to condemn Poland as a country that allegedly violates human rights and threatens democracy – is the best illustration of the real attitude of the current Authorities of the European Union to the cultural diversity of the peoples of Europe. We are celebrating the 1050th anniversary of our baptism, we in Poland at the moment have celebrations and such a gift was sent to us today. But I want to say one thing – let's leave our national perspective. The day when Article 7, which deprives one of these countries of rights in the European Union, against Poland, against Hungary or against any other European country, will be the beginning of the end of the European Union. And you decide whether you run this process or not.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Of course, the government of any country that has come to power through democratic elections undoubtedly has the power to implement reforms, all the more so if these reforms are demanded by the public, if they are party political platforms, the wishes of the electorate. That is what is happening in Poland. But, on the other hand, any government must follow the principles of faith, the government of any country has international treaties and is accountable to international agreements. Unfortunately, at this moment, there are huge problems in the case of the judiciary, with the independence of the mass media, with such essential things that are the cornerstone of the values of our European Union. That is why I abstained from voting in favour of this resolution, and I believe that, to some extent, both sides are playing each other on the nerves of both the Polish Government and the European Union institutions and supposedly want to test which nerves they will not stand first. I repeat that I voted with abstention. Thank you!

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. This report contains no reference to one of the most pressing issues in Poland. The situation of LGTBi women and people is now extremely delicate, having reached the competing ban on abortion in any of the cases. Unfortunately, the GUE/NGL amendments in this direction have been decayed from the opposite position of majority groups, which have turned their backs on Polish feminists who claim their rights on the streets. However, we voted in favour of the resolution as it includes important aspects relating to the need for the protection of fundamental rights in Poland in the face of the current regression situation, and urges compliance with the conclusions of the Venice Commission on the rule of law.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. We call on the Polish authorities to fully implement the recommendations of the Venice Commission on the ability of the Constitutional Court of Poland to respect its Constitution and to ensure respect for the rule of law. If the Polish government does not comply with the recommendations, the European Commission must go further and activate the second stage of the "systemic threats to the rule of law" procedure, launched on 13 January.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution on the situation in Poland, which expresses the European Parliament's deep concern about the regression of the rule of law in that country, the paralysis of poland's Constitutional Court which endangers democracy and human rights and which calls on Poland to implement the decisions and recommendations of the judicial bodies in accordance with international and European standards.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which interferes in the internal affairs of a Member State.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I do not believe that it is for the European Parliament to tell the people of Poland how their country should be run. These matters are sovereign to the Polish people.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the Polish constitutional crisis creates two parallel legal systems, which can lead to great legal uncertainty. It is essential that the PiS government respects the democratic values of the European Union and stops moving Poland away from a community of shared values.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission announced at the beginning of the year the opening of a process for investigating possible violations of the rule of law by the Polish authorities due to changes in the functioning and organisation of the Constitutional Court and in the process of appointing the directions of the public media.  After the terrorist attacks in Brussels, the Polish Prime Minister cancelled the reception of refugees that had been agreed by the previous government. However, all terrorist attacks were perpetrated by European citizens and not refugees. Recently, the government has expressed its intention to promote the criminalization of abortion, the limitation of the use of contraceptive methods and the creation of a new crime typification: prenatal homicide, with a criminal framework of 3 to 5 years. These changes are a civilizational setback in terms of women's rights in a country where, according to the WHO, some 240,000 illegal abortions are performed each year. Finally, the Polish government's decision to replace its representatives in the Venice Commission was made known after they criticised the Polish government's actions. All these episodes deserve the deepest condemnation from the European Parliament.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: in writing. ‒ I vote against this resolution. The EU has no jurisdiction to criticise the Polish Government. Poland is a sovereign nation with a democratically elected government. No dictates from the EU can tell the Polish people how to run their own internal affairs.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution, which calls on Poland to respect democracy and the rule of law. I agree that the Polish authorities must respect the rule of law and guarantee the powers of the country's Constitutional Court to guarantee the primacy of the constitution in the legal system. I support the calls for the Polish authorities to make public and implement the decisions of the country's Constitutional Court, as recommended by the Venice Commission of the Council of Europe.  The European Commission must make efforts with the Polish Government to find a way out of the situation.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The joint proposal calls on the Commission to launch the second phase of the rule of law procedure by presenting a rule of law recommendation if the Polish Government does not comply with the recommendations of the Venice Commission in the structured dialogue and to offer Poland the help to develop solutions to strengthen the rule of law. It is grotesque and perverse that proposals to strengthen the rule of law should come from the Very Commission which does not operate democratically, opaquely, in a globalist interest, in violation of the EU's itemised standards, and acting in the interests of the European people in the interests of the European people, as, for example, when it is determined by a qualified majority against EU rules to set an immigrant distribution standard.  I rejected the proposal because it impermissiblely requires interference in the sovereign functioning of the Polish State in violation of existing EU standards, under the cover of defending liberal values and the rule of law, and, moreover, citing factually unfounded circumstances such as: "In Poland, the effective paralyzing of the constitutional court threatens democracy, human rights and the rule of law."

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP is seriously concerned at the level of interference by the Commission in Poland – in particular the use of the Rule of Law mechanism. We believe this sets a dangerous precedent in the further erosion of the sovereignty of EU Member States. We do not take an opinion on the reforms being pursued by the newly elected Polish government but firmly believe that this is a matter for the democratically elected Government of Poland and the constitutional courts to decide – not the unelected European Commission.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. When will the Commission's unelected bureaucrats allow the democratically elected governments of our Member States to implement the programme that has brought them to account?

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I approved this joint resolution for at least three reasons. Firstly, it reminds us from the outset that it is essential to ensure full respect for the common European values set out in Article 2, as well as the rule of law, democratic principles and human rights. Too many Member States seem to forget this! Secondly, it supports the Commission's decision to launch a structured dialogue under the rule of law framework in Poland, which should clarify whether there is a systemic threat to democratic values and the rule of law in Poland. Thirdly, it states that it expects the Commission to follow up on the situation in all Member States with regard to respect for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, thus avoiding double standards and reporting to Parliament.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. – Poland is immersed in a worrying process, characterized by the dismantling of the rule of law and the weakening of democratic institutions, from the coming to power of the Law and Justice (PiS) party. The Polish government has pushed for justice reform that poses an unequivocal threat to the separation of powers. The Venice Commission called it a danger to democracy, human rights and the rule of law. This report focuses on criticising this judicial reform which, if implemented, will mean a break with the democratic system and with the values and treaties of the Union. That is why I voted for it. Authoritarianism has no place in the EU. The European Union must be proactive in defending democracy in Poland. In this regard, I rejected the resolutions raised by the Eurosceptic and Europhobic groups which refused any Community action in support of and solidarity with Polish democracy. I will also continue to oppose the Polish Government's ultra-conservative, Europhobic and authoritarian policies and its insolidative position on the refugee crisis.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 In 1997 Poland adopted a new constitution which, respecting the principles of the rule of law, has guaranteed political pluralism, the separation of powers and freedom of the press and information in recent years. The Constitutional Court, for all these years the pivot of Polish constitutional democracy, has been the subject of major political and legal disputes in recent months linked to the appointment of five constitutional judges and to a law proposed by the government of Prime Minister Szydlo, which aimed to seriously undermine the prerogatives and independence of the Court. The resolution on the situation in Poland, voted on today in Parliament and supported by me, expresses with concern the succession of these events which risk jeopardising the stability of Polish democracy and respect for human rights. The European Parliament calls on the Polish Government to respect the Judgment of the Court of 9 March 2016, also fully implementing the recommendations of the Venice Commission. The Commission must take on the task of proceeding along the path of structured dialogue with the Government of Poland, without partiality ascertaining whether or not there is a threat of systemic violations of democratic principles.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution because it highlights the serious situation in which the most basic human rights are being enforced. In addition, the text includes amendments by our group specifically discussing the situation in which women's sexual and reproductive rights are located. We consider Polish abortion legislation to be already one of the most restrictive and recall UN international obligations and opinions that denying access to sexual and reproductive health services to the population is a violation of human rights.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution on the situation in Poland is totally abnormal in a European Union that defends democracy and respect for freedoms. Member States are sovereign and must freely decide their domestic policy and the European Union does not have to intervene to criticise Poland in the management, for example, of its Constitutional Court. Polish voters elected a president and then a predominantly conservative assembly around the Law and Justice party and this is the real problem of the Union, which does not accept that people can actually decide their own destiny. I have therefore decided to vote against this resolution.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution represents unacceptable interference with Poland's national sovereignty. The European Union also claims to impose its law on matters which do not fall within the competence of the Community institutions, thus interfering in the internal affairs of the Member States. That is why I did not want to support this text.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have voted in favour of this resolution. The resolution expresses strong concern about political developments in Poland, focusing on constitutional issues, such as amendments to the Constitutional Court. However, it is deeply regrettable that not a word is mentioned about the plans to totally ban abortion. Unfortunately, the Left Group's amendment condemning abortion restrictions and defending women's right to their own bodies did not go through. The resolution would, of course, have been much better off by showing that the oppression of women and contempt for democracy are strongly linked. While the other political groups are groping, we in the left group stand up in solidarity with all the thousands of demonstrators who have protested in Poland and elsewhere in Europe for democracy and women's rights. That is why I voted in favour of both the amendments and the resolution.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. For a few months now, the Polish government has been taking measures not in line with the values and principles of the Union, such as changing the configuration of the Constitutional Court or those adopted to the detriment of the freedom and independence of the media. Such measures take the Warsaw Executive away from Community convergence in terms of democratic quality. In view of this and the worrying situation, the Commission intends to put into operation for the first time the instrument for assessing the democratic quality of the Member States. This instrument is ultimately empowered to provisionally withdraw Poland's voting rights in the Council because it has broken democratic standards against the values and freedoms to be defended by a State that is part of the EU.  To this day, the Polish government remains reluctant to give some explanation and has even alerted the Commission to the possible counterproductive effect that action could have from the Community institutions against the legislative reforms that are being carried out by the Polish government.  In order to help restore democratic normalcy in Poland, I have cast my vote in favour of the resolution.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution, in which the European Parliament approves the Commission's decision to launch a structured dialogue under the rule of law framework, which should clarify whether there is a systemic threat to democratic values and the rule of law in Poland. Parliament welcomes the Commission's assurance that the dialogue with the Polish authorities will take place impartially, in accordance with an evidence-based and collaborative approach, and calls on the Commission, if the Polish Government does not follow the recommendations of the Venice Commission in the context of the structured dialogue, to launch the second phase of the rule of law procedure by issuing its 'rule of law recommendation' and to offer its support to Poland in seeking solutions to the rule of law. Of course, the European Parliament stresses that all the action to be taken, as determined in accordance with the Treaties and the principle of subsidiarity, must fall within the competence of the EU and its Member States. Parliament expects the Commission to monitor all Member States in the same way as regards respect for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, while avoiding double standards, and inform the European Parliament thereof.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \u2012 By supporting the resolution on the situation in Poland, I voted in favour of respect for fundamental rights of the rule of law, human rights and the values and principles set out in the EU Treaties and international instruments. The European Union must, in accordance with the law, respect the equality of the Member States as well as their national identity. I think it is right that we are informed about the current problems of the justice systems, as they are essential for the functioning of the rule of law and for guaranteeing the fundamental rights and freedoms of the citizens of individual members.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I support this document because Poland is not the only EU Member State where fundamental democratic values are at risk. Unfortunately, similar processes are at work in Croatia and the reaction of ambassadors of Western countries to the suppression of media freedoms is proof of this. I call on all GOVERNMENTS of the EU Member States to be guardians of the fundamental values of liberal democracy on which the Union is founded.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that what has been happening in Poland since the new government took office last year violates the provisions of Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union on the common values that undersoe the Union and endanger democracy and the rule of law within Europe's borders.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Respect for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental human rights is an essential obligation which every EU Member State must respect, on a constant basis, in the context of all its political action. As pointed out by the Venice Commission, some reforms recently adopted in Poland, as well as the failure of the current government to publish the verdict of the Polish Constitutional Court of 9 March 2016, actuallye prevent the Court from protecting the principles protected by the Constitution, threatening the very essence of the rule of law. An effective, impartial and independent judicial system is a fundamental prerequisite for protecting citizens' rights and freedoms. In this respect, the European Commission must continue to strictly monitor compliance with these principles and promote a dialogue with the Polish Government in order to put an end to a situation of great concern. The European institutions must also closely monitor the current and growing popular mobilisation in Poland for a reform of the right to abortion, acting with conviction and firmness, should the situation so require, in defence of a fundamental right, the result of bitter battles and unadmissable pieces along the road to effective and complete women's emancipation.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Member States must build on values such as democracy, the promotion of human rights and fundamental freedoms and be guided by the principles of the rule of law. Equality, respect for minorities, tolerance, solidarity are common values shared by member countries. Recent events in Poland concerning legal and political issues concerning the composition of the Constitutional Tribunal and the new structural rules raise certain concerns about the competence of this institution. The Polish Government's actions on the Constitutional Tribunal pose a risk to constitutional democracy, and the Polish Government needs to implement the recommendations drawn up by the European institutions and meet international requirements. The values of democracy and the rule of law must prevail in each Member State and, if not, immediate action must be taken to remedy situations contrary to the principles on which the Union is based, which is why I have expressed myself in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in Poland.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution is an interference in Poland's national sovereignty. The reference to the judgments of the Constitutional Court is spurious, as the majority of judges have guidelines contrary to the current government. I am voting against.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. The Polish government has been reluctant to give any explanation and warned of the counterproductive effect of attacking its country's legislative reforms.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. Since the Eurosceptic PiS (Right and Justice) party came to power, the Polish government has implemented a series of highly controversial reforms, such as the reform of the Constitutional Court and the reform of television and public radio.  On 13 January, the European Commission launched a preliminary inquiry to determine whether the rule of law is threatened by these reforms. Respect for the rule of law and fundamental rights is a major element of European integration. To be part of the European Union, each Member State must ensure that european values in Article 2 of the Treaty are respected. The European Commission, as the guardian of the treaties, must investigate when these values are put at risk. The situation in Poland is clearly worrying and needs to be looked at very closely. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I voted in favour of the proposal [2015/3031(RSP)] on the situation in Poland because we are facing a conservative turn around in the country that is of great concern. It makes the reform of the constitutional court and the law that effectively puts the public media under government control. Poland, despite the concerns expressed by the European Commission, has approved the reform of the Constitutional Court, which limits the authority of judges, thus questioning the fundamental democratic principle of the separation of legislative, executive and judicial powers. The European Commission must ask Poland for more explanations on laws that violate the democratic standards of the Eu ropean Union.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because I am very concerned about the actions of the current Polish Government and the Polish President in relation to the Constitutional Tribunal, an institution which, by definition, should be impartial and ensure checks and balances and control the actions of the government in power. The paralysis of the Tribunal is worrying, especially in a country that contributed so significantly to the abolishment of Communism in Eastern Europe, and borders on the breach of European laws and values such as the rule of law, democracy, human rights and the freedom of speech as enshrined in the Treaties.  I hope that the majority of the Polish people continue to enjoy the benefits of the membership of the EU.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, referring to the situation of denial of the rule of law which the Polish government has authored since taking power. As a reminder, the Polish government introduced two deeply undemocratic laws in December 2015, one severely limiting the powers of the Polish Constitutional Court, the other jeopardizing the functioning of public media and their funding. Following these unfortunate events, the Commission decided to activate the Rule of Law Warning Mechanism to assess systemic threats to the democratic foundations of EU Member States. I am pleased that Parliament, through this resolution, supports the Commission's approach and reminds Poland, which, like other Member States, is dangerously involved in the fragmentation of the Union's fundamental values.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and hope that the structured dialogue between the Polish Government and the Commission will lead to the revision of other decisions of the Polish Government which raise concerns about their legality and their possible impact on fundamental rights.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution following statements by the Council and the Commission on the situation in Poland is an attempt to protect human rights from being hit by political confrontations or tactics. As ensuring respect for common European values is the duty of all of us, I have decided to vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because, while meddling in the internal affairs of a sovereign state, it is only an instrument of political pressure for principles in which I believe. Without going into the substance, I believe that this European Union must respect and enforce certain basic values, while bearing in mind that it itself takes authority from the Member States and not the other way round.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that all Member States must fully comply with EU law in their legislative and administrative practice, and that all legislation, including the primary law of all Member States and candidate countries, must reflect and adhere to basic European values, namely democratic principles, the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 We are a Union of Values, which is founded on democracy, the rule of law and the separation of powers. The country's support is primarily and fundamentally dependent on respect for these principles. Of course, national policies are not immutable and often change after elections. What is not frequent – and should worry us – is that with a new government one wants or changes the nature of the state. What is happening in Poland is frankly worrying. The functioning of a democratic rule of law is based on separation and respect between the different organs of sovereignty and, in this context, the Constitutional Court has a central role.  I support this resolution and firmly share your call for the constitutional standardisation of this important Member State.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution because the Polish Government's recent actions pose a threat to democracy, human rights and the rule of law. The blockade of the Constitutional Court is a violation of the rule of law and cannot be accepted. Our fundamental European values and principles apply to everyone in the EU, but even more so to governments.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP is seriously concerned at the level of interference by the Commission in Poland – in particular the use of the Rule of Law mechanism. We believe this sets a dangerous precedent in the further erosion of the sovereignty of EU Member States. We do not take an opinion on the reforms being pursued by the newly elected Polish government but firmly believe that this is a matter for the democratically elected Government of Poland and the constitutional courts to decide – not the unelected European Commission.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. This report contains no reference to one of the most pressing issues in Poland. The situation of LGTBi women and people is now extremely delicate, having reached the competing ban on abortion in any of the cases. Unfortunately, the GUE/NGL amendments in this direction have been decayed from the opposite position of majority groups, which have turned their backs on Polish feminists who claim their rights on the streets. However, we voted in favour of the resolution as it includes important aspects relating to the need for the protection of fundamental rights in Poland in the face of the current regression situation, and urges compliance with the conclusions of the Venice Commission on the rule of law.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU has always been committed to promoting respect for fundamental rights, including those of women, common European values and the rule of law in the Member States. Recently, in several Member States, governments have undertaken some of the above-mentioned rights reforms. Since December 2015, Poland has launched a series of reforms that have a direct impact on the rule of law situation and respect for fundamental rights in the country. These reforms have raised many concerns within the EU, including changes to the way the Constitutional Court of Poland operates. Several European authorities have shown interest in this situation, including Parliament, the European Commission and the Venice Commission. I join this movement in voting in favour of the resolution, because I believe it is essential that the European Union continues to act to ensure the best possible application of the fundamental principles, so dear to European citizens, in all Member States, including Poland.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider it important that, in the context of fundamental European values, all Member States fully respect the rights of the European Union in their legislative practices, by respecting democratic principles, the rule of law and fundamental rights.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This non-binding resolution on the situation and the rule of law in Poland follows the Commission's decision to begin a first stage of the "framework to deal with systemic threats to the rule of law" in Poland in order to find a way out of the current situation through dialogue with the Polish authorities.  Considering that the measures taken by the Polish Government have led to the paralysis of the Constitutional Court, and that this constitutes a danger to democracy, human rights and the rule of law, I supported this resolution.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the resolution on Poland for the following reasons. While we must always adhere to the principle of subsidiarity, it is also the EU’s responsibility to uphold those values enshrined in Article 2 of the TEU. As this resolution states, these values are effectively under threat in Poland. It rightly mentions that the paralysis of Poland’s constitutional Tribunal is a danger to many of these values and to Poland’s constitutional democracy. In addition, not safeguarding these principles would be a violation of the Charter of Fundamental Rights and the ECHR. In sum, I can only support a resolution that calls on the Government of Poland to respect, publish and fully implement the Constitutional Tribunal’s decisions, thereby respecting Poland’s constitutional framework, and restoring the rule of law.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: Written. 'The SP Group abstained in the vote on Amendment 4. Although we strongly support the right of women to opt for an abortion in the event of an unwanted pregnancy, we believe that legislation on abortion in Member States of the European Union is a national matter on which the European Parliament should not comment.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution. It seems to me impossible to ignore the excesses of the current Polish government (notably the decision of the Constitutional Court deeming its own functioning incompatible with the Polish Constitution). This resolution is not intended to place the European Parliament as a lecturer for the Member States, but rather to engage in a dialogue to find solutions to the failures found. I will make a final judgment on the situation in Poland in the light of the conclusions of the European Commission.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The adopted resolution calls on the Polish Government to respect the values and principles that all Member States have committed to respect and respect. Parliament also called for recognition of the constitutional court's rulings and the recommendations of the Venice Commission. I agree with the structured dialogue established with the Polish Government by the European Commission, which should clarify whether democratic values and the rule of law are systematically threatened in Poland. The Commission has declared that this dialogue will take place impartially and in a spirit of cooperation with a view to offering poland assistance in finding solutions and strengthening the rule of law.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly oppose the resolution on the situation in Poland. The text adopted by the European Parliament is a testimony of a double standard and interference with the internal affairs of a sovereign Member State.  The previous government undertook a speedy amendment of the Law on the Constitutional Court and elected five judges on 8 October 2015, just before the elections on 25 October, the result of securing a crushing majority with 14 out of 15 judges in the Constitutional Court. Isn't that a violation of the elementary principle of pluralism in the courts and the recommendations of the Venice Commission of 1997, which state that "a ruling party should not be able to appoint all judges at its discretion"? Taking the side of the EPP's "Civic Platform" election loser, it becomes increasingly apparent that the Commission is applying double standards and politicising it.  I express my support for President Andrzej Duda and Prime Minister Beata Szydlo. I believe that the rule of the Law and Justice party will contribute to poland's prosperity and prosperity. Our fight is to reform the Union and return to the idea of a "United Europe of Nations"!

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. It is a worrying development we are now seeing in Poland, where the new government is putting forward proposals that challenge the values and principles that are the basis of a democratic state in Europe. This resolution focuses on the importance of all Member States having to stand up for the principles that are the basis of democracy in Europe. It is therefore worrying that the Polish Government, for example, is challenging the rule of law when it does not comply with the ruling of the Polish Constitutional Court. It was important to get a great deal of support from Parliament in this vote.  On the issue of the right to abortion, it is something that I and the Center Party stand up for at all times. Our position on this issue has been clear for a long time. This resolution, which was raised on the very occasion of the Polish Government's choice not to comply with its Constitutional Court, is primarily not about the right to abortion but about fundamental constitutional issues. In view of this, I chose to abstain from voting on two amendments by the GUE/NGL Group, because they were not in line with the real focus of the resolution.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. Recent events in Poland, in particular the political and legal conflict over the composition of the Constitutional Court and the new rules on its functioning, have given rise to concerns about the constitutional court's ability to uphold the Constitution and ensure respect for the rule of law, confirmed by the Venice Commission. The measures decided by the Polish Government and the President of the Republic with regard to the Constitutional Court pose a risk to constitutional democracy. It should be recalled that all Member States must fully comply with EU law and that all legislation must reflect and respect basic European values, including democratic principles, the rule of law and fundamental rights.  I therefore express my concern that the paralysis of poland's Constitutional Court endangers democracy, human rights and the rule of law.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. Recent events in Poland, and in particular the political and legal dispute over the composition of the Constitutional Court and the new rules on its operation, have raised concerns and opened a debate on how best to ensure respect for the rule of law, democracy, human rights and fundamental freedoms, an obligation which the Member States and the European Union are called upon to observe. The European context can help to clarify whether there are threats to democratic values and the rule of law in the Member States and, therefore, we hope that the European institutions will look at them in the same way and avoid unequal treatment.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The situation in Poland, resulting from the rise to power of ultraconservative and reactionary forces, is worrying. In addition to the conditioning of the constitutional court's actions, the attack on freedoms, rights and guarantees of citizens and workers is at stake. Political persecution and the prohibition of communist symbols in that country are of this serious expression. We do not turn off the emergence of these and other far-right and Nazi-fascist forces, the reactionary, racist, xenophobic and undemocratic nature of the Policies of the European Union itself and a continuing strategy of crushing the sovereignty of peoples, situations and policies which we strongly condemn and which we systematically denounce. This resolution is wounded by hypocrisy. Fair criticisms and concerns about attacks on democracy, freedom and the rights of peoples are not compatible with gross interference in sovereign countries, because sovereignty is also a democratic right. It is up to each people to decide on the measures and struggles to defeat those who attack their rights. The EU does not have the authority or the legitimacy to scrutinise or sanction any country. Parliament is responsible for expressing solidarity with those fighting for democracy in Poland. We stand in solidarity with this struggle and defend the democratic rights and sovereignty of the Polish people.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of these motions for a resolution, as I consider full respect for the common European values set out in the Treaty on European Union in its second Article to be of vital importance and I support the Commission's decision to initiate a dialogue under the framework to strengthen the rule of law, offering its support to Poland to develop solutions in this regard.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union maintains a high standard of protection and respect for fundamental human rights and freedoms. All Member States must fully respect and comply with European Union law in their legislative and administrative practice, and all legislation, including the primary law of each Member State or candidate country, must reflect and be consistent with fundamental European values, that is to say, democratic principles, the rule of law and fundamental rights. I am of the opinion that the European Commission should launch a constructive and structured dialogue with the Polish Government, which will clarify the extent to which the polish Government is threatening the rule of law and civil liberties, if at all.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against because the report touches on issues outside the EU's competence.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The EP resolution is not conducive to dialogue and reconciliation in my country. It is politically motivated and does not take into account processes already initiated by the authorities in Poland, such as the establishment under the auspices of the Speaker of the Polish Sejm of a committee of experts examining the opinion of the Venetian Commission. The resolution constitutes a profound interference in the internal affairs Polish, in a difficult constitutional dispute started by the previous government. Similar constitutional disputes have happened and have happened in many Member States with a complete lack of interest on the part of the EP. An example would be the proposal made by the centre-left government of luxembourg to terminate the Constitutional Court in Luxembourg.  The Strasbourg session is the first meeting of the European Parliament after the terrorist attacks in Brussels – at the 'heart' of the European Union and the headquarters of many other organisations – as well as after the Dutch referendum on the EU's association agreement with Ukraine. I consider both events to be extremely important in terms of the effectiveness of the policies and processes taking place in the European Union. Compared to the European Parliament Polish a fraction of the EP's time. Putting Polish under the hustle and bustle can be regarded as a substitute topic that distracts from really important problems and disagreements about solving them.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against all the reports on the situation in Poland. This is because the motion for a resolution is an unacceptable interference in the internal affairs of a Member State, an unacceptable disregard for the popular sovereignty and will of the Polish people, as expressed emphatically in the last elections, and because overall it goes beyond even the loose limits of immorality of the Union.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ My Conservative colleagues and I have always had a consistent approach to situations in individual Member States and the role that the European Parliament has to play. Article 17 of the TFEU states that Member State compliance with EU law is a matter for the European Commission (and the Venice Commission), and not the European Parliament or any other EU institution. The Commission has yet to give its final opinion on the matter and it is premature to pass judgement.  I am afraid that this resolution by the European Parliament is simply political posturing.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Writing. The Rule of Law in Poland – We Members of the European Parliament voted today on a non-binding resolution on the situation in Poland, continuing the plenary debate of 19 January. This vote is part of the "Framework for the Treatment of Systemic Threats to the Rule of Law" in Poland and is an opinion on the legislative amendments enforced by Poland's government to limit the powers of the Polish Constitutional Court. The rule of law in Poland is in great danger. In order to draw attention to this and to appeal to the Polish Government, we had a common objective today: to adopt as strong, clear a resolution on Poland as possible, supported by a large majority. In the run-up to the event, there were also considerations to draw attention to the threat of a ban on abortion in this Member State. However, this could have diluted the result of the vote and, in the worst case scenario, jeopardised it. The S&D and the Greens have therefore withdrawn their amendments on this matter. However, there were two amendments tabled by the Group of the Left which took up this threat of a change in the law. In order not to jeopardise the common objective and the clear positioning, the SPÖ delegation has decided in this case to abstain on these two amendments, even though the SPÖ-EU MEPs fully support the content.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The situation in Poland is very worrying. Poland’s new ruling party ‘Law and Justice’ is taking actions which question whether democracy and the rule of law in that Member State are upheld. It is reported that the government is trying to curb the power of the Constitutional Tribunal by packing the court with judges of its choosing in breach of the Constitution, and altering the Court’s procedures. In addition, Poland’s Government is proposing a hurriedly reformed process of choosing the management of the public broadcaster, which is anticipated to be the first move in a longer-term plan to exert undue influence over Polish media. Furthermore, the decision of the Polish President to pardon a government minister who had been convicted of abuse of power, before a court could rule on an appeal, can be considered as putting at risk the independence of the judiciary. Defending the values enshrined in Article 2 of the TEU has to be our priority. I am not in favour of politics which go against the fundamental values of the European Union.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament today adopted a resolution interfering in Polish internal affairs by double standards. This is unacceptable and I therefore voted against the resolution. The political attack on the Polish government, which was democratically elected last year, is counterproductive, harms Poland as a whole and undermines the credibility of the European institutions.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution as the European institutions must ensure legal certainty and law enforcement. In this case, the Polish Government is intentionally delaying the execution of three judgments of the Constitutional Court, and since the European Parliament it is urged to depose its attitude and respect the current legality, a fundamental principle in democracy.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I abstained on the resolution on the situation in Poland and I very much regret that it has not been possible to convince a majority of the much more balanced alternative resolution tabled by my ECR Group. It is clear to me that the issues raised in Poland can only be adequately resolved if all those involved on the political stage of Poland and Europe act responsibly and reach a compromise or– in a perfectly normal process – follow the decisions of the Constitutional Court.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The fundamental principles of the rule of law, democracy, human rights and fundamental freedoms set out in the EU Treaties have a binding effect on all Member States.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution because it highlights the serious situation in which the most basic human rights are being enforced. In addition, the text includes amendments by our group specifically discussing the situation in which women's sexual and reproductive rights are located. We consider Polish abortion legislation to be already one of the most restrictive and recall UN international obligations and opinions that denying access to sexual and reproductive health services to the population is a violation of human rights.

name: Karoline GRASWANDER-HAINZ
text: Writing. We MEPs have today voted on a non-binding resolution on the situation in Poland, continuing the plenary debate of 19 January. This vote is part of the "Framework for the Treatment of Systemic Threats to the Rule of Law" in Poland and is an opinion on the legislative amendments enforced by Poland's government to limit the powers of the Polish Constitutional Court. The rule of law in Poland is in great danger. In order to draw attention to this and to appeal to the Polish Government, we had a common objective today: to adopt as strong, clear a resolution on Poland as possible, supported by a large majority. In the run-up to the event, there were also considerations to draw attention to the threat of a ban on abortion in this Member State. However, this could have watered down the vote and, in the worst case scenario, jeopardised it. The S&D and the Greens have therefore withdrawn their amendments on this matter. However, there were two amendments tabled by the Group of the Left which took up this threat of a change in the law. In order not to jeopardise the common objective and the clear positioning, the SPÖ delegation has decided in this case to abstain on these two amendments, even though the SPÖ-EU MEPs fully support the content.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: In writing. In recent months, many political and legal controversies have taken place in Poland. Among them are the reform of the functioning of the Polish Constitutional Court and the appointment of public media leaders by the executive. The reform of the Constitutional Court increases the majority needed for the Tribunal to adopt a decision. This reform now makes it possible for unconstitutional laws to be passed without constitutional control and to remain valid for a long time. In other words, this is a dangerous challenge to the rule of law that opens the way to abuses. With regard to the appointment of public media leaders by the executive, it should be remembered that editorial freedom and media pluralism are essential to democracy. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, because I believe that, in addition to being a common fundamental value, respect for the rule of law and democracy is an imperative obligation for the European Union and its Member States.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. The situation in Poland is of great concern to all European democrats. The current government has undertaken a series of reforms that are moving the country away from European democratic standards with its challenges to both press freedom and opposition expression. The most consequential reform concerns the Constitutional Council because it attacks the foundations of democracy and the rule of law. Moreover, the planned changes in IVG legislation would constitute an intolerable regression for the status of women.  The European Parliament, through the vote on this resolution, is expressing its support for the process initiated by the European Commission to get out of the situation through dialogue with the Polish authorities. However, if the Polish government does not comply with its recommendations, the European Commission will have to activate the second stage of the procedure to deal with "systemic threats to the rule of law", launched in January.  The values and principles set out in the European Union treaties on human rights must be respected by each Member State and Poland cannot escape this compelling obligation without serious consequences.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ The situation in Poland is becoming a growing concern for stability in the EU. The effective paralysis of the  Constitutional Tribunal, which was established as one of the central elements in constitutional democracy, poses a danger to democracy, human rights and the rule of law. Respect for the rule of law must be guaranteed by the Tribunal, all the steps to be taken must respect the competences of the EU and of its Member States, as set by the Treaties and the principle of subsidiarity. It is out of these concerns that I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing.
