I supported the resolution on the situation in Poland, which seems to me to be quite cautious in that we cannot ignore some of the excesses of the current government, in particular its decision to ignore the decision of the Constitutional Court which considers the December 2015 law governing its own functioning incompatible with the Polish Constitution. There are institutional mechanisms in Polish democracy that guarantee the separation of powers and monitor effective respect for the rule of law. However, it would appear that the government of the day is not fully respectful of this institutional organization. That is why, when this balance is weakened, it is the duty of the European Commission, which guarantees respect for the European Treaty and European values, to organise a dialogue with the Member State concerned and to identify existing failures. However, I believe that the time is not yet for the final order and I am therefore waiting for the Commission's conclusions to make a final judgment on the situation in Poland.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a motion for a resolution on Poland to reform Poland's constitutional court and the state of the country's public media after last year's elections.  I fully support the Efforts of the European Commission and the launch of the 'Framework for a Legal State' procedures to assess the situation and initiate a dialogue with the Polish authorities regarding the rule of law due to the existing "paralysis" of the constitutional court, which poses a danger to democracy. The rule of law and the independent judiciary are the basis for the protection of fundamental human rights and personal freedoms in the EU. Recent actions by the Polish government and the president of the republic pose a danger to constitutional democracy.  In the same way, without double standards, other Member States should be monitored on the situation of democracy, fundamental human rights and the rule of law.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. Once again, the European Union is interfering in its attempt to enter the heart of the national affairs of a sovereign state. I am opposed to the European authorities deciding the domestic situation of a country like Poland. So I voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – Diane James and her fellow UKIP MEPs voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP is seriously concerned at the level of interference by the Commission in Poland – in particular the use of the Rule of Law mechanism. We believe this sets a dangerous precedent in the further erosion of the sovereignty of EU Member States. We do not take an opinion on the reforms being pursued by the newly elected Polish government but firmly believe that this is a matter for the democratically elected Government of Poland and the constitutional courts to decide – not the unelected European Commission.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ The current political situation in Poland is troubling. An effective democracy should have a good system of checks, balances and accountability. The overriding concern in this resolution was regarding the Venice Commission’s report on the changes being made to Poland’s Constitutional Tribunal as well as the unpublished verdict of the Constitutional Tribunal of 9 March 2016. I share the view that the crippling of the Tribunal would undermine democracy, human rights and the rule of law. I fully support this resolution and call on the Polish government to fully uphold the common EU values outlined in Article 2 of the TEU.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Estéban Gonzalez Pons' report on the situation in Poland. The motion for a resolution stresses that the paralysis of the Polish Constitutional Court threatens democracy, human rights and the rule of law. The report therefore calls on the Polish Government to implement the recommendations of the Venice Commission and supports the Commission's determination in the development of a structured dialogue to determine whether there is a systemic threat to democratic values and the rule of law in Poland. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: in writing. ‒ The resolution expresses deep concern over political developments in Poland, focusing on constitutional issues, such as changes to the Constitutional Court. However, it is deeply regrettable that not a word is mentioned about plans for a total ban on abortions. The Left Group’s additional amendments that condemned abortion restrictions and defended women’s right to their own bodies were unfortunately not adopted. The resolution would obviously have been much better if it had shown that the oppression of women and contempt for democracy are strongly linked. While the other political groups are doubtful, the left group and EH Bildu stand in solidarity with the thousands of demonstrators who protested in Poland and elsewhere in Europe for democracy and women’s rights. Therefore I voted both in favour of the amendments and the resolution.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. The resolution for which I voted was aimed at criticising the blocking of the Constitutional Court by Poland's new conservative government. The current government in Poland has introduced a new law amending the two-thirds qualified majority rule in that court and appointed five judges of its choice, in a controversial procedure. It was therefore necessary to reaffirm the importance of the fundamental values of the European Union, democracy and the rule of law, which must be respected by all its Member States.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: Writing. We Members of the European Parliament have today voted on a non-binding resolution on the situation in Poland, continuing the plenary debate of 19 January. This vote is part of the "Framework for the Treatment of Systemic Threats to the Rule of Law" in Poland and is an opinion on the legislative amendments enforced by Poland's government to limit the powers of the Polish Constitutional Court. The rule of law in Poland is in great danger. In order to draw attention to this and to appeal to the Polish Government, we had a common objective today: to adopt as strong, clear a resolution on Poland as possible, supported by a large majority. In the run-up to the event, there were also considerations to draw attention to the threat of a ban on abortion in this Member State. However, this could have watered down the vote and, in the worst case scenario, jeopardised it. The S&D and the Greens have therefore withdrawn their amendments on this matter. However, there were two amendments tabled by the Group of the Left which took up this threat of a change in the law. In order not to jeopardise the common objective and the clear positioning, the SPÖ delegation has decided in this case to abstain on these two amendments, even though the SPÖ-EU MEPs fully support the content.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting against this motion for a resolution. Poland has a democratically elected government whose projects may not be well received by all the other Member States, but it is neither appropriate nor sensible to adopt ideologically infamous criticism and interference on behalf of Parliament.

name: Rina Ronja KARI
text: Written. – The resolution expresses deep concern at political developments in Poland, focusing on constitutional issues, such as amendments to the Constitutional Court. However, it is deeply regrettable that not a word has been mentioned about the plans for a total ban on abortion. Unfortunately, the amendments tabled by my group, the GUE/NGL, which condemned the limitation of the possibility of abortion and defended the right of women to decide their bodies themselves, were not adopted. This resolution by Parliament would have been much stronger if it had stressed that the oppression of women and contempt for democracy are strongly linked. That is why I voted in favour of both the amendments and the overall resolution.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The Venice Commission has already spoken out loud over the unconstitutional nature of the laws on the media and the Constitutional Court. Now it is high time for the Polish government to comply with these recommendations.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 On Wednesday 13. 4. 2016, a high-profile resolution on the current constitutional situation in Poland was decided in Strasbourg in a plenary vote. Personally, I am mostly strongly opposed to any interference by the European Union in internal political processes taking place not only in any Member State, but also outside the EU. However, the current constitutional, political and social crisis in Poland can no longer leave me cold. In Poland, citizens are now constantly mobilizing against their own government, which is gradually questioning some fundamental human rights, restricting the functioning of fundamental constitutional institutions, and attacking women, and some minorities are returning to the dark era. It should be reminded out loud that constitutional democracy, the independence of courts and judges, fundamental rights, including freedom of the media and the right of a woman to freely choose an abortion, are universal principles that must always be recognised and supported by all Member States and are, above all, one of the fundamental conditions for a country's membership of the European Union. Unfortunately, my faction has failed to push more criticism of the abortion ban into the resolution. However, given that the draft text has managed, despite this, not slipping into cheap political abbreviations, and the text has remained fairly balanced in terms of clearly presenting facts, I am glad that I was able to support it.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution since its aim is to highlight concerns on the existing political and legal context in Poland. All Member States must fully comply with EU law in their legislative and administrative practice, and respect basic European values such as democratic principles, the rule of law and fundamental rights. I voted in favour of this resolution in order to improve the legal situation in Poland, and to reinstall the Constitutional Tribunal as an institution of checks and balances in Poland.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ It is our common European duty to respond to controversial new laws that have given the Polish government more control over the media, right to appoint the heads of public TV and civil service directors. We cannot tolerate legislative and administrative practices that are not in accordance with our common EU law and our common European values such as democratic principles, the rule of law and fundamental rights. Therefore, I am calling on Polish government to engage in structured dialogue with the European Commission in order not only to find working solutions to worrying political developments but also and perhaps most importantly to preserve democracy, rule of law and fundamental rights in Poland. In the name of democracy, in the name of Poland and the EU we should never accept to give up our freedom and we should ever protect it.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. This resolution, together with the main groups, including ours, calls on the Polish authorities to stop blocking the Constitutional Court. As soon as Jaroslaw Kascinski's ultra-conservative PIS party came to power, it began a purge of public media and key state positions, including the Constitutional Court, by reviewing its procedures and judicial appointments. The court responded with rulings blocking these measures, but the Polish government refuses to publish these judgments, thus blocking its activities. This resolution rightly affirms its concerns for the rule of law in Poland and calls on the Polish government to respect and enforce the court's judgments. I obviously voted in favour of this resolution condemning an authoritarian government, which does not support any dissenting voices, from the public media to the institutions at the base of Polish democracy, and which even goes so far as to attack its symbols by attacking Lech Walesa.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the joint resolution on the situation in Poland. The Europe of Nations and Freedoms group had tabled its own resolution. This is once again an unacceptable interference by the European Union in the internal affairs of a Member State. Polish voters have chosen a government that does not please the Brussels cenacles, that is their crime. Once again, the European Union shows a total disregard for the democracy and sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it interferes, scandalously and contrary to the treaties, in the internal policy of a sovereign state: Poland. This state is in fact wrong, in the eyes of the EU, for bringing a sovereignist president and government to power.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. This report contains no reference to one of the most pressing issues in Poland. The situation of LGTBi women and people is now extremely delicate, having reached the competing ban on abortion in any of the cases. Unfortunately, the GUE/NGL amendments in this direction have been decayed from the opposite position of majority groups, which have turned their backs on Polish feminists who claim their rights on the streets. However, we voted in favour of the resolution as it includes important aspects relating to the need for the protection of fundamental rights in Poland in the face of the current regression situation, and urges compliance with the conclusions of the Venice Commission on the rule of law.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I consider the proposal to be inappropriate interference in the internal affairs of a sovereign state. According to the proposal, democracy, human rights and the rule of law are at risk in Poland, which I do not agree with. It is absurd that the procedure initiated by the Commission against Poland may lead to the withdrawal of Poland's voting rights in the Council. The EU has nothing to train Poland in a democracy!

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported the proposal for a European Parliament resolution concerning the situation in Poland on the grounds that I think it is necessary to respect fundamental human rights. The foundations of European unity and unity are primarily media freedom, the rule of law and respect for democracy. I believe that the justice system must be politically independent and foster civil liberties. Only in this way can the state show that it is ready to cooperate at the European level.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the motion for a resolution on the situation in Poland because it is not complete and substantiated.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Since coming to power, the Polish Law and Justice party has passed several ultra-conservative laws. The company protests in the street. The Venice Committee of the Council of Europe (intergovernmental organisation, not the Union) composed of independent lawyers has given an opinion against the reform of the Polish Constitutional Court and is now studying police reform.  The European Parliament is holding a firm position here on respect for the rule of law, while the European Commission has just launched for the first time a "structured dialogue on the rule of law" against Poland. The report is eerily silent on other laws such as the total ban on abortion.  I abstain on this text in order not to endorse an undemocratic and biased procedure for the review of a state's policies by unelected European bodies. We will see whether the Commission ensures that 'fundamental rights' are respected as assiduously as it does for economic 'golden rules'.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. I am opposed to interference in Polish affairs. As a result, I voted against the GUE/NGL proposal.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this resolution on the situation in Poland. There are legitimate concerns about the application of the rule of law and whether the current government there is willing to uphold fundamental rights in the EU. With this resolution we address those concerns, speak out for media freedom and pluralism, and urge all players to respect the Treaties on which our European Union is built.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. At a time when the Council of Europe's Venice Committee has just issued its conclusions and the dialogue continues between the European Commission and the Polish authorities, it was crucial that the European Parliament denounce the paralysis of the Constitutional Court and the threats it poses to the rule of law in Poland.  The rule of law and the balance of power are the basis of any democratic society and the principles to which all the Member States of the European Union have adhered. The Union's response to the constitutional crisis we are witnessing today in Poland must be adapted to the seriousness of its potential impact on our European values.  With regard to the plenary amendments to the abortion bill, I have chosen, together with my group, to abstain in order to keep the text focused on the political-constitutional crisis. Nevertheless, I join all those who express their greatest concern about this bill, which would aim to ban abortion altogether. Such a decline in women's rights does not find its place in Europe and Parliament will therefore have to address this issue.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – The constitutions of all EU Member States are based on democratic principles that are universally respected, unquestionable, unquestionable and irreplaceable in our society. If there is currently a case of grossly infringing these principles, it is the Union's duty to act. I find the current situation in Poland alarming. The decision of the Polish Government to intervene significantly in the independence of the judiciary, in my opinion, has no place in our geopolitical space and represents a serious breach of the balance of power and the system of brakes and balances between the executive and the judiciary. We know from history that radical solutions have never brought anything positive to society, quite the contrary. I therefore fully share the proposal to appeal to the Polish authorities to apply as far as possible the recommendations of the Venice Commission of the Council of Europe regarding the constitutional court's ability to protect and enforce the Constitution and to guarantee respect for the rule of law. If Poland wishes to maintain its status as a credible partner in the eyes of Europe and the rest of the world, built on democratic values, it must immediately put an end to the current tendencies towards gross violations of the rule of law, human rights and justice. I am therefore voting in favour of the report as it stands.

name: Anne-Marie MINEUR
text: Written. 'The SP Group abstained in the vote on Amendment 4. Although we strongly support the right of women to opt for an abortion in the event of an unwanted pregnancy, we believe that legislation on abortion in Member States of the European Union is a national matter on which the European Parliament should not comment.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 In relation to the political situation in Poland, the ENF, EFDD and ECR political groups submitted separate motions for resolutions, while the PPE, S&D, ALDE, GUE/NGL and Verts/ALE political groups tabled a joint motion for a resolution. The joint draft states that the actions of the Polish Government and the President of the Polish Republic against the Constitutional Court threaten constitutional democracy. It proposes that Parliament express serious concern that the effective paralyzing of the Constitutional Court in Poland threatens democracy, human rights and the rule of law, and agrees with the opinion of the Venice Commission that the Polish Constitution and European and international standards require respect for the decisions of the Constitutional Court.  Therefore, call on the Polish Government to fully comply with the recommendations of the Venice Commission, to respect, publish and, without further delay, to fully implement the constitutional court's decisions of 3 and 9 December 2015 and 9 March 2016. Finally, it expects the Commission to monitor and report to Parliament on respect for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in the same way in all Member States in order to avoid double standards. I voted in favour of the joint draft.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The Polish Government has introduced legal changes on the composition and functioning of the Constitutional Court, including changes to the voting system. This reform poses a number of problems with compatibility with the values and principles of the rule of law, in particular the principle of independence and separation of powers.  In addition to the changes to the functioning of the Court, there are also a number of issues which are of concern that they may constitute violations of EU law and fundamental rights, such as matters relating to freedom of the press and respect for ethnic and religious minorities.  As is apparent from Article 2 OF the EU, the Union is founded on the values of democracy and respect for human rights, and it is therefore for the Member States to ensure, in the context of their actions, respect for the values enshrined in the Treaties.  I therefore vote in favour, because I believe that the Commission as guardian of the Treaties must play an active role in assessing the existence of threats and ensure full respect for common European values.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This text shows an implausible interference of the European Parliament in a sovereign country like Poland, whose leaders do not have the ambition to sink their country in the Europeanist mould. The lessons on the rule of law are de rigueur, there is no shortage of mentions of supposed attacks on press freedom... In short, Poland embodies (with Hungary) all that the European spirit cannot bear: that we follow the will of the people.  Worse still, this text entrusts the European Commission, "guardian of the treaties" (or rather of prison of the peoples...), the task of conducting the investigation into Polish democratic desires. He added that Member States must "fully respect EU law". Where was the European Parliament when the German leaders blackmailed the Greek people in flagrant violation of the values pompously recalled in the Treaty of the Union and the Charter of Fundamental Rights? This one-sided indignation is a desperate attempt to save the "European Union" soldier from a certain shipwreck. To no avail. I have of course voted against this grotesque text.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report to raise concerns regarding the Rule of Law in Poland.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls on the Polish authorities to respect democratic principles and the rule of law, including by publishing and implementing the decisions of the Constitutional Court, which has been paralyzed by the recent measures taken by the Polish President and Government.  I also supported an amendment that expresses concerns about the proposed total ban on abortion in Poland.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the motion for a resolution tabled following statements by the Council and the Commission pursuant to Article 123(2) of the Regulation on the situation in Poland. It is important to remember that Poland is an important member of the European Union which, over the years, has contributed to the economic and social development of the Eu ropean Union and is one of the most excellent examples of how European inclusion policies are capable of growing and thriving countries ready to share European values. Unfortunately, Poland has been experiencing a period of great change and disresasure with the past over the last few months. Among the changes of greatest concern is the paralysis of the National Constitutional Court, which is a danger to democracy and the rule of law. The Venice Commission has urged the Polish Government to act in accordance with its recommendations, calling for the judgments of a Constitutional Court to be respected. The European institutions, through Commission Vice-President Tmmermans, expressed their commitment to a constant dialogue with the Polish institutions. It is essential that Poland now responds to these important gestures, ensuring respect for the fundamental rights contained in the constitution and international standards.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. The situation in Poland had already been debated in the European Parliament in February. We are now adopting a resolution in which we recall our values, those of freedom and independence of the media and justice, those of respect for human rights. I welcome a clear and welcome resolution that just expresses our friendship and consideration for Poland and its citizens.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted this motion for a resolution regarding Poland’s respect for the rule of law, democracy, human rights and fundamental freedoms and underlining areas that need improvement.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on the motion for a resolution on the situation in Poland, because I believe that this document comes at a bad time. Given that the situation in Poland is still being analysed at the level of the European Commission and the Polish authorities have agreed to work together to clarify the criticisms made, the text of this resolution is inappropriate in the context of the aim of constructive communication with a Member State, a full State and the possibility of managing its own internal policy. I will await the conclusions of the interinstitutional dialogue, the solutions that will be reached, so that I can express myself firmly on this subject.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on Poland, the basis of which is the call on the Polish Government to fully implement the recommendations of the Venice Commission, and the agreement with the View of the Venice Commission that the Polish Constitution, as well as European and international standards, require that the decisions of the constitutional courts be respected. It is precisely the failure to respect the decision of the Constitutional Court that is probably where the Polish government is most pressured by the boot. The European integration process allows Member States to negotiate an exception for one area or another of European law or for an integration step. However, if such an exception could also apply to the principles of the democratic rule of law, it would undermine the very foundations of the EU. It is therefore necessary to insist consistently that the Polish Government align its actions with European values.

name: Maria NOICHL
text: Writing. The Rule of Law in Poland – We MEPs in the European Parliament voted today on a non-binding resolution on the situation in Poland, continuing the plenary debate of 19 January. This vote is part of the "Framework for the Treatment of Systemic Threats to the Rule of Law" in Poland and is an opinion on the legislative amendments enforced by Poland's government to limit the powers of the Polish Constitutional Court. The rule of law in Poland is in great danger. In order to draw attention to this and to appeal to the Polish Government, we had a common objective today: to adopt as strong, clear a resolution on Poland as possible, supported by a large majority. In the run-up to the event, there were also considerations to draw attention to the threat of a ban on abortion in this Member State. However, this could have watered down the vote and, in the worst case scenario, jeopardised it. The S&D and the Greens have therefore withdrawn their amendments on this matter. However, there were two amendments tabled by the Group of the Left which took up this threat of a change in the law. In order not to jeopardise the common objective and the clear position, I have decided in this case to abstain on these two amendments, although I fully support their content.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – Polish affairs must be dealt with in Poland and with the Poles. The European Union is a union of free states and no decisions can undermine the sovereignty of the Member States. National issues need to be addressed at national level. Politicians should have a strong backbone in order to defend their country's national interests. National politicians must be accountable only to the citizens of the states that have chosen them. The EU should not become a federation. I have always spoken out and will speak out in favour of a Europe of nations, a union of free states and the consolidation of direct democracy, not its fiction in Europe

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP is seriously concerned at the level of interference by the Commission in Poland – in particular the use of the Rule of Law mechanism. We believe this sets a dangerous precedent in the further erosion of the sovereignty of EU Member States. We do not take an opinion on the reforms being pursued by the newly elected Polish government but firmly believe that this is a matter for the democratically elected Government of Poland and the constitutional courts to decide – not the unelected European Commission.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 On this issue, I voted in favour. Given that the worrying paralysis of the Constitutional Court in Poland seriously jeopardises respect for human rights and democratic principles, I believe that the Commission's commitment to monitoring the legislative situation in Poland, through a structured dialogue with the Polish Government, can make an effective contribution to respect for the rule of law and the rule of law. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. —For me, the right to life that begins at conception is the basic human right from which all other rights are based. I voted against contentious amendments that referred to the challenge to Poland's law banning abortion because they were unacceptable to me. The issue of family policy and health is the responsibility of a Member State and the EU must not interfere there.  However, in order for the Polish Government to make the necessary changes to the existing law and not be called into question, there must be no constitutional crisis in the country. The Constitutional Court is the highest body of a country that protects its Constitution and constitutional order, it must be independent and function normally and thus be a guarantor of the rule of law. And the Polish Constitution states that the Republic of Poland must ensure the legal protection of every human being.  It would be bad if some good laws already enacted or planned to enact by the Polish government remain in the shadow of this constitutional crisis or be called into question. That is why I think it is necessary to first solve the constitutional crisis and ensure the normal functioning of all institutions and branches of government, and then to further work on changes that will lead to reforms necessary for a better life for the citizens of Poland.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution is illegitimately interfering in Poland's internal affairs. The Poles are a free and sovereign people. The European Union has neither the right nor the legitimacy to impose anything on them, since the members of the Commission have not even been elected and their policies are rejected by the different peoples when they have the opportunity to vote on them. I therefore vote against this resolution.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Recent events in Poland are a serious concern for the European Parliament. The paralysis of the Constitutional Court, which cannot play its role as guarantor of the supremacy of the Polish constitution, since the verdict of 9 March 2016 has remained unprecedented and, therefore, cannot enter into force, represents a huge risk to the proper conduct of the democratic life of the country and a threat to European law and fundamental values, including women's rights. I voted in favour of this resolution because I support the need to closely monitor the Polish Government to integrate the international standards required by the recommendations of the Venice Commission and to respect the deliberations of the Constitutional Court. The Commission must carry out all the necessary analyses to measure whether there is a systematic violation of the rule of law in the country and to operate in accordance with the competences conferred on it by the Treaties, especially in the field of subsidiarity. The Commission will also have to enter into a dialogue with the Polish authorities conducted on a cooperative and impartial basis and offer its support to the country to develop solutions aimed at strengthening the rule of law in the short term.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. We are aware of the situation in Poland resulting from the rise to power of ultraconservative and reactionary forces. Well beyond the conditioning of the constitutional court, freedoms, rights and guarantees of citizens and workers are attacked. Political persecution and the prohibition of communist symbols in that country are of this serious expression.  We do not turn off the emergence of these and other far-right and Nazi-fascist forces, the reactionary, racist, xenophobic and undemocratic nature of the Policies of the European Union itself and a continuing strategy of crushing the sovereignty of peoples, situations and policies which we strongly condemn and which we systematically denounce. This resolution is wounded by hypocrisy. Fair criticisms and concerns about attacks on democracy, freedom and the rights of peoples are not compatible with gross interference in sovereign countries, because sovereignty is also a democratic right. It is up to each people to decide on the measures and struggles to defeat those who attack their rights. The EU does not have the right or legitimacy to advance recommendations and 'solutions', so little sanctions. Parliament is responsible for expressing solidarity with those fighting for democracy in Poland. Because we stand in solidarity with this struggle and because we defend the democratic rights and sovereignty of the Polish people, we abstained in this Resolution.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ At the end of 2015, the Law and Justice (PiS) party won poland's elections and the current Polish government has the strongest democratic mandate in the country's history since the fall of communism. Recent developments in Poland, in particular the political and legal dispute over the composition of the Constitutional Court and the new rules on its functioning have raised concerns about the Constitutional Court's ability to guarantee compliance with the Constitution and the rule of law.  I believe that respect for fundamental human freedom, media freedom and the rule of law is the cornerstone of a modern and strong European Union. The justice system must be independent of any political option and foster civil liberties. I believe that all Member States must respect EU laws and be ready to cooperate fully with the EU institutions. It is in the interest of the entire European Union to resolve the situation with Poland as soon as possible.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. The situation in Poland is worrying and it is the duty of MEPs to call the country's authorities to order. It is in this spirit that I voted in favour of the resolution urging the Polish State to resolve, as soon as possible, the current paralysis it has with its Constitutional Court. This situation jeopardizes democracy, human rights and the fundamental principles of the rule of law. More than that, I am deeply concerned that these essential values of the European Union are now being flouted in the country most receiving European funds. I therefore support the European Commission's decision to engage in a structured political dialogue with Poland, so that the country can quickly return to the path of respect for the fundamental rules that govern our democracies.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Writing. The Rule of Law in Poland - We Members of the European Parliament voted today on a resolution on the situation in Poland. This vote is part of the "Framework for the Treatment of Systemic Threats to the Rule of Law" in Poland and takes a position on the legislative amendments enforced by Poland's government to limit the powers of the Polish Constitutional Court. The rule of law in Poland is in great danger. In order to draw attention to this and to appeal to the Polish Government, we had a common objective today: to adopt as strong, clear a resolution on Poland as possible, supported by a large majority. In the run-up to the event, there were also considerations to draw attention to the threat of a ban on abortion in this Member State. However, this could have watered down the vote and, in the worst case scenario, jeopardised it. The S&D and the Greens have therefore withdrawn their amendments on this matter. However, there were two amendments tabled by the Group of the Left which took up this threat of a change in the law. In order not to jeopardise the common objective and the clear positioning, the SPÖ delegation has decided in this case to abstain on these two amendments, even though the SPÖ-EU MEPs fully support the content.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP is seriously concerned at the level of interference by the Commission in Poland – in particular the use of the Rule of Law mechanism. We believe this sets a dangerous precedent in the further erosion of the sovereignty of EU Member States. We do not take an opinion on the reforms being pursued by the newly elected Polish government but firmly believe that this is a matter for the democratically elected Government of Poland and the constitutional courts to decide – not the unelected European Commission.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. The arrival in power of the "Right and Justice" party in Poland has led to a paralysis of the Constitutional Court and a questioning of media freedom. Now the government is preparing to attack women's rights by considering passing a law banning abortion. For MEPs, this worrying situation poses a danger to democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in this country. It is also a threat to the integrity of the European Union as a whole.  The Commission, as the guardian of the treaties, must be uncompromising in enforcing European values in all Member States. While it is welcome that the European framework for the rule of law has been activated in Poland, this must lead to concrete results. If the dialogue does not work, we will have to move to the next level, even if we impose sanctions, especially financial ones. If I support the resolution as voted, I would have preferred it to be firmer on this point. All this shows the urgency of adopting a European pact for the rule of law, which will strengthen the Union's capacity to defend the founding principles of democracy and the rule of law on which it was built.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. This report, which I approved favourably, is of concern that the paralysis of the Constitutional Court of Poland endangers democracy, human rights and the rule of law, thus calling on the Polish Government to respect, publish and fully implement the judgment of the Constitutional Court of 9 March 2016 without delay and the judgments of 3 and 9 December 2015.  The document stresses, however, that all measures to be taken must respect the competences of the EU and its Member States, as defined by the Treaties and the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I supported this resolution on the alarming situation in Poland. Unfortunately, it still seems necessary to recall that membership of the Union is based on respect for compelling values, including respect for the rule of law, democracy and fundamental freedoms. Recent events in Poland - including the measures taken by the Polish government against the Constitutional Court - demonstrate the need to defend these values against any inclination of certain governments to dehorn them. That is why we call on the Polish Government to respect and immediately implement the judgments of the Constitutional Court of 3 and 9 December 2015 and 9 March 2016; just as we demand full implementation of the recommendations made by the Venice Commission. We also support the launch of a structured dialogue under the rule of law framework that will determine whether or not there is a systemic threat to democracy and the rule of law in Poland.  No one can deviate from European values without treading the base on which the European project is based and lived.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. For a few months now, the Polish government has been taking clear anti-democratic measures, such as changing the constitutional court's settings or measures taken to the detriment of media freedom and independence. Such measures progressively push the Warsaw Executive away from Community convergence in terms of democratic quality. In view of this and the worrying situation, the Commission proposes to put into operation for the first time the instrument for assessing the democratic quality of the Member States. This instrument is ultimately empowered to provisionally withdraw Poland's voting rights in the Council because it has broken democratic standards against the values and freedoms that are supposed to be assumed, it must defend a state that is part of the European Union.  To this day, the Polish government is still reluctant to give any explanation, and has even alerted the Commission to the possible counterproductive effect that action could have from the Community institutions against the legislative reforms being carried out by the Polish government.  In order to help restore democratic normality in Poland, that is why I have cast my vote in favour of the resolution.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The attitude and decisions of the Polish government not only undermine relations between Poland and the European Union, they undermine the rule of law on its very foundation, which constitute democratic values. We must continue the dialogue with this Member State in order to allow a return to reason. I am concerned, however, that the political party in power in Warsaw, the PiS, is ignoring the hand extended by the Commission, persisting in refusing to review the reform of the functioning of the Constitutional Court and, even worse, putting pressure on judges who rightly consider it unconstitutional. As Mr Timmermans said, we cannot authorise "two parallel legal systems" within the Union. It has been a month since the Venice Commission of the Council of Europe questioned the measures decided by the government in power. In the absence of significant rapid progress, the rule of law mechanism will have to apply to sanctions against Warsaw.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: In writing. The rule of law is the cornerstone of democracy and one of the founding principles of the European Union along with those of human dignity and freedom. Recent events in Poland have led the European Parliament to question the Polish government's adherence to these principles. In this resolution, MEPs express their deep concern at the paralysis of the Constitutional Court which threatens democracy, human rights and the rule of law in Poland. They are also concerned about other Polish government initiatives that may be contrary to European law and fundamental rights, particularly of women. For example, Parliament supports the Commission's decision to launch a structured dialogue under the rule of law framework, which should clarify whether there is a systemic threat to democratic values and the rule of law in Poland. Parliament calls on the Commission to conduct this dialogue impartially and to take the second step towards safeguarding the rule of law if necessary. For all these reasons, I supported this report.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. Since the last elections in October 2015, which gave victory to Beata Szydlo, poland has been carrying out a worrying set of reforms, especially in the field of justice, which may call into question democratic principles, the most elementary human rights and the rule of law itself. The recent legal and political conflict over the composition of the Constitutional Court and its rules of operation threaten to call into question the capacity of this sovereignty body to adequately defend the Constitution and to ensure respect for the rule of law, as they pose a risk to constitutional democracy itself. To that end, I was in favour of the adoption of this motion for a resolution of the European Parliament, which calls on Poland to fully respect the rule of law and fundamental European values, as well as to publish and fully implement judgments which give the Constitutional Court the role of guarantor of the supremacy of the Constitution.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I supported this resolution, which reflects the European Union's concerns about the actions of the current Polish government. This resolution echoes recent events in Poland regarding respect for the rule of law, including appointments to the Constitutional Court and amendments to the law on public service broadcasters. The aim of this resolution is to engage in a dialogue that is part of the dialogue launched by the European Commission in order to reach solutions in a spirit of cooperation between the European institutions and the Polish Government.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution because it highlights the serious situation in which the most basic human rights are being enforced. In addition, the text includes amendments by our group specifically discussing the situation in which women's sexual and reproductive rights are located. We consider Polish abortion legislation to be already one of the most restrictive and recall UN international obligations and opinions that denying access to sexual and reproductive health services to the population is a violation of human rights.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. This report contains no reference to one of the most pressing issues in Poland. The situation of LGTBi women and people is now extremely delicate, having reached the competing ban on abortion in any of the cases. Unfortunately, the GUE/NGL amendments in this direction have been decayed from the opposite position of majority groups, which have turned their backs on Polish feminists who claim their rights on the streets. However, we voted in favour of the resolution as it includes important aspects relating to the need for the protection of fundamental rights in Poland in the face of the current regression situation, and urges compliance with the conclusions of the Venice Commission on the rule of law.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 In Poland, following the emergence of a new government, procedures have been applied that are perceived by the EU as not in line with the fundamental principles of the rule of law. An efficient, independent and impartial judicial system is essential for the rule of law to ensure the protection of the fundamental rights and civil liberties of citizens in Europe. The Constitutional Court was created as one of the main elements ensuring the control and balance of constitutional democracy and the rule of law in Poland. Recent events in Poland, in particular the political and legal dispute over the composition of the Constitutional Court and the new rules for its functioning, have raised concerns about the court's ability to uphold the Constitution and guarantee respect for the rule of law. On 19 January 2016, Polish Prime Minister Beata Szydlo was in the EP to explain the positions and actions of the Polish Government, but as the results of the Venice Commission were not yet there at this time, the resolution was not adopted. Today, we know that the Venice Commission has made it clear that the Constitutional Court cannot fulfil its tasks as guarantor of the sovereignty of Poland's constitution, given that the judgment of 9 March 2016 is not published and therefore cannot become final and that this undermines the rule of law. At the same time, the Venice Commission warned that the weakening of the court threatens democracy, human rights and the rule of law. With the resolution, I supported the Commission's efforts to find a way out of the current situation through dialogue with the Polish authorities.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Democracy and the rule of law are among the fundamental values on which the EU and its Member States stand. In cases of doubt about compliance with these values by one of the Member States, the EU should pay attention. In January, the European Commission launched a dialogue with the Polish Government on some of the controversial reforms that have taken place in Poland. It has not yet reached a clear conclusion, but the latest crisis around the Pr Constitutional Court shows a possible threat to the values of the rule of law, and the Polish government should know that it cannot afford everything, even if it was democratically elected. I have discussed the situation in Poland for a long time with my Polish colleagues from the European People's Party faction and I respect their point of view. Therefore, after some hesitation, I supported the motion for a resolution reflecting the situation around the Polish Constitutional Court and appealing to the Polish Government to respect the position of the Venice Commission and to stop restricting the Constitutional Court. The Commission criticised as unconstitutional the election of new members of the court by the previous and current parliaments and the increase of the decision quorum to 13 from a total of 15 judges. I believe that the impasse around the Polish Constitutional Court will be resolved successfully to the satisfaction of all parties so that it can start operating normally again. However, I strongly insist that a constructive dialogue with the Polish Government should continue and that we be very sensitive to the democratically elected Polish Government.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 In Europe, but also elsewhere in the world, we are seeing a tendency to offer simple and radical solutions. History teaches us that they are almost always wrong and often lead to much greater tragedies than they should have prevented. The European Union is a set of values that every government must uphold. These include freedom of speech and the independence of the judiciary.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ Respect for the rule of law, democracy, human rights, fundamental freedoms and values and principles ensheded in the Treaties of the European Union and international human rights legal documents are obligations for the Union and its Member States to abide by.  Recent developments in Poland, following the arrival of the Law and Justice (PiS) party, have highlighted shortcomings in the constitutional court's ability to guarantee respect for the Constitution and the rule of law. The new rules on the functioning of the Constitutional Court pose a potential danger to constitutional democracy, the rule of law and human rights. For the first time, the European Commission has launched a 'Framework for a Legal State' procedure to initiate a structured dialogue with the Polish authorities and assess the current situation.  I believe that each Member State should fully respect the commitments it has undertaken by joining the EU.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ At the end of 2015, the Law and Justice (PiS) party won the Polish elections. Shortly after coming to power, she implemented several reforms, including the law on the Constitutional Court. Critics of the system resented the dismissal of judges at the constitutional court and media reform and stressed that the state does not respect the rule of law. This attracted the interest of domestic and foreign media and the European Commission launched the 'Framework for a Legal State' procedure for the first time. The aim is to study and investigate whether there is a threat to democracy and the rule of law in Poland. I support the proposal for a resolution on the situation in Poland. I believe that respect for fundamental human freedom, media freedom and the rule of law is the cornerstone of a modern and strong European Union. The justice system must be independent of any political option and foster civil liberties. I believe that all Member States must respect EU laws and be ready to cooperate fully with the EU institutions. It is in the interest of the entire European Union to resolve the situation with Poland as soon as possible.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the joint resolution on the situation in Poland, which was also proposed by the Political Group of the European People's Party. Poland is a stable member of the European Union and it is therefore fundamental to ensure full respect for common European values. Poland must not be marginalised and exclude it from important discussions on migration, terrorism, the internal market, energy policy and foreign policy issues. We need Poland as a strong, stable and credible partner. I believe that the resolution is balanced and based solely on facts, but at the same time calls on the Polish Government to reassess some of its actions, which could be contrary to EU values.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 This resolution is an unacceptable interference in the internal affairs of a Member State, an unacceptable disregard for popular sovereignty and the will of the Polish people, as expressed emphatically in the last elections and overall goes beyond even the loose limits of immorality of the Union.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of this report, especially given that, as a Hungarian Member, I must bear in mind the fact that the situation regarding the democracy deficit in my country is as serious as in Poland because of the government's policies. I consider it justified and important for the European Parliament and the other EU institutions to assess the effectiveing of European values on a regular basis on the basis of the same criteria in all Member States. It is of great importance that the EP is at the forefront of this principled political endeavour, and I hope that, in the wake of the Polish cause, it will also be able to contribute to improving democratic relations in Hungary. Dealing with the situation in Poland, the report focuses on the limitation of constitutional law and, in this connection, the importance of taking into account the recommendations of the Venice Commission.  I consider it a shortcoming that, because of the political compromise required for large-scale parliamentary support, the report does not address criticism of other political aspirations and practices of the Polish Government that violate fundamental rights, in particular the outrageous draft abortion law. Nevertheless, I supported this report in the hope that these issues would be put on the agenda in the framework of a structured dialogue between the European Commission and the Polish Government, as well as in further political action by the EP.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ Recent events in Poland, such as the paralysis of the Constitutional Tribunal and the fact that the Tribunal’s verdict of 9 March 2016 remains unpublished and therefore cannot enter into force, undermines democracy, human rights and the rule of law. Although the Constitutional Tribunal was established as one of the central elements ensuring checks and balances in constitutional democracy and the rule of law in Poland, the Venice Commission clearly stated that, in the current situation, the Constitutional Tribunal cannot fulfil its role as guarantor of the supremacy of the Constitution of Poland. Furthermore, aside from the constitutional issues, there are other issues of serious concern in Poland, such as media freedom. The European Parliament resolution urges the Polish Government to respect, publish and fully implement without further delay the Constitutional Tribunal’s judgment of 9 March 2016 and to implement the judgments of 3 and 9 December 2015, calls on the Polish Government to fully implement the recommendations of the Venice Commission and urges future solutions to strengthen democracy, human rights and the rule of law. I support Parliament’s resolution.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it is a vigorous and direct message the European Parliament has sent to Poland’s PiS government. Under the leadership of ALDE the resolution adopted was supported by a large majority of the European Parliament. It urges the Polish Government to publish the verdict of the Constitutional Tribunal and to deliver the recommendations set out by the Venice Commission on legal changes to the Polish Constitutional Court’s functioning.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I consider the interference of the European Union in Poland's internal politics primarily inappropriate, but also unnecessary since Polish politicians are able to solve internal problems in their own country, if they exist. In my legislative and administrative practice, I believe that Poland fully respects EUROPEAN Union law and upholds fundamental European values, in not all democratic principles, the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights, and I voted against the European Parliament resolution on the situation in Poland.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the motions for resolutions on the situation in Poland, as respect for the rule of law, democracy, human rights, fundamental freedoms and fundamental freedoms and principles set out in the EU Treaties and international human rights instruments must be an obligation to be respected.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution because it highlights the serious situation in which the most basic human rights are being enforced. In addition, the text includes amendments by our group specifically discussing the situation in which women's sexual and reproductive rights are located. We consider Polish abortion legislation to be already one of the most restrictive and recall UN international obligations and opinions that denying access to sexual and reproductive health services to the population is a violation of human rights.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support this resolution because I believe that this is an unacceptable interference with the competences of the nation state. The Commission should certainly not play the scrutiny committee of a democratically elected government.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Recent events in Poland, namely the political and legal debate on the composition and new rules of operation of the Constitutional Court, raise concerns about the constitutional court's ability to uphold the constitution and guarantee respect for the rule of law. The Venice Commission has explicitly stated that the Constitutional Court cannot carry out its task of guaranteeing the primaries of Poland's constitution, since its decision of 9 March 2016 has not been published and cannot enter into force, which threatens the rule of law. The Venice Commission has warned that paralyzing the constitutional court would threaten democracy, human rights and the rule of law. I voted in favour of the S&D Group proposal.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution because it highlights the serious situation in which the most basic human rights are being enforced. In addition, the text includes amendments by our group specifically discussing the situation in which women's sexual and reproductive rights are located. We consider Polish abortion legislation to be already one of the most restrictive and recall UN international obligations and opinions that denying access to sexual and reproductive health services to the population is a violation of human rights.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. This resolution only highlights the need to ensure full respect for the common European values set out in Article 2 of the E TUE, the need for all Member States to respect EU law and for all legislation, including primary law of any Member State or candidate country, to reflect and respect fundamental European values , namely democratic principles, the rule of law and fundamental rights. In this sense, the effective paralysis of Poland's Constitutional Court poses a major danger to democracy, human rights and the rule of law. It is therefore important to vote in favour of that resolution, so that Parliament may set out a firm position in situations which could jeopardize full respect for the common European values set out in Article 2 of the ESO.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of this resolution because it contains a strong message from the European Parliament to the current Polish Government. This resolution urges the Polish Government to publish the ruling of the Constitutional Tribunal and to comply with the opinions expressed by the Venice Commission on the reform of the functioning of the Polish Constitutional Court.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. In this resolution, the European Parliament expresses strong concerns about the rule of law, human rights and democracy in Poland.  The resolution adopted focuses on the Polish government's refusal to comply with a decision of the Polish Constitutional Court.  It highlights concerns about the risks of two legal systems coexisting in parallel.  The resolution calls for compliance with the judgments of the Constitutional Court applying the recommendations of the Venice Commission, i.e. the Council of Europe. Several political groups have refused to go further and integrate the global issue of the evolution of human rights in Poland and in particular women's rights, with the questioning of the right to abortion.  We have proposed four amendments to this effect which have been rejected by the parliamentary majority on the grounds that a specific resolution would be adopted at a future plenary. I regret it considering that one of yours is better than two you will have.  Nevertheless, I voted in favour of this resolution at a minimum in the hope that all the concerns of Polish citizens who defend the rule of law will be addressed very quickly.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. Recent events in Poland have given rise to concerns about the constitutional court's ability to uphold the Constitution and ensure respect for the rule of law.  The Venice Commission has stated that the Constitutional Court cannot play its role as guarantor of the supremacy of the Polish Constitution because its decision of 9 March 2016 has not been published and that it cannot therefore enter into force, thereby compromising the rule of law.  This compromises the rule of law. The decisions of the Polish President and the Government are considered to be a risk to constitutional democracy. In a later case, the Commission will assess whether Poland has been bout of the rule of law.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I believe that the European Union is interfering with the polish government's affairs and the internal affairs of Poland with this resolution. This is intended to exert political pressure in favour of the opposition. Such an EU inaction must be firmly rejected.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Writing. Contrary to the draft resolution, I do not consider the democratic order to be endangered as a result of the legislative measures criticised in Poland. I also strongly reject the measures of a sovereign European country – possibly as a precursor to future sanctions – which is why a 'no' vote was required.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution in order to share my grave concern for the situation in Poland. The ongoing attack on the country’s constitutional court, on fundamental rights, and democratic values are worrying, and the EU and fellow Member States must take action to dissuade the Polish government from its current course of action. I am particularly worried about the attempts to legislate away women’s rights and gender equality generally and sexual and reproductive rights specifically. Women must have access to healthcare and to abortion, and have complete freedom to choose. I stand in solidarity with women and feminist campaigners in Poland protesting against the government initiative. We must engage in constant dialogue with Polish civil society and women’s rights organisations in order to support them in their campaigns and demonstrate our solidarity.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 As the vote on the resolution on the situation in Poland is of great interest, I express my view on this subject.  In January, the EP held a debate on respect for the rule of law in Poland. Contrary to accepted practice, a resolution was not adopted at the time, as the EP hoped that the crisis would be quickly overcome in Poland. It was welcomed that the Polish asked the Venetian Commission on its own initiative to assess the situation. A month ago, the Veneto Commission sent Poland a document that reliably analyses compliance with the rule of law and formulates proposals for action for the Polish government. Unfortunately, in practice, not a single of these proposals has entered into force and the stalemate around the Constitutional Court continues. In this situation, the EP is obliged to express its opinion on the situation in Poland. The paralysis of the activities of the CTM cannot be reconciled, as this weakens the independence of the judiciary, one of the pillars of a democratic state and the legal security of citizens.  The EP resolution rightly expects the Commission to continue to assess compliance with the fundamental principles on which the Union is founded. It is the Commission that is the guardian of the treaties that Poland has ratified. However, I expect that EU Member States will be treated equally in the area of law and law. Just as I expect that the Polish will cooperate with the Commission and that any changes in Poland will be carried out in accordance with the current constitution.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The text of this resolution is proof of the bias and bad will of its inspirers and creators. Poland is a democratic state in which citizens have emerged as a stable parliamentary majority in free elections. Its main objective is to reform the state and restore its subjectivity on the European stage. Unfortunately, the previous government could not come to terms with the impending defeat, and even before the elections, breaking the law and ignoring the elementary principles of political culture, it filled the ediling seats in the Constitutional Tribunal. Back then, in June 2015, no European institution had even stinged itself about violating democratic principles, and no MEP had shed a tear over the rule of law in Poland. The actions subsequently taken by Law and Justice were aimed only at restoring normality, in which the Constitutional Court will not be a tool for fighting the opposition against the government, but an independent and apolitical constitutional court.  We listen attentively to the advice of our partners, but whether and how they will be taken into account is only a decision of the Polish authorities. The crisis that we are currently facing in Poland is political in nature and its escalation is clearly beneficial for opposition parties, as demonstrated by the rejection of many of the compromise proposals put forward by the parliamentary majority. Engaging in this dispute with the European institutions does not bring us closer to finding a solution. I voted against this harmful, unreliable and politically inspired text.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament resolution on the situation in Poland, which, in order to respect the rule of law, democracy and respect for human rights, is laid down in Article 2 TEU and the Polish Constitution.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The following item is on the agenda: a joint debate on the following reports: the report by Jan Philipp Albrecht on civil liberties, Recommendation on behalf of the Committee on Justice and Home Affairs on the protection of the individual in the processing of personal data for second reading (A8-0139/2016) [05419/1/2016 - C8-0140/2016 - 2012/0011(COD)] and the Recommendation on behalf of the Committee on Justice and Home Affairs on the second reading of the Recommendation "Processing of personal data to prevent criminal offences" (A8-0138/2016) [05418/1/2016 - C8-0139/2016 - 2012/0010(COD)]

name: Jan Philipp ALBRECHT
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, after more than four years of work as your rapporteur I am happy to announce that there is a consensus of all democratic parties in this House and of Member States in the Council for the adoption of the General Data Protection Regulation. It is the result of intense negotiations in both legislators’ bodies and in the course of a trilogue on the basis of our first reading in March 2014 and a general approach in the Council from June 2015. The agreement found in December under the Luxembourg Presidency is an important signal, as the finalisation of this file by the end of 2015 was announced by the Commission and Parliament’s Presidents, as well as the heads of state in the European Council several times. Its adoption by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) and the Council of Ministers, both almost by unanimity, shows that we struck the right balance between the high level of protection for the fundamental right to data protection, as well as strong consumer rights in the digital age, on the one hand, and the need to create a fair and functioning digital market with a real chance for growth and innovation on the other. Having said this, I want to emphasise once again that I did not believe, and I will not believe, that these two aspects are mutually exclusive. I am convinced that respect for data protection is not only a precondition for trust and innovation in a digitalised economy, but it will be an important key for the success of our European economies in the future. We Europeans not only export a high protection of privacy and consumer rights online. We will also be able to set a gold standard for the digital market of tomorrow, when these standards will be essential for each and every new technology product and service. At the same time, we are for the first time in European history regulating the application of a fundamental right for the whole European market by a directly applicable EU regulation. We are deepening and harmonising the existing rights and standards from the 1995 Directive on Data Protection and creating a single legal standard for the protection of personal data which is fit for the digitalised society of tomorrow. With new rights such as data portability and new principles like data protection by design, we are further developing the protection of our privacy and self-determination in times of big data and the internet of things. Stronger consumer transparency and choice is building new opportunities for trustful, secure and consumer-friendly products and services. The newly-built consistency mechanism in the future EU Data Protection Board and a strong sanction regime will ensure that there will be equal opportunities, effective rights and legal certainty for everyone on our market which, as the biggest common market in the world, nobody will be able to ignore. This compromise, which we have found in an intense democratic debate in a legislative process throughout recent years, is a huge step forward towards creating a single legal environment for the digital world of tomorrow, and this is our chance as Europeans to have a significant effect on it. I want once again to thank the shadow rapporteurs, the rapporteur for the Police Directive, Marju Lauristin, and all the colleagues here in Parliament, in the Commission and in the Council, as well as all the people involved in this democratic process, for their hard work, their honest and open engagement and contribution to this result. I also thank our staff, the secretariats, translators and lawyer linguists who made it possible for us to ensure final adoption this week. Everybody out there is waiting for us to formally finalise and present the long-expected EU Data Protection Regulation, and data controllers, their consultants, Member State governments and data protection authorities are eager to do what from now on will be the most important thing: to get this single data protection law of the European Union into practice as soon as possible.

name: Marju LAURISTIN
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to start by endorsing Jan Albrecht’s words on thankfulness. We are really very thankful for the tough work we have done together with shadow rapporteurs from all Groups, with our secretariat, with our assistants, with the Commission and its team and with the Council and its team. It has been tough work, and I suppose that half a year ago we were not very optimistic as to the prospects of managing to do the whole data protection package in time and being ready together here now. Concerning my specific area, the directive on the data protection in the field of law enforcement or ‘police directive’, as it is called: this is part of the general data protection package which covers the specificities of police work. All elements of police work not directly related to crime investigation or prevention, including public security issues and crimes against public security – in short, ordinary work which is not criminal –  belong to the regulation presented by Jan Albrecht. What is specific in this directive? We see that police work contains more and more international aspects. In the present situation we all have experience on how important it is that police in different Member States work together, trust each other and transfer information quickly and smoothly. In order to do that they need common rules and a common framework, and this directive is presenting this common framework. It is important that, even in these times of common insecurity, we do not forget about basic fundamental human rights, and privacy protection is one of those. Nor should we forget about non-discrimination and fairness, and this directive also takes that into account – to have a good proper balance to secure personal data and also to give police, in their specific work on criminal investigation, enough space to be effective, quick and also cooperative. What are some of the main innovations for the police? We do not currently have a common framework for data protection or data processing in 28 Member States. We had a general directive that we replaced by regulation, but in the police field we did not have anything like that. This is the first regulatory act which will provide police in all Member States with their common rules. In this framework, the very important thing is that the general principles of proportionality, legitimacy and purpose-limitation are included in police work. That means that no form of mass surveillance is possible. The collection of data is not possible. Retention for an unlimited or unclear period is not possible. Another important point is that we foresee the inclusion of data protection professionals in the police institutional setting: specifically, in police work. This will bring everyday concerns about data protection and privacy protection into police work. There will also be quite a strict and strong regime for recording all excesses and all usages of data. All these principles are very important. We will have the opportunity to have more effective police work and provide more security and confidence for citizens that their privacy will be protected.

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, it is with great pleasure that I attend today’s plenary session on the Data Protection Package. As you know, the Council very much welcomes the agreements that our two institutions reached last December on the General Data Protection Regulation and the directive on data protection in the field of criminal law enforcement. In the negotiations on the regulation and the directive, Parliament and Council have consistently acknowledged that protection of personal data is a fundamental right. As a result, we agreed to empower individuals with strong and enforceable data-protection rights. Parliament and Council recognise the importance of a coherent data protection framework for the digital economy, backed by strong enforcement. This resulted in a general data protection regulation laying down harmonised rules for processing of personal data. These new rules will end the fragmentation stemming from differences in implementation of the current directive. The new legislative framework enhances legal certainty, creates a level playing field for companies and reduces administrative burdens. Furthermore, the directive on data protection in the field of criminal law enforcement will ensure effective judicial cooperation in criminal matters and police cooperation. An important element is that it will cover both cross—border and domestic processing of personal data. The directive will facilitate the exchange of personal data between law enforcement authorities. At the same time, it will guarantee a consistently high level of data protection. Tomorrow’s vote will make the EU’s data protection rules ready for the digital era. On behalf of the Council, I would like to thank Parliament, and in particular its rapporteurs, Mr Albrecht and Mrs Lauristin, for their excellent work and close cooperation with Council.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am really pleased to stand in front of you today at the end of our common journey to the final adoption of the data protection reform package. The Commission welcomes the final text that is before you.
