But the European Parliament continued to linger unnecessarily long.  Colleagues, who do not see the importance of such an information system after the attacks in Paris and Brussels, are blind! We now need short-term solutions, such as the exchange of personal data from passenger flights. Certain parties considered linking PNR to the data protection package as essential. However, there are sufficient guarantees for data protection in the PNR file.  The vote on PNR has therefore been delayed by five years. Hopefully, tomorrow all political groups will show their common sense and prefer security to political games. We really don't have to give up our privacy for that. Moreover, the data protection package is virtually complete. No more reason to delay or vote against the case any longer.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, not least because this is the start of a new chapter in his life where he will not meet with daily harassment by his favourite shadow rapporteur from the ALDE Group. But I will do something unusual for a politician: I am going to confess that in my Group we have been struggling with this topic. Emotions have been running high, we have had and we still have very difficult debates. But I am actually quite proud of the Liberal Group that we have that debate, that we have discussion and doubt and that we do not take a position blindfolded, that we are not dogmatic or ideological or represent certain interests or opportunism. And we have to confess that external pressure has been huge; the debate has often been completely fact-free, the lobby has been aggressive and sometimes immoral, and there have been many ad hominem attacks, but we leave all that behind us. Now we may all assess the outcome differently, including in my Group – I will personally vote against, that will not come as a surprise – but it remains to be seen whether we get the security that everybody is talking about, or whether this is just fake security. My group was unanimous on a number of principles. We wanted a truly European and effective PNR. We wanted a regulation that would enter into force immediately. We wanted mandatory sharing of information, i.e. the result of analysis. We wanted targeted data collection instead of indiscriminate data collection. We wanted the single system, not 28 systems. But all these proposals have been categorically refused by the PPE, the ECR and the Member States. The question is, will this directive see the same fate as the data retention directive? Will it be scrapped in Karlsruhe or Luxembourg? The directive will now have to be implemented by 28 Member States, and after their aggressive campaign they had better do it ‘PDQ’. Finally – and I ask this question to the Commission very urgently – can we finally get some transparency on the financial aspects of all this? I want all the details about the fund of EUR 50 million. On what basis has it been allocated? And I think we also need some transparency on certain conflicts of interest on the part of heads of government.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Well, with the EU PNR it is like the famous needle in a haystack, which is so hard to find, and if you want to find the needle faster and find that you are piling up even more hay – yes, that is absurd. And this is not only absurd, but also dangerous, because the belief that, with ever-increasing data collections – ever more additional, ever new – the security of citizens is a chimera. And what we need is not more and more and additional and all-encompassing, blanket data collections, but the faster and more accurate evaluation of the existing data, in accordance with the principles of purpose, data minimisation and proportionality.  We too had put forward concrete proposals on this, but the conservative side of the House did not even want to discuss them. Despite hailing criticism from data protectionists, NGOs and legal concerns, despite the fact that the Data Retention Directive has been cashed in before the ECJ, despite an expected similar ECJ ruling – presumably – on the PNR agreement with Canada, they now want to push through a stricter EU PNR than the Commission even proposed. An EU PNR, for which you have never and never provided serious proof, at the expense of citizens whose fundamental rights are, of course, restricted.  However, the recent terrorist attacks have also shown something that is really needed: better cooperation between the police and the judiciary of the Member States in order to be able to verify existing information. Instead of spending and sploffing millions on PNR, the police in the countries should be better equipped and not discouraged from working for years, as in Germany.  With this directive, people are becoming suspects without cause, and so we are gradually moving away from the constitutional consensus. Because there is no freedom without security, but there is no security without freedom.

name: Jan Philipp ALBRECHT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, yes, we need to strengthen security. I agree with all those who say we need to deliver whatever is necessary and proportionate to get a higher level of security – but what is proposed here? The proposed blanket mass surveillance of all travellers is exactly the opposite of that. It does not deliver that. Instead, you are delivering a symbolic measure at the cost of effective security and the civil liberties of EU citizens. Even before the Brussels and Paris attacks it was possible to know who was travelling on which plane. We already know that. For decades we have had airlines transferring advance passenger information data. It is there, we can access it and we can know who is on which plane. In the case of known suspects – and 15 out of 17 attackers from several attacks, in Brussels, Copenhagen and Paris, have been known suspects – we can follow them and collect more information. So why are we not focusing on those known suspects? Why do we not focus on the risk? That is what we should do in this directive, because that would be a focused and effective approach towards more security. We need to strengthen the capacity of police officers and security personnel locally, regionally and at European level to analyse this information. We need to be able to connect the dots. That is exactly what has been missing in the past and what has led to the insecure situation we have today. But the problem is that we are spending all our money on blanket surveillance measures like data retention of passenger name records. This money is instead urgently needed for the police everywhere in Europe and for the coordination of European security and police authorities. Europol has just a small amount of money to set up joint investigation teams. We need to invest the money there. That is what we need to do. So we Greens are not convinced by these proposals, and many people out there are not either. The Court of Justice, as well as the European Court of Human Rights here in Strasbourg, has clearly and repeatedly said that it is not in line with our fundamental rights and freedoms to just put everybody under surveillance. You have to choose where you are looking. You have to choose who you are going after. You have to create some determining criteria and indicate where the risk or suspicion is. That is what the Greens propose because this would protect our security better and protect civil liberties, which we defend against these barbaric terrorists. (The speaker declined to take a blue-card question)

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the EFDD Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the We are therefore talking today about the directive on the use of PNR data. The storage of passenger data is hoped to prevent and investigate criminal offences. I consider this to be a very serious interference with civil rights, although we all agree that we must take measures to prevent and investigate attacks. That's clear. But here passenger data is stored by everyone – without cause. We should all endure this interference with our civil rights. It is about private data: who flew where when, who sat next to whom, who ate what, how did they pay for the trip, etc. This data should be stored for all - without cause. It is a gigantic data retention, the data of which the law enforcement authorities are then supposed to access. I do not believe that this will lead to greater security. That is a sheer assertion. The huge mountain of data is being piled up, and it remains unproven that this will continue. The perpetrators and those behind brussels and Paris were known by name to the authorities. Some of them were known as potential perpetrators of violence, and yet the authorities have not been able to prevent the attacks. I think it is wrong to place the citizens under general suspicion. Because that's what it means when we store all the data on a large scale. Hundreds of thousands of people enter and pass through the European Union undetected and unrestricted, hundreds of thousands of whom we do not know who they are or what they want. I believe that we should focus on the problems where they really are and stop putting every citizen under general suspicion. That is, in any case, wrong.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the Schengen area is moribund; the wave of migration has overwhelmed the fragile barriers of its external borders. Unfortunately, many terrorists took the opportunity to enter the European Union. Rather than admitting the failure of Schengen, the Union is trying to distract by creating a European NRL, that is, a widespread record of the hundreds of millions of air passengers entering or leaving the EU. This mass registration will have no effectiveness in the fight against terrorism. It would not have allowed any of the killers from Paris or Brussels to be apprehended. The European Data Protection Supervisor himself acknowledges that the PNR will, I quote, have "little practical use". The PNR is therefore merely a smoke-in designed to mask the failure of Schengen, a pitiful attempt to save a breathless European Union. The real solution is to restore national control of internal borders, the only way to prevent foreign terrorists from entering France, regardless of the access routes they use - land, sea or air.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: – Mr President, I come from a country which has been fighting terrorism for fifty years. We've learned that to win you have to trust the police. Political parties have to be united so that society is not divided. And against terrorism, every effort is little.  Here we have been debating a record of passenger data for years, and in the meantime there has been the attack on Charlie Hebdo, there has been the attack on Paris, there has been the attack on Brussels; and we kept debating.  Some people say that with a PNR we wouldn't have been able to prevent those attacks. Sad consolation. Who knows if we could have avoided them or not. There are fourteen PNRs in Europe, they are not connected and they are all fragmentary. And there are 5,000 Europeans fighting with the Dáesh, who do not know what day they are going to return to Europe; and I'd like to know what flight they're on and what time they land, because I'm not one to care more about the terrorist's right to privacy than the right to life of the victim he's expecting. Through our credit cards any Treasury inspector in use of its functions can know everything about our privacy. I think it's okay to give up a portion of my privacy to pay taxes, but I also think it's okay to give up a part of my privacy to save my life; because private life is important, but life is more important. Because paying taxes is very important, money is very important, but life is much more important. Here are some colleagues who come to talk about transparency every day, except today that it is about talking about the transparency of terrorists.  The People's Group will vote yes to the PNR, not because of the attacks that could be avoided but for those that we will avoid in the future; I hope you're on the same team.  (He refused to be asked three questions under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – Today, I am particularly pleased that we have managed to adopt a package of measures to better protect and protect Europeans' personal data. It is one of the most modern and advanced models of protecting citizens' fundamental rights. Better data protection is a necessary safeguard before we establish a European Air Passenger Data Record. The negotiations have been long and arduous. To be honest, it was wrong for some of them to be used for dirty games at the expense of the fight against terrorism. Yes, PNR can help fight terrorism, but it is quite irresponsible to try to present it as the only tool. Better cooperation between the judicial authorities of the Member States of the Union is essential. That doesn't work today. We need to be aware that PNR is not a magic wand to stop terrorists and criminals. All the air passenger data we have managed to collect so far has not helped prevent recent terrorist attacks in France or Belgium. Therefore, I repeat, the exchange of criminal intelligence is essential, cooperation is essential. Without this, no PNR will succeed. A year ago, we sent the agreement on the exchange of air passenger data between the Union and Canada to the Court, which has not yet delivered its opinion. I'm worried about him going through a court order. Have the arguments in the data retention judgment been duly taken into account? I have similar concerns about the proposal on the table. And I am sorry that, despite many warnings, we have not been able to enter into the text a provision on the mandatory exchange of information on known threats. This information will continue to be shared on a voluntary basis by countries. The information that the passenger enters when booking the air ticket is not reliable. And the question is, will we really be able to stop the terrorist threat? (The speaker answered the question raised by raising the blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. Thank you very much, Mrs. Fajon for accepting my blue card. I would like to ask you as a woman who spoke now about this, about the need to cooperate between member states, but also as a woman who knows the situation in the Western Balkans well, do you agree with me that it should definitely be seen how to incorporate candidate countries into this PNR system and candidate countries for entry into the European Union? Because we know that, especially Bosnia and Herzegovina, and possibly some other countries can be, so to speak, the sources of those who want to deal with terrorism and who can be our danger. Do you agree with me?

name: Tanja FAJON
text: Odgovor na vprašanje, postavljeno z dvigom modrega kartončka. – Hvala kolega Jakovčić, da strinjam se, da bi bilo smiselno harmonizirati obstoječe baze podatkov PNR, ravno to je danes problem, da ima večina nacionalnih držav, nacionalnih letališč dejansko že uvedene neke baze evidenc podatkov in če imamo države kandidatke, kjer vemo, kakšno je sodelovanje, … (zaradi težav s tolmačenjem je poslanka nadaljevala v angleščini) I perfectly agree with our Croatian colleague that it is good to have a harmonised system when it comes to PNR, also considering accession – not the Croatian accession, but for the other countries of the Western Balkans where we know in particular how bad the situation is concerning cooperation between the police, the judiciary, agencies and information and secret services.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – We are facing well-funded, well-organised and determined international terrorist groups to do harm to the extreme. Let's not wait until we're hit again. Europe needs more than ever to be united and to use any means against jihadist terror. This is not to violate human rights, but, on the contrary, to keep them against those who want to destroy them. The Directive on the transmission of passenger data by airlines provides that these airlines must transmit the name, ticket number or payment method for passengers entering or leaving the European Union. And it's also about European citizens. That is because it is urgently necessary to identify European citizens who are going to fight alongside jihadists. No one is saying that this law is a silver bullet that alone will succeed in ending terrorism in Europe, but, together with other measures, we must succeed. (The speaker agreed to answer a question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. " Thank you very much for the opportunity, Mr President. I appeal to my fellow Member on the question of whether he agrees with me that the security of the entire European Union is in fact determined by the least secure European country, that is, the weakest link? In light of this, I ask whether, although you have set up different modalities, how do you feel that some governments – eu member states – give unchecked citizenship or residence permits to different people for effective money? Thank you.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: Answer to a question asked in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Of course, the Member States are not equal either in the way they ensure the protection of the borders of the European Union or in the level of crime, including, as you said, possibly the sale of citizens. And all of these are goals that we must defeat and fight for, to disappear from our reality. Because, all together, along with the others, laid out and prepared by the terrorists, lead us to what happened, to the loss of life.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: Mr President, I, in turn, would like to welcome the outcome of this important dossier, because the collection and use of passenger data will, or hopefully hopefully, enable it to intensify prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of transnational offences and terrorist threats. It is a tool that is now more than ever necessary, in view of the growing threats and, of course, to guarantee the security of Europeans, but it is only one of the tools of an arsenal that needs to be strengthened. For my part, I will vote in favour of this text, at the same time because I am convinced that, if the attacks have targeted us all, the Europeans, the response must be European. And I regret, in this regard, that in this text, which has occupied our Parliament for so long, we have not gone further in the tool of security, protection of the lives of citizens that constitutes the PNR, by making it compulsory for States to transmit information, and that we have failed to convince the States , often a little hypocritical, to make it a highly centralized system

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Mr President, as the French Prime Minister would say, the European Parliament will finally take responsibility and vote on the PNR. They want us to believe that this is the miracle tool against terrorism. Everyone here is committed to the safety of our fellow citizens, and I believe that we should not go to trial in this area.  But I don't think there's anything to be proud to be proud to vote for this text. It will be liberticidal, and I do not go back to everything my colleagues have already said in this area - I share it. It will be useless because it does not target the data collected. It is a lie, because it is not European, but only harmonizes national NRPs, and therefore does not oblige states to share data. It would not have prevented anything, contrary to what some would like to believe, from the attacks in Paris and Brussels. The terrorists travelled by train, by car and they were, yes, known to the police.  We need balance sheets in this area, not technological leaks that will serve the interests of large companies first, a subject on which we should return. The fight against terrorism needs, first and foremost, human resources to enable the police and justice to do their jobs.

name: Eva JOLY
text: Mr President, it is easier to tell European citizens that, if a new tragedy could not be avoided, it is because a supposedly magical tool has not been adopted by these horrible naïve Members of the European Parliament - and I use here the most sympathetic term that has been used against us in recent months - rather than admitting that the tools exist but that the tools exist but that , despite the warnings and the increased threat level, they have not been given the necessary financial and human resources. So we take the PNR out of our hat. Databases and files exist. What sins is cooperation, the exchange of information. That is what we have to make mandatory and that the NRL does not impose in any way.  Let us create the conditions for success, not the programmed failure of an ultra-secure society that is as inefficient as it is dangerous. Let us impose on the Member States the use of existing files and the exchange of information. Let us allow cooperation between Member States' services, train them to work together, to trust each other, to create a European prosecutor's office that would facilitate investigations and remove the last obstacles.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I want to correct a few things. Firstly, those who vote for PNR vote in favour of common European rules, they vote in favour of common data protection standards, and they are voting in favour of more and coordinated cooperation and against 28 completely uncoordinated systems that are not even technically interoperable. Secondly, PNR is an instrument against many types of serious crime. It is not the miracle instrument against terrorism, but it is directed against many of the most serious crimes that our people will suffer. Thirdly, there is only limited access to the data. It is definitely wrong to say that people's data is being viewed en masse here. Targeted search algorithms are sent through. Welcome to the age of modern technology! We are no longer in 1960, but we are in 2016. We must give the police and the security institutions modern technology in their hands, in order to be able to fight against the modern technology of criminals. There is special training for experts, only specific processes may be entered into the data and more than 99% of the data are never consulted. The experts from Great Britain, France, Spain and Belgium have shown us this precisely and accurately. I would also like the Greens to ensure that, when the PPE-DE makes a request for more money for Europol, the Greens will finally give their assent. That's what I would have liked, including from Sophie in 't Veld. When we could have had a European system, Sophie in 't Veld, together with the Greens, together with the Left, decided that we did not have a common European system accordingly. It is wrong to make other claims today. (The speaker agreed to answer several questions under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Jan Philipp ALBRECHT
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mrs Hohlmeier, I would like to thank Mrs Hohlmeier for her work I have a question: you say that it is not right that all the data of air passengers should be used. Do you agree that all the data in this procedure will be analysed by all travellers? And are you aware that the Federal Constitutional Court in Karlsruhe clearly stated in 2006 on the search for the grid that the limits are, that in any such analysis there must be an acute danger to the body, life or security of the state with a view to a specifically limited period and place, and that this is incompatible with such a mass analysis?

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I do not share your opinion, because the state always has a great deal of data, even if it is only used under restrictions. The state has a whole lot of data, which of course can only be used or used for the corresponding purposes, and for this purpose the PNR system provides precisely which ones for what purposes. These are the most serious crimes that start with the child abuser abusing children and taking them on a plane in all sorts of directions in Europe to do what they can. It is directed against drug traffickers, it is directed against terrorists, it is directed against serious crimes, and that is what we are here for.

name: Marju LAURISTIN
text: blue-card question. –  Ms Hohlmeier, I first want to say that I checked PNR against the directive and I have to say that in principle, in spirit, it is in line. But it is not in line in all details, many of which are very important details. I ask you: why was the EPP against there being an obligation to inform passengers about their rights, about the collection of information? This was envisaged, but it is not there. Why are the functions of the data protection officers limited compared to the directive? And third, why was the EPP against automated data sharing, which could be effective using new technology?

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. The first claim is false. The EPP has advocated the joint mandatory exchange of data, and in Germany, for example, it was the SPD Justice Minister who was opposed to a mandatory exchange of data. We have clearly agreed with S&D, with ALDE, to make a mandatory exchange. In the meantime, the Member States have decided to carry out this exchange on a voluntary basis in the framework of a protocol note. That is why we should finally let this shadow battle be.  Secondly, I believe that data protection standards and control mechanisms are very high in the context of how algorithms can be used to search for the most serious criminals. These are very high standards, and they can also be monitored and transparently overlooked afterwards. We have also provided for a mechanism whereby, after a certain period of time – after five years – the system is to be introduced takes a long time to implement and whether any change should be envisaged for data protection reasons.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: – Mr President, as a British Conservative I believe that the EU should only legislate where there is clear added value for our citizens and where achieving our goals cannot be done alone. Combating cross-border crime and terrorism is one such area. We have a duty to provide our citizens with safety and security. Criminals and terrorists do not respect national borders and legal jurisdictions – they will exploit any gaps and weaknesses. We need a fighting chance against them. So do we not need everything we possibly can to help us trace their movements? Therefore my Conservative colleague Mr Kirkhope has my full support, and I want to thank him for all the work he has done. It is time for this Parliament to fulfil its responsibilities and adopt this important crime-fighting measure. It is simple: I will be voting to protect my constituents’ rights, privacy and their lives.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Listening to representatives of the governments of the Member States, one easily gets the impression that if only PNR had existed, terrorism and serious crime would become a thing of the past. However, the reality is not so simple. PNR is a tool among many others, which can facilitate law enforcement work, particularly in the area of serious crime and terrorism. We would have had real efficiency if cooperation had been deepened if we had had an automatic exchange of information, which unfortunately the governments of the Member States did not want to see. After all, PNR is a tool that can help protect and instill security on the part of citizens across the EU. That is why I and a large majority of my group will vote in favour of PNR.

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: Mr President, I would like to welcome the agreement that was finally reached on the PNR. I regret that it took so long and, unfortunately, so many victims to convince those who delayed it too long, for opposite reasons.  But these additional resources which are now being given to the Member States also give them additional duties. First, a duty of speed of execution; it is a directive, so it has to be transposed. Then a duty to use the files; previous tragedies have shown, as several speakers have already pointed out, that the many existing files are undernourished and underutilized by most Member States. This is the case with SIS 2, it is the case with Europol, as is the case with Eurodoc, among others. Finally, the third duty: to prepare the next step, namely the establishment of a European judicial police to deal with cross-border crime.  The European Arrest Warrant was a significant first but insufficient step forward. The treaty defines European crimes and creates a European prosecutor. Borders no longer exist for criminals, and they must also disappear for police officers and judges.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Jan Philipp ALBRECHT
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Lamassoure, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for his excellent work. Like some of your colleagues, you have just said that it took victims to convince others that this PNR directive is needed. I find it impossible to insinuate to those who are committed to an alternative security architecture and who believe that we can move on another path to greater security and freedom, to assume that they are responsible for the victims of these barbaric terrorist attacks. I therefore call for an apology from you for this.

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: "blue card" answer. If there are excuses to ask, it is more from you. Of course, there are other ways, theoretical means that were unrealistic, that governments would not have accepted. We're in politics. We are not looking for an unattainable ideal. We are looking for realistic and effective compromises. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: blue-card question. – I would like to echo the words of my colleague Mr Albrecht, and I actually think that the repeated accusations on the side of the PPE, to the effect that we are somehow responsible for terrorist attacks, are disgusting. I would say to Mr Lamassoure that if you want to accuse people, maybe ask successive French Governments why they have not used their own PNR system for which the legislation has been in place since 2006 and for which they have received EUR 18 million in subsidies from the European Union. What has kept the national governments? Maybe you should ask them rather than accuse us.

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: "blue card" answer. "Mrs. in't Veld, I fully accept your remark, which is a criticism. I accept criticism without calling others populists, and I do believe, I repeat, that the lesson we have to learn is that our governments have a duty to use all the means at their disposal. They have not done enough in the past. Nevertheless, France was one of five countries out of 28 to have used the existing files, and we now have a duty to ensure that all 28 countries use all the files, including, finally, the PNR. If you were offended by my comments, I do apologise. I did not blame anyone. I simply found that the delay could only have had negative effects in the fight against terrorism.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Mr President! The fight against terrorism and organised crime is important, but also difficult. The terrorists are constantly finding new ways and new methods of their activities, and that requires that we, who want to make a good society, have many different tools to combat this. I believe that the European PNR is one of many tools that we can and must use in the fight against terrorism. That is why I support the adoption of the European PNR. This allows us to improve the exchange of information and cooperation at European level.  Is that a perfect system we're going to get? No, of course it's not. That is why I also think it is absolutely right that the vote on a European PNR is linked to the adoption of our data protection package. It is essential that we ensure proper protection of people's data, for example, very limited data retention. However, it is also necessary to strike a balance between, on the one hand, the protection of privacy and, on the other, the protection of us in relation to terrorism and organised crime. I think we should be pragmatic. Of course, we should not pretend that a European PNR stops terrorism, but I think it is important that we give ourselves the opportunity to have another tool to fight terrorism.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: Mr President, the PNR, which we are discussing today, is neither a magic potion against terrorism, as some would have some believe, nor a liberticidal monster, as others denounce.  The NRNP is only one instrument, more precisely one of the instruments needed to help our intelligence and security services collect and process useful information in the fight against terrorists and major criminals. Of course, and we know this, this instrument is not perfect. This is not, and I deplore, a real European NRP, but 28 national NROs whose interconnection remains to be done. I regret that the exchange of information between them is not mandatory and that the time to transpose is too long. But I prefer an instrument, even imperfect, if it can save lives, with no instrument at all. And I don't see why we would refuse to collect information for ourselves that we have been passing on, even today, and for years, to the United States, Canada and Australia. Yes, I will vote in favour of the NRL and I will reject the amendments, I say all the amendments, which could jeopardize its entry into force.

name: Michał BONI
text: – Mr President, in the fight against terrorists, real-time monitoring and the exchange of data and information is crucial for strengthening our prevention capabilities. If we want to analyse the data, first we need to collect it under clear rules. The PNR Directive is a good example of how to achieve a balance between security and privacy. We have introduced into the directive many data protection safeguards and principles that guarantee respect for fundamental rights. For instance, we have a purpose-limitation principle and the masking-out of data after six months. There is an established monitoring mechanism with a strong position for the data protection authorities, and a list of serious crimes. In addition, the EU PNR Directive has a new section dedicated to data protection and privacy standards, explicitly mentioning the role of national data protection authorities as well as the obligation of appointing a data protection officer in each of the personal information units. But we feel there is a lack of binding obligations to share the data and have a centralised unit for collecting and processing PNR data. This approach gives us a concrete response to our security issues without sacrificing the privacy of our citizens – in fact, it includes the protection of data and privacy, and first and foremost citizens’ freedom and security.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: Mr President, the European NRL is strengthening the UNION's legislative arsenal to fight terrorism. This instrument will be useful in addition to other mechanisms already in place to enable us to deal together with this threat, but it can only have real scope if all Member States agree to participate in an active and coordinated way. It was necessary to achieve an effective and operational tool, fair and proportionate, a tool that ensures the protection of individual freedoms, in particular respect for privacy. The link with the data protection package is therefore very important. I will vote on the joint adoption of these two texts, which mark the first step towards the creation of a common legal framework to combat terrorism, while preserving the rights of everyone. But the fight against terrorism is not limited to the PNR. It must be understood through a comprehensive and common approach, which includes monitoring the movement of firearms, drying up sources of terrorist financing, combating the trafficking of false papers, or even European harmonisation in railway security.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for a few days now we have been discussing an instrument that should and could already be available to the authorities, which could use it as an additional instrument to combat terrorism, among other things, a dramatically violent, cruel and cynical terrorism, and yet we are still here debating and some people say: why all this attention to this PNR , as if it were the panacea?  It is not the panacea, it has become such a long debate because for years there have been political forces in this Parliament that are constantly and constantly blocking the normal process. Because the Commission published it in 2011 and since June 2013 some political forces have blocked it, under the guise of privacy. Now I have here, I always cite him, a very famous, emeritus Italian magistrate who, as recently as last year, beginning to see these difficulties, began to say "look that freedom, freedom when it is limited by law, defends itself". So a small restriction of freedom, guided and ordered by law, is to defend freedom.  Then let's not make fun of ourselves, we are in the society of selfies, Facebooks, Twitter, everyone who takes selfies, is here, is there, they are up, they are down, and for terrorists instead privacy – congratulations and good wishes – and they have put amendments to sink it, sink it! They want to sink it, the citizens need to know!

name: Milan ZVER
text: – Congratulations to the rapporteur, Kirkhop, his and my political group, for an achievement that seemed to never come. Since 2003, we have emphasised the urgent adoption of this act, which would allow the use of passenger name record data in air transport. Many years have passed, there have been a lot of terrorist atrocities, many innocent people died before part of the politics of their political principles and interests adapted to real facts. Following the adoption of PNR, the lives of our citizens will be safer, as the security and intelligence services will finally have comprehensive passenger data that only airlines have had until now. The security authorities will link this information to a consistent analysis of the situation on the basis of the travel pattern algorithms, in relation to data on the use of passenger credit cards, addresses and criminal files and so on, in order to accept a security risk assessment. This will prevent many of the planned terrorist attacks. In addition, with the new approach, individuals who have not yet been linked to serious crime or terrorism will also be on the radar, but they are still part of it. We therefore have an important decision ahead – the adoption of PNR could also serve as a basis for a wider mandatory exchange of security-intelligence in the European Union, along the lines of the United States of America.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Madam President, to face the magnitude of the threat against us, we should unite and be constructive to reassure citizens that we are doing all we can for their security. How much more blood has to be shed before we come together and drop this ideologically infected debate? I am sad that there is still resistance to adopting obvious measures when the experts tell us clearly that PNR is essential to prevent and combat terrorism. Passenger name records are not a magic recipe against terrorism but an essential tool in a limited toolbox. Let us be honest: EU common rules on PNR will protect citizens’ privacy more than the current national system, not less. At the moment we do not know what happens to our data when we travel. With the new PNR we will have more transparency and common safeguards. Member States will be able to exchange information in a secure way, also via Europol. The key is better information-sharing to identify the routes taken by foreign fighters going back and forth, for example to Syria and Iraq, to train and plan attacks against us. I also welcome the fact that the Member States decided – despite the fact that the EPP was against it – to also include intra—EU flights. We also need to work on anti—radicalisation, prevention, better control of our external border and more cooperation with third countries. But the key is that we come together to face terrorism. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: blue-card question. – Dear colleague, you said that this discussion on PNR is ideologically poisoned. I object to that expression. If you are saying this, I would like you to have some more arguments rather than simply promising that there will be more and better security. You know as well as I do that in cases where we know about terrorist attacks, no PNR provision would have prevented these attacks. So I think it is wrong to use the word ‘ideological’ for those who want more freedom and more transparency.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: blue-card answer. – Citizens are truly concerned and worried, and we have to show that we are serious and responsible in giving concrete responses. No one will give you a guarantee that something – a tool, an instrument – will suddenly make terrorism and organised crime disappear from Europe, obviously not. But the police, the intelligence community, Europol, all the experts we have been talking to throughout the years (because we are not experts on terrorism): they tell us clearly that  PNR is a way to give them a tool to better collect and use information on travel. When we talk about European citizens travelling to Syria and to Iraq to be radicalised, trained to attack freely there and come back, it is … (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: My dear colleagues, the blue cards are thirty seconds. They are not used to recover a extra minute. I am sorry, but at this rate, we will once again double the length of this debate. It is very important, but let us respect each other's speaking times. You were already fifty seconds away, Mrs. Corazza Bildt, so thank you. We will resume the course of this debate and try to approach it in the most homogeneous way possible.

name: Emil RADEV
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, unfortunately, it took more than five years after the European Commission's initial proposal for a Directive on Passenger Name Data and at least three major terrorist attacks to get to the final vote tomorrow.  Needlessly, more than 100 people had to be killed and hundreds injured. For me as a legislator, this is the terrifying cost of not having the political will to make a decision. The Directive does not in itself prevent future terrorist attacks, but is an important component in the overall package of counter-terrorism measures. The presence of foreign fighters requires law enforcement to have a complete picture of who crosses the air borders so that they can take the necessary measures before carrying out the attacks. The latest developments in the Paris investigation also demonstrate why Member States have taken the right decision to include intra-European Union flights within the scope of the Directive – ensuring security in Europe requires measures within the European Union, not just at the external borders. I believe that the Directive will facilitate cooperation and, in particular, the exchange of information between Member States, which we have been talking about for so long in the context of the fight against terrorism. With the adoption of the Directive, the European Union is taking an important step towards restoring security in Europe. It is our duty to support this measure so that we do not witness other terrorist attacks.

name: Nuno MELO
text: – The PNR has been refused by some left party under the pretext of a protection of personal data that, in many cases, travel agencies already have, but the left wants to turn into absolute rights. They are not, and collective security is a right of more relevance. It would be nice if we thought about what the victims would say if they could argue in this debate. I have even heard the extraordinary argument that, in recent attacks, terrorists were not from outside Europe. Let's see, terrorists born here, they also travel, they have to be controlled. When terrorists from here and outside are indoctrinated in Syria and elsewhere, they are one, in a criminal organization that has moral perpetrators and material perpetrators. They're all criminals. And I would like to remind you that in the 9/11 attacks, 19 terrorists kidnapped the crews and passengers of four planes, murdered 3,000 people. The terrorists weren't from here, they were from outside, and the victims were from all over the world. I would even like to recall a recent important statement by the High Commissioner for Refugees, recalling - I know it was about refugees - that terrorists, when they want, travel by plane. That's exactly why, too, that PNR is very important. And so, frankly, I say, terrorism is not combated with fantasy or with romantic proclamations. Please approve the PNR.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: Madam President, if the European NRL is adopted tomorrow, it will be the victory of perseverance and the success of reason.  Perseverance, first of all, because the right and centre of this Parliament have fought to have this text adopted by never giving up, against a left that opposed it in 2012, 2013, 2014 and 2016. Reason then, because they are common sense measures that do not infringe on fundamental freedoms, not violating any of the principles of human rights.  I have heard this afternoon from his greatest critics that the European PNR would not have prevented the attacks that took place in Brussels and Paris. But what do they know? They would be hard to tell us. Because who can seriously tell us that this system is useless even before it exists? Who can deny that many countries have a comparable system? Who can ignore, for example, the feedback from the United Kingdom, which, thanks to the NRL, was able to arrest more than 20,000 individuals between 2010 and 2015? The truth is that we need this NRL. This will be one of the means - not the only one, of course, but which, together with others, will fight against those who fight and threaten our convictions, our freedoms, our way of life and our societies. (The speaker refuses a "blue card" question from Mr. Albrecht)

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Madam President, I would like to congratulate all those who have worked on this report, but at the same time I cannot fail to note an inadmissible delay in its discussion. Recent events in Brussels or Paris, but beyond, have shown that the peace and security of the European citizen is more fragile than ever in the face of terrorism and cross-border crime, which have become increasingly aggressive and sophisticated. The attacks have confronted us with a reality that we have refused to perceive as such for too long. The enemy is inside the fortress and unfortunately we lack the effective tools to prevent tragedies such as London, Madrid, Paris or Brussels.  The use of passenger name record data will allow not only reactive intervention, but especially a preventive one, which will increase the capabilities of national states to break up terrorist networks and prevent serious crime or organised crime. However, I draw the attention of all those responsible that the adoption of this Directive is only a small step in the fight against terrorism and in strengthening the security process for citizens. Beyond the efforts made at European Union level, the national states that must implement this legislation are responsible for its effectiveness.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, I am involved in this debate, which must lead tomorrow to the adoption of this regulatory legislative instrument of a European PNR, to greet the work of the rapporteur and also of the shadow rapporteurs, with their visions confronted, but above all to vindicate the work of this European Parliament. Because in this European Parliament there are a few of us who have had executive responsibilities of government and, in particular and also on the left, responsibilities in the fight against terrorism in a country particularly hurt by the scourge of terrorism such as Spain. But this Parliament has not dragged its feet and I therefore step up with the criticisms that have been heard, which pretend that this Parliament has unnecessarily delayed the legislative approval of this PNR, because it is not true. This Parliament has long debated this in order to fulfil its work and to strike a reasonable balance between freedom and security, delimiting the object, delimiting serious crimes in which data can be transferred, delimiting the retention time of that data and ensuring that, in no case, can the way to discriminatory profiling be made. Therefore, it is not true what I have heard here. It is not true that privacy was an excuse for this Parliament to delay its approval. No. Privacy is a fundamental right of Europeans, guaranteed as such in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. And privacy is a fundamental right on which the European Parliament is also legislating at this session with the final approval of the Data Protection Regulation. This Parliament has therefore done its job. It is not true that Parliament has tried to unnecessarily delay a tool which is not the panacea – it has been reiterated – but which can be useful in ensuring a reasonable balance between freedom and security for the European citizens we represent.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – We are talking today about the storage and sharing of personal data for the security of EU citizens. I consider this directive to be the minimum we can do to improve safety.  Those who have been blocking the adoption of this directive, this minimum standard for safety, for 5 years, I would like to say to them that their reasons must be called by their real name. I respect them, don't vote for it, but don't say it's for personal safety, privacy reasons, because if you have any card you buy your train tickets on, you're putting your data at risk for a long time to companies that can use it. These are ideological reasons, and those who are serious about the protection and security of EU citizens must vote for the PNR.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, despite the expectations placed on it, PNR will unfortunately not be able to solve security problems on its own, it is only a step towards the creation of a common European framework for investigations and intelligence services.  We desperately need coordinated and comprehensive European instruments to counter the threat of terrorism, as we have seen the ineffectiveness of an exclusively national approach. I agree with the need, highlighted by my group, to vote on PNR together with the data protection package. I firmly believe that the exchange of personal data must be accompanied by the creation of a clear legal framework on their use.  The key thing is for national governments to take coordinated action to combat terrorism, some Member States need to overcome their selfishness and understand the need to fund European counter-terrorism bodies, to make better use of European tools for sharing vehicle registration details, fingerprints and DNA data and, of course, to strengthen Europol.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, in the previous debate we set out our views on the protection of personal data from powerful private interests. In the field of the public sphere, security should serve freedom. In this context, freedom cannot become a concept without content and cease to exist in the name of security and the state of emergency.  At this stage, while maintaining the core of individual rights, we must try to restore a balance between freedom and security. We must not assume that there is a dilemma between security and freedom, because security must always serve freedom.  Therefore, only under strict terms and conditions and subject to compliance with the principle of proportionality, measures may be taken to process personal data and I consider that these conditions are not only not respected, but are, on the contrary, circumvented by the PNR which, under the pretext of hitting terrorism, comes first for institutionalisation and appears as a panacea for dealing with jihadists who, in order to cease to pose a threat, must defeat Daesh in Syria.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: I am actually glad that we will finally be able to vote on PNR tomorrow, although I have to say honestly that I do feel that the mountain has given birth to an elephant.  Yes, it is good that passenger data is being exchanged, but I regret a little that it will be 28 databases, that the countries themselves can decide whether to share the data voluntarily and that this will not be compulsory. But so be it. Rome wasn't built in a day either! We will therefore vote with conviction tomorrow on the PNR and data protection files. But I have heard it many times today: if we think that PNR will be the panacea against terrorism, then we will have to endure a lot of attacks. We, colleagues of the Council, colleagues of the Commission, must focus on what we heard here yesterday in the debate: turn Europol into a real European FBI and do so now!

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – I believe that we need to think deeply about how we want to treat those who voted for us in the EP. Do we really want to choose to spy on them more, to store as much data as possible about them? Are they really potential criminals for all of us, so we have to follow their every move? Personally, I have more faith in our citizens, and I refuse to subject the peaceful majority to the treatment we set against individuals who refuse to comply with the rule of law. I don't know how you want to come before your constituents in three years and explain to them how you're going to vote tomorrow. It's clear to me that you're probably going to keep it quiet, but I find it all the more a very dirty game.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, even if we concede that the European passenger name record would not have prevented the deadly Brussels attack last month, there are strong arguments that showed that it could be one of the most effective instruments in our European security toolbox for averting the next attack in the future. The experience of the countries that use PNR data in the fight against drug and human trafficking and terrorism long ago demonstrated the advantages of proactive and real-time use of this instrument. This makes it all the more difficult to understand why this House has taken so long to vote on this directive. Although praising the way in which usefulness, proportionality and data protection concerns are reflected in the final text, I can only regret that the directive we vote on tomorrow does not include intra-EU flights, given the increased level of efficiency and security such a comprehensive approach would have had.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam President, those who think the PNR system will solve our security concerns are mistaken. PNR will be one good tool and I'll vote for, anyway. But in the end it will still be just one good tool and not much more than that. In fact, I'm advocating for something much more.  I am committed to the mandatory exchange of information, I am committed to creating a common European intelligence agency, I am committed to strengthening Europol. Far more than what's being talked about here in this room today as a lifeline for our security system, because the PNR won't be. Finally, I would like to stress the need for candidate countries from the Western Balkans to be included in this system once we adopt it.  The weapons come from the Western Balkans. In terrorist attacks, they used some devices from the Western Balkans. The Western Balkans must enter this system.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: – I support the directive on the use of HA data for the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of terrorist offences and serious criminal offences. I regret that we have not reached a consensus with all political groups in the past, because PNR is an important tool in the fight against terrorism. Although the fight against terrorism is primarily the responsibility of the Member States, I am an advocate of a common approach at European Union level. We must strengthen the security of our citizens and defend the fundamental values of freedom, democracy and human rights, and we therefore need swift, decisive and effective action. In doing so, of course, we must respect international law and treat private data with extreme care and sensitive.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: membre de la Commission. – Madame la Présidente, Madame la Ministre Hennis-Plasschaert, chers collègues. Madam President, thank you, first of all, for your views and comments. I am now looking forward to tomorrow’s vote. Let me reiterate that the PNR Directive is a key tool in our toolbox to enhance the safety and security of our citizens. The political compromise reached last December manages to find the right balance between security and fundamental rights. Concerns as to whether the directive will sufficiently ensure the exchange of information between Member States have been raised. I find that the directive now provides for the sharing of all relevant and necessary PNR data. We allow the law-enforcement authorities to judge what needs to be shared, while ensuring that strong data protection safeguards are in place. Mrs in ’t Veld submitted a request in March 2014 for access to these documents and she was given access. The Commission will of course provide, upon request, all available information on the implementation of the EU co-funded national PNR projects. I hope that Parliament will now act quickly so as to allow the entry into force of the directive as soon as possible. Once adopted, we need to immediately start its implementation. My commitment is to stand close to the Member States, to support and to urge them to implement this framework as soon as possible.

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I have little to add. Let me underline once more how grateful I am for Parliament’s support. As I said earlier there is no such thing as a single solution to stop the terrorist threat or organised crime. The PNR proposal does not represent a silver bullet. It is not a magic solution. It is an instrument. Surely it will be an important instrument, even if not perfect. It is a European solution, and a European solution is far better than a patchwork of 28 different systems on a national level.

name: Timothy KIRKHOPE
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I think this has been a very important debate and I am very grateful to all of those who contributed. Indeed, throughout the whole process of this Directive and the work on it, I have always been – and I think everyone would agree – not always in agreement with everybody, but certainly very willing to listen to the various suggestions that have been made, even for those who are quite sceptical of the proposals, and I thank them for their contribution today. I do just want to say that I hope that we will be able to get support tomorrow. I would urge people not to support the amendments that have been put down by Groups, because we are dealing with a package of measures here which I hope we can put through as they now are on the table. I think it is an important matter because my country, of course, is in the middle of a nationwide debate on why we should be members of the European Union. I make no apology to say that some of my constituents want more evidence of where there is added value. Frankly, this is timely. It may have taken five years, but our security and our cooperation in the fight against criminality is something that I strongly believe does add value to our membership. As has been said, it is not just a question of dealing with terrorists or threats of terrorism, important though that is; it is also dealing with all the other major criminal areas: people trafficking, child trafficking, trafficking in drugs, and all the other things that are so important that we should be working together to tackle them. So I am asking everybody to vote for this tomorrow, of course, but I think it will also give a message to our citizens that we really do care about them. We care about their security, we care about their privacy and, by doing it in a balanced way, I think we will restore some of the trust, which sometimes our institutions seem to have lost. We are doing the right thing and I hope we are making the right decision.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday 14 April 2016. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. – The collection of data provided by passengers is, in the Commission's view, a way of collecting data on individuals so that we can increase the safety of European citizens. However, systemic and general data collection can only be useful in ensuring security if there is a related obligation to cooperate and exchange relevant information. Without this obligation, the right to privacy is sacrificed without guaranteeing the security of citizens. "Those who are ready to give away their fundamental freedoms to buy crumbs of temporary security, deserve neither freedom nor security" Benjamin Franklin

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the PNR directive because it is an additional tool to secure the European Union in the current context. But this text alone will, unfortunately, remain insufficient to prevent atrocities on European soil. The NRL will only be effective if Member States exchange the crucial information that will emerge from national NRPs. This is a great challenge when we know, for example, how reluctant States are to feed Europol's databases on terrorism and "returnees". The 28 must intensify their efforts to make the exchange of information more effective in detecting suspected terrorists. We will therefore remain extremely attentive to the use and effectiveness of this famous PNR but also to the exchange of information because this is one of the keys to our security. Moreover, in terms of establishing a system that will collect a large number of personal data, we can only welcome the fact that this vote takes place at the same time as the vote on texts relating to the protection of personal data in order to guarantee respect for fundamental freedoms. At all times, it is necessary to ensure that a balance is maintained between the security of citizens and the preservation of their fundamental rights.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. – The recent terrorist attacks have shown that there is no freedom without security, and therefore everything must be done for the security of European citizens. A sense of security for European citizens must be re-established, which must mean very decisive, tough steps, coordinated European policing, intelligence and, not least, political action. This is why information sharing is needed, for example, through the Passenger Data Registration System (PNR). This is a way of preventing people from coming into Europe who have already been identified as potential terrorists somewhere, yet, by abusing the Schengen system, they can move freely in the Union. The compromise text was agreed as far back as December, but formal sanctity in the European Parliament has been awaiting it ever since because of the irresponsible play of left-wing parties. We hope that the left will finally understand that European citizens have a legitimate expectation among today's decision-makers to protect them and restore their sense of security. The European Passenger Data Registration System will help to do this.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. – The basic need of European citizens is safety and security. This is what our citizens ask from us all especially now, after the tragic terrorist attacks on Brussels and Paris. PNR is one of the basic security measures that are needed. All competent institutions, starting with Europol, have strongly advised to adopt it without delays. EPP has strongly supported adoption of PNR because it is considered to be one of elementary and effective measures to reduce and prevent terrorism, human trafficking and international crime. PNR does not mean that we compromise at the expense of privacy, because when boarding a plane we provide our basic data to the air companies anyway. It is truly regrettable that the liberal-leftist majority has delayed adoption of PNR for 5 years. We owe the directive in question to the victims of Paris and Brussels terrorist attacks and to prevent possible future victims. Sharing air passenger data with security services would help to track down potential terrorists. The EPP urges that PNR should be followed by the adoption of an ambitious plan on terrorism as soon as possible, preferably before the summer break.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. The debate on the passenger name register has been going on for years. The subject, certainly with delicate profiles, quickly became very topical following the recent terrorist attacks. How, in fact, can we ensure the proper security of our citizens with regard to fundamentalist violence, while maintaining, for the most part, our European way of life, made up of freedom, democracy and cultural diversity? Somewhat caricaturedly, there are those who wanted to tell of a phantom 'tug-of-war' between the Council of the EU and Parliament. In the Council, where national governments sit and to which citizens demanded rapid responses, a 'seuritarian' logic prevailed, driven by some Member States, whose priority was the sic et simpliciter adoption of PNR. This Parliament wanted to tie PNR closely to the issue of fundamental rights, including the right to privacy, because tying up the issues of the protection of fundamental rights and security is a choice of field, to ensure that our fellow citizens and our Europe do not renounce their fundamental values. If Europe is a community of values, under attack from various fronts, we cannot give in to those who, by not sharing them, resort to terrorism to sink them.

name: Algirdas SAUDARGAS
text: Writing. " The extremely rapid development of information technology has led to the fact that in virtual space our footprints are far more than we tend to think. We voluntarily agree to transfer personal data by registering on various portals, uploading photos and location on social networks. It is therefore paradoxical that, as citizens tend to share more and more private information publicly, left-wing parties have blocked for so many years a crucial initiative to collect data for people travelling within the EU, thereby ensuring the security of European citizens. It is clear that in the vortex of europe-crisis, it is no longer possible to reconcile the openness and security that has been fostered over the years. Therefore, although a person's privacy is an important value to be protected, it must not be a precondition for not taking action to address the fundamental problems arising from a lack of inter-agency or cross-border coordination. It was disappointing, however, that it took paris and brussels massacres to make some groups in Parliament realise that the defence of human rights begins with the creation of a safe environment. If we turn into a society of fear, it will only further strengthen the determination and confidence of the groups seeking western civilisation to destroy their goals. I therefore also support the consistent position of the European People's Group that the creation of a passenger data scoreboard will enable the fight against terrorism and organised crime in Europe to be combated more effectively.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. – In the current european security context, marked by instability, the Report on the Use of Passenger Name Record (PNR) data is absolutely necessary, as it has as its central objective the establishment of a mechanism to improve the security of citizens and EU Member States. The report, which represents a significant step in the fight against terrorism in Europe, establishes a legal framework for the protection and exchange of passenger name register data between Member States and responsible services. This data may only be used for the prevention and detection of terrorist offences and certain types of serious transnational offences and for carrying out relevant investigations and prosecutions. This list of crimes includes: terrorism, trafficking in human beings, sexual exploitation of children, trafficking in drugs, weapons, ammunition and explosives, money laundering and cybercrime. To this end, the report provides for the transfer by air carriers and economic operators other than air carriers (such as agencies and travel organisations) of data from the passenger files of international flights bound for or from the Member States, and the exchange of such data between those States and the Member States and Europol.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the council and Commission's statements on the 2015 Turkey Report (2015/2898 (RSP)).

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, the EU-Turkey relationship is of strategic importance, and we share a long-standing history of wide and deep cooperation. But just as we have many shared interests, we also face many common challenges. This has been particularly highlighted by the migration crisis, and President Tusk reported to you on this earlier today. As you know, accession negotiations are ongoing. We opened the latest chapter – Chapter 17 – in December last year and plan to open Chapter 33 with Turkey in the coming months. And let me underline that in this context, we continue to work within the framework of our existing rules for the accession process, by unanimity, sticking to strict but fair conditionality and without creating any shortcuts. From the Commission’s report it is clear that Turkey has registered progress in many fields of the acquis, and that is good news. It is, however, equally clear that many current domestic developments and worrying events in Turkey give cause for serious concern. Turkey needs to urgently remedy and address major shortcomings, notably in the areas of the rule of law and fundamental rights. The Council has called on Turkey to ensure full respect for human rights, in particular to take urgent steps to work on reversing the undermining of the independence and the impartiality of the judiciary and the significant backsliding in the area of freedom of expression and freedom of assembly. These are indeed important and pressing issues, which were also duly highlighted in your resolution. As reiterated by the European Council in March, we expect Turkey to respect the highest standards. In our contacts with Turkey we also take every opportunity to recall these concerns. We have also repeatedly called for a resumption of peace talks to end the violence in the south-east, thus pushing for a political solution to the Kurdish issue. Finally, I would like to welcome the renewed engagement of the parties to settling the Cyprus issue, and we continue to expect Turkey to actively support negotiations. Like you Members of Parliament, we hope that they will yield a fair, comprehensive and viable settlement.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, Minister, Honourable Members, let me begin by thanking the rapporteur on Turkey, Ms Kati Piri, for the high quality of the report we are discussing today. It addresses the key issues of EU-Turkey relations and generally concurs with the Commission’s findings in its 2015 enlargement package and the report on Turkey. In the current context of the migration and refugee crisis, the geopolitical situation in the region and many interests jointly shared by the EU and Turkey, it is crucial to further reinvigorate and strengthen our cooperation with this strategic partner. Naturally our relations have recently focused on the migration challenge, but they do and should continue to encompass a much broader range of issues to enable us to tap the full potential of this relationship. The re-energised accession process remains the core of our relations. We share your hope that the opening of chapters will lead to concrete progress in Turkey. In line with the EU-Turkey agreement of 18 March, the Commission is currently working on a proposal to the Council to open accession negotiations on financial and budgetary provisions. We are also preparing for the opening of further chapters, including in crucial areas of the judiciary and fundamental rights, as well as justice, freedom and security. We are doing this without prejudice to the positions of Member States and in accordance with the negotiating framework. In this context, the Commission is encouraged by the progress in the Cyprus settlement talks and we look forward to their successful and swift conclusion. We count on Turkey’s lasting and concrete contribution to such a comprehensive settlement. It would be very good news for Europe and for the security and stability of the region and would also contribute to a major turning point for our accession negotiations with Turkey. Let me also thank you for your strong support for structured and more frequent high-level dialogues. The recent high-level political dialogue and high-level energy dialogue have proved to be successful formats to move forward with our joint agenda with Turkey. A high-level economic dialogue on 25 and 26 April will increase EU-Turkey business contacts and will allow an open discussion on macroeconomic issues, economic policy and investment opportunities. As already discussed in the morning, our comprehensive cooperation agenda with Turkey on migration has started to produce the first results towards achieving our goal of ending the irregular migration from Turkey to the EU and breaking the pattern of refugees and migrants risking their lives. The Commission shares the European Parliament’s concern about respect for the rule of law and fundamental freedoms in Turkey. These concerns have been exacerbated by recent worrying developments, including those targeting the freedom of speech of academics, trials of prominent journalists and decisions affecting private assets in the media sector. We have repeatedly called on the Turkish Government to re-engage in reforms in line with European standards and to actively consult all stakeholders. We believe that defining the opening benchmarks and working with Turkey towards the opening of Chapters 23 and 24 will significantly contribute to Turkey’s renewed commitment and the reform efforts in these fields. The European Union also continues to voice its concerns about the serious situation in the south-east of Turkey. A genuine political dialogue in the framework of the Kurdish settlement process is the only way to achieve a peaceful and sustainable solution. The Union remains ready to support such a process. To conclude, the Commission is fully confident about the benefits of the increased cooperation with Turkey to address the immigration crisis and to deepen our relations in many other areas.

name: Kati PIRI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. –  Madam President, today the EU and Turkey are facing many of the same challenges. Think about the refugee crisis, the threat of terrorism, and a long-lasting conflict in Syria that creates instability. One thing that has been made clear through these challenges is that Turkey and the EU need each other to find solutions to combat these issues. However, and I want to stress this, we cannot turn a blind eye to the internal developments in the country. Turkey must be stable and more democratic if we want it to be a strategic partner we can build on. Linking the accession process to migration cooperation is neither wise nor fair. Accelerating talks should depend on the pace of the reforms, not on a political tit-for-tat. A lot has already been said this morning on the EU-Turkey deal, so I will just briefly say: the Turkish population has been hosting three million refugees. Many European countries could learn from the hospitality shown in this regard by the Turks. But Turkey is reaching its limits, and it is time that the EU really reached out to help by providing large-scale resettlement of refugees to EU countries. That is genuine burden-sharing; that is genuine cooperation. Many chances to further connect and work together have been missed in recent years. Let our current talks on migration lead to a more intensified and honest dialogue. This means that genuine concerns should not be taken as insults. The situation in the south-east of the country is of great concern to this Parliament. The EU urges that the peace process be relaunched as there is no military solution to the Kurdish question. The current status quo is unacceptable. While we deeply regret the return to violence by the PKK and strongly condemn the attacks against security forces and civilians, we stress, however, that anti-terrorism measures taken by the government must be proportionate and in line with international law. The 400 000 citizens who had to flee their houses because of the violence and the 24-hour curfews in many Kurdish-populated cities have put a very heavy toll on the livelihood of ordinary people. We believe that Turkey has to return to a path where journalists are not imprisoned for doing their jobs and censorship does not become an instinct for journalists. Turkey has to return to a path where academics are not losing their jobs and put in jail for expressing their views. Finally, Turkey has to return to a path where judges do not hesitate to decide and to give a verdict out of fear of being displaced or fired. We need a more stable and democratic Turkey. This is not a threat but an encouragement. It is important that Turkey returns to the path of democratic reforms and grasps this opportunity of closer engagement with the EU. Finally, let me also thank my colleagues and co-rapporteurs for the good cooperation. I hope that we can send a strong signal from this Parliament with this resolution. (The speaker agreed to take a blue card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: "blue card" question. Madam President, I expect the rapporteur of the report to tell us clearly whether she feels that the European Union is to blame for the fact that Turkey's accession process is not progressing.
