Because Turkey is essentially refusing to implement and implement, not now that the refugee issue exists but for years, the prerequisites to the European Union itself. Because it actually wants to be a member of the European Union, compared to all the other countries - and those within the European Union and those that are candidates for membership - which necessarily meet all the criteria.  And lastly, is it possible for the rapporteur to say that other chapters still need to be opened today without Turkey complying with the prerequisites?

name: Kati PIRI
text: blue-card answer. – It is clear that it would be too harsh to say that it is because of the EU that the process is not accelerating. First of all, the responsibility lies clearly with the Turkish Government. It is a merit-based process, but we must judge Turkey the same way we also judge other candidate countries. I have to say there have certainly been political differences at play here, with some political parties and politicians in Europe not always treating Turkey fairly based on the reforms in the country.

name: Renate SOMMER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would like to thank the rapporteur, Kati Piri, for the cooperation and also the rapporteurs from the other groups. We had agreed to be largely guided by last year's resolution, which was essentially successful and which simplified the negotiations somewhat. That is why I do not understand, Kati, that you now only want to keep a certain agreement when the PPE-DE takes over the Socialists' voting list as its own. This is not being done, and the PPE-DE cannot be put under pressure, either by another group or by a wave of refugees. Our task here is to use this resolution to assess Turkey's internal state, with a view to bringing the country closer to the European Union. We must not mix this up with the refugee crisis, however difficult it is. It is therefore important for us to emphasise that there can be no discounts for Turkey. This applies to visa liberalisation, for which all the conditions must still be met. The opening of negotiating chapters must, of course, continue to be linked to Turkey's fulfilment of the relevant conditions. The country is a long way from that: freedom of the press and freedom of expression, freedom of assembly severely restricted, state interference in the judiciary, Kurdish conflict, escalation of violence in the south-east – in fact, only regression. If we want to continue to be good and reliable neighbours in the future, if we want to continue to develop our special neighbourly cooperation, then we must once again talk to each other and also negotiate. But this will only be possible if Turkey takes the European path again. And, of course, the chapters relating to the Republic of Cyprus can never be opened before a solution to the Cyprus question. Turkey must play a more constructive role in this. It must finally recognise the Republic of Cyprus and help it to develop into a reunited state on the basis of European values and principles. This is also in the Turkish interest.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr Piri, thanks for this report, which once again shows how detrimental Erdogan's authoritarian attitude is for Turkey and for the European Union. I have long expressed concern in this House about the treatment of journalists, the disregard for freedom of expression, the human rights situation. And we're only seeing the situation deteriorate! In the most recent index for press freedom of reporters without borders, Turkey is ranked 148th out of 180 places. The peace process with the Kurds has been abandoned and turned into blind state terror. Madam Minister, I hear you say that you have expressed your concern and that you have asked for the resumption of peace negotiations. You ask, but what do you get? What did you get? Nothing!  The southeast of Turkey is a war zone. Turkey plays an ambiguous role in the fight against IS. The government did not make sufficient efforts to prevent foreign fighters, money or equipment from reaching Syria. Meanwhile, Turks are attacking Kurdish fighters all the more eagerly.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner, you have just said that there are advantages of increased cooperation with Turkey. My group sees it the same way. We are just not sure whether these benefits can be achieved through an accession process that has been described as 'zombie'. He has come to a standstill, he is actually dead. There is virtually no one who still seriously and honestly believes that Turkey can one day join the European Union. What we need instead is a positive agenda based on respect for Turkey and realpolitik. And there are so many fields in which we could actually achieve a great deal through good cooperation with Turkey. Whether this is the refugee issue, energy cooperation, cultural exchange, people-to-people contacts, tourism, trade – there are endless fields in which we can achieve success with this great, important neighbour, a neighbour who is entitled to respectful treatment. But if you are already saying here that you are making a proposal for the opening of further chapters, so to speak without prejudice to the positions of certain member states, and at the same time we know that there will be no openings without a consensus of the Member States, then it is clear from the outset that a failed process is being desperately maintained here, that there is a lack of courage here. to create a new basis for good relations with Turkey. Since we have been negotiating with Turkey – it is now eleven years – relations between the country and the European Union have not improved, they have deteriorated considerably, and have done so considerably. Some of them are even poisoned. Please take the behaviour of the Turkish President towards the German comedian Jan Böhmermann. This is absolutely impossible behaviour, which shows that Turkey cannot cope at all with the set of values of artistic freedom, freedom of the press and freedom of expression. So, if we take a step forward, we have the courage to break new ground! Let us treat Turkey sensibly and create a respectful and positive agenda, but let us leave this accession process, which will not lead to any objective.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Kati Piri, on her excellent and productive cooperation throughout the discussions. I think, at the same time, that the situation in Turkey far outweighs the debate we are having here on the report. A report which, to a great many, reflects reality.  There are already around 300,000 displaced people in southeastern Turkey. Much of the city of Sor has been completely abandoned. Much of it has been confiscated, expropriated. In fact, they took the fortunes of 60,000 people. Academics and journalists are prosecuted simply for speaking freely. On 22 April, a week from now, these people are being tried in Istanbul and I have already been asked by the accused to attend and watch the trial as observers.  We call on Turkey to immediately enter into a dialogue to resolve the Kurdish issue and to stop persecuting freedom of expression. Deleting and deleting the PKK from the European Union's list of terrorist organisations will help.  The report contains very positive reports on the Cyprus issue, including the report that the solution will be an evolution of the Republic of Cyprus. So far, however, it contains at least indirect reports of the opening of funds, which we disagree with, since Turkey has not implemented any obligations it has undertaken.  On the Cyprus issue, while positive reports are welcomed by Turkish officials, we are obliged to say that these reports have not been translated into action at the negotiating table. We expect, immediately, a map of the territorial, which will also facilitate the resolution of the asset. I believe that Turkey faces many challenges and our aim is to provide all assistance to the Turkish people.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I would have liked to have been able to stand here today and praise developments in Turkey. I would have liked to have been able to say that democratic development is on the right track. I would have liked to have said that freedom of the press, freedom of expression, the independence of the courts and human rights are generally respected. I would have liked to have said that Turkey's path to EU membership is without stones on the way to stumble over. I would have liked to have been able to say that the peace negotiations with the Kurds went well and that there is peace in sight. Unfortunately, I can't say anything like that. Instead, most things go in the wrong direction. It is extremely tragic, especially for all those democrats in Turkey who, against all odds, stand up for democracy, the human rights of all, peace and justice. This year's resolution is highly critical of the development in Turkey of virtually all rights. It also very clearly calls on both parties to stop acts of violence and to return to peace negotiations. Today, one party is building palaces, while the other is imprisoned and isolated since 1999. Abdullah Öcalan has not met his family since October 2015 and not his lawyer since July 2011. His correspondence has been completely blocked since April 2015. According to several UN envoys, it constitutes cruel, inhuman or disparaging treatment that may constitute torture. That is why we greens are proposing to put an end to Öcalan's isolation.

name: James CARVER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, the question over Turkey highlights precisely how far the European Union will go in the name of its neo-colonialist ambitions. For all the posturing over your defence of democracy, human rights and the freedom of press around the world, you have hugely contradicted yourselves with the renewed prospects of Turkey’s EU membership at the very moment that concerns regarding the backsliding of these issues have reached their height. To top it all you have used taxpayers’ money to effectively bribe Turkey into accepting your disastrous asylum policy. That the EU is willing to consider even opening up negotiations on the future accession of Turkey underlines how you are carrying on with business as usual, whilst doing an excellent impression of an ostrich with its head in the sand. Last week the Dutch effectively rejected EU expansion in their own referendum and, as British public support for Brexit increases, polls in Denmark show that, if the UK leaves, a majority of Danish people will want likewise. All this at the very time of the ongoing crisis over the eurozone, the Schengen area and migration. Further enlargement of the EU is a threat to my country, so accordingly the only way to ensure British security is to vote to leave on 23 June.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this report is a masterpiece of hypocrisy, it would like to hide the rules documented also by the speeches that have been made about the difficulties that objectively stand in the way of Turkey's entry into the European Union, through the emphasis and even praise of Turkey's behaviour, which would be hosting the largest number of refugees in the world.  However, the report does not take account of the way in which and also of what nature the hospitality processes are and, above all, the practices of mass refoulement denounced at this very hour by Amnesty International. There is a question that arises at this point: is Turkey to be considered a safe country for refugees? And another question: this principle of refoulement, which the European Union has so often applied to those in Italy, Greece and France who posed problems with the influx and perhaps even the invasion of illegal immigrants, does not apply to Turkey?  You do not care that the principle of refoulement is applied in turkey on a mass basis, and that is a fundamental contradiction which shows how crazy this fine idea of the agreement with Turkey is. At this point, it seems clear to me that we need to reject visa liberalisation, as we do, and to call for verification of Turkey's real commitment to the fight against foreign fighters and to put an end to ambiguities about Turkey's relations with Isis.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I really wonder: what does Turkey have in blackmailing the EU in this way? You yourself have drawn up a catalogue of fundamental rights here, and this no longer applies to Turkey. In Turkey, it is commonplace for Christian churches to be desecrated, for buildings to be confiscated by Christian communities. The murder of three Christians in Malatya in 2007 has not yet been punished, although the five perpetrators are known. Turkey is fighting the Kurds on Syrian territory. It is violating Syrian sovereignty, and European states are training Kurdish Peshmerga fighters. The same Kurds are being killed again by the Turkish air force, and you are simply saying that we should continue accession negotiations and that economic dialogue must be stepped up! Can such a country be a partner of the EU in the future, where it is revealed that ISIS has been increasingly supplied with arms from Turkey, that Turkish reporters have unmasked it and now have to answer in court for this unmasking? How can you seriously negotiate with such a partner? Turkey is not part of Europe!

name: Manolis KEFALOGIANNIS
text: Madam President, one cannot be entirely satisfied with such a difficult report and for such a problematic country. But, as chairman of the European Union-Turkey Joint Committee, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Piri, the party rapporteurs, Mrs Sommer, on the truly professional work they have done, within the framework of the principles and values of the European Union, with a sense of responsibility.  Of course, the report mentions many of the policy deficits that Turkey has. Turkey must respect the sovereign rights of neighbouring countries, ratify the Law of the Sea of 1982, which is the only acceding country that has not ratified it, lift the threat of war on Greece, stop violations of the airspace and territorial waters of neighbouring countries, recognise the universality of the patriarchy and the functioning of Halki , change its tragic policy, with many victims in south-eastern Turkey and, of course, the funds will not be opened unless it confirms the European acquis and the principles governing the European Union.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Madam President, I will start by thanking Kati Piri for such a comprehensive and very well-organised report. I will just emphasise some of the most important points in my view. I will start by saying that today we shall assess the stalemate on Turkish accession to the EU, which unfortunately has also contributed to the slowdown in the pace of the reforms and progress on the rule of law and fundamental rights in Turkey. I am deeply worried about the serious deterioration in freedom of speech, expression and opinion in the country in the last two years. Therefore, I strongly encourage, yet again, the Council and the Commission to open Chapters 23 and 24. Simultaneously, I urge Turkey to continue the reform process to resolve outstanding bilateral issues with its neighbours and to play a constructive role in the Cyprus negotiations. The success of these negotiations is important for the EU and, I believe, also for Turkey. Second, there is no doubt about the necessity of deepening our cooperation with Turkey in order to solve the current refugee and migration crisis. This being said, I have an important concern about certain aspects of the latest EU—Turkey deal. Last, but not least, I would like to express my condolences and support to all Turkish people and the authorities in fighting terrorism. For some of my colleagues, I will remind them of the wisdom of my people: God give me the words to hide my intention.

name: Bas BELDER
text: – The rapporteur rightly refers in paragraph 30 to the mysterious violent phenomenon of the Esedullah teams, the 'lions of Allah'. It also calls on the Turkish authorities to carry out a thorough investigation into the serious human rights violations of which the 'lions of Allah' are accused in the south-east of the country. I fear that this request will never be granted by President Erdogan. Because inquiries by insiders yesterday and today provided me with a plausible explanation for the esedullah's right to exist. They must protect President Erdogan from all domestic dangers. Not only for the PKK, but also for a possible army coup. That's Turkey in 2016! Meanwhile, I am reaching out to poignant first-hand reports about defenceless Syrian and Iraqi Christian refugees in Turkey, at the mercy of Sunni tormentors! They are desperately trying to leave Turkey to finally be safe. Such distressing situations, Madam President, expose the ethical pain points in EU-Turkey relations.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: – Madam President, our vote on the annual report on Turkey comes at a new low point. The text that we are going to adopt is more critical on the rule of law, press freedom, the separation of powers as well as the violence in the south-east. And frankly, we are seeing a pattern that has become predictable but no less concerning, and it frankly seems like we are the only politicians and the only EU institution that is clearly and vocally speaking out. It is very problematic that the European Commission and the Council have halted their agendas, that the Commission delayed its publication of the annual report and that there has been a deafening silence when it comes to human rights violations in Turkey recently. We saw Vice-President Timmermans rushing to shake hands with President Erdoğan eight days before critical elections, and I would actually like to see him participate in a debate on Turkey in this House. It is key that the Council does not outsource its responsibilities on asylum and consider hope a strategy and hope that Turkey will solve its problems. The deal on migration has been a toxic one, and I am afraid we have paid the highest price – the price of our credibility, of our principles and of our words. We are clear in our report on what needs to be done, and I hope the Commission and the Council will change their course.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the progress report captures the reality in Turkey with such apocalyptic realism for the first time. And this is credited to Mrs. Piri and those of us involved in the process.  I stress two points: you are calling on Turkey to negotiate a comprehensive and sustainable solution to the Kurdish problem. But as long as the European Union calls the PKK a terrorist organisation and is part of the solution, it legitimises Turkey's clearing operations, even inside Syria. You welcome the joint agreement on refugees and NATO's involvement in the Aegean. Again, the European Union deliberately engages third parties in matters concerning it, citing weakness. The next one concerns the involvement of the IMF. The results will be just as devastating for the people. Where Nato is involved, it exacerbates tensions.  I close with a question: what accession process can there be with a country, as described in the report, which in addition tramples on international law and the agreements it signs?

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: – Madam President, we clearly support Mrs Piri's critical, necessarily critical report and therefore also support the opening of Chapters 23 and 24. That is where the European Union must assert its reasons. Turkey is Europe and Europe is incomplete without Turkey, despite the walls that continue to rise and despite the current undemocratic drift of the Turkish authorities. But it is true that the accession process is being negatively contaminated with the issue of refugees. Worse, Turkey is using this issue as a political exchange commodity. That is why — and also for other reasons, but certainly for that reason — I am against an agreement which this Parliament has not been able to discuss or, therefore, approve or reject. And that is why the practice we see in Turkey today of expelling or returning citizens who have just escaped the war to Syria is also unacceptable. And so we cannot ignore the situation in the Kurdish territories. We have to get back to the peace process. The PKK must show its availability to abandon violent practice and the Government must lift the siege and reopen the dialogue that was interrupted after last June's elections. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: "blue card" question. – I would like to ask my colleague why he will make us forget geography here, too, how it turns out that Turkey is a European country.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: "blue card" response. – Yes, mate. You can look back on history and look in all directions at the map of Europe and you will see that I am right, that Turkey is Europe. That Turkey can and should be Europe and that history fills us with reasons, examples and arguments for this reality. And geography, even more. And today's political strategy, even more so. The role Turkey is playing on the issue of the Syrian conflict is a reason. If there were no others already, it would suffice on its own to consider it as a country, as a society. We must distinguish between the royal country and the official country. The official country we don't like and the real country is Europe.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The report on Turkey contains a lot of facts that call into question the country's current leadership – not to mention its suitability as a candidate country. We can read in the report that Turkey's positive development has stalled, particularly with regard to fundamental aspects of democracy, such as the rule of law, freedom of expression and freedom of assembly. We can read about how the leaders of Turkey have created a constitution that establishes a parliamentary threshold of as much as 10%. This shows that Turkey is a country with clear authoritarian tendencies. Furthermore, it is clear that Turkey is playing a very high and risky game in its foreign and security policy. In their eagerness to relive old Ottoman great power ambitions, they have thrown themselves into the deadly machinations of the Middle East. Turkey has interfered in the conflict in Syria, and many also claim – legitimately or not – that Turkey is playing under the table with killer groups such as al-Nusra and Isis. To top it off, Turkey has managed to push for extremely favourable agreements with the EU on the issue of migrants.

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: – Once again this Parliament is coming up with a nonsense report on Turkey and this time too it can go straight to waste! Turkey has supported AND earned a lot of money from IS. Turkey has sent migrants to the EU and made a big living from them.  The Turkish Government is committing crimes against humanity by genocide against the Kurdish population. The Turkish government is silencing any opposition to its radical Islamic agenda. The country is sliding hard into an Islamic dictatorship. The Sultan of Ankara is accelerating the Islamisation of the EU. Grey wolves demonstrate in the squares of our capitals, mosques call for hatred against our state and culture, migrants militantly engulf our villages and towns. I say to the Commission: no accession negotiations, no visa-free travel, no money to this corrupt clique! Turkey must never become a member of the European Union!

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Madam President, the name 'progress report for Turkey' alone is unfortunate and shows that European politicians are embellishing reality and wanting to serve Turkish interests. Turkey has not made progress in any area. On the contrary, it always remains an arrogant state, far from any sense of respect for its neighbours, with complete disregard for international law.  We are all well aware that the Turkish Government has supported the criminals of the Islamic Caliphate, that it has continued for 42 years to illegally own part of Cyprus and every day makes territorial claims against Greece. On the issue of migration, on the same day that 150 migrants were repatriated to Turkey, 600 arrived on the Greek islands. Turkey is "turning a blind eye" or cooperating with slave traders.  And one of these actions would be enough to interrupt any thought of cooperating with this state for a long time. On the contrary, however, the Union insists on treating Turkey as a strategic partner with a regime that imprisons anyone who dares to challenge it. Lately, in fact, he has decided to drag journalists from other countries to court if they dare to satirize the "great sultan" Erdogan, with the support of Chancellor Merkel, of course, who probably thought there were many Turkish voters in Germany.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Madam President, I support the Turkey progress report. The time has come to recognise Turkey’s role in receiving three million refugees with dignity. At the same time we should continue to raise our concerns on freedom of expression, an independent judiciary and the rule of law, as well as the humanitarian situation and a disproportionate military reaction in the south-east. Both sides must lay down weapons and return to the negotiating table. I also welcome the EU action plan with Turkey and the disbursement of EUR 95 million. This should benefit the refugees. Implementation should be according to international standards and the principle of non-refoulement. Asylum seekers must be evaluated on a human, legally-certain and individual basis and Turkey should be listed as a safe country of return. I also welcome the fact that the accession process finally is back on track. The best way to boost democratic reforms is by opening chapters with a European perspective. It is not a trade-off, it is win-win.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: – Madam President, this report deliberately does not endorse the EU/Turkey refugee deal. For the EU to be party to arrangements described by the UN Refugee Agency as illegal may be contested, but it is deeply worrying. It is right for Europe to seek to cooperate with Turkey and all countries neighbouring Syria in this humanitarian cause of refugees, but clearly only if it encompasses full respect for international humanitarian law. Europe can never be silenced in criticisms on democracy and human rights in return for cooperation on migration. I saw the siege of Sur in southeast Turkey for myself a month ago. Fight terrorism with our support, but not your own people. Lift the curfews. Allow innocent civilians to be evacuated and bodies to be buried. Most of all, return to a Kurdish peace process. Do not prosecute journalists because they publish stories you do not like or protest against the British Consul attending their court hearing, because surely you should have nothing to hide. Do not accuse free academics of being terrorists and then have your Ministry of Justice say those accused of terrorism can have their nationality removed. It is a direct defiance of Article 15 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. To those on the other side who still oppose the opening of EU negotiating chapters with Turkey on justice and human rights, understand how short-sighted are your arguments and that if Turkey should avoid hypocrisy, so should we.

name: Amjad BASHIR
text: – Madam President, I cannot imagine anyone who has been in negotiations where they have asked someone for help who was then surprised when the other party asked for something back. This appears to be what is happening with Turkey, and it seems to have taken many colleagues by surprise. Ideally, I would also prefer to isolate issues from one another. However, we must also be realistic. Turkey plays a crucial role geopolitically in the region and we need its help to tackle systematic issues which are of enormous concern to everyone, from the immigration package to accession talks in general. This makes some overlap almost inevitable, but it is not necessarily something we should be afraid of. Whilst we must be careful not to give Turkey a free pass, enhanced cooperation in critical areas, from the fight against terrorism to the migrant crisis, should be seen as an opportunity to breathe life into our relationship instead of being seen as a step backwards.

name: Nedzhmi ALI
text: – Madam President, regarding the 2015 report on Turkey, we can underline a number of developments concerning the state of play in EU-Turkey relations: cooperation on migration, the internal situation, and the progress on the Cyprus reunification talks. The report welcomes the reinvigoration of the accession process, expresses the hope of opening new negotiation chapters when the benchmarks are met, and supports a structured and more frequent high-level dialogue on thematic issues. During 2015 Turkey’s security situation deteriorated. Where the economic criteria are concerned Turkey is well advanced, but the external and internal imbalances should be corrected. In the current geopolitical situation, the 2015 report on Turkey draws special attention to EU-Turkey cooperation on migration. Despite the significant challenges of the migration issue, we should proceed faster with the planned activities for mutually-beneficial and pragmatic cooperation with Turkey. We welcome the progress made concerning the Cyprus reunification talks that will lead to positive outcomes for both communities on the island. As an overall assessment, despite a number of shortcomings, we can see clear signals that the accession process is moving forward.

name: Julia REID
text: – Madam President, Turkish accession to the EU is important in its own right but is especially so now in the light of the UK referendum. Immigration alone makes this a contentious issue as Turkey, which has been trying to join the EU for many years, is allowing Erdoğan to blackmail the EU into accelerating the process. Turkey is not even part of Europe. Ninety-seven per cent of it is in Asia, and although like us it has a history that shares the glories of Greece, Rome and the Italian Renaissance, it is not part of European culture. Under Atatürk Turkey became a secular nation, but more recently it has been moving towards Islamism as it was practised in the 6th century. Does the EU really want Turkey as a member? What will accession mean? We do not even know for certain what the true population is – figures range from 75 to 79 million. Turkey is also home to millions of refugees who could, in the future, be given a Turkish passport. When Turkey becomes a member of the EU all these people will have the right to come to Britain. Labour, Lib Dems, Greens and Conservatives all support Turkey’s entry and, incidentally, the Tories are members of the Alliance of European Conservatives and Reformists, a pan-European party in which one of the members is Erdoğan’s own Justice and Development Party. Turkish membership alone is a big reason for the British to vote to leave on 23 June.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Madam President, this is a lucid report. He is telling truths about dictator Erdogan, he acknowledges that the Union has turned a blind eye to fundamental rights in Turkey and this, for a cooperation to say the least problematic, let's face it. One could therefore expect an immediate halt to accession negotiations. No! This report even proposes a relaunch of the process.  Colleagues, do you want a political Islam in Europe - in fact, the spread of Islamism? I'm afraid I'm afraid. You are faced, in fact, with the truth of a terrorist regime, logistical and financial support of Daesh, with the truth of a forced partnership imposed by the Americans to "otanize" NATO even more, with the truth of a mafia regime that practices racketeering against migrants and European institutions. And, in the face of these truths, you have chosen to lie, out of weakness, out of cowardice in the face of a master singer whom you have already made your sultan against our Europe, that of the peoples you have betrayed.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: – Madam President, we want it or not, Turkey is our neighbour, it will be one in the future. What is more normal than seeking good neighbourly, mutually beneficial relations? A good neighbor respects the commitments made – respects human rights, media freedom, does not react with aggression to any criticism.  I expect Turkey to abide by the agreement reached on migrants and not allow the creation of new migration routes after the restriction of the current Balkan route. This time it is also in our interest to support the European path of Turkish civil society and to develop mutually beneficial relations in the economy, energy, tourism, culture, etc. Respect for their rights requires access to bulgarian language training, Bulgarian media and freedom of self-determination without the threat of repression. Turkey should also influence Azerbaijan to find a peaceful solution to the re-emerging conflict around Karabakh.  (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: a question asked by raising a blue card. – Dear Colleague, how would you comment on Turkey's compliance with the agreement in the fact that last night alone our border police captured 97 illegal immigrants who had crossed from the Turkish side to Bulgarian? This is my first question, and the second is how will you comment on Turkey's unacceptable interference in our internal affairs through the engineering of Bulgarian political projects inside Bulgaria?

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: answer a question asked by raising a blue card. – Mr. Dzhambazki, it has always been the policy of the neighbors, to have their own intelligence and curlers or tools for influence in neighboring countries, it is also the job of our services and our political elite to oppose such interventions, be it from Turkey, be it from Russia or wherever. As regards compliance with the agreement, I said this to her in my speech, I expect Turkey to seriously prevent the emergence of a new route in the Balkans.

name: Miltiadis KYRKOS
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Kati Piri, because the situation she gave us in the report is absolutely accurate. For us, this annual report is not an opportunity to blame Turkey, and the point that there is a setback in matters of democracy, freedom of expression and the press, justice and religious freedoms takes its true meaning, not only if it triggers a deep debate with both the Turkish Government and civil society, which , reluctantly now, continues to have as its vision European integration.  But, at last, a political solution must go ahead in Kurdish, with a unilateral ceasefire and a simultaneous end to police operations before acts such as the lifting of parliamentary immunity promoted by the government lead to even worse days.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: "Let's close our eyes, imagine the map after Turkey's entry into the European Union. Well, our neighbours, our neighbours, are Iraq, Iran, Syria. Isn't that a fascinating neighborhood?  Dear! I would like us to avoid such double standards in this discussion. Because if the same politicians who have said over the years that we should not let Turkey into the European Union, or even approach it, because human rights are not respected there, and the same politicians are suddenly silent about these human rights, because you have to sign refugee agreements quickly with Turkey, because there are local elections in one of the big countries of the European Union. , but this is an example of some hypocrisy. I would like us to talk about Turkey in a certain perspective and not under pressure from current political events. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card question. – Madam President, the other issue that nobody speaks about in this Chamber, with the possibility of eventual Turkish EU membership, is the shift in the dynamics of the politics of this Chamber. Were Turkey to join the European Union, with a population of, say, 77 million – if we take the estimates and start in the middle – they would have the largest number of MEPs. The existing Member States would have even less representation. Is that not another reason why Turkey should be kept out of the European Union? Because the main players – and indeed the smaller players – within the European Union would have even less democratic ability to represent their citizens.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – I understand that my esteemed speaker has stated that the European Parliament is not made of rubber, it will not stretch, it will continue to have the same number of members, so it will be difficult to maintain the same number of representatives for each country. Yes, this will, of course, mean a decrease in the number of members from individual countries that have hitherto been in the European Union – it is clear, we have adopted the principle that we do not leave above 751 members.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Yes, we are talking today about the European Union's new best friend, Turkey. After the refugee deal, the next step is visa-free travel, and then accession to the EU is required. There is no one among Europe's neighbours who tramples on freedom of expression, freedom of the press, freedom of assembly, women's rights, the rights of the Kurds, the rights of Christians, as much as President Erdogan, and there is no one to whom we have surrendered ourselves as much as to this Mr Erdogan.  All the big-headed people agree – especially Mrs Merkel – that we should now seek the salvation of the EU in bringing the EU closer to Turkey. Everyone agrees: we can do it. For this, Turkey should only – please, please – do the dirty work, which has become all the more important because of Mrs Merkel's open borders.  The President who, I repeat, tramples on freedom of expression, freedom of the press, freedom of assembly, women's rights, the rights of Christians, the rights of the Kurds more than anyone else, or even more so, who is fighting them with brutal police violence, who is waging war in his country against his own people and in his neighbouring country, this man is now seen as the saviour of the EU. Is this not the ultimate oath of revelation by the European Union? How has it always been said about a crisis: we need "more EU"! And now it is no longer working with 'more EU', and now it is said to the crisis: we need 'more Turkey'. It's creepy.  Anyone who opens the EU's doors to Turkey is softening European values. I quote Mr Erdogan: 'Democracy is only the train we are on until we reach our destination. The mosques are our barracks, the minarets our bayonets, the domes our helmets and the believers our soldiers."  Let's wake up before it's too late! The accession negotiations between the EU and Turkey are not interrupted, they have been broken off. Good relations with Turkey yes, accession no.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: Mr President, because Turkey buys oil from Islamic State refineries, because Turkey has reportedly supplied the same Islamic State with materials necessary for the development of sarin gas, because Turkey prefers to bomb Kurdish rebels rather than jihadists from the Al-Nusra Front and Islamic State, because Turkey allows migrants on its soil to enter the Schengen area illegally. , for all these reasons, it is unacceptable to liberalise the visas of Turkish nationals coming to Europe, just as it is unacceptable to pay an additional EUR 3 billion to Turkey. But, above all, it would be truly suicidal to continue negotiations on Turkey's accession to the European Union.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: – I highly value Turkey as our nato ally. I appreciate Turkey's initiatives in dealing with the refugee issue. It is because of this cooperation that I am protesting against the violence that Turkey is committing against the Kurds. They do so on the territory of Turkey, let us recall the destruction of the city of Cizre. It is bombing Kurdish camps in Iraq, supporting an IS attack on the town of Kobani in Syria. The Kurdish PKK party, whose terror I reject, is also developing a spiral of mutual hatred. But often Kurdish terror is a response to the terror of the Turkish armed forces.  I understand that Turkey's national policy has changed in recent decades. Turkey, for example, no longer calls kurds Mountain Turks, Kurds have representation in the Turkish parliament. The Turkish public is beginning to look at historical tragic events and Turkish nationalism, such as the public remembrance of the Armenian genocide. The commemorion will take place next week in Istanbul.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The settlement of relations with Turkey is one of the most important tasks of the present Commission. It is of fateful importance, full of opportunities and opportunities, dangers and risks. There are many things that cause concern, such as the Kurdish question. The current government believes that it can solve this by using force and that it has a carte blanche to do so. After years of talks and rapprochement, we are now back in civil war- That cannot be in our interest. The report also makes these developments very clear. Europe should also try to play a role as a mediator in this situation. The model could be the peace agreement in Northern Ireland, where all the parties to the conflict have also come to the table, including those who were initially classified as terrorists at the time.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: Mr President, both the report and many colleagues clearly say that Turkey cannot become a member of the European Union, despite the supposedly positive developments in cyprus. Where, of course, this is a mistake, Commissioner Hahn, the European Parliament will also make a major mistake if it becomes complicit in proceedings that promote Turkish aggression against the Republic of Cyprus and overturn decisions by itself, the Commission and the Council. If you believe that a solution is imminent, I declare that a solution at this time means the dissolution of the Republic of Cyprus. Because the bi-social bi-community federation and the principles and values of the European Union and human rights are incompatible terms. Instead of defending the Republic of Cyprus, the European Parliament rejects amendments that support it, in the logic of the forthcoming solution and the late Republic of Cyprus. Even the Minister did not once use the term "Cypriot Republic".  It is not the responsibility of the European Parliament to find a solution to the Cyprus problem. It is, however, its duty to safeguard, as guardian of the principles and values of the European Union, and to ensure that the solution respects human and political rights and the European acquis without derogations for all citizens. On the other side, it will be jointly responsible for the rejection of the solution by the Cypriot people. That is why I call on you to reject the report.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: – The German vaudeville on whether or not the tasteful satirist, on the one hand, the Turkish Prime Minister, on the other, and the question of goats, show that the Bosphorus wants to extend the Turkish rule of law to those places in Europe where there are enough Turks to put pressure on European leaders.  The fact that Angela Merkel is playing that game instead of protecting free speech - 'Je suis Charlie', not that of my colleagues - perfectly illustrates why we, as citizens of Europe, with European leaders like you in cases such as illegal immigration and membership, are at the mercy of brutal forms of blackmail and deceit. We must dare to protect our borders instead of relying on someone like Erdogan.

name: Esther de LANGE
text: I believe that the rapporteur is in a very difficult position this year. Last year, she removed all sorts of phrases from her report at the last minute, which were about the rapid opening of negotiating chapters. And this year there are actually just as few reasons to open those same negotiating chapters. In fact, there is only more concern about restricting freedom of expression, Turkey's role in regional conflicts, the lack of the rule of law and the lack of respect for minorities. And yet, in this year's report, it is full of references to the opening of those negotiating chapters. Turkey has not changed, the world around us has changed. It is very easy to say - and many colleagues do - that you should not link this morning's discussion on the Turkey deal to enlargement, but it is happening nonetheless. Let me be very clear, my party, the CDA, will vote tomorrow against the passages on the opening of the negotiating chapters. Yes, we must work with Turkey and I fully support the rapporteur in this, but a president who thinks that you can crack down on satire is just showing that he is still a long way from how we in Europe treat each other.

name: Eva KAILI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, because of the refugee crisis we are at the highest level in contact with Turkey, although the agreement does not seem to have the expected results. It must therefore be made clear that we have not given a blank cheque and that respect for the lives of refugees and fundamental human rights is required. Turkey must respect the media, the independence of the authorities, but also the minority rights of the Kurds. Respect the national sovereignty of its neighbours, as we observe daily provocative violations in the Aegean.  Finally, the occupying troops will withdraw from Cyprus and of course we expect the recognition of historical events, the genocide of the Pontians, Armenians and Assyrians. Moreover, Turkey must respect our historic churches, operating as museums and not as mosques, such as Agia Sophia Trabzontas and many others. Turkey still has a long way to go. It must proceed with too many reforms to rebuild trust between us.

name: Nikolay BAREKOV
text: – Mr President, 150 years ago the brilliant Bulgarian and European poet Hristo Botev, whose family my roots and those of my sons also come from, called Ottoman Turkey "the sick man of Europe". Botev died fighting for freedom from a Turkish bullet. For seven centuries, Turkey has been the "sick man of Europe", but it wants to be part of Europe. Today, a dozen think Turkey is keeping European countries dependent on gas, the southern corridor and refugees and immigrants, and I say the opposite. Today, Turkey is dependent on us. Turkey depends on our money, on our markets, on our will, Turkey has no other friends. America, Russia, Iran, Syria, Israel are her opponents of Erdogan too. Now is the time for the European Union to choose what Turkey wants in the future and Bulgaria is the only European country that has freed itself from Turkish slavery, knows Turkey well, its mistakes and its problems. Bulgaria can be a real leader in the subsequent Negotiations Europe – Turkey.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, if I were to sum up the work of the Commission and the rapporteur, I would say: courage, let us run away! As for you, ladies and gentlemen, you are now opening your eyes after opening 17 chapters on Turkey's accession to the European Union. Since 1987 you socialists, liberals, EPP have put in place the principles of Turkey's accession to the European Union, when you have not seen that there is an attack on democracy, on the rights of people, on respect for minorities, in the occupation since 1974 of Cyprus - what hypocrisy!  But we also have no principles to pass on to Turkey. We have no lessons to teach them, because here too, the European Union is a totalitarian body that also despises peoples.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Mr President, I believe that in this report the European Parliament has a duty to speak clearly about the issue of Turkey. Every year and worse is Turkey, at all levels. Turkey itself is making its position worse in all institutions, at all levels. It does not respect anyone, not even the principles and values of the European Union, which you wanted to respect, fully integrated into the European Union. So if he has someone responsible for Turkey's accession process, it is Turkey itself.  However, I believe that the European Parliament, in particular, must send a clear message: that there can be no discounts on those who do not respect any principle, particularly on the accession path, because this in itself will abolish the Very European Union, which is a union of principles and values. I also believe that this must be made clear to those colleagues who are trying and calling for funds to be opened up for Turkey before it implements the minimums it has to implement.  Let me remind you that it does not recognise its own signature in the Ankara Protocol, it does not recognise a Member State of the European Union, it holds the territory of a Member State of the European Union and a member country of the euro area. Turkey itself maintains 40,000 troops in a Member State of the European Union and I wanted to ask my dear colleagues: what would they do if they were in the same fate as the Cypriot people today, in terms of the behaviour of Turkey's treatment and violation of principles? That is why, Mr President, in conclusion, I will also call on the European Commission and my dear colleagues in the European Parliament to send this strong clear message to everyone that there will be no discounts on Turkey.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to acknowledge the excellent work that the rapporteur has done in this complex report. Turkey is a strategic player for all the global challenges we have in Europe today, but this condition cannot exempt us from talking about what the Turks are suffering today: with a president — Erdogan – with a clear authoritarian drift; with a country subjected to civil war in part of its territory; with a weakening rule of law; with closed newspapers, imprisoned journalists, closed liberties for many Turks and even it seems that Erdogan wanted to put some German comedian in jail.  What have we decided to do? Use chapters 23 and 24 to scrutinize, put the magnifying glass on the situation of fundamental freedoms and human rights that is now being lived in Turkey. And to remind all the European institutions that they cannot do as before, that they cannot use refugees as a currency of exchange in their management of Turkey's accession to the European Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, Turkey continues to violate Greek airspace and maintains the "casus belli" against Greece. At the same time, Turkish troops continue to illegally occupy 37% of the territory of the Republic of Cyprus. Turkey cooperates with Daesh, does business with jihadist oil smugglers, equips Daesh in Syria and Libya.  At the same time, it guides the slave trade circuits that have filled Greece with thousands of refugees. Nevertheless, Mr Hahn, the European Union is finally giving Ankara a pardon and rewarding it by giving it more than six billion euros, upgrading Turkey to political dialogue and abolishing visas for Turkish citizens, which by millions will now overwhelm Greece and the rest of the European Union.  Mr Hahn, you must understand this! Turkey is not part of the solution. Turkey is part of the problem, as it was in the past, when it committed the genocide of our Pontian brothers, which the report does not even mention, although it should have done so.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, Turkey has repeatedly been criticised in this Chamber for violating the human rights of its citizens, for gagging the press and social media, for its attitude to Kurdish, for its relations with ISIS, for blackmailing refugees, for the occupation of Cyprus.  The question is one and very simple: has Turkey made progress over the years or is it going for the worse? And we all know the answer: every day it moves away from the values of the European Union. Don't you think it's time for Europe to change Ankara's attitude, to force Turkey to become a truly democratic country without creating problems and becoming a pole of peace and stability? The College of Commissioners decided yesterday to rename the "task force for Turkish Cypriots" a "support group for the solution of the Cyprus problem".  If you really want to resolve the Cyprus problem, one is the way: the withdrawal of the occupying troops, the application of the four basic freedoms and the implementation of the acquis communautaire throughout the territory, in a united Europe. Otherwise, anything else will fail.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Mr President, colleagues, this year's resolution on Turkey's progress is completely unacceptable. First of all, I am shocked that the European Parliament welcomes the initiative to make Turkish an official language in the European Union. This cannot and cannot be allowed because it is a threat to the sovereignty of European countries, a threat to the national security of my country and will have irreversible consequences. Secondly, we support the reunification of Cyprus, which is not supported by our very colleagues in Cyprus. Have we forgotten that Turkey occupied Greek Cyprus? Is it right that we interfere drastically in their internal affairs? Third, the agreement with Turkey is completely unacceptable. The European Parliament is silent about the disregard for the rule of law and the violation of fundamental rights in exchange for questionable cooperation with Ankara on refugees. It's pure hypocrisy. Can't you see that Turkey itself organizes and directs refugee flows and that it sabotages and bends the hands of the European Union. Fourth, Turkey is interfering unacceptably in the internal affairs of my country by organising political parties. Fifth, nowhere in the resolution does it mention that Turkey is cooperating with Islamic State, helping the terrorist organization to proce foreign fighters, equipment and personal funds. There are other reasons to vote against this resolution, but the main one is that Turkey has no place in the European Union and I will vote against it.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr. President, the report recognises well that Turkey is a key partner to the European Union and that this bilateral relationship has enormous potential that can only be achieved with an active and credible negotiation process.  But I'm afraid the reporter and I don't have the same idea of credibility. Negotiating this long with a country whose membership of the Union has not been positively stated by all Member States is not credible in the slightest. It is therefore certain that negotiations with Turkey can last for decades and still not end with Turkish membership in the Union. The big question is, can an Islamic democracy ever become a copy of Western society, and should we even aspire to it? Let us not ignore the fact that Western societies have matured for centuries, so I do not believe in the slightest that Turkey, even with the best will, will succeed in tailoring its society to European standards in the short term.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: – Mr President, before being a candidate to join the European Union, Turkey is a strategic partner with whom we have to work together on many current issues, such as the refugee crisis and the fight against terrorists. I welcome the recent agreement between the EU and Turkey on the readmission of persons residing without authorisation. But at the same time I want to stress that Turkey’s accession to the EU is essentially connected to the Copenhagen criteria. Therefore Turkey has to make further progress towards the necessary reforms in order to ensure respect for the principle of the separation of powers and human rights protection, especially freedom of expression, the rights of minorities and freedom of religion. Having said this, we need to see a real commitment by Turkey in this process of accession to the EU, fully respecting the EU’s values and standards, and also to make sincere efforts to find a solution to the Cyprus problem.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Mr President, this report contains a number of realities and truths about what is happening today in Turkey, particularly in relation to the Kurds. But the question I am asking, so as not to repeat the same thing, is what we are doing today for Turkey.  I will take you, Commissioner, a few years back. In 2005, the Republic of Cyprus consented to the opening of chapters for Turkey and its accession talks. From then until today, it's been eleven years. Objective finding by all: things in Turkey are three times worse than they were. Violations, freedom of the press, all of this has disappeared. In relation to Cyprus, nothing.  It requires Akinji, the Turkish Cypriot leader, to legitimize the settlers, builds a dam in the province of Kyrenia that is occupied and from there I come from as a refugee, trying to connect the occupied part of Cyprus to a pipeline from Turkey. That means he doesn't want a solution.  I would like to end with a suggestion, Mr President: the immediate withdrawal of the occupying troops from Cyprus will mean that it wants a solution.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mr. President, every country on the European continent has the right to become a member of the European Union. However, there are also conditions for this. There are conditions that any country that wants to come to our club, to the European Union, must meet. There are no concessions to anyone, including Turkey, a great country, a country that is our partner, a country that is in some way also a strategic partner of the European Union on many issues, but there can be no special concessions, because we must not trample on our values, all that the countries that have entered the European Union have gone through and we who are sitting here today as representatives of those countries.  So I am convinced that Turkey needs help when we talk about migrants and refugees, because every country that cares about migrants and refugees - also Jordan Lebanon and others - needs help, but it cannot be blackmail to join the European Union. So Turkey does, but with conditions like for any other country.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, violations of fundamental rights, the dismantling of the rule of law and persecution of Kurds, journalists and academics in Turkey are rightly denounced in the report.  But since we recognise that Turkey is violating human rights and basic freedoms, even of its own people, how are the pressure to open chapters 23 and 24 justified? It's an oxymoron that shows that some people close their eyes and reinforce state terrorism.  Then how do you ask for the funds to be opened when Turkey continues provocatively not to recognise the Republic of Cyprus and to trample on its sovereign rights? It is also unacceptable to promote exchanges for Turkey's alleged services to refugees, even when it has not taken any measures to support refugees.  Unfortunately, the report welcomes the unacceptable agreement between the European Union and Turkey, which tramples on international law and sets the conditions for human trafficking with Turkey. Our position is clear. Turkey's accession path goes through the democratisation of the country itself and the fulfilment of its cypriot obligations.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, if a third independent observer could follow the discussions we are having here today, he would not know what to understand. Turkey is in breach of the agreements it has signed with the European Union, but requires the European Union to implement them.  Turkey does not recognise the Republic of Cyprus, of which it illegally holds part of the territory, threatens Greece with war, but at the same time requires those countries to vote to open the chapters of membership of the European Union.  It illegally promotes hundreds of thousands of migrants to Greece and the European Union is paying it three billion euros and because we are talking about Turkey's progress report, the independent observer could point out that Turkey has made significant progress on very serious issues: violation of international law, violation of human rights, gagging of the press, imprisonment of those who express views that are not liked in Ankara's new "sultan" , more precise bombardment of the positions of the Kurdish fighters and in the end, it would conclude, precisely because it is impartial, that in order to solve all these problems, one is the solution: Turkey's immediate accession to the European Union.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Thank you again for this enlightening debate. I believe that everyone here here agrees on one thing today, namely that Turkey is a strategic partner for the European Union. This is due to the geostrategic situation, which is the number of inhabitants. It is therefore obvious that the European Union has a very vital interest in seeking a sensible form of cooperation here. It is clear that cooperation with Turkey has its ups and downs. But it is also clear that this cooperation must be a very comprehensive one. And the situation of interest with Turkey is multifaceted. It is, for example– and has hardly been mentioned today – a very important economic one, because Europe is by far Turkey's most important economic and investment partner. We have around 600 000 employees in Europe who work for Turkish companies. Turkey is Europe's sixth most important partner. So here it is necessary to find a sensible form of cooperation. That is why, for example, the upgrading of the Customs Union is an important task, which we have been devoting ourselves intensively to for over a year and a half. The current challenge surrounding the refugee crisis has given this form of cooperation a new impetus, and it is quite obvious. We have developed an action plan which includes a wide range of elements. Visa liberalisation is an issue and visa liberalisation has already been on the agenda. It was and is about speeding up this issue. But visa liberalisation does not mean that the next step is automatically accession, as is sometimes assumed. After all, we have visa liberalisation with many countries around the world. Nevertheless, no one comes up with the idea that this country can become a member. On the other hand, yes, we have a mandate from the European Council to hold accession negotiations here. This has been an open mandate since 2005. We are called upon to conduct these negotiations and to reach a result, because the mandate says that open-ended negotiations must be conducted. And, frankly, my professional ambition is that such negotiations must be brought to an end. Then an assessment can be made, unless we come to the conclusion that these negotiations are to be interrupted or broken off. I have often heard today how important it is to address and take into account the principles of the rule of law in Turkey and to ensure that they are guaranteed. However, I can also tell you that this is only possible if we have accession negotiations, because only then will we have a lever, because only then can we demand something. It is a qualitative difference whether I am negotiating accession or whether I deal with my neighbour and identify commonalities. At the moment, we have the task, the obligation, as the Commission, to fulfil this task. I have therefore noted with interest what Count Lambsdorff and others have said. However, as I said, this is something that is not the object of our task at the moment, but is the object of our task to implement our mandates, to ensure that we have stability in the region. And I believe that this can only be guaranteed by the fact that we have a very close network of cooperation with Turkey. This can also ensure that, for example, the current refugee problem can be adequately addressed and resolved. I can also tell you on this occasion that the Turkey facility has already started. The occasional statement from Turkey that she has not yet seen a penny is simply not true. It is true in that we do not pay turkey, but we finance projects in Turkey which serve to ensure the additional costs and expenses of Turkey in terms of accommodation, food and schooling and to make a significant contribution to ensuring that the refugees have a chance to stay in the region, especially in eastern Turkey. to return immediately to Syria, if security and the political situation allow. That is why our expenditure is focused on the fact that we are using the funds accordingly, primarily in eastern Anatolia. In this respect, initial activities have started. We have ensured, with around EUR 55 million, that 350 000 people will have food for at least half a year. With EUR 40 million, we can already ensure that 200 000 children can attend school for one year. These are exactly the things that essential. We should focus on this, and they also help to improve mutual trust between Turkey and Europe, hopefully. There is no question that there is sand in the gearbox here, so to speak. But between partners, between neighbours, it is necessary to have a trusting relationship. We should be interested in this together. And how things develop in the future is simply the result of the negotiations.

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I am very happy to be here. Let me first of all thank you very much for this very interesting debate and also for the timely exchange of views, which demonstrates that we in many respects share both many hopes and concerns with regard to Turkey. It is important in my view to remember that the EU and Turkey share many ties and that our relationship goes back way longer than the current migration crisis. Closer cooperation is good for both Turkey and the EU, and the EU was and will continue to be an important anchor for Turkey’s political and economic reforms. To be clear, as has been mentioned several times, we are not linking migration and accession talks. These are separate issues. As we have set out, we are aware of existing shortcomings and we share your concerns about negative trends in the areas of rule of law, human rights and fundamental freedoms. We are firm and we are clear about this. Let me stress once more that we continue to follow these and other developments such as the situation in the south-east closely, and that we will continue to bring up our concerns in all our meetings and at all levels with Turkey. On the issue of visa liberalisation, the Commissioner already touched upon this: there will be no shortcut. As we have agreed in our common statement with Turkey, visa requirements for Turkish citizens can be lifted by the end of June this year provided that all benchmarks have been met. Whether that will materialise, of course, depends on Turkey and the progress it makes. A few words in closing on the 18 March agreement. In my view the agreement has the potential to be a major step towards finding a viable and legal European solution to the migration crisis. It is not going to be a silver bullet. It is not going to be a magic solution, but it is a step in the right direction and an important instrument. This will be done in accordance with the relevant international standards and by respecting the principle of non-refoulement. It is not plain sailing – we are all aware of this, and we are not outsourcing our problems. It is still too early to assess the concrete effects of this agreement, as the concrete measures to implement it only became truly operational as of 4 April. But let me be clear: it is in all our interests that this is successful.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 14 April 2016. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: Writing. - Turkey first applied to join the EU in 1963. It was not rejected at the time, but the European Community institutions declared at the time that Turkey must first implement a number of fundamental reforms. Since then, this wording has been repeated in relation to Turkey. The peculiarity of Turkish society since the days of Mustafa Kemal Pash (Ataturk) has always been the strict separation of state and church, the guarantor of which has always been the army. If the military considered that a party was too religiously focused, that party was abolished. So the Islamist AKP has many predecessors. Only today's Turkish President has managed to break this tradition, and the consequence is, unfortunately, the gradual Islamization of Turkish society. Corruption in the judicial system has not disappeared, tolerance of non-Islamic religions has not improved, the rights of national minorities have stagnated, the war against the Kurds is continuing, the women's rights movement has also not made a decision. The continued occupation of Northern Cyprus without adequate commentary by the EU institutions shows the inability of the apparatus to negotiate to correct such a flagrant violation of international law. In this situation, I consider it ill-advised to expose Turkey to an open account of EUR 6 billion with very vague conditions. I recommend further negotiations with Turkey on the possibility of harmonising legislation and the possibility of broad application of EU standards in the various areas of the country's social life, but I must reject the report as it is formulated.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - Turkey is a very important partner of the EU, it is a member of the G20, it is a regional power and it is crucial for regional stability and especially for peace in the Middle East. This is why Turkey as a partner must be part of the solution to the migrant crisis.  Turkey has repeatedly tried to raise its status since joining the membership negotiations, and since 2005 has been conducting accession negotiations that stalled from 2013 until the start of this major refugee-migration crisis. It has become not only more acceptable but also a reference for how to reach a controlled influx of migrants. It has a very specific and challenging environment and, just as it is able to control the entry of refugees and migrants into the country, turkey is also expected to control their exit. This is very important in the Aegean Sea where the Greek islands are very close to the Turkish coast and where, as we know, a huge number of tragedies have occurred in recent months. Turkey is expected to strengthen its capacity and does not allow uncontrolled and unregulated flow of migrants towards the EU.  Over the past years, Turkey has shown only partial progress, but I am convinced that it is extremely important at the moment that it continues reforms related to the rule of law, media freedom and freedom of expression.

name: Marek PLURA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Ladies and gentlemen, in my speech I would like to refer to Turkey's progress in the implementation of the principles of non-discrimination, especially for persons with disabilities. I am pleased that the social assistance system for people with disabilities in Turkey is developing and more and more people are benefiting from different types of support, including institutional and semi-institutional care centres and services. However, according to the Commission Communication, the employment rate of persons with disabilities is still extremely low. Public sector employment is less than 2%, in the private sector the situation is even worse. I am concerned about this fact, especially as, despite the introduction by the Turkish Government of a law on civil service and the definition of a standard of employment for persons with disabilities, it still has 3% of the more than 24 000 jobs for persons with disabilities remaining vacant.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the Council and Commission statements – 2015 Report on Albania (2016/2896(RSP)).

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, let me first of all welcome the steady progress Albania has made in addressing the five key priorities for the opening of accession negotiations. These are positive signals, showing that Albania is on the right path, and we encourage it to continue these efforts. In addition, we welcome the adoption of the decriminalisation legislation which should enhance citizens’ trust in their political representatives and public institutions. We now look forward to concrete steps and results for its effective implementation. At the same time, I would like to stress that significant challenges lie ahead and further efforts to fulfil the key priorities are still needed. In particular, it will now be essential to swiftly adopt the judicial reform package in line with the Venice Commission’s opinion. Judicial reform is key to further forward movement on Albania’s EU accession process. Progress is also needed to fight corruption as well as organised crime. A solid track record of proactive investigations, prosecutions and final convictions, at all levels, needs to be established. Let me also reiterate the need for effective legislative and policy measures to reinforce the protection of human rights and anti-discrimination policies, including the equal treatment of all minorities. As you know, the European Council will consider the opening of accession negotiations once Albania has met the five key priorities. The Council has invited the Commission to report on these key priorities in a comprehensive and detailed manner in addition to its 2016 report. Let me underline that a constructive and sustainable dialogue between the government and the opposition on EU-related reforms will be vital for the success of these endeavours. I would like to commend Albania on its full alignment with the EU’s common foreign and security policy. In closing, let me point out that we are closely monitoring the situation in Albania with regard to the migration crisis and the possible development of an alternative Balkan route across the sea to Italy.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like first of all to thank the rapporteur Knut Fleckenstein for his input and coordination efforts, which resulted in a very balanced text. The resolution not only captures the progress that Albania has made over the past months but also the challenges that lie ahead in order to move the country closer to the European Union. I particularly welcome the emphasis that this resolution places on the reform of the justice system. This will help to embed the rule of law in the country. Strengthening efficiency and professionalism throughout this sector while striking the right balance between independence and accountability is a key challenge. As the resolution has emphasised, the preparatory work carried out so far on this important dossier is rather solid. Political parties should now engage in a decisive, constructive dialogue and finalise the reform. This is a long-overdue development that is in the interest of all citizens. Adapting to judicial reform is a crucial opportunity for the country as a whole which is too precious to be subject to any party political manoeuvring. I expect constructive cross-party cooperation from both the ruling majority and the opposition, as this reform should be seen by all political actors as a win-win opportunity. The last mile is always the hardest, especially when we are in the final stage of a very comprehensive and slow reform process. But this is a path worth completing. I made this point very clearly during my recent visit to Tirana for the high-level dialogue on the five key priorities for the opening of accession negotiations. Negotiations opened at the end of March. Let me also point out that, beyond judicial reform, the resolution also provides a clear review of progress on other matters related to the rule of law, in particular the fight against organised crime and corruption. Albania needs to demonstrate further progress with a view to establishing a solid track record of investigations, prosecutions and convictions in the fight against organised crime and corruption at all levels. High-level corruption needs to be tackled more effectively. The same goes for the challenge posed by organised crime. More results are needed to dismantle organised criminal networks that operate locally, regionally and globally. I would also like to commend the emphasis that the resolution attaches to a number of processes that fall outside the scope of the five key priorities but are nevertheless crucial to consolidate the credibility of the state and its institutions. Albania urgently needs to finalise the reform of the electoral system, aligning all the relevant legislation to the recommendations issued by the OSCE/ODIHR. Moreover, integrity throughout the public sector needs to be further strengthened. A lot has been achieved already through ongoing public administration reform. In addition, the process of so-called decriminalisation needs to advance. Both civil servants and elected officials should be subject to the scrutiny mechanism foreseen in the law, and sanctions applied whenever necessary. The Commission maintains its strong commitment to support Albania’s efforts to advance further on its path towards European integration.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Albania has undergone an astonishing transformation over the last 25 years. From a communist dictatorship cut off from all its neighbours to a country with a free society committed to democracy and the social market economy, to a country that has built constructive relations with its neighbours and is on its way to the European Union.  The majority of people in Albania regularly express their desire in surveys to further strengthen the rule of law in their country. This includes an independent judiciary that is not impressed by attempts to influence. This includes a professional public administration that is accessible to every citizen and is fairly managed and violent. This includes the successful prevention and prosecution of corruption and organised crime.
