The Albanian Government and the Albanian Parliament have set out to adopt a particularly ambitious judicial reform. They have therefore also consulted with international experts, including the Venice Commission. This judicial reform must now be adopted by the Albanian Parliament as soon as possible. Its implementation must be put in place, so that Albania can unequivocally demonstrate, through its self-determined objective, that it is on the right track.  The large majority that was in favour of the report in the Committee on Foreign Affairs shows that we are very much in agreement: we want to encourage Albania to maintain the momentum of reform so far and to press ahead with the reforms ambitiously or even more ambitiously. We say: Keep it that way! But we know that much remains to be done, much has not yet been achieved.  The Minister, the Commissioner have mentioned a number of things in terms of electoral laws, corruption and the economy. If, however, the five reform priorities are pursued further, if the judicial reform is now also adopted by a large majority and implementation begins, then it is also time to start the accession negotiations at last. This Parliament will support Albania in this.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to congratulate Mr Fleckenstein on his report and appreciate highly our cooperation on Albania. The European Parliament is sending a message of support and encouragement for the reforms in the country in this report. Albania made solid progress in the reforming process over the last year and became a reliable ally in the region. Progress along the path of integration is only possible with the cooperation of all political forces in the country. We mention in the report the ongoing reform of the judiciary, which is key to strengthening justice and the rule of law in the country. I hope that once the reform is adopted it opens doors to the further integration of Albania into the EU. At the same time we also have to look realistically at other areas such as the fight against corruption, public administration reform, media or ongoing electoral reform, the last of which will be particularly important for the upcoming 2017 elections. I hope that the political parties will find a consensus on the reform. Implementation of the OSC/OD recommendation is the key. It will be really important to see democratic, free and fair elections in Albania next year. (The speaker agreed to take a blue card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: blue-card question. – You mentioned some of the shortcomings as well but, in spite of this fact, do you not think that the case of Albania could be shown and demonstrated as a really good example for all those countries in the neighbourhood which are much further behind?

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: blue-card answer. –  I fully agree with you, but let us wait until all the necessary reforms are implemented. Not before that. Then we can use it as an example for the others.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, colleagues, I thank rapporteur Flekenstein and the shadow rapporteurs for constructive cooperation in drafting the resolution on Albania's progress in 2015.  I congratulate the Albanian authorities on the progress made over the past year, in particular with regard to reforms in the five key areas identified by the Commission – public administration reform, strengthening the judiciary, the fight against corruption and organised crime and strengthening fundamental rights and freedoms. I am pleased that the resolution pays special attention to most of these areas, because they are the foundation of any properly functioning rule of law. Unfortunately, this year's resolution very laconicly addresses the problems and rights of national minorities. As you know well, national minorities are the most vulnerable groups in balkan countries. According to data of our state agency for Bulgarians abroad, in the municipalities of Mala Prespa, Golo Bado and Gora live between 40 and 50 thousand Bulgarians by self-determination. They are not recognised as a national minority by the Albanian authorities, which puts them at a very disadvantage compared to other minority communities. I call on the Albanian authorities to recognise the Bulgarian minority, because by guaranteeing the rights and freedoms of all citizens, Albania will show that it is ready for membership of the European Union.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, colleagues, I would like to thank our rapporteur, Mr Flekenstein, for the fruitful cooperation on albania's progress report. Albania has made significant progress in its European integration over the past year and today the country plays an important role in regional stability with its constructive positions in the region. In foreign policy terms, Albania has met a small part of the political criteria for membership of the European Union and this is clearly noted in the report we are debating today. However, we need to continue, call on and encourage the country's leading political forces for a more constructive and sustainable political dialogue between them on European Union-related reforms. Political consensus on vital reforms is essential for the country's further progress, and confrontation can undermine this process. The report clearly outlines the challenges Albania faces and some of the positive steps the government has taken to address them. Serious efforts need to be made to reform the judiciary. The country has shown political will to fight corruption, which together with organised crime remains the biggest problem facing Albania. These vices of the young democracies of the Balkans erode statehood. On economic reforms, the government has continued its work, but constructive reforms need to be accelerated. As a result of the low competitiveness of the economy, unemployment remains high and the grey sector occupies an essential part. Dear Mr President, in conclusion, I would like to call on the authorities in the country to continue with the reforms initiated and to consolidate the achievements in the area of the key priorities that are so needed to open accession negotiations.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are discussing the accession path of Albania, a state which according to all statistics is one of the poorest countries in Europe, with a real per capita income of EUR 280 and unemployment of 18%.  In addition, the country is plagued by serious problems of corruption and political polarisation. It is for these reasons that, while we support the country's accession process and the will of its citizens to join the Union, we disagree with the policies promoted by the Union in that country. We disagree with the economic and social policies being promoted. What is needed is an open and frank dialogue with the representatives of the country about the specifics of this country.  Albania, like the other western Balkan states, needs support to create real structures that are ready to deal with their serious problems. Problems such as deepening the rule of law and democracy, tackling corruption, organised crime and protecting freedom of expression. We must not assume that we hold the absolute truth that applies to everyone and apply it fully to everyone.

name: Tamás MESZERICS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, first allow me to express my great thanks to the rapporteur who, as usual, has been very constructive in the shadow meetings. I think that we have a good progress report on Albania. I am glad to see on this occasion that the only issues that need raising in this very short time are the classic green issues. Possibly this is the only accession country nowadays – maybe with the exception of Serbia – that poses us no bigger problems than asking the Albanian Government to make concerted efforts to align its environmental policies with EU standards, do everything in its power to meet the Chapter 27 requirements and also reconsider its hydroelectric policies. Some of the hydro plants need to be reconsidered. I am glad to be able to say that, because there are other countries for which there are much bigger issues at stake in the accession negotiations. Although it is true that Albania is also facing the classic problems of south—eastern Europe, with endemic corruption and a number of other shortcomings in good governance, it does – I am glad to say – seem to be on the right track. I hope very much that it will successfully conclude all the negotiations and become part of the European Union very soon.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Madam President, Commissioner Avramopoulos and the Commission, in general, plan to include Albania together with Turkey, Kosovo, Skopje and Bosnia and Herzegovina in the list of safe countries. Of course, this is done in order to make deportations easier, but it makes me wonder how far the introspection of some European politicians can go. I don't know if "purpose justifies means." But, on the altar of finding a pressing solution to the migration crisis, are we sacrificing basic principles and universal values?  Did Albania suddenly become a country where human rights, freedom of speech and freedom of religion are protected? Where does the internationally recognized Greek minority of Northern Epirus enjoy the rights that define international law and conventions? Where there are no criminal gangs, branches of turkish, Boscopic, Kosovar and Macedonian equivalents that trade arms, drugs, human organs and white flesh? Have we forgotten or are we making the naïve and ignorant that jihadist terrorists live and train in Albania?  It would be good for some European leaders, with a short memory and knowledge, to remember that the Europeanisation of the Balkans without respecting the basic conditions of stability and solidarity will lead to the violent Balkanisation of the European Union and, as has been said many years ago, the Balkans are Europe's powder keg.

name: David McALLISTER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which We have heard it this evening: on Albania's path to the European Union, it is essential that the government and parliament in Tirana continue to press ahead with the modernisation process and implement reforms that have already been adopted. The rule of law in that country must be further strengthened, corruption must be combated, as must organised crime. Judicial reform, as Rapporteur Fleckenstein rightly pointed out, is of paramount importance. Without an independent judiciary, there can be no functioning democracy. But ladies and gentlemen, I would like to raise another issue: I have read in a German newspaper these days that exactly 54 762 Albanian citizens applied for asylum in Germany in 2015. After people from Syria, the second most asylum seekers came from Albania in 2015. That is not possible! I call on those responsible in Albania to adopt the necessary economic reforms so that young people have a lasting perspective in that country. And people need to be fully informed that their asylum applications in the EU have no chance of being recognised.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I would like to join our rapporteur, Knut Fleckenstein, but I can say that this is such a solid company that its report can always be either very good or even more than very good, that is, excellent. On the other hand, listening to the Minister and Also Commissioner Hahn, I have the impression that a package of cases is repeated regardless of which country we are talking about, namely corruption, crime, the efficiency of the judicial system, minority affairs, human affairs. I think we should draw our Albanian friends' attention to economic issues – that they should gain economic momentum before they join the European Union – and social issues – in order to make them realise that our economy is a social market economy, and therefore social packages, social packages, in order to prepare the population for this dwelling, living in this new home.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Madam President, as Chair of the EU-Albania Parliamentary Committee on Stabilisation and Association, I insist on a regular political dialogue between the two sides, and I also insist on the adoption of recommendations when we have these meetings, because they must not be prevented, because they are beneficial to the Albanian people. Secondly, I welcome Albania's progress in the five key areas, and I hope that the pace of reform will remain unchanged, even if it accelerates, precisely so that we can start discussions on Albania's accession. The judicial system: we still have shortcomings, there is a change in the Constitution in terms of justice, and the most important thing is that the laws are properly applied, judicial practice is uniform and the judicial system must be cleaned by corrupt and incompetent judges and prosecutors. As far as corruption and organised crime are concerned, they are extensive, anti-corruption and anti-organised crime strategies have been adopted, but the number of convictions remains very low. We cannot make reforms on paper alone, they must have a result in practice.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: – Madam President, this Frankenstein – I mean Fleckenstein – report on Albania looks at their progress towards achieving the criteria that will eventually allow them to join the EU. And whilst ongoing reform in Albania is obviously welcome, I am concerned about what you said about that country, Commissioner. That really was a tale of woe, and they have obviously got a very long way to go before they can become EU members. But of course, once they are EU members, it will draw Albania into the Schengen area – already notorious for facilitating organised crime and human trafficking. The UK has a GDP per capita approximately 10 times that of Albania and a minimum wage level and social benefit structure that will draw Albanians to Britain like an electromagnet. If I was an honest young man in Albania today, I would take English lessons and save up for a train ticket to London and pray that the Brits vote to remain in the club on 23 June 2016. If I was a criminal in Albania today, I would view EU membership as a passport to paradise. Whilst the EU sits in judgement on Albania, it presides over appalling problems within its own jurisdiction. Getting its own financial accounts satisfactorily signed off would be a good start and a good example to Albania. The lesson just never seems to be learned that making the EU bigger does not make the EU better.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Hahn, thank you very much for your presentation of albania's current state of progress. I see that my colleague Agnew really does not know Albania, because if iole knew her, he would know how talented our young Albanian friends are in their knowledge of the language. I personally saw this many times when I visited Albania.  In any case, it would be good for our friends in Albania to continue with key political, judicial and economic reforms, for which it is important to reach a consensus of all political actors and develop a culture of constructive parliamentary dialogue between the ruling and opposition. The Commission has well detected all the benchmarks to be met before accession negotiations can be opened, and particular attention should be paid to a thorough reform of the judiciary in order to ensure an effective and policy-free and other influence independent legal system that guarantees the rule of law. I welcome Albania's constructive role in foreign policy and security in southeast Europe, and as a Croatian MEP and member of the European Parliament, I will be friendly to firmly and strongly encourage their European path and further reforms towards the EU. (The Speaker accepts to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the E.S. Rules of Procedure)).

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Since I always appreciate Mr Plenkovici's position very much, including on regional matters, I would like to ask: can you mention very briefly two, three fundamental positive aspects and perhaps one risky membership of Albania from the point of view of the region?

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Albania, like any other southeast European country and as a European country, has the right to apply for membership and has the right to become part of this political family in which we are. The transformational impact of the rapprochement process and accession process will be crucial for Albania to become a state of rule of law, respect for human rights, strengthening democracy and economic capacity. What is good is that the European process will speed up and improve relations with its neighbours, and I see the special added value of Albania's European path.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: – Madam President, I believe the report and discussions this afternoon send a clear signal to both Tirana and Brussels. Albania has made remarkable progress in the past 12 months on the key priorities required for the opening of accession negotiations. This is why it is crucial for this House to acknowledge the reform efforts and ambitions of the authorities and to encourage the European aspirations of the Albanian people. I feel this was the spirit of the visit of the High Representative in March, and it is very much the message the rapporteur is conveying with this year’s report. Now it is vital to keep the current momentum for reforms and to build on the achievement thus far. Bold implementation will be key to delivering on the ground, with far-reaching policies providing for effective, transparent and accountable institutions as well as higher living standards for the benefit of all Albanian citizens.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, Albania oppresses the Greek minority of Northern Epirus and dares to claim Greek territory in its attempt to create the illusory dream of Great Albania. Albania's recent decision to close its border with Greece and ban refugees from entering its territory violates, Mr Hahn, both the Agreement of 25 October 2015 on the migration route to the Balkans and the 1951 Geneva Convention on Refugees.  And all this happens when the Albanians themselves, after the collapse of Enver Hoxha's regime, crossed undisturbed, by the thousands, the Greek border, hosted them, ate bread in Greece, worked in Greece and sent their savings to Albania.  So in the case of our neighbours, Albanians, the saying 'no one more ungrateful than the benefactor' applies, that is to say, the one who has benefited turns out, in the end, to be the most ungrateful.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I welcome Albania's progress in the area of economic reforms, the fight against radicalism and terrorism and measures against the recruitment of Islamic State fighters. The European Union cannot be completed without the full integration of the Western Balkan countries.  Respect for the rights of minorities is one of the most important criteria that member candidates must fulfil in order to be able to join our Union. In this regard, discrimination against ethnic minorities, including the Bulgarian one, the only unrecognised historical minority that has been waiting for this recognition for decades, should not be allowed in Albania.  In 1932, according to a resolution voted on by the Second Balkan Conference in Istanbul, the two sides signed a final protocol stating verbatim: "Article 1: The Albanian delegation recognizes the existence of a Bulgarian minority in Albania." The question has since been opened. I ask the Albanian officials to accept the solution to this matter. I call on you, recognize the Bulgarian minority and let us together contribute to the fact that Albanian citizens become European citizens as well.

name: Susanne MELIOR
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I have listened carefully and many things have already been raised. I very much agree with the thanks to Knut Fleckenstein, who has presented a very good report on the difficult transformation process that Albania is still going through. However, I would like to draw your attention to one point – as Mrs Macovei has already said: we were also on the ground as a delegation, as the Stabilisation and Association Committee, and I believe that the role of the institutions in this process of transformation is also part of this process. And then we must also succeed in taking on the role of the opposition and the government more in Albania, taking on board them, learning to deal with them and then also coming to the opportunity to launch joint papers following our delegation trips. Unfortunately, this has not been achieved in the last two times. I very much regret that. And here I would like to see the committee and its role strengthened, as the rapporteur has already mentioned in his report.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: – Thank you very much for the opportunity, and first of all, I would like to say very humbly to some of my colleagues that I do not think this disdainful, demeaning style has any place in albania either. Albania is a European perspective, simply a security issue, a European security issue. So I'd like to offer more responsibility to one or two of our colleagues. We must maintain the real perspective of accession for Albania. Some results give cause for optimism: Albania has made significant progress in its administrative reform. This is a sign of the adoption of a new Civil Servants Act or a redesign of the territorial administration.  Of course, for example, decisive action against organised crime is needed. There are still few achievements in detecting criminal organisations and illegal trade. Eu accession will continue to be the driving force behind these transformations. In addition to successes and justified criticisms, Albania deserves the encouragement and recognition of Europe.  I would like to stress once again that it is in our common interest that albanian accession be given a new impetus as soon as possible. Thank you very much. (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – Do you not think that we should have to ask the Albanian Government and also the European Commission to clarify Albania’s position on Kosovo? I have recently heard lots of things about a common economic space encompassing Albania and Kosovo, the Albanian regional market and so on. And secondly, as regards the national minorities: they never mention the Vlachs, the Romanians living in Albania.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you very much for your very relevant question. I can join you with this question, and maybe we will have an answer a little bit later from the side of the Commission.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – Sincere congratulations to Mr Fleckenstein on the report, which is very balanced and well-prepared. Thank you also to Commissioner Hahn for closely monitoring the situation in Kosovo.  Those of us who know Kosovo, and have followed it in the past, can peacefully acknowledge kosovo's very great progress in transforming from one of the most closed communist countries into a country that has the right direction, a direction towards parliamentary democracy and respect for European values.  I also agree with those who draw attention to the major problems that are still in Albania, particularly in the area of corruption, including organised crime, and it is right that such things should be eliminated through such reports and also through the recommendations of the European Commission on the way to the European Union. It is very important, however, that we also enable Albania to develop economic development so that young Albanians do not look for perspective all over Europe, but that they find it at home.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam President, what is certain at the moment is albania's positive role is the fact that Albania is a significant factor in regional stability. I have already highlighted in this hall the meeting between Vucic and Rama in Belgrade and Tirana as a bold move by both politicians and this is an indication that a new quality in the Balkans is to be achieved. However, this is not enough.  Albania, if it is to become a member of the European Union, must meet absolutely all the requirements. This is where the problems with minorities stood out. However, I would like to highlight above all what is already common knowledge, namely the rule of law, corruption at various levels and organised crime. These are dangers to Europe and this needs to be highlighted in particular. Of course, it will be necessary to meet all other criteria, but I believe albania has the strength to meet such criteria and I want to see it as soon as possible and in our society.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – First of all, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for the excellently prepared report and add what has already been said by most. Albania has gone through a difficult period in its history and, relatively in a short period of time, in the last fifteen, twenty years, has made significant progress.  So, Albania has absolutely made significant progress in a number of areas in recent years, it acknowledges and writes in the report that we will be 700, and the Commission has also prepared in its report quite a few encouraging words for the achievements that Albania has made in recent years.  There are, of course, many other issues that still need to be resolved, many of them have already pointed to corruption, to the justice system, to organised crime, but, of course, it is also the duty of the European Parliament and also the Commission to help them to offer a hand of cooperation and, of course, to recognise Albania as an important regional partner, because without Albania and without some other neighbouring countries there will also be no stability and peace in the region. This will also be important in this cooperation for the European Union in the management of the refugee river, which has still not ended.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission welcomes the resolution on Albania. I would once again like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Fleckenstein, and all the others who actively contributed to the discussion in the past few months. The Commission takes note of this resolution and will continue to rely on the views expressed by Parliament in its upcoming engagement with Albania. Since candidate status was granted, Albania has consistently made steady progress on the five key priorities for the opening of accession negotiations. We share the assessment that the upcoming months will be crucial to consolidate all that has been achieved to date and that all necessary efforts should be made to pursue outstanding reform processes. Challenges related to the entrenchment of the rule of law will continue to receive specific attention. The observations in the resolution provide good guidance in this specific regard. To conclude, I would like to reiterate that the Commission will continue to intensify its support, monitoring and assessment of the results that Albania achieves on the reform agenda. Concrete results will bring the country closer to the European Union. But, most importantly, concrete results are needed to guarantee that all the citizens throughout the country can rely on a functioning democratic state that successfully provides welfare, security and opportunities. This is the most important perspective, I believe, and I hope that all political actors in Albania will genuinely work with this very same objective in mind. Once again, I think Albania is on a good path, but now it needs the cooperation of all political parties in the country. The main focus now should be on the reform of the judicial system, which is a very comprehensive and decisive step by Albania towards the European Union.

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, let me express my sincere gratitude for the excellent work by Parliament’s rapporteur on Albania, Mr Fleckenstein. Albania has, as you mentioned, taken many steps in the right direction. For the political leaders it is now important to overcome internal difficulties and continue on this path. Decisive action is now needed to meet the five key priorities, in particular to adopt the wide-ranging justice reform, and the EU, for its part, stands ready to deliver in good faith. Madam President, a final point, which was raised by Mr McAllister. The arrival of many Albanians in a number of EU Member States, including Germany and, moreover, the Netherlands, is another matter of great concern to us, to which I would briefly draw the Commissioner’s attention to make sure that we can discuss it later on.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: I have received one motion for a resolution tabled pursuant to the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 14 March 2008. Adopted on 14 April 2016. Written statements (Article 162 of the Tyojarjes

name: Vladimir URUTCHEV
text: in writing. – Dear Colleagues, over the past 25 years Albania has undergone significant changes and stands firmly on its democratic path. Let us give what is deserved to the efforts and ingesting the Albanian people for the country's accession to the EU, which will not be a complete project if all the countries of the Western Balkans do not become its members. Let us support with this resolution the albanians' demands for reform of our country, for the rule of law, for the successful prosecution of organised crime and corruption. There is no doubt that an independent judiciary is a cornerstone of the country's progress towards the EU and the reforms needed to achieve such a judicial system, as prescribed by the Venice Commission, must happen with political will, civil support and EU assistance. No less important are the other reforms on the 5 key priorities – the electoral system, free media, transparent public administration and the strengthening of fundamental civil rights and freedoms. For example, the Bulgarian minority in the country has not yet been recognised, which may also become a condition for EU membership. It is clear to us all that Albania has serious and difficult obstacles to overcome on the road to progress towards European membership, but an Albania in the EU strategically means more regional stability.

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, let me start by saying that it is a positive sign that Bosnia and Herzegovina is back on the reform path necessary to move forward in its EU integration process. And let me mention the adoption of the reform agenda and its accompanying action plan last year in particular. The Council has reinforced Bosnia and Herzegovina’s EU perspective in its conclusions of December 2015. At the same time, it has underlined that meaningful progress in the implementation of the reform agenda is necessary for the EU to consider a membership application. I would therefore like to encourage the authorities to continue the necessary reforms and to consolidate progress – in particular in the area of the rule of law, including the fight against corruption and organised crime, the reform of public administration and socio-economic reforms.  The functionality of Bosnia and Herzegovina’s institutions remains a priority. Moreover, a functioning coordination mechanism on EU matters will be essential for the country to be able to face the challenges ahead on its EU path. The adaptation of the stabilisation and association agreement following the accession of Croatia will allow Bosnia and Herzegovina to normalise its trade relations with the Union. It is, moreover, an important element of the country’s commitment to the EU integration process. Let me commend in this respect the ongoing progress in the current negotiations. The Council will refer to Bosnia and Herzegovina’s EU membership application in due course.  First of all, Bosnia and Herzegovina will need to deliver concrete and irreversible results in the reform process. When requesting the Commission’s opinion on the membership application, the Council will ask the Commission to pay particular attention to the implementation of the Sejdić—Finci ruling of the European Court of Human Rights. I would also like to reiterate the Council’s serious concern about preparations for holding an entity—level referendum on the state—level judiciary in Republika Srpska. Such a referendum would challenge the cohesion, sovereignty and territorial integrity of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Outstanding shortcomings in the country’s judiciary should be addressed with the structured dialogue on justice.  We expect the authorities at all levels to ensure that the challenges the country faces are addressed constructively, in a spirit of dialogue and mutual understanding. It is now central for Bosnia and Herzegovina to seize the momentum gained so far and to keep working hard. Obviously, we stand ready to support it.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Cristian Preda, for the resolution on Bosnia and Herzegovina. We welcome the text, which is balanced and largely in line with the Commission’s November 2015 report on Bosnia and Herzegovina. It reflects well the state of play in that country, notably when it comes to being back on the reform track and starting to address the outstanding issues on its European Union integration path.  I welcome the support this resolution provides for the renewed EU approach towards Bosnia and Herzegovina, in particular the focus on socio-economic rule of law and public administration reforms, as adopted by Bosnia and Herzegovina under the July 2015 reform agenda.  In addition, I welcome Parliament’s call for Bosnia and Herzegovina to ensure that it has an effective coordination mechanism on Union matters in place as well as to adapt the Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA) following the accession of Croatia to the European Union.  The Commission is fully dedicated to advancing Bosnia and Herzegovina’s European Union perspective. First, the SAA which entered into force in June 2015 is a springboard for deep reforms in that country. In this context, in December 2015 we successfully held SAA Council and SAA Committee meetings. In cooperation with international financial institutions we are closely following the implementation of the comprehensive reform agenda, which once again started in July 2015. This has resulted in the adoption of a number of key pieces of legislation and strategies and implementation has already started. I expect Bosnia and Herzegovina to further implement the reform agenda, not only as a key condition for the country on its path to the Union but also in the best interests of its citizens. This includes the dissemination of the 2013 population census results. Together with the High Representative, Vice-President Mogherini, we have taken note of Bosnia and Herzegovina’s application for European Union membership submitted to the European Council Presidency in February.  This is a renewed commitment from this country to decisively advance towards the European Union, deliver on the necessary reforms and meet its citizens’ aspirations for a more prosperous future. The country is also participating in the connectivity agenda and I would expect it to be a closer partner when discussing measures for youth, particularly against the backdrop of massive youth employment – and we are talking here about a youth unemployment rate of 55%.  To conclude, I would like to stress that I witnessed a positive dynamic during my latest visit to Sarajevo two weeks ago. The European Union initiative was launched in December 2014. This initiative has shown that Bosnia and Herzegovina can deliver. At the same time, outstanding challenges remain and need to be seriously addressed, including through the further implementation of the reform agenda. This will require the EU to remain fully engaged in Bosnia and Herzegovina and to support the country in delivering on its priorities in close cooperation with international and local stakeholders such as the international financial institutions and civil society organisations.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate you on the energy invested in the Bosnia and Herzegovina issue.  Since the beginning of your mandate, this country has been on a positive trajectory. The report you presented in November 2015 is also better than before, and proves that the new European approach is working very well. But the most important proof of progress is the filing by Bosnia and Herzegovina of its application for membership on 15 February, an impossible act a year ago and which was not foreseen by the Dutch Presidency. It should be noted that it has not devoted a single word to enlargement in its programme for the six months of 2016. Moreover, she does not seem to be interested in this subject. In the Committee on Foreign Affairs, we have reached a very broad consensus on the need to support this country. We welcome the application for membership and call on the Council to review it as soon as possible and send it to the Commission quickly in order to begin the preparation of the opinion. In order for this to be possible, Bosnia and Herzegovina must make the coordination mechanism on European affairs operational and adapt the Association and Stabilization Agreement, as you also indicated, Commissioner, during your last visit to Sarajevo. We also call on the authorities to continue on the path of reforms for the benefit of citizens, in terms of the economic situation, but also to pursue political reforms. The fight against corruption, the independence of the judiciary, the reform of public administration, the fight against terrorism, respect for freedom of expression and the media must be a priority.  2016 is an election year in Bosnia, but I call on the authorities to remain focused on the objective of European integration and to act decisively so that the date they have mentioned, namely 2017, for obtaining candidate status, is respected.  With regard to the Dutch Presidency, I believe that working faster on Bosnia's candidacy would be an excellent response to the referendum you suffered a week ago. That would be a real European response, instead of retreating and being soft and shy in front of our opponents.  Do something for Bosnia, and you will gain support for the European Netherlands and for a united Europe.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, over the past year, Bosnia and Herzegovina has taken steady steps on its European path. Twenty years after the end of the Bosnian war the country presented its EU membership application. It was a welcome step forward, and we call on the Council to examine this application at the earliest opportunity and to forward it without delay to the Commission in order to start the preparation of the avis.  How Bosnia progresses should be of importance to the EU as we seek to bring stability and prosperity to our neighbourhood. Euro-Atlantic integration remains the best hope for a stable and prosperous Bosnia. It will be a long journey for the country but it is an important one. Many outstanding issues remain, however. Addressing the socioeconomic problems is an immediate priority. We must keep the government accountable for public administration reform and support initiatives improving economic growth and social justice in Bosnia. That is what ordinary Bosnians want and need. I am particularly concerned about the nationalistic rhetoric that still dominates Bosnian politics. We must be firm against those who attempt to promote secession and undermine judicial and state institutions. Also worrying is the most recent case law and practice of the Bosnian state court and state prosecutor’s office. As part of the structural dialogue on justice, we must work hard to further professionalise and depoliticise these institutions. If we do not ensure respect for the rule of law, backed by a credible judiciary, all our other efforts will fail.  Constitutional change will also eventually be needed for the country to transform it into a fully functional, democratic and inclusive state. It is also essential to promote education in order to break down the ethnic barriers, while guaranteeing the right to educate children in their own language. The S&D Group remains committed to a peaceful and progressive future for Bosnia and Herzegovina where all its citizens are guaranteed fundamental freedoms.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: on behalf of the ECR Club. – Madam President, Bosnia and Herzegovina has long been treated as a protectorate. Senior representatives have repeatedly unilaterally changed the original Dayton Agreement, utilising a hard-to-reach agreement among the three peoples. I agree that Dayton needed and still needs an upgrade because it is deeply unfair to Croats, but this upgrade must not be imposed and cooked in foreign cuisines.  That is why I regret that some poorly informed colleagues continue to insist on international tutoring that has so far resulted only in the irresponsibility and incompetence of domestic politicians who have never been forced to make key decisions for the future of the country. They were brought in instead by poorly informed or cheering foreigners, often out of completely wrong motives, without taking into account the interests of all three constituent peoples. Such an approach must go down in history once and for all, otherwise Bosnia and Herzegovina will never become a functioning state.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, colleagues and colleagues. First of all, I would like to thank Mr. Preda for his excellent report and for his work in promoting the European path of Bosnia and Herzegovina in general. Likewise to the Commission, mr. Hahn, on very persistent work on the integration of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as the other five countries in the Western Balkans.  On behalf of the ALDE Group, I welcome the steps bosnia and herzegovina has made so far, among which it is certainly most striking to submit applications for membership in the European Union. Bosnia and Herzegovina's path to the European Union has so far been slow and very complicated. It's probably going to stay that way, but it's important that it continues. It is not clear what Bosnia will look like at the end of this journey and this report does not provide answers to some key questions such as constitutional changes, the structure of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Only the requirements in principle, i.e. expectations, are made, but neither is the Task of the European Parliament at the moment to provide solutions and answers to these very complicated questions.  How demanding bosnia and herzegovina's path is is shown by two examples. The first is the coordination mechanism, which is the most complicated that any country has had on the road to the European Union, and the second is just one example from the joint action plan, i.e. a reform plan that talks about budget consolidation, public spending cuts, restrictions on pension, social and health costs, which is demanding for each country, and for Bosnia and Herzegovina in particular. And this is probably not the most difficult task either, and that is why it is important to continue internal communication, to seek common solutions.  And once again, the alde group's full support for the European Path of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the efforts of its citizens and also its support for the Commission and Mr. Hahn on its efforts and activities concerning the accession of Bosnia and Herzegovina to the European Union.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, this is a triumphant report, but you cannot hide reality. Bosnia remains a major sning for the European Union. We are still trying to work with a broken country and society. The worst part is that the EU itself has helped make Bosnia a country of small local chieftains: ethnic sectarianism was put before respect for the will of the citizen.  In 2014 it was rectified. The Bosnians took to the streets asking to be treated as citizens, not figures, in an ethnic census; called for more employment and less national pride. The rapporteur ignores this reality and calls for the idea of a referendum to be abandoned because it poses a challenge to the cohesion, sovereignty and integrity of the country. Are you serious? The referendum is on the judiciary in the Republika Srpska. The policy of enlargement has long since ceased to be a tool for transformation. It's a tool for states to settle scores.  Europe must reconsider the position so far, recognise the origin and significance of these protests that sprouted the seed of the country's real political and social change, and respect the will of the people as part of an onset of entry into the European Union.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Mr President, commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. – Thank you for the floor, first of all, of course, thanks to the rapporteur, who, of course, has tried to reconcile these differing opinions, with some we may agree, some of them not.  Bosnia has been, is and will be a very hard nut to be in the future of the European Union. And it is clear that she will have to solve the biggest problems above all. Here, of course, the European Union and the European Parliament can help Twenty years from Dayton, we talked about whether it is time to think about how to move forward, whether the status quo and status quo is the only one that can bring Bosnia a step forward, even in terms of greater economic development, lower unemployment, which seriously threatens the stay in Bosnia, and also the brain drain, many young people are looking for jobs elsewhere, outside Bosnia and Herzegovina, even in groups that are not the most, I will say positive. That is why, of course, it is also the duty of both the European Commission and the European Parliament to try to find a hand and a way to Bosnia, too, to find a way to find a way to reach Bosnia, in fact, to resolve those key issues that are currently addressed by Bosnia and Herzegovina.  It is clear that there are also some signs in this resolution that may be positive, and of course we also miss the judgment of Sejdić and Finns, which we consider very important, which is actually based on the position of the European Court of Human Rights and means that Bosnia must assume its duty to tackle the border issue and also recognise equality for those who do not belong to these so-called three entities.  (the speaker answered the question raised by raising the blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – I thank you, Mr. Soltes, for accepting my blue card. You mentioned how to help Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the report states this need, but do you agree with me that, at the moment, when we suffer a lot in the European Union, primarily in security terms, it is Bosnia and Herzegovina that we need to help their state bodies to better control the security situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina because I fear that Bosnia and Herzegovina could be the source of our great security problems?

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: The answer to the question raised by raising the blue card. – Colleague Javkovčić, thank you for this question. Of course, the situation in Bosnia is also a major security challenge for Europe, not only because of the internal situation, but also because of the security situation in the region and the so-called refugee and migrant crisis.  I therefore think that we must do everything to help Bosnia in this and that our competent authorities also cooperate in the exchange of information in order to avoid any unwillingness to take any events that may follow in the future. And we are not talking about one month, we are also talking about six months ahead, so that what has happened in Europe is not happening to us because of our unwillingness and the lack of information - including the security services - in recent months.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, Europe's Balkan policy has been against the Serbian people. Against the Serbian people, it is summed up by two Islamic-mafia entities, the alliance of crime and jihad in Kosovo and Bosnia and Herzegovina. Against the Serbian people as well, the repeated and systematic application of a policy of "double standards". Turkey's two million refugees, mostly Muslims, are refugees, but the two million Serb Christians who have been deported are displaced. Albanian minorities in Serbia and Kosovo, as well as minority Muslims, are pampered by the Washington-Berlin-Ankara axis that has become the European axis; they are "good" minorities - but Bosnian Serbs are "bad" minorities, and they cannot defend themselves by voting, by referendum or by more autonomy. More than 60 local powers of the Bosnian Serbs were reportedly taken away from them, in violation of the Dayton Agreements. The resistance of the Serbian people is the future path of defending our Europe against political Islamism; they are the heroic forerunners of resistance.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Madam President, I would first like to thank the rapporteur for the good report. Following the positive news about BIH membership application, this report clearly reflects the achievements marked by the country in the last months, but also states what work needs to be done in order to advance on the EU accession path – continued implementation of the reform agenda, focus on reforming the judiciary and fighting corruption. Our objective is to encourage BIH to become a country that is inclusive for all its citizens. In this respect, the failure to implement Sejdić—Finci still overtly provides for discrimination against BIH citizens. Also, cooperation among all different parliaments remains the key. I hope that, in this spirit, the EU-BIH SAPC will adopt its rules of procedure. We should also continue to strongly oppose the negative efforts of Republika Srpska, despite the postponement of the referendum.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, I would certainly like to commend the work of the rapporteur, Mr. Prede, at the outset. The result is a high-quality and objective progress report on Bosnia and Herzegovina in the past year, which in many respects was special for the country. A year ago, a written commitment was signed by all leaders in Bosnia and Herzegovina on the readiness for reforms, which, after years of delay, resulted in the entry into force of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement in June. Bosnia and Herzegovina formally concluded its year of progress by submitting its candidacy for full membership. I see this as an important contribution to the much-needed exit from the decade to the Brussels phase of that country. The report therefore registers progress, but also lists a number of areas where the right results are needed to be able to evaluate the membership application as successful. First of all, we expect a final agreement on the establishment of an effective coordination mechanism. Two other key preconditions for progress, the full implementation of the reform agenda and the adaptation of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement, have yet to happen. It should also be mentioned, unfortunately, unresolved issues that delay the final publication of the long-held census. There is also a lack of a number of strategies at the state level, which prevents Bosnia and Herzegovina from starting to use serious funds for the construction of energy and transport infrastructure. Corruption remains a serious systemic problem. Adequate protection for whistleblowers should be ensured, but the best support would be to strengthen the judiciary at all levels. In parallel, it is necessary to prepare work on future political, electoral and constitutional reforms that will shape Bosnia and Herzegovina into a functional, inclusive and efficient state based on the principles of federalism, subsidiarity, equality and equality of all its peoples and citizens. As head of the European Parliament's delegation for relations with Bosnia and Herzegovina, I am sorry for the failed constitution of the joint parliamentary body of the BiH Parliament and the European Parliament, but we could not allow the attempt to transpose into the common rules of procedure provisions involving ethnic census. I hope that at the next meeting in June we will agree, adopt a common rules of procedure and contribute with our work to our common goal – the European future of Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: – I thank Commissioner Hahn, Minister Hennis-Plasschaert and my friend and colleague Preda for a very high quality report on Bosnia and Herzegovina. It is the first report since the historic submission of the application for membership on February 15th this year, which we in the European Parliament strongly advocated, which marks a new phase of Bosnia and Herzegovina's rapprochement with the European Union.  It is essential that the Council and the Commission process the application without delay in accordance with the EU treaty and past practice and that an opinion on the application is started as soon as possible, so that Bosnia and Herzegovina receives candidate status. I call on Bosnia and Herzegovina to ensure the adjustment of stabilisation and association agreements through negotiations with the Commission in order to maintain traditional trade between Croatia and BiH. To undertake economic and social reforms and adapt to the EU acquis, it is essential to establish an effective EU coordination mechanism in which all levels of government will participate.  It is also necessary to ensure the cohesion and functionality of the country and prevent disintegration trends, especially from Republika Srpska. Therefore, in due course it is necessary to approach the constitutional reform that will guarantee the equality of constituent peoples, and in particular ensure equality of Croats, as the smallest, and others on the principles of federalization, decentralization, subsidiarity and legitimate representation. I thank and offer my full support to Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: Madam President, Commissioner, the report of our colleague Cristian Dan Preda sheds a positive light on bosnia and Herzegovina's progress towards the rule of law and the implementation of democracy.  Nor does it hide the considerable efforts that still need to be made to fight corruption, to promote freedom of expression, to provide a minimum base of education for young people, to reject discrimination and ethnic discrimination. But what I remember most striking is the incredible news of the situation in this country. It bridges the gap between the warrior tumults of yesterday and the troubles of today. The Balkans have been the scene of the murderous madness of Europeans in the past and the European Union must now, it seems to me, assist in what I call the "de-de-establishment" of these territories, by welcoming with benevolence the applications for accession of the countries of the former Yugoslavia.  I believe that it is the duty of the European Union to work in this area to make the unity that has been lost.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: – Congratulations to Commissioner Hahn and the rapporteur, Before, for his good work. I am particularly pleased with this report on two facts. Firstly, that this is the Commission's first more favourable report on Bosnia and Herzegovina, secondly, Bosnia and Herzegovina's request for membership of the European Union reflects the clear political ambition of that European country. I see progress on the coordination mechanism for issues related to the European Union as the next important fact and I expect the near final harmonisation by the entities to be followed by implementation. This is necessary for the credibility of the application for membership. So, I welcome the progress made by Bosnia and Herzegovina and wish it a successful internal political coordination that can dynamicise its accession process.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate Commissioner Hahn and also our colleague Preda on the excellent report. I can say that this is the first report in years that is positive about Bosnia and Herzegovina. It's always been so far: Bosnia and Herzegovina doesn't move out of place.  At this point we can say that we have very positive news. In February, Bosnia and Herzegovina submitted a membership application. It is true that this application for membership had only symbolic value, but it is a great support for the authorities of Bosnia and Herzegovina. We are pleased that the political leaders in Bosnia and Herzegovina have finally agreed, that there is consensus on the European path, but of course we from the European Parliament and the Commission will strive to help to the maximum.  Of course the Stabilisation and Association Agreement needs to be adapted, that a coordination mechanism should be applied, that work needs to be done on the reform agenda. There is a lot of work ahead for Bosnia and Herzegovina, in front of its authorities, but they have a lot of support in us, representatives in the European Parliament. We care that all three peoples are constituent, especially here I emphasize the Croatian people and the desire for the Croatian people to exercise their rights, especially the right to their Croatian language, to a channel in The Croatian language and a broadcasting channel. This is what does not exist in Bosnia and Herzegovina at the moment, and that is why we care that Bosnia and Herzegovina continues on its European path, in the best way and as quickly as possible.  Thank you again to Commissioner Hahn and our Mr. Preda.

name: Julie WARD
text: –  Madam President, as a member of the delegation for relations with Bosnia and Herzegovina I have made a commitment to developing a deep relationship with civil society grassroots organizations and, in particular, young people, who are, after all, the future. I have made several visits to the country in order to get to know and build long-lasting trusting relationships with young people, who I believe hold the future of this country in their hands: they must not be let down.  I would like to use this opportunity to praise in particular the work of young people from Srebrenica, Bratunac and Višegrad and other towns and communities in that area who participated in a pan-European project funded by the EU called ‘The complete freedom of truth’. During a three-week project last summer I worked with those young people to help them develop definitions of democracy. Together they really committed to developing new forms of participation amongst each other, and I would just like to read the definition. It is very quick. ‘Democracy is freedom in a framework, powered by people working together for each other with equality, kindness, respect and responsibility.’ Well done, the youth of Srebrenica. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the Dayton Agreement has not solved the fundamental problems that divide the peoples of Bosnia. Croats show their displeasure at being forced to share Bosnia's territory with Bosnian Muslims.  The debate shows that Bosnia does not respect human rights, both the Serbs who have returned there and the Roma. The jihadists are also present in Bosnia and Herzegovina, while the mafia is all over the place.  Corruption is on the agenda, it reaches the highest levels, while the rule of law does not work and the legal system is unable to enforce the law. This is also demonstrated by the low number of convictions.  In the political field, the electoral law must be amended in order to lay the foundations for genuine democratic changes. The role of civil society within the political system must also be strengthened, while mass unemployment must be tackled effectively in the field of the economy.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Let me first thank the rapporteur for an excellent report. Bosnia and Herzegovina has made very significant and substantial progress in its quest for EU membership. The Council must respond quickly to its application. In the country, there is a gradual process of implementing the necessary reforms to meet eu requirements. It is important that all three largest ethnic groups have constitutionally protected rights to be represented in this work and in all the country's political institutions. At the same time, this benevolent intention may be hampered if it is only applied excessively and used to stop the necessary reforms. Representation is an important principle, but if you draw it to extreme, it will be an obstacle. I therefore expect the European Commission to encourage more strongly the implementation of reforms and put that work first. It is more important that reforms are implemented than those that implement them. In the forthcoming work on a new electoral law, it is particularly important to focus on citizens, their participation and not the involvement of ethnic groups. That is the only way we can enable the country to meet the demands we impose on them more quickly.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – First of all, my sincere congratulations to Mr Preda and also to Commissioner Hahn for his progress made by Bosnia and Herzegovina. It congratulates Bosnia and Herzegovina on its application for accession to the European Union, thus clearly showing its pro-European orientation, and on the other hand, I look forward to helping bosnia and herzegovina to start working as a functioning country, a country where the three nations – given their complex political system – will successfully start talking to each other, with good examples and assistance.  There needs to be strong economic development and, on the other hand, a halt to the development of radicalism, extremism, which has been in Bosnia and Herzegovina over the last year, because in such a poor country, where there has been great discontent, we also have the most Isis fighters per population. We are also fighting this as Bosnia and Herzegovina moves closer to the European Union.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: – Madam President, I first thank my colleague Preda for this report, which gives full support to the European path of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Commissioner, I am pleased that in your speech you have put to the forefront the need for reforms, employment measures and economic growth and development. However, and of course you know this very well, the precondition for this is political and legal certainty and stability.  This is the basis for trust that is crucial for investments and new business ventures and so on. Certainly because of what you have put at the forefront, I expect you, commissioner, from the European Commission, to help Bosnia and Herzegovina use the funds from the new European Fund for Strategic Investments. None of their projects have been approved or are on the list of projects to be approved.  I also expect you to accelerate the start of IPA use in those parts for regional development, for agriculture and rural development, for employment and social policy. This is not yet in use, and I expect BiH to define a new structure and establish political and legal certainty in the unity and partnership of the three constituent peoples.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Madam President, I congratulate my colleague Preda on this report, and I wish Bosnia and Herzegovina with all my heart to become a member of the European Union as soon as possible. Belonging to a European family is demonstrated by respecting the values that the European Union believes in and is built on. Therefore, the European future of Bosnia and Herzegovina is possible only if all three constituent peoples will have equal rights. Croats are discriminated against on all grounds, they are almost gone in some parts of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the Croatian language is insufficiently present in public and political life. The system of public broadcasting in Bosnia and Herzegovina does not meet the needs of the Croatian people and I hereby call for the establishment of national programs within public television.  The authorities of Bosnia and Herzegovina must ensure that Croats as a constituent people respect their rights and make greater efforts when it comes to compliance with EUROPEAN Union standards in all areas. Finally, I thank my colleague Preda for accepting my amendments, especially the one by which I call on the authorities of Bosnia and Herzegovina to eliminate the problem of cross-border air pollution due to the operation of the refinery in Bosanski Brod.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank Members for the overwhelmingly positive comments on Bosnia and Herzegovina which I was able to witness today. The Commission very much welcomes the resolution on Bosnia and Herzegovina. I would like once again to congratulate the rapporteur, Cristian Preda, on his high-quality report and to thank all the Members who have actively participated in the debate, not only today, but also in committee, and have shown a keen interest in Bosnia and Herzegovina’s European future. The Commission takes note of this resolution and will take Parliament’s views into account, including those expressed today. We specifically share Parliament’s view that the country’s authorities need to continue with their determination in pursuing socio-economic reforms, including their effective implementation and making steady progress towards the European Union. This would be particularly necessary to enable the Council to decide whether to seek the Commission’s opinion on the merits of Bosnia and Herzegovina’s application. At the same time, the Commission is also looking to the country’s authorities to ensure the functionality of the coordination mechanism on EU affairs and to adapt the SAA, following Croatia’s accession to the European Union.  Let me also mention that the Commission has taken note of Parliament’s call for internal reform within the country based on several principles such as decentralisation and federalism. However, in line with our approach to all enlargement countries, including past EU enlargements, the Commission reiterates that the European Union has no competence regarding the internal structure of a state. What matters is the capacity of a country to meet all its obligations as a future European Union member. It will be up to Bosnia and Herzegovina’s authorities and citizens to decide how best to comply with the European Union membership requirements. Likewise, I would like to emphasise that, as is the case with any country aspiring to the EU, the Commission will particularly insist that the country fully abide by the principles of non—discrimination against its citizens, irrespective of their ethnicity, belief or gender, in line with the European Union acquis.  Finally, I would like to stress that the Commission will spare no effort in supporting Bosnia and Herzegovina on its path towards the European Union. This also applies when it comes to using EU money efficiently and in a sustainable targeted manner, but there has to be a national strategy in the relevant areas. That is what we are discussing with the Bosnia and Herzegovina authorities: there has to be an idea of how to best use the money in order to ensure not only that it will have an impact on the country, but also that it will provide the necessary European added value.  The Commission will keep Parliament informed in the coming months on further developments regarding Bosnia and Herzegovina. I hope that we shall be able to report more very positive developments from this country in the Western Balkan region.

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, there is little I can add after everything that has been said, for example by our Commissioner Hahn. But let me express once more my sincere gratitude for the excellent work of Parliament’s rapporteur on Bosnia and Herzegovina, Mr Preda. I want to underline that we obviously stand ready to provide further support and assistance to help the country move closer to the EU, but the hardest job lies ahead of the country’s leaders, who now need to ensure meaningful progress in the implementation of the reform agenda.  The Council will then be able to consider Bosnia and Herzegovina’s EU membership application in due course.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 14 April 2016. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. – On 15 February, bosnia and herzegovina, the only Member State of the former Yugoslavia, ahead of Kosovo, submitted its application for EU accession. It is noteworthy that for the first time the European Commission has more positively assessed bosnia and herzegovina's aspirations than in previous years. However, it cannot be disputed that the accession process is hampered by a number of factors. Bosnia and Herzegovina has a number of problems to overcome until full membership. The main requirements for accession include reforming public administrations, building an independent judicial system, increasing economic growth and social justice, and, perhaps most importantly, the development of a coordination mechanism for cooperation between the two parts of the country and the District of Brčko in order to join the Union. It is also necessary to a change in the discriminatory electoral law against minorities outside the three constituent nationalities. The application for membership in February is of historic importance, which also gives Bosnia a reason to speed up economic and political stabilisation processes and to enter the path of accession supported by citizens. I therefore hope that, 21 years after the conclusion of the Dayton Peace Treaty, real reforms will speed up bosnia and herzegovina's integration process with the European Union. I believe that supporting Bosnia and Herzegovina's perspective in the European Union is also crucial for a united Europe.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the report by Constance Le Grip, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of undisclosed know-how and business information (trade secrets) against their unlawful acquisition, use and disclosure (COM(2013)0813 – C7—0431/2013 – 2013/0402(COD)) (A8—0199/2015).

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, we are here this evening in the Chamber of Parliament to discuss the draft directive on the protection of professional know-how, know-how, confidential business information, all these things commonly referred to as 'business secrets'. In particular, we are responsible for debating among ourselves the agreement reached in trilogue on this important draft directive. This is the first time that we have had the opportunity to present in plenary the fruit of the agreement reached in the trilogue. Tackling economic and industrial espionage, the plundering of our European companies, protecting our innovation and research, defending our European competitiveness, these are the main objectives of this directive. Of course, it is a question of providing a common legal basis, common European rules to all the economic actors present in the territory of the European Union, in order to ensure a stable and secure legal framework. It is a question of combating the legal fragmentation that currently exists in this European internal market, which we must, of course, complete, and which we need to improve. The patchwork of different, disparate national legislative arrangements leads to instability and legal uncertainty. The idea is therefore to have the most harmonised uniform protection possible at European level of what these trade secrets, professional know-how, know-how, strategic, commercial information, which have value, which represent the intangible heritage of our companies and which are important for their economic development and for the development of our jobs in Europe. We have been committed to supporting these main objectives together in the European Parliament, in particular in the Committee on Legal Affairs. We have, of course, also been committed - and we were very determined in this regard - to ensure that the protection of trade secrets cannot in any way undermine the exercise of fundamental freedoms, nor the fundamental rights of freedom of expression and information, the first of which are, of course, freedom of the press and pluralism of the media. , and that, for example, workers also have the right to be represented by trade union representatives, who may be made aware of trade secrets, or the right to professional mobility. After a very long work - more than 18 months of work in three parliamentary committees - we have managed to agree on these key priorities and to significantly modify, amend, transform and improve the original proposal of the directive as presented to us by the European Commission. We have transformed it, we have improved it, in particular, and especially in a spirit, I would say, very positive, very constructive and of a genuine collegiality of the members of the Committee on Legal Affairs, and then of the european Parliament's negotiating team, which went to discuss, negotiate, engage in a sometimes quite violent confrontation with the Council, strengthen fundamental freedoms, strengthen protection, strengthen protection. , of course, with regard to freedom of expression and freedom of information, which must be granted both to journalists, particularly investigative journalists, and to whistleblowers whose activities must be able to be carried out freely and in conscience. And it is on the strength of this extremely positive contribution from all the shadow rapporteurs who have been with me very active stakeholders in the negotiating team that we have obtained, in negotiations with the Council, a text which has taken up 100% of the recommendations and red lines of the European Parliament. It is now a balanced text, which protects not only what is essential for our companies, their professional know-how, their intangible heritage so precious for their economic development, but also the fundamental freedoms and the exercise of the profession of journalist and the activities of whistleblowers. I therefore call for outspoken and overwhelming support for this balanced and just text that we have worked out together.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Legal Affairs Committee and warmly congratulate the rapporteur, Ms Constance Le Grip, and the shadow rapporteurs for the excellent and successful work on the trade secrets protection directive. Both the work and the constructive spirit in the negotiations facilitated reaching satisfactory compromise and hopefully, if this House votes in favour tomorrow, the swift adoption of the directive at first reading. Trade secrets are an important part of businesses’ intellectual capital in the knowledge economy. Trade secrets are widely used to obtain a competitive advantage, to undertake research and development activity or to innovate in general. For instance, secret know-how is licensed every day between business partners as part of technology transfer deals, and trade secrets are essential for success. Every patent first started as a trade secret. This widespread use of trade secrets is general to all businesses, but SMEs value and rely on trade secrets even more than larger companies. Valuable trade secrets, however, become worthless if misappropriated by others. The risk of such misappropriation is real and could come from cyberattacks, economic espionage and unreliable partners in extended supply chains, for instance. The new EU rules will provide for effective EU-wide means of redress against such trade secret misappropriation. EU businesses will have better tools to fight against unfair and dishonest behaviour that threatens the value of their intellectual capital. This is an important step forward in allowing our creators and innovators to get profit from their hard work and intellectual efforts. Let me be clear: this directive is not about promoting secrecy in business, it is about trust. Thousands of EU companies, most of them SMEs, are innovating out there, sharing confidential information. The new EU rules will contribute to building such trust, as they will ensure that the risk of sharing information diminishes. This directive is also about the fairer and deeper single market, one of the priorities of this Commission. A deeper single market, because the new rules will provide for more predictability and legal certainty. They will also result in a simpler legal framework facilitating the life of enterprises. Companies will no longer need to research and analyse 28 different and disparate national laws; they can count on a harmonised approach. At the same time, rules will reduce unfair competition from rogue competitors who are cutting corners by not respecting the rules. A fairer single market means saying ‘no’ to hacking, cheating and economic espionage as business practices. This directive is not only about protecting businesses holding trade secrets; it is also about placing limits on the protection of trade secrets, avoiding abuse and ensuring full respect for disclosing obligations established by transparency rules. It is not here to protect potential illegal behaviour of companies. On the contrary, it serves to safeguard fundamental rights and freedoms and the legitimate interest of citizens, consumers, employees, honest competitors, journalists and public administrations. A significant added value of this directive lies in achieving the right balance between the different interests in this area. The European Parliament has been decisive in improving the clarity of the proposal in this regard. Thus, considering the overall compromise that has been achieved by the co-legislators and the benefits and significant added value for enterprises and citizens at large, the Commission welcomes and endorses the agreed compromise deal.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. Madam President, I disagree with what I have heard. I believe that this directive was originally proposed to protect the know-how of companies in the face of unfair practices.
