However, it is feared that such a piece of legislation will further promote the culture of secrecy and the lack of transparency on the part of companies.  How many health, environmental and human scandals have been ignored because of the inability of institutions to obtain information classified as "confidential"? We have new cases every day. For example, with regard to glyphosate, we are unable to obtain studies that are classified as "confidential" by companies. As for clinical trials, it is the pharmaceutical companies that say they are trade secrets. Every time a scandal broke out, public opinion was informed and parliament took the necessary steps in response, it was thanks to the courage of a few zealous whistleblowers.  Today, this text calls into question the ability of these extraordinary people to reveal information that they were supposed to keep quiet. For the question is not whether, after a long trial, they will be acquitted. No, the question is whether companies will not abuse this directive to ruin their lives, destroy their families, prevent them from finding a job and plunge them into a distress that few people imagine.  I would have liked - and I am speaking to the Commission - that, in relation to this directive, you had previously proposed a directive to protect whistleblowers. The two go together; it is not a question of choosing one or the other.

name: Lara COMI
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to thank Mr Syderman for his excellent report. Le Grip and the Commissioner.  I am sorry, but I totally disagree with what was said a moment ago, because having also followed the data protection regulation, I have to say that in times of insecurity, terrorism and consumer health problems, there is no secret that it holds. This, we have been very clear, we have said it in all languages and translated into all languages, if I may use this euphemism.  You see, this directive has a clear and precise aim, that of protecting small and medium-sized enterprises, of protecting those who innovate, those who produce and those who at the same time have the genius of having found something new. I think that this is the time to move from words to deeds, because we fill our mouths with saying we help small businesses, well, but when they have the added value that big business does not have, we must be able to protect them with trade secret. I will end very briefly by saying that harmonisation must also take place from the point of view of justice at European level. Those who make mistakes pay equally throughout Europe.

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab In a world where every technological novelty, every new solution is at a premium for the company, especially the small and medium, giving such a protective mechanism is absolutely essential. The existence of a number of different legal provisions weakens the possibility of protection where there is an infringement.  What we have just heard from the Representative of the Greens shows what we have been faced with in the negotiations and in the work of the Committee on Legal Affairs in the European Parliament. Well, it cannot be assumed in advance that they are all thieves and criminals who just want to cheat and exploit. Individual cases must not cast a shadow over the vast majority of honest companies in the European Union. The definition adopted in the framework of the negotiations, as well as the list of exceptions, is so broad that it does not in any way affect workers' rights or, even less, restrict the freedom of the media. On the contrary, they open up these possibilities for access to information.  I would like to make it very clear that only by protecting small and medium-sized enterprises, who spend money on it, who often come to very modern solutions to strengthen their competitiveness for years, can the European market be open to the whole world and provide jobs for our workers in the European Union. If tomorrow someone wants to vote against this agreement, let them be aware that they are voting against EU entrepreneurs.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the result we have achieved after a long and delicate debate is very important.  The Council's initial proposal – and indeed the Commission's proposal, which is not always properly supported by the Council – had clear limits, explicitly risked restricting freedom of expression and information and did not adequately protect whistleblowers and workers.  The end result is exactly the opposite. We have achieved, patiently and with everyone's help, changes which are now appreciable as a whole and also for each individual chapter. I would add that I hope that in the course of the debate in this Parliament, the Commission intends to present new proposals which will have to concern whistleblowers. Today whistleblowers are protected in the directive we are talking about because they are excluded from the scope, for other activities they will need to be better guaranteed where they are not today, but I would add that I also hope that there will be positive innovations with regard to the protection of workers.  If I have any regrets, it is that I, together with my other colleagues, have not been able to give workers the same protection as whistleblowers, but as long as there is life there is hope. Therefore, today we are taking an important step forward, we will vote for this report, I hope that there will be a willingness on your part to revisit the issues that have remained objectively and inevitably partly unfulfilled.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, first of all, I would like to thank my colleague Le Grip and the other shadow rapporteurs for their successful work and congratulate them on the result achieved – the final text reflects the compromise that the rapporteur was able to negotiate with the Representatives of the Commission and the Council during the four trialogas. This proposal is of the utmost importance. Protection against the unlawful acquisition, disclosure and use of trade secrets is key. The legislation will discourage industrial espionage and unfair competition, especially as regards practices coming from outside the European Union. This Directive recognises the strategic importance of know-how, growth, competitiveness and innovation in Europe, while protecting labour mobility, freedom of expression and information. It also provides fundamental guarantees for whistleblowers. I believe that the final text reflects the position of the European Parliament and once again congratulate the rapporteur on the result achieved.

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, it is important to remind ourselves what the purpose of this legislation is. It is to protect companies which cannot patent and cannot use other intellectual property rights but still have trade secrets and need their work to be protected. Their trade secrets are their main asset. This is needed to support open innovation as well as collaborative research, and that requires trust between companies. One important issue for me – and I am really happy to see it in the final agreement – was ensuring that the right to remedy on trade secrets is not abused. It should not be misused to create barriers to competition – something that could eventually end up killing innovation, especially for the digital sector, which is a fast-moving market in which a court case lasting years could make an innovation worthless. I believe that this new law manages to strike the balance between protecting trade secrets and ensuring that procedures are not used to hinder competition and innovation. But only the implementation will tell if we have got it right. The issue of whistle-blowers has been discussed a lot by colleagues. Yes, we should keep asking the Commission to propose a specific legal instrument for whistle-blowers, but we should also know that both Parliament and the Council improved the Commission proposal, making an exemption for whistle-blowers.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – The Trade Secrets Protection Directive is not only superfluous, but also dangerous for the position of whistleblowers, journalists and trade unions. I now read to you the statement that my group has received from Antoine Deltour, the whistleblower behind LuxLeaks, in English.  In 2012 I gave documents to a journalist whose publication triggered the LuxLeaks scandal. I was awarded the European Citizens' Award by the European Parliament last year for this. But both me and the journalist are now being prosecuted in Luxembourg for trade secrets 'violation'. The exemptions foreseen in this directive to supposedly protect whistle-blowers would not protect me or the journalist, because we did not reveal anything illegal, just immoral. This directive will enable companies to sue anyone who accesses, uses or publishes any information that they consider a trade secret, which, according to the definition foreseen in the text, can be almost any internal information. It applies to all citizens and not, as it should, to economic competitors only. Before you vote on this directive, I urge you to reflect on this question: do you really want a society where it is impossible for the public to access information crucial to the public good? So much for Antoine Deltour. On April 26, I will be present at the trial against Deltour. I hope I don't stand there empty-handed. The Committee on Budgetary Control has already agreed that I will write a report on the goal of whistleblowers to protect the EU's financial interests. At least that's something. But it is unacceptable that we do not yet have any agreement on legislation that actually protects whistleblowers, but does adopt legislation that directly undermines their position.  With the adoption of this directive no more LuxLeaks, no more Panama Papers! But more lawsuits against whistleblowers! That is why I call on my colleagues tomorrow to support our amendment to reject the bill as a whole.

name: Julia REDA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, the Panama Papers, Dieselgate, LuxLeaks: what do these scandals have in common? There are two things: 1. they uncovered secret corporate activities that the public had a right to know about; 2. companies used trade secrets laws to fight against their exposure, threaten journalists and go after whistle-blowers. This directive will expand corporate secrecy and, contrary to the claims of some previous speakers, it will endanger and deter whistle-blowers and investigative journalists. Those are not just my concerns. I am joined in these assessments by many of the people most affected. The French journalists’ union says that it resembles a blanket right to corporate secrecy. The editorial committees of the German public broadcasters say that it will intimidate journalists and hinder editorial work. The LuxLeaks whistle-blower Antoine Deltour says it will not protect cases like this leak of massive tax avoidance. These voices cannot be ignored. I would like to remind you that this Parliament awarded Mr Deltour the European Citizens’ Prize just last year for his contributions. We must not now turn around and dismiss his concerns. We must not put more whistle-blowers in court or discourage them from coming forward in the first place. Dear colleagues, let us postpone the vote on this directive until we have actually seen a whistle-blower protection law presented by the Commission. I do not think that simply asking for it without putting on any pressure is going to do any good. I would welcome it if the Commissioner were to prove me wrong on this. There is absolutely no urgency about going ahead with a vote tomorrow. The unintended consequences if we do, however, promise to be dire. Let me tell you: European voters will not understand if two weeks after important revelations we respond to the Panama Papers by strengthening corporate secrecy. We must get the balance right, and this directive at this point clearly does not.

name: Diane JAMES
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, I have to say that, at the moment, I am very disappointed in what I am hearing tonight. The EU appears to consider that within the cloak of the single market – if I understood correctly – it can unilaterally tackle a global challenge. The two key areas of threat, as I understand it, in terms of protecting business know—how, trade secrets and business information, are actually internal theft and internal release and access of information, coupled – or, secondly – in the area of cybercrime. None of what I have heard so far this evening is even beginning to look at that. We seem to be completely and utterly focused on whistle—blowers. I do not see that the European Union has the competency to address this. It certainly does not have the resources, and it is a challenge that faces the global business world in every business sector. To suddenly start picking out things like the Panama Papers, or even the global pharmaceutical world, I really do not think is the right approach and one that we ought to be taking. So for once – and it is not often that I am in agreement with a fellow colleague this evening – I do believe we ought to delay this directive. I think it ought to go back and be considered in light of a much broader picture, which is that security of knowledge and stopping global criminals, global cybercrime and rogue states, who at the moment will look at what we are potentially going to pass and think gleefully, ‘great, they have just opened up yet more opportunity for us’.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, this directive has the merit of protecting trade secrets from economic espionage. This protection corresponds to a high expectation of European companies, especially SMEs, because it prohibits the illegal disclosure of know-how that is intended to be patented and whose confidentiality must be guaranteed in the research and development phase. It is also in the interest of the european peoples, whose capacity for innovation is thus encouraged.  This directive, on the other hand, has the merit of ensuring the protection of whistleblowers. Article 5 allows them to reveal in the public interest, I quote - "misconduct, inappropriate behaviour or illegal activity".  If this directive were already implemented, it would oppose the conviction of Frenchmen Antoine Deltour and Édouard Perrin, who are currently being prosecuted in Luxembourg for revealing the LuxLeaks scandal, for breach of business secrecy. Jean-Claude Juncker has behaved inappropriately in this case within the meaning of this directive.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: – Madam President, may I start by congratulating colleague Le Grip and the shadows for their work. They have managed to shape the proposal in a way that brings about much—needed protection for trade secrets, while addressing concerns. Europe needs innovation and research. This directive is one way of providing researchers, as well as those who invest in research, with much-needed protection. It will enhance the value of innovation and research by providing legal certainty, where none existed to date, over research which is not at a stage of being registered for protection or published. To date, European researchers have depended heavily on uncertain ways to protect their work from being unjustifiably taken by others. European researchers were in limbo on safeguarding their work until it was advanced enough to entitle them to register it or publish it under their name. This situation has prejudiced cooperation between researchers and stakeholders and has also negatively impacted the opportunities of individual researchers, SMEs and start-ups. The proposed directive will bring about legal certainty and protection where there was none. It will make collaboration and cooperation between researchers, institutes and companies more feasible. This will also place European researchers on a more equal platform of protection with their counterparts outside the EU. Most importantly, this directive will give value and recognition to what otherwise would have been considered to be merely ‘confidential information’. This will provide SMEs and start-ups with protection of their research and innovation at a point where registration is not possible, even due to prohibitive costs.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The employees in the company are particularly important to me. It is important to me that whistleblowers expose the abuses and that they can do so without being prosecuted. No one should be able to disguise abuses as a trade secret. The starting point of this directive was extremely industrial interests. What do we have now? A definition of trade secrets, according to which experience and skills acquired by employees in the course of their normal activities should not be regarded as a trade secret. Thank you, Sergio Cofferati and others who have worked for it. What else do we have? We have real whistleblower protection. For the first time in a directive, we have this clearly defined protection for representatives of workers, for trade unionists on supervisory boards, for journalists, for all those who now uncover not only illegal behaviour, illegal acts, but also illegitimate acts. In other words, this is quite comprehensive protection, and these are minimum standards. minimum standards should be improved. I invite all Member States to do so. Finally, Commissioner, I would like to make a request to you: this is about trade secrets. There are also professional secrets, official secrets, all kinds of secrets. We need more protection for whistleblowers. Put something forward in this regard!

name: Pascal DURAND
text: Madam President, this directive is not going well. It's bad luck! In the midst of the Panama Papers, after Dieselgate, after LuxLeaks, the Commission finds nothing better to do than to speed up a text on opacity. I know that the transatlantic treaty is being negotiated and that this is one of the terms of the treaty that is being negotiated, but the reality is that, through this text, you are giving a legal basis to opacity and concealment. Far from defending SMEs - because everyone tells us that we are here to defend the know-how of SMEs or small businesses, which is not true - you will simply reinforce the large companies that want to hide behind opaque walls to carry out their activities. There's nothing to be proud of! To vote against this directive is to defend freedom of information and whistleblowers against fraudsters.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: – Let me start by thanking the rapporteur, Constance Le Grip, from the Committee on Legal Affairs, and the other colleagues who participated in the agreement that we will be voting on tomorrow. I believe that a good compromise has been reached, which the vast majority of colleagues in the committee have voted for.  The proposal from trialogues is based on the fact that trade secrets are an important institute of commercial law and trade relations. As such, it deserves protection and effective regulation. This is about combating unfair practices, which is the objective of all 28 EU Member States. It is therefore a good thing that we are moving towards one basic legislation that will support the EU economy. Its absence causes economic damage every day. Trade secrets also have a relationship with intellectual property and its protection is therefore also important for the development of research and the digital market.  This institute has a clear purpose, which is certainly not to prevent freedom of speech, expression, free access to information or the detection of bad practice or illegal activities. I believe that compromise is a good one, which is why I will support it tomorrow.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the debate on the protection of trade secrets has caused, and still is, a great deal of emotion. This is legitimate, because in some Member States, in the absence of this directive, whistleblowers are now being prosecuted under business secrecy. Moreover, the Commission's original proposal was far too vague, and therefore far too dangerous. And yet, the fight against industrial espionage is something essential and, contrary to what has been said, it is essential for SMEs, which account for two thirds of the victims. That is why we cannot allow the fight against industrial espionage and freedom of information to be mixed on the one hand. The work of our negotiator, Sergio Cofferati, has enabled us to obtain unprecedented protection for journalists, who are excluded from the scope of the directive, and for whistleblowers who, for the first time, are recognised as in need of protection. And because these are fragile audiences, who can be prosecuted for theft, receiving or defamation, we must have a directive that protects them. That is why, in addition to this directive on trade secrets, which is introducing protection for the first time, the Commission must propose a horizontal text to defend them; and we're counting on you.

name: Max ANDERSSON
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for This evening we are debating the trade secrets directive. Trade secrets are designed to protect companies against industrial espionage, not to protect companies from scrutiny. The Commissioner said in the debate that the aim is not to protect cheating companies. But that is what will be the effect of the far too weak whistleblower protection contained in this proposal.  Let's assume a whistleblower wants to leak out thousands of pages of information that reveals really gross violations of public morality and good manners that a company commits. That whistleblower ends up in a legal grey area. It is impossible to verify that some trade secrets are not also released when maladministration is revealed.  I am not surprised that the Commission has listened too much to big business. What surprises me, however, is that the Social Democrats have not fought enough for better protection for whistleblowers.

name: Dietmar KÖSTER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The Commission had put forward a unilateral proposal which provided only for the interests of companies in the security of trade secrets. Above all, it is to the credit of S&D's stubborn negotiations that the directive has been improved in the interests of workers, journalists and also whistleblowers. I would like to emphasise three points: far-reaching rights have been achieved for workers. These include, for example, exceptions to the safeguarding of trade secrets when collective agreements are negotiated and when it comes to the mobility of workers. S&D has enforced the protection of journalists. S&D has also ensured that whistleblowers are protected when it comes to protecting the common good, i.e. when acting in the public interest. That is why I think it is right that we will vote on this directive tomorrow and vote in favour of it.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: – Madam President, the protection of 'know-how' and confidential commercial information against the acquisition of illegal use and disclosure is a priority for us in the European Parliament. Uniform legislation at European level allows protection of our competitive advantage and maintenance of innovation performance. Increased attention has been paid to small and medium-sized enterprises, which face the greatest difficulty in protecting their intellectual property. Small entrepreneurs and innovators, for example in Romania, especially in the digital sector, have often been subjected to thefts of confidential information, which has affected their potential and hard work. The same was the case with companies in the 1990s, which lost their competitiveness due to a lack of protection from the theft and illegal disclosure of confidential information. That is why I believe that the report is a balanced formula for protecting them at European level, without restricting the dissemination of knowledge or the mobility of the workforce.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, all businesses, regardless of size, value trade secrets, confidentiality and intellectual property rights in order to enhance innovation, competitiveness and research. In particular, small and medium-sized enterprises attach greater value to trade secrets, since the use of intellectual property rights is costly and often does not have sufficient resources to manage and protect those rights.  Of course, the circulation of information is particularly important for strengthening democracy, publicity, transparency and for hitting tax evasion, tax avoidance and money laundering. For this reason, there must be cover, not punishment, for those who denounce the scandals and illegalities of multinationals, because that is the only way we will be able to have new revelations again, as has already been the case with luxleaks and the Panama Papers. Because that is the only way to stop the prosecutions of journalists and whistleblowers who reveal the financial scandals.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I have listened carefully to the exchanges and comments on the trade secrets protection proposal. I would like to thank you for your contributions to this important debate, and I can understand that there are some different views and analyses. In closing, let me stress a few key points. Trade secrets are particularly important for competitiveness and for the innovation—related performance of European businesses. Both are key prerequisites for growth. The Le Grip proposal will lead to a fairer internal market. It will be easier for businesses to fight dishonest market behaviour by those who try to misappropriate others’ efforts. I also want to underline – and it is important to do so – that the Le Grip proposal does not undermine the rights and freedoms of employees, competitors, journalists, public administrations and citizens at large. The Commission acknowledges the importance of protecting whistle-blowing and of promoting, amongst other things, good governance, privacy, freedom of expression and the fight against corruption. The whistle-blowing protection clause inserted in this directive is an important one and a major step forward in this area. Whistle-blowers will be protected for the purpose of protecting the public interest if there is real misconduct, wrong-doing or illegal activity. I may therefore commend the proposed deal to the European Parliament and call on your very strong support.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, no naivety, let us open our eyes to the world as it is, the context of economic war, of unbridled global competition. Europe must protect itself. We have to protect our interests. We must protect European interests, protect our innovations, protect our discoveries, protect our research processes.  Protecting innovation, research and our discoveries means protecting our jobs, protecting the work of Europeans and Europeans. The key word in this area is trust. If we want information and knowledge to flow within the territory of the European Union, outside the territory of the European Union, with the rest of the world, if we want confidence, we need clear, sound and precise rules, and we need that common legal basis within the European market that can bring stability and security. Please, ladies and gentlemen, as I said in the introduction, there is no naivety, but also no confusion or mixing of genres. No instrumentalization of recent scandals that have, of course, made headlines, and which continue to do so, and which have nothing to do with professional know-how, with innovation, with know-how, with business information, but which have everything to do with illegal activities and fraud. Let us not take European companies, the work of Europeans, discoveries and innovations hostage, in the name of struggles that are spreading and which lead us to make Europe a land that no longer knows where its interests are and which no longer knows how to protect its interests, protect its producers, protect its companies, protect its researchers and its workers.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 14 April 2016.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the report by Indrek Tarand, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, on Parliament’s estimates of revenue and expenditure for the financial year 2017 (2016/2019(BUD)) (A8—0131/2016).

name: Indrek TARAND
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, money, of course, matters – and time is money, so four minutes is very precious for me. In this House, it is common knowledge – but perhaps not to all European citizens – that the annual budgetary exercise is triangular. The Secretary-General, the Bureau and the Committee on Budgets are at the top, and the rapporteur is navigating between them according to the rules of procedure, which, in their most rigid interpretation, might be said to define the time slot for deep, detailed and constructive discussions as very short – even too short, I must say. However, there are other players in the outside world, like the European Commission, who rightfully expect Parliament to meet the agreed deadlines. If a report is adopted tomorrow in plenary, we may send it out and say better late than never. The second aspect is that there are lots of regulations, interinstitutional agreements, gentlemen’s agreements, inflation estimations by the Commission, etc., which have been decided on and agreed by the generations before us. These really affect the outcome of our budgetary negotiations, because you can neither go higher than that nor reduce the amount of money than that, even in cases when it seems necessary. From a personal point of view, that has been for me the most difficult aspect of preparing this report. Nevertheless, for the great flexibility shown by the numerous director—generals of Parliament’s services, the budget secretariat, the Secretary-General and his office staff of different political groups, the accredited assistants and, last but not least, the main actors – the shadow rapporteurs, coordinators and the president of the committee: thank you all.  We are here. We stand here right now, and the report is ready. The generally contradicting wishes, the need to make savings corresponding to the economic dire straits outside the European institutions, and on the other hand to manage the needs of a properly functioning House have been tackled at the – sometimes quite heated – debates and consultations. Compromises were sought and mostly found; the rest of the text is purely the outcome of a democratic vote in the Budget Committee. As usual, I can live with the outcome of a democratic vote, and hence I recommend that the Members vote in favour. There seems to be a minor problem, and that is the notorious internalisation of transport services. The Committee on Budgets discussed the matter, as did the Bureau. The committee tasked the rapporteur to put a sum of money in reserve, which means that we will come back to the issue later, in autumn or sooner if so decided, and define on the basis of various information whether to release the funds or hold them back. When I now look at the Annex to the report, the conditionality has been given to the discretion of the Bureau. That is not in accordance to the agreement of conciliation; moreover, this is in my opinion against the very same rules of procedure. I will see how to remedy that injury, and I do hope sincerely that I am not forced to add insult to it. On a more positive note, we have discovered that our excellent translation services are the primary source for the well-known corporation called Google. They develop their product, Google Translate, very much based on the European Parliament’s translations into 28 languages, and earn quite good money. I also hear that they are also very eager to optimise taxes, so my proposal is to ask them to make a voluntary contribution to the budget of our institution – perhaps then they will understand the nexus between paying maximum taxes and keeping middle—class jobs. That will also be a step towards the EU’s own resources. To conclude, I am proud and happy that the green initiatives, such as a more transparent depiction of the very poor distinction between investments and running costs, green public procurement, and more fuel and cost—efficient transport have been included in this report.  I would like to thank again every each and every person who has been part of this difficult and somewhat obscure exercise, and I hope we will pass the report tomorrow.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would also like to thank Mr Tarand in particular. As rapporteur for the European Parliament for the 2017 budget, he has taken a good, balanced position. It has done a great deal to ensure that we have been able to agree on a budget that has already been cut by 4% by the Heads of State or Government for the seven-year period and which provides for 1% savings in the posts every year. In this respect, we in Parliament have also committed ourselves to using taxpayers' money as sparingly as possible. We have reduced the 20% share of expenditure that we normally have in administrative costs to 19.17%. This is actually unique. I do not remember that we have had similar figures in the last eight years. The increase in the safety surcharge, which we only made last year, is 0.6%, well below the rate of inflation. And even if you actually compare the ordinary expenditure, it is 1.4%. So I think it's a very frugal budget. Nevertheless, I would ask all my colleagues in the House to take advantage of their own savings. We have many areas where there are ceilings, and not everyone has to take advantage of all borders at all times. We have many free choices. The beauty of this European Parliament is that the individual Member of the European Parliament has a great responsibility in how it handles its expenditure situation, whether it works a lot, whether it works little. It is the free mandate that allows us a great deal.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: On behalf of the Group of The President, I would like to thank Mr Tarand, who has actually listened to the shadow rapporteurs, and thanks to whom the report has gone in the right direction.  It is true that we have been working urgently and in a climate bereaved by the Brussels attacks, in order to arrive, it must be said, with budget estimates for 2017 which I think, at this stage, are balanced and reasonable. Discussing bowls and cans is not always an exciting subject for the crowds, but it is still an obligatory part of the overall budget procedure of the European institutions. As such, we can be pleased to have contained current expenditure to limit it to a slight increase of 1.4%, which will have to absorb the entire structural share of changes indexed to the cost of living, but also the expenditure of multilingualism due to the introduction of the Gaelic language, as well as, of course, the expenditure related to security issues. For my part, I stressed the need for a strict separation between investment and operation. Indeed, there is no visibility of the budget if we do not distinguish between the two: I believe that there is the current operation, which must be monitored very closely, and the investment, which prepares the future - I believe that it is in this spirit that we will build the budget in the future.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, my friend Indrek Tarand. The process around the estimates for the parliamentary budget for 2017 has been, to put it mildly, a very interesting one. Has it been transparent or should it be transparent? We tend to believe that politics in general and the use of monetary resources in particular has to be transparent. That is at least what we usually say back home. The truth of the matter is that Parliament’s budget is opaque to a degree that is not actually acceptable. There are a lot of structural problems: no differentiation between investments and current expenditure, no detailed information about how extraordinary expenditure is used in reality and no control on how different budget lines are used outside the original intention of the budget. In a way this resembles something that was published in 1494. Sebastian Brandt was born in Strasbourg around 1457. In 1494 he published the book Das Narrenschiff, the ship of fools, where an identifiable crew of persons left for Narragonia. We immensely dislike being treated as the fools on the Narrenschiff, where you get piecemeal information on a process which is very important. We have decided to vote against this file in tomorrow’s vote. We will not be part of a crew on board a ship that does not know how a ship should be navigated in dangerous waters. We have good reasons for this approach. We see a growing distrust concerning the EU, and we would like to remedy this mistrust. We will ask for more transparency and we will do it in the months approaching the final vote on the budget in October.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, let me also commend the work done by our rapporteur. It was not an easy job to do.  In developing this budget, we had a threefold requirement. The need to safeguard European democracy, the need to deal with the security problem and, above all, a demand for exemplary status.  In terms of exemplarity, I think we could have done better. I think a number of expenses are not quite helpful. I am thinking, in particular, of the renewal of the offices of the European Parliament. I am also thinking of some of the transport expenditure of MEPs.  But the main thing is elsewhere. The key is the possibility of strengthening the legislative capacity of the European Parliament and European democracy. I have to tell you that I do not understand the cuts in interpretation spending, when there was unanimity within our team to maintain those appropriations. I also want to say that we were able to get sign language interpretation in this report. This is positive and I hope that it will happen very soon.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: – Madam President, I would like to greet the rapporteur, to highlight the positive work he has done, the enormous effort. You did your best. Congratulations, and that is why we voted in favour of the report.  I would like to remind you that the Budget of the European Union is mainly investment: 94 % for investment and only 6 % is for all administrative expenditure. And then to talk about the European Parliament's budget is to talk about 1/5 of these administrative expenditures. And we must defend the interests of the citizens of the European Union, and they require adequate legislation, high-quality legislation. And to do this we need the minimum, but the least, particularly with regard to technical resources and human resources.  In addition, we all advocate diversity, multilingualism, and also, of course, the safety, safety of those who work here. We also advocate robust systems that resist cyberattacks. We therefore therefore also advocate the necessary and sufficient means for this purpose.  We want a strict budget, and we work for it. An efficient budget, with the means necessary to respond positively to the challenges we have made here, which we have set here, to the challenges that the European Union imposes on us.  And so I ask you to vote in favour of this report. It is not the ideal report, but it is the possible report and we have done our utmost to save, in order to improve the initial proposal given to us by the Secretary-General.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, allow me to focus on very few aspects of this budget, first of all thanking the rapporteur and all those who have worked on the budget.  I believe that the work we have done in committee through all the groups would have made it possible to make far more savings than has been done, it would have made it possible to do much more work than has been done. I believe that the new security expenditure, of which we are of course all convinced – not so much for our own safety, but for the safety of our staff, for the safety of officials and others working within Parliament – is necessary expenditure, absolutely, but is spent, as it were, exaggerated.  I believe that we must stop it, we must end it with the issue of safety in order to justify any kind of expenditure. An example of this is the example – and I will cite this only because I see that I no longer have time – of drivers. I think we are making a big mistake, I think we are making an error of assessment, I think we are making a mistake. We should give the citizens of Europe – because the European Parliament's budget also responds to the citizens of Europe – a more balanced budget with greater savings.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: – Madam President, I am going to begin my speech by denouncing the lack of seriousness with which this budget for Parliament has been raised, not because of the rapporteur. Parliament has enough legislative capacity today to follow, in the rebutty of the European Commission, with deadlines of one day to assess the reports. The budget for 2017 of the European Parliament should be exemplary. Given the crisis in the European Union and since austerity is required of states, perhaps it could start with the institutions themselves. There is no definition of extraordinary spending, diets are not controlled in any way, flights are paid for in business, services are outsourced. Please let us reduce the expendable and not the support for legislative and parliamentary activity. Finally, we are going to add to the request of a single chamber for the European Parliament. The maintenance of several venues, coupled with the travel between Brussels and Strasbourg is expensive and unnecessary, 180 million euros per year. If there are any doubts, and if I may say so, I will propose that you move to my land, to Bilbao.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – I will repeat myself on one thing by thanking the rapporteur and all the shadow rapporteurs for their excellent work, but I have one very original idea for you, which no one has said here today.  You may not realize the fact, but as the EP becomes increasingly important, it also increases its threat on its own. In the future budget, we must therefore not only ensure sufficient funding for the safety of our buildings, but also some flexibility in implementing ad hoc security measures, as we could have faced this year. There is another aspect to this. There is no point in debating the ineffective use of European taxpayers' money by our travels here to Strasbourg. That's just a fact. The EP does not have one or two buildings, but three buildings, ladies and gentlemen, in which they must increase security measures to ensure the safety of all those who work there.  Did anyone ever care how much money we would save if we shut down these buildings? Either way, in the EP budget, it should not just be revenue on the one hand and expenditure on the other, but how this money is used. To do this, I would like to invite all of us here in the hall to try and pay more attention to this site.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: – When anyone makes up any budget, there is nothing easier than multiplying last year's budget by an inflation factor or some other coefficient. However, such budgeting, if you repeat it year after year, can cause inaccuracies and wastefulness in the use of resources over time. In recent years, actual inflation has been significantly lower than what we envisaged when drawing up the European Parliament's budget. But in the budgets of the following years, we have not taken this into account altogether. Colleagues, of course, we want to improve this, and I believe that, after tomorrow's vote, we will draw up the future budgets of the European Parliament on the basis of the real needs of the individual items. We are on track to show the public that we are using resources as efficiently as possible.

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would like to express my sincere thanks to the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs, because we have a solid result and a result that we can also defend. In the case of a budget, especially in an institution as we are, it is always important to see a little bit of the two sides. First of all, the citizens are certainly demanding that we be careful with the money and that we also try to spend as little as possible on our activities. There are certainly possibilities. When I think, for example, of the fact that delegations travel, we can also consider how many people have to travel, what languages we need. Accordingly, there are also savings in this proposal, which I can certainly support. On the other hand, however, the quality of parliamentary work must be guaranteed, and the quality of parliamentary work consists in the financing of our staff, the financing of political parties. Fortunately, we have also managed to continue the budget for the European Parliamentary Society, which I am allowed to lead as President. There, too, a contribution is made to democratic decision-making and debate. It is important that we maintain this budget and that we have the appropriate funding. In this respect, I can easily support this budget and I hope that we will adopt it tomorrow together.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: – Madam President, the report on the estimate of the European Parliament's revenue and expenditure budget for the financial year 2017 is the reflection of a balanced approach to the funds needed for the functioning of the European legislature. Important measures are proposed to increase Parliament's efficiency, but also to increase transparency. Thus, the publication on Parliament's website of the detailed budget is a sign of our desire to enable all citizens to better understand our activities and priorities. A strong democracy requires a strong, hard-working parliament that communicates with citizens wherever it is. The European Parliament must be known not only in Brussels or Strasbourg, but also in the most remote localities. I must therefore reject any desire by some to maintain or impose new differences between Member States and their MEPs. I therefore reject the limitations imposed on staff in Eastern Europe, which are imposed simply because, if the area is less developed, employees in those countries must be paid less.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, in the context of Parliament's revenue and expenditure forecasts for 2017, security and cyber security have been set as the primary targets for the budget. In particular, there is a provision for an overall increase in the European Parliament's budget in 2017 of 3.9%, compared to that of 2016, while to enhance security, investments of EUR 36.8 million are required.  More generally, any security measure should be taken after an assessment of Parliament's needs and potential risks. In other words, there should be control over both the security measures envisaged and the financial implications they will have.  Finally, the development of Parliament's budget for each year should be accurately presented in order to ensure transparency in the revenue and expenditure incurred. Transparency, then, in everything and everything.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: – A Uachtaráin, bhuel ba mhaith liom tréaslú leis an rapóirtéir, an tUasal Tarand, as an obair ar fad atá sé tar éis a chur isteach sa tuarascáil seo. Gan dabht ba mhaith liom aird a tharrac ar an tosaíocht atá tugtha don Ghaolainn agus gabhaim buíochas le gach aon Fheisire anseo a thug agus atá ag tabhairt tacaíochta dó seo – tú féin san áireamh, a Uachtaráin. Is páirt dár bhféiniúlacht í ár dteanga agus tá sé thar a bheith tábhachtach go mbeadh an Ghaolainn ar comhchéim le gach teanga eile a labhraítear anseo. Mar sin, tá sé ag tabhairt teachtaireacht láidir do gach uile Éireannach eile, comh maith le tíortha eile, cé comh tábhachtach is atá ár bhféiniúlacht agus cé comh tábhachtach atá sé é sin a thabhairt in aitheantas anseo sa tigh seo.  Tréaslaím go mór leis an tuairim go mbeidh EUR 3.7 milliún á chur ar fáil le cúnamh Dé, agus mar sin tá mé ag glaoch ar an rialtas ag an mbaile tosnú ar an bpróiseas earcaíochta ionas go mbeidh na scileanna ann agus go mbeidh na seirbhísí ateangaireachta iomlána ar fáil anseo sa tigh seo. Mar sin, mar Fheisire Eorpach atá tar éis a bheith ag troid ar son chearta na teanga, táim ag súil go mór amach anseo go mbeidh sé ar fáil domsa go luath san áit seo.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Madam President, we note in this report the importance of being efficient in the use of public resources and completely transparent in accountability.  The dematerialisation and digitisation of processes should always, however, avoid any kind of exclusion. What we do not follow is this fashion of austerity, which always imposes a reduction of costs and which is always felt in the same headings.  We are sensitive to the issue of security, but we do not feed this security drift, which makes this House increasingly belike a prison or fortress.  We do not understand this reduction in staff, while at the same time the aim is to give more and more importance and centrality to the European Parliament. Nor do we follow fears about the service of drivers. Just as we defend the interests of those who work, we also want this House to set an example, giving stability to its workers.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, it has been an interesting and substantial debate, and the comments and speeches have made a good impression on the rapporteur. There are about 20 of us in this Chamber at this late hour, and our opinions and beliefs and political positions will determine tomorrow’s vote. As I said, I am pretty well prepared to live with a democratic outcome. I am also prepared for last-minute negotiations tonight if they seek or can achieve some kind of changes to improve the report. No report which seeks a compromise between different institutions, political groups and personalities – and I was lucky enough to have met several of those during this journey – can be ideal. There is a lot to be criticised, ridiculed and contested. Yet this is what we have for the time being and tomorrow we will have a vote, so let’s vote and see what happens.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 14 April 2016. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. – I am very glad that the Committee on Budgets was able to agree so quickly on the form of an estimate of the European Parliament's budget for 2017. Especially given the circumstances that our institution has faced in recent months. I am thinking in this regard of terrorist attacks and ensuring security for Parliament's staff. This time, the parliamentary budget will increase by 3.4% year-on-year, but the increase in current expenditure will be only 1.4%. Parliament's budget will therefore continue to account for less than 20% of the total expenditure of the administrative budget. I am very satisfied that we are able to keep Parliament's expenditure under control even during such a difficult period and that Parliament continues through the investigation by introducing further environmental measures. We must manage the European budget effectively and transparently. I therefore encourage the Secretary-General to clearly divide investment-related expenditure and plans from current expenditure when the draft budget is next. Management information must also be made more accessible to citizens who are entitled to access the management of an institution that holds their interests at any time. I look forward to comparing the effectiveness of this Parliament and national parliaments.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. While the states are tight in the grip of austerity and deflation, the plenary voted in favour of increasing the European Parliament's budget by 3.4% compared to 2016, for a total of €1,900,873,000. The 5-Star Movement has put forward proposals for a rational and considered cut of around 130 million euros, including a 15% reduction in Members' salaries and allowances. Our proposals have not been accepted. Unfortunately, the proposal to eliminate subsidies to European political parties and foundations, whose budget has increased by 248.46% since 2008, has not been accepted, reaching the figure of EUR 50 905 000 for 2017. This is the Europe that needs to be changed and that we want to change: one that does not renounce privileges and that favours lobbies, to the detriment of the citizens to whom it continues to demand sacrifices.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on  – the oral question to the Commission on review of the SME supporting factor by Antonio Tajani, Othmar Karas, Burkhard Balz, on behalf of the Group of the European People’s Party (Christian Democrats) (O—000045/2016 – B8—0353/2016); – the oral question to the Commission on review of the SME supporting factor by Elisa Ferreira, on behalf of the Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament (O—000057/2016 – B8-0354/2016); – the oral question to the Commission on review of the SME supporting factor by Paloma López Bermejo, Fabio De Masi, Marisa Matias, Dimitrios Papadimoulis, Miguel Viegas, Merja Kyllönen, on behalf of the Confederal Group of the European United Left – Nordic Green Left (O—000060/2016 – B8—0355/2016); – the oral question to the Commission on SME supporting factor by Sylvie Goulard, Michael Theurer, Marian Harkin, Petr Ježek, Sophia in 't Veld, Nils Torvalds, Philippe De Backer, Cora van Nieuwenhuizen, on behalf of the Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe  (O—000065/2016 – B8—0356/2016); – the oral question to the Commission on review of the SME supporting factor by Kay Swinburne, on behalf of the European Conservatives and Reformists Group  (O—000066/2016 – B8—0357/2016).

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the aim of this question is to contribute to the process of reviewing the EMS supporting factor, which is a fundamental measure for access to credit for small and medium-sized enterprises.  SMEs are the engine of our economy, generating 55 % of Europe's gross domestic product and employing almost 80 million of our fellow citizens. In order to continue to contribute to growth, however, small and medium-sized enterprises need to be supported with funding that allows them to internationalise, to keep up with the times, to invest in new projects, to hire new employees. However, the monetary policy of the European Central Bank is not sufficient to achieve this objective. Quantitative easing, for example, and rate cuts, can only support policies in favour of the real economy, but they cannot replace them.  In order to prevent deflation – or worse, as the International Monetary Fund warned us just yesterday, secular stagnation in Europe – we need concrete measures, such as the EMS supporting factor, a virtuous example of a balance between regulatory constraints and flexibility. Thanks to this support factor, bank lending to small and medium-sized enterprises has increased by 2 % over the last year and a half, compared with a 7 % reduction in that granted to large enterprises, and interest rates have been reduced by about 20 basis points.  In view of the end-of-year review, we call for the EMS supporting factor to be confirmed and strengthened, extending its application to credits of more than EUR 1.5 million, thus removing the threshold currently provided for. This would allow more companies, especially medium-sized enterprises, to benefit from the discount factor. I also share and support Commissioner Hill's commitment to making this instrument an international standard, through the Basel Committee.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: Author. – Madam President, it is in Countries of the European Union like mine that financial interests have hit the popular classes harder with brutal reforms that have dismantled the socio-economic fabric that existed before the crisis. It is this process that explains the current situation of small and medium-sized enterprises, SMEs and micro-enterprises; the forced disappearance of the Banks and the concentration in the banking sector have diverted credit from the real economy to speculation, in a model of transnational banking that will culminate in the banking union. SMEs, however, are productively anchored to their territory, to local employment, and therefore no longer of interest to this new banking. And I have no doubt that if SMEs have to go public for credit — as the Commission intends - they will further increase the risks and interest paid for the benefit, precisely, of finance.  In addition, economic volatility and the serious deterioration in the social conditions of the working majority – the victim of unemployment and wage falls – have added a horizon of uncertainty for SMEs. For large companies, the precariousness of work is another tool in the fight for global competition. For SMEs, their workers are also their consumers and only improving working conditions will ensure a market for their products. We are lost in a technical debate on credit factors when the European Banking Authority itself has already stated that little or nothing will come out of it. Let us truly address the debate on the financing of SMEs within its overall framework; the instability and economic stagnation that you have imposed on countries intervened and rescued by their austerity policies. Only in this way will we be able to progress towards truly transformative policies, weaving alliances against our common enemy that, believe it or not, is the great capital.

name: Michael THEURER
text: Author. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. In adopting CRD IV and CRR, the European Parliament and the Council were right to ensure that there were lower capital requirements for small and medium-sized enterprises. Now there is a report by the Basel Committee which finds that, in some cases, in a sample of nine Member States examined, the banks are partly incompatible with the Basel legal framework. That's what got us on the map here. As the European Parliament, we want to make it clear that we believe that the lower capital base for small and medium-sized enterprises is absolutely necessary in order to ensure the financing of small and medium-sized enterprises in the future. And it is not the case that there are no financing difficulties for small and medium-sized enterprises. It is not only in the periphery, even in those countries that are doing well economically at the moment, that there are companies that are very, very difficult to get financing. The vast majority of financing for small and medium-sized enterprises – 99% of all enterprises are small and medium-sized enterprises, 23 million in Europe – is financed by credit. In other words, we also need credit financing here in the future, because it is not to be expected that small and micro-enterprises will be able to place direct bonds with the Capital Markets Union. So, a very clear signal at this point from the Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats that we, together across all political groups, are calling on the Commission, as a whole, to find ways of ensuring that lending to small and medium-sized enterprises will also be ensured in the future. The banks complain about high regulatory requirements. The Goethe University in Frankfurt has presented an interesting study which shows that small and medium-sized banks are also disadvantaged here. There is therefore a need for action, and we ask the Commission to keep the ball on the ball here in terms of jobs and small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: author. – Madam President, Europe’s SMEs, including in my own constituency of Wales, have shown remarkable resilience in times of recent financial troubles, but now need capital to fuel their expansion and growth. In much of the regulation that was negotiated during the aftermath of the financial crisis, there was emphasis placed on higher capital requirements for credit institutions across the board. However, we sought in this House, where possible, to minimise the impact that this would have on lending to the real economy. Part of these measures included the SME supporting factor, which was intended to provide an incentive to banks to lend to SMEs as they would receive a slightly lower capital charge for this type of lending. However, the European Banking Authority (EBA) report on how this has been implemented suggests it is having little impact. I quote: ‘SME bank lending has suffered a significant backdrop in volumes from a peak of EUR 95 billion in 2008 to approximately EUR 54 billion in 2013-14. Bank lending to larger corporates, on the other hand, has already recovered to its pre-crisis volumes. The EBA analysis questions the effectiveness of the entire SME supporting factor. However, I do not think it is fair to look at this factor in isolation, as other factors affecting lending, such as reduced demand and confidence among the SMEs themselves, have also got to be taken into account.  Both anecdotal evidence in my own constituency and data analysed by the Bank of England suggests that nearly 77% of SMEs in the last year that have applied for bank loans have received them; so I am concerned that the EBA only looks at the level of capital supplied, as opposed to the level of capital requested, and therefore its conclusions should be treated with a healthy level of scepticism. Can the Commission therefore explain how the Directorate-General for Financial Stability, Financial Services and Capital Markets Union (DG FISMA) is working with the Directorate-General for Internal Market, Industry, Entrepreneurship and SMEs (DG GROW) to look at the wider confidence issues in the SME sector, and bear these measures in mind when reviewing the very important SME supporting factor.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission is aware of the importance of the role played by small- and medium-sized enterprises, which contribute to economic growth and job creation in the European Union. The Commission is fully committed to identifying the most appropriate policies and tools to address their funding needs. SMEs face structural financing obstacles – as has been said several times now – as they are largely dependent on bank financing, whereas larger companies have a more diversified source of funding thanks to their access to capital markets. Their dependence on bank loans and less-diversified sources of income make SMEs more vulnerable to downturns in the economic cycle. European SMEs have experienced huge difficulties in accessing finance in the aftermath of the financial crisis. The problem is especially serious in some Member States, which has led to the concerns voiced by this European Parliament. In this spirit, the Commission has supported the inclusion in the Capital Requirement Regulation of a measure – the SME-supporting factor – aimed at granting loans to SMEs and giving them more risk-sensitive potential treatment, and thus reducing the potential impact of the tougher capital charges introduced by the Capital Requirements Regulation on lending to SMEs. The SME-supporting factor has been in force since 1 January 2014. Thanks to your and the Commission’s efforts, the importance of the issue has also been acknowledged at global level, and the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision is now also considering lowering capital charges for exposures to SMEs. The Commission is currently assessing the effects of the SME factor in the context of the review of the Capital Requirement Regulation, which will be published towards the end of the year. In particular, we are looking at its impact on the volumes of SME lending since its introduction, compared to other factors, for example, the macroeconomic environment or the SME’s credit history. Moreover, we will be looking to verify whether, according to the available evidence, the SME factor remains potentially sound, taking into account its features in terms of the definition of an SME and the size of the loan. We are drawing on various sources of information for this exercise, such as the recent public consultation on the impact of the Capital Requirements Regulation on banking financing of the economy and the call for evidence on financial regulation launched in September last year. The recently published European Banking Authority report on SMEs and the SME-supporting factor has also provided the Commission with useful elements for its forthcoming policy recommendations. Finally I should stress that, in future, bank lending should not remain the only – or at least the largely dominant – response to the financing gap of EU SMEs. An appropriate degree of diversification of funding sources should be sought and the dominant role of banks reduced. This is precisely one of the objectives of the Capital Market Union project, which aims at fostering the role of capital markets for the European Union economy.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the first thing I have to do is to thank and welcome the words of the Commissioner, who I largely subscribe to. SMEs, said here, are the engine of growth and job creation in the European Union, and must be at the heart of this house's political activity. In this regard, I would like to congratulate Vice-President Tajani on the great effort he has made — not only now, but also in his time as Vice-President of the European Commission — in support of SMEs. Because, thanks to many of the initiatives launched by my dear friend Antonio, today SMEs are in a better position than they were a few years ago. And, as Mr Tajani rightly said, the European Central Bank is not the solution, it is only part of the solution. That is why we value the SME support factor initiative, but we also need to move towards the single capital market. And I ask you, ladies and gentlemen, to support the first legislative packages on this subject, such as the securitisation package, of which I have the honour to be rapporteur. I ask you, ladies and gentlemen, to speed up the legislative process to diversify the sources of funding for small and medium-sized enterprises, because, ladies and gentlemen, to support SMEs is to support employment, to support SMEs is to support economic growth.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Commissioner Hahn for his words, as well as Commissioner Hill for his reply to the letter in which a large number of members of the ECON Committee expressed a very clear position, which I would like to reiterate here and which, moreover, has clearly emerged from the debate. There is a very large majority in the ECON Committee, in the European Parliament, which says that the EMS supporting factor must be maintained and that, indeed, it must be strengthened. This is a political fact which, of course, the Commission and the other bodies of the Union cannot but take into account, and we have a firm political will with regard to which we read with interest the considerations made by the EBA in its report, but they do not seem to us, shall we say, to support and support the need for any change in prudential policy towards small and medium-sized enterprises.  The European Parliament has had this initiative during the definition of crr – crd IV and now what we are saying clearly is that it must be maintained and indeed strengthened. The evidence that is carried out here can also be overturned, because for example the fact that the difference in credit risk on one and a half is not evident, also supports the idea of raising this threshold, not necessarily lowering it as the EBA alludes. Parliament's position is therefore clear and we are happy with the Commission's support and will continue our initiative on this issue.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: gue/NGL Group. – SMEs, which are the backbone of the European economy, are now facing more difficulties in financing their investment projects and especially their cash needs with the crisis. That's a fact.  Despite all the measures taken, allegedly to help solve this problem, from cosme to Horizon 2020, through this measure to amend the capital waste regulation, the billions of euros injected into the financial system by the ECB do not reach those in need. It is the OECD itself that recognises it.  It is therefore important to understand where the root of the problem is. And for us, the problem continues to lie, on the one hand, in this infernal circle of perpetual austerity, which undermines the trust of those who invest, and, on the other, in a banking system focused on speculative activities, for their own benefit.  We continue to believe that only a public investment policy that drags private investment, together with a restructuring of the financial system, can revive growth and put the economy at the service of development and people.

name: Margot PARKER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, this oral question states that one of the main obstacles to SME growth is their access to finance. Whilst this may be true to some extent, this question does not address the fundamental issues that SMEs face in EU regulations that are excessive. Statistics have recently revealed some quite extraordinary facts about the amount of rules that businesses within the EU have to comply with. For example, it has been estimated that if you stacked together all of the EU rules and regulations, it would be higher than Nelson’s column – that is over 52m of rules that affect British businesses, British employers and British employees. They have to comply with these rules. It really is no wonder that British businesses feel inundated by the tides of EU regulations that companies – both large and small – have to comply with. No wonder they want to leave the EU. Only by voting to leave the European Union on 23 June 2016 can businesses and the economy really begin to thrive, free from excessive and burdensome EU regulations.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I believe that it would indeed be better for the British economy if it remained in the European Union, as every entrepreneur knows, but unfortunately some politicians do not. If, in times of financial crisis, there had only been global corporations and banks in the European Union, today our continent would be in a bad state of affairs. It was precisely the flexible medium-sized enterprises of a wide range of sectors that cushioned the effects of the crisis in the regions.  Small medium-sized enterprises, family-run companies Your owners identify with regions with the company, with employees. Let us therefore not make life unnecessarily difficult for them. It is no more than fair – it is absolutely appropriate – for SMEs to have a correction factor in risk weighting and capital deposit in the Capital Requirements Regulation.  Investment by small and medium-sized enterprises is the risk and economic buffer for Europe's economy and, ultimately, for financial markets. The correction factor for SME loans must therefore not only remain permanent, but the exemption limit for this should also be significantly increased, and there should also be further easing for owner-managed companies in securing the equity of loans. I call on the Commission to take this into account in its report, because investment in small and medium-sized enterprises is investment in the future of the European Union. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". – We all know that the basis for good financing is the profits of the company that writes it. This also has something to do with taxation. Do you think that these issues should play an important role in the SME test in the nation states?

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. – Of course, in matters of taxation, taxes should be paid where services are actually provided. That is why we in the European Parliament are also making a committee of inquiry into the corresponding misconduct and misconduct of companies. I also think that the Commission would be well advised to carry out the most careful impact assessments of small and medium-sized enterprises on all new matters – whether it is new VAT rules or whether it is a common base for tax bases – as regards small and medium-sized enterprises – the impact assessment centres, which we, as mandatory SME tests as the PPE-DE, have repeatedly called for.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: – SMEs are the backbone of the European economy. Supporting them should not just be a slogan. The main difficulty faced by new and young entrepreneurs is access to finance. I know that because I used to be a young entrepreneur. Which bank funds a young entrepreneur with no experience? How do you market without expertise? How to access other markets when certain countries offer tax facilities to large companies? How, in practice, should a person trust to open a company in Europe today? It is important to establish a strategy at European level to facilitate access to finance by SMEs. The risk factor for SMEs is a good first measure, but it is insufficient. Europe and the Member States must support the provision of funding for SMEs as well as start-ups. For example, the European Fund for Strategic Investments provided for the allocation of funding to SMEs, but unfortunately we are far from the EUR 75 billion promised to SMEs through this plan and we have no solutions. Europe must come up with concrete measures, beyond this proposal, which we discussed today.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, small and medium-sized enterprises account for 55% of the European Union's total GDP. They employ 75 million citizens and depend heavily on bank lending to finance their activities. In order to strengthen this lending by credit institutions, the capital reduction factor for loans to small and medium-sized enterprises has been introduced in the Capital Requirements Regulation which, according to the European Banking Authority, should be revised. However, the impact of the support factor is not yet known.  Moreover, in countries such as Greece, which has been impoverished by the Memorandums, only 18% of small and medium-sized enterprises apply for a loan, while 38% face increased difficulties in accessing bank lending. Furthermore, Mr Hahn, in Greece, the troika in which the Commission also participates requires the sale of non-performing loans of small and medium-sized enterprises to aggressive funds, with the result that many small and medium-sized enterprises are at risk of dismantling and divestment of their assets.  How about that, Mr. Hahn? How do we reconcile what is happening in Greece with what we are discussing here? Will you continue this aggressive policy as a troika for the red loans of small and medium-sized enterprises in Greece? You have to answer that.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, at least those who are still there! I would like to express my sincere thanks for your committed discussion and I regret that so late in the evening we are talking about something as essential as small and medium-sized enterprises in Europe, because they are indeed the backbone of the European economy. I would just like to remind you that we have some 23 million small and medium-sized enterprises in Europe and about as many unemployed, and if only each of these companies were to take in an unemployed person, then the problem of unemployment would be eliminated.  If this were to be left to the 500 largest European companies, each company would have to create around 50 000 jobs, which is probably not possible in theory. This shows how important small and medium-sized enterprises are, and I can therefore assure you that the Commission will continue to work intensively on the development and strengthening of small and medium-sized enterprises in Europe. However, I can also assure you that our approach is to create conditions and not to act in a dirigiste manner, but to ensure that the European economy can develop, and it can only do so if an appropriate framework is in place. But entrepreneurship must be guaranteed. Only then will a successful economy be possible, which ultimately secures or creates jobs.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Thank you, Commissioner; you have given us food for thought. Mr Moraes, your microphone is not switched on. What I will do out of respect for the Commissioner – and please do not heckle – is to ask him if he wishes to reply, but he is not obliged to answer that question. If he does not wish to, I hope you will respect his reply. Commissioner, if you do not wish to answer, that is fine. I was going to conclude the debate by saying to you, Commissioner, that you have given us food for thought on the numbers of SMEs and the potential for employment, so thank you for that.
